column7: : text A Sermon.
column8: : text A Sermon.

column7: T Here was a certayne riche man, which was clothed in purple and fyne white, and fared delyciously euery daye &c. Our Lorde Iesus Christe (honourable audyence) in the beginnyng of this.xvj. chapter of the holy Euangeliste saynte Luke, propouned & setfurthe a parable of a certeyn wicked and craftie Stewarde, whom he lawded, because he ordered the matter so wt his maisters fermers and tenauntes, that he should neuer wante whiles they had.
column8: THere THere was a certain rich man, which was clothed in purple and fine white, and fared delyciously every day etc. Our Lord Jesus Christe (honourable audience) in the beginning of this xvj chapter of the holy Euangeliste faint Lycia, proponed & setfurthe a parable of a certain wicked and crafty Steward, whom he lawed, because he ordered the matter so with his masters fermers and tenants, that he should never want while they had.

column7: This mans wisedome, was lauded of our sauiour Christ, not because it was wicked, but because he made prouisyon, that is to say fryndes, here in this present world, for the tyme that was to come.
column8: This men wisdom, was lauded of our saviour Christ, not because it was wicked, but because he made prouisyon, that is to say friends, here in this present world, for the time that was to come.

column7: And so in this parable of this wicked Stuard he techeth vs all to make vs frendes whiles that we be here in this present worlde, that we lacke not in the world that is to come.
column8: And so in this parable of this wicked Steward he teacheth us all to make us friends while that we be here in this present world, that we lack not in the world that is to come.

column7: These be our saluiour Christes woordes, and the hole pitthe openyng of this afore named parable.
column8: These be our saviour Christes words, and the hold pitthe opening of this afore nam parable.

column7: And I saie (saith he) make you frendes of the vnrighteous and wicked Mammon, that when ye shall haue nede, they maie receiue you into euerlastyng habitacions.
column8: And I say (says he) make you friends of the unrighteous and wicked Mammon, that when you shall have need, they may receive you into everlasting habitations.

column7: There shall a greate chaunge come at that daie, where the pacient and the thankefull poore beggers, shalbe very ryche.
column8: There shall a great change come at that day, where the patient and the thankful poor beggars, shall very rich.

column7: And the vnmercifull and vnthankefull riche shalbe very beggers and poore.
column8: And the unmerciful and unthankful rich shall very beggars and poor.

column7: This is the riches that the pacient & thankefull poore beggers shall receiue: euerlastyng, (that is to saie) felicytie and glory with god in heauen.
column8: This is the riches that the patient & thankful poor beggars shall receive: everlasting, (that is to say) felicytie and glory with god in heaven.

column7: And this is the pouertie and beggery that the vnmercifull and vnthankefull riche men shall receiue with the deuell in hell, that is to saie euerlastynge payne and misery.
column8: And this is the poverty and beggary that the unmerciful and unthankful rich men shall receive with the devil in hell, that is to say everlasting pain and misery.

column7: This doctryne is bothe liuely and truly setfurth in this parable of Diues and Lazarus, that is to saie in the parable of ye richeman & of ye poore begger Lazarus.
column8: This doctrine is both lively and truly setfurth in this parable of Diues and Lazarus, that is to say in the parable of the richeman & of the poor beggar Lazarus.

column7: Althing heare in this parable, is setfurth so liuely & plainly, that a man marking it thoroughly and depely, with all the circumstaunces of thesame, shal rather thynke, that he seeth althynges done before his eyes, as it ware played in a playe, and euery persone sene, then to haue redde it or to haue harde it preached.
column8: Allthing hear in this parable, is setfurth so lively & plainly, that a man marking it thoroughly and deeply, with all the circumstances of thesame, shall rather think, that he sees allthings done before his eyes, as it beware played in a play, and every person seen, then to have red it or to have harden it preached.

column7: Nowe whether this parable of this richeman & of this begger, ware a thyng that was done in dede, or rather a thynge inuented by our sauiour Christ to teche with all suche thynges as be heare taught: it maketh no matter for vs to know.
column8: Now whither this parable of this richeman & of this beggar, beware a thing that was done in deed, or rather a thing invented by our saviour Christ to teach with all such things as be hear taught: it makes no matter for us to know.

column7: Let vs consider, vs (I say) whiche either bee, or oughte to bee very Christians, lette vs marke well, and depely consider, what thynges bee taught in this parable for our instructions and lerninges, and let vs beleue the doctrines of thesame to bee moste true.
column8: Let us consider, us (I say) which either bee, or ought to be very Christians, let us mark well, and deeply consider, what things be taught in this parable for our instructions and lerninges, and let us believe the doctrines of thesame to be most true.

column7: And that the selfsame thynges here taught in the parable, shall chaunce vnto vs, if we do as they dyd.
column8: And that the selfsame things here taught in the parable, shall chance unto us, if we do as they did.

column7: Let vs therfore haue contynually before our eyes, ye eyes I say of our consciences: these.ij. persones in this parable or example: setfurth (and by our sauiour Christe to learne vs by.
column8: Let us therefore have continually before our eyes, you eyes I say of our consciences: these ij persons in this parable or example: setfurth (and by our saviour Christe to learn us by.

column7: This parable is very necessary and also profitable & worthy to be had in memory of all men, whether they be riche or poore, for there is no persone of what soeuer degree or state, he or she be, but may learne by this parable.
column8: This parable is very necessary and also profitable & worthy to be had in memory of all men, whither they be rich or poor, for there is no person of what soever degree or state, he or she be, but may learn by this parable.

column7: The riche may learne & beware by it.
column8: The rich may learn & beware by it.

column7: The poore man maye learne and take greate comfort of it.
column8: The poor man may learn and take great comfort of it.

column7: I would wyshe this storie or parable to be painted or graue in euery mannes house; but rather imprinted in euery mannes conscience & memory.
column8: I would wish this story or parable to be painted or graven in every man's house; but rather imprinted in every man's conscience & memory.

column7: Nowe let vs come vnto the parable, & therein marke, both notable wordes and sentences.
column8: Now let us come unto the parable, & therein mark, both notable words and sentences.

column7: There was a certeyne Riche man, whiche was clothed in purple and fyne whyte, and fared deliciously euery daie.
column8: There was a certain Rich man, which was clothed in purple and fine white, and fared deliciously every day.

column7: The holy scripture teacheth.ij. maner or sortes of riche men.
column8: The holy scripture teaches ij manner or sorts of rich men.

column7: The one sorte are suche as are riche in God.
column8: The one sort are such as are rich in God.

column7: The other sorte that are riche to theselues.
column8: The other sort that are rich to themselves.

column7: They are riche in God, that knowe that all riches are geuen and come of god, and muste be spent accordynge to the will and pleasure of God.
column8: They are rich in God, that know that all riches are given and come of god, and must be spent according to the will and pleasure of God.

column7: They knowe what Dauid in his xxiij. Psalme dothe confesse and saie, not onely with mouthe but also wyth harte: in these wordes.
column8: They know what Dauid in his xxiij. Psalm doth confess and say, not only with mouth but also with heart: in these words.

column7: Domini est terra, & plenitudo eius: The earthe is the Lordes and all the plentuousnes that is in it Ergo suche goodes as we haue and possesse, be not ours, but the lordes.
column8: Domini est terra, & plenitudo eius: The earth is the Lords and all the plentuousnes that is in it Ergo such goods as we have and possess, be not ours, but the lords.

column7: We haue but the vse of them, and shall make a strait compt for them how that we vse them ether to our own, or to the lordes vse, to our owne profite and pleasure, or to the lordes profite or pleasure.
column8: We have but the use of them, and shall make a strait count for them how that we use them either to our own, or to the lords use, to our own profit and pleasure, or to the lords profit or pleasure.

column7: If that we ernestly, woulde weye these wordes and ernestly beleue the to be true (as they be moste ernestly to be waied, and also most ernestly to be beleued,) I suppose we should not be so vnthankeful in receiuing, so vnwares either in kepyng or spending, contrary to the wil and pleasur of the owner of them as we now are.
column8: If that we earnestly, would weye these words and earnestly believe thee to be true (as they be most earnestly to be weighed, and also most earnestly to be believed,) I suppose we should not be so unthankful in receiving, so unwares either in keeping or spending, contrary to the will and pleasure of the owner of them as we now are.

column7: Then should we receiue of the handes of our Lorde a great summe or porcion of his goodes, loke to make of thesame Lord, a great and a perfete compte for those goodes receyued.
column8: Then should we receive of the hands of our Lord a great sum or portion of his goods, look to make of thesame Lord, a great and a perfete compte for those goods received.

column7: I pray you, doe no greate riche men of the woorlde, looke for a compte of them to whom they commit ther substaunce or goodes.
column8: I pray you, do not great rich men of the world, look for a compte of them to whom they commit their substance or goods.

column7: Is it not right and reason that the tenauntes, knowe their lande lordes, and ones in the yere to paye their rentes, and knowleage their dueties.
column8: Is it not right and reason that the tenants, know their land lords, and ones in the year to pay their rents, and knowledge their duties.

column7: Seyng that al me that haue aught, do loke to haue their deuties paied and done vnto the accordyng to couenautes, why should not al men both highe and lowe noble and vnnoble, looke to do their duties to their lorde god?
column8: Sing that all me that have aught, do look to have their duties paid and done unto the according to couenautes, why should not all men both high and low noble and unnoble, look to do their duties to their lord god?

column7: Let them consider they haue receiued that that thei haue they be none owners, they be but seruauntes and disposers of their Lordes goodes.
column8: Let them consider they have received that that they have they be none owners, they be but servants and disposers of their Lords goods.

column7: God geue grace to all suche seruauntes, to receiue suche thynges, as they receiue truly, and to spende and bestowe their goodes truly, that in tyme to come, they may make suche a compte, as shalbe thankfully receiued, and they to be rewarded abundantly.
column8: God give grace to all such servants, to receive such things, as they receive truly, and to spend and bestow their goods truly, that in time to come, they may make such a compte, as shall thankfully received, and they to be rewarded abundantly.

column7: Of suche a seruaunte Dauid writethe in the.
column8: Of such a servant Dauid writeth in thee.

column7: Cxij. Psalme thus saiyng: Opes & diuitiae in domo eius & iusticia eius manet ineternum. Abundance and greate riches are in his house, and his rightuousnes and vprighte dealynge remayneth for euer.
column8: Cxij. Psalm thus saying: Opens & diuitiae in domo eius & justicia eius manet ineternum. Abundance and great riches are in his house, and his righteousness and upright dealing remaineth for ever.

column7: He saith not, Robberyes, euell gotten goodes and vsury are in his house: for then Dauid wold haue said that his vnrightuousnes and subtile dealyng had remained in his house for euer.
column8: He says not, Robberies, evil got goods and usury are in his house: for then Dauid would have said that his unrighteousness and subtle dealing had remained in his house for ever.

column7: Here lette vs weye and depely consider, the great gyfte of god wherby these.ij. thynges may be ioyned together in one house, that is to saye, rghtuousnes and Riches.
column8: Here let us weye and deeply consider, the great gift of god whereby these ij things may be joined together in one house, that is to say, rghtuousnes and Riches.

column7: When the good man of the house is bothe Riche and rightuous, howe muche is that man bounde to God.
column8: When the good man of the house is both Rich and righteous, how much is that man bound to God.

column7: For seldome be these.ij. gistes lodged in one house.
column8: For seldom be these ij gistes lodged in one house.

column7: And yet it is not vnpossible to God although it be vnpossible to man.
column8: And yet it is not unpossible to God although it be unpossible to man.

column7: We reade in holy scripture of many (by the goodnes of god) that ware bothe riche and rightuous.
column8: We read in holy scripture of many (by the goodness of god) that beware both rich and righteous.

column7: As Abraham, Isaac, Iacob, Ioseph, Samuel, Iob; Dauid, &c. These men ware more then men, for they wer good men, that both feared god & loued god, & that by hys grace and goodnes: whiche was not receiued of them in vaine, they vsed al their goodes to godes will & pleasure.
column8: As Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Joseph, Samuel, Job; Dauid, etc. These men beware more then men, for they were good men, that both feared god & loved god, & that by his grace and goodness: which was not received of them in vain, they used all their goods to gods will & pleasure.

column7: And so doe all good men that are riche in god.
column8: And so do all good men that are rich in god.

column7: Richesse and pouertie of themselues, be thynges indifferente neither good nor badde, but the vse of them maketh all.
column8: Richesse and poverty of themselves, be things indifferent neither good nor bad, but the use of them makes all.

column7: God is not pleased by and by, because that a man is poore, for there be many poore that be also wicked, and none more wicked then they.
column8: God is not pleased by and by, because that a man is poor, for there be many poor that be also wicked, and none more wicked then they.

column7: Nether is god displeased, because a man is riche, for ther haue bene, and I doute not but ther be, many riche me bothe riche & good also, that pleasen god right well.
column8: Neither is god displeased, because a man is rich, for there have be, and I doubt not but there be, many rich me both rich & good also, that pleasen god right well.

column7: For riches be meanes and instrumentes, wherby God maie be pleased, if thei that possesse them, be bothe riche and rightuous.
column8: For riches be means and instruments, whereby God may be pleased, if they that possess them, be both rich and righteous.

column7: Then doe they vse there richesse to goddes pleasure and poore mens profettes.
column8: Then do they use there richesse to gods pleasure and poor men's profettes.

column7: And they beynge suche riche men, there spryngethe out of them as it ware.ij. founteynes, one is: they will do good, And another yt they are able to do that good that they wil.
column8: And they being such rich men, there spryngethe out of them as it beware ij founteynes, one is: they will do good, And another that they are able to do that good that they will.

column7: Here ye see, that the riche man may do one thynge, that the poore cannot do, That is, he hath wherwith to do that yt he will do, & so hath not the poore man, yet for al that the poore man is neuer the more vnrightuous because he hath not to do with all, but it is sufficyente for hym to whom god geueth nomore, to haue a good will and a mercifull harte towardes all them that haue nede.
column8: Here you see, that the rich man may do one thing, that the poor cannot do, That is, he hath wherewith to do that that he will do, & so hath not the poor man, yet for all that the poor man is never the more unrighteous because he hath not to doe with all, but it is sufficyente for him to whom god giveth nomore, to have a good will and a merciful heart towards all them that have need.

column7: And lette hym deale hys almose with hys tongue, in comfortynge, counseilynge and exhorting other to pacience and to al other goodnes.
column8: And let him deal his almose with his tongue, in comforting, counseilynge and exhorting other to patience and to all other goodness.

column7: But although the rich ma be bound to do al these, yet he must helpe the neadie to, with his substaunce accordynge to his abilytie and their necessitie, or els he is not that man, that is afore spoken of, that is bothe riche and rightuous.
column8: But although the rich ma be bound to do all these, yet he must help the needy to, with his substance according to his abilytie and their necessity, or else he is not that man, that is afore spoken of, that is both rich and righteous.

column7: I pray god make all them that haue riches of god geuen vnto them, or rather lent vnto them, to be of this sort, that is bothe riche and rightuous, and to consider deaply the will of god, and to remember charitably, the nede of their poore neighbours.
column8: I pray god make all them that have riches of god given unto them, or rather lent unto them, to be of this sort, that is both rich and righteous, and to consider deaply the will of god, and to remember charitably, the need of their poor neighbours.

column7: It foloweth also in the afore rehersed texte & Iusticia eius manet ineternum. His rightuousnes dothe remaine for euer.
column8: It followeth also in the afore rehearsed text & Justicia eius manet ineternum. His righteousness doth remain for ever.

column7: Aboundaunce and richesse remainethe not for euer, but the righte vsyng of them and the vpright dealing with them remaineth for euer.
column8: Abundance and richesse remaineth not for ever, but the right using of them and the upright dealing with them remains for ever.

column7: Some men perchaunce will say, sir ye say wel, that I muste helpe and releue my neighboures nedes and necessities.
column8: Some men perchance will say, sir you say well, that I must help and relieve my neighbours needs and necessities.

column7: But I pray you tel me? benot my gooddes mine owne gooddes, and maie not I bestowe them according to mine owne mind?
column8: But I pray you tell me? benot my gods mine own gods, and may not I bestow them according to mine own mind?

column7: This obiection is answered to partely before, but heareafter it shalbe answered fully, that neither the gooddes that thou haste in thy possessyon, are thy gooddes, but goddes gooddes, and are not geuen the to be bestowed at thy pleasure, but at goddes pleasure.
column8: This objection is answered to partly before, but hereafter it shall answered fully, that neither the gods that thou haste in thy possession, are thy gods, but gods gods, and are not given thee to be bestowed at thy pleasure, but at gods pleasure.

column7: Heare and marke it wel in this matter, what the holy man Dauid in ye.ciiij. psalme saith.
column8: Hear and mark it well in this matter, what the holy man Dauid in you ciiij psalm says.

column7: Impleta est terra facultatibus, tuis. The earthe O lorde (saith he) is replenished with thy goodes and substance.
column8: Impleta est terra facultatibus, tuis. The earth Oh lord (says he) is replenished with thy goods and substance.

column7: Then if we beleue the saiyng of this holy man Dauid, as we muste nedes and are bounde to do, because it is autenticke scripture.
column8: Then if we believe the saying of this holy man Dauid, as we must needs and are bound to do, because it is autenticke scripture.

column7: We shall perceiue that al the goodes and substance that is on the earth, is the Lordes and not ours, and that we be but balliefes and Stuardes of thesame, to bestowe them after his wyll and not after our owne wyll, & that on payne of damnacion.
column8: We shall perceive that all the goods and substance that is on the earth, is the Lords and not ours, and that we be but balliefes and Stuardes of thesame, to bestow them after his will and not after our own will, & that on pain of damnation.

column7: Wylt thou knowe what is thine owne proper good, among al the gooddes of the earth, consider well what thou broughtest in with the in to this world, that is to say, nothyng, the that nothynge maiste thou bestowe accordyng to thyne owne will, for all other thynges are to be bestowed accordyng to the Lordes will, that is the owner of them.
column8: Wilt thou know what is thine own proper good, among all the gods of the earth, consider well what thou broughtest in with the in to this world, that is to say, nothing, the that nothing maiste thou bestow according to thine own will, for all other things are to be bestowed according to the Lords will, that is the owner of them.

column7: Perchaunce a man will saie, although I brought nothing into this world with me, yet ther be many thinges, that I my self with my witte and wisedome, with my diligence and poll^cye haue gotten, may I not bestowe those goodes at myne owne will and pleasure?
column8: Perchance a man will say, although I brought nothing into this world with me, yet there be many things, that I my self with my wit and wisdom, with my diligence and poll^cye have got, may I not bestow those goods at mine own will and pleasure?

column7: I pray the tell me, who gaue the that witte and wisedom, that with thy diligence & policie, thou haste gotte these (as thou accomptest the) thyne owne goodes?
column8: I pray the tell me, who gave the that wit and wisdom, that with thy diligence & policy, thou haste got these (as thou accomptest the) thine own goods?

column7: Did not god geue the al that thou haste, witte, reason, vnderstandynge, knowlege, and whatsoeuer thou haste els, to serue hym with all.
column8: Did not god give the all that thou haste, wit, reason, understanding, knowledge, and whatsoever thou haste else, to serve him with all.

column7: Art not thou his bounde seruaut with all that thou haste, and arte bounde to serue him to ye vttermost of thi powre?
column8: Art not thou his bound seruaut with all that thou haste, and art bound to serve him to you uttermost of thy pour?

column7: May a seruaunt that is sure bounde to his maister, make himselfe free, and to do what hym lyste, when he wyll?
column8: May a servant that is sure bound to his master, make himself free, and to do what him list, when he will?

column7: Standeth he not bound to his maister to do hym seruice, to the vttermoste of his powre, with all his witte, with all his reason, with all his vnderstandynge and knowlege, & with all that is possible for him to do, and thus muste he continue vntill the tyme his couenaunt be out?
column8: Stands he not bound to his master to do him service, to the uttermost of his pour, with all his wit, with all his reason, with all his understanding and knowledge, & with all that is possible for him to do, and thus must he continue until the time his covenant be out?

column7: Are not all manner of persons with all there qualities, both inwarde and outwarde, bothe greate and small, high & lowe, men & women, from the highest sorte to the lowest, bounde to serue God with all there goodes and substance, and with al that thei haue or be beside.
column8: Are not all manner of persons with all there qualities, both inward and outward, both great and small, high & low, men & women, from the highest sort to the lowest, bound to serve God with all there goods and substance, and with all that they have or be beside.

column7: Who hath made any man free from this seruice?
column8: Who hath made any man free from this service?

column7: Not god: for he saith in the.xij. chapiter of Exodus Ego sum dominus deus tuus I am (saithe he) the Lorde thy God.
column8: Not god: for he says in the xij chapter of Exodus Ego sum dominus deus tuus I am (sayeth he) the Lord thy God.

column7: This saiynge is spoken to euery man and woman of whatsoeuer state they be, here is none excepted.
column8: This saying is spoken to every man and woman of whatsoever state they be, here is none excepted.

column7: If god be the Lorde of vs all: be not we then all hys seruauntes, wyth all our qualities.
column8: If god be the Lord of us all: be not we then all his servants, with all our qualities.

column7: Who hath made vs free?
column8: Who hath made us free?

column7: Not god, for he wil neuer make vs free fro hys seruice, so longe as we be in this body, Can we make ourselues free?
column8: Not god, for he will never make us free from his service, so long as we be in this body, Can we make ourselves free?

column7: That cannot a seruaunte do duryng his couenant.
column8: That cannot a servant do during his covenant.

column7: Our couenant is made, it cannot be broken durynge this lyfe.
column8: Our covenant is made, it cannot be broken during this life.

column7: Therefore we with all that we haue be goddes bound seruauntes, and are bounde to serue hym faithfully and truly, and that to our ende euen on panye of Damnacion.
column8: Therefore we with all that we have be gods bound servants, and are bound to serve him faithfully and truly, and that to our end even on panye of Damnation.

column7: Nowe therefore, ye that wylbe ryche and rightuous, see that ye get youre gooddes accordyng to the wyll of God godly, kepe them godly & spende the godly, be mercyfull to the poore and nedye, be not hyghe mynded and haultie ouer other that be poore, Truste not in vncerteyn riches, but in the liuynge God, be riche in good workes: for all these lessons dothe the holy Apostle Paule teche vs, in his firste Epistle to Timothe.vj. Suche a nother good lesson dothe Dauid teche vs in the lxxxj. Psalme saiynge: Si diuitiae affluunt, nolite cor apponere. If riches (saithe he) flowe or be abundante, sette not your harte on them, Make not your good, your God.
column8: Now therefore, you that wylbe rich and righteous, see that you get your gods according to the will of God godly, keep them godly & spend the godly, be merciful to the poor and needy, be not high minded and haultie over other that be poor, Trust not in uncertain riches, but in the living God, be rich in good works: for all these lessons doth the holy Apostle Paule teach us, in his firste Epistle to Timothe vj Suche a neither good lesson doth Dauid teach us in the lxxxj. Psalm saying: Si diuitiae affluunt, nolite cor apponere. If riches (sayeth he) flow or be abundant, set not your heart on them, Make not your good, your God.

column7: Serue you your God, and lette your good serue you.
column8: Serve you your God, and let your good serve you.

column7: Nowe heare ye haue heard the properties of those riche men yt are bothe Ryche and Rightuous, and they that are suche are also Ryche in God.
column8: Now hear you have herd the properties of those rich men that are both Rich and Righteous, and they that are such are also Rich in God.

column7: I beseche God of his infinite goodnes, to geue vs all grace to learne to be riche in this wise, that is in God, & to practyse the same in our liuynge, whiche shalbe if that we be ryche and rightuous, but all are not riche & rightuous, it is good inoughe if we be rightuous whether we be riche or poore.
column8: I beseech God of his infinite goodness, to give us all grace to learn to be rich in this wise, that is in God, & to practise the same in our living, which shall if that we be rich and righteous, but all are not rich & righteous, it is good enough if we be righteous whither we be rich or poor.

column7: Whatsoeuer be awaye, rightuousnes maye not be away.
column8: Whatsoever be away, righteousness may not be away.

column7: Here endeth the first parte of this sermon.
column8: Here endeth the first part of this sermon.

column7: The seconde parte.
column8: The seconde part.

column7: F Vrthermore accordyng to my promes, I will speake of another sorte of men, that are rich in themselues and not in god.
column8: Furthermore Furthermore according to my promise, I will speak of another sort of men, that are rich in themselves and not in god.

column7: Of this sorte of riche men was this riche man of whom Christe made this parable.
column8: Of this sort of rich men was this rich man of whom Christe made this parable.

column7: Of such sorte of riche men the holy scripture is plentyfull, and the whole worlde is not emptie.
column8: Of such sort of rich men the holy scripture is plentiful, and the whole world is not empty.

column7: Of that sorte of men Sainte paule admonissheth Timotheus his dysciple.j. Timothy.vj. Charge them (saith he) whiche are riche in this worlde, that they benot highe mynded, nor to truste in vncerten riches: and in thesame chapiter he spekethe also, of suche riche men.
column8: Of that sort of men Saint paule admonisheth Timotheus his dysciple j Timothy vj Charge them (says he) which are rich in this world, that they benot high minded, nor to trust in uncertain riches: and in thesame chapter he speaketh also, of such rich men.

column7: They (saith he) that wilbe riche, (that is to say to themselues & not to God) fall into temptacion and snares of the Deuell, and to many folyshe and noisome lustes, whiche drawe men into perdicion and destruction &c. Here ye see partly in what case they are that are riche in themselues and not in god.
column8: They (says he) that will rich, (that is to say to themselves & not to God) fallen into temptation and snares of the Devil, and to many foolish and noisome lusts, which draw men into perdition and destruction etc. Here you see partly in what case they are that are rich in themselves and not in god.

column7: Paule calleth them the riche of this worlde, because they looke for none other riches of the other worlde.
column8: Paule calls them the rich of this world, because they look for none other riches of the other world.

column7: They maye well bee called the riche of this worlde, for they shalbe poore beggers in the other worlde, forthey make no preparacion here, that they may be riche there.
column8: They may well be called the rich of this world, for they shall poor beggars in the other world, forthey make no preparation here, that they may be rich there.

column7: A liuely example of suche a riche man is setfurth by our sauiour Christe himselfe in the xii. of Saint Luke & that by a parable.
column8: A lively example of such a rich man is setfurth by our saviour Christe himself in the xii. of Saint Lycia & that by a parable.

column7: The grounde (saith Christe) of a certen riche man brought forth plentiful frutes, and he thought within himself saiyng, what shal I do? because I haue no rome where to bestowe my frutes?
column8: The ground (says Christe) of a certain rich man brought forth plentiful fruits, and he thought within himself saying, what shall I do? because I have no room where to bestow my fruits?

column7: And he saied, thus wil I do I wyl destroye my barnes and buylde greater and therein wil I gather all my gooddes that are growen vnto me and I wyll saie vnto my soule: Soule thou haste muche goodes layed vp in store for many yeares, take thyne ease, eate, drinke, be mery.
column8: And he said, thus will I do I will destroy my barns and build greater and therein will I gather all my gods that are grown unto me and I will say unto my soul: Soul thou haste much goods laid up in store for many years, take thine ease, eat, drink, be merry.

column7: But God saied vnto hym: Thou foole, this night they shall fetche away thy soule againe from the then whose shall those thynges be, whiche thou haste prouided?
column8: But God said unto him: Thou fool, this night they shall fetch away thy soul again from the then whose shall those things be, which thou haste provided?

column7: Here is many wounderous thinges in this parable to be considered, if men of thys worlde ware so wyse to consider them in tyme, no doubte of this matter, they shall consider it & that depely and ernestly, but all to late, all to late I say.
column8: Here is many wondrous things in this parable to be considered, if men of this world beware so wise to consider them in time, no doubt of this matter, they shall consider it & that deeply and earnestly, but all to late, all to late I say.

column7: It ware very expedient for all menne, and namely for suche as be laden with worldly, goodes, riches, Dignities & promocions, & that nowe in tyme, whyle tyme is, for that tyme wyll awaye shortely ere a manne be ware.
column8: It beware very expedient for all men, and namely for such as be laden with worldly, goods, riches, Dignities & promotions, & that now in time, while time is, for that time will away shortly ere a man be aware.

column7: It ware good to beware in tyme I saie, for after that tyme, it is to late to be beware, It is to late to be wyse, for al thy warenesse and wisedome will not helpe then.
column8: It beware good to beware in time I say, for after that time, it is to late to be beware, It is to late to be wise, for all thy warenesse and wisdom will not help then.

column7: Lette them be ware nowe ere it be ouer late.
column8: Let them be aware now ere it be over late.

column7: Remember the olde prouerbe: happie is he that can be ware by another manes hurte, he is wise, that can learne wisedome by another manes folishnes.
column8: Remember the old proverb: happy is he that can be aware by another manes hurt, he is wise, that can learn wisdom by another manes foolishness.

column7: He is happie that can learne to be ware in tyme.
column8: He is happy that can learn to be aware in time.

column7: All menne, that haue godly witte and vnderstandynge, maye be ware howe they vse their gooddes and their liues, by these.ij. men setfurth in these.ij. parables, to all men to learne by, howe to haue heare in this worlde there goodes, and howe to spende them.
column8: All men, that have godly wit and understanding, may be aware how they use their gods and their lives, by these ij men setfurth in these ij parables, to all men to learn by, how to have hear in this world there goods, and how to spend them.

column7: Of the one mencion is made in Luke.xij. Chapiter, And of the other in the.xvj. Chapiter of thesame Euangeliste.
column8: Of the one mention is made in Lycia xij Chapter, And of the other in the xvj Chapter of thesame Euangeliste.

column7: I wyll begynne nowe with the fyrste.
column8: I will begin now with the fyrste.

column7: I haue rehersed vnto you, alredy the texte, which begynneth thus.
column8: I have rehearsed unto you, already the text, which beginneth thus.

column7: The grounde of a certeyne Ryche manne broughte furthe plentifull frutes.
column8: The ground of a certain Rich man brought forth plentiful fruits.

column7: &c. Here is to be marked, the greate and infinite goodnes of god that gaue such aboundaunce of al erthly thynges, to this vnthankefull man, that dothe not once consider the abundant goodnes of God towardes hym, nor yet is he merciful towardes his neighbors, but forgate his bounde dewtie, bothe towardes god and his neighbours, and remembred onely hymself.
column8: etc. Here is to be marked, the great and infinite goodness of god that gave such abundance of all earthly things, to this unthankful man, that doth not once consider the abundant goodness of God towards him, nor yet is he merciful towards his neighbours, but foregate his bound duty, both towards god and his neighbours, and remembered only himself.

column7: Marke the wordes of ye history or parable, marke what this man saied, and marke also what he dyd, Marke I say, for al men oughte to beware, either of suche saiynges or doynges, for the prouerbe is true: so do: so haue.
column8: Mark the words of the history or parable, mark what this man said, and mark also what he did, Mark I say, for all men ought to beware, either of such sayings or doings, for the proverb is true: so do: so have.

column7: Say and do as this man dyd, and it shalbe sayed and done to you, as it was sayed and done vnto him.
column8: Say and do as this man did, and it shall said and done to you, as it was said and done unto him.

column7: Marke this man well, with his saiynges and doynges, for euen so, it shalbe saied and done vnto you as was saied and done vnto hym.
column8: Mark this man well, with his sayings and doings, for even so, it shall said and done unto you as was said and done unto him.

column7: Firste what saied he? what dyd he?
column8: Firste what said he? what did he?

column7: He saied, what shall I do, because I haue no roume where to bestowe my frutes.
column8: He said, what shall I do, because I have no room where to bestow my fruits.

column7: And he saied: thus will I do: I wil destroy my barnes, and buyld greater, and therin will I gather all my goodes that are growen to me.
column8: And he said: thus will I do: I will destroy my barns, and build greater, and therein will I gather all my goods that are grown to me.

column7: &c. Here ye heare part of this mannes saiynges, and see his doynges, not without his thinkinges.
column8: etc. Here you hear part of this man's sayings, and see his doings, not without his thinkings.

column7: He saied, what shall I do?
column8: He said, what shall I do?

column7: Was this euill said?
column8: Was this evil said?

column7: It had not been euill said, if the meanyng of his saiyng had been good.
column8: It had not been evil said, if the meaning of his saying had been good.

column7: Euery man ought to examyne his awne consciece: saiyng to hymself, what shall I do?
column8: Every man ought to examine his awn conscience: saying to himself, what shall I do?

column7: This manes saiyng maie be borne with in part, but consider the whole, with the meanyng, all is naught.
column8: This manes saying may be born with in part, but consider the whole, with the meaning, all is nought.

column7: He saieth: what shall I do.
column8: He sayeth: what shall I do.

column7: His meanyng was naught, his awne wordes declare no lesse.
column8: His meaning was nought, his awn words declare no less.

column7: He meaneth not, when he saieth, what shall I do, accordyng to Goddes will, and to the comfort of my neighbor.
column8: He means not, when he sayeth, what shall I do, according to Goddes will, and to the comfort of my neighbour.

column7: His meaning was altogether to get, to kepe, and to spende, all for his awne pleasure, all for his awne profite.
column8: His meaning was altogether to get, to keep, and to spend, all for his awn pleasure, all for his awn profit.

column7: He regarded neither his dutie towardes God, nor yet towardes his neighbour.
column8: He regarded neither his duty towards God, nor yet towards his neighbour.

column7: He made no reconyng, whence his aboundance of his goodes came, who gaue that plentie, whose goodes thei were, and how thei ought to be bestowed.
column8: He made no reckoning, whence his abundance of his goods came, who gave that plenty, whose goods they were, and how they ought to be bestowed.

column7: His mynd was set another waie, how he should kepe these his goodes, wher he should bestowe the, his mind was occupied in pullyng doune those thynges, yt were to litle for his purpose, & to build greater, & to lacke no rome, where to lay al suche goodes, as wer growe vnto him as God had sent, geuen, or lent hym.
column8: His mind was set another way, how he should keep these his goods, where he should bestow thee, his mind was occupied in pulling down those things, that were to little for his purpose, & to built greater, & to lack no room, where to lay all such goods, as were grow unto him as God had sent, given, or lent him.

column7: Was this an euill thyng, either to speake or to do? to buyld greater houses, and to make greater romes, wher god sendeth suche great plentie?
column8: Was this and evil thing, either to speak or to do? to build greater houses, and to make greater romes, where god sends such great plenty?

column7: Nay truly.
column8: Nay truly.

column7: Herein was his faulte, that all that he either thought, said or did, was thought, said and doen, to none other end, but al for hymself.
column8: Herein was his fault, that all that he either thought, said or did, was thought, said and done, to none other end, but all for himself.

column7: He neither regarded his duetie towardes God, nor yet towardes his neighbor.
column8: He neither regarded his duty towards God, nor yet towards his neighbour.

column7: We heare nothyng of his thoughtes, saiynges & doinges, that his goodes came-fro god and ought to haue been receiued with thankesgeuyng, and also to haue been bestowed, accordyng to God the geuers wil.
column8: We hear nothing of his thoughts, sayings & doings, that his goods came-fro god and ought to have been received with thankesgeuyng, and also to have been bestowed, according to God the geuers will.

column7: We heare tell of none of all these thynges, neither by his thoughtes, wordes nor dedes, but he thought said and did, al thynges, accordyng to his awne will, to his awne pleasure, & for his awne profit.
column8: We hear tell of none of all these things, neither by his thoughts, words nor deeds, but he thought said and did, all things, according to his awn will, to his awn pleasure, & for his awn profit.

column7: He compted al his goodes and substaunce his awne, growen vnto himself onely, and onely (as he toke it) to vse the to his awne pleasure and profite.
column8: He counted all his goods and substance his awn, grown unto himself only, and only (as he took it) to use thee to his awn pleasure and profit.

column7: This I will do, this I will say, saith he to hymself.
column8: This I will do, this I will say, says he to himself.

column7: He remebred not, what the will of god was what he should saie, & what he should do; but he saied: thus wil I do, & thus will I saie.
column8: He remebred not, what the will of god was what he should say, & what he should do; but he said: thus will I do, & thus will I say.

column7: Be there not many now a daies, that bothe dooe and saie: euen as this man did and saied.
column8: Be there not many now a days, that both do and say: even as this man did and said.

column7: If a manne would consider the doynges & the saiynges, of many me now a daies, shuld we not thinke ye, finde them as mad & as marueilous, as this mannes doynges & saiynges were?
column8: If a man would consider the doings & the sayings, of many me now a days, should we not think you, find them as mad & as marvelous, as this man's doings & sayings were?

column7: Should we not perceiue by suche saiynges and doynges their imaginacios and thoughtes to be as vain, as mad and as vngodly, as this mannes were.
column8: Should we not perceive by such sayings and doings their imaginacios and thoughts to be as vain, as mad and as ungodly, as this man's were.

column7: Should not a man markyng these thinges, perceiue that men now a daies, be as vnthankful to God, as this man was?
column8: Should not a man marking these things, perceive that men now a days, be as unthankful to God, as this man was?

column7: Should not a man finde suche now a daies, as hath receiued suche aboundaunce of goodes, of substaunce, of honours and promocions at Goddes hand, and regarde their dueties in these thynges, towardes God and their neighbour, as litle as this manne did.
column8: Should not a man find such now a days, as hath received such abundance of goods, of substance, of honours and promotions at Goddes hand, and regard their duties in these things, towards God and their neighbour, as little as this man did.

column7: But what nedeth me to go furth and dilate this matter at length.
column8: But what needeth me to go forth and dilate this matter at length.

column7: Loke vpon mennes maners, and ye shall se, that thei now a daies, passe this man, bothe in their doynges & saiynges, and also by their imaginacions, whiche be seen vnto vs by their saiynges and doynges, to bee nothyng behynd hym.
column8: Look upon men's manners, and you shall see, that they now a days, pass this man, both in their doings & sayings, and also by their imaginations, which be seen unto us by their sayings and doings, to be nothing behind him.

column7: Thynke ye not that those menne, beyng either equall with this ma, or passyng hym, in their imaginacions, saiynges and doynges, shall not all these heare also by the mouthe of God, said vnto the, as this man did, saied vnto hym?
column8: Think you not that those men, being either equal with this ma, or passing him, in their imaginations, sayings and doings, shall not all these hear also by the mouth of God, said unto thee, as this man did, said unto him?

column7: Yes, truely shall thei.
column8: Yes, truly shall they.

column7: Nowe what the mouthe of God spake to this man then, and no lesse to oure menne of like condicions now ye shall heare hereafter.
column8: Now what the mouth of God spoke to this man then, and no less to our men of like conditions now you shall hear hereafter.

column7: Butere I passe, I muste reherse vnto you, one saiyng of this mannes more, and then I wil come to Gods saiyng, for, when we haue all saied, we muste bee content to geue God licence also, to saie his mynd, for surely so will he do, wil we: nil we.
column8: Butere I pass, I must rehearse unto you, one saying of this man's more, and then I will come to Gods saying, for, when we have all said, we must be content to give God licence also, to say his mind, for surely so will he do, will we: nil we.

column7: And we will not heare hym here, we must and shal heare him there, with a worse will and lesse profite.
column8: And we will not hear him here, we must and shall hear him there, with a worse will and less profit.

column7: I will returne again, to that one saiyng of this man that is behind, and then will I tell you what God saith.
column8: I will return again, to that one saying of this man that is behind, and then will I tell you what God says.

column7: This man saied thus, saieth the text: And I will saie vnto my soule (saieth he) soule, thou haste muche goodes layed vp in store for many yeres.
column8: This man said thus, sayeth the text: And I will say unto my soul (sayeth he) soul, thou haste much goods laid up in store for many years.

column7: Take thyne ease, eate, drinke, be mery.
column8: Take thine ease, eat, drink, be merry.

column7: First and formoste ye must marke, who it is, that speaketh on this fashion, it is the riche ma, that heare afore is described he that had suche abundance of gooddes, that he wist not where to lay the, he that had no Godly regarde to bestowe them, but all his mynde was, in gettyng, in gatheryng, in hourdyng, and laiyng vp in store, for log tyme to come.
column8: First and foremost you must mark, who it is, that speaks on this fashion, it is the rich ma, that hear afore is described he that had such abundance of gods, that he wist not where to lay thee, he that had no Godly regard to bestow them, but all his mind was, in getting, in gathering, in hourdyng, and laying up in store, for log time to come.

column7: Suche menne thus full, hauyng all thyng after their awne mind, then thei begin to saie to the selfes, in their awne coceiptes: soule thou hast much goodes laied vp in store for many yeres.
column8: Suche men thus full, having all thing after their awn mind, then they begin to say to the selves, in their awn coceiptes: soul thou hast much goods laid up in store for many years.

column7: Marke here the imaginacion of suche riche men, thei wene, through the multitude of their substaunce, to liue many yeres and daies.
column8: Mark here the imagination of such rich men, they ween, through the multitude of their substance, to live many years and days.

column7: This man was of that opinion, because he had suche aboundaunce of goodes, he promised hymself many yeres, to make mery in, and to leade a getlemanly life, bothe a pleasaunt and a long.
column8: This man was of that opinion, because he had such abundance of goods, he promised himself many years, to make merry in, and to lead a getlemanly life, both a pleasant and a long.

column7: But he made his reconyng (as the Prouerbe is) without his hoste: and so he is fain to recon again.
column8: But he made his reckoning (as the Proverb is) without his host: and so he is fain to recon again.

column7: His many yeres were sone run ouer.
column8: His many years were soon run over.

column7: He was not suffered to liue, the space of an whole day.
column8: He was not suffered to live, the space of and whole day.

column7: He promised hymself, many other thynges mo: whiche came to as good effect and passe, as this thyng did.
column8: He promised himself, many other things more: which came to as good effect and pass, as this thing did.

column7: He saied also: take thine ease, eate drinke and be mery.
column8: He said also: take thine ease, eat drink and be merry.

column7: Where is that long ease that was promised, with that delicacie in eatyng and that pleasauntnesse in drynkyng.
column8: Where is that long ease that was promised, with that delicacy in eating and that pleasantness in drinking.

column7: Where is become, the carelesse life, wherein there should be nothyng, but mirthe and ioye, and makyng merie: settyng the Cocke vpon houpe, and all should bee well.
column8: Where is become, the careless life, wherein there should be nothing, but mirth and joy, and making merry: setting the Cock upon houpe, and all should be well.

column7: All together is turned: arsie, versie.
column8: All together is turned: arsie, versie.

column7: There came one sodainly, vnloked for, and also vnwelcome, that marred all the playe.
column8: There came one suddenly, unlooked for, and also unwelcome, that marred all the play.

column7: Who was that?
column8: Who was that?

column7: Truly GOD.
column8: Truly GOD.

column7: Why, is it come to his course, to speake nowe?
column8: Why, is it come to his course, to speak now?

column7: Yea surely.
column8: Yea surely.

column7: When men haue shewed their vanitie, then will God shewe his veritie.
column8: When men have showed their vanity, then will God show his verity.

column7: Men doo take their pleasure, when thei bee here hauyng all thyng after their awn lustes, but whe the tyme commeth, that God dooeth appoyncte, he will take then his luste and pleasure, and will bryng theim: cora nobis in a wilde wanion, and he will tell them a newe tale then, farre vnlike to their tale, wherein thei promised themselfes long life and wel to fare.
column8: Men do take their pleasure, when they be here having all thing after their awn lusts, but when the time comes, that God doth appoyncte, he will take then his lust and pleasure, and will bring them: cora nobis in a wild wanion, and he will tell them a new tale then, far unlike to their tale, wherein they promised themselves long life and well to fare.

column7: But when God beginneth to speake, then thei begin to holde their peace.
column8: But when God begins to speak, then they begin to hold their peace.

column7: Why will God begin once to speake?
column8: Why will God begin once to speak?

column7: Yea, that he will truely.
column8: Yea, that he will truly.

column7: A practise of Goddes speakyng, wee learne here, in this present place of Scripture.
column8: A practice of Goddes speaking, we learn here, in this present place of Scripture.

column7: When this riche manne had talked ful his bely, after his awn fansie, thinkyng al thyng should come to passe, euen as he had imagined it.
column8: When this rich man had talked full his belly, after his awn fancy, thinking all thing should come to pass, even as he had imagined it.

column7: Euen when he had went he had been mooste sure, he was sonest deceiued.
column8: Euen when he had went he had been most sure, he was soonest deceived.

column7: I told you, he made his reconyng without his hooste.
column8: I told you, he made his reckoning without his host.

column7: His hooste (whiche is God, to whom all reconynges muste be made truely) called hym to a newe reconyng, he made hym make a newe compt.
column8: His host (which is God, to whom all reconynges must be made truly) called him to a new reckoning, he made him make a new count.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: But God saied vnto hym: thou foole, this night thei shal fetche awaie thy soule again fro thee, then whose shall those thynges bee, whiche thou hast prouided?
column8: But God said unto him: thou fool, this night they shall fetch away thy soul again from thee, then whose shall those things be, which thou hast provided?

column7: It is the fashion of GOD, to call suche menne to a reare compt.
column8: It is the fashion of GOD, to call such men to a rear count.

column7: Is God so sharpe in his woordes, that he will call as many as he findeth in this case, fooles?
column8: Is God so sharp in his words, that he will call as many as he finds in this case, fools?

column7: Yea truly, this is his fashion, and thus will he do.
column8: Yea truly, this is his fashion, and thus will he do.

column7: I feare me then, that a greate many of our wise men, at whose wisedome the worlde wondereth now, will bee called fooles then.
column8: I fear me then, that a great many of our wise men, at whose wisdom the world wondereth now, will be called fools then.

column7: I feare me, that a greate nober of noble men, whose nobilitie the worlde worshippeth, will bee proued fooles then.
column8: I fear me, that a great nober of noble men, whose nobility the world worshippeth, will be proved fools then.

column7: I feare me, that a greate nomber of our Iudges and Iustices, whose aucthoritie is not small in the worlde, will bee proued fooles then.
column8: I fear me, that a great number of our Judges and Justices, whose authority is not small in the world, will be proved fools then.

column7: I feare me, that a greate many of our learned clergie, whose learnyng is in no small reputacion: will bee founde fooles then.
column8: I fear me, that a great many of our learned clergy, whose learning is in no small reputation: will be found fools then.

column7: What shall I nede to run ouer, all the states and sortes of men: seeyng that all menne, of whatsoeuer state or condicion thei be, if thei do, as this foolishe riche man did, no doubte the mouthe of God, here in this place of Scripture, calleth all the many of theim fooles.
column8: What shall I need to run over, all the states and sorts of men: seeing that all men, of whatsoever state or condition they be, if they do, as this foolish rich man did, no doubt the mouth of God, here in this place of Scripture, calls all the many of them fools.

column7: All suche men that thus liueth, and so dieth, be created fooles by Goddes awne mouth, whiche calleth theim fooles, because thei vse the selfes, here in this life, so like fooles.
column8: All such men that thus lives, and so dieth, be created fools by Gods awn mouth, which calls them fools, because they use the selves, here in this life, so like fools.

column7: Thei liue fooles, thei shall die fooles (except thei repent) and shall arise again fooles: and shall go to their iudgemet fooles, and after that, thei shal go to the deuill, like fooles as thei be.
column8: They live fools, they shall die fools (except they repent) and shall arise again fools: and shall go to their iudgemet fools, and after that, they shall go to the devil, like fools as they be.

column7: Men compt now a daies, none fooles but suche as we are fooles cotes, cockes cobes, eares & belles.
column8: Men count now a days, none fools but such as we are fools coats, cocks cobes, ears & bells.

column7: But I feare me, that this manne that our sauiour Christe speaketh of in this Parable, with all those that are like vnto hym in condicios, be more fooles then thei, for all their cockes combes, eares, bables and bel^es.
column8: But I fear me, that this man that our saviour Christe speaks of in this Parable, with all those that are like unto him in condicios, be more fools then they, for all their cocks combes, ears, babbles and bel^es.

column7: What if a man should aske but a questio in a similitude: whether he were worthie to bee called a foole that had in his awne possession of his awne patrimonie, a. M. pound lande, and if that manne hauyng this thousand pound land, would chaunge his thousande pounde of patrimonie, for an hudred shillynges of copie hold lande, onely to haue it ad uoluntatem domini? Were not this man worthie to be called of all me a foole, and worthie to weare a Cockes combe and a bel.
column8: What if a man should ask but a questio in a similitude: whither he were worthy to be called a fool that had in his awn possession of his awn patrimony, a. M. pound land, and if that man having this thousand pound land, would change his thousande pound of patrimony, for and hudred shillings of copy hold land, only to have it ad uoluntatem domini? Were not this man worthy to be called of all me a fool, and worthy to wear a Cocks comb and a bel.

column7: &c. wer he neuer so wise compted.
column8: etc. were he never so wise counted.

column7: Suche fooles almost are al the whole worlde.
column8: Suche fools almost are all the whole world.

column7: Doeth not all the worlde (for the most part) chaunge heauely thynges for yearthly thynges, perpetuall thynges, for transitorie thynges, the life euerlasting, for this preset life.
column8: Doth not all the world (for the most part) change heavily things for yearthly things, perpetual things, for transitory things, the life everlasting, for this preset life.

column7: Is not this foole as wise as thei?
column8: Is not this fool as wise as they?

column7: What will ye make of a foole, or how will ye discerne or knowe a foole, but by that he doth like a foole, and as no wise ma would doo, he will not geue his bable for a Kynges raund some, he knoweth not what is good & what is euill.
column8: What will you make of a fool, or how will you discern or know a fool, but by that he does like a fool, and as no wise ma would do, he will not give his babble for a Kings rand some, he knoweth not what is good & what is evil.

column7: He wil leaue the best and chose the worst.
column8: He will leave the best and chosen the worst.

column7: He knoweth not (as the Prouerbe saieth) chese from chalke, and therfore he is iudged a foole, and is a foole in deede, and if he neuer ware wiser, he shall die a foole in very deede.
column8: He knoweth not (as the Proverb sayeth) cheese from chalk, and therefore he is judged a fool, and is a fool in deed, and if he never beware wiser, he shall die a fool in very deed.

column7: Now I pray you, do not thei, that receiue goodes, richesse, honors, offices, and promocious of this worlde, & either abuse them, or be vnthankfull to god for the and so for these vncertein & vnstable goodes, riches, honors, offices and promocions of this false flattryng world, do for lacke of godly wisedom and takyng hede here in tyme, lose euerlastyng, sure and permanent, goodes, richesse, honors, offices and promocios.
column8: Now I pray you, do not they, that receive goods, richesse, honours, offices, and promocious of this world, & either abuse them, or be unthankful to god for thee and so for these uncertain & unstable goods, riches, honours, offices and promotions of this false flattering world, do for lack of godly wisdom and taking heed here in time, loose everlasting, sure and permanent, goods, richesse, honours, offices and promocios.

column7: Be not these thinke ye, those that the mouth of God, doth openly, plainly, & sharpely here in this place cal fooles? yes truly, & shalbe serued like fooles, as the coclusion, & knittyng vp of this aforesaid parable of our sauior Christ doth plainly & vndoubtedly pronouce and declare to all maner of persones, none excepted: saiyng.
column8: Be not these think you, those that the mouth of God, does openly, plainly, & sharply here in this place call fools? yes truly, & shall served like fools, as the coclusion, & knitting up of this aforesaid parable of our saviour Christ does plainly & undoubtedly pronounce and declare to all manner of persons, none excepted: saying.

column7: So it is with him, that gathereth riches to himself, and is not riche towardes god.
column8: So it is with him, that gathereth riches to himself, and is not rich towards god.

column7: Heare the mouthe of truthe, yea, the truth it self pronounceth, what shall come of all suche as abuse, and be vnthankfull to God for suche thynges, and vncharitable to their neighbors, with their goodes, richesse, honours, offices, and promocions of this world, and regard not suche thynges, as bee prepared for good and godly men, in the world that is to come.
column8: Hear the mouth of truth, yea, the truth it self pronounceth, what shall come of all such as abuse, and be unthankful to God for such things, and uncharitable to their neighbours, with their goods, richesse, honours, offices, and promotions of this world, and regard not such things, as be prepared for good and godly men, in the world that is to come.

column7: I would fain if it wer possible, sette furthe some thyng, before these worldly wise mennes iyes, that thei might clerely se their awne state, that thei bee here in, in this present worlde.
column8: I would fain if it were possible, set forth some thing, before these worldly wise men's eyes, that they might clearly see their awn state, that they be here in, in this present world.

column7: I cannot imagine how better to shewe them their state, (if it be not rather worthy to be called a fall) then to copare their whole life, to men that dreame, pleasaunt and profitable dremes, and do thinke themselfes, for the tyme so well, as thei can imagin them selfes, that thei cannot be better, and so long as that swete slepe dooth continue, so long are thei (as thei imagin) mooste happie.
column8: I cannot imagine how better to show them their state, (if it be not rather worthy to be called a fallen) then to copare their whole life, to men that dream, pleasant and profitable dreams, and do think themselves, for the time so well, as they can imagine them selves, that they cannot be better, and so long as that sweet sleep doth continue, so long are they (as they imagine) most happy.

column7: But when thei awake out of that dreame, and perceiue al the matter, to bee turned to a dreamyng matter, all that their felicitie, is turned to misery, all their ioye, is turned to sorowe, and so to conclude, al thyng is turned topsie turuie.
column8: But when they awake out of that dream, and perceive all the matter, to be turned to a dreaming matter, all that their felicity, is turned to misery, all their joy, is turned to sorrow, and so to conclude, all thing is turned topsy turuie.

column7: Truly, truly, if the worldly mynded manne, whose hart, mynd and al, is set vpo worldly thynges, his state, the ende considered is euen like the state of a dreamer, or a dreamyng man, that is in the middes of his pleasaunt & profitable dreames.
column8: Truly, truly, if the worldly minded man, whose heart, mind and all, is set upon worldly things, his state, the end considered is even like the state of a dreamer, or a dreaming man, that is in the mids of his pleasant & profitable dreams.

column7: He thynketh all is well, and he hath al thinges after his awne hartes lust, and supposeth all thynges so to continue.
column8: He thinketh all is well, and he hath all things after his awn hearts lust, and supposeth all things so to continue.

column7: But alacke alacke, he is farre deceiued, euen as a dremyng man is.
column8: But alack alack, he is far deceived, even as a dremyng man is.

column7: For when God shall take suche men, from this vain and dreamyng life, then shal thei, truly se and perceiue, with their awne greate hurte, because thei will not consider it in tyme, that al was as vain, as vain dreames, that thei tooke for bothe stable and profitable, which doeth but make fooles fain for a tyme.
column8: For when God shall take such men, from this vain and dreaming life, then shall they, truly see and perceive, with their awn great hurt, because they will not consider it in time, that all was as vain, as vain dreams, that they took for both stable and profitable, which doth but make fools fain for a time.

column7: Therefore I would aduise, all suche worldly men to bee wise in tyme, and to cosider what Ecclesiastes teacheth them in the.xij. Chapiter of his boke, saiyng: Vanitas uanitatum (dixit Ecclesiastes) & oiauanitas. Ecclesiastes saieth, he can see nothyng here in this world, but all was vanitie, vanitie, vanitie, fondnesse, fondnesse, foolishenesse, foolishenesse.
column8: Therefore I would advise, all such worldly men to be wise in time, and to consider what Ecclesiastes teaches them in the xij Chapter of his book, saying: Vanitas uanitatum (dixit Ecclesiastes) & oiauanitas. Ecclesiastes sayeth, he can see nothing here in this world, but all was vanity, vanity, vanity, fondness, fondness, foolishenesse, foolishenesse.

column7: Now what is all your greate richesse, high honours offices and promocions?
column8: Now what is all your great richesse, high honours offices and promotions?

column7: Are not all vanities.
column8: Are not all vanities.

column7: When your dreamyng tyme is out, ye shal then truly perceiue the to bee verie vanities.
column8: When your dreaming time is out, you shall then truly perceive thee to be very vanities.

column7: Yea, and worse then vanities, if either ye abuse them, or be vnthankfull to God for the, and help not your neighbors with the, thei shalbe vnto you dampnable vanities.
column8: Yea, and worse then vanities, if either you abuse them, or be unthankful to God for thee, and help not your neighbours with thee, they shall unto you damnable vanities.

column7: Now I beseche god for his great mercies sake, to geue vnto all me grace, to vse well their riches, high honors, offices and promocions, and to be thankfull to god for them, and charitable to their neighbors with them.
column8: Now I beseech god for his great mercies sake, to give unto all me grace, to use well their riches, high honours, offices and promotions, and to be thankful to god for them, and charitable to their neighbours with them.

column7: And so to vse these thynges (whiche of the selfes if thei be abused) bee but vanities, to vse the (I saie) as instrumentes, wherby thei may please god, & profite their neighbors, and make the here frendes by the right vsing of these worldly vanities, whiche maie receiue them into euerlastyng habitacions.
column8: And so to use these things (which of the selves if they be abused) bee but vanities, to use the (I say) as instruments, whereby they may please god, & profit their neighbours, and make the here friends by the right using of these worldly vanities, which may receive them into everlasting habitations.

column7: Now here I haue shewed you of suche riche me, as are riche to themselfes, & not to God, Better it wer for theim to be warned here in tyme, then to tary to log, vntil thei for lacke of warnyng come to hel, where warnyng will not serue.
column8: Now here I have showed you of such rich me, as are rich to themselves, & not to God, Better it were for them to be warned here in time, then to tarry to log, until they for lack of warning come to hell, where warning will not serve.

column7: As it chaunced vnto this riche man, of who ye now shall heare, in this Parable folowyng, whiche is now for lacke of takyng hede in tyme: dapned in hell, & fain would haue remedy, but because he seketh it to late, none wilbe found.
column8: As it chanced unto this rich man, of who you now shall hear, in this Parable following, which is now for lack of taking heed in time: dapned in hell, & fain would have remedy, but because he seeketh it to late, none will found.

column7: & Here endeth the secod part of this Sermon.
column8: & Here endeth the secod part of this Sermon.

column7: N Owe to the Parable.
column8: Now Now to the Parable.

column7: There was a certain riche ma, which was clothed in Purple & fine white, & fared delicioufly euery day, & there was a begger named Lazarus, whiche lay at his gate full of sores, desiryng to be refreshed with ye cromes whiche fell fro the riche mans borde, & no man gaue vnto hym.
column8: There was a certain rich ma, which was clothed in Purple & fine white, & fared delicioufly every day, & there was a beggar nam Lazarus, which lay at his gate full of sores, desiring to be refreshed with you cromes which fell from the rich men board, & no man gave unto him.

column7: The Dogges came also, & licked his sores.
column8: The Dogs came also, & licked his sores.

column7: Here, in the beginnyng of this parable, Christ did set furthe to the Iewes, to whom he preached then, and no lesse to vs, to who this his doctrine is preached now two me, of the which, one was a riche man, and the other a poore begger, by the whiche twoo, he setteth furthe by antithesin, the felicitie of this worlde in thone, and the misery of this world in the other.
column8: Here, in the beginning of this parable, Christ did set forth to the Jewes, to whom he preached then, and no less to us, to who this his doctrine is preached now two me, of the which, one was a rich man, and the other a poor beggar, by the which twoo, he sets forth by antithesin, the felicity of this world in thone, and the misery of this world in the other.

column7: That is, in this riche ma is set furthe, the life that is compted onely happie in this worlde.
column8: That is, in this rich ma is set forth, the life that is counted only happy in this world.

column7: In the poore man, is set furth the life, that is compted moste vnhappie, and miserable in this worlde.
column8: In the poor man, is set forth the life, that is counted most unhappy, and miserable in this world.

column7: First, let vs cosider earnestly, the state of these twoo men, beyng bothe here in this worlde: and also their states in the world to come.
column8: First, let us consider earnestly, the state of these twoo men, being both here in this world: and also their states in the world to come.

column7: These thynges are to bee considered earnestly of vs, euen now while tyme is, lest perchaunce we deferre it, til it be to late, as this riche man did, as ye maie well consider in this Parable.
column8: These things are to be considered earnestly of us, even now while time is, lest perchance we defer it, till it be to late, as this rich man did, as you may well consider in this Parable.

column7: Here we maie learne also to consider not thynges that be onely present, but rather thendes of al thynges.
column8: Here we may learn also to consider not things that be only present, but rather thendes of all things.

column7: The life of the riche manne was compted best, and the poore mannes life worste, but the ende sheweth farre otherwise.
column8: The life of the rich man was counted best, and the poor man's life worst, but the end shows far otherwise.

column7: Let vs not folowe the fashion and maner of men of this worlde, whiche care litle for the ende, so that thei now maie haue the pleasaunt life, that this rich man had, nothyng at all consideryng the ende, what chaunced vnto hym after this life was past.
column8: Let us not follow the fashion and manner of men of this world, which care little for the end, so that they now may have the pleasant life, that this rich man had, nothing at all considering the end, what chanced unto him after this life was passed.

column7: This aforesaied man, is named here riche, & was riche in deede, and was compted happie and fortunate, for he lacked nothyng, whiche belonged to leade a pleasaunt life withall.
column8: This aforesaid man, is nam here rich, & was rich in deed, and was counted happy and fortunate, for he lacked nothing, which belonged to lead a pleasant life withal.

column7: He was clothed in Purple, and fine white, and fared deliciously euery daie.
column8: He was clothed in Purple, and fine white, and fared deliciously every day.

column7: In these two thynges, that is, in costly and precious raiment, and delicate fare, is comprehended al thinges, that are to this present life, either pleasaunt or delectable.
column8: In these two things, that is, in costly and precious raiment, and delicate fare, is comprehended all things, that are to this present life, either pleasant or delectable.

column7: Vnder these twoo kyndes, that is, purple & white, is comprehended, all maner of costly and sumpteous apparel, whether it be linen, or wollen.
column8: Under these twoo kinds, that is, purple & white, is comprehended, all manner of costly and sumptuous apparel, whither it be linen, or woollen.

column7: And by these wordes he fared deliciously euery daie, is vnderstande, that he had abundance of al costly and delicate meates and drinkes We rede not here, that this riche man was condempned in hell, for his costly raiment, and his delicate fare, but that he hauyng suche abundance of theim bothe, could not finde in his hart, that poore Lazarus should haue any parte with hym.
column8: And by these words he fared deliciously every day, is understand, that he had abundance of all costly and delicate meats and drinks We rede not here, that this rich man was condemned in hell, for his costly raiment, and his delicate fare, but that he having such abundance of them both, could not find in his heart, that poor Lazarus should have any part with him.

column7: All thei that are costly arayed, and fare delicatly, are not condepned, so that thei kepe theim within their limites and boundes, and forgette not theim that lacke, euen their castraimet, and their scrappes also of their table.
column8: All they that are costly arrayed, and fare delicately, are not condemned, so that they keep them within their limits and bounds, and forget not them that lack, even their castraimet, and their scraps also of their table.

column7: Here are codempned onely thei, that are to theimselfes to liberall, yea, to prodigall, bothe in raimet and fare, regardyng not, what thei spende vpon theimselfes, painperyng vp their awne bodies, & in the meane season, are altogether vnliberall, and starke nigardes to the poore and nedy and can finde in their hartes, to se the die at their gates, bothe for hunger and also for cold.
column8: Here are codempned only they, that are to themselves to liberal, yea, to prodigal, both in raimet and fare, regarding not, what they spend upon themselves, painperyng up their awn bodies, & in the mean season, are altogether unliberal, and stark niggards to the poor and needy and can find in their hearts, to see the die at their gates, both for hunger and also for cold.

column7: Thus did this riche manne, to the poore begger Lazarus: therfore he is in hel for his labor.
column8: Thus did this rich man, to the poor beggar Lazarus: therefore he is in hell for his labour.

column7: And what learne we by this riche mannes doyng, but to bewart, lest wee doyng like, shall haue like, euen as he hath.
column8: And what learn we by this rich man's doing, but to bewart, lest we doing like, shall have like, even as he hath.

column7: For, therfore is this rich man set here to teache vs to be ware by his exaple.
column8: For, therefore is this rich man set here to teach us to be aware by his example.

column7: Here I saie, euery manne muste kepe himself, within his limites and boundes, and so there shalbe no man dampned, either for rayment, or for costly fare, so that men bee beneficiall to the poore.
column8: Here I say, every man must keep himself, within his limits and bounds, and so there shall no man dampened, either for raiment, or for costly fare, so that men be beneficial to the poor.

column7: But boudes be broken, limites be ouer trode, there is almoste no persone that kepeth hymself within his limites or boundes: there is almost no man, that can be cotent with his awne state, neither in raimet, nor yet in fare.
column8: But boudes be broken, limits be over trodden, there is almost no person that keepeth himself within his limits or bounds: there is almost no man, that can be content with his awn state, neither in raimet, nor yet in fare.

column7: The yeoman will approche to the getlemannes state, the gentleman to the knightes state, the knight to the lords state, and so furth on: and not onely in raiment, but also in fare.
column8: The yeoman will approach to the getlemannes state, the gentleman to the knights state, the knight to the lords state, and so forth on: and not only in raiment, but also in fare.

column7: And that see the seruauntes, and thei passe their degree also: and so euery man is out of order.
column8: And that see the servants, and they pass their degree also: and so every man is out of order.

column7: O that men would be content, to fare and go, euery man after his degree, and beware of climyng.
column8: O that men would be content, to fare and go, every man after his degree, and beware of climbing.

column7: And also if euery man would beware of excesse in all thynges, the pouerties nedes might bee releued in all thynges.
column8: And also if every man would beware of excess in all things, the poverties needs might be relieved in all things.

column7: For there is more spet in superfluous raiment, and superfluous fare (I holde my peace from superfluous gamyng, and superfluous giftes geuyng) in Englande, then would serue to the necessities, of the very nedy of al Englande.
column8: For there is more spet in superfluous raiment, and superfluous fare (I hold my peace from superfluous gaming, and superfluous gifts giving) in Englande, then would serve to the necessities, of the very needy of all Englande.

column7: Nowe yet a litle to the texte.
column8: Now yet a little to the text.

column7: There is a certain riche man.
column8: There is a certain rich man.

column7: &c. We reade not that this riche manne, gatte his goodes euil, but he bothe kept the euill, and spent them not well.
column8: etc. We read not that this rich man, gat his goods evil, but he both kept the evil, and spent them not well.

column7: I rede not, that he was a bribe taker, nor an extorcioner, nor a ret raiser, nor a fine taker, nor a leasemonger, nor an vsurer, nor a piller, or poller of the poore, nor a false purchaser.
column8: I rede not, that he was a bribe taker, nor and extortioner, nor a rest raiser, nor a fine taker, nor a leasemonger, nor and usurer, nor a pillar, or poller of the poor, nor a false purchaser.
