column7: In suma, I rede not that he gatte his goodes euil, but that he spent theim all vpon his awne persone, and after his awne pleasure, and not vpo the poore, after the pleasure of God.
column8: In suma, I rede not that he gat his goods evil, but that he spent them all upon his awn person, and after his awn pleasure, and not upon the poor, after the pleasure of God.

column7: The text saith, this man was riche, but it was to hymself, and to the world, and altogether after the worldly estimacio, and alone afore the worlde and worldly men, but he was a very miser and poore begger, before God and all godly men.
column8: The text says, this man was rich, but it was to himself, and to the world, and altogether after the worldly estimacio, and alone afore the world and worldly men, but he was a very miser and poor beggar, before God and all godly men.

column7: Here ye haue heard of this rich man, in what felicitie and pleasure, he ledde his life, how that he was compted happie and fortunate, emong all other here, and as he liued honourably, so he died to the world honorably, and was buried honorably.
column8: Here you have herd of this rich man, in what felicity and pleasure, he led his life, how that he was counted happy and fortunate, among all other here, and as he lived honourably, so he died to the world honorably, and was buried honorably.

column7: All his life was honorable, euen vnto the very graue, but to what honor he came afterward beyng dedde ye shall heare hereafter.
column8: All his life was honourable, even unto the very graven, but to what honour he came afterwards being dead you shall hear hereafter.

column7: First, ye shal heare of the poore begger Lazarus life howe miserably he liued, in a worldly respect: as it foloweth in the text.
column8: First, you shall hear of the poor beggar Lazarus life how miserably he lived, in a worldly respect: as it followeth in the text.

column7: And there was a certein begger, named Lazarus, whiche laie at his gate full of sores, desiryng to be refreshed with the cromes, whiche fel from the riche mannes borde, and no man gaue vnto hym, the dogges came also and licked his sores.
column8: And there was a certain beggar, nam Lazarus, which lay at his gate full of sores, desiring to be refreshed with the cromes, which fell from the rich man's board, and no man gave unto him, the dogs came also and licked his sores.

column7: Nowe herken here of this poore beggers life.
column8: Now harken here of this poor beggars life.

column7: There was a certain begger named Lazarus, a man as farre drouned in miserie, as the riche man was in felicitie: this manne was not onely poore and a begger, but also a miserable begger, as far out of monnes reputacion, as the riche man was in estimacio.
column8: There was a certain beggar nam Lazarus, a man as far drowned in misery, as the rich man was in felicity: this man was not only poor and a beggar, but also a miserable beggar, as far out of monnes reputation, as the rich man was in estimacio.

column7: This man was as poore in lackyng, as the other was riche in hauyng.
column8: This man was as poor in lacking, as the other was rich in having.

column7: This man lacked, euen verie necessaries, where as the other abunded in superfluousnes.
column8: This man lacked, even very necessaries, where as the other abunded in superfluousnes.

column7: This miser (as the worlde taketh misers) had neither house nor home, neither coate nor goune, he lacked neither sores nor huger, who would not saie, that he was moste vnhappie of all other, that euer liued in the worlde?
column8: This miser (as the world takes misers) had neither house nor home, neither coat nor gown, he lacked neither sores nor huger, who would not say, that he was most unhappy of all other, that ever lived in the world?

column7: Who would saie that doth cosider, bothe these mennes lifes, that is to say, this riche mannes life, & the poore beggers life, but that the riche manne was euen a verie paterne, full of felicitie, and the begger a paterne of very misery.
column8: Who would say that does consider, both these men's life's, that is to say, this rich man's life, & the poor beggars life, but that the rich man was even a very pattern, full of felicity, and the beggar a pattern of very misery.

column7: Thone was riche, the other a beggar and poore, the one had abundance of all thynges and the other the lacke of all thynges.
column8: Thone was rich, the other a beggar and poor, the one had abundance of all things and the other the lack of all things.

column7: The one had to many houses, & the other neuer a one. Thone had to much meate and drinke, and the other neuer a whit.
column8: The one had to many houses, & the other never a one. Thone had to much meat and drink, and the other never a whit.

column7: The one was sound and mery and the other sicke and sorie.
column8: The one was found and merry and the other sick and sorry.

column7: The one was all to well clothed: and the other all together naked.
column8: The one was all to well clothed: and the other all together naked.

column7: Here a man maie se a liuely exaple of worldly felicitie & of worldly misery.
column8: Here a man may see a lively example of worldly felicity & of worldly misery.

column7: What man seyng & consideryng, bothe these menes lifes, but would saie, thone wer altogether happie, & thother altogether vnhappy The state of this riche man is highly estemed, with all that be but men, and a lonely worldly men, and yet it is nothyng lesse, then so estemed of God, & godly men.
column8: What man sing & considering, both these menes life's, but would say, thone were altogether happy, & tother altogether unhappy The state of this rich man is highly esteemed, with all that be but men, and a lonely worldly men, and yet it is nothing less, then so esteemed of God, & godly men.

column7: As our sauior Christ saith in Luke.xvi. chap. That that is highly estemed emogmen: is abhominable in the sight of god.
column8: As our saviour Christ says in Luke xvi chap. That that is highly esteemed emogmen: is abominable in the sighed of god.

column7: He saith not onely it is litle or lightly set by, in the sight of God, but it is abhominable in the sight of god.
column8: He says not only it is little or lightly set by, in the sighed of God, but it is abominable in the sighed of god.

column7: Marke here, that all honors, all dignities, all promocions, all offices, & al riches, whiche, although thei be neuer so highly estemed in the worlde of worldly men: if thei bee not rightly vsed, vnto the honor of God, and charitably ordered, to the commoditie and wealthe of Goddes people, the state of theim that possesse theim: although it bee in the sight of menne, highly estemed and honourable, in the sight of GOD and Godly menne, is bothe horrible & abhominable.
column8: Mark here, that all honours, all dignities, all promotions, all offices, & all riches, which, although they be never so highly esteemed in the world of worldly men: if they be not rightly used, unto the honour of God, and charitably ordered, to the commodity and wealth of Goddes people, the state of them that possess them: although it be in the sighed of men, highly esteemed and honourable, in the sighed of GOD and Godly men, is both horrible & abominable.

column7: What shall wee then saie?
column8: What shall we then say?

column7: Shall thynges of this present worlde, continue still in their estimacion, in another world also, as menne esteme theim here, whether thei bee good or bad?
column8: Shall things of this present world, continue still in their estimation, in another world also, as men esteem them here, whither they be good or bad?

column7: This matter is clerely set furthe, to all mennes iyes that will see, in this present Parable, of this riche manne, and poore Lazarus.
column8: This matter is clearly set forth, to all men's eyes that will see, in this present Parable, of this rich man, and poor Lazarus.

column7: Consider the ende of those twoo persones, and then ye shall see, and that euidently, that the matter is farre otherwise.
column8: Consider the end of those twoo persons, and then you shall see, and that evidently, that the matter is far otherwise.

column7: Sodeinly, death comming, turneth ye matter vpside doune.
column8: Suddenly, death coming, turns you matter upside down.

column7: Death commyng to the riche man, maketh an ende of all his felicitie & pleasure, wherin he was thought to be so happie.
column8: Death coming to the rich man, makes and end of all his felicity & pleasure, wherein he was thought to be so happy.

column7: Death on the other side, commyng to this poore man, is the ende of all sorowes and miseries.
column8: Death on the other side, coming to this poor man, is the end of all sorrows and misery's.

column7: O that the world, whiche is so blinded in worldly vanities: would cosider this thyng bothe hartly and earnesty.
column8: O that the world, which is so blinded in worldly vanities: would consider this thing both heartily and earnesty.

column7: Then men should not be so forgetful, and so litle remember the state, that is to come in another worlde.
column8: Then men should not be so forgetful, and so little remember the state, that is to come in another world.

column7: It is not for naught, that that good man, Iesus the sonne of Siracke in his boke, whiche is called Ecclesiasticus, in the.vij. Chapit. doth warne euery man of this thyng, saiyng: Sonne, remeber thy last ende, and thou shalt neuer doo amisse.
column8: It is not for nought, that that good man, Jesus the son of Siracke in his book, which is called Ecclesiasticus, in the vij Chapit. does warn every man of this thing, saying: Son, remember thy last end, and thou shalt never do amiss.

column7: The lacke of this remembrance in tyme, is the cause, that so many menne go to the deuill.
column8: The lack of this remembrance in time, is the cause, that so many men go to the devil.

column7: If that we would, earnestly and often remeber, what is to come in another worlde, after this present life, we should neuer so forget, (as we now doo) neither our duetie to God, nor yet to our neighbour.
column8: If that we would, earnestly and often remember, what is to come in another world, after this present life, we should never so forget, (as we now do) neither our duty to God, nor yet to our neighbour.

column7: We should not set so muche by worldly vanities as we do: we should not so lightly regard heauenly and eternall thynges, and so highly esteme worldly thynges as we do.
column8: We should not set so much by worldly vanities as we do: we should not so lightly regard heavenly and eternal things, and so highly esteem worldly things as we do.

column7: Remember therfore thy last ende, and what thy state shalbee after this present life.
column8: Remember therefore thy last end, and what thy state shalbe after this present life.

column7: Remember (I saie, yea, bothe earnestly and ofte, and that remembraunce shall cause thee to exchue vice, and to folowe and embrace vertue.
column8: Remember (I say, yea, both earnestly and oft, and that remembrance shall cause thee to exchue vice, and to follow and embrace virtue.

column7: Beware by thexample of this riche man, whiche delighted and had somuche pleasure, that he thought not once of deathe, and of his state after deathe.
column8: Beware by example of this rich man, which delighted and had somuch pleasure, that he thought not once of death, and of his state after death.

column7: And therefore is he nowe, (although to late) taught with his awne dampnacion, to teache other in tyme, by his example, the waie to saluacion.
column8: And therefore is he now, (although to late) taught with his awn damnation, to teach other in time, by his example, the way to salvation.

column7: He was so full of richesse, that he had no regard to pouertie.
column8: He was so full of richesse, that he had no regard to poverty.

column7: He had somuch wealth, that he regarded nothyng at all poore mennes miserie.
column8: He had somuch wealth, that he regarded nothing at all poor men's misery.

column7: Poore Lazarus desired no deinties, but onely to releue his hunger, with the cromes or scrappes, that were lefte at this riche manne's table, but no man gaue vnto him.
column8: Poor Lazarus desired no dainties, but only to relieve his hunger, with the cromes or scraps, that were left at this rich manne's table, but no man gave unto him.

column7: By like there was an vncharitable house, that neither one nor other, could finde in his harte, to geue this begger some almose.
column8: By like there was and uncharitable house, that neither one nor other, could find in his heart, to give this beggar some almose.

column7: I doubt not, but euery manne within the dores had to muche, eue dogges and all.
column8: I doubt not, but every man within the doors had to much, eve dogs and all.

column7: But there was nothyng without the doores, for the poore nedy and hungrie, but hunger and small ease.
column8: But there was nothing without the doors, for the poor needy and hungry, but hunger and small ease.

column7: Yea, the very dogges were more mercifull, then either their maister, or maistres, or houshold for thei delte their almose vpon hym.
column8: Yea, the very dogs were more merciful, then either their master, or masters, or household for they dealt their almose upon him.

column7: The dogges (saith the text) came and licked his sores.
column8: The dogs (says the text) came and licked his sores.

column7: Suche maister, suche seruauntes, is commonly sene.
column8: Suche master, such servants, is commonly seen.

column7: This man was altogether liberall, yea, prodigall vpon hymself and his, after his awne luste and pleasure: but concernyng the poore nedy, and Goddes lust and pleasure, he was eue a very starke nigard.
column8: This man was altogether liberal, yea, prodigal upon himself and his, after his awn lust and pleasure: but concerning the poor needy, and Goddes lust and pleasure, he was eve a very stark niggard.

column7: Well, this man liued here all in his felicitie, and so did poore Lazarus, euen in his miserie.
column8: Well, this man lived here all in his felicity, and so did poor Lazarus, even in his misery.

column7: But nowe commeth death (as I haue saied) and turneth all topsie turuie.
column8: But now comes death (as I have said) and turns all topsy turuie.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: And it fortuned, that the begger died, and was caried by the angels into Abrahams bosome.
column8: And it fortuned, that the beggar died, and was carried by the angels into Abrahams bosom.

column7: It chauced (saieth the texte) that the begger died.
column8: It chanced (sayeth the text) that the beggar died.

column7: That begger (I saie) that no ma regarded whiles he liued, but god shewed howe muche he regarded hym, in that that his angelles brought him in to Abrahams bosome.
column8: That beggar (I say) that no ma regarded while he lived, but god showed how much he regarded him, in that that his angels brought him in to Abrahams bosom.

column7: The riche man wold not once vouchsafe, to take hym into his house, to releue hym, but god doth vouchsafe to take hym, to suche a place, where is euerlastyng felicitie & glory.
column8: The rich man would not once vouchsafe, to take him into his house, to relieve him, but god does vouchsafe to take him, to such a place, where is everlasting felicity & glory.

column7: Let vs consider, what maner of departing had Lazarus fro this world Death to this good and godly begger yea, to all godly men, is a greate benefite.
column8: Let us consider, what manner of departing had Lazarus from this world Death to this good and godly beggar yea, to all godly men, is a great benefit.

column7: For it deliuereth all suche, from innumerable euils, eue as it wer men that had been long in a sharpe prison, from greate affliccion, to great refreshyng.
column8: For it delivereth all such, from innumerable evils, eve as it were men that had been long in a sharp prison, from great affliction, to great refreshing.

column7: Therefore it is no pein nor miserie, for a good and godly man to die.
column8: Therefore it is no pein nor misery, for a good and godly man to die.

column7: For to hym death is the very way and passage, to euerlastyng ioye and high felicitie.
column8: For to him death is the very way and passage, to everlasting joy and high felicity.

column7: This poore man is ded (saith the text). He is ded I graunt, but not so dedde, or with suche a death, as the wicked men vse to die, but after another fashion, of the whiche the holy man Iob, the.
column8: This poor man is dead (says the text). He is dead I grant, but not so dead, or with such a death, as the wicked men use to die, but after another fashion, of the which the holy man Job, the.

column7: Lxvi Chap. speaketh on saiyng: The death of his sainctes (saith he) is very precious in the lordes sight This poore Lazarus soule was caried, not of one Angell, but of many saieth the text.
column8: Lxvi Chap. speaks on saying: The death of his saints (says he) is very precious in the lords sighed This poor Lazarus soul was carried, not of one Angel, but of many sayeth the text.

column7: Whether did thei cary it?
column8: Whither did they carry it?

column7: Into Abrahams bosome, that is, in to euerlastyng ioye & rest in the lorde.
column8: Into Abrahams bosom, that is, in to everlasting joy & rest in the lord.

column7: Whiche place, some men call Paradise, after Christes saiyng to the thefe hangyng on his right hand, whiche desired hym, to haue hym in his remembraunce, whe he should come into his kyngdome, Luke.xxiij. where Christe saith vnto him: this daie shalt thou be with me in Paradise.
column8: Which place, some men call Paradise, after Christes saying to the thief hanging on his right hand, which desired him, to have him in his remembrance, when he should come into his kingdom, Lycia xxiij where Christe says unto him: this day shalt thou be with me in Paradise.

column7: Some call this place the hande of the Lorde, as it is written in the.iij. Chap. of the boke of Sapiece.
column8: Some call this place the hand of the Lord, as it is written in the iij Chap. of the book of Sapience.

column7: The soules of the righteous are in the hande of the Lorde.
column8: The souls of the righteous are in the hand of the Lord.

column7: Marke here, that although mencion is made, that the soules of good, godly, & righteous persones, be safe enough, either in Abrahams bosome, in Paradise, in the hande of the Lorde, or in heauen.
column8: Mark here, that although mention is made, that the souls of good, godly, & righteous persons, be safe enough, either in Abrahams bosom, in Paradise, in the hand of the Lord, or in heaven.

column7: And I doubte not but that thei haue, suche glory and felicitie: as.
column8: And I doubt not but that they have, such glory and felicity: as.

column7: S. Paule to the Cori. speaketh of in the.i. Epistle the.ij. Chap. saiyng, that mannes iye hath not seen, and theare hath not heard, neither haue entered into the hart of man, the thynges whiche God hath prepared for them that loue him.
column8: S. Paule to the Cori. speaks of in the i Epistle the ij Chap. saying, that man's lie hath not seen, and there hath not herd, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him.

column7: But to tell you what glory thei haue what thei do, and where thei be: I can nomore tel, then the scripture telleth.
column8: But to tell you what glory they have what they do, and where they be: I can nomore tell, then the scripture telleth.

column7: I let God alone with all suche secretes, as Christe, his Apostles, and the prophetes, hath not reueled and made manifest to vs in holy scripture.
column8: I let God alone with all such secrets, as Christe, his Apostles, and the prophets, hath not revealed and made manifest to us in holy scripture.

column7: Now I doubt not but Abrahames bosome, is the place wherin all the elected and chosen of God, whiche doo truely folowe Abrahams faith, do rest in.
column8: Now I doubt not but Abrahames bosom, is the place wherein all the elected and chosen of God, which do truly follow Abrahams faith, do rest in.

column7: But nowe where that place is, I knowe not, and therfore I will not go about to determyne a thyng that I knowe not.
column8: But now where that place is, I know not, and therefore I will not go about to determine a thing that I know not.

column7: Lette vs not bee muche carefull, where that place is, but rather let vs bee carefull, how wee shall come thether.
column8: Let us not be much careful, where that place is, but rather let us be careful, how we shall come thither.

column7: There was neuer time, but that God had appoyncted a place for his elected to rest in.
column8: There was never time, but that God had appointed a place for his elected to rest in.

column7: Afore Christes commyng, that place was called, the bosome of Abraham: but now it is called heauen, the house of the eternall father, as.
column8: Afore Christes coming, that place was called, the bosom of Abraham: but now it is called heaven, the house of the eternal father, as.

column7: S. Paule witnesseth in his.ij Epistle, the.v. Chap to the Cori. For we knowe (saieth he) that if our yearthy mansion of this dwellyng wer destroyed, we haue a buyldyng of God, an habitacion, not made with handes but eternall in heauen.
column8: S. Paule witnesseth in his ij Epistle, the v Chap to the Cori. For we know (sayeth he) that if our yearthy mansion of this dwelling were destroyed, we have a building of God, and habitation, not made with hands but eternal in heaven.

column7: Also Christ in Iho.xiiij. speakyng of the same thyng, saieth: In my fathers house there bee many dwellyng places.
column8: Also Christ in Iho xiiij speaking of the same thing, sayeth: In my father's house there be many dwelling places.

column7: And the same Christ safeth also in Ihou.xii. Where I am (saith he) there shal my minister bee also.
column8: And the same Christ safeth also in Ihou xii Where I am (says he) there shall my minister be also.

column7: Paule also in his Epistle to the Philippians the.i. Cha. Desireth to bee losed, and to bee with Christe.
column8: Paule also in his Epistle to the Philippians the i Cha. Desires to be losed, and to be with Christe.

column7: Now here ye haue hard thende of this poore begger, beyng righteous before God, what came to hym after his deth and departyng fro his body.
column8: Now here you have hard th'end of this poor beggar, being righteous before God, what came to him after his death and departing from his body.

column7: Although he were of no reputacion before the worlde, yet he was highly regarded before God.
column8: Although he were of no reputation before the world, yet he was highly regarded before God.

column7: In this good poore man, beyng in the sight of God righteous: all good, godly, and righteous poore beggers, and men of small reputacio, make greate comfort, vnto whom the ioye & felicitie of the life to come, shal recompense the sorowe and miserie, that is in this life all comen and past.
column8: In this good poor man, being in the sighed of God righteous: all good, godly, and righteous poor beggars, and men of small reputacio, make great comfort, unto whom the joy & felicity of the life to come, shall recompense the sorrow and misery, that is in this life all come and passed.

column7: Here ye heard of Lazarus death, and what chanced vnto him after his deth.
column8: Here you herd of Lazarus death, and what chanced unto him after his death.

column7: Now shall ye heare of the riche mannes death.
column8: Now shall you hear of the rich man's death.

column7: Why? do suche men die, as well as poore men doo?
column8: Why? do such men die, as well as poor men do?

column7: So well?
column8: So well?

column7: No God knoweth, thei die all doubtles, but how well thei die, and how well cometh to the after their death, marke well this parable, and ye shall know.
column8: No God knoweth, they die all doubtless, but how well they die, and how well comes to the after their death, mark well this parable, and you shall know.

column7: It foloweth in the parable.
column8: It followeth in the parable.

column7: The rich man also died and was buried.
column8: The rich man also died and was buried.

column7: Is he ded in deede?
column8: Is he dead in deed?

column7: How chaunced he died?
column8: How chanced he died?

column7: It was not (I truste) for lacke of clothes?
column8: It was not (I trust) for lack of clothes?

column7: For he had to many.
column8: For he had to many.

column7: It was not for lacke of meate and drynke, for he had to muche.
column8: It was not for lack of meat and drink, for he had to much.

column7: Why? will not gay and costly clothes & delicate meates, kepe men from death?
column8: Why? will not gay and costly clothes & delicate meats, keep men from death?

column7: No, rather I feare me thei help men to death.
column8: No, rather I fear me they help men to death.

column7: Then I se that neither costly araye, nor delicate fare, nor abundaunce of goodes, nor excellencie of dignities, nor greatnes in office, nor yet noblenesse of birthe: will kepe any man from death.
column8: Then I see that neither costly array, nor delicate fare, nor abundance of goods, nor excellency of dignities, nor greatness in office, nor yet nobleness of birth: will keep any man from death.

column7: For as sone dieth the riche man with his riches, and his costly raiment, and with his delicate fare, as the poore manne with his pouertie, course raimet, and homely fare.
column8: For as soon dieth the rich man with his riches, and his costly raiment, and with his delicate fare, as the poor man with his poverty, course raimet, and homely fare.

column7: Assone die thei in dignities and greate Offices, as other that haue none of them bothe.
column8: Assoon die they in dignities and great Offices, as other that have none of them both.

column7: Assone dieth the noble, as the base borne.
column8: Assoon dieth the noble, as the base born.

column7: Assone dieth the Prelate, as the Pulter, as sone dieth the prieste as the clerke.
column8: Assoon dieth the Prelate, as the Pulter, as soon dieth the priest as the clerk.

column7: &c. For as Paule saieth to the Hebrues, ix. Chapiter.
column8: etc. For as Paule sayeth to the Hebrews, ix. Chapter.

column7: It is appoyncted vnto al men, that thei shall once die.
column8: It is appointed unto all men, that they shall once die.

column7: And the olde saiyng is true: There is nothyng more certain then death, but there is nothyng more vncertain, then thoure of death.
column8: And the old saying is true: There is nothing more certain then death, but there is nothing more uncertain, then thoure of death.

column7: Now to the text again.
column8: Now to the text again.

column7: The riche also died.
column8: The rich also died.

column7: &c. Why?
column8: etc. Why?

column7: Is he dedde that promised hymself so long tyme to liue?
column8: Is he dead that promised himself so long time to live?

column7: He is dedde.
column8: He is dead.

column7: But is he dedde in deede?
column8: But is he dead in deed?

column7: Yea truly.
column8: Yea truly.

column7: What shall we then saie? what?
column8: What shall we then say? what?

column7: Mary if he wer, as many of our riche menne be now a daies, I knowe what men bee wont to saie, I would not that thei should so saye.
column8: Mary if he were, as many of our rich men be now a days, I know what men be wont to say, I would not that they should so say.

column7: What (I praie thee) bee thei wont to saie, when suche riche coueteous men die?
column8: What (I pray thee) be they wont to say, when such rich covetous men die?

column7: What?
column8: What?

column7: Euen thus plumpe out.
column8: Euen thus plump out.

column7: The deuill in hell be with theim.
column8: The devil in hell be with them.

column7: Let theim gesse again, if thei had saied so when this riche man died, and had layed any wager on it, it maie fortune thei should haue won.
column8: Let them guess again, if they had said so when this rich man died, and had laid any wager on it, it may fortune they should have wone.

column7: But what shal we saie?
column8: But what shall we say?

column7: God haue mercy on his soule that wer but lost labor.
column8: God have mercy on his soul that were but lost labour.

column7: For God wil haue no mercie vpon theim that be in hell.
column8: For God will have no mercy upon them that be in hell.

column7: For scripture saieth: in hell is no redempcion.
column8: For scripture sayeth: in hell is no redemption.

column7: What shall I saie, God haue mercie on poore Lazarus soule?
column8: What shall I say, God have mercy on poor Lazarus soul?

column7: That also is lost labor, for God hath mercie on him all redy.
column8: That also is lost labour, for God hath mercy on him all ready.

column7: It is now past God haue mercy of all christen soules matter, when men de departed all redy.
column8: It is now past God have mercy of all christian souls matter, when men de departed all ready.

column7: Praie here, and that in time, for to praie when men be ded, it is to late.
column8: Pray here, and that in time, for to pray when men be dead, it is to late.

column7: It foloweth in the text.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: And was buried.
column8: And was buried.

column7: What matter was this, that he was buried.
column8: What matter was this, that he was buried.

column7: It is a matter, for we read nothyng of Lazarus buriyng, and yet I doubte not but that he was buried.
column8: It is a matter, for we read nothing of Lazarus burying, and yet I doubt not but that he was buried.

column7: Here is mencion made of this riche mannes buriyng: by that is signified, that his buriall was like, as al his like was compted, that is moste honorable and I doubt not, but so was his buriall also.
column8: Here is mention made of this rich man's burying: by that is signified, that his burial was like, as all his like was counted, that is most honourable and I doubt not, but so was his burial also.

column7: Moreouer, I doubte not but this riche man, had Diriges, Masses, Trintals, and priestes enough to saie Masses for hym.
column8: Moreover, I doubt not but this rich man, had Diriges, Masses, Trintals, and priests enough to say Masses for him.

column7: He neither lacked singyng nor ringing, chimyng nor tollyng, if suche thynges were vsed in those daies.
column8: He neither lacked singing nor ringing, chimyng nor tolling, if such things were used in those days.

column7: I doubt not but ther wer at his buriall, all the foure orders of Friers, with al the religious men and women, that could bee gotten for money.
column8: I doubt not but there were at his burial, all the foure order of Friars, with all the religious men and women, that could be got for money.

column7: There wer also many mourners with whoodes & blacke gounes, with many a dri^ye more, and so he was brought into the yearth moste honourrably.
column8: There were also many mourners with whoodes & black gounes, with many a dri^ye more, and so he was brought into the earth most honourrably.

column7: But poore Lazarus lacked us more but al this pomp^ and glory * he lacked not euerlastyng glory * had not this riche manne with all his trinkettes, wrought and dooen so honourably, euerlastyng felicitie?
column8: But poor Lazarus lacked us more but all this pomp^ and glory * he lacked not everlasting glory * had not this rich man with all his trinkettes, wrought and done so honourably, everlasting felicity?

column7: Nor, ware that, for that is gotte with * suche tropery But where is he then?
column8: Nor, ware that, for that is got with * such tropery But where is he then?

column7: Where?
column8: Where?

column7: Mary euen where he should be, & where he sought in all his whole life for to be: Where is that?
column8: Mary even where he should be, & where he sought in all his whole life for to be: Where is that?

column7: Euer in hell: for so saieth the text.
column8: Ever in hell: for so sayeth the text.

column7: What man, is al that ringyng and singyng, al that Massyng & dirigyng, with crouchyng and kneelyng, with that bitter weapyng and wailyng, with the Churche hangyng and greate offeryng, al together loste?
column8: What man, is all that ringing and singing, all that Massyng & dirigyng, with crouching and kneeling, with that bitter weeping and wailing, with the Church hanging and great offering, all together lost?

column7: Yea truely; all was lost to hym.
column8: Yea truly; all was lost to him.

column7: For whosoeuer founde aught; he found naught.
column8: For whosoever found aught; he found nought.

column7: Perchaunce ye wil say there were no suche thynges at that tyme, as is now vsed.
column8: Perchance you will say there were no such things at that time, as is now used.

column7: I answere, although there were no suche thynges, at that tyme vsed, yet I doubt not but there was then, as pratie deuices deuised by the Clergie, and receiued of the laitie, as wee haue seen in tymes past, and yet maie se, so that we wil se it.
column8: I answer, although there were no such things, at that time used, yet I doubt not but there was then, as pratie devices devised by the Clergy, and received of the laity, as we have seen in times past, and yet may see, so that we will see it.

column7: See ye not what pratie trickes bee in our this moste knowyng tyme conueighed into the blessed Communion for to get money withall?
column8: See you not what pratie tricks be in our this most knowing time conveyed into the blessed Communion for to get money withal?

column7: Now let vs returne again to this riche man, thus honorably buried, and so semeth vnto vnknowyng people of the worlde, to be in no worse state in another world, then he was in this world.
column8: Now let us return again to this rich man, thus honorably buried, and so seemeth unto unknowing people of the world, to be in no worse state in another world, then he was in this world.

column7: But it wil bee founde farre otherwise, when the truthe is knowen.
column8: But it will be found far otherwise, when the truth is known.

column7: Here endeth the third part of this Sermon.
column8: Here endeth the third part of this Sermon.

column7: IT foloweth in the text: And beyng in hell in tormentes, he lift vp his iyes, and sawe Abraham a farre of, and Lazarus in his bosome, and he cried and said: father Abraham haue mercie on me, and send Lazarus that he maie dippe the tippe of his finger in water, and coole my tongue, for I am tormented in this flambe.
column8: IT followeth in the text: And being in hell in torments, he lift up his eyes, and saw Abraham a far of, and Lazarus in his bosom, and he cried and said: father Abraham have mercy on me, and send Lazarus that he may dip the tip of his finger in water, and cool my tongue, for I am tormented in this flambe.

column7: But Abraham saied: sonne remember that thou in thy life tyme, receiuedest thy pleasure, and contrarywise Lazarus receiued pain, but now he is coforted, and thou art punished.
column8: But Abraham said: son remember that thou in thy life time, receiuedest thy pleasure, and contrariwise Lazarus received pain, but now he is coforted, and thou art punished.

column7: Ye haue heard here afore, how honourably this rich man (to the worlde) led his life, died and was also honorably buried.
column8: You have herd here afore, how honourably this rich man (to the world) led his life, died and was also honorably buried.

column7: Now his honor is turned to horror, his prosperous state, to an vnluckie state.
column8: Now his honour is turned to horror, his prosperous state, to and unlucky state.

column7: He liued here in all delicacie and pleasures, but he leadeth his life now in all miseries and paines.
column8: He lived here in all delicacy and pleasures, but he leads his life now in all misery's and pains.

column7: Let vs consider out of the texte here, in what miserable case this riche man is comen into nowe, after all his felicitie, and pleasure taken in this worlde.
column8: Let us consider out of the text here, in what miserable case this rich man is come into now, after all his felicity, and pleasure taken in this world.

column7: First, he is cast into hell, whiche is a place for the that are perpetually dapned, in whiche place, there is no hope of any deliuery or saluacion.
column8: First, he is cast into hell, which is a place for thee that are perpetually dapned, in which place, there is no hope of any delivery or salvation.

column7: Furthermore, in that helle he is tormenred with firie flambes.
column8: Furthermore, in that hell he is tormenred with firy flames.

column7: We read no lesse written by Esate the Prophete, in his.lxvi. chap. Their wormes (saith he) shal not die, neither shall their fire bee quenched, and all fleshe shall abhorre the.
column8: We read no less written by Esate the Prophet, in his lxvi chap. Their worms (says he) shall not die, neither shall their fire be quenched, and all flesh shall abhor thee.

column7: Christ saieth also in Matthewe.xiij. Chapi.
column8: Christ sayeth also in Matthewe xiij Chapi.

column7: Thei shall cast theim into a furnes of fire, there shalbe wailyng, & gnashing of tethe.
column8: They shall cast them into a furnes of fire, there shall wailing, & gnashing of teeth.

column7: Yet more, this riche ma seeth sette before his iyes, poore Lazarus, whom in tymes paste, he did nothyng regard, in greate and perpetuall felicitie.
column8: Yet more, this rich ma sees set before his eyes, poor Lazarus, whom in times past, he did nothing regard, in great and perpetual felicity.

column7: This is no litle pain to the that be dampned, to se them that were nothyng, in comparison to them, now so to be in perpetuall pleasure, and them selfes in perpetuall pain, & al through their awne folie.
column8: This is no little pain to the that be dampened, to see them that were nothing, in comparison to them, now so to be in perpetual pleasure, and them selves in perpetual pain, & all through their awn folly.

column7: Furthermore, this riche manne is driuen to that nede, through his exceding pain, to begge of him, to whom in his life, he would not once vouchsafe to geue the cromes of his table.
column8: Furthermore, this rich man is driven to that need, through his exceeding pain, to beg of him, to whom in his life, he would not once vouchsafe to give the cromes of his table.

column7: He saith; send Lazarus that he may dippe the tippe of his finger in water, and coole my tongue, for I am tormented in this flambe.
column8: He says; send Lazarus that he may dip the tip of his finger in water, and cool my tongue, for I am tormented in this flambe.

column7: This is the very iudgement of God: whereby the pride and stoutnesse of suche men, are wont to be punished withall.
column8: This is the very judgement of God: whereby the pride and stoutness of such men, are wont to be punished withal.

column7: For thei whiche were in plentie, and felicitie: contempned poore s^ly soules in their misery and beggarie, not hauyng pitie vpon thein to helpe them, but thei despised theim and iudged the not worthy to their companie.
column8: For they which were in plenty, and felicity: contemned poor s^ly souls in their misery and beggary, not having pity upon thein to help them, but they despised them and judged thee not worthy to their company.

column7: These me thus doyng, doeth finde no lesse at Goddes hande, and that by the right iudgemet of God, bee brought to suche extreme necessitie and high miserie, that thei would thanke God with al their hartes, that those men, whom thei contepned and sette so litle by, would now vouchsafe once to geue theim one familiar countenaunce, or speake vnto the one familiar worde.
column8: These me thus doing, doth find no less at Goddes hand, and that by the right iudgemet of God, be brought to such extreme necessity and high misery, that they would thank God with all their hearts, that those men, whom they contepned and set so little by, would now vouchsafe once to give them one familiar countenance, or speak unto the one familiar word.

column7: It is (I saie) the very ordinaunce of God, that thei shalbee measured with the same measure, that thei measured other withal for so saieth Christe in Matthewes Gospell. vil.
column8: It is (I say) the very ordinance of God, that they shalbe measured with the same measure, that they measured other withal for so sayeth Christe in Matthewes Gospel. vil.

column7: Chapi. with what measure ye mete, with the same shal other men measure to you?
column8: Chapi. with what measure you meet, with the same shall other men measure to you?

column7: There is a meruerlous equalitie in god, for this riche man (not withstandyng his bitter prayer) obteined not so muche at Goddes hand, as a droppe of water, because he had defiled afore a crome of bread.
column8: There is a meruerlous equality in god, for this rich man (not withstanding his bitter prayer) obtained not so much at Goddes hand, as a drop of water, because he had defiled afore a crome of bred.

column7: We haue here a liuely example, what thei shall finde hereafter, that now in this life doeth not prepare for theimselfes frendes of the wicked Mammon, that whe thei shalbe take fro their goodes whiche thei copt their frendes, and be very beggers in deede, & haue greate nede, thei shall find as this ma found, euerlastyng lackyng, & euermore beggyng.
column8: We have here a lively example, what they shall find hereafter, that now in this life doth not prepare for themselves friends of the wicked Mammon, that when they shall take from their goods which they copt their friends, and be very beggars in deed, & have great need, they shall find as this ma found, everlasting lacking, & evermore begging.

column7: There is no begger in worse case, and a more miser, then he that euer beggeth, and neuer obteineth.
column8: There is no beggar in worse case, and a more miser, then he that ever beggeth, and never obtaineth.

column7: Suche shalbe all that dooeth as this man did.
column8: Suche shall all that doth as this man did.

column7: Therfore here in tyme what remedy Christ hath found, for as many as doth beleue him, and folowe his counsaill.
column8: Therefore here in time what remedy Christ hath found, for as many as does believe him, and follow his counsel.

column7: Luke.xvi. I saie vnto you, (saith he) make you frendes of the vnrighteous Mammon, that when ye shall haue nede, thei maie receiue you into euerlastyng habitacions.
column8: Luke xvi I say unto you, (says he) make you friends of the unrighteous Mammon, that when you shall have need, they may receive you into everlasting habitations.

column7: Wil ye folowe Christes counsail? while ye be here riche, and be able to make fredes by your riches, make them I counsail you.
column8: Wil you follow Christes counsel? while you be here rich, and be able to make fredes by your riches, make them I counsel you.

column7: Geue here, and it shalbee geuen vnto you there, helpe the poore here, and thei shal help you there.
column8: Give here, and it shalbe given unto you there, help the poor here, and they shall help you there.

column7: Receiue theim here, and thei shall receiue you there.
column8: Receive them here, and they shall receive you there.

column7: Loke what ye do vnto the here. shalbe doen vnto you again there, bee it good or euill: for Christe compteth altogether, that is doen to one of his, beyng neuer so poore, to be doen vnto himself.
column8: Look what you do unto the here. shall done unto you again there, be it good or evil: for Christe counteth altogether, that is done to one of his, being never so poor, to be done unto himself.

column7: And wher it is promised that thei (to whom ye are beneficiall here) shall receiue you into euerlastyng habitacions: By that wee gather, that Christ of his goodnes, hath geuen the bothe goodes and aucthoritie, to dooe you good again, that haue doen theim good here.
column8: And where it is promised that they (to whom you are beneficial here) shall receive you into everlasting habitations: By that we gather, that Christ of his goodness, hath given the both goods and authority, to do you good again, that have done them good here.

column7: Here ye se, how to be receiued of God, and how to bee abiected.
column8: Here you see, how to be received of God, and how to be abjected.

column7: Be good therfore vnto the poore, and do to them, as ye would that thei here after, shall do vnto you.
column8: Be good therefore unto the poor, and do to them, as you would that they here after, shall do unto you.

column7: And so ye doyng good vnto theim, shall dooe your self greate good, and laie vp threasure for your selfes, that neuer shall faile you.
column8: And so you doing good unto them, shall do your self great good, and lay up treasure for your selves, that never shall fail you.

column7: And so dooyng here, ye shall not lacke ther.
column8: And so doing here, you shall not lack there.

column7: And to the text again.
column8: And to the text again.

column7: And beyng in hell in tormentes, he lifte vp his iyes, & saw Abraham a farre of, &c. Here are in this parable that Christ propouneth, many straunge thynges, to them that knoweth not the nature of a Parable.
column8: And being in hell in torments, he lift up his eyes, & saw Abraham a far of, etc. Here are in this parable that Christ propouneth, many strange things, to them that knoweth not the nature of a Parable.

column7: In a Parable, there be many thynges feigned to be, that wer neuer doen: & yet maie there be muche and Godly doctrine taught by theim.
column8: In a Parable, there be many things feigned to be, that were never done: & yet may there be much and Godly doctrine taught by them.

column7: This one thyng emong many, is to be marked in euery Parable: the scopt, the meanyng and thend, wherfore the parable is spoken, & all thynges in parables, must be directed to yt purpose.
column8: This one thing among many, is to be marked in every Parable: the scopt, the meaning and th'end, wherefore the parable is spoken, & all things in parables, must be directed to that purpose.

column7: Now in this Parable ye muste marke well, although here in the Parable, it semeth that thei that be in heaue, or in a place of saluacio, should bothe se and talke with the, yt be in the place of dapitation, yet there is no suche thinges in deede, but we muste marke to what end christ spake this parable.
column8: Now in this Parable you must mark well, although here in the Parable, it seemeth that they that be in heave, or in a place of saluacio, should both see and talk with thee, that be in the place of dapitation, yet there is no such things in deed, but we must mark to what end christ spoke this parable.

column7: He spake it to the Iues & in them to all vs, teachyng bothe the and vs, how to liue in this world, yt we may liue in the world that is to come also.
column8: He spoke it to the Iues & in them to all us, teaching both the and us, how to live in this world, that we may live in the world that is to come also.

column7: Here is in this Parable taught, how that wee maye not iudge, after the iudgement of the worlde, but after the Iudgement of God: whiche is knowen onely in holy scriptures, neither of thynges present in this worlde, neither of thynges in the worlde to come.
column8: Here is in this Parable taught, how that we may not judge, after the judgement of the world, but after the Judgement of God: which is known only in holy scriptures, neither of things present in this world, neither of things in the world to come.

column7: Now once again to the text: and beyng in hel in tormetes, he lift vp his iyes, and sawe Abraham &c. Here must ye note (as I haue partly told you before) that although that Christ setteth furth in this parable, as though soules departed out of this worlde, some to the place of glorie, and some to the place of miserie: should speake or talke one with another, yet there is no suche thyng, nor Christ meaneth no suche thyng.
column8: Now once again to the text: and being in hell in tormetes, he lift up his eyes, and saw Abraham etc. Here must you note (as I have partly told you before) that although that Christ sets forth in this parable, as though souls departed out of this world, some to the place of glory, and some to the place of misery: should speak or talk one with another, yet there is no such thing, nor Christ means no such thing.

column7: But Christes meanyng is, to teach vs that bee his, and here a liue, to bee ware of suche imaginacious or saiynges, as this man beyng in hell, doth saie here.
column8: But Christes meaning is, to teach us that be his, and here a live, to be aware of such imaginacious or sayings, as this man being in hell, does say here.

column7: For eue as Christ feigneth this man, to speake in hell: euen so doth deuilish men imagin and speake in yearth supposyng suche thynges to bee true, as this man in hell doth speake, or is rather by Christ feigned to speake.
column8: For eve as Christ feigneth this man, to speak in hell: even so does devilish men imagine and speak in earth supposing such things to be true, as this man in hell does speak, or is rather by Christ feigned to speak.

column7: And ye muste note also, that like as in this mannes speakyng is signified all euill mestnes imaginacions and saiynges: so here is also to bee marked in Abrahams saiynges, Gods will and pleasure knowen in scriptures, for Abraham doeth speake here in the persone of god, and there is here nothyng spoken of hym, but that is true, and doth confute all this wicked mannes assertions & saiynges.
column8: And you must note also, that like as in this man's speaking is signified all evil mestnes imaginations and sayings: so here is also to be marked in Abrahams sayings, Gods will and pleasure known in scriptures, for Abraham doth speak here in the person of god, and there is here nothing spoken of him, but that is true, and does confute all this wicked man's assertions & sayings.

column7: Now let vs example the text, whiche saith: he beyng in hell in tormentes, lift vp his iyes, and saw Abraha a farre of, and Lazarus in his bosome, and he cried and saied, father Abraham haue mercie on me, and send Lazarus that he maie dippe the tippe of his finger in water, and coole my tongue, for I am tormented in this flambe.
column8: Now let us example the text, which says: he being in hell in torments, lift up his eyes, and saw Abraha a far of, and Lazarus in his bosom, and he cried and said, father Abraham have mercy on me, and send Lazarus that he may dip the tip of his finger in water, and cool my tongue, for I am tormented in this flambe.

column7: Now here is shewed the imaginacions of them, that bee in helle in pain.
column8: Now here is showed the imaginations of them, that be in hell in pain.

column7: Thei doo consider the state that thei be in, in helle, that is in pain and misery.
column8: They do consider the state that they be in, in hell, that is in pain and misery.

column7: Thei do also consider the state of them that be in glorie and felicitie, and that doth augment their pain and miserie.
column8: They do also consider the state of them that be in glory and felicity, and that does augment their pain and misery.

column7: Thei beyng thus altogether wrapped in sorow on euery side, shew their affeccion, & desiryng relief of the same, crie to Abraham (that representeth God) for mercie, but altogether is in vain, because thei do it all out of due tyme.
column8: They being thus altogether wrapped in sorrow on every side, show their affection, & desiring relief of the same, cry to Abraham (that representeth God) for mercy, but altogether is in vain, because they do it all out of due time.

column7: But Abraham saied: sonne, remember that thou in thy life tyme, receiue dost thy pleasure, and cotrary-wise, Lazarus receiued pain, but now is he coforted, and thou art punished.
column8: But Abraham said: son, remember that thou in thy life time, receive dost thy pleasure, and cotrary-wise, Lazarus received pain, but now is he coforted, and thou art punished.

column7: Here speaketh almightie God in Abrahams person, not onely to this ma but rather to all menne, that doeth as this manne did.
column8: Here speaks almighty God in Abrahams person, not only to this ma but rather to all men, that doth as this man did.

column7: He asketh mercie, but out of tyme.
column8: He asks mercy, but out of time.

column7: He would haue helpe of Lazarus, whom when he might haue holpe, he would not help.
column8: He would have help of Lazarus, whom when he might have help, he would not help.

column7: Therfore he heareth Abraham speakyng the sentence of god to hym, saiyng: sonne, remembre that thou in thy life.
column8: Therefore he hears Abraham speaking the sentence of god to him, saying: son, remember that thou in thy life.

column7: &c. God doth call men to a reare copt, because thei do folowe their awne sensualitie, takyng in al thinges their awne pleasure, thei regard nothyng at all what is gods pleasure.
column8: etc. God does call men to a rear copt, because they do follow their awn sensuality, taking in all things their awn pleasure, they regard nothing at all what is gods pleasure.

column7: Thei care not what God would haue theim dooe, but thei regard and onely care for their awne pleasures, and suche thynges as thei will, and haue pleasure to do.
column8: They care not what God would have them do, but they regard and only care for their awn pleasures, and such things as they will, and have pleasure to do.

column7: Consider also, that he calleth Abraham father, & also Abraha calleth him sonne.
column8: Consider also, that he calls Abraham father, & also Abraha calls him son.

column7: But likewise as this man here beyng a liue and in prosperitie, regarded not Abraha, that is to say god, any thing at al, & he toke him not once for his father (except it wer with the mouth onely.)
column8: But likewise as this man here being a live and in prosperity, regarded not Abraha, that is to say god, any thing at all, & he took him not once for his father (except it were with the mouth only.)

column7: He loked for no helpe at his hande, he trusted not in hym, nor was for thynges receiued, thankful vnto him * so doth Abraha, that is to say god, calleth hym sone after the same fashio, as he called him father, nothyng meanyg to shewe his fatherly pitie, & compassion vpon hym, neither doeth he make hym once partaker of any parte of his euheritaunce; but saieth: Sonne, remembre that thou in thy life tyme, receiuedst thy pleasure, & contrarywise Lazarus receiued pain.
column8: He looked for no help at his hand, he trusted not in him, nor was for things received, thankful unto him * so does Abraha, that is to say god, calls him soon after the same fashio, as he called him father, nothing meanyg to show his fatherly pity, & compassion upon him, neither doth he make him once partaker of any part of his euheritaunce; but sayeth: Son, remember that thou in thy life time, receivedst thy pleasure, & contrariwise Lazarus received pain.

column7: As though he might saie, like as thou in the worlde, beeyng in high prosperitie, forgottest me, regardedst me not, haddest no trust in me to do thee good in time to come, but folowedst thyne awne pleasure; & not myne, thyne awne will, and not myne, and was also in al thynges vnthankfull.
column8: As though he might say, like as thou in the world, being in high prosperity, forgottest me, regardedst me not, hadst not trust in me to do thee good in time to come, but folowedst thine awn pleasure; & not mine, thine awn will, and not mine, and was also in all things unthankful.

column7: Remembre now how thou hast doen the, and therefore now thou must be concent to receiue there after Thou regardedst not, neither my wil nor pleasure then, but thyne awne: therefore now thou hast, accordyng to thyne awne deseruynges.
column8: Remember now how thou hast done thee, and therefore now thou must be concent to receive there after Thou regardedst not, neither my will nor pleasure then, but thine awn: therefore now thou hast, according to thine awn deservings.

column7: But cotrary wise Lazarus beyng in aduersitie, forgat me not, all tymes he regarded my waies.
column8: But contrary wise Lazarus being in adversity, forgot me not, all times he regarded my ways.

column7: He put his whole truste in me, to do hym good, in tyme to come.
column8: He put his whole trust in me, to do him good, in time to come.

column7: He folowed not his awne pleasure, but myne, he did not his awne will, but myne.
column8: He followed not his awn pleasure, but mine, he did not his awn will, but mine.

column7: He was pacient in his aduersitie, and gaue thankes in all his misery.
column8: He was patient in his adversity, and gave thanks in all his misery.

column7: Therfore, now is he coforted, and thou art now punished.
column8: Therefore, now is he coforted, and thou art now punished.

column7: This doctrine is not set furthe here, neither for this riche manne, nor yet for this poore manne, for thei can neither take good nor harme by it.
column8: This doctrine is not set forth here, neither for this rich man, nor yet for this poor man, for they can neither take good nor harm by it.

column7: But it is sette furth (as all other scripture is) for vs to do vs good, to teache vs, to monish vs, whether we bee riche or poore, to haue before oure tyes, here in this worlde, whether we be in prosperitie, or aduersitie, al tymes the state of the worlde that is to come.
column8: But it is set forth (as all other scripture is) for us to do us good, to teach us, to monish us, whither we be rich or poor, to have before our ties, here in this world, whither we be in prosperity, or adversity, all times the state of the world that is to come.

column7: If that wee would earnesty and often do this, we (I saie) of what state soeuer we bee, truely, truely, it would make vs, that be riche to consider, from whence our goodes come, to what purpose.
column8: If that we would earnesty and often do this, we (I say) of what state soever we be, truly, truly, it would make us, that be rich to consider, from whence our goods come, to what purpose.

column7: God either did lende them vs, or put theim into our handes, it would make vs to remember what good, we beyng here riche, maie dooe vnto oure selfes in another worlde, (hourdyng vp oure Threasure there) in ministeryng thesame goodes, gladly, liberally, and with a louyng harte, to our poore brethren and sisterne, accordyng to their necessitie, and our abilitie.
column8: God either did lend them us, or put them into our hands, it would make us to remember what good, we being here rich, may do unto our selves in another world, (hourdyng up our Treasure there) in ministering thesame goods, gladly, liberally, and with a loving heart, to our poor brothers and sisterne, according to their necessity, and our ability.

column7: It would also make vs thankefull to GOD, whiche hath geuen vs the same gooddes, and hath made vs to be in a more blessed state, whiche is in the state of geuyng, accordyng to the saiyng of our Lorde Christe, in the Actes of the Apostles the twentie Chapiter, whiche saieth: It is more blessed to geue, then to receiue.
column8: It would also make us thankful to GOD, which hath given us the same gods, and hath made us to be in a more blessed state, which is in the state of giving, according to the saying of our Lord Christe, in the Acts of the Apostles the twentie Chapter, which sayeth: It is more blessed to give, then to receive.

column7: This doctrine also would make theim that bee poore and in miserie, to bee pacient, and thankefull to GOD their father, knowyng that ther is nothyng that can come or chaunce to theim, no, not one here of their heade shall perisshe, without either their fathers wil or permission.
column8: This doctrine also would make them that be poor and in misery, to be patient, and thankful to GOD their father, knowing that there is nothing that can come or chance to them, no, not one here of their head shall perish, without either their father's will or permission.

column7: Now therfore both riche & poore take hede to this doctrine, cosider what is setforth in the same, either to eschue of folowe.
column8: Now therefore both rich & poor take heed to this doctrine, consider what is setforth in the same, either to eschew of follow.

column7: If ye take hede in tyme and folow this poore mans doyng, that is, the wyll & pleasure of god, walkynge trulie in your vocation, trulie seruing your callyng, doing in all poyntes to your power your duty & office, bothe towardes God & your neighbours, ye shall haue as this poore man (your paterne and examplar, doinge his office and seruing his vocacion) hadde, that is euen heuen for his labour.
column8: If you take heed in time and follow this poor men doing, that is, the will & pleasure of god, walking truly in your vocation, truly serving your calling, doing in all points to your power your duty & office, both towards God & your neighbours, you shall have as this poor man (your pattern and exemplar, doing his office and serving his vocation) had, that is even heaven for his labour.

column7: If ye regard not this doctrine setforth here in this parable of this riche ma, but be negligent and carelesse in doyng your office, and seruing your vocacion, geuing your selues to your owne lustes & pleasures, as th^ riche ma did, that that is written here in the parable to come to hym, doubtles shall come to you, that is to be perpetually damned in hel.
column8: If you regard not this doctrine setforth here in this parable of this rich ma, but be negligent and careless in doing your office, and serving your vocation, giving your selves to your own lusts & pleasures, as th^ rich ma did, that that is written here in the parable to come to him, doubtless shall come to you, that is to be perpetually damned in hell.

column7: It foloweth furthermore i the texte: Beyond all this, betwene vs & you, ther is a greate space set, so that they which wolde go fro hence to you cannot, neither may come from thence to vs. Here is a nother doctrine of the heauenly father taught here by our saluiour Christ, in the person of Abraham.
column8: It followeth furthermore i the text: Beyond all this, between us & you, there is a great space set, so that they which would go from hence to you cannot, neither may come from thence to us Here is a neither doctrine of the heavenly father taught here by our saviour Christ, in the person of Abraham.

column7: By this doctrine of Christe here set furth, is signified vnto all men, that in a nother worlde, ther is no chaunge of thinges, but al thinges be ther firme, stable, suer and perpetual.
column8: By this doctrine of Christe here set forth, is signified unto all men, that in a neither world, there is no change of things, but all things be there firm, stable, sure and perpetual.

column7: Therfore they yt be ones made happy in that world (as all those shalbe that doth departe in faith) shall for euer & perpetually, remaine happy and neuer be chaunged, as Iohn saieth in ye Apocalipse the.xiiii. Blessed are all they yt die in the lorde, yt is in ye faith of Iesu Christe.
column8: Therefore they that be ones made happy in that world (as all those shall that does depart in faith) shall for ever & perpetually, remain happy and never be changed, as John sayeth in you Apocalipse the xiiii Blessed are all they that die in the lord, that is in the faith of Jesu Christe.

column7: Eue so they, that are once vnhappy, shal euer & perpetually be vnhappy, & ther is no place lefte of repetyng amendyng & obteinyng of saluacion.
column8: Eue so they, that are once unhappy, shall ever & perpetually be unhappy, & there is no place left of repeating amending & obtaining of salvation.

column7: Marke what is writte in Ecclesiastes the.ij. chapiter.
column8: Mark what is written in Ecclesiastes the ij chapter.

column7: If the tree falle, ether to the sowth or to ye northe, in whatsoeuer place it falleth, ther it lieth.
column8: If the tree fall, either to the south or to the north, in whatsoever place it falls, there it lies.

column7: This doctrine is not ment of fallyng of trees, but of the deathe of men.
column8: This doctrine is not meant of falling of trees, but of the death of men.

column7: By ye South is vnderstade faith, by the North infidelite.
column8: By you South is vnderstade faith, by the North infidelite.

column7: Lyke as the tree lieth still where it falleth: So dothe the man signified ther by, abide stil for euer in one state & neuer chaungeth.
column8: Like as the tree lies still where it falls: So doth the man signified there by, abide still for ever in one state & never changeth.

column7: If he die in faith he is saued, if in infidelitie, he is damned.
column8: If he die in faith he is saved, if in infidelity, he is damned.

column7: So that he that is ones damned shall neuer be saued, Euen so nomore shall he that is ones saued, euer after be dampned.
column8: So that he that is ones damned shall never be saved, Even so nomore shall he that is ones saved, ever after be dampened.

column7: Wher is then become purgatory, that hath put so many both great & smal in a wanne hope, to be saued by other mes merites after their death?
column8: Where is then become purgatory, that hath put so many both great & small in a won hope, to be saved by other mes merits after their death?

column7: I trust it be runne home again to his first inuenter & founder the pope.
column8: I trust it be run home again to his first inventer & founder the pope.

column7: I wolde wish yt al purgatorie mainteiners were with him also vntil I wold wish the here again.
column8: I would wish that all purgatory maintainers were with him also until I would wish the here again.

column7: Seyng that euery man at his death is either saued or dampned, wherfore is all that money bestowed for the dead.
column8: Sing that every man at his death is either saved or dampened, wherefore is all that money bestowed for the dead.

column7: If they be in heaue, ther can no money increace ther ioy ther.
column8: If they be in heave, there can no money increase there joy there.

column7: If thei be i hel, ther can no money minish their paines there.
column8: If they be i hell, there can no money minish their pains there.

column7: Therfore the money that is bestowed for the dead with that opinion, either to increase the ioy of ye one, or to relese the paine of the other, is euel spent.
column8: Therefore the money that is bestowed for the dead with that opinion, either to increase the joy of you one, or to relese the pain of the other, is evil spent.

column7: For ye dead be neuer the better, and the liuyng bestowers be moche the worse.
column8: For you dead be never the better, and the living bestowers be much the worse.

column7: Why sir may not a man geue his goodes to be bestowed among the poore when he is dead?
column8: Why sir may not a man give his goods to be bestowed among the poor when he is dead?

column7: I say not nay.
column8: I say not nay.

column7: For ther is litell enowgh geuen vnto the poore by mens liues.
column8: For there is little enowgh given unto the poor by men's lives.

column7: Therfor I thinke it mete to geue at ye lestwyse at ther deathes.
column8: Therefore I think it meet to give at you leastwise at their deaths.

column7: But I will counsel noma to tary and differ is almosse vntill he die: for then I doubte whether it be his almosse or not.
column8: But I will counsel noma to tarry and differ is almosse until he die: for then I doubt whither it be his almosse or not.

column7: Or whether other me wil geue for him that he coulde not finde in his owne harte to geue for himselfe.
column8: Or whither other me will give for him that he could not find in his own heart to give for himself.

column7: We be bounde to geue that yt we be able to spare to them that hathe present neade and necessite, and not to tarie vntill we die, for then we geue, because we can no longer kepe it, and I am a fraied that god shall thanke vs therafter, that is to say, nothyng at all.
column8: We be bound to give that that we be able to spare to them that hath present neade and necessity, and not to tarry until we die, for then we give, because we can no longer keep it, and I am a frayed that god shall thank us thereafter, that is to say, nothing at all.

column7: For he neuer gaue vs his goodes nor yet lent them vs to kepe them tyll we die, but in all our life tyme to bestowe them vppon the neady: & not to kepe them that other men may bestow them for vs, or rather striue for them after our deathe.
column8: For he never gave us his goods nor yet lent them us to keep them till we die, but in all our life time to bestow them upon the needy: & not to keep them that other men may bestow them for us, or rather strive for them after our death.

column7: Here we may lerne of this doctrine, that although this riche man begged a pace, (beyng in hell in tormentes), to haue bene relesed of some of his paine: yeat he founde no relief at gods hades at al, for he asked it to late.
column8: Here we may learn of this doctrine, that although this rich man begged a pace, (being in hell in torments), to have be relesed of some of his pain: yet he found no relief at gods hades at all, for he asked it to late.

column7: Nomore shall we finde at gods handes, if we come to late as he did, which died i infidelitie.
column8: Nomore shall we find at gods hands, if we come to late as he did, which died i infidelity.

column7: And as many as dieth in infidelitie, shall neuer obteine mercy, pray they neuer somoche for the selues, as this man is made mencion to do.
column8: And as many as dieth in infidelity, shall never obtain mercy, pray they never somuch for the selves, as this man is made mention to do.

column7: And moreouer and if all the whole worlde together wolde pray for one of them: yet shulde he neuer obteine any relief of his paine.
column8: And moreover and if all the whole world together would pray for one of them: yet should he never obtain any relief of his pain.

column7: Now by ye sentece of god, ther is nothing behind then but this, that both this riche man and his lyke companions must content them selues with ther state & paine that thei be in, & neuer to loke for better.
column8: Now by you sentece of god, there is nothing behind then but this, that both this rich man and his like companions must content them selves with their state & pain that they be in, & never to look for better.

column7: Now here we may see & lerne by this doctrine of this place, that ther be nomore but ij. places prepared for the that be departed out of this world, One for the that are blessed, yt is a place of refreshyng Another for them that are dampned, that is a place of tormeting.
column8: Now here we may see & learn by this doctrine of this place, that there be nomore but ij. places prepared for the that be departed out of this world, One for the that are blessed, that is a place of refreshing Another for them that are dampened, that is a place of tormeting.

column7: We finde not one worde in scriptures of yt forged purgatory, wherin sowles be not purged, but fooles purses be emptied.
column8: We find not one word in scriptures of that forged purgatory, wherein souls be not purged, but fools purses be emptied.

column7: Here endeth the fowerth parte of this Sermon.
column8: Here endeth the fowerth part of this Sermon.

column7: B Ut whe this afore named riche ma saw yt he could not preuaile any thing at al for himselfe, tha he began to make his peticio for other saieng: I pray the therfor father sende him to my fathers howse, for I haue fyue bretherne, for to warne the, leste they also come to this place of tormentes.
column8: BUt BUt when this afore nam rich ma saw that he could not prevail any thing at all for himself, than he began to make his peticio for other saying: I pray the therefore father send him to my father's house, for I have fyue brethren, for to warn thee, lest they also come to this place of torments.

column7: Here is also to be marked, in this parte of the parable, a nother damnable opinion spoken by this man being in hell, to teache them that are yet here in the earth, to be ware of it and suche lyke.
column8: Here is also to be marked, in this part of the parable, a neither damnable opinion spoken by this man being in hell, to teach them that are yet here in the earth, to be aware of it and such like.

column7: This mans opinion was, as Christe teacheth here in the parable, that men wolde geue more credence to Spirites that come from a nother worlde, tha to the holie scriptures beyng taught the here in thys world.
column8: This men opinion was, as Christe teaches here in the parable, that men would give more credence to Spirits that come from a neither world, than to the holy scriptures being taught the here in this world.

column7: This opinion is confuted here by ye heuelie Fathers doctrine taught by Christe in the person of Abraham, as ye shall heare hereafter This opinion is confuted here of Christe, not for this riche mans sake, nor for to teache hym and to conuerte hym, but it is set here to teache vs, to conuerte vs, whiche be yet here, where we may be taught, where we may be conuerted.
column8: This opinion is confuted here by you heuelie Father's doctrine taught by Christe in the person of Abraham, as you shall hear hereafter This opinion is confuted here of Christe, not for this rich men sake, nor for to teach him and to convert him, but it is set here to teach us, to convert us, which be yet here, where we may be taught, where we may be converted.

column7: Why? be there any nowe a lyue thinke ye, that be of that opinion that this riche dampned man was of?
column8: Why? be there any now a live think you, that be of that opinion that this rich dampened man was of?

column7: Ye trulie, I fere me to many.
column8: the truly, I fere me to many.

column7: There be yt be not ashamed to vtter ther dampnable opinion, with these and suche lyke wordes: We knowe (say they) what we haue here, but we know not what we shall haue ther.
column8: There be that be not ashamed to utter their damnable opinion, with these and such like words: We know (say they) what we have here, but we know not what we shall have there.

column7: Who dothe know, whether there be any other life after this life?
column8: Who doth know, whither there be any other life after this life?

column7: Who wil chaunge (that wise is) the certentie of thinges that we be suer of here in this worlde, for the vncertentie of thynges that be to come, in a nother (to vs vnkowen) worlde.
column8: Who will change (that wise is) the certainty of things that we be sure of here in this world, for the uncertainty of things that be to come, in a neither (to us vnkowen) world.

column7: Ther is none (say they) that will do thus except a few of momishe mopers whiche can do none other thyng else, but mope vppon ther bookes, to make vs afraied of shadowes and buggeberes.
column8: There is none (say they) that will do thus except a few of momishe mopers which can do none other thing else, but mope upon their books, to make us afraid of shadows and buggeberes.

column7: Therfore (say these wicked me) we wyll abyde in this our opinion, vntill we haue some messenger sent from heuen or hell, to shew vs what newes be ther, and take our pleasure here in the meane season, let the teche what they wyll.
column8: Therefore (say these wicked me) we will abide in this our opinion, until we have some messenger sent from heaven or hell, to show us what news be there, and take our pleasure here in the mean season, let the teach what they will.

column7: Of this opinion the parable teacheth vs that this riche man was, and he doth here represent all those that be now of that opinion, and that answere that was made vnto hym than, is to warne them that be of suche opinion now.
column8: Of this opinion the parable teaches us that this rich man was, and he does here represent all those that be now of that opinion, and that answer that was made unto him than, is to warn them that be of such opinion now.

column7: That the parable doeth teach, this ma to be careful for his bretherne, that wer yet of the opinion that he was of: is not set here to teche that the sowles in hell dothe care for them that are in earthe, but it is set here to teache vs to be carefull for our owne selues and for our fryndes also here, while care wil help.
column8: That the parable doth teach, this ma to be careful for his brethren, that were yet of the opinion that he was of: is not set here to teach that the souls in hell doth care for them that are in earth, but it is set here to teach us to be careful for our own selves and for our friends also here, while care will help.

column7: For lyke as this mans care (that the parable speaketh of) preuailed not, nomore shall no mans care preuaile, nether for himselfe, nor yet for other, that is not taken in tyme.
column8: For like as this men care (that the parable speaks of) prevailed not, nomore shall no men care prevail, neither for himself, nor yet for other, that is not taken in time.

column7: What was this mans care in hell? that his bretherne all together vntawght of the will of god, that is, that they that lyue here in this world godly, folowing the wil and the pleasure of god, shulde haue with god euerlasting glorie, as he saw Lazarus had.
column8: What was this men care in hell? that his brethren all together vntawght of the will of god, that is, that they that live here in this world godly, following the will and the pleasure of god, should have with god everlasting glory, as he saw Lazarus had.

column7: And the contrarie wise, as many as toke ther owne pleasure, regarding not the will of god, shulde be in paine euerlasting, as he himselfe was.
column8: And the contrary wise, as many as took there own pleasure, regarding not the will of god, should be in pain everlasting, as he himself was.

column7: This was his care, but to late.
column8: This was his care, but to late.

column7: He saide, Vt testificetur illis, for to warne them (quod he) leste thei also come in to this place of torment.
column8: He said, Vt testificetur illis, for to warn them (quod he) lest they also come in to this place of torment.

column7: This mans opinion thus farre was good, yt he wolde haue his bretherne warned, to be ware here i this preset lyfe furth But in this his opinion was nought, that he wolde haue one to come owe of a nother worlde to teache them, for that is a false opinion confuted here by our saluiour Christ, let vs be warned here in tyme, while lyfe is in vs. But let vs loke neither for Angell, sowle, nor deuel to teach vs, but onely Scripture, as ye be here taught by Abraham speaking in gods person to this riche man, and not onely to hym, but rather vnto vs, that we heringe this his doctrine, beleuing & working after ye same, may be saufe: wher doing ye cotrarie we shulde be daned.
