column7: I say kyl & offer you vp the worldly & erthly affectios of your bodyes, for Christ our Ester lambe is offred vp for vs, to slee the power of synne, to delyuer vs from the daunger therof and to gyue vs exemple to dye to synne in our lyfe.
column8: I say kill & offer you up the worldly & earthly affectios of your bodies, for Christ our Ester lamb is offered up for us, to slee the power of sin, to deliver us from the danger thereof and to gyve us exemple to die to sin in our life.

column7: As the Iues dyd eate theyr Ester labe & kept theyr fest in remembrauce of theyr deliuerauce out of Egypt: Eue so let vs kepe our Ester feast in ye thankfull remebraunce of Christes benefytes whych he hath purchased for vs by hys resurrectio & passyng to hys father: wherby we be deliuered from ye captiuitie & thraldome of al our enemyes.
column8: As the Iues did eat their Ester labe & kept their fist in remembrance of their deliverance out of Egypt: Eue so let us keep our Ester feast in you thankful remebraunce of Christes benefits which he hath purchased for us by his resurrectio & passing to his father: whereby we be delivered from you captivity & thraldom of all our enemies.

column7: Let vs in like maner passe ouer the affections of our olde conuersacion to be delyuered from ye bondage therof to ryse wt Christ. <NOTE> The Iues kept theyr feast in absteynynge from leuened breade by the space of.vij. dayes: let vs christen folke kepe our holy day in a spiritual maner yt is in absteining not from material leuened bread, but from the olde leuen of synne the leuen of maliciousnes & wyckednes.
column8: Let us in like manner pass over the affections of our old conversation to be delivered from you bondage thereof to rise with Christ. The Iues kept their feast in abstaining from leavened bread by the space of vij days: let us christen folk keep our holy day in a spiritual manner that is in abstaining not from material leavened bred, but from the old leuen of sin the leuen of maliciousness & wickedness.

column7: Let vs cast fro vs ye leuen of corrupt doctrine yt wyl infect our soules.
column8: Let us cast from us the leuen of corrupt doctrine that will infect our souls.

column7: Let vs kepe oure feast ye hole terme of our lyfe wt eatynge the bred of purenes of godly lyfe, & truth of Christes doctrine.
column8: Let us keep our feast you hold term of our life with eating the bred of pureness of godly life, & truth of Christes doctrine.

column7: Thus shall we declare yt Christes gyftes & graces haue theyr effect in vs & that we haue ye right beleue & knowlege of his holy resurrection, whervnto yf we applye our fayth to ye vertue therof, & in our lyfe coforme vs to the exemple & signification ment therby, we shalbe suer to ryse hereafter to euerlastynge glorye by the goodnes and mercy of our Lorde Iesus Christe, to whome wyth the father and the holy goost.
column8: Thus shall we declare that Christes gifts & graces have their effect in us & that we have you right believe & knowledge of his holy resurrection, whereunto if we apply our faith to you virtue thereof, & in our life coforme us to the exemple & signification meant thereby, we shall sure to rise hereafter to everlasting glory by the goodness and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christe, to whom with the father and the holy ghost.

column7: &c.: homily P A G Ei On the fyrst sondaye after Ester.
column8: etc.: homily PAGEi PAGEi PAGEi PAGEi On the fyrst sondaye after Ester.

column7: The Epistle on the fyrste sondaye after Ester daye, called lowe sondaye.
column8: The Epistle on the fyrste sondaye after Ester day, called low sondaye.

column7: The fyrst Epistle of Iohn, and the.v. Chapter.
column8: The fyrst Epistle of John, and the v Chapter.

column7: Thargument of thys Epistle.
column8: Thargument of this Epistle.

column7: Of the excellency of fayth and how it ouercometh the worlde.
column8: Of the excellency of faith and how it overcometh the world.

column7: M Ost dere beloued brethren, al that is borne of God ouercometh the worlde.
column8: MOst MOst dear beloved brothers, all that is born of God overcometh the world.

column7: And this is the victory that ouercometh the world, eue our faith.
column8: And this is the victory that overcometh the world, eve our faith.

column7: Who is it that ouercommeth the worlde: <NOTE> but he whyche beleueth, that Iesus is the sonne of God?
column8: Who is it that overcometh the world: but he which believeth, that Jesus is the son of God?

column7: Thys Iesus Christe is he that came by water and bloud, not by water onely: but by water & bloud.
column8: This Jesus Christe is he that came by water and blood, not by water only: but by water & blood.

column7: And it is the spirite that beareth wytnesse, because the spirite is trueth.
column8: And it is the spirit that bears witness, because the spirit is truth.

column7: (for there are thre whiche beare recorde in heauen, the father, the worde, and holy goste.
column8: (for there are thre which bear record in heaven, the father, the word, and holy ghost.

column7: And these thre are one.)
column8: And these thre are one.)

column7: And there are thre whyche beare record (in earth) the spirite water and bloud: and these thre are one. Yf we receaue the wytnes of men, the wytnes of God is greater.
column8: And there are thre which bear record (in earth) the spirit water and blood: and these thre are one. If we receive the witness of men, the witness of God is greater.

column7: For thys is the wytnes of God (that is greater) whyche he testifyed of hys sonne.
column8: For this is the witness of God (that is greater) which he testified of his son.

column7: He that beleueth on the sonne of god hath the wytnes in hymselfe.
column8: He that believeth on the son of god hath the witness in himself.

column7: An exhortation vpon thys Epistel.
column8: And exhortation upon this Epistel.

column7: O Vre Epistle taken out of the first epistle catholyke of saint Iohn good christen brethern doth shewe vnto vs that we haue a generation from god which is that which procedeth of faith, & this ouercommyth the worlde that is to saie the concupiscences of synes, which be pryde, couetous, and lecherye.
column8: OVre OVre Epistle taken out of the first epistle catholic of saint John good christian brother does show unto us that we have a generation from god which is that which proceedeth of faith, & this ouercommyth the world that is to say the concupiscences of sins, which be pride, covetous, and lechery.

column7: Assuredly my frendes ther is I trust no man amonges vs but knoweth that of nature we be al born in synnes, <NOTE> vnrightuousnes, in vtter ignorance of al ghostly and spiritual thinges.
column8: Assuredly my friends there is I trust no man among us but knoweth that of nature we be all born in sins, unrighteousness, in utter ignorance of all ghostly and spiritual things.

column7: And therfore Sainct Austine wryteth on this wise. <NOTE> Beholde my brethern beholde the generacion of mankynde from the firste death of that first man.
column8: And therefore Saint Austine writes on this wise. Behold my brother behold the generation of mankind from the firste death of that first man.

column7: For synne from the first man hath entred into this world and by syne hath death entred and so hath passed thorough all men as witnesseth thapostle.
column8: For sin from the first man hath entered into this world and by sin hath death entered and so hath passed through all men as witnesseth apostle.

column7: But marke (sayth saynte Austine) this worde passed through. <NOTE> Synne is rune through vpon all the ofsprynge of Adam, and for this cause is the new borne chylde gylty of eternal damnation, he hath not yet done syn, but he hath caught synne.
column8: But mark (say faint Austine) this word passed through. Sin is rune through upon all the ofsprynge of Adam, and for this cause is the new born child guilty of eternal damnation, he hath not yet done sin, but he hath caught sin.

column7: For surely that fyrst synne of oure foreparentes dyd not styll remayne in the headsprynge, but it passed through into the ofsprynge not into hym and hym but into al men.
column8: For surely that fyrst sin of our foreparentes did not still remain in the headsprynge, but it passed through into the ofsprynge not into him and him but into all men.

column7: The fyrst synner the fyrst trasgressour begat synners subiecte to death.
column8: The fyrst sinner the fyrst trasgressour begat sinners subject to death.

column7: Than came the Sauiour of a virgine to heale & saue them, he came to the, but not the waye that thou camest.
column8: Than came the Saviour of a virgin to heal & save them, he came to thee, but not the way that thou camest.

column7: For he proceded not of the concupiscece of the male and female, he came not of that bonde of concupiscence.
column8: For he proceeded not of the concupiscence of the male and female, he came not of that bond of concupiscence.

column7: Bycause therfore he came to the not by yt waye that thou cammest: <NOTE> he delyuered the.
column8: Because therefore he came to thee not by that way that thou cammest: he delivered the.

column7: But where dyd he fynde the?
column8: But where did he find thee?

column7: He founde the solde vnder synne, lyenge in the death of the fyrste man drawynge vp the synne of the fyrst ma beynge gylty and hauynge condemnation yer thou couldest discerne good and euell asunder.
column8: He found the sold under sin, lying in the death of the fyrste man drawing up the sin of the fyrst ma being guilty and having condemnation year thou couldst discern good and evil asunder.

column7: Hetherto I haue rehersed vnto you P A G Eij the wordes of saynt Austyne.
column8: Hitherto I have rehearsed unto you PAGEij PAGEij PAGEij PAGEij the words of saint Austyne.

column7: Wherfore to retourne to my purpose: forasmuch as we be borne in synne whych bryngeth wyth it ignoraunce, blyndnes, and infidelitie, therfore we can not chalenge thys to our owne power and vertue that we beleue Iesus to be Christ, but for the beleuynge herof we haue nede to be borne agayne and to be renewed through the holy goost and by ye worde of God to thintent we may purely vnderstande the thynges that be of God and that we maye by faythe take holde of the promyses of Christ and so finally wyth sure confidence determine wyth our selues that Iesus is Christe, <NOTE> that is to saye, the annoynted Kynge and Sauioure of the worlde. <NOTE> For no doubte before we be thus borne agayne, we be all but Nicodemes, that is to saye, we maye well beleue that Christ came as a greate mayster from God and that noma coulde do the sygnes and myracles that he dyd.
column8: Wherefore to return to my purpose: forasmuch as we be born in sin which bringeth with it ignorance, blindness, and infidelity, therefore we can not challenge this to our own power and virtue that we believe Jesus to be Christ, but for the believing hereof we have need to be born again and to be renewed through the holy ghost and by the word of God to intent we may purely understand the things that be of God and that we may by faith take hold of the promises of Christ and so finally with sure confidence determine with our selves that Jesus is Christe, that is to say, the anointed King and Saviour of the world. For no doubt before we be thus born again, we be all but Nicodemes, that is to say, we may well believe that Christ came as a great master from God and that noma could do the signs and miracles that he did.

column7: But thys is but an historial fayth, and they that haue it do as yet walke out of the kyngdom of heuen wyth Nicodemus, to who Christ answereth.
column8: But this is but and historial faith, and they that have it do as yet walk out of the kingdom of heaven with Nicodemus, to who Christ answereth.

column7: Verely, verely, I saye vnto the, onles a ma be borne agayne from aboue he can not se the kyngdome of God, <NOTE> whych selfe thynge the holy apostle saynte Ihon doth in thys place declare in other termes saynge: <NOTE> he can not beleue Iesus to be Christe.
column8: Verily, verily, I say unto thee, unless a ma be born again from above he can not see the kingdom of God, which self thing the holy apostle faint Ihon does in this place declare in other terms saying: he can not believe Jesus to be Christe.

column7: For he that beleueth not thys, can not se the kyngdome of god.
column8: For he that believeth not this, can not see the kingdom of god.

column7: To beleue yt Iesus is Christe, is surely to determine and conclude wyth thy self that Iesus is fyrste to the a Sauiour: and secodly, <NOTE> that he is a kynge anoynted wt the oyle of gladnes, perpetually to rule, to preserue, & to defend the so saued by hym, And here saynt Ihons entent and purpose is to declare vnto vs a difference betwene the historiall faythe concernynge Christe (whyche the deuyll also hath, <NOTE> and so all hypocrites) and betwene ye true and sauynge fayth whych beleueth that Christ doth both saue vs and also taketh a continuall charge & regard of our saluation.
column8: To believe that Jesus is Christe, is surely to determine and conclude with thy self that Jesus is fyrste to the a Saviour: and secodly, that he is a king anointed with the oil of gladness, perpetually to rule, to preserve, & to defend the so saved by him, And here saint Ihons intent and purpose is to declare unto us a difference between the historial faith concerning Christe (which the devil also hath, and so all hypocrites) and between the true and saving faith which believeth that Christ does both save us and also takes a continual charge & regard of our salvation.

column7: To thys fayth we be borne agayne whan through the holy goost we be called by the worde to the knowlege of Gods wyll, <NOTE> thintent we maye vnderstande that Iesus is Christe, I meane, that he is such one in whome is reposed all grace, helth, defense, and sauegarde agaynste synne, death, Satan, the worlde and so forth.
column8: To this faith we be born again when through the holy ghost we be called by the word to the knowledge of Gods will, intent we may understand that Jesus is Christe, I mean, that he is such one in whom is reposed all grace, health, defence, and safeguard against sin, death, Satan, the world and so forth.

column7: This he that beleueth, <NOTE> is sayd to be borne of god, as though saint Ihon shulde say: To beleue yt Iesus is Christ is not a worke of humane power & strength, but it is suche a worke whervnto is requyred the power of God & an heauenly renewyng or regeneration wherby the holy goost transformeth vs into newe creatures.
column8: This he that believeth, is said to be born of god, as though saint Ihon should say: To believe that Jesus is Christ is not a work of humane power & strength, but it is such a work whereunto is required the power of God & and heavenly renewing or regeneration whereby the holy ghost transformeth us into new creatures.

column7: And what is this faith whiche is so myghty?
column8: And what is this faith which is so mighty?

column7: It is (as I haue sayde) the same that maketh vs beleue that Iesus is the sonne of god that was baptysed (which thinge is to be comen by water) that suffered death and passion for the redemption of men (which is to be comen by bloude) That Iesus Christ is verite (for the holy ghost doth witnesse it) that is to say both trew god and trewe man.
column8: It is (as I have said) the same that makes us believe that Jesus is the son of god that was baptised (which thing is to be come by water) that suffered death and passion for the redemption of men (which is to be come by blood) That Jesus Christ is verity (for the holy ghost does witness it) that is to say both true god and true man.

column7: And that he is trewe god, thre thinges doth witnesse it in heue, the father the sonne (which is him selfe) and the holy ghost, and these thre be one selfe witnesse.
column8: And that he is true god, thre things does witness it in heaven, the father the son (which is him self) and the holy ghost, and these thre be one self witness.

column7: And that he is trewe man, thre thinges doth witnesse it in erth, the spirite which he hath bequethed into the handes of his father at his death, the water with which he was baptised, P A G Eiij and the bloude which he hath shed with water when his syde was percyd after that he was deade.
column8: And that he is true man, thre things does witness it in earth, the spirit which he hath bequeathed into the hands of his father at his death, the water with which he was baptised, PAGEiij PAGEiij PAGEiij PAGEiij and the blood which he hath shed with water when his side was pierced after that he was dead.

column7: And these thre thinges be one selfe witnesse.
column8: And these thre things be one self witness.

column7: And if we receyue the witnesse of menne, why shuld we not take the witnesse of god (which is infinitely greater than mas) that he is the sonne of god?
column8: And if we receive the witness of men, why should we not take the witness of god (which is infinitely greater than mass) that he is the son of god?

column7: This witnesse was made by god the father in his baptisme. <NOTE> And also he hath testified yt in the mountaine, he hath testified it by the lawe & by the prophetes.
column8: This witness was made by god the father in his baptism. And also he hath testified that in the mountain, he hath testified it by the law & by the prophets.

column7: Who so euer then beleueth that he is the sone of god, he hath the witnesse of god in him, he receyueth the recorde and testimonye of god, he is borne of god and in the spirite of his faith, he is farre stronger ouer ye world and victorious of the worlde.
column8: Who so ever then believeth that he is the soon of god, he hath the witness of god in him, he receiveth the record and testimony of god, he is born of god and in the spirit of his faith, he is far stronger over you world and victorious of the world.

column7: Folowe we then good brethren and systers this generation of God, of fayth and of baptisme and lo we haue ouercome all thynges, that is to wytte the worlde the fleshe and the concupiscences.
column8: Follow we then good brothers and sisters this generation of God, of faith and of baptism and lo we have overcome all things, that is to wit the world the flesh and the concupiscences.

column7: Nowe yf we be rydde and not combred wyth these thynges surely the yuel spirite can haue nothynge in vs but than the spirite of god only may all and doth all in vs. Vnto god then be all thankes honour and glory accordingly.
column8: Now if we be rid and not cumbered with these things surely the evil spirit can have nothing in us but than the spirit of god only may all and does all in us Unto god then be all thanks honour and glory accordingly.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily On the fyrste sondaye after Ester.
column8: : homily On the fyrste sondaye after Ester.

column7: The Gospell on the fyrst sondaye after Ester daye, called lowe sondaye, the.xx. chapter of Ihon. Thargument of thys Gospell.
column8: The Gospel on the fyrst sondaye after Ester day, called low sondaye, the xx chapter of Jhon. Thargument of this Gospel.

column7: How Christ appeareth to hys disciples which were assembled togyther, and of theyr comission that was gyuen them to preache.
column8: How Christ appears to his disciples which were assembled together, and of their commission that was given them to preach.

column7: T He same daye at nyght, whyche was the fyrst daye of the Sabbothes, whan the dores were shut (where the disciples were assembled together for feare of the Iewes) came Iesus, and stode in the mydde, and sayeth vnto them: Peace be vnto you.
column8: THe THe same day at night, which was the fyrst day of the Sabbaths, when the doors were shut (where the disciples were assembled together for fear of the Jewes) came Jesus, and stood in the mid, and sayeth unto them: Peace be unto you.

column7: And whan he had so sayd, he shewed vnto them hys handes, and hys syde.
column8: And when he had so said, he showed unto them his hands, and his side.

column7: Then were the disciples glad wha they sawe the Lorde. <NOTE> Than sayd Iesus to them agayn: Peace be vnto you.
column8: Then were the disciples glad wha they saw the Lord. Than said Jesus to them again: Peace be unto you.

column7: As my father sent me, euen so sende I you also.
column8: As my father sent me, even so send I you also.

column7: And wha he had sayd those wordes, he brethed on them and sayeth vnto them: Receyue the holy goost.
column8: And wha he had said those words, he breathed on them and sayeth unto them: Receive the holy ghost.

column7: Whoseouers synnes ye remytte, they are remytted vnto them.
column8: Whoseouers sins you remytte, they are remitted unto them.

column7: And whosoeuers synnes ye retayne, they are retayned.
column8: And whosoevers sins you retain, they are retained.

column7: But Thomas one of the twelue (whych is called Didimus) was not wyth them, whan Iesus came.
column8: But Thomas one of the twelue (which is called Didimus) was not with them, when Jesus came.

column7: The other disciples therfore sayde vnto hym: we haue sene the Lorde.
column8: The other disciples therefore said unto him: we have seen the Lord.

column7: But he sayde vnto them: excepte I se in hys handes the prynte of the nayles, and put my fnnger into the prynt of the nayles, and thurst my hande into hys syde, I wil not beleue.
column8: But he said unto them: except I see in his hands the print of the nails, and put my fnnger into the print of the nails, and thirst my hand into his side, I will not believe.

column7: And after P A G Eiiij eyghte dayes, agayne hys disciples were wyth in, and Thomas wyth them.
column8: And after PAGEiiij PAGEiiij PAGEiiij PAGEiiij eyghte days, again his disciples were with in, and Thomas with them.

column7: Then came Iesus when the dores were shut, and stode in the myddes, and sayde: peace be vnto youe.
column8: Then came Jesus when the doors were shut, and stood in the mids, and said: peace be unto youe.

column7: After that sayde he to Thomas, brynge thy fynger hyther, and se my handes, and reache hyther thy hande, and thurste into my syde, and be not faythlesse, but beleuyng.
column8: After that said he to Thomas, bring thy finger hither, and see my hands, and reach hither thy hand, and thirst into my side, and be not faithless, but believing.

column7: Thomas answered and sayd vnto hym, my Lorde and my God: Iesus sayth vnto hym: Thomas, because thou haste sene me, thou haste beleued: blessed are they that haue not sene, and yet haue beleued.
column8: Thomas answered and said unto him, my Lord and my God: Jesus say unto him: Thomas, because thou haste seen me, thou haste believed: blessed are they that have not seen, and yet have believed.

column7: And many other sygnes truly dyd Iesus in the presence of hys disciples, <NOTE> whyche are not wrytten in thys boke.
column8: And many other signs truly did Jesus in the presence of his disciples, which are not written in this book.

column7: These are written, that ye might beleue, that Iesus is Christ the sonne of God, and that (in beleuynge) ye myght haue lyfe thorowe hys name.
column8: These are written, that you might believe, that Jesus is Christ the son of God, and that (in believing) you might have life thorough his name.

column7: An exhortacion vpon thys Gospel.
column8: And exhortation upon this Gospel.

column7: T He Gospell of thys daye good people doth declare vnto vs the appearyng of our Lorde Iesu Christ vnto hys disciples after hys resurrection, that is to wyt how he came and shewed hymselfe vnto them, the dores beynge shut for feare of ye Iues.
column8: THe THe Gospel of this day good people does declare unto us the appearing of our Lord Jesu Christ unto his disciples after his resurrection, that is to wit how he came and showed himself unto them, the doors being shut for fear of you Iues.

column7: And here truly he dyd shew the diuersitie of bodyes, and what difference there shalbe betwene the sensuall bodyes, and betwene the spirituall, betwene the materiall and corruptible bodyes in thys worlde, & betwene the spirituall bodyes and incorruptible after the resurrection.
column8: And here truly he did show the diversity of bodies, and what difference there shall between the sensual bodies, and between the spiritual, between the material and corruptible bodies in this world, & between the spiritual bodies and incorruptible after the resurrection.

column7: Trouth it is also that we ought not to suffer any infideles as were the Iues to enter in amonges vs from whome the Apostles dyd shut theyr dores.
column8: Troth it is also that we ought not to suffer any infideles as were the Iues to enter in among us from whom the Apostles did shut their doors.

column7: Nowe Iesus beynge in the myddes of them dydde salute them in gyuynge vnto them hys peace wyth whych gretynge or salutation he conforted and confirmed hys disciples myndes that they shulde nothynge doubt of hys resurrectio whych as the Euangelist Luke wytnesseth they counted but for a dreame. <NOTE> Wherfore he shewed vnto them hys handes and hys syde perced.
column8: Now Jesus being in the mids of them did salute them in gyving unto them his peace with which greeting or salutation he comforted and confirmed his disciples minds that they should nothing doubt of his resurrectio which as the Euangelist Lycia witnesseth they counted but for a dream. Wherefore he showed unto them his hands and his side pierced.

column7: And by thys shewynge of hys handes and feete, Christe openeth two thynges.
column8: And by this show of his hands and feet, Christe openeth two things.

column7: Fyrst by these sygnes he wolde be knowen.
column8: Fyrst by these signs he would be known.

column7: For in affliction is Christ truly knowen.
column8: For in affliction is Christ truly known.

column7: Seconde by them he wolde assure hys disciples of hys glorious resurrection.
column8: Seconde by them he would assure his disciples of his glorious resurrection.

column7: And verely thys shalbe the signe of saluation vnto the faithful at the greate daye of iugement, and the signe of lamentation and of sorowe vnto the infidels which tha shal se whome they haue percyd.
column8: And verily this shall the sign of salvation unto the faithful at the great day of judgement, and the sign of lamentation and of sorrow unto the infidels which tha shall see whom they have pierced.

column7: The faithfull shalbe gretly coforted in seing him as his disciples were at this tyme.
column8: The faithful shall greatly coforted in sing him as his disciples were at this time.

column7: To these disciples I saye he did ones gyue his peace and made them his apostles that is to saye his legates or ambassadours not onely of Iurye, but of al the worlde, in lyke maner as god the father had sent him and made hym apostle in the worlde.
column8: To these disciples I say he did ones gyve his peace and made them his apostles that is to say his legates or ambassadors not only of Jury, but of all the world, in like manner as god the father had sent him and made him apostle in the world.

column7: And he gaue them the holy gost for to remytte synnes, and to pardo in his name, and whose synnes so euer they pardoned shuld be forgyuen in heauen.
column8: And he gave them the holy ghost for to remytte sins, and to pardon in his name, and whose sins so ever they pardoned should be forgiven in heaven.

column7: The pardone of the apostles assuredly was but a signe of the trewe pardone, which was made on hygh alredye.
column8: The pardon of the apostles assuredly was but a sign of the true pardon, which was made on high already.

column7: And vnto them to whome they wolde not remytte here in erthe they shulde not be remytted nor pardoned in heuen.
column8: And unto them to whom they would not remytte here in earth they should not be remitted nor pardoned in heaven.

column7: And this that they did not pardon them, was signe P A G Ev that they were not pardonyd on hygh. <NOTE> Surely it is not man of him selfe that forgiueth, but God.
column8: And this that they did not pardon them, was sign PAGEv PAGEv PAGEv PAGEv that they were not pardoned on high. Surely it is not man of him self that forgives, but God.

column7: For as saynt Cypriane sayth.
column8: For as saint Cyprian say.

column7: Non potest seruus remittere quod in dominu commissum est, that is to say the seruant can not pardone the thinge that is trespassed againste the maister. <NOTE> And therfore saint Ambrose sayth in his boke of Cain & Abell, that synnes be forgiuen by the worde of god wherof the prest is as an interpretour and certain executour.
column8: Non potest seruus remittere quod in dominu commissum est, that is to say the servant can not pardon the thing that is trespassed against the master. And therefore saint Ambrose say in his book of Cain & Abell, that sins be forgiven by the word of god whereof the pressed is as and interpretor and certain executor.

column7: But who were they whome they dyd not forgyue?
column8: But who were they whom they did not forgive?

column7: Truly all those which dyd not giue feith and credence to their wordes.
column8: Truly all those which did not give faith and credence to their words.

column7: Nowe in thys apperinge Thomas called Didimus was not present.
column8: Now in this appearing Thomas called Didimus was not present.

column7: Wherfore when the disciples dyd shewe hym that they had sene our Lorde rysyn agayne to life, whyche had shewed vnto them bothe his handes and hys syde percyd, he answered that he wolde not beleue them, onles he myghte se him and put his finger in to the holes of the nailes and hys hande into hys syde.
column8: Wherefore when the disciples did show him that they had seen our Lord rysyn again to life, which had showed unto them both his hands and his side pierced, he answered that he would not believe them, unless he might see him and put his finger in to the holes of the nails and his hand into his side.

column7: So eighte dayes after oure Lorde the dores beynge shutte, dyd againe apere in the myddes of them as he had done before and gaue them for gretynge hys peace accordynge to the vsage of the Iues, <NOTE> by whyche is vnderstande quietnes of conscience and all goodnes.
column8: So eighte days after our Lord the doors being shut, did again apere in the mids of them as he had done before and gave them for greeting his peace according to the usage of the Iues, by which is understand quietness of conscience and all goodness.

column7: And nowe Thomas was there also vnto whome he sayde (answering hym vnto the wordes whyche he had sayde by hys vnfeithfulnes) beholde my handes and put thy finger into the holes, hold forthe thy hande and put it into my syde.
column8: And now Thomas was there also unto whom he said (answering him unto the words which he had said by his vnfeithfulnes) behold my hands and put thy finger into the holes, hold forth thy hand and put it into my side.

column7: Be no more feithles, but faythfull, hereby declaringe vnto hym that he seeth all, that he heareth all, that he is in all places, and that he maye do all.
column8: Be no more feithles, but faithful, hereby declaring unto him that he sees all, that he hears all, that he is in all places, and that he may do all.

column7: Whiche done, Thomas did confesse hym to be his Lorde and his God.
column8: Which done, Thomas did confess him to be his Lord and his God.

column7: And truly not so much Thomas as the spirite of fayth whiche wyth the fayth entred into hym.
column8: And truly not so much Thomas as the spirit of faith which with the faith entered into him.

column7: At that tyme oure Lorde gaue witnesse of fayth vnto Thomas whiche hathe beleued in seynge of hym, but he dothe gyue farre greater prayse and comendacion vnto them whiche haue beleued, and yet haue not sene hym in person corporally, but only spiritually with the eye of feyth or mystically in forme of breade in the moost blessed sacrament of the aulter, and also vnto them whiche shall beleue him.
column8: At that time our Lord gave witness of faith unto Thomas which hath believed in sing of him, but he doth gyve far greater praise and commendation unto them which have believed, and yet have not seen him in person corporally, but only spiritually with the eye of faith or mystically in form of bread in the most blessed sacrament of the alter, and also unto them which shall believe him.

column7: Then let vs beleue him, by seynge him spiritually, and so doyng we shal be more happy then Thomas, in thys that he hath sene hym corporally.
column8: Then let us believe him, by sing him spiritually, and so doing we shall be more happy then Thomas, in this that he hath seen him corporally.

column7: Now, sayth the Euangelist, al these thinges be wryten vnto vs, to thende that we shulde beleue that Iesus is Christ the sonne of God: <NOTE> and in beleuyng this, that we shulde haue euerlastynge lyfe by his name.
column8: Now, say the Euangelist, all these things be written unto us, to th'end that we should believe that Jesus is Christ the son of God: and in believing this, that we should have everlasting life by his name.

column7: For asmuch as the ende and vse of all the sygnes and miracles of Christe is that by them we shulde be broughte and allured to the true fayth in Christ, which thyng shal make vs to enioye euerlastyng blysse through his name that is to wit, by his word. <NOTE> For verely Gods word is the vertue & power of God vnto the helth & saluation of al that beleue on Christ Iesus our Lorde & redemer.
column8: For as as the end and use of all the signs and miracles of Christe is that by them we should be brought and allured to the true faith in Christ, which thing shall make us to enjoy everlasting bliss through his name that is to wit, by his word. For verily Gods word is the virtue & power of God unto the health & salvation of all that believe on Christ Jesus our Lord & redeemer.

column7: To who with ye father & holy goost be glory & praise for euer.
column8: To who with you father & holy ghost be glory & praise for ever.

column7: Ame: homily The Epistle on the seconde sondaye after Ester.
column8: Am: homily The Epistle on the seconde sondaye after Ester.

column7: The.i. Epistle of Peter the.ij. Chapter.
column8: The i Epistle of Peter the ij Chapter.

column7: Thargument The Apostle saynt Peter doth exhort vs here to folow Christ in al thynges, euen as shepe folowe theyr shepherde.
column8: Thargument The Apostle saint Peter does exhort us here to follow Christ in all things, even as sheep follow their shepherd.

column7: P A G Evi M Ost derely beloued brethren, Christe also suffered for vs leauing to vs an exemple, that ye shuld folow his steppes, which dyd no synne, neyther was there gyle founde in his mouthe: whiche whan he was reuyled, reuyled not agayne: whan he suffered, he threatened not, but comytted the vengeaunce to hym that iudgeth ryghtuously whiche his owne selfe bare oure synnes in his body on the tree, that we beynge delyuered from synne, shulde lyue vnto ryghtuousnes.
column8: PAGEvi PAGEvi PAGEvi PAGEvi MOst MOst dearly beloved brothers, Christe also suffered for us leaving to us and exemple, that you should follow his steps, which did no sin, neither was there gyle found in his mouth: which when he was reviled, reviled not again: when he suffered, he threatened not, but comytted the vengeance to him that judgeth ryghtuously which his own self bore our sins in his body on the tree, that we being delivered from sin, should live unto righteousness.

column7: By whose strypes ye were healed.
column8: By whose stripes you were healed.

column7: For ye were as shepe goynge astraye, but are now turned vnto the shepherde and byshop of your soules.
column8: For you were as sheep going astray, but are now turned unto the shepherd and bishop of your souls.

column7: T He Epistle of thys daye (good christen people) whiche be the wordes of saynt Peter doth put before our eyes the liefe of our Lord Iesu Christ to this intent & purpose that we shuld folow hym as a perfecte president and exemplar.
column8: THe THe Epistle of this day (good christian people) which be the words of saint Peter does put before our eyes the lief of our Lord Jesu Christ to this intent & purpose that we should follow him as a perfect president and exemplar.

column7: For it is he whiche dyed for vs, which hath done no synne, according to the sayeng of the prophete Esaye, & in whose mouth hath bene founde no gyle nor deceipte. <NOTE> And whiche when any sayde harme by hym, he sayde no harme agayne.
column8: For it is he which died for us, which hath done no sin, according to the saying of the prophet Esaye, & in whose mouth hath be found not gyle nor deceit. And which when any said harm by him, he said no harm again.

column7: When he suffered, he dyd not threaten, but commytted the vengeaunce vnto hym that iudgeth iustly, that is to wit vnto God the father.
column8: When he suffered, he did not threaten, but committed the vengeance unto him that judgeth justly, that is to wit unto God the father.

column7: No doubt God iugeth ryghtly, neyther regardyng mens persons (as doth the worlde) neither only after the outwarde workes but after the hart & outwarde workis to.
column8: No doubt God judgeth rightly, neither regarding men's persons (as does the world) neither only after the outward works but after the heart & outward works to.

column7: And therfore is gods iugement according to the trouthe as Paule sayeth. <NOTE> Furthermore it is Christe whiche hath borne our synnes on the tree of ye crosse that our synnes myghte be so by hym taken awaye and we beynge deade vnto synne shulde lyue vnto iustice.
column8: And therefore is gods judgement according to the truth as Paule sayeth. Furthermore it is Christe which hath born our sins on the tree of you cross that our sins might be so by him taken away and we being dead unto sin should live unto justice.

column7: But what iustice?
column8: But what justice?

column7: Truly vnto the iustice or ryghtuousnes that procedeth of fayth which is fro aboue.
column8: Truly unto the justice or righteousness that proceedeth of faith which is from above.

column7: For we be healed of our synne by hys woundes, by his passion, by his sacrifisyng for vs. Wherfor this is the final vse of our deliueraunce or iustificacion by Christ that we shulde no loger lyue vnto synne, but vnto iustice & vertue.
column8: For we be healed of our sin by his wounds, by his passion, by his sacrificing for us Wherefore this is the final use of our deliverance or justification by Christ that we should no lodger live unto sin, but unto justice & virtue.

column7: As though saint Peter wolde saye.
column8: As though saint Peter would say.

column7: Ye wol be christians who Christe hath redemed, <NOTE> go to, it shall not become you any longer by disobedience towardes youre rulers & superiours to lyue vnto sinne but vnto ryghteousnes, to thintent ye maye be obedient vnto them and suffre persecution, vexacio, yea and dethe of them yf occacion be gyuen, euen as Christ dyd.
column8: the will be christians who Christe hath redeemed, go to, it shall not become you any longer by disobedience towards your rulers & superiors to live unto sin but unto righteousness, to intent you may be obedient unto them and suffer persecution, vexacio, yea and death of them if occasion be given, even as Christ did.

column7: And thys is euen the right vse of Christes passio, to lyue a newe lyfe & to become iust & rightuous in al our lyuyng.
column8: And this is even the right use of Christes passio, to live a new life & to become just & righteous in all our living.

column7: For as the Apostle saynt Paule witnesseth writyng to the Ephesians, <NOTE> we be the workmanshyp of God created & made to do good workes.
column8: For as the Apostle saint Paule witnesseth writing to the Ephesians, we be the workmanshyp of God created & made to do good works.

column7: But to returne to the texte, S. Peter allegeth here vnto you (good people) the workes of the prophete Esaye, where he sayeth, <NOTE> that by the strypes & woundes of Christe ye were healed.
column8: But to return to the text, S. Peter allegeth here unto you (good people) the works of the prophet Esaye, where he sayeth, that by the stripes & wounds of Christe you were healed.

column7: O moost comfortable wordes.
column8: O most comfortable words.

column7: Bytter verely were these strypes to our Sauiour Christe, but they were swete to vs, so swete yt wythout them we shulde haue ben in moost paynfull misery & anguyshe.
column8: Bitter verily were these stripes to our Saviour Christe, but they were sweet to us, so sweet that without them we should have been in most painful misery & anguish.

column7: Let vs than neuer put out of our myndes thys moost comfortable tydynges, thys swete & mery Gospell that Christ bare our synnes in hys body P A G Evij on the tree.
column8: Let us than never put out of our minds this most comfortable tidings, this sweet & merry Gospel that Christ bore our sins in his body PAGEvij PAGEvij PAGEvij PAGEvij on the tree.

column7: Thys treasure I meane the knowlege of this thyng who so wanteth is moost nedy & pore yea he hath nothynge at all.
column8: This treasure I mean the knowledge of this thing who so wants is most needy & poor yea he hath nothing at all.

column7: For this is (no doubte) that preciouse perle that Christe speaketh of in the Gospell of Matheu, where he sayth, <NOTE> that the kyngdome of heauen is lyke vnto a marchaunt man, sekynge goodly perles which wha he founde one precious perle, went and solde al that he had & bought it.
column8: For this is (no doubt) that precious pearl that Christe speaks of in the Gospel of Matheu, where he say, that the kingdom of heaven is like unto a merchant man, seeking goodly pearls which wha he found one precious pearl, went and sold all that he had & bought it.

column7: Nowe thoughe thys thynge be playne ynoughe and apparaunt: yet wyth your pacience I wyll declare vnto you what the moost excellente doctoure of the churche saynte Hierome wryteth vpon thys place. <NOTE> Surely (sayeth saynte Hierome) there is one perle moost precious of all, that is to wit, the knowlege of oure Sauioure and the mystery of his passion and resurrection, whiche whan a marchaunte man hath founde (as saynt Paule the Apostle dyd) he despyseth all the mysteries of the lawe & prophetes & his olde obseruauncies wherin he lyued without reproche, yea and he regardeth them no better tha the parynges of hys nayles or chyppes to thintent to wynne Christe vnto hym.
column8: Now though this thing be plain enough and apparent: yet with your patience I will declare unto you what the most excellent doctor of the church faint Hierome writes upon this place. Surely (sayeth faint Hierome) there is one pearl most precious of all, that is to wit, the knowledge of our Saviour and the mystery of his passion and resurrection, which when a merchant man hath found (as saint Paule the Apostle did) he despiseth all the mysteries of the law & prophets & his old observancy wherein he lived without reproach, yea and he regardeth them not better than the parings of his nails or chyppes to intent to win Christe unto him.

column7: Thys Christe (as Ihon baptist witnesseth) is the lambe of God which taketh awaye the synne of the worlde. <NOTE> Where as before his commynge we were as shepe wandering wythout a sheperde but nowe by fayth we be conuerted vnto oure sheperde which is the onely good shepherde, and vnto the byshop of our soules which is eternall, alwayes mediatoure and intercessoure for vs, alwayes presentyng and offerynge hymselfe for vs. Let vs than good people follow his couersation.
column8: This Christe (as Ihon baptist witnesseth) is the lamb of God which takes away the sin of the world. Where as before his coming we were as sheep wandering without a sheperde but now by faith we be converted unto our sheperde which is the only good shepherd, and unto the bishop of our souls which is eternal, always mediator and intercessoure for us, always presenting and offering himself for us Let us than good people follow his conversation.

column7: Let vs beare paciently al thingis for the loue of hym, which hath suffred so many tribulations and extreme paynes for vs. Let vs not synne wyllingly Let vs not speake any vntrouthe, fraude, dissimulation, and lyes.
column8: Let us bear patiently all things for the love of him, which hath suffered so many tribulations and extreme pains for us Let us not sin willingly Let us not speak any untruth, fraud, dissimulation, and lies.

column7: Let vs not curse, if any say euyl of vs. Let vs not threaten if any do greue vs. Let vs giue vp all vengeaunce vnto God.
column8: Let us not curse, if any say evil of us Let us not threaten if any do grieve us Let us give up all vengeance unto God.

column7: Let vs remembre ye good whiche he hath done vs by his glorious passion, that we maye be deade with him as to him, and mortified by his spirite as to vs. Let vs liue no more in beastly wise to our selues but in most clenly sorte to him, which is our iustice, for we be the shepe which he hath conuerted from wandering forthe of the right path, from errour & infidelitie, vnto fayth.
column8: Let us remember you good which he hath done us by his glorious passion, that we may be dead with him as to him, and mortified by his spirit as to us Let us live no more in beastly wise to our selves but in most cleanly sort to him, which is our justice, for we be the sheep which he hath converted from wandering forth of the right path, from error & infidelity, unto faith.

column7: He is our shepherd, let vs worthely folow him vnto ye pasture of life.
column8: He is our shepherd, let us worthily follow him unto you pasture of life.

column7: He is our bishop, our mediatour our intercessour, our oblacion.
column8: He is our bishop, our mediator our intercessor, our oblation.

column7: And how do we feare that we shulde not be exalted to his glorye?
column8: And how do we fear that we should not be exalted to his glory?

column7: Let vs haue this faith that none is refused which foloweth hym mekely and paciently.
column8: Let us have this faith that none is refused which followeth him meekly and patiently.

column7: Who so euer hath thys fayth can not peryshe, yea there was neuer so great a sinner but that this mediatour & raunsomer hath satisfied from him, if being truly conuerted and penitent for his synnes he be garnished and cladde with this frutefull fayth and brenning charitie and hope in him which is our only sauiour & redemer.
column8: Who so ever hath this faith can not perish, yea there was never so great a sinner but that this mediator & ransomer hath satisfied from him, if being truly converted and penitent for his sins he be garnished and clad with this fruitful faith and brenning charity and hope in him which is our only saviour & redeemer.

column7: To whom with the euerlasting father of heauen & holy goost be glory without ende, in secula seculorum.
column8: To whom with the everlasting father of heaven & holy ghost be glory without end, in secula seculorum.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospel on the second sonday after Ester day The.x. chapter of Ihon. Targument.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the second sonday after Ester day The x chapter of Jhon. Targument.

column7: P A G Eviij Christe is the true shepherde.
column8: PAGEviij PAGEviij PAGEviij PAGEviij Christe is the true shepherd.

column7: I Esus said to his disciples.
column8: IEsus IEsus said to his disciples.

column7: I am the good shepeherde.
column8: I am the good shepherd.

column7: A good shepherde giueth his life for hys shepe.
column8: A good shepherd gives his life for his sheep.

column7: An hyred seruaunt, and he whyche is not the shepherd neyther the shepe are his owne, seeth the wolf come and leueth the shepe and fleeth and the wolfe catcheth and scattereth the shepe.
column8: And hired servant, and he which is not the shepherd neither the sheep are his own, sees the wolf come and leveth the sheep and fleeth and the wolf catches and scattereth the sheep.

column7: The hired seruaut fleeth because he is an hyred seruaunt, and careth not for the shepe.
column8: The hired seruaut fleeth because he is and hired servant, and careth not for the sheep.

column7: I am the good shepeherd and knowe my shepe, and I am knowen of myne.
column8: I am the good shepherd and know my sheep, and I am known of mine.

column7: As my father knoweth me, euen so know I also my father.
column8: As my father knoweth me, even so know I also my father.

column7: And I geue my lyfe for the shepe, and other shepe I haue, whych are not of thys fold, Them also muste I brynge, and they shall heare my voyse, and there shall be one folde and one shepeherde.
column8: And I give my life for the sheep, and other sheep I have, which are not of this fold, Them also must I bring, and they shall hear my voyse, and there shall be one fold and one shepherd.

column7: IN this Gospel good people our Lord doth shew vs, that he is the true and right shepherd.
column8: IN this Gospel good people our Lord does show us, that he is the true and right shepherd.

column7: And it is good reason, for he only hath giuen himselfe vnto the death, and hath quyckened all hys shepe.
column8: And it is good reason, for he only hath given himself unto the death, and hath quickened all his sheep.

column7: He alonly doth nourish with his doctrine all his shepe with the fode of euerlastinge life.
column8: He alonely does nourish with his doctrine all his sheep with the food of everlasting life.

column7: Yf the wolfe doth come, that is the greate deuell of hell or any of hys members, he neuer forsaketh his shepe but doth defende and delyuer them from the force and myghte of the enemye, for he is stronge aboue all, & is more myghty then all.
column8: If the wolf does come, that is the great devil of hell or any of his members, he never forsaketh his sheep but does defend and deliver them from the force and might of the enemy, for he is strong above all, & is more mighty then all.

column7: And also the shepe be hys, and he hath bought them with a greate pryce, which is aboue all prices.
column8: And also the sheep be his, and he hath bought them with a great price, which is above all princes.

column7: He doth loue them according to the price, yt is to say, more than any thought can thinke or tonge expresse.
column8: He does love them according to the price, that is to say, more than any thought can think or tongue express.

column7: And he hath not alonly boughte them agayne, but he hathe made them and created them so that they be his owne workes and his owne shepe.
column8: And he hath not alonely bought them again, but he hath made them and created them so that they be his own works and his own sheep.

column7: He surely is the shepherde by who al thinges bene made.
column8: He surely is the shepherd by who all things be made.

column7: Wherfore naturally he ca not hate them.
column8: Wherefore naturally he ca not hate them.

column7: He is no forgetfull shepherde, but he is a shepherde knowing all, he can forget nothinge.
column8: He is no forgetful shepherd, but he is a shepherd knowing all, he can forget nothing.

column7: For as the eternal father knowith al: so in like maner he knoweth al. As ye father eternal knowith al in giuing him al, in like maner he knowith his shepe in giuing the all.
column8: For as the eternal father knoweth all: so in like manner he knoweth all As you father eternal knoweth all in giving him all, in like manner he knoweth his sheep in giving the all.

column7: For he giueth them life, wisedome & might.
column8: For he gives them life, wisdom & might.

column7: Yea and suche life, wisdome, and might, as is aboue the capacitie of the worlde.
column8: Yea and such life, wisdom, and might, as is above the capacity of the world.

column7: For those that be accordinge to the worlde be but shadowes of them.
column8: For those that be according to the world be but shadows of them.

column7: And by this wisdom which surmouteth ye world, his shepe know him.
column8: And by this wisdom which surmouteth you world, his sheep know him.

column7: This is ye good herdina giuing life to al, knowing al & which is almighty.
column8: This is the good herdina giving life to all, knowing all & which is almighty.

column7: But the hired shepherd is none such.
column8: But the hired shepherd is none such.

column7: He woll not dye for his shepe.
column8: He will not die for his sheep.

column7: He doth not giue them life.
column8: He does not give them life.

column7: Yea when the wolfe commeth he doth leue them forasmoch as they be not his owne.
column8: Yea when the wolf comes he does leave them forasmuch as they be not his own.

column7: He hath neither made them nor yet bought them againe.
column8: He hath neither made them nor yet bought them again.

column7: He therfore rennyth awaye, and letteth them be loste, and deuoured wyth the wolfe, and fynally go into euerlasting damnatio.
column8: He therefore rennyth away, and lets them be lost, and devoured with the wolf, and finally go into everlasting damnatio.

column7: He is vnmighty.
column8: He is unmighty.

column7: He is ignorant & cleane vnlike vnto the good herdma.
column8: He is ignorant & clean unlike unto the good herdma.

column7: Furthermore this hired shepherd hath but a lytle & a particuler flocke.
column8: Furthermore this hired shepherd hath but a little & a particular flock.

column7: But ye good herdma hath a grete flocke, he hath the slocke of ye natio of Israel & of al other nations.
column8: But you good herdma hath a great flock, he hath the slock of you natio of Israel & of all other nations.

column7: He hath the vniuersal flocke, whyche from daye to daye he leadethe and gatheryth to gether, that they may heare his swete voice & hys holy doctrine (whyche is the doctrine of the gospell) tyll tyme that all the worlde shall be but one flocke, and that there be but one herdman, whyche is our Lord P A G Eix Iesu Christe, as it is sayde here.
column8: He hath the universal flock, which from day to day he leadeth and gatheryth to gether, that they may hear his sweet voice & his holy doctrine (which is the doctrine of the gospel) till time that all the world shall be but one flock, and that there be but one herdsman, which is our Lord PAGEix PAGEix PAGEix PAGEix Jesu Christe, as it is said here.

column7: And there shalbe made one shepecote and one herdman.
column8: And there shall made one shepecote and one herdsman.

column7: Now by this parable good frendes we be taught and enformed of the true office of Christ, and wherfore he came into thys worlde.
column8: Now by this parable good friends we be taught and informed of the true office of Christ, and wherefore he came into this world.

column7: Hys office whervnto he was sent of hys father was to teach vs and also to saue vs. As touchynge hys doctrine and teachynge, who euer in fedynge of hys flocke was more vigilant, more busy, more paynfull than he was?
column8: His office whereunto he was sent of his father was to teach us and also to save us As touching his doctrine and teaching, who ever in feeding of his flock was more vigilant, more busy, more painful than he was?

column7: Who euer ministred to hys shepe more diligently the fode of the euangelicall veritie?
column8: Who ever ministered to his sheep more diligently the food of the evangelical verity?

column7: All that herde hym speake and preach were astonnyed vpon hys doctrine.
column8: All that herd him speak and preach were astonnyed upon his doctrine.

column7: For he taught them not after the fashion of the scribes and pharisees whych neuertheles were the greate doctours & learned men of the lawe but as one hauynge a wonderfull grace and authoritie.
column8: For he taught them not after the fashion of the scribes and pharisees which nevertheless were the great doctors & learned men of the law but as one having a wonderful grace and authority.

column7: Yea euen his very enemyes were copelled to testifie of hym that he taught the waye of God in trouth, as appeareth in the.xxij. chapter of Matheu.
column8: Yea even his very enemies were copelled to testify of him that he taught the way of God in troth, as appears in the xxij chapter of Matheu.

column7: Neyther dyd Christ only teach hys shepe, that is to saye, those that folowed hym lyke shepe that were well nere lost, but he also healed them bestowynge euen hys very lyfe for them.
column8: Neither did Christ only teach his sheep, that is to say, those that followed him like sheep that were well never lost, but he also healed them bestowing even his very life for them.

column7: For I praye you dyd he not dye for our synnes?
column8: For I pray you did he not die for our sins?

column7: Was it not he only which with his bloude wasshed awaye the fylthynes of oure synnes?
column8: Was it not he only which with his blood washed away the filthiness of our sins?

column7: Yea doubtles.
column8: Yea doubtless.

column7: But who be these hyrelynges whyche whan they se the wolfe come to deuoure the shepe they rune theyr waye?
column8: But who be these hirelings which when they see the wolf come to devour the sheep they rune their way?

column7: Surely these be those whych preach ye worde and that also purely and syncerely, but they prech it for lucre, for honoure, for glorye, or for the belyes sake.
column8: Surely these be those which preach you word and that also purely and sincerely, but they preach it for lucre, for honour, for glory, or for the belies sake.

column7: These I saye be no true herdmen but hyrelynges, for these dryue not awaye the rauenous wolues that is to saye the deuyll and hys lymmes I meane the Antichristes whych persecute & deuoure Christes flocke, but as soone as persecution & trouble for the worde commeth, <NOTE> anone they are gone.
column8: These I say be not true herdsmen but hirelings, for these drive not away the ravenous wolves that is to say the devil and his limbs I mean the Antichristes which persecute & devour Christes flock, but as soon as persecution & trouble for the word comes, anon they are gone.

column7: Of these do the prophete Ieremy speake, sayenge: Wo be vnto the shepeherders that destroye and skatter my flocke.
column8: Of these doe the prophet Jeremy speak, saying: Woe be unto the shepeherders that destroy and skatter my flock.

column7: I wyll therfore vysite the wyckednes of theyr ymaginations.
column8: I will therefore visit the wickedness of their imaginations.

column7: It is true that the Apostle wryteth. <NOTE> Qui episcopatu desiderat bonu opus concupiscit, that is to saye: He that desyreth an ouersyght or a cure ouer a flocke (whych after the greke worde is called a byshoprych) coueteth a good worke.
column8: It is true that the Apostle writes. Qui episcopatu desiderat bonu opus concupiscit, that is to say: He that desireth and ouersyght or a cure over a flock (which after the greke word is called a byshoprych) covets a good work.

column7: Lo sayeth saynt Ierome wrytynge to Oceanus) the Apostle calleth a byshopryke a worke and not a dignitie, <NOTE> a laboure and not a deyntenes, a worke wherby through humilitie he muste be lowly & not to swelle in pryde.
column8: Lo sayeth saint Ierome writing to Oceanus) the Apostle calls a byshopryke a work and not a dignity, a labour and not a deyntenes, a work whereby through humility he must be lowly & not to swelle in pride.

column7: For a byshop or curate must be fautles, sobre, full of good doctrine, not gyuen to foule and fylthy gaynes, but meke, diligent, full of charitie accordynge to thexemple of Christ the hygh and supreme shepeherde of all and the shepeherde of shepeherdes whych as thys Gospell sayeth gaue hys owne lyfe for the sauegarde and health of hys shepe that is to saye of all vs that folowe and beleue on hym.
column8: For a bishop or curate must be fautles, sober, full of good doctrine, not given to foul and filthy gains, but meek, diligent, full of charity according to thexemple of Christ the high and supreme shepherd of all and the shepherd of shepherds which as this Gospel sayeth gave his own life for the safeguard and health of his sheep that is to say of all us that follow and believe on him.

column7: Wherfore my brethren and systers to conclude how happy be we for to haue suche a herdman & for to know to loue, to folowe, to heare hys swete voyce that gyueth lyfe, to heare hys doctrine, to be refectioned & fedde wyth the meate whyche gyueth euerlastynge lyfe, to haue wysedome and myght that surmouteth the worlde by the sayd our herdmen, lyghtenyng vs in hym by fayth, drawynge vs to hym by hope, & inflamynge P A G Ex vs by charitie.
column8: Wherefore my brothers and sisters to conclude how happy be we for to have such a herdsman & for to know to love, to follow, to hear his sweet voice that gyveth life, to hear his doctrine, to be refectioned & fed with the meat which gyveth everlasting life, to have wisdom and might that surmouteth the world by the said our herdsmen, lightning us in him by faith, drawing us to him by hope, & inflaming PAGEx PAGEx PAGEx PAGEx us by charity.

column7: Vnto hym therfore be glorye in all the nations wythin the compasse of ye erth for euer and euer.
column8: Unto him therefore be glory in all the nations within the compass of you earth for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.iij. sonday after Ester.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the iij sonday after Ester.

column7: The fyrst epistle of saynt Peter the.ij. Chapter.
column8: The fyrst epistle of saint Peter the ij Chapter.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Peter exhorteth to laye asyde all vyce, to absteyne from fleshly lustes and to obeye worldlye rulers.
column8: Peter exhorteth to say aside all vice, to abstain from fleshly lusts and to obey worldly rulers.

column7: D Earely beloued brethre, I besech you as straugers and pylgrems, abstayne fro fleshly lustes, <NOTE> which fyght agaynste the soule, <NOTE> and se that ye haue honest conuersacio among the Gentils, that where as they backbyte you as euyll doars, they maye se your good workes, <NOTE> and prayse God in the daye of visitation.
column8: Dearly Dearly beloved brethren, I beseech you as straugers and pylgrems, abstain from fleshly lusts, which fight against the soul, and se that you have honest conuersacio among the Gentiles, that where as they backbyte you as evil doars, they may see your good works, and praise God in the day of visitation.

column7: Submytte youre selues therfore vnto al maner ordinauce of man for the Lordes sake, <NOTE> whether it be vnto the Kynge, as vnto the chiefe heed: other vnto rulars, as vnto the that are sent of hym, for the punyshemet of euyl doars: but for the laud of them, that do well.
column8: Submytte your selves therefore unto all manner ordinance of man for the Lords sake, whither it be unto the King, as unto the chief heed: other unto rulars, as unto the that are sent of him, for the punyshemet of evil doars: but for the laud of them, that do well.

column7: For so is the wyll of God, that wyth well doynge ye maye stoppe the mouthes of folysh and ignoraunte men: as fre, and not as hauyng the libertye for a cloke of maliciousnes, but euen as the seruautes of God.
column8: For so is the will of God, that with well doing you may stop the mouths of foolish and ignorant men: as from, and not as having the liberty for a cloak of maliciousness, but even as the seruautes of God.

column7: Honoure al men. <NOTE> Loue brotherly feloshyp.
column8: Honour all men. Love brotherly feloshyp.

column7: Feare God, honoure the Kynge.
column8: Fear God, honour the King.

column7: Seruauntes obey your masters wyth feare, not onely yf they be good and courteous: but also thoughe they be frowarde.
column8: Servants obey your master's with fear, not only if they be good and courteous: but also though they be forward.

column7: For it cometh of grace in Christ Iesus our Lorde.
column8: For it comes of grace in Christ Jesus our Lord.

column7: T Hys Epistle, good christian brethern & systers is very excellent and notable.
column8: This This Epistle, good christian brother & sisters is very excellent and notable.

column7: For in it is handeled the second part of Christianitie that is to wit, how in thys liefe after we haue ones receyued and taken the euangell or glad tydynges of oure saluation (whych thyng we call commonly in englyshe a gospell) we ought to lyue.
column8: For in it is handled the second part of Christianitie that is to wit, how in this lief after we have ones received and taken the evangel or glad tidings of our salvation (which thing we call commonly in english a gospel) we ought to live.

column7: In the processe that goeth before thys epistle, saynt Peter taught and shewed ye other parte of Christianitie, whych is of fayth and howe we ought to beleue the gospell and also how we be edified and buylded vpon Christ the corner stone, wheras before that tyme we were the chyldren of vengaunce and as abiectes and castawayes in gods syght but nowe we be made the chyldren of God by Christ.
column8: In the process that goes before this epistle, saint Peter taught and showed you other part of Christianitie, which is of faith and how we ought to believe the gospel and also how we be edified and builded upon Christ the corner stone, whereas before that time we were the children of vengeance and as abjects and castaways in gods sight but now we be made the children of God by Christ.

column7: Whyche treasure truly saynt Peter doth extolle and lyfte vp wyth prayses aboue measure, so that it were well with vs, if after the knowlege of so greate ryches we myght be lycenced forth with to departe out of thys miserable lyfe.
column8: Which treasure truly saint Peter does extol and lift up with praises above measure, so that it were well with us, if after the knowledge of so great riches we might be licenced forth with to depart out of this miserable life.

column7: But forasmoch as we dye not by and by after the receyuing of so greate commodities & felicities, therfore nowe doth saynt Peter teache vs how and by what meanes we shuld lyue here in erth that we dye not eternally.
column8: But forasmuch as we die not by and by after the receiving of so great commodities & felicities, therefore now does saint Peter teach us how and by what means we should live here in earth that we die not eternally.

column7: For Satan our mortal ennemy neuer slepeth but euer watcheth that he maye eyther quite and cleane plucke vs frome gods worde, or at lest waye that he myght wery vs and make vs slauthful and negligent in doyng of good workes.
column8: For Satan our mortal enemy never sleepeth but ever watches that he may either quite and clean pluck us from gods word, or at lest way that he might weary us and make us slauthful and negligent in doing of good works.

column7: For assuredly it commethe so commenly to passe, that forthwyth when we heare by the preachyng of the gospell, that we be set at peax wyth God & iustified in hys syght by only faith in him, then noman wil do any longer P A G Exi any goodnes at al, whych thynge no doubte chaunced euen in saynt Peters tyme. <NOTE> By reason wherof he toke occasion to wryte these thynges concernyng the institution of the christian liefe.
column8: For assuredly it cometh so commonly to pass, that forthwith when we hear by the preaching of the gospel, that we be set at peax with God & justified in his sight by only faith in him, then noman will do any longer PAGExi PAGExi PAGExi PAGExi any goodness at all, which thing no doubt chanced even in saint Peters time. By reason whereof he took occasion to write these things concerning the institution of the christian lief.

column7: As though this holy Apostle Peter wold say.
column8: As though this holy Apostle Peter would say.

column7: Good brethern syth ye haue now receyued the gospell, and syth ye be iustified by fayth in Christ, now it shalbe very good and necessarie for you to goo about to redresse your maner of lyuing, and to absteyne from carnal and flesshely desires and lustes.
column8: Good brother sith you have now received the gospel, and sith you be justified by faith in Christ, now it shall very good and necessary for you to goo about to redress your manner of living, and to abstain from carnal and fleshly desires and lusts.

column7: But it is an horrible thyng to be spoken, that fleshly disires and lustes do not cease no not in the iustified persons.
column8: But it is and horrible thing to be spoken, that fleshly disires and lusts do not cease no not in the justified persons.

column7: Yea we se by daily experience that then more and more carnall desires do breake forth, not bicause this faulte commeth by the gospel, <NOTE> many ennemyes of the Gospell and papystes blasphemously do allege, but bycause Satan is the ennemy of the gospel and of the iustice whych the gospell teacheth.
column8: Yea we see by daily experience that then more and more carnal desires do break forth, not because this fault comes by the gospel, many enemies of the Gospel and papists blasphemously do allege, but because Satan is the enemy of the gospel and of the justice which the gospel teaches.

column7: He doubtles neuer slepeth though we slepe neuer so soudly & carelessy, but lyke a roryng lyon he runnyth and leapeth about, seakyng whome to deuoure as thapostle S. Peter doth testifie in the ende of this firste epistle. <NOTE> But forasmoche as the power of desires and lustes is so greate yea & that after iustification receyued, saynt Peter vseth certein warlyk wordes wherwith he expresseth the strength and power of these carnal & worldly desires, which he sayth do warre againste vs and (as the greke worde purporteth) do dayly exercise with vs a pyched felde, <NOTE> whych thing the scripture otherwhyles calleth the conflycte of the fleshe and of the spirite, agaynst whych no outwarde workes can do any good.
column8: He doubtless never sleepeth though we sleep never so soudly & carelessy, but like a roaring lion he runnyth and leapeth about, seakyng whom to devour as apostle S. Peter does testify in the end of this firste epistle. But forasmuch as the power of desires and lusts is so great yea & that after justification received, saint Peter uses certain warlyk words wherewith he expresses the strength and power of these carnal & worldly desires, which he say do war against us and (as the greke word purporteth) do daily exercise with us a pyched field, which thing the scripture otherwhiles calls the conflict of the flesh and of the spirit, against which no outward works can do any good.

column7: As the holy fathers also haue confessed and complayned of themselues. <NOTE> For saint Hierom hymselfe when he sought euery where a present remedy agaynst the desyres of the fleshe, at last after longe delyberation departed into the woode, trustynge that by thys meane he shulde eschue and shake of from hym hys carnal and fleshely desyres, but it wolde not be, for euen in his very mysery and vexation of hys body whych he toke vpon hymselfe for that purpose, he yet thought he satte at Rome amoges the Romane ladies and fayre wenches, and that he daunced wyth them.
column8: As the holy father's also have confessed and complained of themselves. For saint Hierom himself when he sought every where a present remedy against the desires of the flesh, at last after long delyberation departed into the wood, trusting that by this mean he should eschew and shake of from him his carnal and fleshly desires, but it would not be, for even in his very misery and vexation of his body which he took upon himself for that purpose, he yet thought he sat at Room amoges the Roman ladies and fair wenches, and that he danced with them.

column7: Wherfore syth here in thys lyfe it is not in our powers vtterly to do awey carnall desyres: the holy fathers and prophetes desyred wyth hygh lamentation that they myghte be lycenced to departe out of thys vale of teares to the heauenly and perfyte ioyes.
column8: Wherefore sith here in this life it is not in our powers utterly to do away carnal desires: the holy father's and prophets desired with high lamentation that they might be licenced to depart out of this vale of tears to the heavenly and perfect joys.

column7: For here they thought themselues onely straungers and as pylgrimes or wayfarynge men.
column8: For here they thought themselves only strangers and as pylgrimes or wayfaring men.

column7: Whych thynge thapostle Paule in hys seconde epistle to the Corinthians doth wonderfully well declare, wrytynge on thys wyse.
column8: Which thing apostle Paule in his seconde epistle to the Corinthians does wonderfully well declare, writing on this wise.

column7: We knowe, <NOTE> sayeth he, that yf our erthy mansion of thys dwellynge were destroyed, we haue a buyldynge of God, an habitation not made wyth handes, but eternall in heauen.
column8: We know, sayeth he, that if our erthy mansion of this dwelling were destroyed, we have a building of God, and habitation not made with hands, but eternal in heaven.

column7: And therfore sygh we desyrynge to be clothed wyth our mansion whych is from heuen, so yet yf that we be founde clothed and not naked, and so forth.
column8: And therefore sygh we desiring to be clothed with our mansion which is from heaven, so yet if that we be found clothed and not naked, and so forth.

column7: Now, suche straungers S. Peter here wylleth vs to be, whyche ought continually to loke vp, to contende, and laboure thyther, settynge asyde all earthly thynges, all cares and worldly desyres, and euer to stande redy in hope to be delyuered out of thys our earthly tabernacle or hostrye, and to enioye P A G Exij the euerlastynge inheritaunce.
column8: Now, such strangers S. Peter here willeth us to be, which ought continually to look up, to contend, and labour thither, setting aside all earthly things, all cares and worldly desires, and ever to stand ready in hope to be delivered out of this our earthly tabernacle or hostry, and to enjoy PAGExij PAGExij PAGExij PAGExij the everlasting inheritance.

column7: Howbeit yet in the meane season, good people, we teache not (as do these Anabaptistes) that he that hath ryches, shulde cast them awaye, but that he cleaue not in harte vnto them, lyke as other places of holy scripture do teach vs and namely thys present epistle of S. Peter, whych by a similitude of straungers or pylgrimes, doth declare vnto vs, that in ye hostrye of thys present worlde, we shulde be in loue with nothynge, we shulde vaynly & ambiciously require nothynge, that is in our hoostes house whych is the worlde, euen none otherwyse, than a straunger, a pawmer, or wayfarynge body doth, whych knoweth yt nothinge in hys ynne or lodgynge doth pertayne vnto hym, <NOTE> only maketh hast homewarde into hys owne cotrey.
column8: Howbeit yet in the mean season, good people, we teach not (as doe these Anabaptists) that he that hath riches, should cast them away, but that he cleave not in heart unto them, like as other places of holy scripture do teach us and namely this present epistle of S. Peter, which by a similitude of strangers or pylgrimes, does declare unto us, that in you hostry of this present world, we should be in love with nothing, we should vainly & ambitiously require nothing, that is in our hosts house which is the world, even none otherwise, than a stranger, a pawmer, or wayfaring body does, which knoweth that nothing in his in or lodging does pertain unto him, only makes haste homeward into his own cotrey.

column7: Now they whych be in loue & admiration with any thynge in thys worlde, they can not be called forenners, straungers, or pylgrimes, but cytizens and inhabitauntes of thys worlde.
column8: Now they which be in love & admiration with any thing in this world, they can not be called foreigners, strangers, or pylgrimes, but citizens and inhabitants of this world.

column7: Wherfore it is great folly now amonges christen men to be in loue wyth the thynges of the worlde, & to seke pleasure in carnall desyres, <NOTE> syth suche thynges belonge no more to christians.
column8: Wherefore it is great folly now among christian men to be in love with the things of the world, & to seek pleasure in carnal desires, sith such things belong no more to christians.

column7: But I praye you what vyces doth saynt Peter cal here desyres?
column8: But I pray you what vices does saint Peter call here desires?

column7: Surely not only those grosse faultes, but also ye inwarde croked affections, which doubtles be the very causes of those outwarde and grosse vyces.
column8: Surely not only those gross faults, but also you inward crooked affections, which doubtless be the very causes of those outward and gross vices.

column7: Saynt Peter therfore wrytyng especyally to the Iewes whych were disperpled abrode in dyuers countreyes and by them vnto vs Englyshe men and to all others ryght tederly exhorteth them (callynge them hys moost derely beloued brethren) to absteyne as forenners and pylgrymes, from all fleshly lustes, that is to wit, all vices, whyche of nature do stycke to the fleshe, whych vices do kepe continuall warre and batell agaynst the soule and spirite of ma that euer more tendeth and laboureth to do the wyll of God.
column8: Saint Peter therefore writing especially to the Jewes which were disperpled abroad in dyuers countries and by them unto us English men and to all others right tederly exhorteth them (calling them his most dearly beloved brothers) to abstain as foreigners and pilgrims, from all fleshly lusts, that is to wit, all vices, which of nature do stick to the flesh, which vices do keep continual war and battle against the soul and spirit of ma that ever more tendeth and laboureth to do the will of God.

column7: And he wylleth them that they haue honest conuersacion amonges the Gentyls or paynems whych worshipped false Goddes amonge whome at that tyme when saynte Peter wrote thys epistle the christen men lyued.
column8: And he willeth them that they have honest conversation among the Gentles or painims which worshipped false Gods among whom at that time when faint Peter wrote this epistle the christian men lived.

column7: Saint Peter therfore wyll not that christen men shulde departe from the panyms, but that they shulde lyue honestly amoges them, to thintent that where as they backbyte them as euyll doers, they myght se theyr good workes & myghte prayse and glorifye God in the daye of visitation, <NOTE> that is to saye, that the paynyms beynge more ryghtly instructed and taught by the honeste lyfe of the christians, myghte by gods visitation be called also to the Gospell and so to haue a better opinion and iudgement of gods worde, whych thynge in dede came to passe in the primatiue church by the godly exemple of the good Apostolicall fathers and christen people in Rome and els where.
