column8: Saint Peter therefore will not that christian men should depart from the painims, but that they should live honestly amoges them, to intent that where as they backbyte them as evil doers, they might see their good works & might praise and glorify God in the day of visitation, that is to say, that the painims being more rightly instructed and taught by the honest life of the christians, might by gods visitation be called also to the Gospel and so to have a better opinion and judgement of gods word, which thing in deed came to pass in the primitive church by the godly exemple of the good Apostolical father's and christian people in Room and else where.

column7: Where as now the paynims and infidels as be turkes & Iues be rather plucked frome the Gospell then allured vnto it by thexemple of those that woll neuertheles be called the successours of Peter and Paule and ye vicares of Christ.
column8: Where as now the paynim's and infidels as be turkes & Iues be rather plucked from the Gospel then allured unto it by thexemple of those that will nevertheless be called the successors of Peter and Paule and you vicars of Christ.

column7: Wherfore it is to be feared, leste God wyll visite them, not by heapynge vpon them hys benefytes and graces whych they refuse & neglecte, but by pourynge vpon them hys iuste yre and vengeaunce accordynge to theyr desertes.
column8: Wherefore it is to be feared, lest God will visit them, not by heaping upon them his benefits and graces which they refuse & neglect's, but by pouring upon them his just ire and vengeance according to their deserts.

column7: Be you subiecte therfore good christen people to the worde P A G Exiij of God.
column8: Be you subject therefore good christian people to the word PAGExiij PAGExiij PAGExiij PAGExiij of God.

column7: Obeye hys commaundementes prescribed in the same.
column8: Obey his commandments prescribed in the same.

column7: Let your lyght shyne before me and namely before the proude Pharisees & infidels (whych thynke there is no God) that they may se your good workes and honest conuersacion and glorifye your father in heauen.
column8: Let your light shine before me and namely before the proud Pharisees & infidels (which think there is no God) that they may see your good works and honest conversation and glorify your father in heaven.

column7: Submytte your selues, <NOTE> according to Peters counsayle here, vnto euery humane creature, that is to saye, vnto all maner ordinaunce or power whych humane creatures do administer, and that euen for the Lordes sake.
column8: Submytte your selves, according to Peters counsel here, unto every humane creature, that is to say, unto all manner ordinance or power which humane creatures do administer, and that even for the Lords sake.

column7: For it pleaseth the Lorde ye shulde so do, lest your conscience shulde be polluted and defyled wyth synne through disobedience.
column8: For it pleases the Lord you should so do, lest your conscience should be polluted and defiled with sin through disobedience.

column7: And euen here maye ye lerne good people that when ye obeye the publyke ruler and magistrate ye do please God by thys obedience.
column8: And even here may you learn good people that when you obey the public ruler and magistrate you do please God by this obedience.

column7: Be obedient therfore sayth S. Peter whether it be vnto ye kynge as vnto ye chefe head, or vnto rulers as to the yt are sent of hym for the punyshmet of euel doers. <NOTE> And surely as wytnesseth S. Paule, whoseoeuer resysteth power, resysteth the ordinauce of God.
column8: Be obedient therefore say S. Peter whither it be unto you king as unto you chief head, or unto rulers as to the that are sent of him for the punyshmet of evil doers. And surely as witnesseth S. Paule, whoseoeuer resisteth power, resisteth the ordinance of God.

column7: For he is the minister of God to take vengeaunce on them that do euell.
column8: For he is the minister of God to take vengeance on them that do evil.

column7: Wherfore ye must obeye (sayth Paule) not only for feare of vengaunce, but also bycause of conscience.
column8: Wherefore you must obey (say Paule) not only for fear of vengeance, but also because of conscience.

column7: For as it foloweth here in the text so is the wyll of God, that with well doing ye may stoppe the mouthes of folyshe and ignorant persons, whych oftentymes iuge such thinges as they vnderstand not, and whych esteme the gospell and the worde of god by the maners of the gospellers (whych of humayne frayltie mnay tymes do fal into fowle vices) and do not esteme it by the owne proper nature. <NOTE> Wheras in very dede it is the power & vertue of God to the helth and saluation of al them that beleue.
column8: For as it followeth here in the text so is the will of God, that with well doing you may stop the mouths of foolish and ignorant persons, which oftentimes judge such things as they understand not, and which esteem the gospel and the word of god by the manners of the gospelers (which of human frailty mnay times do fall into fowl vices) and do not esteem it by the own proper nature. Whereas in very deed it is the power & virtue of God to the health and salvation of all them that believe.

column7: Let vs then good christen brethern so be free and vse the libertie of the gospell, that we haue it not for a cloke of maliciousnes, workyng (vnder the pretence of it) all naughtynes accordyng to our foule lustes and desires, as many gospellers and euangelicall brethren do, which be in dede no gospellers but bablers no trewe brethern but false brethern, no christians but antichristes and sklauders to gods holy worde.
column8: Let us then good christian brother so be free and use the liberty of the gospel, that we have it not for a cloak of maliciousness, working (under the pretence of it) all naughtynes according to our foul lusts and desires, as many gospelers and evangelical brothers do, which be in deed no gospelers but babblers no true brother but false brother, no christians but antichrists and sklauders to gods holy word.

column7: Let vs then be no feyned christians, but ryght christians and seruauntes of God.
column8: Let us then be no feigned christians, but right christians and servants of God.

column7: Let vs honoure and haue in reuerence all men. <NOTE> Let vs loue fraternitie not fraternitie of monkes, fryers, nunnes, and such other cloystered & disguysed people whych vnder ye cloke of fraternitie deuoured pore wydowes houses & the lyuinges of other in their fratryes, & of whom the christen people were fowly mocked and seduced while they perswaded them that they could not do better then be of their brotherhode or fraternitie, whych in dede was nothyng elles but a swarme of ydle dranes that lyued not by the swette of their face (as gods commaundement wylled them) but by other mens labours vnder the pretence of longe prayer, but let vs loue such brotherhode and fraternitie as gods worde alloweth, whych is yt we shulde loue one an nother after a gentle and christian maner, al lordlines and proude lokes layde downe, and when we make a dyner or feast, not to call the ryche whych may quyte vs agayne but our poore christen brethern and systers whych cannot acquite vs, but our father in heuen shal acquite it vs. This is the fraternitie or brotherhode that Christ alloweth and P A G Exiiij that saynt Peter doth here speake of.
column8: Let us honour and have in reverence all men. Let us love fraternity not fraternity of monks, friars, nuns, and such other cloistered & disguised people which under you cloak of fraternity devoured poor widows houses & the livings of other in their fratryes, & of whom the christian people were foully mocked and seduced while they persuaded them that they could not do better then be of their brotherhode or fraternity, which in deed was nothing else but a swarm of idle dranes that lived not by the sweat of their face (as gods commandment willed them) but by other men's labours under the pretence of long prayer, but let us love such brotherhode and fraternity as gods word alloweth, which is that we should love one and neither after a gentle and christian manner, all lordliness and proud looks laid down, and when we make a dinner or feast, not to call the rich which may quite us again but our poor christian brother and sisters which cannot acquit us, but our father in heaven shall acquit it us This is the fraternity or brotherhode that Christ alloweth and PAGExiiij PAGExiiij PAGExiiij PAGExiiij that saint Peter does here speak of.

column7: Let vs then feare God whych doth prospere our obedience and helpeth vs that we maye truly honour all men, that we may loue brotherhode and gyue due honour to our kynge whych is our supreme hedde next vnder Christe none excepted, neyther bishop of Rome nor other.
column8: Let us then fear God which does prosper our obedience and helpeth us that we may truly honour all men, that we may love brotherhode and gyve due honour to our king which is our supreme head next under Christe none excepted, neither bishop of Room nor other.

column7: For if there were, <NOTE> Peter wold not haue passed it ouer wt silence.
column8: For if there were, Peter would not have passed it over with silence.

column7: Neyther is it to be thought that Peter which was one of Christes Apostles and that of the chefest knewe not the bisshop of Romes power or his own power.
column8: Neither is it to be thought that Peter which was one of Christes Apostles and that of the chiefest knew not the bishop of Romes power or his own power.

column7: He agnized no such supremacie as the bishoppe of Rome doth chalenge vnto him as S. Peters successour.
column8: He agnized no such supremacy as the bishop of Room does challenge unto him as S. Peters successor.

column7: Saint Peter byddeth vs here feare god and honour the king.
column8: Saint Peter biddeth us here fear god and honour the king.

column7: If the bisshop of Rome were to be honoured next God and before kynges, why doth saynt Peter set the kynge nexte God?
column8: If the bishop of Rome were to be honoured next God and before kings, why does saint Peter set the king nexte God?

column7: Yea why doth he speake nothynge at all of the byshop of Romes authoritie?
column8: Yea why does he speak nothing at all of the bishop of Romes authority?

column7: So ye se good christen people that saynte Peter maketh nothynge wyth the byshoppe of Rome, and yet he sayeth he is hys successour.
column8: So you see good christian people that faint Peter makes nothing with the bishop of Room, and yet he sayeth he is his successor.

column7: But what shulde I speake more of thys mater?
column8: But what should I speak more of this mater?

column7: I doubt not but loge ago there is none of you but regardeth the byshop of Rome none otherwyse then an other byshop in hys byshopryche ought to be regarded.
column8: I doubt not but loge ago there is none of you but regardeth the bishop of Rome none otherwise then and other bishop in his byshopryche ought to be regarded.

column7: Let him medle with his owne flocke, with vs he hath no thing a do, any otherwise then one christen man hath to do with an other.
column8: Let him meddle with his own flock, with us he hath no thing a doe, any otherwise then one christian man hath to do with and other.

column7: Let vs therfore charitably pray for him that he may execute his office in his owne diocese and not entre into other mens officies.
column8: Let us therefore charitably pray for him that he may execute his office in his own diocese and not enter into other men's offices.

column7: Let vs tha honour our kinge next vnto God as our supreme hedde according to S. Peters counsayle in this epistle, and according to the aduise of saynt Paule in the place before alleged.
column8: Let us than honour our king next unto God as our supreme head according to S. Peters counsel in this epistle, and according to the advise of saint Paule in the place before alleged.

column7: Let also seruauntes obey theyr maisters not only if they be good & courteouse, but also thoughe they be froward, not doynge seruice to the eye (as Paule sayth wryting to the Ephesians (and as they do that go aboute to please men, <NOTE> but as the seruautes of Christ, doing the wyll of God from the harte with good will, seruinge the Lord and not men.
column8: Let also servants obey their masters not only if they be good & courteous, but also though they be froward, not doing service to the eye (as Paule say writing to the Ephesians (and as they do that go about to please men, but as the seruautes of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart with good will, serving the Lord and not men.

column7: For it is then thanke worthy, sayth saynt Peter.
column8: For it is then thank worthy, say saint Peter.

column7: Hitherto haue I brefly declared vnto you the meanyng of this Epistle.
column8: Hitherto have I briefly declared unto you the meaning of this Epistle.

column7: Now therfore good people if ye wol be true christians, if ye woll be true feithfull persons, boost not of your feyth in wordes only, but declare in youre dedes and workes that ye haue the feith of Christ.
column8: Now therefore good people if you will be true christians, if you will be true faithful persons, boost not of your faith in words only, but declare in your deeds and works that you have the faith of Christ.

column7: Shewe your beleue in such workes as thys Apostle saynt Peter doth here exhort you vnto, and then shal we beleue that you haue the right belefe & fayth in Iesu Christ, which in whom so euer it is in, can not but fructifie and brynge forth fruct euen as sede doth that is sowne in the good grounde, <NOTE> some an hundreth folde some syxty fold some thyrty folde.
column8: Show your believe in such works as this Apostle saint Peter does here exhort you unto, and then shall we believe that you have the right belief & faith in Jesu Christ, which in whom so ever it is in, can not but fructify and bring forth fruct even as seed does that is sown in the good ground, some and hundreth fold some syxty fold some thyrty fold.

column7: And this feyth shall iustifie you and make you the chyldren of god and inheritours of his heuely kyngdome which was prepared for you before the beginnyng of the world by the father of heuen, <NOTE> to whome with the sonne and holy goost be glorye and prayse eternally.
column8: And this faith shall justify you and make you the children of god and inheritors of his heuely kingdom which was prepared for you before the beginning of the world by the father of heaven, to whom with the son and holy ghost be glory and praise eternally.

column7: : homily The Gospell on the thyrde sondaye after Ester.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the thyrde sondaye after Ester.

column7: The.xvi. chapter of Ihon. Thargument Of the spiritual raigne & kyngdom of Christ.
column8: The xvi chapter of Jhon. Thargument Of the spiritual reign & kingdom of Christ.

column7: P A G Exv I Esus sayd to his disciples.
column8: PAGExv PAGExv PAGExv PAGExv IEsus IEsus said to his disciples.

column7: After a whyle ye shal not se me, <NOTE> and agayne after a whyle ye shall se me, for I go to the father, Then sayd some of hys disciples betwene themselues: what is thys that he sayeth vnto vs, after whyle, ye shall not se me, and agayne after a whyle ye shall se me, and that I go to the father?
column8: After a while you shall not see me, and again after a while you shall see me, for I go to the father, Then said some of his disciples between themselves: what is this that he sayeth unto us, after while, you shall not see me, and again after a while you shall see me, and that I go to the father?

column7: They sayd therfore: what is this that he sayeth: after a whyle? we can not tell what he sayeth.
column8: They said therefore: what is this that he sayeth: after a while? we can not tell what he sayeth.

column7: Iesus perceaued that they wolde aske hym, and sayd vnto them: Ye enquyre of thys betwene youre selues, because I sayd after a whyle ye shall not se me, and agayne after a whyle ye shall se me.
column8: Jesus perceived that they would ask him, and said unto them: You inquire of this between your selves, because I said after a while you shall not see me, and again after a while you shall see me.

column7: Verely verely I saye vnto you: ye shall wepe and lament, but contrary wyse, the worlde shall reioyse.
column8: Verily verily I say unto you: you shall weep and lament, but contrary wise, the world shall rejoice.

column7: Ye shall sorowe, <NOTE> but your sorowe shalbe turned to ioye.
column8: You shall sorrow, but your sorrow shall turned to joy.

column7: A woman whan she trauayleth, hath sorowe, because her houre is come.
column8: A woman when she travaileth, hath sorrow, because her hour is come.

column7: But as sone as she is delyuered of the chylde, she remebreth no more the anguysh, for ioy that a ma is borne into the world.
column8: But as soon as she is delivered of the child, she remebreth no more the anguish, for joy that a ma is born into the world.

column7: And ye now therfore haue sorow: but I wyl se you agayne, and your hertes shal reioyse, and your ioye shall no man take from you.
column8: And you now therefore have sorrow: but I will see you again, and your herts shall rejoice, and your joy shall no man take from you.

column7: IN the Gospell of thys present daye (good christe people) it is fyrst to be consydered & marked, how Christ sheweth hys louynge disciples of hys crosse and passion that he shulde suffre for the redemption of the worlde, and also of hys moost glorious vprysynge agayne from death to lyfe.
column8: IN the Gospel of this present day (good christe people) it is fyrst to be considered & marked, how Christ shows his loving disciples of his cross and passion that he should suffer for the redemption of the world, and also of his most glorious vprysynge again from death to life.

column7: And furthermore how and in what wyse by hys vprysyng or resurrection he shulde comence hys raigne and haue accesse to hys father.
column8: And furthermore how and in what wise by his vprysyng or resurrection he should commence his reign and have access to his father.

column7: And assuredly the preachyng and fore shewynge hereof was ryght necessary to the Apostles of Christ to be often made and dryuen into theyr heades.
column8: And assuredly the preaching and before show hereof was right necessary to the Apostles of Christ to be often made and driven into their heads.

column7: For the flesh (as Christe sayeth hymselfe) is weake, and agayne the articles of oure religion be suche that they surmount the sklender capacitie of mans wyt neyther can they easely be perceyued.
column8: For the flesh (as Christe sayeth himself) is weak, and again the articles of our religion be such that they surmount the slender capacity of men wit neither can they easily be perceived.

column7: Thys is the cause why Christ lyke a faythful mayster neuer ceaseth to dryue into hys disciples heades the sume & cotent of our fayth, to thintent he myght fully execute thoffice that he came for.
column8: This is the cause why Christ like a faithful master never ceases to drive into his disciples heads the fume & content of our faith, to intent he might fully execute intent that he came for.

column7: Now thys is hys sentence and mynde whych he declareth to hys disciples, Wythin a lytle whyle O you my louynge scholers and disciples I shalbe betrayed vnto the Iues, as I haue often tymes heretofore shewed vnto you that I shulde be condemned, <NOTE> scourged, bobbed and at last nayled to the crosse.
column8: Now this is his sentence and mind which he declareth to his disciples, Within a little while Oh you my loving scholars and disciples I shall betrayed unto the Iues, as I have often times heretofore showed unto you that I should be condemned, scourged, bobbed and at last nailed to the cross.

column7: And for asmuch as euen lyke as Ionas was in the whales bely thre dayes and thre nyghtes I must in lykewyse be buryed in the grounde for the space of thre dayes and thre nyghtes: <NOTE> Therfore for a lytle whyle in dede ye shall not se me.
column8: And for as as even like as Jonas was in the whale's belly thre days and thre nights I must in likewise be buried in the ground for the space of thre days and thre nights: Therefore for a little while in deed you shall not see me.

column7: But agayne after a lytle whyle, that is to wyt, the thyrde daye after whan I shall ryse agayne ye shall verely se me, how be it that shall not be longe, for I must awaye to my father and begyn wt hym my spirituall raygne. <NOTE> Lo my deare frendes wt such wordes Christe teacheth hys apostles what maner thyng his kyngdo shuld be & how ye comyng is to ye same.
column8: But again after a little while, that is to wit, the thyrde day after when I shall rise again you shall verily see me, how be it that shall not be long, for I must away to my father and begin with him my spiritual reign. Lo my deer friends with such words Christe teaches his apostles what manner thing his kingdom should be & how the coming is to you same.

column7: Assuredly ye kingdo or raigne of Christ is none other thynge tha that Christ hath coquered the world, syn, death, sata, & hell, & furthermore hath P A G Exvi taken of his father all power both in heuen and in erth in such sort as hensforth he is to be ye most puissaunt and mighty kinge ouer the mount Sion, <NOTE> leading and gouernyng his subiectes with the holy spirite of comforte.
column8: Assuredly the kingdom or reign of Christ is none other thing tha that Christ hath coquered the world, sin, death, sata, & hell, & furthermore hath PAGExvi PAGExvi PAGExvi PAGExvi taken of his father all power both in heaven and in earth in such sort as henceforth he is to be the most puissant and mighty king over the mount Sion, leading and governing his subjects with the holy spirit of comfort.

column7: Into this his kingdom it behoued hym to entre by the crosse, by sheding of his mooste precious bloude and by death, euen as the prophete Dauid longe before had prophecied of him, sayeng, he shall drynke of the floude in the waye, <NOTE> and therefore he shall lyft vp his heade.
column8: Into this his kingdom it behooved him to enter by the cross, by shedding of his most precious blood and by death, even as the prophet Dauid long before had prophesied of him, saying, he shall drink of the flood in the way, and therefore he shall lift up his head.

column7: Now this spirituall kingdome was not moche knowne to his apostles.
column8: Now this spiritual kingdom was not much known to his apostles.

column7: For they thought rather that the kingdom of Christ shulde haue ben a worldly and an outwarde kyngdome whych thinge they styl loked for, vntyl the spirite was gyuen them whych taught them the knowlege hereof, and how they ought to come vnto it and to gette it, and how to perseuer and continue in the same.
column8: For they thought rather that the kingdom of Christ should have been a worldly and and outward kingdom which thing they still looked for, until the spirit was given them which taught them the knowledge hereof, and how they ought to come unto it and to get it, and how to persever and continue in the same.

column7: If we therfore good brethren and systers be lykewise mynded to entre into thys kingdome, and by Christ to vanquysh synne, death, Satan, and hel: we must nedes acknowlege and take Christ for oure Lorde and sauiour, for our kinge and hyghe bishop, fastelye beleuing that we be reconciled and made at one agayne with the father of heuen by his bloude and in suffering and doinge the thinges that Paule speaketh where he sayth. <NOTE> If we shall suffer togither with him: we shall also reigne with him.
column8: If we therefore good brothers and sisters be likewise minded to enter into this kingdom, and by Christ to vanquish sin, death, Satan, and hell: we must needs acknowledge and take Christ for our Lord and saviour, for our king and high bishop, fastelye believing that we be reconciled and made at one again with the father of heaven by his blood and in suffering and doing the things that Paule speaks where he say. If we shall suffer together with him: we shall also reign with him.

column7: Seconde, <NOTE> we haue here (good people) an exemple of oure ignoraunce and blyndnesse and that in thapostles.
column8: Seconde, we have here (good people) and exemple of our ignorance and blindness and that in apostles.

column7: For loke how lytle they attayned the mystery of the gospell wythout the holy goost: so lytle can we also attayne by oure owne powers to iustice or soule health.
column8: For look how little they attained the mystery of the gospel without the holy ghost: so little can we also attain by our own powers to justice or soul health.

column7: But harke your selues out of the very texte the rudenes or ignoraunce of the appostles.
column8: But hark your selves out of the very text the rudeness or ignorance of the apostles.

column7: Christ had shewed them that after a litle whyle they shulde not se him, & agayne after a lytle whyle they shulde se him agayne for he muste go to hys father.
column8: Christ had showed them that after a little while they should not see him, & again after a little while they should see him again for he must go to his father.

column7: This must nedes be vnderstande of his death and resurrection and of his spiritual kyngdome. <NOTE> For assuredly to go to his father is nothinge elles, but to fulfyll all thynges (as it is declared in the.v. chapi. to the Ephesians) and by hys holye gooste to exalte gloryfie & saue mankynde, or (to speake the wordes of ye prophete) dona dare hominibus to gyue gyftes to men.
column8: This must needs be understand of his death and resurrection and of his spiritual kingdom. For assuredly to go to his father is nothing else, but to fulfil all things (as it is declared in the v chapi. to the Ephesians) and by his holy ghost to exalt glorify & save mankind, or (to speak the words of the prophet) dona dare hominibus to gyve gifts to men.

column7: But I praye you, how do thapostles vnderstande thys?
column8: But I pray you, how do apostles understand this?

column7: They talke and conferre wt themselues what meaneth that he sayeth, after a whyle ye shall not se me: and agayn, after a whyle ye shal se me, we knowe not (saye they) what he speketh.
column8: They talk and confer with themselves what means that he sayeth, after a while you shall not see me: and again, after a while you shall see me, we know not (say they) what he speaketh.

column7: Lo my frendes the apostles do here confesse theyr ignoraunce and that they atteyne not to ye wordes that he spake albeit he had spoke often tymes before of hys crosse deathe and resurrection vnto them.
column8: Lo my friends the apostles do here confess their ignorance and that they attain not to you words that he spoke albeit he had spoke often times before of his cross death and resurrection unto them.

column7: Wherfore I do not a lytle wonder, what these men meane whyche fyghte so strongly for the defence of theyr owne naturall and carnall power syth they se here so manyfestly yt the apostles themselues whyche had Christe so moch conuersaunt amonges them coulde not by theyr owne mere power before the holy gooste came vnto them, vnderstande the spirituall kyngdome of Christe.
column8: Wherefore I do not a little wonder, what these men mean which fight so strongly for the defence of their own natural and carnal power sith they see here so manifestly that the apostles themselves which had Christe so much conversant among them could not by their own mere power before the holy ghost came unto them, understand the spiritual kingdom of Christe.

column7: So that it manifestly appeareth that while they woll be doctours and teachers of other, they be them selues full of all blyndenes and ignoraunce.
column8: So that it manifestly appears that while they will be doctors and teachers of other, they be them selves full of all blindness and ignorance.

column7: Thys therfore is the summe and effecte of thys P A G Exvij place, that the flesh in suche thynges as perteine to iustification can do no good, onles the holy gost beyng communitate by the word be receiued and had.
column8: This therefore is the sum and effect of this PAGExvij PAGExvij PAGExvij PAGExvij place, that the flesh in such things as pertain to justification can do no good, unless the holy ghost being communitate by the word be received and had.

column7: For as the prophete Ieremy recordeth, <NOTE> they shalbe taught of God and not of themselues.
column8: For as the prophet Jeremy recordeth, they shall taught of God and not of themselves.

column7: Thyrdly Christe doth preuent his apostles when he espyed them not to atteine his wordes and that they wold aske him the meanyng of the same, sayeng vnto them in thys wise.
column8: Thyrdly Christe does prevent his apostles when he espied them not to attain his words and that they would ask him the meaning of the same, saying unto them in this wise.

column7: Of thys ye do question amonges your selues that I sayd a litle and ye shall not see me and agayne a lytle and ye shall se me.
column8: Of this you do question among your selves that I said a little and you shall not see me and again a little and you shall see me.

column7: Verely verely I saye vnto you ye shall wepe and lamente, but the worlde shal reioyce.
column8: Verily verily I say unto you you shall weep and lament, but the world shall rejoice.

column7: Ye shal sorow but your sorowe shalbe turned into ioye.
column8: You shall sorrow but your sorrow shall turned into joy.

column7: Lo how Christ tendereth his apostles, he shaketh them not of for their rudenes and ignoraunce but moste gentlye instructeth them, shewinge them howe his format wordes ought to be vnderstand, sayenge vnto them in thys wise.
column8: Lo how Christ tendereth his apostles, he shakes them not of for their rudeness and ignorance but most gently instructeth them, show them how his format words ought to be understand, saying unto them in this wise.

column7: Ye shall wepe and be sory but why? bycause ye shall see youre Lorde and mayster apprehended and take nayled vpon the crosse and put to death. <NOTE> Then shall calamitie and sorow begynne, and principally this shall trouble you, that the world shal reioyce at your aduersitie and your maysters aduersitie.
column8: You shall weep and be sorry but why? because you shall see your Lord and master apprehended and take nailed upon the cross and put to death. Then shall calamity and sorrow begin, and principally this shall trouble you, that the world shall rejoice at your adversity and your masters adversity.

column7: And euen as Christ had spoken, so it came to passe concernyng both hys owne crosse affliction and heuines & also his apostles.
column8: And even as Christ had spoken, so it came to pass concerning both his own cross affliction and heaviness & also his apostles.

column7: For do ye thynke yt a lytle crosse vnto hym when yt he was reuiled and vpbrayded of the Iues sayeng vnto hym, let God delyuer hym if he woll haue hym?
column8: For do you think that a little cross unto him when that he was reviled and upbraided of the Iues saying unto him, let God deliver him if he will have him?

column7: I omytte and passe ouer with silence the thing that he himself complayneth of wher be sayeth by his prophet Dauid, <NOTE> I am a worme and not a man a laughing stocke or an obprobrie of men and the refuse of the people.
column8: I omit and pass over with silence the thing that he himself complaineth of where be sayeth by his prophet Dauid, I am a worm and not a man a laughing stock or and obprobrie of men and the refuse of the people.

column7: As many as behold me mocke me, they shake their hedes at me.
column8: As many as behold me mock me, they shake their hedes at me.

column7: What is thys but to cast Christ into trouble and heuynesse & not only hym but also hys apostles and louyng fredes, whyche kept hym company?
column8: What is this but to cast Christ into trouble and heaviness & not only him but also his apostles and loving fredes, which kept him company?

column7: And albeit Christe dothe specially in this place speake of the tyme of his owne crosse whych shulde be the occasion of weping and mournyng to his apostles, yet hys mynde was hereby to shewe what state and fortune is to be loked for in thys world vnto all true christias.
column8: And albeit Christe doth specially in this place speak of the time of his own cross which should be the occasion of weeping and mourning to his apostles, yet his mind was hereby to show what state and fortune is to be looked for in this world unto all true christias.

column7: True christians no doubt can not but suffer in this world moch displeasures and persecution, wheras the wicked persons and such as care neither for God nor deuell make good chere and lyue according to their hartes ease. <NOTE> Hereunto agreeth Salomon in his prouerbes sayeng.
column8: True christians no doubt can not but suffer in this world much displeasures and persecution, whereas the wicked persons and such as care neither for God nor devil make good cheer and live according to their hearts ease. Hereunto agreeth Salomon in his proverbs saying.

column7: Cast not awaye the chastisement of the lord.
column8: Cast not away the chastisement of the lord.

column7: Lo ye se how Christ instructeth his apostles and armeth them with pacience to abyde and suffer thobprobriouse wordes scornes and persecutions of the wicked persons and Antichristes.
column8: Lo you see how Christ instructeth his apostles and armeth them with patience to abide and suffer thobprobriouse words scorns and persecutions of the wicked persons and Antichristes.

column7: And that he willeth the apostles to do, the same he commaudeth and speaketh euen vnto vs so many as wolbe hys disciples and folowers. <NOTE>
column8: And that he wills the apostles to do, the same he commaudeth and speaks even unto us so many as wolbe his disciples and followers.

column7: Fourthly forasmoche as Christe hath tolde hys apostles of the sorowe and heuines & of the persecutions that shuld happen vnto them for hys sake: he nowe agayne doth comforte them declaringe vnto them what shall happen after such stormes of affliction.
column8: Fourthly forasmuch as Christe hath told his apostles of the sorrow and heaviness & of the persecutions that should happen unto them for his sake: he now again does comfort them declaring unto them what shall happen after such storms of affliction.

column7: Your heuines sayth he shalbe chaunged into ioye, as who shulde saye the worlde as sone as they shal haue kylled me woll thynke they haue won the P A G Exviij spurres & that they haue put me downe, but it shall not be so: for ye thyrde daye after shall I ryse agayne from death maugre theyr heades.
column8: Your heaviness say he shall changed into joy, as who should say the world as soon as they shall have killed me will think they have wone the PAGExviij PAGExviij PAGExviij PAGExviij spurs & that they have put me down, but it shall not be so: for you thyrde day after shall I rise again from death maugre their heads.

column7: I shall comforte you, and in your heuynes pacifie you, & make you gladde.
column8: I shall comfort you, and in your heaviness pacify you, & make you glad.

column7: And albeit, after that tyme also ye must styll suffre moch wronge and reproche for my name and for the gospel sake: yet your affliction & crosse shall not laste longe, but eternall ioye shall anone ensue & folowe.
column8: And albeit, after that time also you must still suffer much wrong and reproach for my name and for the gospel sake: yet your affliction & cross shall not laste long, but eternal joy shall anon ensue & follow.

column7: An exemple of thys thynge I wol ye take in a woman that traueleth with chylde: <NOTE> A woman wha she traueleth ye know is in heuynes & payn, for her houre is at hande.
column8: And exemple of this thing I will you take in a woman that traueleth with child: A woman wha she traueleth you know is in heaviness & pain, for her hour is at hand.

column7: But assone as she hath brought forth into the worlde a chylde & is delyuered, she remembreth no more her payne and greife for the ioye she hath of the chylde that is borne into the worlde.
column8: But assoon as she hath brought forth into the world a child & is delivered, she remember no more her pain and grief for the joy she hath of the child that is born into the world.

column7: In semblable wise ye be nowe sadde and heuy for my departure, but I shal come see you agayne, and tha your hartes shal leape for ioye & no man shalbe hable with all the displeasure he can do you, to take awaye this your ioye from you.
column8: In semblable wise you be now sad and heavy for my departure, but I shall come see you again, and than your hearts shall leap for joy & no man shall able with all the displeasure he can do you, to take away this your joy from you.

column7: Assuredly (my frendes) thys similitude whych is here brought forth of Christ, is excedingly comfortable.
column8: Assuredly (my friends) this similitude which is here brought forth of Christ, is exceedingly comfortable.

column7: For fyrst of all yt sheweth that persecution trouble and crosse must as surely folowe the confession of the gospell, as it is sure that a trauelyng woman cannot brynge forth her chyld without sorow and grefe, but in the meane season the Christen man thorough the word of God muste nedes afterwarde haue greate comforte and ioye.
column8: For fyrst of all that shows that persecution trouble and cross must as surely follow the confession of the gospel, as it is sure that a traveling woman cannot bring forth her child without sorrow and grief, but in the mean season the christian man through the word of God must needs afterward have great comfort and joy.

column7: Furthermore this trouble crosse affliction and persecution of the true christians shall not be continuall and euerlastinge, but it shall endure but for a season.
column8: Furthermore this trouble cross affliction and persecution of the true christians shall not be continual and everlasting, but it shall endure but for a season.

column7: And on the contrary parte the worlde shall ioye for a season.
column8: And on the contrary part the world shall joy for a season.

column7: But their ioye shal not longe laste as Christe himself in an other place witnesseth wher he sayth: <NOTE> Wo be to you which laugh here, for ye shal wepe and lamente.
column8: But their joy shall not long laste as Christe himself in and other place witnesseth where he say: Woe be to you which laugh here, for you shall weep and lament.

column7: Albeit in very dede the christian man shall not be cleane voyde of ioye in this worlde but what ioye is thys?
column8: Albeit in very deed the christian man shall not be clean void of joy in this world but what joy is this?

column7: I woll (sayeth Christ) see you agayne, and your hartes shal ioye and no man shal take your ioye from you.
column8: I will (sayeth Christ) see you again, and your hearts shall joy and no man shall take your joy from you.

column7: Vndoubtedly the ioye that Christe here speaketh of is the gladnes and peace of conscience that the true christians shall haue in asmoche as they knowe that God shalbe merciful vnto them throughe Christ and shal kepe and preserue them into euerlasting liefe whych was prepared for them before the worlde was made as Christ hymself witnesseth by the father of heuen.
column8: Undoubtedly the joy that Christe here speaks of is the gladness and peace of conscience that the true christians shall have in as as they know that God shall merciful unto them through Christ and shall keep and preserve them into everlasting lief which was prepared for them before the world was made as Christ himself witnesseth by the father of heaven.

column7: To whome wyth the sonne and holye ghost be thankes &.c.: homily The Epistle on the.iiij. sonday after Ester daye.
column8: To whom with the son and holy ghost be thanks & c: homily The Epistle on the iiij sonday after Ester day.

column7: The.i. chapter of Iames. Thargument.
column8: The i chapter of James. Thargument.

column7: Saynt Iames sheweth that Gods worde is an heuenly gyfte and howe it ought to be receyued.
column8: Saint Iames shows that Gods word is and heavenly gift and how it ought to be received.

column7: M Ost derely beloued brethren, euery good gyft and euery perfect gyft, is from aboue, and comethe downe frome the father of lyghtes wythe whome is no variablenes, neyther is he chaunged vnto darkenes.
column8: MOst MOst dearly beloved brothers, every good gift and every perfect gift, is from above, and cometh down from the father of lights wythe whom is no variableness, neither is he changed unto darkness.

column7: Of his owne will begate he vs wyth the word of trouth, that we shulde be the first frutes of his creatures.
column8: Of his own will begat he us with the word of troth, that we should be the first fruits of his creatures.

column7: Wherfore (deare brethren) let euery man be swyfte to heare, slow to speake, slow P A G Exix to wrath.
column8: Wherefore (deer brothers) let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow PAGExix PAGExix PAGExix PAGExix to wrath.

column7: For the wrath of man worketh not that whych is ryghteous before God.
column8: For the wrath of man works not that which is righteous before God.

column7: Wherfore laye a parte all fylthynes and superfluitie of malyciousnes, and receaue with mekenes the word that is grafted in you whych is hable to saue your soules.
column8: Wherefore say a part all filthiness and superfluity of malyciousnes, and receive with meekness the word that is grafted in you which is able to save your souls.

column7: The holy Apostle saynt Iames (good christian brethren and systres) in the epistle of this daye doth fyrste open and declare vnto vs the causes of gods worde frome whence it commeth, and then he commendeth and setteth oute the authoritie of the same as a meane or instrument, whereby throughe new birth or regeneration we be the chyldren of god and as saynt Iames here speaketh the firste frutes of gods creatures.
column8: The holy Apostle saint Iames (good christian brothers and systres) in the epistle of this day does fyrste open and declare unto us the causes of gods word from whence it comes, and then he commends and sets out the authority of the same as a mean or instrument, whereby through new birth or regeneration we be the children of god and as saint Iames here speaks the firste fruits of gods creatures.

column7: As towching the causes of gods worde, ye shall vnderstande that the gospell or word of God is no humaine thinge, it is the word neither of Emperour, Kinge, Prince, Duke nor other temporall ruler, neither is it any meritorious word whych ca chauce vnto vs for our own deseruinges or merites, neyther yet is it an vnpythy weake or vnperfect word whych eyther of it selfe is not stronge ynough, or nedeth any other worde to the perfection and accomplyshement therof, but it is a diuine or heuenly worde a good gyft of God and perfecte, that is to saye whyche hath almyghty god for authour of yt, whych god gyueth of his mere grace and fauour & whych is stronge and full of efficacie and power according to saynt Paule whych sayth it is the power of god to the helth and sauetye of all such as beleue the same. <NOTE> It is perfecte forasmoche as it neither nedeth any other word neyther yet can it suffre any other to be matched with it.
column8: As touching the causes of gods word, you shall understand that the gospel or word of God is no human thing, it is the word neither of Emperor, King, Prince, Duke nor other temporal ruler, neither is it any meritorious word which ca chance unto us for our own deservings or merits, neither yet is it and vnpythy weak or unperfect word which either of it self is not strong enough, or needeth any other word to the perfection and accomplishment thereof, but it is a divine or heavenly word a good gift of God and perfect, that is to say which hath almighty god for author of that, which god gyveth of his mere grace and favour & which is strong and full of efficacy and power according to saint Paule which say it is the power of god to the health and sauetye of all such as believe the same. It is perfect forasmuch as it neither needeth any other word neither yet can it suffer any other to be matched with it.

column7: Nowe al thys tendeth to this purpose and intent, that saynt Iames woll comende and set forth vnto vs the authoritie of gods worde, lest by errynge and strayeng out of the waye we myght happen to deceiue our selues thynkyng it ynough & sufficient to heare the worde of god wyth out any maner of regeneracion and newe lyefe.
column8: Now all this tendeth to this purpose and intent, that saint Iames will commend and set forth unto us the authority of gods word, lest by erring and straying out of the way we might happen to deceive our selves thinking it enough & sufficient to hear the word of god with out any manner of regeneration and new lyefe.

column7: For the worde is a farre greater thyng, it is euen an heuenly diuine good and perfecte gyfte whych cometh from aboue euen from the father of lyghtnes, wyth whome is no transmutation of lyght and of darkenes, neither can he suffer that we shuld mengle our dreames and darknes with his lyghtsome worde, I meane our owne inuetios, our blindnes, our careles maners, our carnal lybertie, our euel liefe & so forth.
column8: For the word is a far greater thing, it is even and heavenly divine good and perfect gift which comes from above even from the father of lightness, with whom is no transmutation of light and of darkness, neither can he suffer that we should mengle our dreams and darkness with his lyghtsome word, I mean our own inuetios, our blindness, our careless manners, our carnal liberty, our evil lief & so forth.

column7: We be also here admonished and taught of the final vse of gods worde & wherfore it serueth.
column8: We be also here admonished and taught of the final use of gods word & wherefore it serveth.

column7: Yt serueth doubtles, that by it we shulde be regenerate and be made the fyrste frutes of the creature of god, whych cometh not of oure owne deseruynges, but it is the worke of god the father, whych doth renewe and regendre vs wythe ye worde of trouth that we maye be the first frutes of hys creature.
column8: It serveth doubtless, that by it we should be regenerate and be made the fyrste fruits of the creature of god, which comes not of our own deservings, but it is the work of god the father, which does renew and regendre us wythe you word of troth that we may be the first fruits of his creature.

column7: Saynt Iames therfore in thys place wylleth vs to sette asyde and laye downe all securitie and slauthfulnes towardes the worde of god, and that we shulde praye god that he woll vouchesaue to open & disclose vnto vs the vnderstandynge of hys worde, and that he wolle gyue vs also encrease in the same, that we maye heare the worde wyth frute, vnderstandynge it, and beynge regenerate therby, <NOTE> might be made the fyrst frutes of ye creature of god.
column8: Saint Iames therefore in this place willeth us to set aside and say down all security and slauthfulnes towards the word of god, and that we should pray god that he will vouchesaue to open & disclose unto us the understanding of his word, and that he wool gyve us also increase in the same, that we may hear the word with fruit, understanding it, and being regenerate thereby, might be made the fyrst fruits of the creature of god.

column7: Do not then erre my dere brethre P A G Exx as thoughe it were inoughe only to heare the worde of god and not to vnderstande it wyth the harte, not to catche holde of it by faythe, not to worke well outwardlye.
column8: Do not then err my dear brethren PAGExx PAGExx PAGExx PAGExx as though it were enough only to hear the word of god and not to understand it with the heart, not to catch hold of it by faith, not to work well outwardly.

column7: Euery good and perfyte gyfte is from aboue, that is to saye, the worde of god is perfyte, it nedeth none other worde to stey it, & to make it perfyte.
column8: Every good and perfect gift is from above, that is to say, the word of god is perfect, it needeth none other word to stey it, & to make it perfect.

column7: Yea thou canest neither take it nor vnderstade it perfytly, onles it be gyuen the of god.
column8: Yea thou canst neither take it nor vnderstade it perfectly, unless it be given the of god.

column7: Yt is of it selfe moste perfyte, and it is it also whych onlye can make vs perfyte.
column8: It is of it self most perfect, and it is it also which only can make us perfect.

column7: Yt procedeth frome the father of lyghtes, that is to wytte from god whych is ye only cause of all lyght in such sorte that ye thynge whych we se in vnderstandynge the worde, is of god.
column8: It proceedeth from the father of lights, that is to wit from god which is the only cause of all light in such sort that you thing which we see in understanding the word, is of god.

column7: Yt is also the gyfte of god that hys worde dothe lyghten, for the father is of hymselfe lyght.
column8: It is also the gift of god that his word doth lighten, for the father is of himself light.

column7: Wyth whom is no variablenes nor chaunge into darkenes, that is to saye, he can not abyde nor suffer that the lyght & darknes shuld be confounded or myngled togither.
column8: With whom is no variableness nor change into darkness, that is to say, he can not abide nor suffer that the light & darkness should be confounded or mingled together.

column7: For he is the father of lyght only, and not of darkenes, Neither can he suffer that we shulde glorye and bragge of his worde as of a gyfte and in the meane season do the workes of darkenes.
column8: For he is the father of light only, and not of darkness, Neither can he suffer that we should glory and brag of his word as of a gift and in the mean season do the works of darkness.

column7: And by this the apostle saynt Iames doth moue vs from euyl workes by thexemple of god whyche is intransmutable and inconuertible that is to say he is not now light now darkenes.
column8: And by this the apostle saint Iames does move us from evil works by thexemple of god which is intransmutable and inconuertible that is to say he is not now light now darkness.

column7: And therfore ought not we to folow both lyght and darknes togither.
column8: And therefore ought not we to follow both light and darkness together.

column7: For wyllyngly be gatte he vs wyth the worde of his trouth, that we shulde be the first frutes of his creature. As though saynt Iames wold saye.
column8: For willingly be gat he us with the word of his troth, that we should be the first fruits of his creature. As though saint Iames would say.

column7: Bicause god hath regenerate vs by the word of trouth that we might be now his first frutes, then seing we be his first frutes, it becommeth vs not to folow the darkenes, it becometh vs no more to leade oure lyefe in vyce and naughtines, but it behoueth vs to be doers & not only hearers of the word.
column8: Because god hath regenerate us by the word of troth that we might be now his first fruits, then sing we be his first fruits, it becomes us not to follow the darkness, it becometh us no more to lead our lyefe in vice and naughtiness, but it behooves us to be doers & not only hearers of the word.

column7: In that he sayth, voluntarily, or of his owne will, <NOTE> he excludeth marite.
column8: In that he say, voluntarily, or of his own will, he excludeth marite.

column7: It is called the word of trouth aswel because of it selfe & of the own nature it is true as bicause it maketh other true.
column8: It is called the word of troth aswell because of it self & of the own nature it is true as because it makes other true.

column7: Secondly.
column8: Secondly.

column7: Ye shal diligently note and marke (good people) that thappostle Iames in the latter parte of this epistle doth sturre vs to newe liefe and to such workes as the worde of god and regeneration wold aske.
column8: You shall diligently note and mark (good people) that apostle Iames in the latter part of this epistle does stir us to new lief and to such works as the word of god and regeneration would ask.

column7: For it is euen due and annexed to newe byrth that a man shulde do good workes, as also Paule testifieth sayenge. <NOTE> What shall we then saye, shall we abyde in synne yt grace myght aboud?
column8: For it is even due and annexed to new birth that a man should do good works, as also Paule testifieth saying. What shall we then say, shall we abide in sin that grace might abound?

column7: God forbyd.
column8: God forbid.

column7: We that be deade to synne, howe shall we hereafter lyue in the same? <NOTE> Also to the Ephesians he sayeth.
column8: We that be dead to sin, how shall we hereafter live in the same? Also to the Ephesians he sayeth.

column7: We be gods hadworke created in Christ to do good workes whyche god hathe prepared that we shulde walke in them. <NOTE> And to the Colossians.
column8: We be gods hadworke created in Christ to do good works which god hath prepared that we should walk in them. And to the Colossians.

column7: Wherfore if ye haue risen wythe Christe, seke ye the thynges aboue, regard heuenly thinges & not erthly thinges. wherfore deare brethren (sayeth saynt Iames) let euery man be swyfte to heare, slowe to speake.
column8: Wherefore if you have risen wythe Christe, seek you the things above, regard heavenly things & not earthly things. wherefore deer brothers (sayeth saint Iames) let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak.

column7: By whych wordes he forbyddeth chefely moch talkyng and pratlynge wherby in saynte Iames tyme many dyd bragge (as they do at this daye) of the gospell without chaunging of their former liefe and wythout lyuinge after the gospell. <NOTE> Such persons sainte Iames wolde haue swyft to heare & slow to speake tyl tyme they rightly vnderstande the worde and do P A G Exxi dedes worthy for the same.
column8: By which words he forbiddeth chiefly much talking and prattling whereby in faint Iames time many did brag (as they do at this day) of the gospel without changing of their former lief and without living after the gospel. Such persons saint Iames would have swift to hear & slow to speak till time they rightly understand the word and do PAGExxi PAGExxi PAGExxi PAGExxi deeds worthy for the same.

column7: He willeth vs also to be slowe to wrath, but he wol we shuld be meke and paciet.
column8: He wills us also to be slow to wrath, but he will we should be meek and paciet.

column7: For the wrath of ma worketh not that whych is rightouse before god, that is to saye.
column8: For the wrath of ma works not that which is righteous before god, that is to say.

column7: Ire or wrath & the effectes therof can not do the thynges whych be iust before god, or whyche god requireth of vs. And saynt Iames calleth here the iustice of god, not that where by we be iustifyed before God, but that whych god requireth of vs beyng alredy iustified to the declaration of that iustice whyche iustifieth and whych is gotten by fayth.
column8: Ire or wrath & the effects thereof can not do the things which be just before god, or which god requires of us And saint Iames calls here the justice of god, not that where by we be justified before God, but that which god requires of us being already justified to the declaration of that justice which justifieth and which is got by faith.

column7: Wherfore casting awaye all vnclenlynes and superfluitie of maliciousnes se ye receyue with mekenes the worde that is grafte & implanted in you of god the father of heue. <NOTE> Receyue it (he sayth) with mekenes that is to say with al modestie and reuerence, not after a ryottouse and sediciouse sorte as thoughe ye wolde fyght for it, nor agayne with an euel and struglyng mynde (as many Papistes do) but gladly thankfully and gently.
column8: Wherefore casting away all vnclenlynes and superfluity of maliciousness see you receive with meekness the word that is graft & implanted in you of god the father of heaven. Receive it (he say) with meekness that is to say with all modesty and reverence, not after a ryottouse and seditious sort as though you would fight for it, nor again with and evil and struggling mind (as many Papists do) but gladly thankfully and gently.

column7: For it is the thinge whych is hable to saue youre soules. whych thing also saynt Paule proueth wrytinge to the Romaynes where he teacheth that we be iustified by fayth by the ministery of gods worde. <NOTE>
column8: For it is the thing which is able to save your souls. which thing also saint Paule proves writing to the Romans where he teaches that we be justified by faith by the ministry of gods word.

column7: Nowe therfore good people let vs accordinge to the meanyng of this epistle whych I haue brefly declared vnto youe imbrase this worde of trouthe that saynt Iames doth here speake of, and so imbrace it that we may be couted doers and not hearers only.
column8: Now therefore good people let us according to the meaning of this epistle which I have briefly declared unto youe embrace this word of truth that saint Iames does here speak of, and so embrace it that we may be couted doers and not hearers only.

column7: Thus doynge we shall declare our selues to be the chosen people of God and we shall inioy at last the kyngdom prepared for vs of almyghty God.
column8: Thus doing we shall declare our selves to be the chosen people of God and we shall enjoy at last the kingdom prepared for us of almighty God.

column7: Who be lauded &.c.: homily P A G Exxi The Gospell on the.iiij. sondaye after Ester. the.xvj. chapter of Ihon. Thargument.
column8: Who be lauded & c: homily PAGExxi PAGExxi PAGExxi PAGExxi The Gospel on the iiij sondaye after Ester. the xvj chapter of Jhon. Thargument.

column7: Christe promyseth to sende the holy gooste. and of hys offyce.
column8: Christe promiseth to send the holy ghost. and of his office.

column7: Iesus sayd to hys disciples.
column8: Jesus said to his disciples.

column7: Nowe I go my waye to him that sent me, and none of you asketh me whyther I go.
column8: Now I go my way to him that sent me, and none of you asks me whither I go.

column7: And because I haue sayd such thynges vnto you, your hartes are ful of sorowe.
column8: And because I have said such things unto you, your hearts are full of sorrow.

column7: Neuerthelesse I tel you the trouth, it is expediet for you that I go awaye.
column8: Nevertheless I tell you the troth, it is expediet for you that I go away.

column7: For yf I go not awaye, that coforter wyl not come vnto you.
column8: For if I go not away, that coforter will not come unto you.

column7: But yf I departe, I wyl sende hym vnto you.
column8: But if I depart, I will send him unto you.

column7: And when he is come, he wyl rebuke the worlde of synne, and of ryghtousnesse, and of iudgemente.
column8: And when he is come, he will rebuke the world of sin, and of ryghtousnesse, and of judgement.

column7: Of synne, because they beleue not on me.
column8: Of sin, because they believe not on me.

column7: Of ryghtousnes, because I go to my father, and ye shall se me no more.
column8: Of righteousness, because I go to my father, and you shall see me no more.

column7: Of iudgemente, because the prynce of thys world is iudged alredy.
column8: Of judgement, because the prince of this world is judged already.

column7: I haue yet many thynges to saye vnto youe, but ye cannot beare them away nowe.
column8: I have yet many things to say unto youe, but you cannot bear them away now.

column7: Howbeit, when he is com (whych is the spirite of trouth) he wyl leade you into al trouth.
column8: Howbeit, when he is come (which is the spirit of troth) he will lead you into all troth.

column7: He shal not speake of himselfe, but what so euer he shall heare, that shall he speake and he wyll shewe you thynges to come.
column8: He shall not speak of himself, but what so ever he shall hear, that shall he speak and he will show you things to come.

column7: He shall glorifie me, for he shall receaue of myne, and shall shewe vnto you. <NOTE>
column8: He shall glorify me, for he shall receive of mine, and shall show unto you.

column7: T He cheife parte of this daye gospell good brethren and sistres consistethe in the declaration of the office of the holy ghost which for that purposis P A G Exxij sente of Christe that he myghte reuelate and open the spirituall kingdome of Christ and myght detect the blyndnes of the worlde concernynge this kingdome.
column8: THe THe chief part of this day gospel good brothers and sistres consisteth in the declaration of the office of the holy ghost which for that purposis PAGExxij PAGExxij PAGExxij PAGExxij sent of Christe that he might reuelate and open the spiritual kingdom of Christ and might detect the blindness of the world concerning this kingdom.

column7: For the spirituall kingdome of Christ bicause it consysteth in feyth is not perceyued of the worlde, no more then is his iustice and beatitude, forasmoch as the worlde, bicause it is ledde with reason, requireth an other kingdome, an other iustice, and consequently an other blesse, euen such as be most agreable to the iugement of reason and may be seen wyth the carnall eyen and groped withe the fleshely handes.
column8: For the spiritual kingdom of Christ because it consisteth in faith is not perceived of the world, no more then is his justice and beatitude, forasmuch as the world, because it is led with reason, requires and other kingdom, and other justice, and consequently and other bless, even such as be most agreeable to the judgement of reason and may be seen with the carnal eyes and groped with the fleshly hands.

column7: Suche thinges bicause reason alloweth them, they flatter the worlde, and they be lettes and impedimentes, that the true spirituall raigne or kyngdome of Christe can neuer be rightly vnderstanded of the worlde.
column8: Suche things because reason alloweth them, they flatter the world, and they be lets and impediments, that the true spiritual reign or kingdom of Christe can never be rightly understanded of the world.

column7: And assuredly the disciples dyd here gayly represente the worlde, for they also dyd as yet after a carnall sorte trust and hope vpon the carnall presence of Christe as thoughe he had come into the worlde to set vp some carnal raigne or Empire that all the worlde shulde haue loked vpon and sene. <NOTE> when they harde Christ saye he wolde go agayne to hys father from whom he was sent, their hartes were cold and replenished wyth care and heuynesse.
column8: And assuredly the disciples did here gaily represent the world, for they also did as yet after a carnal sort trust and hope upon the carnal presence of Christe as though he had come into the world to set up some carnal reign or Empire that all the world should have looked upon and seen. when they harden Christ say he would go again to his father from whom he was sent, their hearts were cold and replenished with care and heaviness.

column7: As though they shulde saye vnto hym: We trusted that thou woldeste haue commenced and set vp here a galant and triumphante kyngdome, and now thou sayst that thou wolt departe hence to thy father.
column8: As though they should say unto him: We trusted that thou woldeste have commenced and set up here a galant and triumphant kingdom, and now thou sayest that thou wolt depart hence to thy father.

column7: Assuredly my brethren all we be euen thus naturally affected and disposed before the sendinge of the holy ghost that we styl dreame vpon some carnall thynge concernynge Christes kyngdome.
column8: Assuredly my brothers all we be even thus naturally affected and disposed before the sending of the holy ghost that we still dream upon some carnal thing concerning Christes kingdom.

column7: But when the holy ghoost come, he shall teache vs that the kingdom of Christ consisteth in feyth and spirite and not in an outward dominion or worldly power.
column8: But when the holy ghost come, he shall teach us that the kingdom of Christ consisteth in faith and spirit and not in and outward dominion or worldly power.

column7: The also shall our iustice shrynke and quake which we feyne we haue before the lightenyng of the holy ghost, and our iugement shall appere wherby accordinge to reason we iuge of the reigne of Christe.
column8: The also shall our justice shrink and quake which we feyne we have before the lightning of the holy ghost, and our judgement shall appear whereby according to reason we judge of the reign of Christe.

column7: Finally also our synnes shal be disclosed concernynge our incredulitie or misbelefe whyche we had towardes Chryst the only Sauiour, when we se that those be synnes whych before we iuged for rightuousnes as for exemple the affiaunce and truste in our workes and suche lyke.
column8: Finally also our sins shall be disclosed concerning our incredulity or misbelefe which we had towards Chryst the only Saviour, when we see that those be sins which before we judged for righteousness as for exemple the affiance and trust in our works and such like.

column7: And leste a man shulde feyne to himselfe some peculiar vision and illumination I wot not what, ye shal vnderstand that the holy gost commeth when the worde is preached whych worde no doubte is the worke of the holy ghost.
column8: And lest a man should feyne to himself some peculiar vision and illumination I wot not what, you shall understand that the holy ghost comes when the word is preached which word no doubt is the work of the holy ghost.

column7: This holy ghost doth lyghten vs and leadeth vs to the knowlege of gods worde. <NOTE> Now therfore (sayth Christe) I go my wey to him that sent me, to thintet I mought come agayne and begynne a newe and spirituall raigne in reuerting by death.
column8: This holy ghost does lighten us and leads us to the knowledge of gods word. Now therefore (say Christe) I go my weigh to him that sent me, to thintet I might come again and begin a new and spiritual reign in reverting by death.

column7: And notwithstanding that I saye vnto you that I muste departe and go my wayes from you, ye aske me not whether I go.
column8: And notwithstanding that I say unto you that I must depart and go my ways from you, you ask me not whither I go.

column7: As who shulde saye, yf ye were not blynded with the care of the flesshe and soughte not for worldly thynges, ye wolde vndoubtedly haue asked me whether I go, syth I tolde you I must departe.
column8: As who should say, if you were not blinded with the care of the flesh and sought not for worldly things, you would undoubtedly have asked me whither I go, sith I told you I must depart.

column7: Neuertheles bycause I haue sayd such thynges vnto you, your hartes be full of sorowe, not so much bycause of my departure, as bycause ye se that ye shall lacke those outwarde and worldly pleasures and promocions P A G Exxiij whych ye hoped to haue receyued in my kyngdome. <NOTE> Howbeit I tel you the trouth, it is expedient for you that I go my waye, as who shulde saye, your opinio concernynge my raigne is false and cleane wronge.
column8: Nevertheless because I have said such things unto you, your hearts be full of sorrow, not so much because of my departure, as because you see that you shall lack those outward and worldly pleasures and promotions PAGExxiij PAGExxiij PAGExxiij PAGExxiij which you hoped to have received in my kingdom. Howbeit I tell you the troth, it is expedient for you that I go my way, as who should say, your opinio concerning my reign is false and clean wrong.

column7: But I wole shewe you the treuth why I muste departe, partly bycause ye maye vnderstand what maner kyngdome my kingdome is, and partly what ye ought to loke for in it.
column8: But I will show you the truth why I must depart, partly because you may understand what manner kingdom my kingdom is, and partly what you ought to look for in it.

column7: I saye it is expedient and profitable for you that I departe.
column8: I say it is expedient and profitable for you that I depart.

column7: Brethren here ye see that all thinges whych Christ doth, he doth the same for our vtilite and profyte, insomoche that euen his departure out of thys worlde yt is to saye his deathe was so profytable to vs that without it we shulde neuer haue bene delyuered oute of oure damnable state of euerlastynge death.
column8: Brothers here you see that all things which Christ does, he does thee same for our vtilite and profit, insomoche that even his departure out of this world that is to say his death was so profitable to us that without it we should never have be delivered out of our damnable state of everlasting death.

column7: He addeth.
column8: He adds.

column7: For yf I go not awaye, that comforter shall not come vnto you. <NOTE> Lo good people in this place is conteyned the great vtilitie and profyte of the death and departure of Christ vnto hys father.
column8: For if I go not away, that comforter shall not come unto you. Lo good people in this place is contained the great utility and profit of the death and departure of Christ unto his father.

column7: For therfore departed he out of this world, bicause he wolde begynne a spirituall kyngdome, which neuertheles could not helpe, yf he hadde not also sente the holy ghost.
column8: For therefore departed he out of this world, because he would begin a spiritual kingdom, which nevertheless could not help, if he had not also sent the holy ghost.

column7: For where there shulde be a spirituall kyngdome, and we yet carnall, we coulde in no wise vnderstande nor perceiueit.
column8: For where there should be a spiritual kingdom, and we yet carnal, we could in no wise understand nor perceiueit.

column7: No more then euen at thys daye we vnderstad it but by the helpe and ayde of the holy gooste.
column8: No more then even at this day we vnderstad it but by the help and aid of the holy ghost.

column7: Wherefore let vs remembre that Christ hath for our cause sent the holy goost whych myght leade vs into all truth that is to wite, whych might disclose and open vnto vs oure synnes that do naturally stycke in vs and yet neuertheles we take them for no synnes, whyche holy ghost also myght bewrey our ryghtuousnes to be befor god more vnrightuousnes, & finally whych myght shewe the deuell to be iuged by the ouerture and openyng of the gospell, all whyche thinges noman shuld haue vnderstanded, had not Christ sente his holy ghost, <NOTE> whom in this place he surely promiseth shulde come and he came in dede accordinge to hys promise vpon the daye of Pentecoste as it is redde in the first chapter of the Actes of the Apostles.
column8: Wherefore let us remember that Christ hath for our cause sent the holy ghost which might lead us into all truth that is to wite, which might disclose and open unto us our sins that do naturally stick in us and yet nevertheless we take them for no sins, which holy ghost also might bewrey our righteousness to be before god more unrighteousness, & finally which might show the devil to be judged by the overture and opening of the gospel, all which things noman should have understanded, had not Christ sent his holy ghost, whom in this place he surely promises should come and he came in deed according to his promise upon the day of Pentecoste as it is red in the first chapter of the Acts of the Apostles.

column7: Now the holy ghost is called a comforter whych in the Greake is called Paracletus of hys effecte or office forasmuche as his office and feate is euen fro tyme to tyme so longe as this spirituall kyngdome shall endure, <NOTE> to comforte mens consciences in this world.
column8: Now the holy ghost is called a comforter which in the Greake is called Paracletus of his effect or office forasmuch as his office and feat is even from time to time so long as this spiritual kingdom shall endure, to comfort men's consciences in this world.

column7: When this comforter commeth, saith Christ, he shal rebuke the worlde of synne, of rightuousnes, and of iugemente. <NOTE> Here ye se good people, thre lettes or obstacles, whych by thoffice of tholy ghost muste be moued awey to thintente thys spirituall kyngdome mighte be vnderstande, that is to saye, synne whych is, not to beleue in god, & this thinge noman doth vnderstande by his propre nature, and yet onles it be vnderstande noman can haue accesse to the kingdome of Christ.
column8: When this comforter comes, says Christ, he shall rebuke the world of sin, of righteousness, and of judgement. Here you see good people, thre lets or obstacles, which by intent of tholy ghost must be moved away to thintente this spiritual kingdom might be understand, that is to say, sin which is, not to believe in god, & this thing noman does understand by his proper nature, and yet unless it be understand noman can have access to the kingdom of Christ.

column7: The seconde is the ignoraunce of the true iustice whych pleaseth god, and this also can no man take nor perform of himselfe.
column8: The seconde is the ignorance of the true justice which pleases god, and this also can no man take nor perform of himself.

column7: The third is iudgement, wheras we vnderstand not naturally that the deuell is iuged by the disclosing of the gospell.
column8: The third is judgement, whereas we understand not naturally that the devil is judged by the disclosing of the gospel.

column7: These thre lettes and impedimentes be roted naturally in euery mans mynde whych no man can vnderstande of himselfe or take them awaye by hys owne power.
column8: These thre lets and impediments be roted naturally in every men mind which no man can understand of himself or take them away by his own power.

column7: Wherfore to the doinge hereof is the holy gost promysed in this gospell.
column8: Wherefore to the doing hereof is the holy ghost promised in this gospel.

column7: Now for asmoch P A G Exxiiij as the kingdome of Christe is heare conuersaunt amonge men which be synners and whyche of nature can do nought but synne but loue their own rightuousenes and iudge after their owne faschion of the gospell: therfore the holy ghost in executinge his office doth not moue the to departe out of this worlde that thou mayste haue no occasion to synne, neyther woll he that ciuile iustice or humane iudgemente shulde not be executed in thys worlde, but he teacheth the, truly to knowe, what thynge synne is.
column8: Now for as PAGExxiiij PAGExxiiij PAGExxiiij PAGExxiiij as the kingdom of Christe is hear conversant among men which be sinners and which of nature can do nought but sin but love their own rightuousenes and judge after their own faschion of the gospel: therefore the holy ghost in executing his office does not move thee to depart out of this world that thou mayste have no occasion to sin, neither will he that civil justice or humane judgement should not be executed in this world, but he teaches thee, truly to know, what thing sin is.

column7: For euery man of hys owne brayne, & by hys owne power & wytte feyneth thys or that to be synne, as it hath been sufficiently proued vnder ye kyngdome of the Byshoppe of Rome.
column8: For every man of his own brain, & by his own power & wit feyneth this or that to be sin, as it hath been sufficiently proved under you kingdom of the Bishop of Rome.

column7: But when the holy gooste cometh and repryueth vs by gods worde, our owne imaginacions & fantasyes destroyed, then we know that to be synne whyche no man iudged before to be synne.
column8: But when the holy ghost comes and repryueth us by gods word, our own imaginations & fantasies destroyed, then we know that to be sin which no man judged before to be sin.

column7: So we knowe nowe that it is synne, yf a ma beleue not in only Christe concernynge iustice, whyche thynge before the receyuynge of the holy gooste none of vs all knewe.
column8: So we know now that it is sin, if a ma believe not in only Christe concerning justice, which thing before the receiving of the holy ghost none of us all knew.

column7: In semblable wyse it is to be spoken of ryghtousnes and iudgement, whych two thynges, we vtterly cosydered not before ye openyng of the gospell, wherby the holy gooste reproueth the worlde.
column8: In semblable wise it is to be spoken of righteousness and judgement, which two things, we utterly cosydered not before you opening of the gospel, whereby the holy ghost reproveth the world.

column7: But leste ye shuld suspecte thys interpretacion to be not grounded of scripture, harken howe Christe hymselfe expouneth thys thynge: <NOTE> The holy gooste (he sayeth) shall rebuke the worlde of synne.
column8: But lest you should suspect this interpretation to be not grounded of scripture, harken how Christe himself exponeth this thing: The holy ghost (he sayeth) shall rebuke the world of sin.

column7: Why? because they beleue not (sayth Christ) on me.
column8: Why? because they believe not (say Christ) on me.

column7: Loo howe Christ expouneth hymselfe what he meaneth by synne, that is to witte incredulitie or mysbeleue towardes hym, whyche only thynge doth condemne men, lyke as on the contrary parte the onlye belefe in Christe saueth. <NOTE> papistes haue wrested thys texte (as they do al other) to the mysbeleue of ye Turkes & Sarasynes, and such people as be farre from vs, but they oughte to remembre that in thys behalfe they do synne worse then the Turkes, forasmoch as they wold be counted Christianes, and yet in ye meane season they labour to be made rightouse and iuste before god by theyr owne workes without fayth in Chryste.
column8: Loo how Christ exponeth himself what he means by sin, that is to wit incredulity or mysbeleue towards him, which only thing does condemn men, like as on the contrary part the only belief in Christe saveth. papists have wrested this text (as they do all other) to the mysbeleue of the Turkes & Sarasynes, and such people as be far from us, but they ought to remember that in this behalf they do sin worse then the Turkes, forasmuch as they would be counted Christianes, and yet in you mean season they labour to be made righteous and just before god by their own works without faith in Chryste.

column7: Of thys abhominable synne, the worlde knoweth nothynge at all.
column8: Of this abominable sin, the world knoweth nothing at all.

column7: Of ryghtuosnesse shall the holy goost rebuke ye worlde.
column8: Of ryghtuosnesse shall the holy ghost rebuke you world.

column7: Why? because sayeth Christe, I go to my father, and ye shall se me no more: That is to saye, bicause I shall begynne my newe reigne, wherin an other maner of iustice then ye ymagine, must be required and shalbe of valour before god.
column8: Why? because sayeth Christe, I go to my father, and you shall see me no more: That is to say, because I shall begin my new reign, wherein and other manner of justice then you imagine, must be required and shall of valour before god.
