column7: Of iudgement the holy ghost shall rebuke the worlde, why? bycause (sayeth Christe) the Prince of this worlde is iudged alredy. <NOTE> And he calleth iugemet the blyndnes of ma wherby the worlde alloweth naturallye the reygne and the workes of Satan, for the worlde hath a corrupt iudgement by Adams fall, so that it seeth not what thinges god aloweth and what not. <NOTE> But (sayth Christ) I haue yet many thynges to speake vnto you meanyng of his crosse and of hys glory but by reason of your weakenes and infirmytie ye are not able to beare them nowe.
column8: Of judgement the holy ghost shall rebuke the world, why? because (sayeth Christe) the Prince of this world is judged already. And he calls iugemet the blindness of ma whereby the world alloweth naturally the reign and the works of Satan, for the world hath a corrupt judgement by Adams fallen, so that it sees not what things god alloweth and what not. But (say Christ) I have yet many things to speak unto you meaning of his cross and of his glory but by reason of your weakness and infirmytie you are not able to bear them now.

column7: As who shuld saye ye be yet carnall and therfore ye perceiue not the thinges that be of the spirite But whe the spirite of trouth that is the holy ghost shall come he shall leade you into all trouth.
column8: As who should say you be yet carnal and therefore you perceive not the things that be of the spirit But when the spirit of troth that is the holy ghost shall come he shall lead you into all troth.

column7: The spirite shall teache you thinges spirituall.
column8: The spirit shall teach you things spiritual.

column7: He shall P A G Exxv transforme you and of carnall persones shall make you goostly.
column8: He shall PAGExxv PAGExxv PAGExxv PAGExxv transform you and of carnal persons shall make you ghostly.

column7: For surely because ye be yet carnall, ye canot perfytly perceyue the scriptures concernynge my death and gloriouse resurrection, whych is to be fulfilled for your redeptions sake.
column8: For surely because you be yet carnal, you canot perfectly perceive the scriptures concerning my death and glorious resurrection, which is to be fulfilled for your redeptions sake.

column7: Here ye se playnly good people, yt thys place maketh nothynge at al for the confirmation of the papisticall traditios but rather agaynst them.
column8: Here you see plainly good people, that this place makes nothing at all for the confirmation of the papistical traditios but rather against them.

column7: For I praye you what is thys trouth that the holy ghost shall teache you?
column8: For I pray you what is this troth that the holy ghost shall teach you?

column7: Mannes traditions? no not so.
column8: Man's traditions? no not so.

column7: In them is no certayntie.
column8: In them is no certainty.

column7: It is Christ and hys worde that is the only trouth.
column8: It is Christ and his word that is the only troth.

column7: Wherfore he shal teache only Christ and the worde of god, for this is all trouthe. <NOTE> For (as Chrysostome sayth) the gospel conteyneth al together.
column8: Wherefore he shall teach only Christ and the word of god, for this is all truth. For (as Chrysostome say) the gospel containeth all together.

column7: And the office (sayeth he) of a good preacher is truely to prosecute all that is in hys commission & not to chaunge, <NOTE> to, or take away any thyng.
column8: And the office (sayeth he) of a good preacher is truly to prosecute all that is in his commission & not to change, to, or take away any thing.

column7: But this ye Bishoppes of Rome in tymes paste haue done, and yet at this day do presume to do.
column8: But this you Bishops of Room in times past have done, and yet at this day do presume to do.

column7: Wherfore they are no interpretours but deprauers of scripture, no vicars of Christe, but of the deuell.
column8: Wherefore they are no interpreters but depravers of scripture, no vicars of Christe, but of the devil.

column7: They speake of their owne heddes their own inuentions and dreames, wheras the holy ghost whyche here is promysed by Christe vnto vs shall speake nothyng of hymselfe, but what so euer he shall heare, that shall he speake, that is to saye, he shall speake none other worde or gospel, only he shal open and declare the worde that is alredy spoken by Christ.
column8: They speak of their own heads their own inventions and dreams, whereas the holy ghost which here is promised by Christe unto us shall speak nothing of himself, but what so ever he shall hear, that shall he speak, that is to say, he shall speak none other word or gospel, only he shall open and declare the word that is already spoken by Christ.

column7: This do not the papistes, for they expoude not Christes worde, but they bring another word besides Christes word.
column8: This do not the papists, for they expoude not Christes word, but they bring another word beside Christes word.

column7: Thys spirite of trouth shall also shewe of thynges to come, that is to wit, of the spreading abrode of Christes gospel throughout the hole world euen vnto the Gentilles or hethe persons aswell as to the Iewes, whom yet the Iues despysed and toke for refuse and abiecte persos and counted them selues onely for Gods electe and chosen.
column8: This spirit of troth shall also show of things to come, that is to wit, of the spreading abroad of Christes gospel throughout the hold world even unto the Gentiles or heathen persons aswell as to the Jewes, whom yet the Iues despised and took for refuse and abject persons and counted them selves only for Gods elect and chosen.

column7: This holy ghoste shall glorifie Christe, that is, he shall expoune him, he shall make him clearer and shall auaunce and set him forthe.
column8: This holy ghost shall glorify Christe, that is, he shall expoune him, he shall make him clearer and shall advance and set him forth.

column7: But the byshop of Rome doth cleane contrary for he obscureth & darkeneth Christe and his doctryne.
column8: But the bishop of Room does clean contrary for he obscureth & darkeneth Christe and his doctrine.

column7: This holy ghost (sayeth Christ) shall receyue of myne and shall shewe vnto you.
column8: This holy ghost (sayeth Christ) shall receive of mine and shall show unto you.

column7: And al that the father of heue hath are myn.
column8: And all that the father of heaven hath are mine.

column7: This is to saye good people that the holy spirite of god wherwyth euery christen man must be renewed (according to Christes communication wyth Nicodemus) shall breath or inspire nothing into the mindes of christian folke but that whych Christes gospell and worde wylleth. <NOTE> He teacheth no newe thing Wherfore my frendes, if we woll be true christians not only in name but also in dede, let vs put of oure carnall and olde man, and let vs be ledde wyth the spirite of god which is here called ye spirite of trouth Whych spirite by the instrument of godes word as here is declared shall open and disclose vnto vs all trouth necessarye to oure saluation and soule helth.
column8: This is to say good people that the holy spirit of god wherewith every christian man must be renewed (according to Christes communication with Nicodemus) shall breath or inspire nothing into the minds of christian folk but that which Christes gospel and word willeth. He teaches no new thing Wherefore my friends, if we will be true christians not only in name but also in deed, let us put of our carnal and old man, and let us be led with the spirit of god which is here called you spirit of troth Which spirit by the instrument of gods word as here is declared shall open and disclose unto us all troth necessary to our salvation and soul health.

column7: Which thyng also the aucient doctour Ihon Chrysostome witnesseth, <NOTE> sayeng.
column8: Which thing also the ancient doctor Ihon Chrysostome witnesseth, saying.

column7: What so euer is sought to the soule helth the same is al togither conteyned and accomplished in holy scripture.
column8: What so ever is sought to the soul health the same is all together contained and accomplished in holy scripture.

column7: He that is ignoraunt shal fynde there ynoughe to lerne.
column8: He that is ignorant shall find there enough to learn.

column7: He that is stubborne and a synner shall fynde there the skourgies of the iudgemente to come that he maye feare.
column8: He that is stubborn and a sinner shall find there the skourgies of the judgement to come that he may fear.

column7: He that laboureth shall fynde there the gloryes and P A G Exxvi promises of lief euerlasting, by chawyng wherof, he may be more & more kyndled to do good workes as becommeth a christian man to do.
column8: He that laboureth shall find there the glories and PAGExxvi PAGExxvi PAGExxvi PAGExxvi promises of lief everlasting, by chawing whereof, he may be more & more kindled to do good works as becomes a christian man to do.

column7: Let vs praye then to god with pure hartes that he woll vouche saue to send vs this holy ghost this coforter vnto our myndes which may open vnto vs al trouth.
column8: Let us pray then to god with pure hearts that he will vouch save to send us this holy ghost this coforter unto our minds which may open unto us all troth.

column7: To whome be glory and prayse immortally &.c.: homily The Epistle on the.v. sondaye after Ester.
column8: To whom be glory and praise immortally & c: homily The Epistle on the v sondaye after Ester.

column7: The fyrste chapter of saynt Iames. Thargument Saynt Iames exhorteth christen men to declare their feyth wyth good workes.
column8: The fyrste chapter of saint James. Thargument Saint Iames exhorteth christen men to declare their faith with good works.

column7: And he sheweth what thyng true Religion or deuotion is.
column8: And he shows what thing true Religion or devotion is.

column7: M Ost deare beloued brethren, euery good gifte and euery perfyte gyfte is from aboue and cometh downe from the father of lyghtes, wyth who is no variablenes, neither is he chaunged vnto darckenes.
column8: MOst MOst deer beloved brothers, every good gift and every perfect gift is from above and comes down from the father of lights, with who is no variableness, neither is he changed unto darkness.

column7: Of hys owne wyll begat he vs wyth the worde of trouth, that we shuld be the fyrste frutes of hys creatures.
column8: Of his own will begat he us with the word of troth, that we should be the fyrste fruits of his creatures.

column7: Wherfore (deare brethre) let euery man be swyft to heare, slowe to speake, slowe to wrath.
column8: Wherefore (deer brethren) let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath.

column7: For the wrath of ma worketh not that whyche is ryghtouse before god.
column8: For the wrath of ma works not that which is righteous before god.

column7: Wherfore laye aparte all fylthynes and superfluitie of maliciousnes, and receaue wythe mekenes the worde that is grasted in you, whych is hable to saue your soules.
column8: Wherefore say apart all filthiness and superfluity of maliciousness, and receive wythe meekness the word that is grasted in you, which is able to save your souls.

column7: T He holy Apostle of God saynte Iames good christen people in the epistle of this day doth discerne the true hearers of gods worde from the false hearers.
column8: THe THe holy Apostle of God faint Iames good christian people in the epistle of this day does discern the true hearers of gods word from the false hearers.

column7: And ye shal vnderstande that the true hearers of gods worde be they whiche take it with fayth, <NOTE> whiche vnderstande it in theyr harte & whiche do garnishe it outwardely with suche workes as be prescribed and appoynted them to do, and (as the parable of Christe declareth) whiche do heare the word of god and vnderstande it, whiche also bryng forthe frute some an hundred folde, some sixty folde, some thyrty folde. <NOTE> And it is he (according to the wordes of the prophete Dauid) whiche is lyke a tre planted by the ryuer syde, bearyng his frute in due tyme.
column8: And you shall understand that the true hearers of gods word be they which take it with faith, which understand it in their heart & which do garnish it outwardly with such works as be prescribed and appointed them to do, and (as the parable of Christe declareth) which do hear the word of god and understand it, which also bring forth fruit some and hundred fold, some sixty fold, some thyrty fold. And it is he (according to the words of the prophet Dauid) which is like a tre planted by the river side, bearing his fruit in due time.

column7: But the false hearers of the worde be they, <NOTE> whiche heare it, but they receiue it nat with fayth, they vnderstande it nat in theyr harte, neyther do they furnyshe and declare it to the worlde with good workes and as the parable of ye sower sayeth, they suffre the deuyll to take the worde out of theyr harte.
column8: But the false hearers of the word be they, which hear it, but they receive it nat with faith, they understand it nat in their heart, neither do they furnish and declare it to the world with good works and as the parable of the sour sayeth, they suffer the devil to take the word out of their heart.

column7: These be only temporall hearers and but for a season, they be but starters, they stycke nat by it.
column8: These be only temporal hearers and but for a season, they be but starters, they stick nat by it.

column7: They be also suche as when they haue perceyued & taken the true word of god, they choke it with the care of this world and with the disceitfulnes of ryches & so make the worde vnfruteful, for they receiue it nat with ful mynd but by snatches and myndyng other thynges, euen as he whiche beholdeth his bodely face in a glasse, and forthwith goeth hys waye and forgetteth by and by what maner thyng it was. <NOTE> Be ye then doers of the worde, that is to wete, declare wt good workes that ye truly vnderstande it, and be nat hearers onely, as who shulde say.
column8: They be also such as when they have perceived & taken the true word of god, they choke it with the care of this world and with the disceitfulnes of riches & so make the word unfruitful, for they receive it nat with full mind but by snatches and minding other things, even as he which beholdeth his bodily face in a glass, and forthwith goes his way and forgetteth by and by what manner thing it was. Be you then doers of the word, that is to weet, declare with good works that you truly understand it, and be nat hearers only, as who should say.

column7: Ye that heare the worde of god with your eares and do boste and glory in the knowledge therof, and neuertheles be occupyed and intangled in other maters ye do nothyng els but deceiue your P A G Exxvij selues whych thyng he declareth with a wonderful goodly and apte similitude. <NOTE> lyke as it nothinge helpeth a man to stade before a glasse and to se hym selfe faire, whan he goeth away forthwyth, and forgetteth strayte hys beawtie, So it helpeth a man nothynge at all to heare gods worde, onles he receyue it in hys harte, and take holde of it by fayth, depely printyng in hys mynde the beautie therof, and be delyted therin, and fynally declare wyth good workes that he doth truly vnderstande it.
column8: You that hear the word of god with your ears and do boast and glory in the knowledge thereof, and nevertheless be ocupied and entangled in other maters you do nothing else but deceive your PAGExxvij PAGExxvij PAGExxvij PAGExxvij selves which thing he declareth with a wondered goodly and apt similitude. like as it nothing helpeth a man to stade before a glass and to see him self fair, when he goes away forthwith, and forgetteth strait his beauty, So it helpeth a man nothing at all to hear gods word, unless he receive it in his heart, and take hold of it by faith, deeply printing in his mind the beauty thereof, and be delighted therein, and finally declare with good works that he does truly understand it.

column7: Furthermore he that standeth before a glasse maye well glorie and bragge of hys beautye for a tyme: So he that heareth the worde may well reioyse and glorie of it.
column8: Furthermore he that stands before a glass may well glory and brag of his beauty for a time: So he that hears the word may well rejoice and glory of it.

column7: But whan the glasse is taken away anone the beautie is out of the mynde.
column8: But when the glass is taken away anon the beauty is out of the mind.

column7: So in tyme of necessitie and tribulation, yf the true glasse of gods wyll that is to wyt the worde of God be taken awaye and not cosydered, anone the promyses and gospell that is to saye the glad tydynges concernynge our redemption is out of mynde, the beautie of gods goodnes is forgotten, and finally the wyll and pleasure of the Lorde is neglected.
column8: So in time of necessity and tribulation, if the true glass of gods will that is to wit the word of God be taken away and not cosydered, anon the promises and gospel that is to say the glad tidings concerning our redemption is out of mind, the beauty of gods goodness is forgotten, and finally the will and pleasure of the Lord is neglected.

column7: But on the contrary parte who so loketh in the perfyte lawe of lybertie and continueth therin, yf he be not a forgetful hearer but a doer of the worke, the same shalbe happy in hys dede.
column8: But on the contrary part who so looketh in the perfect law of liberty and continueth therein, if he be not a forgetful hearer but a doer of the work, the same shall happy in his deed.

column7: As who shulde saye: He that rightly heareth and vnder standeth the worde and doeth expresse the same with worthy workes in such wyse as he sheweth hymselfe to haue a firme & sure vnderstandynge of the same whereby he may vaynquish and chase away death, Satan, and synne: he shalbe happye in hys dede or worke, he shalbe declared by hys dedes to be a iustified person and saued.
column8: As who should say: He that rightly hears and under stands the word and doth express the same with worthy works in such wise as he shows himself to have a firm & sure understanding of the same whereby he may vaynquish and chase away death, Satan, and sin: he shall happy in his deed or work, he shall declared by his deeds to be a justified person and saved.

column7: For dedes & workes in christe men be testimonies and wytnesses of our iustifyeng fayth and that we do vnderstande ryghtly and truly gods worde. <NOTE> For (as saynt Augustine affirmeth) fayth ought to go before workes.
column8: For deeds & works in christe men be testimonies and witnesses of our iustifyeng faith and that we do understand rightly and truly gods word. For (as saint Augustine affirmeth) faith ought to go before works.

column7: Yea he declareth playnly ye workes wythout fayth can not be good, and he allegeth for hys purpose that texte of saynte Paule: <NOTE> Omne quod non est ex fide peccatum est. That is to saye, what so euer is not of faythe, the fame is synne. <NOTE> Herevnto also agreeth Chrysostome where he sayeth: Fayth ought to shyne before workes, and workes muste be the handmaydes or waytynge seruauntes and folowers of fayth.
column8: Yea he declareth plainly the works without faith can not be good, and he allegeth for his purpose that text of faint Paule: Omne quod non est ex fide peccatum est. That is to say, what so ever is not of faith, the fame is sin. Hereunto also agreeth Chrysostome where he sayeth: Faith ought to shine before works, and works must be the handmaids or waiting servants and followers of faith.

column7: <NOTE> Secode, in thys epistle saynt Iames doth teach vs (good people) what the ryght and perfyte religion of a christian man or woman is.
column8: Secode, in this epistle saint Iames does teach us (good people) what the right and perfect religion of a christian man or woman is.

column7: Yf any man (sayeth saynt Iames) woll seme to be religiouse amonges you, not refraynynge hys tonge, but seducynge and deceyuynge hys owne harte, thys mans religion is vayne. <NOTE> and vndefyled religion before God the father is thys: to vysite the fatherlesse and wedowes in theyr aduersitie, & to kepe thy selfe vnspotted in the worlde.
column8: If any man (sayeth saint Iames) will seem to be religious among you, not refraining his tongue, but seducing and deceiving his own heart, this men religion is vain. and undefiled religion before God the father is this: to visit the fatherless and wedowes in their adversity, & to keep thy self unspotted in the world.

column7: Lo good people here ye haue a true definicion of religion.
column8: Lo good people here you have a true definition of religion.

column7: It is not to be locked vp in stone walles and to departe from the company of the worlde, as those disguysed and false religiouse persones lately in thys realme dyd, but it is to be conuersaunt amonges men wythout spotte or reproufe, it is to vysite orphanes and fatherlesse chyldren, to go and succour the poore wydowes, to go aboute and to wynne ye people to Christ, to fysh mens soules and to brynge them into the kyngdome of P A G Exxviij Christ out of the tyranny and raygne of Antichriste.
column8: It is not to be locked up in stone walls and to depart from the company of the world, as those disguised and false religious persons lately in this realm did, but it is to be conversant among men without spot or reproufe, it is to visit orphans and fatherless children, to go and succour the poor widows, to go about and to win you people to Christ, to fish men's souls and to bring them into the kingdom of PAGExxviij PAGExxviij PAGExxviij PAGExxviij Christ out of the tyranny and reign of Antichriste.

column7: I call Antichrist whosoeuer teacheth other deuotions and holynesses then Christ dyd ordeyne.
column8: I call Antichrist whosoever teaches other devotions and holinesses then Christ did ordain.

column7: For he that is not wyth Christ is agaynst Christ.
column8: For he that is not with Christ is against Christ.

column7: Wherfore good brethren and systers, let vs be accordynge to saynt Iames monition here, not onely hearers but also doers of the worde, but of what worde? of the bishop of Romes worde, of Antichristes word which is contrary to Christes vnspotted & syncere worde? no but of gods worde, to thintent we maye loke into the perfyte lawe whych breaketh out of fre spirite & fayth into workes of charitie.
column8: Wherefore good brothers and sisters, let us be according to saint Iames monition here, not only hearers but also doers of the word, but of what word? of the bishop of Romes word, of Antichristes word which is contrary to Christes unspotted & sincere word? no but of gods word, to intent we may look into the perfect law which breaks out of from spirit & faith into works of charity.

column7: Let vs imbrace ye true religio that is here prescribed and set forth vnto vs Let vs vysite the orphanes, the desolate wydowes & our poore neyghbours that be destitute of comforte and relyfe.
column8: Let us embrace you true religio that is here prescribed and set forth unto us Let us visit the orphans, the desolate widows & our poor neighbours that be destitute of comfort and relyfe.

column7: Thys let vs do of a fre and franke harte not as constraynedly but wyllyngly and gladly.
column8: This let us doe of a from and frank heart not as constrainedly but willingly and gladly.

column7: Thys doynge we shall declare by our dedes that we haue the lyuely fayth that shall iustifie vs in gods sight.
column8: This doing we shall declare by our deeds that we have the lively faith that shall justify us in gods sighed.

column7: In these our dedes, but not by these our dedes nor through these our dedes, we shall as saynt Iames assureth vs be happy, and so happy that noma shalbe able to take our ioye and blysse from vs. For we shall not onely lyue here in thys worlde in peace of conscience and in the kyngdome of Christ, but we shall also in an other worlde inherite the vnspeakable ioye and felicitie of heauen, where lyueth & raygneth the father the sone and holy goost perpetually Amen.
column8: In these our deeds, but not by these our deeds nor through these our deeds, we shall as saint Iames assureth us be happy, and so happy that noma shall able to take our joy and bliss from us For we shall not only live here in this world in peace of conscience and in the kingdom of Christ, but we shall also in and other world inherit the unspeakable joy and felicity of heaven, where liveth & reigneth the father the soon and holy ghost perpetually Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospel on the.v. Sondaye after Ester daye which is the next sonday before the crosse dayes, the.xvi. Chapter of Ihon. Thargument Prayers are hard through Christ.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the v Sondaye after Ester day which is the next sonday before the cross days, the xvi Chapter of Jhon. Thargument Prayers are hard through Christ.

column7: I Esus sayd to his disciples, after a whyle ye shall not se me, and againe after a while ye shal se me, for I go to the father.
column8: IEsus IEsus said to his disciples, after a while you shall not see me, and again after a while you shall see me, for I go to the father.

column7: Tha sayd some of his disciples betwene them selues: what is this that he saith vnto vs, after a while ye shal not se me, and againe after a whyle ye shal se me: and that I go to the father?
column8: Than said some of his disciples between them selves: what is this that he says unto us, after a while you shall not see me, and again after a while you shall see me: and that I go to the father?

column7: They said therfore: what is this that he saith, after a whyle? we can not tell what he sayth.
column8: They said therefore: what is this that he says, after a while? we can not tell what he say.

column7: Iesus perceyued that they wolde aske him, and said vnto them.
column8: Jesus perceived that they would ask him, and said unto them.

column7: Ye inquyre of this betwene youre selues, because I sayd after a while ye shall not se me, and agayne after a whyle ye shall se me.
column8: the inquire of this between your selves, because I said after a while you shall not see me, and again after a while you shall see me.

column7: Verely, verely I saye vnto you: ye shall wepe and lament, but contrary wise, the world shall reioyse.
column8: Verily, verily I say unto you: you shall weep and lament, but contrary wise, the world shall rejoice.

column7: Ye shal sorowe, but your sorowe shalbe turned to ioye.
column8: You shall sorrow, but your sorrow shall turned to joy.

column7: A woman whe she traueyleth hath sorowe, because her hour is come.
column8: A woman when she traueyleth hath sorrow, because her hour is come.

column7: But as sone as she is deliuered of the child she remebreth no more the anguyshe for ioye that a man is borne into the worlde.
column8: But as soon as she is delivered of the child she remebreth no more the anguish for joy that a man is born into the world.

column7: And ye nowe therfore haue sorowe: but I wyll se you agayne, and youre hartes shall reioyse, and youre ioye shall no man take from you.
column8: And you now therefore have sorrow: but I will see you again, and your hearts shall rejoice, and your joy shall no man take from you.

column7: IN the first parte of the Gospel of this daie (good people) is a commaudemet and promise set forth vnto vs wherby we be allured and sturred to praye. <NOTE> And surely sith a christian person can no wher haue better coumforte in such thynges as he is troubled P A G Exxix in, and in tyme of necessitie and aduersitie, then instantly to pray and to open his affliction and grefe with ardent peticion and humble sute to God, who onely wyll and can helpe him in his distres & gyue him comforte, vndoutedly it is ryght necessary that we throughly perceiue & knowe the institucion and intent of this present gospel, to the intent we might be the more inclined and disposed vnto prayer.
column8: IN the first part of the Gospel of this day (good people) is a commaudemet and promise set forth unto us whereby we be allured and stirred to pray. And surely sith a christian person can no where have better comfort in such things as he is troubled PAGExxix PAGExxix PAGExxix PAGExxix in, and in time of necessity and adversity, then instantly to pray and to open his affliction and grief with ardent petition and humble suit to God, who only will and can help him in his distres & gyve him comfort, undoubtedly it is right necessary that we thoroughly perceive & know the institution and intent of this present gospel, to the intent we might be the more inclined and disposed unto prayer.

column7: For who wolde reiecte and despice prayer as a thyng lytle necessary, seyng it is so muche auaunced and comaunded by Christe vnto vs?
column8: For who would reject and despice prayer as a thing little necessary, sing it is so much advanced and commanded by Christe unto us?

column7: Yea this comaundement dothe as straytly bynde vs, as the fyrste commaundemet of the Decalogie doth.
column8: Yea this commandment doth as straitly bind us, as the fyrste commaundemet of the Decalogie does.

column7: This to be true we may se in another place where Christe byddeth vs alwayes to pray and that without ceasing or intermission. <NOTE> Marke that it is necessary then and conuenient that we shulde pray.
column8: This to be true we may see in another place where Christe biddeth us always to pray and that without ceasing or intermission. Mark that it is necessary then and convenient that we should pray.

column7: Wherfore as we be by speciall word and comaundement of Christe drawe and inforced to pray: So also this gospell allureth vs to the same with a speciall promise.
column8: Wherefore as we be by special word and commandment of Christe draw and enforced to pray: So also this gospel allureth us to the same with a special promise.

column7: For it is here promised vs by Christe that our prayers that is to wete the prayers of christen persons shal not be vaine ne frustrate, but that we shalbe surely herde & shall obteyne our sutes.
column8: For it is here promised us by Christe that our prayers that is to weet the prayers of christian persons shall not be vain ne frustrate, but that we shall surely herd & shall obtain our suits.

column7: For why elles wolde Christ haue bounde this his worde and promise with an othe, sayeng, verely verely, What so euer ye aske the father in my name he shall gyue it you.
column8: For why else would Christ have bound this his word and promise with and other, saying, verily verily, What so ever you ask the father in my name he shall gyve it you.

column7: Also aske and it shalbe gyuen you.
column8: Also ask and it shall given you.

column7: Do ye not heare how our prayers shal not be vayne nor frustrate?
column8: Do you not hear how our prayers shall not be vain nor frustrate?

column7: Who then wold nowe be slouthfull to pray seyng Christe by his speciall comaundement hath wylled vs to the same?
column8: Who then would now be slothful to pray sing Christe by his special commandment hath willed us to the same?

column7: Forthermore, ye shal here vnderstande that bycause we shuld not thynke that the labour of our prayers shuld be in vayne: therfore doth Christe here in this place allure vs with a notable and special promyse as is before remembred.
column8: Forthermore, you shall here understand that because we should not think that the labour of our prayers should be in vain: therefore does Christe here in this place allure us with a notable and special promise as is before remembered.

column7: But herin are two thinges to be considered & pondered of vs. The one is yt we shuld pray in none other name the in only Christes name. <NOTE> Now we pray in the name of Christ when we approche to god in the faythe of Christ and do comforte our selues with the trust and affiaunce in him, that is to wete, that he only is our mediatour or aduocate, by whom all be forgyuen vs, and without whom we can deserue nothyng but gods indignacion and wrath.
column8: But herin are two things to be considered & pondered of us The one is that we should pray in none other name the in only Christes name. Now we pray in the name of Christ when we approach to god in the faith of Christ and do comfort our selves with the trust and affiance in him, that is to weet, that he only is our mediator or advocate, by whom all be forgiven us, and without whom we can deserve nothing but gods indignation and wrath.

column7: For I pray you what saynte, what holy man is there either in heauen or earthe whiche sueth maketh intercession and is mediatour to the father of heauen for vs in suche wyse as Christe is?
column8: For I pray you what faint, what holy man is there either in heaven or earth which sues makes intercession and is mediator to the father of heaven for us in such wise as Christe is?

column7: Assuredly it is Christe only by whose merite and intercession not only we obteine pardon of our synnes & ryghteousnes but also he taketh vs in the place of his brethren comunicating vnto vs the roume or office of presthoode as testifyeth also S. Peter in his fyrst epistle so that we also by authoritie and vertue herof may lykewyse haue accesse to the father & seke of him in our afflictions grace helpe and comforte. <NOTE> Thys thyng confirmeth also Christ himselfe where he sayeth I saye not vnto you that I shalbe an intercessour or suter for you to my father.
column8: Assuredly it is Christe only by whose merit and intercession not only we obtain pardon of our sins & righteousness but also he takes us in the place of his brothers comunicating unto us the room or office of presthoode as testifieth also S. Peter in his fyrst epistle so that we also by authority and virtue hereof may likewise have access to the father & seek of him in our afflictions grace help and comfort. This thing confirmeth also Christ himself where he sayeth I say not unto you that I shall and intercessor or suitor for you to my father.

column7: For the father himself loueth you because ye haue loued me in beleuyng that I am come fro the father.
column8: For the father himself loves you because you have loved me in believing that I am come from the father.

column7: Wherfore good christen brethren syth we haue suche an aduocate and mediatour for vs yea sithe we also our selues be admitted by Christe to the function & offyce P A G Exxx of prestes: I pray you why shulde we so muche depede vpo confidece of others to be meanes & suters for vs?
column8: Wherefore good christian brothers sith we have such and advocate and mediator for us yea sith we also our selves be admitted by Christe to the function & office PAGExxx PAGExxx PAGExxx PAGExxx of priests: I pray you why should we so much depede upon confidence of others to be means & suitors for us?

column7: This thyng also doth the auncient and holy father S. Chrysostom ful wel declare in his homely De profectu euangelij Where he writeth in this wyse. <NOTE> Thou shall nede no patrones or aduocates wt god, neyther shalt thou nede to runne hyther and thyther to flatter other that they maye intreate for the, but albeit thou be alone and hast no patrone or intercessour, but prayest to god by thy selfe alone, yet shalt thou throughly obteyne thy sute & demaunde.
column8: This thing also does the ancient and holy father S. Chrysostom full well declare in his homely De profectu euangelij Where he writeth in this wise. Thou shall need no patroness or advocates with god, neither shalt thou need to run hither and thither to flatter other that they may entreat for thee, but albeit thou be alone and hast no patron or intercessor, but prayest to god by thy self alone, yet shalt thou thoroughly obtain thy suit & demand.

column7: For god doth not so easely graunte when other men praye for vs as when we praye our selues although we be full of many vices and synnes.
column8: For god does not so easily grant when other men pray for us as when we pray our selves although we be full of many vices and sins.

column7: Lo what thys holy doctour saythe.
column8: Lo what this holy doctor say.

column7: He certifieth the that thou arte soner herd when thou praiest for thy selfe then when thou makest other to praye for the. <NOTE> Whyche thynge Theophilactus affirmeth also, where he saith.
column8: He certifieth thee that thou art sooner heard when thou prayest for thy self then when thou makest other to pray for thee. Which thing Theophilactus affirmeth also, where he says.

column7: Marke that albeit sayntes or holy men praye for vs, as the Apostles dyd for the woman of Cananee, yet we be rather herd when we praye for our selues.
column8: Mark that albeit saints or holy men pray for us, as the Apostles did for the woman of Cananee, yet we be rather heard when we pray for our selves.

column7: Furthermore we muste take hede good people that we be suters vnto god in our prayers for nothinge that is repugnaunt to the glory of god to our owne saluation and to gods will.
column8: Furthermore we must take heed good people that we be suitors unto god in our prayers for nothing that is repugnant to the glory of god to our own salvation and to gods will.

column7: For in thys behalfe that god almyghty wyll neither admytte nor heare oure prayers it is manifestlye shewed by that he teacheth vs in our pater noster to saye.
column8: For in this behalf that god almighty will neither admit nor hear our prayers it is manifestly showed by that he teaches us in our pater noster to say.

column7: Fiat voluntas tua, <NOTE> thy wil be done.
column8: Fiat voluntas tua, thy will be done.

column7: Wherfore we shall then be hard when in our necessities we desire and require gods helpe hauing respect euer and casting our eyes to his wyl to hys comaundement and promise and not alledging our owne worthynes (whyche is nothyng at all) but only the merite of Christe, then I saye oure petition and sute shal surely be admitted & hard.
column8: Wherefore we shall then be hard when in our necessities we desire and require gods help having respect ever and casting our eyes to his will to his commandment and promise and not alleging our own worthiness (which is nothing at all) but only the merit of Christe, then I say our petition and suit shall surely be admitted & hard.

column7: Forasmoch as all the promises in Christ be est and amen that is to saye moost certeine and sure, <NOTE> as Paule in his second epistle to the Corinthians wryteth.
column8: Forasmuch as all the promises in Christ be est and amen that is to say most certain and sure, as Paule in his second epistle to the Corinthians writes.

column7: Moreouer bicause oftentymes we be so vntoward and folyshe, that we cannot espye oure owne necessitie and nede: Therfore Christ wil likewise teache vs what maner thyng our petition ought to be, <NOTE> (praye sayth he) that your ioye may be ful.
column8: Moreover because oftentimes we be so untoward and foolish, that we cannot espy our own necessity and need: Therefore Christ will likewise teach us what manner thing our petition ought to be, (pray say he) that your joy may be full.

column7: What ioye I pray you is this? vndoutedly it is no worldely or corporall leapynge or daunsing and reioising, but it is a spirituall ioye wherof saint Paule maketh mention wher he saith. <NOTE> Reioise in the lord.
column8: What joy I pray you is this? undoubtedly it is no worldly or corporal leaping or dancing and rejoicing, but it is a spiritual joy whereof saint Paule makes mention where he says. Rejoice in the lord.

column7: And againe I saye reioise.
column8: And again I say rejoice.

column7: From whence then procedeth this ioye?
column8: From whence then proceedeth this joy?

column7: Surely of faythe.
column8: Surely of faith.

column7: But howe is this?
column8: But how is this?

column7: Truly if at any tyme I heare the gospell taughte wherin is offeryd by Christe to all men remission of synne: I muste beleue it if I woll that that sermon or preachyng of Christe shulde do me good.
column8: Truly if at any time I hear the gospel taught wherein is offered by Christe to all men remission of sin: I must believe it if I will that that sermon or preaching of Christe should do me good.

column7: But beleue it I cannot, onles by the word the holy ghost be gyuen me whych maye worke such feith in me.
column8: But believe it I cannot, unless by the word the holy ghost be given me which may work such faith in me.

column7: That if the worde & the spirite workethe in me fayth, I nede not to doubte any thynge at all herein, but that Christe hathe not only perdoned me my synnes in suche wise that they canne no more be called into iudgement and condemne me, <NOTE> but also that he hath recociled the father in heauen vnto me and made him my speciall good lorde and father in such sorte as he now knowledgeth and reputeth me for his sonne and that he wol preserue and conserue me vnto euerlasting liefe, and from hens afterward P A G Exxxi spryngeth oute peace of conscience vnto me and the spirituall ioye wherof in thys gospell oure sauioure Christe speaketh, but suche ioye oughte alweyes to growe and to be increased if it wolbe made perfecte and ful. <NOTE> Wherfore that it may growe and wyth perpetual encrease waxe greater and greater, vndoubtedly god of his most bountifull mercy will brynge to passe, if so be we instantly call vpon hym with cotynuall prayers.
column8: That if the word & the spirit worketh in me faith, I need not to doubt any thing at all herein, but that Christe hath not only pardoned me my sins in such wise that they can no more be called into judgement and condemn me, but also that he hath recociled the father in heaven unto me and made him my special good lord and father in such sort as he now knowledgeth and reputeth me for his son and that he will preserve and conserve me unto everlasting lief, and from hens afterwards PAGExxxi PAGExxxi PAGExxxi PAGExxxi springeth out peace of conscience unto me and the spiritual joy whereof in this gospel our saviour Christe speaks, but such joy ought always to grow and to be increased if it wolbe made perfect and full. Wherefore that it may grow and with perpetual increase wax greater and greater, undoubtedly god of his most bountiful mercy will bring to pass, if so be we instantly call upon him with cotynuall prayers.

column7: Syth therfore (good christen people) Christ hath gyuen vs in commaundement that for such ioye of harte we shulde praye to thentente it myght be made consumate & fully perfecte, we must here obey him that we may truly saye with ye blessed virgine Marye. <NOTE> Et exultauit spiritus meus in deo salutari meo. That is to saye.
column8: Sith therefore (good christian people) Christ hath given us in commandment that for such joy of heart we should pray to tenteth it might be made consummate & fully perfect, we must here obey him that we may truly say with you blessed virgin Mary. Et exultauit spiritus meus in deo salutari meo. That is to say.

column7: My spirite reioyseth in god my sauioure.
column8: My spirit rejoiceth in god my saviour.

column7: Finally (my brethren) Christe doth here agayne setoute the rudenes and ignorance of his apostles before theyr eyes, and confesseth that hys lessons and teachinges haue bene hithervnto but as ridles and parables vnto them, and that to the vnderstanding of such thynges as he taught them it was necessarie that he shulde not speake vnto them in parables and ryddelles, but that he shulde speake of hys father vnto them openly and frely, that is, that it was necessary that he shulde sende them the holy ghoste who myght make them able to attayne hys wordes.
column8: Finally (my brothers) Christe does here again setoute the rudeness and ignorance of his apostles before their eyes, and confesses that his lessons and teachings have be hitherunto but as riddles and parables unto them, and that to the understanding of such things as he taught them it was necessary that he should not speak unto them in parables and ryddelles, but that he should speak of his father unto them openly and freely, that is, that it was necessary that he should send them the holy ghost who might make them able to attain his words.

column7: And suerly good people this kinde of ignoraunce and blyndnes was not only in the apostles before they were confirmed with the holy ghost, <NOTE> but it is also naturally planted in all men in so moch that ther is not one whych canne either vnderstand or worke any thinge that good is, onles he be transformed by the spirite of god vnto a newe creatute.
column8: And surely good people this kind of ignorance and blindness was not only in the apostles before they were confirmed with the holy ghost, but it is also naturally planted in all men in so much that there is not one which can either understand or work any thing that good is, unless he be transformed by the spirit of god unto a new creatute.

column7: We thinke our selues neuertheles very prudent and wyse euen as the apostles dyd in this gospell sayenge, lo nowe thou speakeste frely & openly, neyther speakest thou any parable, now I know that thou knowest al thinges.
column8: We think our selves nevertheless very prudent and wise even as the apostles did in this gospel saying, lo now thou speakest freely & openly, neither speakest thou any parable, now I know that thou knowest all things.

column7: &c. But no doubt thys was a very folyshe rashnes and arrogauncie euen as that was, that Peter dyd when he wolde go with Christ both into pryson and into death by whyche rashe promise he shamed hymselfe when before the cocke crewe he denied his Maister Christ thryse.
column8: etc. But no doubt this was a very foolish rashness and arrogance even as that was, that Peter did when he would go with Christ both into prison and into death by which rash promise he shamed himself when before the cock crew he denied his Master Christ thrice.

column7: Wherfore all thys hole thynge is wrytten for oure cause that we shuld not arrogautly presume to take any thynge vpon vs rashely and temerariously, but that we shuld rather walke in an humble mynd and spirite, confessinge and knowledginge continually that we be bothe miserable and ignoraunte persons in such thynges as concerne Christes glorye, forasmoche as without the spirite of god we canne neuer vnderstande the mystery of the gospel.
column8: Wherefore all this hold thing is written for our cause that we should not arrogautly presume to take any thing upon us rashly and temerariously, but that we should rather walk in and humble mind and spirit, confessing and knowledging continually that we be both miserable and ignorant persons in such things as concern Christes glory, forasmuch as without the spirit of god we can never understand the mystery of the gospel.

column7: For assuredly the wysdome of the fleshe is foly before god, and the more knowlege it boasteth & pretendith in spiritual and diuine thynges, so moch the more is the foly of it declared and vttered.
column8: For assuredly the wisdom of the flesh is folly before god, and the more knowledge it boasts & pretendith in spiritual and divine things, so much the more is the folly of it declared and uttered.

column7: Let vs then my good brethren and sisters in all oure necessities and troubles pray accordynge to the wordes of this gospel, but to whom?
column8: Let us then my good brothers and sisters in all our necessities and troubles pray according to the words of this gospel, but to whom?

column7: To the father of heuen.
column8: To the father of heaven.

column7: In whose name?
column8: In whose name?

column7: In Christes. <NOTE> what shall we praye for? that our ioye may be perfyte & full.
column8: In Christes. what shall we pray for? that our joy may be perfect & full.

column7: What is thys to saye? that by Christ our sinne beynge taken away, our conscience maye be quyet and sure of euerlastinge lyfe, whyche P A G Exxxij is a ryght perfecte ioye.
column8: What is this to say? that by Christ our sin being taken away, our conscience may be quiet and sure of everlasting life, which PAGExxxij PAGExxxij PAGExxxij PAGExxxij is a right perfect joy.

column7: Let vs praye that we maye be taught openly and playnly wythout prouerbes or parables, that is, yt we maye receyue the holy spirite of coforte into our soules whych in gods worde maye instructe vs of all trouth.
column8: Let us pray that we may be taught openly and plainly without proverbs or parables, that is, that we may receive the holy spirit of coforte into our souls which in gods word may instruct us of all troth.

column7: Whych graunt vs God the father of heuen.
column8: Which grant us God the father of heaven.

column7: Qui viuit et regnat in secula seculorum.
column8: Qui viuit et regnat in secula seculorum.

column7: Amen.: sermon A sermon in the Rogation weke or a briefe instruction for the weake in the faithe what they ought to do in these dayes of Rogation.
column8: Amen.: sermon A sermon in the Rogation week or a brief instruction for the weak in the faith what they ought to do in these days of Rogation.

column7: G Ood people thys weke is called the Rogation weke, bicause in thys weke we be wote to make solemne and general supplycatios or prayers which in Greke be called Lytanyes. <NOTE> Nowe therfore I exhorte you and in the Lordes name I require you, that in al your Litanies or supplications ye wol so do, that the thynge maye agre to the name, and that this oure Litanye, thys our supplication and rogation may be made wythe such true and ernest fayth, that we may admonishe god and put him in mynde of hys fatherly promises.
column8: GOod GOod people this week is called the Rogation week, because in this week we be wot to make solemn and general supplycatios or prayers which in Greek be called Lytanyes. Now therefore I exhort you and in the Lords name I require you, that in all your Litanies or supplications you will so do, that the thing may agree to the name, and that this our Litanye, this our supplication and rogation may be made wythe such true and earnest faith, that we may admonish god and put him in mind of his fatherly promises.

column7: He that wyll not endeuour hymselfe to do this, let hym tarye styll at home, let him kepe him and absteyne from thys holy processio lest he happen to iritate and to angre god more, then other men shalbe hable to pacifie and styll hym. <NOTE> Albeit (alacke for pitie) these solemne & accustomable processions and supplications, whyche we vse commonly as in this weke to make, be now growen into a ryght foule and detestable abuse, so that the moost parte of men and women in these solemne dayes of supplication do come forth rather to set out & shewe themselues and to passe the tyme wyth vayne & vnprofytable tales and mery fables than to make general supplications and prayers to god for theyr necessities.
column8: He that will not endeavour himself to do this, let him tarry still at home, let him keep him and abstain from this holy processio lest he happen to iritate and to anger god more, then other men shall able to pacify and still him. Albeit (alack for pity) these solemn & accustomable procession and supplications, which we use commonly as in this week to make, be now grown into a right foul and detestable abuse, so that the most part of men and women in these solemn days of supplication do come forth rather to set out & show themselves and to pass the time with vain & unprofitable tales and merry fables than to make general supplications and prayers to god for their necessities.

column7: I let passe the other enormities and vices, whych on these dayes be customably perpetrate and done.
column8: I let pass the other enormities and vices, which on these days be customably perpetrate and done.

column7: I wyll not speake of the rage and furour of these vplandysh processions and gangynges about, whych be spente in ryottynge and in bely chere.
column8: I will not speak of the rage and furor of these uplandish procession and gangynges about, which be spent in ryottynge and in belly cheer.

column7: Furthermore the banners and badges of the crosse be so vnreuerently handled and abused that I maruayle greatly God destroye vs not all in one yeare.
column8: Furthermore the banners and badges of the cross be so unreverently handled and abused that I marvel greatly God destroy us not all in one year.

column7: What shall I say?
column8: What shall I say?

column7: Surely they are now growen into such abuse that there be farre greter causes to take them awaye and vtterly to abrogate them wyth the other holydayes, than ther were in tymes past to institute and ordeyne them.
column8: Surely they are now grown into such abuse that there be far greater causes to take them away and utterly to abrogate them with the other holidays, than there were in times past to institute and ordain them.

column7: And assuredly it is the parte of byshops, of parsons, of vycares, and curates, yea & also of ye prophane Magistrates to se that those vnchristen and vngodly abuses be auoyded and taken awaye, or, yf the thynge be past remedy, vtterly to abolish and abrogate these letanies and supplicacios thus abused.
column8: And assuredly it is the part of bishops, of parsons, of vycares, and curates, yea & also of the profane Magistrates to see that those unchristen and ungodly abuses be avoided and taken away, or, if the thing be passed remedy, utterly to abolish and abrogate these litanies and supplicacios thus abused.

column7: For assuredly it were much better and more christian lyke, <NOTE> christian men and women were gathered and assembled together in the church there to make theyr supplications & prayers to god, than after such an hethe & vnruly fashion to mocke God and his holy sygnes.
column8: For assuredly it were much better and more christian like, christian men and women were gathered and assembled together in the church there to make their supplications & prayers to god, than after such and heathen & unruly fashion to mock God and his holy signs.

column7: And (no doubt) such as be curates and herdmen of Christes churche shall rendre a sharpe rekenynge and accomptes to God for P A G Exxxiij wynkynge at these abuses.
column8: And (no doubt) such as be curates and herdsmen of Christes church shall render a sharp reckoning and accounts to God for PAGExxxiij PAGExxxiij PAGExxxiij PAGExxxiij winking at these abuses.

column7: Now in these Rogation dayes, <NOTE> two thynges are to be asked of God and prayed for.
column8: Now in these Rogation days, two things are to be asked of God and prayed for.

column7: The fyrst is, that God of hys goodnes and clemecy woll defende and saue ye corne in the felde, and that he woll purge the ayer, to thintent that not only the lappe of the earth may be replenished wyth seasonable rayne, and that the ayer maye be tempered to the vtilitie and furtheraunce of the corne, but also that it be not infected & that by the eatynge and drynkynge therof neyther we nor our bestes do catche any pestilence, poxe, feuers, or other diseases. <NOTE> For as testifyeth saynt Paul in hys fyrst epistle to Timothie, gods creatures as meate, drynke, corne, <NOTE> such other thynges be sanctifyed by the worde of God, and by prayer.
column8: The fyrst is, that God of his goodness and clemency will defend and save you corn in the field, and that he will purge the air, to intent that not only the lap of the earth may be replenished with seasonable rain, and that the air may be tempered to the utility and furtherance of the corn, but also that it be not infected & that by the eating and drinking thereof neither we nor our bests doe catch any pestilence, pox, fevers, or other diseases. For as testifieth saint Paul in his fyrst epistle to Timothie, gods creatures as meat, drink, corn, such other things be sanctified by the word of God, and by prayer.

column7: For fro whence come pestilencies & the other kindes of diseases and of syckenesses than that the noysome spirites do infecte the aier?
column8: For from whence come pestilences & the other kinds of diseases and of sicknesses than that the noisome spirits do infect the air?

column7: And by reason herof comonly our corne and grayne be peryshed, infected, and blasted, and so we (God permyttynge the same) by eatynge and drynkynge our owne grayne do gette vs death and greuouse affections of the body.
column8: And by reason hereof commonly our corn and grain be perished, infected, and blasted, and so we (God permyttynge the same) by eating and drinking our own grain do get us death and grievous affections of the body.

column7: For this cause be certayne gospels redde in the wyde felde amoges the corne and grasse, that by the vertue and efficacie of gods worde, the power of the wycked spirites whych kepe in the ayer may be broken, and the ayer made pure & cleane, to thintent the corne maye remayne vntouched & not infected of the sayd hurtfull spirites but serue vs for our vse and bodely sustenaunce.
column8: For this cause be certain gospels red in the wide field amoges the corn and grass, that by the virtue and efficacy of gods word, the power of the wicked spirits which keep in the air may be broken, and the air made pure & clean, to intent the corn may remain untouched & not infected of the said hurtful spirits but serve us for our use and bodily sustenance.

column7: Wherfore (my deare brethren) we oughte to make these solemne processions wyth ernest myndes and wyth all reuerence, & in especiall we oughte to handle and to heare the worde of God wyth deuoute and religiouse myndes.
column8: Wherefore (my deer brothers) we ought to make these solemn procession with earnest minds and with all reverence, & in especial we ought to handle and to hear the word of God with devout and religious minds.

column7: Thus doynge, doute we nothynge, but that gods worde wol vtter and execute hys vertue vpon the corne and ayer, that those noysome spirites of the ayer shall do no hurte at all to our corne.
column8: Thus doing, doute we nothing, but that gods word will utter and execute his virtue upon the corn and air, that those noisome spirits of the air shall do no hurt at all to our corn.

column7: Seconde, thys is also moost of all to be desyred & humbly to be prayed for in these rogation dayes, that God woll vouchsaue to blesse hys creatures not only (as before is sayd) for the comoditie of oure bodyes, but also for our soules helth, lest our miserable soules do herby catche vnto themselues pestiferous infection and damnable contagion.
column8: Seconde, this is also most of all to be desired & humbly to be prayed for in these rogation days, that God will vouchsaue to bless his creatures not only (as before is said) for the commodity of our bodies, but also for our souls health, lest our miserable souls do hereby catch unto themselves pestiferous infection and damnable contagion.

column7: I meane as thus: The poyson and infection of the soule is synne.
column8: I mean as thus: The poison and infection of the soul is sin.

column7: Now whan God poureth vpon vs plentyful croppes and increase of all thynges: forthwyth we beynge moost ingrate and vnkynde persons do vylaynously gyue oure selues to dayly bankettes and feastynges and to moost beastly fyllynge of our pachies, herof by & by ensueth ydelnes, & of it sprynge whordomes, adulteries, blasphemies, cursynges, periuries, murders, warres, and all myschiefe, so that it were much better for vs yf our corne and cattel dyd not so happely and plenteously prosper and take.
column8: Now when God pours upon us plentyful crops and increase of all things: forthwith we being most ingrate and kind persons do vylaynously gyve our selves to daily banquets and feastings and to most beastly filling of our pachies, hereof by & by ensueth idleness, & of it spring whoredoms, adulteries, blasphemies, cursings, perjuries, murders, wars, and all mischief, so that it were much better for us if our corn and cattle did not so happily and plenteously prosper and take.

column7: So the thynge that we demaunded in our processions and supplications we do fynde, for god maketh vs here aboundauntly in this behalfe to enioye our requestes and desyres and doth minister al thynges to the bodye wyth a large blessynge, whyche thynge neuerthelesse is moost present poyson and pestilence to the soule and it is the occasion of great myschefe.
column8: So the thing that we demanded in our procession and supplications we do find, for god makes us here abundantly in this behalf to enjoy our requests and desires and does minister all things to the body with a large blessing, which thing nevertheless is most present poison and pestilence to the soul and it is the occasion of great mischief.

column7: For doubtles surfettynge and ydelnes, of all noughtynes P A G Exxxiiij be the rotes, and the fountaynes of all euels.
column8: For doubtless surfeiting and idleness, of all noughtynes PAGExxxiiij PAGExxxiiij PAGExxxiiij PAGExxxiiij be the rotes, and the fountains of all evils.

column7: But alake, alake, thys goostly infection we nothing at all regarde, we passe not of it. <NOTE> The pestilece which noyeth the body we eschue it with great care and we study to dryue it awaye wyth often prayers and supplications laynge vnto it all the medicines and remedies we can deuyse.
column8: But alake, alake, this ghostly infection we nothing at all regard, we pass not of it. The pestilece which noyeth the body we eschew it with great care and we study to drive it away with often prayers and supplications long unto it all the medicines and remedies we can devise.

column7: But in thys spirituall pestilence we go styll on and procede wythout care or thought and euen for thys purpose as it semeth we desyre of God large sustentacion and aboundaunce of al thynges and to be delyuered from the corporal pestilence and infections that we maye the more frely and aboundautly endure after a delicate sorte in ye spirituall infection.
column8: But in this spiritual pestilence we go still on and proceed without care or thought and even for this purpose as it seemeth we desire of God large sustentation and abundance of all things and to be delivered from the corporal pestilence and infections that we may the more freely and aboundautly endure after a delicate sort in you spiritual infection.

column7: But assuredly (my frendes) almyghty god the sercher of hartes whyle he seyth vs slepynge in such careles wyse and that we nothynge regarde thys so pestilent a pestilece: he also winketh at our destruction accordynge to our owne vowes & requestes, he graunteth vs copye and aboundaunce of all thynges and so blyndeth vs wyth the prosperous successe of all thynges and drowneth vs in the synke and puddell of synnes tyll at last oure synnes by longe vse runne into a custome and that the name of synne be forgotten.
column8: But assuredly (my friends) almighty god the searcher of hearts while he sayeth us sleeping in such careless wise and that we nothing regard this so pestilent a pestilece: he also winketh at our destruction according to our own vows & requests, he granteth us copy and abundance of all things and so blindeth us with the prosperous success of all things and drowneth us in the sink and puddell of sins till at last our sins by long use run into a custom and that the name of sin be forgotten.

column7: Wherfore moost dearely beloued brethren and systers albeit euery day we ought to exhibite supplications and prayers to the Lorde wyth a rough chastisement of our body to dryue awaye fro vs so horrible floudes of all myschefe, namely in thys region moost addict and gyuen to comessacions, to bankettynges, to reuelynges, to surfettynges, to ydelnes, & to the vyces that ensue of them to thintent that god ones at laste maye lyghten vs wyth hys grace that we maye vse his gyftes to the helth of our soule and to the holsomnes of our body, in suche sorte, as these goodes of the contrey, I meane our corne and cattel myght be auaylable aswell to the tuicion and defece of our body as to our soules health.
column8: Wherefore most dearly beloved brothers and sisters albeit every day we ought to exhibit supplications and prayers to the Lord with a rough chastisement of our body to drive away from us so horrible floods of all mischief, namely in this region most addict and given to comessacions, to banquetings, to reuelynges, to surfeitings, to idleness, & to the vices that ensue of them to intent that god ones at laste may lighten us with his grace that we may use his gifts to the health of our soul and to the holsomnes of our body, in such sort, as these goods of the country, I mean our corn and cattle might be available aswell to the tuition and defence of our body as to our souls health.

column7: But as I haue sayd and saye agayne God hath made vs so blynde and so vnsauery, <NOTE> that we are waxen playne Epicures vtterly voyde of all feare or care of God mooste shamefully abusynge hys gyftes to the ryot of the body and destruction of the soule.
column8: But as I have said and say again God hath made us so blind and so unsavoury, that we are waxed plain Epicures utterly void of all fear or care of God most shamefully abusing his gifts to the riot of the body and destruction of the soul.

column7: And for asmuche as thys our detestable wickednes and abuse of this godly institucion is not amended but waxeth yerly worse and worse, therfore God hath gyuen vs vp in to a disalowed mynde so yt we make these letanyes and rogation dayes by our sinnes vtterly vnprofytable and vnfrutfull vnto vs. <NOTE> Beholde how angrye and how sore displeased God is wyth vs, neyther is there any to aswage and appeace hys fury, syth our letanyes, our supplications, processions, & prayers wherewyth we rather mocke god tha worshyp hym, spendynge our tyme and abusynge hys benefites in thys wyse: be rather kyndlynges and nouryshmentes of goddes indignation and vengeaunce, tha mitigacions and swagynges therof.
column8: And for asmuch as this our detestable wickedness and abuse of this godly institution is not amended but waxes yearly worse and worse, therefore God hath given us up in to a disallowed mind so that we make these letanyes and rogation days by our sins utterly unprofitable and unfruitful unto us Behold how angry and how soar displeased God is with us, neither is there any to assuage and appeace his fury, sith our letanyes, our supplications, procession, & prayers wherewith we rather mock god tha worship him, spending our time and abusing his benefits in this wise: be rather kyndlynges and nourishments of gods indignation and vengeance, than mitigations and swagynges thereof.

column7: God graunt therfore and be presently at hade & assystent to vs (good people) that ones at last we may come home againe to our selues and to returne to the hart and that we may beynge instincted and kyndled wyth ernest and sure fayth put from vs hys wrath and displeasure, to whome be prayses and glory, in secula seculorum Amen.
column8: God grant therefore and be presently at hade & assystent to us (good people) that ones at last we may come home again to our selves and to return to the heart and that we may being instincted and kindled with earnest and sure faith put from us his wrath and displeasure, to whom be praises and glory, in secula seculorum Amen.

column7: : homily P A G Exxxv The epistle on the Ascension daye.
column8: : homily PAGExxxv PAGExxxv PAGExxxv PAGExxxv The epistle on the Ascension day.

column7: The fyrst chapter of the actes of the Apostles.
column8: The fyrst chapter of the acts of the Apostles.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Christes Ascension into heauen is here described.
column8: Christes Ascension into heaven is here described.

column7: IN the former treatyse (Deare Theophylus) we haue spoken of all that Iesus beganne to do and teach, vntyll the daye in whych he was taken vp, after that he, thorow the holy goost, had gyuen commaundemente vnto the Apostles whome he hadde chosen, <NOTE> to whom also he shewed hymselfe alyue after hys passion (and that by many tokens) appearynge vnto them fourtye dayes, and speakynge of the kyngdome of God, <NOTE> and gathered them together, and commaunded them, that they shulde not departe fro Ierusale: <NOTE> but to wayte for the promise of the father wherof (sayth he) ye haue herd of me For Ihon truly baptysed with water: <NOTE> but ye shalbe baptised wyth the holy gost after these few dayes.
column8: IN the former treatise (Dear Theophylus) we have spoken of all that Jesus began to do and teach, until the day in which he was taken up, after that he, thorough the holy ghost, had given commandment unto the Apostles whom he had chosen, to whom also he showed himself alive after his passion (and that by many tokens) appearing unto them fourtye days, and speaking of the kingdom of God, and gathered them together, and commanded them, that they should not depart from Ierusale: but to wait for the promise of the father whereof (say he) you have heard of me For Ihon truly baptised with water: but you shall baptised with the holy ghost after these few days.

column7: Whan they therfore were come together, <NOTE> they asked of hym, saynge: Lorde, wylt thou at this tyme restore agayne the kyngdom to Israel?
column8: When they therefore were come together, they asked of him, saying: Lord, wilt thou at this time restore again the kingdom to Israel?

column7: And he said vnto them: <NOTE> It is not for you to knowe the tymes or the seasons, whych the father hath put in hys owne power: but ye shall receaue power after that the holy goost is come vpon you. <NOTE> And ye shalbe wytnesses vnto me, not only in Ierusalem, but also in all Iewry and in Samary, and euen vnto the worldes ende.
column8: And he said unto them: It is not for you to know the times or the seasons, which the father hath put in his own power: but you shall receive power after that the holy ghost is come upon you. And you shall witnesses unto me, not only in Jerusalem, but also in all Jewry and in Samary, and even unto the world's end.

column7: And wha he had spoke these thynges, whyle they behelde, he was taken vp an hye, <NOTE> and a cloude receaued hym vp out of theyr syght.
column8: And wha he had spoke these things, while they beheld, he was taken up and high, and a cloud received him up out of their sight.

column7: And whyle they loked stedfastly vp toward heaue, as he went, beholde, two men stode by them in whyte apparell whych also sayd: <NOTE> ye men of Galilee, why stande ye gasynge vp into heauen?
column8: And while they looked steadfastly up towards heave, as he went, behold, two men stood by them in white apparel which also said: you men of Galilee, why stand you gazing up into heaven?

column7: Thys same Iesus whyche is taken vp from you into heauen, shall so come, euen as ye haue sene hym go vp into heauen.
column8: This same Jesus which is taken up from you into heaven, shall so come, even as you have seen him go up into heaven.

column7: W Elbeloued brethren and systers in our Sauiour Christe, thys daye is called the Ascension daye, because that as thys daye, Christe our Sauiour and redemer mounted or styed vp to heauen after hys resurrection leauynge hys Apostles and disciples vpon the earth whych thynge is one of the articles of our Crede or beleue.
column8: Well-beloved Well-beloved brothers and sisters in our Saviour Christe, this day is called the Ascension day, because that as this day, Christe our Saviour and redeemer mounted or stied up to heaven after his resurrection leaving his Apostles and disciples upon the earth which thing is one of the articles of our Crede or believe.

column7: And albeit saynt Luke the holy Euagelist doth ascertayne vs of this thing in the ende of hys Gospell whych he wrote of the actes and lyfe of Christ, yet for asmuche as he touched the thynge but brefly and lyghtly there, therfore he doeth here in the lesson of thys daye whych is the begynnynge of an other boke that he wrote for our instruction of the dedes and actes of the Apostles, intreate the mater more at large.
column8: And albeit saint Lycia the holy Euagelist does ascertain us of this thing in the end of his Gospel which he wrote of the acts and life of Christ, yet for asmuch as he touched the thing but briefly and lightly there, therefore he doth here in the lesson of this day which is the beginning of and other book that he wrote for our instruction of the deeds and acts of the Apostles, entreat the mater more at large.

column7: Fyrst therfore ye shall marke and obserue (good people) that the Euangelical histories do paynt out Christ vnto vs as yet couered wyth the burthen of ye fleshe, <NOTE> as yet not glorifyed, how be it in the meane season he declared hymselfe aswell by hys heauenly doctrine as by many hys myracles which he shewed that he was very God.
column8: Fyrst therefore you shall mark and observe (good people) that the Euangelical histories do paint out Christ unto us as yet covered with the burden of the flesh, as yet not glorified, how be it in the mean season he declared himself aswell by his heavenly doctrine as by many his miracles which he showed that he was very God.

column7: But in the actes of the Apostles he is described and set forth vnto vs as one that nowe raygneth & is glorifyed.
column8: But in the acts of the Apostles he is described and set forth unto us as one that now reigneth & is glorified.

column7: Thus therfore saynt P A G Exxxvij Luke begynneth hys description.
column8: Thus therefore saint PAGExxxvij PAGExxxvij PAGExxxvij PAGExxxvij Lycia beginneth his description.

column7: In the former treatyse or boke whych I wrote dearly beloued fred Theophilus (whych by interpretation sygnifyeth a louer of God) we haue spoken of all that Iesus beganne to do and teache. <NOTE> He sayeth not of all that Iesus began to teache & do.
column8: In the former treatise or book which I wrote dearly beloved fred Theophilus (which by interpretation signifieth a lover of God) we have spoken of all that Jesus began to do and teach. He sayeth not of all that Jesus began to teach & do.

column7: For our Sauiour Christe fyrst dyd practyse and worke such thynges as he afterwarde taught.
column8: For our Saviour Christe fyrst did practise and work such things as he afterward taught.

column7: He wente to Ihons baptisme. <NOTE> He wythdrewe hymselfe for a season out of the company of the worlde afore he wolde take vpon hym to preache, and to teach other. <NOTE> The spirite led hym into wyldernesse, where he fasted fourty dayes and fourty nyghtes.
column8: He went to Ihons baptism. He withdrew himself for a season out of the company of the world afore he would take upon him to preach, and to teach other. The spirit led him into wilderness, where he fasted fourty days and fourty nights.

column7: He suffred there moost sharpe honger to arme hymselfe wyth abstinence and pacience.
column8: He suffered there most sharp hunger to arm himself with abstinence and patience.

column7: He there endured the mooste bytter assaultes and temtacions of our goostly enemye the deuell, as appeareth manyfestly in the fourth chapter of Mathewe.
column8: He there endured the most bitter assaults and temptations of our ghostly enemy the devil, as appears manifestly in the fourth chapter of Mathewe.

column7: Al thys he dyd to shewe vs an exeple how we ought to do.
column8: All this he did to show us and exeple how we ought to do.

column7: We haue many teachers but fewe doers.
column8: We have many teachers but few doers.

column7: Thou (sayeth Paule) whyche teachest another, <NOTE> teachest not thy selfe.
column8: Thou (sayeth Paule) which teachest another, teachest not thy self.

column7: Thou preachest a man shulde not steale, and thou stealest thy selfe.
column8: Thou preachest a man should not steal, and thou stealest thy self.

column7: Thou that sayest a man shulde not commytte adultrye, comyttest horedome thy selfe.
column8: Thou that sayest a man should not commit adultrye, comyttest whoredom thy self.

column7: Thou abhorrest ymages, & yet thou doest robbe God of hys due honour.
column8: Thou abhorrest images, & yet thou dost rob God of his due honour.

column7: Christ byddeth hys Apostles and preachers that theyr lyght shulde shyne before men. <NOTE> He wolde haue them to be the salt of the earth.
column8: Christ biddeth his Apostles and preachers that their light should shine before men. He would have them to be the salt of the earth.

column7: But yf the salt (sayeth he) be vnsauery, wherewith shal it be sauered? it is good for nothyng but to be cast out of the dores and trode vnder fete.
column8: But if the salt (sayeth he) be unsavoury, wherewith shall it be savoured? it is good for nothing but to be cast out of the doors and trodden under feet.

column7: And in conclusion he sayeth in thys wyse.
column8: And in conclusion he sayeth in this wise.

column7: Whosoeuer doth and teacheth, the same shalbe called greate in the kyngdome of heauen.
column8: Whosoever does and teaches, the same shall called great in the kingdom of heaven.

column7: Yea he furthermore assureth vs, <NOTE> that onles our ryghtuousnes do passe the ryghtuousnes of the scribes, and pharisees: we shall not entre into the kyngdome of heauen.
column8: Yea he furthermore assureth us, that unless our righteousness do pass the righteousness of the scribes, and pharisees: we shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.

column7: But wol ye knowe good people what be scribes and pharisees?
column8: But will you know good people what be scribes and pharisees?

column7: Herken what Christe sayeth in the.xxiij. chapter of Mathew.
column8: Harken what Christe sayeth in the xxiij chapter of Mathew.

column7: The scribes and pharisees syt in Moses chaire.
column8: The scribes and pharisees fit in Moses chair.

column7: All therfore that they byd you obserue, that obserue and do, but do not ye after theyr workes, for they saye and do not.
column8: All therefore that they bid you observe, that observe and do, but do not you after their works, for they say and do not.

column7: Yea they bynde together heuy burthes and greuous to be borne, and laye them on mens backes, but they themselues wyll not heue at them wyth one of theyr fyngers.
column8: Yea they bind together heavy burthes and grievous to be born, and say them on men's backs, but they themselves will not heaven at them with one of their fingers.

column7: But let vs now se, whether there be any suche scribes and pharisees amoges Christe men, <NOTE> as were in olde tyme amonges the Iues.
column8: But let us now see, whither there be any such scribes and pharisees amoges Christe men, as were in old time among the Iues.

column7: Origene that auncient doctour, <NOTE> wrytynge vpon thys place of Mathew, sayeth, that those be scribes, whych depart not from the letter of the law.
column8: Origene that ancient doctor, writing upon this place of Mathew, sayeth, that those be scribes, which depart not from the letter of the law.

column7: These be such persons as teach nothynge but the outwarde obseruynge and as who shulde saye the barke of the lawe, where as accordynge to saynt Paule the lawe kylleth and the spirite quyckeneth. <NOTE> For as saynt Austine doth very well declare, <NOTE> the letter of the lawe wythout the spirite is not ynough.
