column8: These be such persons as teach nothing but the outward observing and as who should say the bark of the law, where as according to saint Paule the law killeth and the spirit quickeneth. For as saint Austine does very well declare, the letter of the law without the spirit is not enough.

column7: It is the spirite that quyckeneth, <NOTE> of whome, onles a ma be borne agayne, he can not entre into the kyngdome of God.
column8: It is the spirit that quickeneth, of whom, unless a ma be born again, he can not enter into the kingdom of God.

column7: Thys spirite is wont to lede men into al trouth, he discloseth and openeth vnto vs the pyth of the lawe, that is to say, the lyuely and ernest fayth in Messias that was promysed so longe before by the prophetes, euen our sauiour Christ Iesus, for whose loue we ought frelye P A G Exxxvij to fulfyll and worke the lawe and not constrainedly lyke slaues and bondmen, forasmuch as the spirite of God hath infranchised vs and made vs Christes freemen.
column8: This spirit is wont to lede men into all troth, he discloseth and openeth unto us the pyth of the law, that is to say, the lively and earnest faith in Messias that was promised so long before by the prophets, even our saviour Christ Jesus, for whose love we ought freely PAGExxxvij PAGExxxvij PAGExxxvij PAGExxxvij to fulfil and work the law and not constrainedly like slaves and bondmen, forasmuch as the spirit of God hath enfranchised us and made us Christes freemen.

column7: They than whych teach not thys fredome and enfranchisement of christian men, that is to wit whych teach not the pyth or karnell of the lawe but the barke or houske, be no better than scribes. <NOTE> Now I pray you, what other be al papistes but euen such & worse, for they can skant abyde to teache so muche as the letter of gods law, whych neuertheles beyng taught nakedly and alone doth but kyll, it quyckeneth not.
column8: They than which teach not this freedom's and enfranchisement of christian men, that is to wit which teach not the pyth or karnell of the law but the bark or houske, be no better than scribes. Now I pray you, what other be all papists but even such & worse, for they can skant abide to teach so much as the letter of gods law, which nevertheless being taught nakedly and alone does but kill, it quickeneth not.

column7: Yea they wol teach welnere nothynge but theyr owne traditions, customes and beggerly elemetes.
column8: Yea they will teach welnere nothing but their own traditions, customs and beggarly elemetes.

column7: I haue brefly shewed you (my frendes) which be scribes, accordynge to the definition of the auncient doctour Origene.
column8: I have briefly showed you (my friends) which be scribes, according to the definition of the ancient doctor Origene.

column7: Let vs now se, <NOTE> what he calleth a Pharisee.
column8: Let us now see, what he calls a Pharisee.

column7: Such as professynge (sayeth he) some greater thyng do diuide themselues as better from the multitude and comon sorte of men, be called pharisees, which by interpretacion be as much to say as diuisi or segregati, that is to wyt, diuided or seuered persons.
column8: Such as professing (sayeth he) some greater thing do divide themselves as better from the multitude and common sort of men, be called pharisees, which by interpretation be as much to say as divisi or segregati, that is to wit, divided or severed persons.

column7: For Phares in Ebrue is called a diuision.
column8: For Phares in Ebrue is called a division.

column7: Now accordynge to thys definicion whether there be any pharisees in Christendome I reporte me to your selues.
column8: Now according to this definition whither there be any pharisees in Christendome I report me to your selves.

column7: Lorde God what diuisions, what sectes what sudry sutes of holy holy persons haue we had in Englade now of late whych thought themselues better and holyer than the rest of people, yea whiche wolde suffer none to be called religiouse but themselues, where as after the diffinitio of saint Iames, they were as farre wyde and differed as much from religiouse persons, as an ape differre from an owle.
column8: Lord God what divisions, what sects what sudry suits of holy holy persons have we had in Englade now of late which thought themselves better and holier than the rest of people, yea which would suffer none to be called religious but themselves, where as after the diffinitio of saint Iames, they were as far wide and differed as much from religious persons, as and ape differre from and owl.

column7: But let vs retourne to our lection.
column8: But let us return to our lection.

column7: These scribes and pharisees dyd teach but they dyd not ye thinges whych they taught.
column8: These scribes and pharisees did teach but they did not you things which they taught.

column7: Christ (as saynt Luke doth here wytnesse) fyrste dyd the thynges, and after he taught them.
column8: Christ (as saint Lycia does here witness) fyrste did the things, and after he taught them.

column7: And of all these thynges (sayth Luke) whych Iesus began to do and teache vntyll ye tyme of hys ascension haue we spoken in the former treatyse.
column8: And of all these things (say Luke) which Jesus began to do and teach until you time of his ascension have we spoken in the former treatise.

column7: Thys treatyse we call comonly the Gospell of saynt Luke.
column8: This treatise we call commonly the Gospel of saint Lycia.

column7: Now than whan the Apostles were as on thys daye assembled and come together they asked Christ, sayenge: Lorde wylte thou at thys tyme restore agayne the kyngdome of Israel?
column8: Now than when the Apostles were as on this day assembled and come together they asked Christ, saying: Lord wilt thou at this time restore again the kingdom of Israel?

column7: Lo (good people) here ye haue a ryght notable exemple of the Apostles infirmitie and weakenes. <NOTE> For albeit they had herde oftentymes that Christes kyngdome or raygne shulde be spirituall yet they continued styll to dreame of a certaine corporal Monarchy or rule.
column8: Lo (good people) here you have a right notable exemple of the Apostles infirmity and weakness. For albeit they had herd oftentimes that Christes kingdom or reign should be spiritual yet they continued still to dream of a certain corporal Monarchy or rule.

column7: But nowe what doth Christe vnto them?
column8: But now what does Christe unto them?

column7: Albeit they thought & spake foolyshly, yet he reiected them not, but ryght gently he plucketh them awaye from those carnall thoughtes, saynge: It is not for you to knowe the tymes or the seasons which the father hath put in hys owne power, as who shulde saye, medle ye wyth your office wherevnto ye be appoynted.
column8: Albeit they thought & spoke foolishly, yet he rejected them not, but right gently he plucketh them away from those carnal thoughts, saying: It is not for you to know the times or the seasons which the father hath put in his own power, as who should say, meddle you with your office whereunto you be appointed.

column7: Your office is to testifye of me & of my doctrine.
column8: Your office is to testify of me & of my doctrine.

column7: Ye shalbe wytnesses (sayeth Christ) vnto me, not only in Ierusalem, but also in all Iury and in Samary, <NOTE> and euen vnto the worldes ende.
column8: You shall witnesses (sayeth Christ) unto me, not only in Jerusalem, but also in all Jury and in Samary, and even unto the world's end.

column7: And here is to be noted that Christ woll not haue hys preachers curiouse vpon ydle questions or vayne philosophie.
column8: And here is to be noted that Christ will not have his preachers curious upon idle questions or vain philosophy.

column7: For theyr only office and feate is to preache Christe and hys doctrine, that is to wyt, to set forth and propowne P A G Exxxviij only such thynges as Christe hath taught & done to be beleued of the ignoraut people for which cause also the holy goost was gyuen vnto them, eue to thintent to make the Apostles mete to teache and vs to receyue theyr teachynge. <NOTE> whan Christe had spoke these thynges, whyle hys Apostles beheld hym, lo sodenly he was taken vp on hygh, & a cloud receyued hym vp out of theyr syght. <NOTE> Here (my brethren) ye shall marke the frute and profyte of our sauiour Christes Ascension.
column8: For their only office and feat is to preach Christe and his doctrine, that is to wit, to set forth and propowne PAGExxxviij PAGExxxviij PAGExxxviij PAGExxxviij only such things as Christe hath taught & done to be believed of the ignorant people for which cause also the holy ghost was given unto them, eve to intent to make the Apostles meet to teach and us to receive their teaching. when Christe had spoke these things, while his Apostles beheld him, lo suddenly he was taken up on high, & a cloud received him up out of their sight. Here (my brothers) you shall mark the fruit and profit of our saviour Christes Ascension.

column7: For by hys styenge or ascendynge vp into heauen he wrought two thynges for vs. The one was, he had a most goodly and gloriouse triumphe vpon oure mortall enemye the deuell.
column8: For by his styenge or ascending up into heaven he wrought two things for us The one was, he had a most goodly and glorious triumph upon our mortal enemy the devil.

column7: The other was, he anone sent downe the holy goost to hys Apostles, as also the prophete Dauid wytnesseth, sayenge: Ascendit in altum, captiuam duxit captiuitatem, dedit dona hominibus. That is to saye.
column8: The other was, he anon sent down the holy ghost to his Apostles, as also the prophet Dauid witnesseth, saying: Ascendit in altum, captiuam duxit captiuitatem, dedit dona hominibus. That is to say.

column7: He ascended vp on hygh, he led captiuitie captiue, he gaue gyftes to men.
column8: He ascended up on high, he led captivity captive, he gave gifts to men.

column7: Fynally, ye shall marke yt our Sauiour Christe at hys departure from hys disciples whan he mouted vp to heauen, comforted them by hys angels, surely promysynge them, that euen suche one as they sawe hym ascendyng now vp to heue, they shulde in the last daye se agayne, at whych tyme vndoubtedly he shall rendre to euery man hys rewarde according to hys dedes.
column8: Finally, you shall mark that our Saviour Christe at his departure from his disciples when he mouted up to heaven, comforted them by his angels, surely promising them, that even such one as they saw him ascending now up to heaven, they should in the last day see again, at which time undoubtedly he shall render to every man his reward according to his deeds.

column7: They which haue done wyckedly, and wolde not beleue, shalbe condemned into hell fyre, where shalbe wepynge and gnashynge of teth.
column8: They which have done wickedly, and would not believe, shall condemned into hell fire, where shall weeping and gnashing of teth.

column7: But they that haue beleued on Christ Iesu & wyth worthy dedes haue expressed and declared theyr fayth to the worlde, they shal inherite the kyngdom of heuen and shall entre into the ioye whych the father of heauen hath prepared for them.
column8: But they that have believed on Christ Jesu & with worthy deeds have expressed and declared their faith to the world, they shall inherit the kingdom of heaven and shall enter into the joy which the father of heaven hath prepared for them.

column7: To whome wyth the sonne and holy goost be glorye and laude in infinita secula.
column8: To whom with the son and holy ghost be glory and laud in infinita secula.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospell on Ascension daye.
column8: : homily The Gospel on Ascension day.

column7: The xvi. chapter of Marke.
column8: The xvi. chapter of Mark.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Of the commission that Christe gaue to hys Apostles to preach hys gospell through out the hole worlde.
column8: Of the commission that Christe gave to his Apostles to preach his gospel through out the hold world.

column7: And howe Christe ascended vp to heauen.
column8: And how Christe ascended up to heaven.

column7: A Fter thys Iesus appeared agayne vnto the eleleue as they sat at meat: and cast in theyr teeth theyr vnbelefe and hardnes of harte, because they beleued not them whych had sene that he was rysen agayne fro the deade.
column8: AFter AFter this Jesus appeared again unto the eleleue as they sat at meat: and cast in their teeth their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they believed not them which had seen that he was risen again from the dead.

column7: And he sayd vnto them: Go ye into all the worlde, and preach the Gospell to al creatures: he that beleueth and is baptised shal be saued.
column8: And he said unto them: Go you into all the world, and preach the Gospel to all creatures: he that believeth and is baptised shall be saved.

column7: He that beleueth not shalbe damned.
column8: He that believeth not shall damned.

column7: And these tokens shall folow them that beleue.
column8: And these tokens shall follow them that believe.

column7: In my name they shal cast out deuels, they shal speake wyth new tonges, they shall dryue awaye serpetes.
column8: In my name they shall cast out devils, they shall speak with new tongues, they shall drive away serpetes.

column7: And yf they drynke any deadly thynge, it shal not hurte them.
column8: And if they drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them.

column7: They shall laye theyr handes on the sycke, and they shall recouer.
column8: They shall say their hands on the sick, and they shall recover.

column7: So then whan the Lorde had spoken vnto them he was receaued into heaue, and is on the ryght hande of God.
column8: So then when the Lord had spoken unto them he was received into heave, and is on the right hand of God.

column7: And they wente forth, and preached euery where: the Lorde workynge wyth them and confirmynge the worde P A G Exxxix wyth myracles folowynge.
column8: And they went forth, and preached every where: the Lord working with them and confirming the word PAGExxxix PAGExxxix PAGExxxix PAGExxxix with miracles following.

column7: T He Christian mans lyfe in thys present Gospel (good people) is set before our eyes.
column8: THe THe Christian men life in this present Gospel (good people) is set before our eyes.

column7: For fayth and charitie are here propouned vnto vs as in all ye rest of the gospels.
column8: For faith and charity are here proponed unto us as in all the rest of the gospels.

column7: Wherfore syth the Gospell bryngeth euer these two wyth it, we ought also continually to preache and entreate of them.
column8: Wherefore sith the Gospel bringeth ever these two with it, we ought also continually to preach and entreat of them.

column7: For he sayeth who so beleueth and be baptised shalbe saued, which thynges we shall now in order peruse and consyder.
column8: For he sayeth who so believeth and be baptised shall saved, which things we shall now in order peruse and consider.

column7: Fyrst of all Christ vpbraydeth in thys Gospell hys Apostles of theyr faynte beleue and hardenes of harte and consequently blameth them declaryng what they wanted and yet he reiecteth them not neyther is moued rygorously and hastely agaynst them but he gently blameth them none other wise than yf one of vs wolde saye to an other. <NOTE> Arte thou not ashamed to do the thynge thou goest about? speakynge after thys sorte to brynge hym to knowe hymselfe & to make hym ashamed that he may leaue of his euel enterpryse or worke, and yet we reiecte hym not nor hate hym nor yet plucke our loue from hym.
column8: Fyrst of all Christ upbraideth in this Gospel his Apostles of their faint believe and hardens of heart and consequently blameth them declaring what they wanted and yet he rejects them not neither is moved rygorously and hastily against them but he gently blameth them none other wise than if one of us would say to and other. Art thou not ashamed to do the thing thou goest about? speaking after this sort to bring him to know himself & to make him ashamed that he may leave of his evil enterprise or work, and yet we reject him not nor hate him nor yet pluck our love from him.

column7: Neyther was it a lyghte matter why the Lorde rebuked hys disciples, <NOTE> surely infidelitie or lacke of beleue is of all synnes that can be named the greatest.
column8: Neither was it a light matter why the Lord rebuked his disciples, surely infidelity or lack of believe is of all sins that can be nam the greatest.

column7: And he expresseth vnto them the maner of theyr mysbeleue whan he sayeth, that theyr hartes were hardened, and yet notwythstandynge he handleth them gently and myldely.
column8: And he expresses unto them the manner of their mysbeleue when he sayeth, that their hearts were hardened, and yet notwithstanding he handleth them gently and myldely.

column7: All these thynges were done to our comforte and consolation that we shulde not be discoraged though we be any thynge fautye in oure fayth as yf we doute, stomble, or fall, but rather that we shuld quyckly ryse agayne, establysh oure fayth and runne to God takynge trust & affiaunce at hym and constantly also retainynge it, namely syth he deleth wyth vs not accordynge to rygoure, but can wynke at our falles & infirmities.
column8: All these things were done to our comfort and consolation that we should not be discouraged though we be any thing faulty in our faith as if we doubt, stumble, or fallen, but rather that we should quickly rise again, establish our faith and run to God taking trust & affiance at him and constantly also retainynge it, namely sith he dealeth with us not according to rygoure, but can wink at our falls & infirmities.

column7: And he that reputeth hym to be such shall also fynde hym such one: I saye yf he can take hym for a mercyfull God he wyll suffer hymselfe to be founde such one, he woll so declare hymselfe towardes hym.
column8: And he that reputeth him to be such shall also find him such one: I say if he can take him for a merciful God he will suffer himself to be found such one, he will so declare himself towards him.

column7: Contrary wyse an euell conscience and an vnfaythfull harte doth not so, he beareth no such affiaunce towardes God, but flyeth from hym, reputynge hym a sore & rygorouse iudge, and therfore also fynde hym such one. The same we must also do wyth our neyghbours.
column8: Contrary wise and evil conscience and and unfaithful heart does not so, he bears no such affiance towards God, but flies from him, reputing him a soar & rygorouse judge, and therefore also find him such one. The same we must also do with our neighbours.

column7: Yf we se any swarue fro the fayth he is not to be beloued in hys malyce but we ought to reproue and laye hys faute and shrynkynge before hys eyes but yet not after such sorte that we shulde hate hym or be agaynst hym or turne our frendshyp and loue from him. <NOTE> For thus sayeth saynt Paule.
column8: If we see any swerve from the faith he is not to be beloved in his malice but we ought to reprove and say his fault and shrynkynge before his eyes but yet not after such sort that we should hate him or be against him or turn our friendship and love from him. For thus sayeth saint Paule.

column7: Brethren although a man be founde in any faute, <NOTE> that be spiritual redresse such a person wyth the spirite of mekenes.
column8: Brothers although a man be found in any fault, that be spiritual redress such a person with the spirit of meekness.

column7: But the moost holy father or god rather, the bishop of Rome whych wol be called Pope, hys byshops, hys prestes hys monkes, hys chanons, hys freers, and hys nonnes can not abyde whan that they be founde in any notable cryme, to be reproued.
column8: But the most holy father or god rather, the bishop of Room which will be called Pope, his bishops, his priests his monks, his canons, his freers, and his nuns can not abide when that they be found in any notable crime, to be reproved.

column7: For what so euer euel do chaunce they pretende and allege for them that it come not through theyr faute but through the faute of theyr subiectes. <NOTE> Theyr subiectes and suche as be vnder theyr obedience shalbe cruelly and roughlye handled.
column8: For what so ever evil do chance they pretend and allege for them that it come not through their fault but through the fault of their subjects. Their subjects and such as be under their obedience shall cruelly and roughly handled.

column7: Summa summarum any iniury and wyckednes ought to be punyshed, but loue and veritie P A G Exl must be kept towardes euery man.
column8: Summa summarum any injury and wickedness ought to be punished, but love and verity PAGExl PAGExl PAGExl PAGExl must be kept towards every man.

column7: Neyther oughte we to suffer our mouth to be stopped.
column8: Neither ought we to suffer our mouth to be stopped.

column7: For none of vs all shall so lyue as longe as we be in thys fleshe that we can be founde on euery parte blameles.
column8: For none of us all shall so live as long as we be in this flesh that we can be found on every part blameless.

column7: But I am fauty in thys thynge, and an other in that.
column8: But I am faulty in this thing, and and other in that.

column7: Namelye sythe it is ryghte manifest to all men that euen thapostles themselues lacked that whych was chyfe and the hyghest poynt of al, where as notwithstandynge, they were the corner stones and the rockes of foundacion.
column8: Namely sith it is right manifest to all men that even apostles themselves lacked that which was chyfe and the highest point of all, where as notwithstanding, they were the corner stones and the rocks of foundation.

column7: Yea and the best and the most excellent part of christendome.
column8: Yea and the best and the most excellent part of christendome.

column7: No man yet thynketh that thapostles were vtterly and all together infideles.
column8: No man yet thinketh that apostles were utterly and all together infideles.

column7: For they beleued the thynges that were wrytten in the law and in the prophetes, albeit they had not yet the full perfection of fayth.
column8: For they believed the things that were written in the law and in the prophets, albeit they had not yet the full perfection of faith.

column7: Fayth was in them and it was not in them.
column8: Fayth was in them and it was not in them.

column7: Fayth therfore is a thynge whych alwayes groweth bygger and bygger accordynge to the parable of the mustarde sede.
column8: Fayth therefore is a thing which always grows bigger and bigger according to the parable of the mustard seed.

column7: So the Apostles were not vtterly voyde and destitute of fayth for they had a parte of it.
column8: So the Apostles were not utterly void and destitute of faith for they had a part of it.

column7: For it is wyth fayth as it is wyth a man that is sycke and begynneth by lytle and lytle to crepe & vp waxe stronge.
column8: For it is with faith as it is with a man that is sick and beginneth by little and little to creep & up wax strong.

column7: The lord than expresseth and declareth to hys apostles where in they beleued not and what they wanted, whyche doubtles was that they perfytly beleued not his resurrection.
column8: The lord than expresses and declareth to his apostles where in they believed not and what they wanted, which doubtless was that they perfectly believed not his resurrection.

column7: For albeit they beleued all the rest, yet in thys behalfe they remayned infideles.
column8: For albeit they believed all the rest, yet in this behalf they remained infideles.

column7: For happely they beleued also thys that God wolde be mercyfull vnto them, but yet this was not ynough. <NOTE> For it was necessary also that they shulde beleue Christes resurrection.
column8: For happily they believed also this that God would be merciful unto them, but yet this was not enough. For it was necessary also that they should believe Christes resurrection.

column7: Wherfore he vpbraydeth them of theyr infidelitie sayenge that albeit they had sene altogether yet they beleued it not, and that they yet wated thys article of resurrection. <NOTE> What is it than to beleue the resurrection of Christ whych beareth so great a stroke and is of such importaunce that ye disciples were called infideles and mysbeleuynge persones for the defaute of it?
column8: Wherefore he upbraideth them of their infidelity saying that albeit they had seen altogether yet they believed it not, and that they yet wanted this article of resurrection. What is it than to believe the resurrection of Christ which bears so great a stroke and is of such importance that you disciples were called infideles and mysbeleuynge persons for the default of it?

column7: Certes, to beleue the resurrection of Christ is nothynge els than to beleue we haue a reconciler before God whych is Christ whych maketh vs at one wyth God the father and iustifyeth vs in hys syght.
column8: Certes, to believe the resurrection of Christ is nothing else than to believe we have a reconciler before God which is Christ which makes us at one with God the father and justifieth us in his sight.

column7: For what so euer is in man of hys owne nature and byrth wythout regeneratio is but synne and death whereby he heapeth vpon hymselfe gods vengeaunce.
column8: For what so ever is in man of his own nature and birth without regeneratio is but sin and death whereby he heapeth upon himself gods vengeance.

column7: Agayne, God is the eternal iustice and clerenes, whych of hys nature hateth synne.
column8: Again, God is the eternal justice and clearness, which of his nature hates sin.

column7: Hereof it commeth that betwene God and man is perpetuall enmitie neyther can they be frendes or agre together.
column8: Hereof it comes that between God and man is perpetual enmity neither can they be friends or agree together.

column7: Christe therfore beynge incarnate dyd bothe translate our synnes vpon hymselfe and drowned ye wrath of the father in himselfe to reconcile vs to his father.
column8: Christe therefore being incarnate did both translate our sins upon himself and drowned you wrath of the father in himself to reconcile us to his father.

column7: Wythout thys fayth we be ye chyldren of vegeaunce, we can do no good worke that maye be acceptable to God, neyther wyll God heare our prayers.
column8: Without this faith we be you children of vegeaunce, we can do no good work that may be acceptable to God, neither will God hear our prayers.

column7: For thus in the.xviij. psalme it is wrytte.
column8: For thus in the xviij psalm it is writ.

column7: They cryed and ther was no helper, to the Lorde, and he answered them not.
column8: They cried and there was no helper, to the Lord, and he answered them not.

column7: Yea the moost excellente worke wherby we thought to obtayne grace, helpe, & comforte of God was imputed vnto vs for synne, as the prophete in the.cix. psalme sayth: Oratio eius in peccatum fiat. Be hys prayer counted for synne, for surely we can not wyth al our powers of our owne nature pacifie god.
column8: Yea the most excellent work whereby we thought to obtain grace, help, & comfort of God was imputed unto us for sin, as the prophet in the cix psalm say: Oratio eius in peccatum fiat. Be his prayer counted for sin, for surely we can not with all our powers of our own nature pacify god.

column7: We neded therfore Christe to be mediatour for vs to the father, and to make vs at one P A G Exli wyth hym, and finally to obtayne what so euer is necessary for vs. By the same Christ it behoueth vs to aske of God what so euer thynge we nede, <NOTE> as Christ hymselfe enstructeth vs sayenge: What so euer ye aske the father in my name it shalbe done vnto you.
column8: We needed therefore Christe to be mediator for us to the father, and to make us at one PAGExli PAGExli PAGExli PAGExli with him, and finally to obtain what so ever is necessary for us By the same Christ it behooves us to ask of God what so ever thing we need, as Christ himself enstructeth us saying: What so ever you ask the father in my name it shall done unto you.

column7: What soeuer we demaunde of God, surely by thys Christ (which hath satisfied for our synnes) we must obteyne and get it.
column8: What soever we demand of God, surely by this Christ (which hath satisfied for our sins) we must obtain and get it.

column7: For Christ is he whych layeth a garison about vs, <NOTE> is the defece and bukler vnder whome we be hydden, euen as the chekens be nouryshed and hydde vnder the wynges of the henne.
column8: For Christ is he which layeth a garrison about us, is the defence and buckler under whom we be hidden, even as the chekens be nourished and hid under the wings of the hen.

column7: By him only our prayer is allowed before God.
column8: By him only our prayer is allowed before God.

column7: By hym onely we be herde and get the fauoure & grace of the father.
column8: By him only we be herd and get the favour & grace of the father.

column7: Thys is now to beleue vpon Christes resurrection yf as it is recited we beleue that Christ hath borne vpon hym aswell our synnes as the synnes of the hole worlde & hath drowned in hymselfe the one and the other and also theyre of the father wherby we be reconciled to God and made ryghtuouse before hym.
column8: This is now to believe upon Christes resurrection if as it is recited we believe that Christ hath born upon him aswell our sins as the sins of the hold world & hath drowned in himself the one and the other and also their of the father whereby we be reconciled to God and made righteous before him.

column7: Now ye se your selues howe fewe christian men and wemen there be whych haue thys fayth wherby all men be delyuered from theyr synnes and be made ryghtuouse. <NOTE> For they beleue not in the resurrection of Christe, that theyr synnes be taken awaye also by Christe, but go about to be iustifyed by theyr owne workes.
column8: Now you see your selves how few christian men and women there be which have this faith whereby all men be delivered from their sins and be made righteous. For they believe not in the resurrection of Christe, that their sins be taken away also by Christe, but go about to be justified by their own works.

column7: Thys man entreth into the cloyster & is made a monke or freer, she a nonne some one thynge, some another, that they may be delyuered from theyr synnes, and yet they saye they beleue in the resurrection of Christe, where theyr workes do shew cleane contrary.
column8: This man entereth into the cloister & is made a monk or freer, she a nonne some one thing, some another, that they may be delivered from their sins, and yet they say they believe in the resurrection of Christe, where their works do show clean contrary.

column7: Wherfore thys article haue the holy fathers preached and inculked specially before other.
column8: Wherefore this article have the holy father's preached and inculked specially before other.

column7: For thus saynt Paule in the.xv. chapter of hys fyrste epistle to the Corinthi. sayeth.
column8: For thus saint Paule in the xv chapter of his fyrste epistle to the Corinthi. sayeth.

column7: Yf Christ hath not rysen fro death to lyfe tha vayne is our preachynge, vayne also is your fayth, And a lytle after.
column8: If Christ hath not risen from death to life tha vain is our preaching, vain also is your faith, And a little after.

column7: Yf Christ haue not rysen vayne is youre fayth, ye be yet in your sines.
column8: If Christ have not risen vain is your faith, you be yet in your sines.

column7: What maner coseques is thys? how do thys folowe?
column8: What manner coseques is this? how do this follow?

column7: Thus truly, yf Christe rose not from death to lyfe, it foloweth, that synne & death dyd swalowe hym vp and kylled hym.
column8: Thus truly, if Christe rose not from death to life, it followeth, that sin & death did swallow him up and killed him.

column7: After that we could not ryd our selues out of our synnes, Iesus Christ toke them vpon hym to treade vnder hys fete death and hell, and to be made Lorde ouer them.
column8: After that we could not rid our selves out of our sins, Jesus Christ took them upon him to tread under his feet death and hell, and to be made Lord over them.

column7: Now yf he rose not agayne, than surely he ouercame not synne, but was ouercome of synne.
column8: Now if he rose not again, than surely he overcame not sin, but was overcome of sin.

column7: And yf he rose not agayne, he redemed vs not, and so we be yet in our synnes.
column8: And if he rose not again, he redeemed us not, and so we be yet in our sins.

column7: Furthermore in the teth to the Romaynes he sayeth thus.
column8: Furthermore in the teth to the Romans he sayeth thus.

column7: Yf thou confessest wyth thy mouth Iesus to be the Lorde, and beleuest in thy harte, that God hath raysed hym from death, <NOTE> shalt be saued.
column8: If thou confessest with thy mouth Jesus to be the Lord, and believest in thy heart, that God hath raised him from death, shalt be saved.

column7: Herevnto agreeth all scripture both olde and newe.
column8: Hereunto agreeth all scripture both old and new.

column7: But it is not yet sufficient to beleue the resurrection of Christ.
column8: But it is not yet sufficient to believe the resurrection of Christ.

column7: For al wicked persones beleue thys, yea Satan doubteth not but that God suffered & rose agayne. <NOTE> we must also beleue the summe of the resurrection and also what frute and profyte we haue taken therby, that is to saye, pardon of our gylt and as it were a gayle delyuerey of all our synnes that Christe passed thorough death and by it ouercame synne & death, yea and what so euer coulde hurt vs he trode vnder his fote and is constitute and made at the ryght hande of the father in heauen the myghty Lorde ouer syn, Satan, death, hell, and what soeuer hurteth vs and that all these thynges be done for our sake whyche P A G Exlij thynge the wycked persons beleue not.
column8: For all wicked persons believe this, yea Satan doubteth not but that God suffered & rose again. we must also believe the sum of the resurrection and also what fruit and profit we have taken thereby, that is to say, pardon of our guilt and as it were a gayle delyuerey of all our sins that Christe passed through death and by it overcame sin & death, yea and what so ever could hurt us he trodden under his foot and is constitute and made at the right hand of the father in heaven the mighty Lord over sin, Satan, death, hell, and what soever hurteth us and that all these things be done for our sake which PAGExlij PAGExlij PAGExlij PAGExlij thing the wicked persons believe not.

column7: Ye se than (my fredes) how much is layde in thys artycle of resurrection so that we may better wante all the reste than thys one article.
column8: the se than (my fredes) how much is laid in this article of resurrection so that we may better want all the rest than this one article.

column7: For what were it to beleue all the artycles, as that God was borne of the virgine Mary, that he dyed and was buryed: yf thou doest not also beleue that he rose agayne? <NOTE> And thys God meaneth in Abacuc where he sayeth: I shall worke a worke in you whych no man shall beleue whan it shalbe tolde.
column8: For what were it to believe all the articles, as that God was born of the virgin Marry, that he died and was buried: if thou dost not also believe that he rose again? And this God means in Abacuc where he sayeth: I shall work a work in you which no man shall believe when it shall told.

column7: And thys is the cause why Paule in al hys epistles handleth no worke or myracle of Christ so diligently, as he doth the resurrection of Christ.
column8: And this is the cause why Paule in all his epistles handleth no work or miracle of Christ so diligently, as he does the resurrection of Christ.

column7: Yea he letteth passe all the workes and myracles of Christ, and chefly teacheth vs the frute of it, so that none of thapostles hath so paynted Christ vnto vs as Paule. <NOTE> Wherfore not wythout cause Christ sayd to Ananias: Thys is my vessell of election to beare my name before the Hethen people, and kinges and the chyldren of Israell.
column8: Yea he lets pass all the works and miracles of Christ, and chiefly teaches us the fruit of it, so that none of apostles hath so painted Christ unto us as Paule. Wherefore not without cause Christ said to Ananias: This is my vessel of election to bear my name before the Heathen people, and kings and the children of Israell.

column7: It foloweth in the texte: Go ye into the hole worlde, and preach the Gospell to euery creature.
column8: It followeth in the text: Go you into the hold world, and preach the Gospel to every creature.

column7: What shall they preach? none other thynge, but that Christe is rysen from death, and that he hathe vaynquished and take awaye synne and all mysery, <NOTE> he that beleueth thys, is saued.
column8: What shall they preach? none other thing, but that Christe is risen from death, and that he hath vanquished and take away sin and all misery, he that believeth this, is saved.

column7: For ye gospel (which in the Greke soundeth a glad tydynges) is nothyng els, but a preachynge or shewynge of Christes resurrectio, he that gyueth fayth vnto it is saufe, he that doth not, is lost. <NOTE> And here consyder me the nature of fayth.
column8: For you gospel (which in the Greek soundeth a glad tidings) is nothing else, but a preaching or show of Christes resurrectio, he that gyveth faith unto it is saufe, he that does not, is lost. And here consider me the nature of faith.

column7: Fayth constrayneth none to the gospell, but leaueth euery man to hys owne lybertie and choise He that beleueth, maye frely beleue, he that cometh let hym come, he that wyl not, chose hym.
column8: Fayth constraineth none to the gospel, but leaveth every man to his own liberty and choice He that believeth, may freely believe, he that comes let him come, he that will not, chosen him.

column7: And here agayne ye shall marke that the Romysh byshop erreth and doth nought, in that he goeth about by violence to drawe men to the christen fayth.
column8: And here again you shall mark that the Romish bishop erreth and does nought, in that he goes about by violence to draw men to the christian faith.

column7: For besydes the preachynge of the Gospel, Christe gaue nothynge in commission vnto hys disciples.
column8: For besides the preaching of the Gospel, Christe gave nothing in commission unto his disciples.

column7: So they preached it accordyngly to theyr commission & lefte it in mens free lybertie to come to it or not.
column8: So they preached it accordingly to their commission & left it in men's free liberty to come to it or not.

column7: They sayd not, <NOTE> beleue it or I wyl kyll the.
column8: They said not, believe it or I will kill thee.

column7: So ye se ye infidels as turkes, sarases, & Iues ought not violently to be drawe to our fayth, but louyngly rather inuited and allured.
column8: So you see you infidels as turkes, sarases, & Iues ought not violently to be draw to our faith, but lovingly rather invited and allured.

column7: But here is a doubte, how thys texte ought to be vnderstande (go into al the world) syth the Apostles neuer passed through out all the worlde.
column8: But here is a doubt, how this text ought to be understand (go into all the world) sith the Apostles never passed through out all the world.

column7: For none of the apostles came so farre as to vs. Furthermore there be many Ilandes foude out now in our tyme whych be inhabited with people to whome gods worde was neuer preached, where as yet the scripture confirmeth, <NOTE> sayenge: In omnem terram exiuit sonus eorum, that is, theyr soude wet forth into all the worlde.
column8: For none of the apostles came so far as to us Furthermore there be many Islands foude out now in our time which be inhabited with people to whom gods word was never preached, where as yet the scripture confirmeth, saying: In omnem terram exiuit sonus eorum, that is, their soude wet forth into all the world.

column7: I saye theyr preachynge wente out into al lades although it be not yet come into the hole worlde.
column8: I say their preaching went out into all lades although it be not yet come into the hold world.

column7: And thys commynge out is begonne, albeit it be not yet fynished and ended, but it spredeth continually more and more and shal do tyl the last daye.
column8: And this coming out is begun, albeit it be not yet finished and ended, but it spreadeth continually more and more and shall do till the last day.

column7: And it is wyth thys commyssion or ambassadie of preachynge as it is wyth a stone, whan it is cast into the water, for it maketh waues about it, & one waue dryueth forth another, tyll they come to the shoore, & albeit there be in the myddes a great caulme, yet the waues cease not, but go continually forth.
column8: And it is with this commyssion or ambassadie of preaching as it is with a stone, when it is cast into the water, for it makes waves about it, & one wave driveth forth another, till they come to the shore, & albeit there be in the mids a great calm, yet the waves cease not, but go continually forth.

column7: Euen so it is wyth the preachynge of the gospell, P A G Exliij it began by thapostles, and it styll goeth forth, and by preachers it spreadeth further and further, it suffreth in the worlde persecution and chasynge awaye, yet it is alwayes opened more & more to suche as herde not of it before, though in the mydde iourney it be dryuen downe and be made starke herisie.
column8: Euen so it is with the preaching of the gospel, PAGExliij PAGExliij PAGExliij PAGExliij it began by apostles, and it still goes forth, and by preachers it spreadeth further and further, it suffers in the world persecution and chasing away, yet it is always opened more & more to such as herd not of it before, though in the mid journey it be driven down and be made stark herisie.

column7: Or it may be lykened to an ambassage that one sendeth out, as yf oure soueraygne lorde the kynge of Englande shulde sende hys ambassadours into Fraunce, or Spayne, we saye that an ambassadie is gone forth from our kynge thyther, all be it the ambassadours be not in dede as yet come thyther.
column8: Or it may be likened to and ambassage that one sends out, as if our sovereign lord the king of Englande should send his ambassadors into Fraunce, or Spayne, we say that and ambassadie is gone forth from our king thither, all be it the ambassadors be not in deed as yet come thither.

column7: It foloweth in the text.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: He that beleueth and is baptised shalbe saued. <NOTE> Here ye shal note that god doth hange an outward sygne to hys worde whych signe maketh hys worde to be the stroger vnto vs, so that it confirmeth our hartes & maketh vs not to doubt therof.
column8: He that believeth and is baptised shall saved. Here you shall note that god does hang and outward sign to his word which sign makes his word to be the stroger unto us, so that it confirmeth our hearts & makes us not to doubt thereof.

column7: Thus God dyd set ye rayne bowe for a signe to Noye to assure hym he wolde nomore destroy the worlde wyth floudes.
column8: Thus God did set you rain bow for a sign to Noye to assure him he would nomore destroy the world with floods.

column7: So that thys rayne bow is as it were a seale or suretye both to Noye and to al vs none otherwyse than a seale is put to wrytynges to make them sure.
column8: So that this rain bow is as it were a seal or surety both to Noye and to all us none otherwise than a seal is put to writings to make them sure.

column7: And lyke as princes and noble me be knowen by theyr colours, badges, and armes: euen so dealeth god wyth vs and hath stablished his wordes as wyth a seale yt we shuld nothynge doubt He gaue to Abraha circumcision for a signe of Christes comynge that shulde blesse the worlde. <NOTE> Lykewyse hath he done here by puttynge to this promise of saluation an outwarde sygne, I meane baptisme For baptisme is as it were a watchword to put god in remembraunce of hys promyse, which yf it can be had, <NOTE> ought in any wyse to be take (as saynt Austine sayeth) and not to be despysed.
column8: And like as princes and noble me be known by their colours, badges, and arms: even so deals god with us and hath established his words as with a seal that we should nothing doubt He gave to Abraha circumcision for a sign of Christes coming that should bless the world. Likewise hath he done here by putting to this promise of salvation and outward sign, I mean baptism For baptism is as it were a watchword to put god in remembrance of his promise, which if it can be had, ought in any wise to be take (as saint Austine sayeth) and not to be despised.

column7: But yf it can not be had, or yf it be denyed a man, yet he shall not be damned so that he beleueth the Gospell.
column8: But if it can not be had, or if it be denied a man, yet he shall not be damned so that he believeth the Gospel.

column7: For where the Gospel is, there is baptisme and al that pertayneth to christianitie.
column8: For where the Gospel is, there is baptism and all that pertaineth to christianity.

column7: And therfore the Lorde sayeth.
column8: And therefore the Lord sayeth.

column7: He that beleueth not shalbe damned.
column8: He that believeth not shall damned.

column7: He sayeth not, he that is not baptised.
column8: He sayeth not, he that is not baptised.

column7: For baptisme wythout fayth is nothynge worth, but it is lyke to a paper that hathe a seale hangynge to it and hath no wrytynge in it.
column8: For baptism without faith is nothing worth, but it is like to a paper that hath a seal hanging to it and hath no writing in it.

column7: Wherfore they that haue sygnes (whych we call sacrametes) wythout fayth, they haue seales without wrytynges.
column8: Wherefore they that have signs (which we call sacrametes) without faith, they have seals without writings.

column7: Furthermore ye se here (good people) what is thoffice of such as wolbe called Christes apostles, that is to wyte, to go into the world & preach Christes Gospel.
column8: Furthermore you see here (good people) what is intent of such as wolbe called Christes apostles, that is to wit, to go into the world & preach Christes Gospel.

column7: And so here ye may iudge whether the byshop of Rome with his galant prelates which ryde lyke princes vpo theyr moyles & neuer preach one worde but rather stoppe the mouthes of true preachers, ought to be called Apostolyke persons or no.
column8: And so here you may judge whither the bishop of Room with his galant prelates which ride like princes upon their moils & never preach one word but rather stop the mouths of true preachers, ought to be called Apostolic persons or no.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: And these tokes shall folowe them that beleue.
column8: And these tokes shall follow them that believe.

column7: In my name they shal cast out deuels, they shal speke wyth newe tonges, they shal dryue awaye serpentes.
column8: In my name they shall cast out devils, they shall speak with new tongues, they shall drive away serpents.

column7: And yf they drynke any deadly thynge, it shall not hurte them.
column8: And if they drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them.

column7: They shall laye theyr handes on the sycke, and they shall recouer.
column8: They shall say their hands on the sick, and they shall recover.

column7: My frendes how shal we verefy thys texte, that he that beleueth shal haue power to worke all these sygnes? for the Lorde sayth that these tokens shal folowe the beleuers.
column8: My friends how shall we verefy this text, that he that believeth shall have power to work all these signs? for the Lord say that these tokens shall follow the believers.

column7: Moreouer it is certaynly knowen P A G Exliiij vnto vs that not all ye Apostles wrought them.
column8: Moreover it is certainly known PAGExliiij PAGExliiij PAGExliiij PAGExliiij unto us that not all you Apostles wrought them.

column7: For it is recorded of none to haue dronken poyson but of Ihon the Euangelist.
column8: For it is recorded of none to have drunken poison but of Ihon the Euangelist.

column7: Furthermore yf thys sayenge of Christ must nedes stande, few shalbe saued for very fewe of the sayntes haue done al these.
column8: Furthermore if this saying of Christ must needs stand, few shall saved for very few of the saints have done all these.

column7: Some therfore to auoyde thys inconuenience do expounde these sygnes mystically, <NOTE> sayenge that they do speake wyth new tonges whych where as before they taught deuelysh doctrines, nowe they confesse Christ and so they be new men.
column8: Some therefore to avoid this inconvenience do expound these signs mystically, saying that they do speak with new tongues which where as before they taught devilish doctrines, now they confess Christ and so they be new men.

column7: By takynge awaye of serpentes they vnderstande the destroyenge of pestiferouse doctrines, heresies and sectes.
column8: By taking away of serpents they understand the destroyenge of pestiferous doctrines, heresies and sects.

column7: By drynkynge of poyson wythout hurte, they vnderstande that the readyng or hearyng of false doctrines shal not hurte them.
column8: By drinking of poison without hurt, they understand that the reading or hearing of false doctrines shall not hurt them.

column7: By healynge and curynge of sycke persons they vnderstande the healynge of the soule.
column8: By healing and curing of sick persons they understand the healing of the soul.

column7: Albeit thys interpretation is honest and a mater of trouth that such as beleue shall worke these feates, yet it is not the ryght sense and meanynge of thys text.
column8: Albeit this interpretation is honest and a mater of troth that such as believe shall work these feats, yet it is not the right sense and meaning of this text.

column7: This than is the meanynge.
column8: This than is the meaning.

column7: Where a christian man hath fayth, he shall haue power to worke these sygnes and they shal folow hym, as Christ hymselfe sayeth in an other place: <NOTE> Verely verely I saye vnto you, he that beleueth in me the workes that I do he shal do, yea and he shal do greater then they be.
column8: Where a christian man hath faith, he shall have power to work these signs and they shall follow him, as Christ himself sayeth in and other place: Verily verily I say unto you, he that believeth in me the works that I do he shall do, yea and he shall do greater then they be.

column7: For the christen man hath the same power wyth Christe, Christ is a comunitie, he is sette in the same goodes wyth Christ.
column8: For the christian man hath the same power with Christe, Christ is a community, he is set in the same goods with Christ.

column7: Furthermore Christ gaue them power agaynst wycked spirites to cast them out & to heale al maner of syckenesses as it is redde in the tenth of Matheu.
column8: Furthermore Christ gave them power against wicked spirits to cast them out & to heal all manner of sicknesses as it is red in the tenth of Matheu.

column7: Also in the.xix. psalme ye rede: Thou shalt walke vpon Lions and Dragons.
column8: Also in the xix psalm you rede: Thou shalt walk upon Lions and Dragons.

column7: Wherfore where a christen man is, the power to worke these sygnes & myracles is not taken awaye, as by many exemples it hath ben proued.
column8: Wherefore where a christian man is, the power to work these signs & miracles is not taken away, as by many examples it hath been proved.

column7: But no man ought to do them, onles it be necessarie and the case requyre it.
column8: But no man ought to do them, unless it be necessary and the case require it.

column7: For the Apostles theselues wrought not these myracles but only to the testification of gods worde that so by myracles the Gospell myght be confirmed, as the texte sayeth.
column8: For the Apostles themselves wrought not these miracles but only to the testification of gods word that so by miracles the Gospel might be confirmed, as the text sayeth.

column7: They went and preached euery where, the Lorde workynge wyth them and confirmynge the worde wyth myracles folowynge.
column8: They went and preached every where, the Lord working with them and confirming the word with miracles following.

column7: But nowe after yt the Gospell is spred abrode and opened to the hole world, myracles be not necessary as they were in the Apostles tyme.
column8: But now after that the Gospel is spread abroad and opened to the hold world, miracles be not necessary as they were in the Apostles time.

column7: It foloweth: whan the Lorde had spoken vnto them, he was receyued into heauen. That is to saye, he went vp to begyn hys spirituall and heauenly kyngdome, and drewe wyth hym oure hopes into heuen that thyther, whether we sawe him ascende we shulde also folowe.
column8: It followeth: when the Lord had spoken unto them, he was received into heaven. That is to say, he went up to begin his spiritual and heavenly kingdom, and drew with him our hope's into heaven that thither, whither we saw him ascend we should also follow.

column7: And he sytteth on the ryght hande of God. Thys is a maner or fygure of speakynge and it sygnifyeth, he is God, egall and of lyke power wyth the father.
column8: And he sitteth on the right hand of God. This is a manner or figure of speaking and it signifieth, he is God, equal and of like power with the father.

column7: And as the prophete sayeth, he ascended vp on hygh & hath led captiuitie a prisoner.
column8: And as the prophet sayeth, he ascended up on high & hath led captivity a prisoner.

column7: So that nowe, we be no longer in thraldome, for Christ hath caryed it awaye wyth hym and made vs the chyldren of hys father to lyue eternally wyth hym in heauen.
column8: So that now, we be no longer in thraldom, for Christ hath carried it away with him and made us the children of his father to live eternally with him in heaven.

column7: To whome be glorye for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be glory for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily P A G Exlv The Epistle on the sonday after the Ascension daye.
column8: : homily PAGExlv PAGExlv PAGExlv PAGExlv The Epistle on the sonday after the Ascension day.

column7: The.i. Epistle of Peter the.iiij. chap. Thargument.
column8: The i Epistle of Peter the iiij chap. Thargument.

column7: An exhortacion to do good workes according to thexemple of Christ.
column8: And exhortation to do good works according to thexemple of Christ.

column7: M Oost deare beloued brethren.
column8: Most Most deer beloved brothers.

column7: Be ye therfore sober, and watch vnto prayer.
column8: Be you therefore sober, and watch unto prayer.

column7: But aboue all thinges haue feruent loue amonge your selues.
column8: But above all things have fervent love among your selves.

column7: For loue shall couer the multitude of synnes.
column8: For love shall cover the multitude of sins.

column7: Be ye herberous one to another, wythout grudgynge.
column8: Be you herberous one to another, without grudging.

column7: As euery man hath receyued the gyfte, euen so minister the same one to another, as good ministers of the manyfolde grace of God.
column8: As every man hath received the gift, even so minister the same one to another, as good ministers of the manifold grace of God.

column7: Yf any man minister, let hym do it as of the abilitie whych god ministreth vnto hym, that god in all thynges maye be glorifyed thorow Iesus Christ.
column8: If any man minister, let him do it as of the ability which god ministereth unto him, that god in all things may be glorified thorough Jesus Christ.

column7: G Ood brethre and systers in our sauiour Christ the lection of the epistle of thys daye redde in ye church is taken forth of the.iiij. chapter of the fyrste epistle of ye Apostle & messanger of Christ S. Peter.
column8: GOod GOod brethren and sisters in our saviour Christ the lection of the epistle of this day red in you church is taken forth of the iiij chapter of the fyrste epistle of the Apostle & messenger of Christ S. Peter.

column7: Ye shall therfore vnderstande that forasmuch as thys holy ma S. Peter had now in the chapters goynge before thys place sufficiently taught the Iues and others whome he wrote thys epistle vnto, <NOTE> of the fayth and iustification whych cometh by Christe, he doth now in the chapters folowynge monysh them of good workes, <NOTE> to the maner of syncere and pure preachers, whych before they gyue any preceptes of good maners, woll fyrst intreate of ye causes of new lyfe.
column8: You shall therefore understand that forasmuch as this holy ma S. Peter had now in the chapters going before this place sufficiently taught the Iues and others whom he wrote this epistle unto, of the faith and justification which comes by Christe, he does now in the chapters following monish them of good works, to the manner of sincere and pure preachers, which before they gyve any precepts of good manners, will fyrst entreat of you causes of new life.

column7: Wherfore thys present lesson is nothynge but an exhortation to good workes after the exemple of Christe.
column8: Wherefore this present lesson is nothing but and exhortation to good works after the exemple of Christe.

column7: Thus than he sayeth:
column8: Thus than he sayeth:

column7: Be ye therfore sobre and watch vnto prayer.
column8: Be you therefore sober and watch unto prayer.

column7: Thys texte contayneth a generall exhortacion to all such thynges as become christen men to do in this lyfe. <NOTE> For modesty and sobrenes be not so greatly good workes, as they be the selfe rules wherby al good woorkes be tempered.
column8: This text containeth a general exhortation to all such things as become christian men to do in this life. For modesty and soberness be not so greatly good works, as they be the self rules whereby all good works be tempered.

column7: Ye shall therfore vnderstand here by modestie and sobrenesse fyrst those ciuile vertues whych haue contrary vyces, arrogancye and pryde.
column8: You shall therefore understand here by modesty and sobrenesse fyrst those civil virtues which have contrary vices, arrogance and pride.

column7: In lyke wyse doth also Paule vnderstande them in the.xij. to the Romaynes where he wryteth.
column8: In like wise does also Paule understand them in the xij to the Romans where he writes.

column7: I saye vnto you by the grace whych is gyuen me to euery one of you, that none thynke proudly of hymself aboue that it becometh hym to thynke but lette hym so thynke that he be demure and sobre euen as God hath bestowed to euerye one the measure of fayth.
column8: I say unto you by the grace which is given me to every one of you, that none think proudly of himself above that it becometh him to think but let him so think that he be demure and sober even as God hath bestowed to every one the measure of faith.

column7: Seconde, ye shal vnderstande by modestye and sobrenes here, also the soudnes of mynde so that ye thynke modestly & soberly of gods worde, lest through your owne ymaginations and good intencions ye go awaye from the true vnderstandyng of gods worde, or suffer your selues to be plucked away wyth any maner wynde of new doctrine.
column8: Seconde, you shall understand by modesty and soberness here, also the soudnes of mind so that you think modestly & soberly of gods word, lest through your own imaginations and good intentions you go away from the true understanding of gods word, or suffer your selves to be plucked away with any manner wind of new doctrine.

column7: Now wha we be modest and sober aswell in lyfe as in doctrine it foloweth consequently that we muste nedes watch and gyue our selues to prayer.
column8: Now wha we be modest and sober aswell in life as in doctrine it followeth consequently that we must needs watch and gyve our selves to prayer.

column7: It foloweth.
column8: It followeth.

column7: But afore all haue feruent loue amonges youre selues, for loue shal couer the multitude of synnes.
column8: But afore all have fervent love among your selves, for love shall cover the multitude of sins.

column7: As though saynt Peter shuld saye.
column8: As though saint Peter should say.

column7: It may happen peraduenture that a man may fayne wyth hymselfe that he is sober, <NOTE> modest, and busye in prayer.
column8: It may happen peradventure that a man may fain with himself that he is sober, modest, and busy in prayer.

column7: Therfore before al thynges se ye haue charitie without P A G Exlvi whych, youre demurenes, youre sobernes, your prayer maye be but fayned and cloked workes, with out whych charitie also they be nothynge worth nor yet thankfull to God accordynge to the sayenge of Christ. <NOTE> Whan thou shalte offer thy offerynge at the aulter and remembrest, that thy brother haue ought agaynst the, leaue there thy offeryng, and go and be at one wyth thy brother first, and then come and offre thy oblation.
column8: Therefore before all things see you have charity without PAGExlvi PAGExlvi PAGExlvi PAGExlvi which, your demureness, your soberness, your prayer may be but feigned and cloaked works, with out which charity also they be nothing worth nor yet thankful to God according to the saying of Christ. When thou shalt offer thy offering at the alter and remembrest, that thy brother have ought against thee, leave there thy offering, and go and be at one with thy brother first, and then come and offer thy oblation.

column7: Doubtles (my brethren) charitie is to be preferred before all other workes for wythout it none of all oure other workes can please God as Christ hymselfe wytnesseth Math. v. And also the prophete Esay in the fyrst chapter.
column8: Doubtless (my brothers) charity is to be preferred before all other works for without it none of all our other works can please God as Christ himself witnesseth Math. v. And also the prophet Esay in the fyrst chapter.

column7: Thou shalt nomore offer to me sacrifice and so forth, but learne to do ryghte, helpe the nedye.
column8: Thou shalt nomore offer to me sacrifice and so forth, but learn to do right, help the needy.

column7: &c. <NOTE> And saint Peter wyl that our charitie be vehement or feruent, not colde and negligent such as theyrs is, whych wyth theyr mouth make as though they loue a man, but wyth theyr harte they hate hym as euel as a tode.
column8: etc. And saint Peter will that our charity be vehement or fervent, not cold and negligent such as theirs is, which with their mouth make as though they love a man, but with their heart they hate him as evil as a toad.

column7: And he addeth the cause, <NOTE> loue or charitie couereth ye multitude of synnes.
column8: And he adds the cause, love or charity covereth you multitude of sins.

column7: Thys sentence is taken forth of ye x. chapter of the prouerbes.
column8: This sentence is taken forth of you x. chapter of the proverbs.

column7: For the moost proper office of charitie is to hyde the infirmities of the neghboure.
column8: For the most proper office of charity is to hide the infirmities of the neghboure.

column7: Furthermore hospitalitie and harbourynge wythout murmurynge or grudgynge is also one of the effectes of charitie.
column8: Furthermore hospitality and harbourynge without murmuring or grudging is also one of the effects of charity.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: As euery man hath receyued the gyfte, euen so minister the same one to another as good dispensours or stewardes of the manyfold grace of god.
column8: As every man hath received the gift, even so minister the same one to another as good dispensours or stewards of the manifold grace of god.

column7: Here good people, the Apostle Peter exhorteth euery man particularlye to do hys office in hys callynge.
column8: Here good people, the Apostle Peter exhorteth every man particularly to do his office in his calling.

column7: He that is a preacher of gods worde, oughte to be content wyth hys gyfte and to execute his dutie in hys vocatio, that is to wyt, he ought to preach not hys owne dreames, but the sermos and wordes of God, and so of all other offices in Christes cogregation, whych yf they were done accordynge to S. Peters aduyse here, we shuld both haue gods word more purely set forth, and also the churche in better vnitie and concorde.
column8: He that is a preacher of gods word, ought to be content with his gift and to execute his duty in his vocatio, that is to wit, he ought to preach not his own dreams, but the sermos and words of God, and so of all other offices in Christes cogregation, which if they were done according to S. Peters advise here, we should both have gods word more purely set forth, and also the church in better unity and concord.

column7: Then accordyng to euery mas gyfte, and (as Paule sayeth) euen as God hath allotted euerye man accordynge to the measure of hys fayth, <NOTE> so let hym serue in hys callynge.
column8: Then according to every mass gift, and (as Paule sayeth) even as God hath allotted every man according to the measure of his faith, so let him serve in his calling.

column7: As good stewardes or dispensours let them behaue themselues in executynge theyr office. <NOTE> I praye you is not he a foolysh stewarde whych of other mes goodes wold glorie and take a pryde, <NOTE> he is but onely ye stewarde and not the owner of them?
column8: As good stewards or dispensours let them behave themselves in executing their office. I pray you is not he a foolish steward which of other mes goods would glory and take a pride, he is but only the steward and not the owner of them?

column7: Nowe they be good stewardes whyche be faythfull and prudente, whych knowe what, how, to whome and what tyme they oughte to preache and laye out the treasure of gods worde, the treasure I saye of the manyfolde grace of God accordynge to the sundry and manyfold gyftes.
column8: Now they be good stewards which be faithful and prudent, which know what, how, to whom and what time they ought to preach and say out the treasure of gods word, the treasure I say of the manifold grace of God according to the sundry and manifold gifts.

column7: He that speaketh let hym speake the sermons and wordes of almyghtye God, let hym not preach hys owne gloses, hys owne inuencions hys owne dreames and fansies.
column8: He that speaks let him speak the sermons and words of almighty God, let him not preach his own gloss, his own inventions his own dreams and fancies.

column7: And to what so euer ministracion he be called and appointed in the church, <NOTE> let hym do it (sayeth saint Peter) as of the vertue, power, and abilitie whyche God ministreth vnto hym, and not as though he were able by hys owne wyt & prudence to execute hys ministerie.
column8: And to what so ever ministration he be called and appointed in the church, let him do it (sayeth saint Peter) as of the virtue, power, and ability which God ministereth unto him, and not as though he were able by his own wit & prudence to execute his ministry.

column7: It foloweth.
column8: It followeth.

column7: That God in all thynges maye be glorifyed thorow P A G Exlvij Iesus Christ.
column8: That God in all things may be glorified thorough PAGExlvij PAGExlvij PAGExlvij PAGExlvij Jesus Christ.

column7: Here saynt Peter declareth the principall ende of all our gyftes offices and good workes, whych is that by them shulde ryse contentions, stryfes, debates, and discordes. <NOTE> Nowe God is glorifyed by oure gyftes, offices, duties, and workes, when we so vse them that the congregacion may take profyte & edificacion therby, and may take occasion by the good distribution of the same to glorifye God by Iesus Christe.
column8: Here saint Peter declareth the principal end of all our gifts offices and good works, which is that by them should rise contentions, strifes, debates, and discords. Now God is glorified by our gifts, offices, duties, and works, when we so use them that the congregation may take profit & edification thereby, and may take occasion by the good distribution of the same to glorify God by Jesus Christe.

column7: For oure Sauiour Christe Iesus ascendynge vp to heuen distributed and gaue gyftes vnto men as the prophete sayeth. <NOTE> To whome be all glorie, al prayse, all imperie and dominion aswel to saue as to rule and gouerne hys faythful ones, together wyth the father and the holy goost for euer and euer AMEN.
column8: For our Saviour Christe Jesus ascending up to heaven distributed and gave gifts unto men as the prophet sayeth. To whom be all glory, all praise, all impery and dominion aswell to save as to rule and govern his faithful ones, together with the father and the holy ghost for ever and ever AMEN.

column7: : homily The Gospell on the sondaye after the Ascension daye.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the sondaye after the Ascension day.

column7: The.xv. chapter of Ihon. Thargument.
column8: The xv chapter of Jhon. Thargument.

column7: The holy goost is promysed to be sente by Christ to hys Apostles.
column8: The holy ghost is promised to be sent by Christ to his Apostles.

column7: I Esus sayd vnto hys disciples.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples.

column7: But whan the comforter is come whom I wyll sende vnto you fro the father (euen the spirite of trouth, whych procedeth of the father) he shall testifye of me.
column8: But when the comforter is come whom I will send unto you from the father (even the spirit of troth, which proceedeth of the father) he shall testify of me.

column7: And ye shall beare wytnesse also, bycause ye haue ben with me from the begynnynge.
column8: And you shall bear witness also, because you have been with me from the beginning.

column7: These thynges haue I sayd vnto you bycause ye shulde not be offended.
column8: These things have I said unto you because you should not be offended.

column7: They shall excommunicate you: yea the tyme shall come, that whosoeuer kylleth you, wyl thinke that he doth god seruice.
column8: They shall excommunicate you: yea the time shall come, that whosoever killeth you, will think that he does god service.

column7: And such thinges wyl they do vnto you, bycause they haue not knowe the father neyther yet me.
column8: And such things will they do unto you, because they have not know the father neither yet me.

column7: But these thynges haue I told you that whan the tyme is come, ye may remeber them that I tolde you.
column8: But these things have I told you that when the time is come, you may remember them that I told you.

column7: F Or asmuch as our Lorde Christ in his maundie (good people) wyth many promyses had bequethed and deputed the holy goost to his Apostles, <NOTE> he doth now at last name hym more playnly wyth hys proper name of office, declarynge therby what profyte and commoditie he shall brynge to the worlde.
column8: FOr FOr as as our Lord Christ in his maundy (good people) with many promises had bequeathed and deputed the holy ghost to his Apostles, he does now at last name him more plainly with his proper name of office, declaring thereby what profit and commodity he shall bring to the world.

column7: He sayeth: whan the comforter is come. Thys propre and true name he gyueth the holy goost callyng hym paracletum, that is saye a comforter.
column8: He sayeth: when the comforter is come. This proper and true name he gyveth the holy ghost calling him paracletum, that is say a comforter.

column7: For who els certifyeth our conscience, <NOTE> that we shulde beleue yt by Christ we be the chyldren of God and crye Abba father, but thys only comforter?
column8: For who else certifyeth our conscience, that we should believe that by Christ we be the children of God and cry Abba father, but this only comforter?

column7: I praye you, who maketh vs both desyrefull and also hardy to cofesse thys fayth?
column8: I pray you, who makes us both desyrefull and also hardy to cofesse this faith?

column7: Who comforteth vs in all such mysfortune and afflictions as we suffre in thys worlde for thys confessions sake?
column8: Who comforts us in all such misfortune and afflictions as we suffer in this world for this confessions sake?

column7: Surely the same selfe good spirite, whych procedeth from ye father doth al thys, thys is hys feate and offyce.
column8: Surely the same self good spirit, which proceedeth from you father does all this, this is his feat and office.

column7: For thobteynynge of whych spirite, the prophet Dauid so busely prayeth P A G Exlviij in the.l. psalme.
column8: For thobteynynge of which spirit, the prophet Dauid so busily prayeth PAGExlviij PAGExlviij PAGExlviij PAGExlviij in the l psalm.

column7: But ye maye more lyuely beholde the nature and workynge of thys holy goost or spiryte in the apostles, whyche before the commynge of the holy goost, in tribulation fledde from the Lorde and vtterly denyed hym.
column8: But you may more lively behold the nature and working of this holy ghost or spirit in the apostles, which before the coming of the holy ghost, in tribulation fled from the Lord and utterly denied him.

column7: For they hyd themselues in corners, some here some there.
column8: For they hid themselves in corners, some here some there.

column7: But wha thys spirite, thys comfortour was ones confirmed in them: then they confessed Christ frely and hys resurrectio in so much that they also toke pleasure and delyte in the crosse or affliction that was layde vpon them as appeareth playnly in the Actes. <NOTE> Now thys comforter, <NOTE> bycause by the vertue of hys offyce he maketh men trouthe tellers, yea and comforteth and strengtheneth the faythfull in the confession of the trouth, by the vertue also of hys office he shall testifie of Christ.
column8: But wha this spirit, this comforter was ones confirmed in them: then they confessed Christ freely and his resurrectio in so much that they also took pleasure and delight in the cross or affliction that was laid upon them as appears plainly in the Acts. Now this comforter, because by the virtue of his office he makes men truth tellers, yea and comforts and strengtheneth the faithful in the confession of the troth, by the virtue also of his office he shall testify of Christ.

column7: So ye must here marke that ye holy goost ought to beare wytnesse of Christ.
column8: So you must here mark that you holy ghost ought to bear witness of Christ.

column7: But what shall he testifye, what shall he teache of Christ? <NOTE> none other thyng but yt which Christ preached and taught before, that is to say, he shall make them whyche before coulde not perceyue Christes doctrine, now to vnderstade it, by wrytyng the gospel in theyr hartes.
column8: But what shall he testify, what shall he teach of Christ? none other thing but that which Christ preached and taught before, that is to say, he shall make them which before could not perceive Christes doctrine, now to vnderstade it, by writing the gospel in their hearts.

column7: A mans owne wysedome can here do nothynge, it muste be thys holy spirite & comforter whych must do the dede, <NOTE> euen as Ieremy the prophete in the.xxxi. chapter sayeth: I shal plant my lawe in the inwarde partes of them and wryte it in theyr hartes, and wylbe theyr God and they shall be my people.
column8: A men own wisdom can here do nothing, it must be this holy spirit & comforter which must do the deed, even as Jeremy the prophet in the xxxi chapter sayeth: I shall plant my law in the inward parts of them and write it in their hearts, and wylbe their God and they shall be my people.

column7: And from thence forth shall noman teach hys neyghbour or his brother and saye: know the Lorde.
column8: And from thence forth shall noman teach his neighbour or his brother and say: know the Lord.

column7: But they shall all knowe me from the lowest to the hyghest, sayeth the Lorde.
column8: But they shall all know me from the lowest to the highest, sayeth the Lord.

column7: Of all these thynges it is gathered manyfestly that wythout the holy goost we neyther can know the truth nor beare wytnes vnto Christ Iesus.
column8: Of all these things it is gathered manifestly that without the holy ghost we neither can know the truth nor bear witness unto Christ Jesus.

column7: Seconde, ye may espye here (good people) verye playnly thoffice of Apostles or Christes messangers That is to wyt, that they ought to beare wytnesse of Christ. <NOTE> to testifye or beare wytnes in scripture sygnifyeth to teach and speake not the thynge that pleaseth vs but the thinge that almyghty god hath comaunded.
column8: Seconde, you may espy here (good people) very plainly intent of Apostles or Christes messengers That is to wit, that they ought to bear witness of Christ. to testify or bear witness in scripture signifieth to teach and speak not the thing that pleases us but the thing that almighty god hath commanded.

column7: After thys sorte is Christ named in the psalme a faythfull wytnes in heauen. <NOTE> Also Esay the prophete speaketh of Christ in the persone of the father.
column8: After this sort is Christ nam in the psalm a faithful witness in heaven. Also Esay the prophet speaks of Christ in the person of the father.

column7: I haue set hym for a wytnes to the people for the prince and mayster of the gentyls.
column8: I have set him for a witness to the people for the prince and master of the gentles.

column7: Wherfore syth the recorde and wytnes of Christ and of hys apostles ought to be egall and agreable togethers: surely they muste haue one tenure of theyr testimonies, and furthermore it must nedes folowe that the holy goost executed his testimonie and recorde by ye apostles as in the.x. of Mathew it appeareth.
column8: Wherefore sith the record and witness of Christ and of his apostles ought to be equal and agreeable together: surely they must have one tenure of their testimonies, and furthermore it must needs follow that the holy ghost executed his testimony and record by you apostles as in the x of Mathew it appears.

column7: It is not you (sayth Christ) whyche speake, but the spirite of my father whych shall speake in you.
column8: It is not you (say Christ) which speak, but the spirit of my father which shall speak in you.

column7: Where be nowe these felowes whyche here tofore haue cryed that the holy goost haue reuelated and disclosed to thapostles and fathers certaine secreter and hygher thynges whych be not comprised in the gospell?
column8: Where be now these fellows which here tofore have cried that the holy ghost have revelated and disclosed to apostles and father's certain secreter and higher things which be not comprised in the gospel?

column7: To whome wyll ye gyue more credence?
column8: To whom will you gyve more credence?

column7: To Christe or to these vayne tryflers?
column8: To Christe or to these vain tryflers?
