column7: Christe sayeth that the holy goost shall testifye of hym to the worlde and shall make me mete and apte to receceyue his gospel and shall teach none other thynge than that whyche he hymselfe hath taught.
column8: Christe sayeth that the holy ghost shall testify of him to the world and shall make me meet and apt to receceyue his gospel and shall teach none other thing than that which he himself hath taught.

column7: But these tryflers bable that P A G Exlix the holy goost ought to teach some thynge of more excellencye than that whych is comprysed in ye holy gospell.
column8: But these tryflers babble that PAGExlix PAGExlix PAGExlix PAGExlix the holy ghost ought to teach some thing of more excellency than that which is comprised in you holy gospel.

column7: Surely I wolde thynke it moost conuenient that we shulde obey and beleue hym to whom the father of heauen bare wytnes sayenge: <NOTE> Thys is my welbeloued sone in whom I am right wel pleased heare ye hym.
column8: Surely I would think it most convenient that we should obey and believe him to whom the father of heaven bore witness saying: This is my well-beloved soon in whom I am right well pleased hear you him.

column7: But they that can not be satisfied wyth Christes doctrine to whome not only thapostles but also the holy goost hath borne wytnesse, let them at theyr parell chose them other doctrines.
column8: But they that can not be satisfied with Christes doctrine to whom not only apostles but also the holy ghost hath born witness, let them at their parell chosen them other doctrines.

column7: Certes I wyll not counsayle you lyke owles to wader in darkenes but rather to fyxe stedfastlye youre fete in the lyght.
column8: Certes I will not counsel you like owls to wader in darkness but rather to fyxe steadfastly your feet in the light.

column7: Last of all ye shall consyder and note (good christen brethren and systers) in thys gospell, yt the word and institution of Christ, of whych the spirite & the apostles do testifye, can in no wyse b gratefull and acceptable to the worlde.
column8: Last of all you shall consider and note (good christian brothers and sisters) in this gospel, that the word and institution of Christ, of which the spirit & the apostles do testify, can in no wise b grateful and acceptable to the world.

column7: For those that wol admyt thys worde, the worlde wolle caste them out of al honest mens company (as they call honeste men) they woll as heretykes dryue them out of theyr churches and assembles, they woll excommunicate them, they woll curse them wyth boke bell and candell.
column8: For those that will admit this word, the world wool cast them out of all honest men's company (as they call honest men) they will as heretics drive them out of their churches and assembles, they will excommunicate them, they will curse them with book bell and candle.

column7: Yea yf they may wyth all kynde of punyshment and death persecute the true Apostles and messegers of Christ they wyll thynke to do a hygh seruice to God, & that theyr zeale hath hyghly serued gods wyl.
column8: Yea if they may with all kind of punishment and death persecute the true Apostles and messegers of Christ they will think to do a high service to God, & that their zeal hath highly served gods will.

column7: But what sayeth Christ in the meane season?
column8: But what sayeth Christ in the mean season?

column7: Therfore I wyll be wyth you.
column8: Therefore I will be with you.

column7: They shal so handle themselues towardes you, bycause they knowe nother me nor my father.
column8: They shall so handle themselves towards you, because they know neither me nor my father.

column7: Here ye se wyth what successe and fortune in thys wycked world the moost precious worde of the gospell wyth the imbrasers therof be commonly receyued.
column8: Here you see with what success and fortune in this wicked world the most precious word of the gospel with the imbrasers thereof be commonly received.

column7: For thou mayst not loke to lyue a swete an ydle and a delicate lyfe yf thou wolte confesse Christ For he that woll lyue after a godlye sorte (as sayeth saynt Paule) must nedes suffer persecution. <NOTE> And in an other place he sayeth: <NOTE> Yf I wolde please men I shulde not be the seruaunt of Christ.
column8: For thou mayest not look to live a sweet and idle and a delicate life if thou wolte confess Christ For he that will live after a godly sort (as sayeth saint Paule) must needs suffer persecution. And in and other place he sayeth: If I would please men I should not be the servant of Christ.

column7: Wherfore yf persecution shall inuade vs for cofessynge of Christ: it is good that we be armed wyth goddes worde that we maye knowe how persecutio hangeth ouer our heades by the proper wyl of God to thyntent our fayth myght thus by such persecution be clarifyed, tryed, and purged.
column8: Wherefore if persecution shall invade us for cofessynge of Christ: it is good that we be armed with gods word that we may know how persecutio hangs over our heads by the proper will of God to thyntent our faith might thus by such persecution be clarified, tried, and purged.

column7: For yf we be ful certifyed hereof, we can not easely be offended wyth temptation but wyth a pacient mynde we shall suffer all the wronge that the world for Christes cause woll put vs to.
column8: For if we be full certified hereof, we can not easily be offended with temptation but with a patient mind we shall suffer all the wrong that the world for Christes cause will put us to.

column7: And surely thys shalbe a comforte vnto vs, that oure persecuters for all theyr proude bragges and vauntes neyther know Christ nor his father.
column8: And surely this shall a comfort unto us, that our persecuters for all their proud brags and vaunts neither know Christ nor his father.

column7: Fynally we be ryght well assured that ye trouble and affliction of thys tyme (as Paule sayth) can in no wyse be copared wyth the glorye to come that shalbe disclosed vnto vs. <NOTE> Wyth thys our knowlege comfortynge our selues we shall remayne quyet in our conscience, styll awaytynge wyth stedfaste hope for the immortall crowne of the sayd glorye whyche the father of heauen hath prepared for vs. To whom wyth the sone & holy goost be al glorye and prayse for euer and euer.
column8: Finally we be right well assured that you trouble and affliction of this time (as Paule say) can in no wise be copared with the glory to come that shall disclosed unto us With this our knowledge comforting our selves we shall remain quiet in our conscience, still awaiting with steadfast hope for the immortal crown of the said glory which the father of heaven hath prepared for us To whom with the soon & holy ghost be all glory and praise for ever and ever.

column7: AMEN.
column8: AMEN.

column7: : homily The Epistle on wytsondaye.
column8: : homily The Epistle on wytsondaye.

column7: The.ij. chapter of the actes of the Apostles.
column8: The ij chapter of the acts of the Apostles.

column7: PAGEL The holy goost is here gyuen accordynge to Christes promyse before.
column8: PAGEL The holy ghost is here given according to Christes promise before.

column7: W Han the fyftye dayes were come to an ende, they were all wyth one accorde together in one place.
column8: When When the fyftye days were come to and end, they were all with one accord together in one place.

column7: And sodenly ther came a sounde fro heauen, as it had bene the comynge of a myghty wind and it fylled al the house where they sate.
column8: And suddenly there came a sound from heaven, as it had be the coming of a mighty wind and it filled all the house where they sat.

column7: And there appeared vnto them cloue tonges, lyke as they had ben of fyre, and it sat vpon ech one of them: and they were all fylled wyth the holy goost, and bega to speake wyth other tonges, euen as the same spirite gaue them vtteraunce.
column8: And there appeared unto them clove tongues, like as they had been of fire, and it sat upon each one of them: and they were all filled with the holy ghost, and began to speak with other tongues, even as the same spirit gave them utterance.

column7: There were dwellynge at Ierusalem, Iues, deuoute men, out of euery nation of them that are vnder heauen.
column8: There were dwelling at Jerusalem, Iues, devout men, out of every nation of them that are under heaven.

column7: When thys was noysed aboute, the multitude came together, and were astonnyed, bycuase that euery man herde the speake wyth hys owne langage.
column8: When this was noised about, the multitude came together, and were astonnyed, bycuase that every man herd the speak with his own langage.

column7: They wondered al and marueled, saynge amonge themselues: behold are not al these whych speake, of Galile?
column8: They wondered all and marveled, saying among themselves: behold are not all these which speak, of Galilee?

column7: And how heare we euery man hys owne tonge wherein we were borne?
column8: And how hear we every man his own tongue wherein we were born?

column7: Parthians and Medes, and Elamytes, and the inhabyters of Mesopotamia, and of Iury, and of Capadocia, of Ponthus and Asia, Phrygia, and Pamphilia, of Egypte, and of the parties of Lybia whych is besyde Syren, and straungers of Rome, Iues and Proselytes, Grekes and Arabians: we haue herde them speake in oure owne tonges the great workes of God.
column8: Parthians and Medes, and Elamytes, and the inhabiters of Mesopotamia, and of Jury, and of Capadocia, of Ponthus and Asia, Phrygia, and Pamphilia, of Egypte, and of the parties of Lybia which is beside Syren, and strangers of Room, Iues and Proselytes, Greeks and Arabians: we have herd them speak in our own tongues the great works of God.

column7: C Hrist had oftentymes (good people) promysed vnto hys disciples the holy goost to confirme them in the true doctrine.
column8: CHrist CHrist had oftentimes (good people) promised unto his disciples the holy ghost to confirm them in the true doctrine.

column7: For wythout ye holy goost noman can ryghtly eyther vnderstande or certainly beleue the worde of God, neyther can stycke by it costantly wythout staggerynge or shrynkyng from it.
column8: For without the holy ghost noman can rightly either understand or certainly believe the word of God, neither can stick by it costantly without staggering or shrynkyng from it.

column7: It is the holy goost doubtles that teacheth al thynges and that putteth men in mynde of gods wyll. <NOTE> And therfore Christ sayeth in the.x. Chapter of Mathew.
column8: It is the holy ghost doubtless that teaches all things and that putteth men in mind of gods will. And therefore Christ sayeth in the x Chapter of Mathew.

column7: It is not you that be the speakers, but it is ye spirite of your father whych speaketh in you.
column8: It is not you that be the speakers, but it is the spirit of your father which speaks in you.

column7: Wherfore thys often promyse of sendynge the holy goost which was made to the disciples, Christ now in this daye of Pentecost perfourmeth.
column8: Wherefore this often promise of sending the holy ghost which was made to the disciples, Christ now in this day of Pentecost performeth.

column7: But bycause it helpeth lytle to know that the disciples receyued the holy goost, onles we draw thys receyuyng also to our profyte & auauntage, therfore it were good to know the causes why the holy goost was sent.
column8: But because it helpeth little to know that the disciples received the holy ghost, unless we draw this receiving also to our profit & advantage, therefore it were good to know the causes why the holy ghost was sent.

column7: Ye shall therfore vnderstande (good people) that the holy gost was not sent to thapostles nor at this daye is sent as some men do dreame, to teache a dyuerse or straunge doctrine frome Christes doctrine whych Christ either taught not before or had forgotten to teache: <NOTE> But he was sente and is sente for thre causes.
column8: You shall therefore understand (good people) that the holy ghost was not sent to apostles nor at this day is sent as some men do dream, to teach a diverse or strange doctrine from Christes doctrine which Christ either taught not before or had forgotten to teach: But he was sent and is sent for thre causes.

column7: The fyrst is that he shulde teache and put in mynde & expoude all such thynges as Christ taught And of thys fynal cause and offyce of the holy goost our Sauiour Iesus Christ in the.xiiij. and.xv. chapters of Ihon very copiously and at length speketh.
column8: The fyrst is that he should teach and put in mind & expoude all such things as Christ taught And of this fynal cause and office of the holy ghost our Saviour Jesus Christ in the xiiij and xv chapters of Ihon very copiously and at length speaketh.

column7: The seconde cause that the holy goost is sente, is to confirme, strengthen, and as it were to seale vs & to make vs full assured and certayne of the veritie P A G Eli of gods worde.
column8: The seconde cause that the holy ghost is sent, is to confirm, strengthen, and as it were to seal us & to make us full assured and certain of the verity PAGEli PAGEli PAGEli PAGEli of gods word.

column7: Of thys office the epistle of thys day maketh mencion, whyle it declareth that the holy goost sat vpo euery of them and fylled them, whych thynge betokeneth nothynge els, but that the holy goost confirmed and certifyed the myndes of the Apostles vpon the veritie of gods word, <NOTE> and therfore he is called of Paule the gage and the ernest.
column8: Of this office the epistle of this day makes mention, while it declareth that the holy ghost sat upon every of them and filled them, which thing betokeneth nothing else, but that the holy ghost confirmed and certified the minds of the Apostles upon the verity of gods word, and therefore he is called of Paule the gage and the earnest.

column7: The thyrde cause that the holy goost is sente, is that in temptation he myght comforte vs and preserue vs from desperacion, and therfore he is called paracletus that is to say a comforter.
column8: The thyrde cause that the holy ghost is sent, is that in temptation he might comfort us and preserve us from desperation, and therefore he is called paracletus that is to say a comforter.

column7: Now therfore yf ye couete to knowe, who & what the holy goost is whych is called the thyrde persone in trinitie, consyder wel the forsayd offices of hym, and ye shal ryghtly answere: <NOTE> The holy goost is God equall wyth the father and sonne, whych was to thys intent sent of them both, that he shulde more clearly expoune the diuine wyll of the father whych was openly publisshed to the worlde by Christ, and that he shulde put men in remembraunce of the same and confirme it in theyr hartes to thintent they myght boldlye confesse it.
column8: Now therefore if you covet to know, who & what the holy ghost is which is called the thyrde person in trinity, consider well the foresaid offices of him, and you shall rightly answer: The holy ghost is God equal with the father and son, which was to this intent sent of them both, that he should more clearly expoune the divine will of the father which was openly published to the world by Christ, and that he should put men in remembrance of the same and confirm it in their hearts to intent they might boldly confess it.

column7: But let vs now approche to the texte of thys present lesson.
column8: But let us now approach to the text of this present lesson.

column7: Whan the daye of Pentecoste.
column8: When the day of Pentecoste.

column7: <NOTE>

That is to saye the fyftye daye from Ester was a fulfyllyng whych was one of thre solemne feastes in whych all the Iues were wont to be assembled accordynge to the lawe of Moses in Deuteromye in the.xvi. chapter, whych feast we christen men do obserue wyth an other lybertie & for an other respecte then it was kept of the Iues.
column8: That is to say the fyftye day from Ester was a fulfilling which was one of thre solemn feasts in which all the Iues were wont to be assembled according to the law of Moses in Deuteromye in the xvi chapter, which feast we christen men do observe with and other liberty & for and other respect then it was kept of the Iues.

column7: For we do solemnize & kepe thys daye onely in memorie of the speciall and wonderfull sendynge of the holy gooste as on thys daye.
column8: For we do solemnize & keep this day only in memory of the special and wonderful sending of the holy ghost as on this day.

column7: Whan thys feast (I saye) of the Iewes called Pentecost otherwyse named the feast of wekes was in the complyshynge and doynge, the Apostles were all wyth one accorde together in one place, as Christ had commaunded them before to do, <NOTE> that they shuld not departe from Ierusalem but that they shuld awayte for the promyse of the father.
column8: When this feast (I say) of the Jewes called Pentecost otherwise nam the feast of weeks was in the complyshynge and doing, the Apostles were all with one accord together in one place, as Christ had commanded them before to do, that they should not depart from Jerusalem but that they should await for the promise of the father.

column7: And sodenly there came a soude from heaue, as it had been the comynge of a myghtie wynde, and it fylled all the house where they sate.
column8: And suddenly there came a soude from heave, as it had been the coming of a mighty wind, and it filled all the house where they sat.

column7: My frendes thys soden commynge of the holy goost doth admonyshe vs of the maner or forme of hys commynge whych is not humane nor chauceth after mans fashion, but as the similitude declareth in the thyrd chapter of Ihon.
column8: My friends this sudden coming of the holy ghost does admonish us of the manner or form of his coming which is not humane nor chanceth after men fashion, but as the similitude declareth in the thyrd chapter of Jhon.

column7: The spirite or wynde bloweth where it woll, and thou hearest hys voyce, but thou knowest not whence it cometh nor whether it goeth.
column8: The spirit or wind blows where it will, and thou hearest his voice, but thou knowest not whence it comes nor whither it goes.

column7: Now for as much as Christ applyeth thys similitude and sayth: So is euery one that is borne of the spirite, therfore ye must also vnderstand here, that the holy goost in dede commeth vnto vs, but how or after what sorte it passeth mans wyt and capacitie whyche neyther can comprehende the maner of hys commynge neyther yet the qualitie of hys accion, albeit of the accion & presence of the holy goost we be made certayne euen as we may be certayne of the blowynge of the wynde.
column8: Now for as much as Christ applieth this similitude and say: So is every one that is born of the spirit, therefore you must also understand here, that the holy ghost in deed comes unto us, but how or after what sort it passes men wit and capacity which neither can comprehend the manner of his coming neither yet the quality of his action, albeit of the action & presence of the holy ghost we be made certain even as we may be certain of the blowing of the wind.

column7: Finally it is here to be consydered in what wyse the holy goost is to be receyued of vs. <NOTE> he is not to be receyued simpliciter as a doue that muste P A G Elij be miraculously sent from heauen, (as certayne heretykes at thys daye do thynke) neyther is he to be taken as a vertue of God procedynge from the father and from the sonne (as Campanus thynketh) neyther yet in a prescribed and diuised forme as the papistes haue prefixed hym before all theyr counsaylles were they neuer so contrary to gods worde, but he is to be receyued as very god of the selfe same essencie and godhed wyth the father and sonne.
column8: Finally it is here to be considered in what wise the holy ghost is to be received of us he is not to be received simpliciter as a dove that must PAGElij PAGElij PAGElij PAGElij be miraculously sent from heaven, (as certain heretics at this day do think) neither is he to be taken as a virtue of God proceeding from the father and from the son (as Campanus thinketh) neither yet in a prescribed and devised form as the papists have prefixed him before all their counsaylles were they never so contrary to gods word, but he is to be received as very god of the self same essencie and godhead with the father and son.

column7: It foloweth in the texte:
column8: It followeth in the text:

column7: And there appeared vnto them clouen tonges lyke as they had bene of fyre and sat vpon ech one of them.
column8: And there appeared unto them cloven tongues like as they had be of fire and sat upon each one of them.

column7: Here (good people) ye maye learne the effectes or frutes of the holy goostes comminge, for he cometh not in vayne but maketh dispertite or clouen toges and fyry, he maketh men to speake wyth other tonges, that is to saye, he regendreth them, he createth in them new motions, he assureth them of the word that they heare, he openeth theyr mouthes and maketh them boldly and wythout feare to confesse the trouth.
column8: Here (good people) you may learn the effects or fruits of the holy ghosts coming, for he comes not in vain but makes dispertite or cloven toges and fyry, he makes men to speak with other tongues, that is to say, he regendreth them, he createth in them new motions, he assureth them of the word that they hear, he openeth their mouths and makes them boldly and without fear to confess the troth.

column7: And al they that is to wyt the Apostles that were assebled together for thys purpose were forthwyth and sodenly al at ones replete and fylled with the holy goost in such straunge sorte that by and by they beganne to speake wyth sondry and newe tonges, <NOTE> not wyth olde tonges and such as the tonge of Moses the lawspeaker is discribed to be that is to wyt harde and vnpleasaunt, as it is wrytten in the fourth chapter of Exodus.
column8: And all they that is to wit the Apostles that were assebled together for this purpose were forthwith and suddenly all at ones replete and filled with the holy ghost in such strange sort that by and by they began to speak with sundry and new tongues, not with old tongues and such as the tongue of Moses the lawspeaker is described to be that is to wit harden and unpleasant, as it is written in the fourth chapter of Exodus.

column7: And here maye ye note the dyuersitie and difference of the lawe and gospel.
column8: And here may you note the dyuersitie and difference of the law and gospel.

column7: Moses tonge was sengle and but one, <NOTE> one certayne people.
column8: Moses tongue was sengle and but one, one certain people.

column7: But the tonges of the gospell be soundry, whereby is sygnifyed the lybertie of the gospel.
column8: But the tongues of the gospel be sundry, whereby is sygnifyed the liberty of the gospel.

column7: They spake therfore wyth sundry toges euen as the spirite gaue them vtteraunce.
column8: They spoke therefore with sundry toges even as the spirit gave them utterance.

column7: The holy goost gaue not all to all, <NOTE> but (as Paule sayth) accordynge to the measure of fayth as it semeth good vnto hym.
column8: The holy ghost gave not all to all, but (as Paule say) according to the measure of faith as it seemeth good unto him.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: There were dwellynge at Ierusalem Iewes deuoute men out of euery nation of them that are vnder the heauen and so forth.
column8: There were dwelling at Jerusalem Jewes devout men out of every nation of them that are under the heaven and so forth.

column7: Here be contayned the comune and vulgare effectes whych be wont to folowe the workes of ye holy goost.
column8: Here be contained the common and vulgar effects which be wont to follow the works of you holy ghost.

column7: These effectes be stoynynge & wonderyng, and they declare vnto vs ye power of the holy gooste in them whych were moued wyth the workes of the holy goost.
column8: These effects be stoynynge & wondering, and they declare unto us the power of the holy ghost in them which were moved with the works of the holy ghost.

column7: For the reste of people were rather more and more offended wt the workes of the holy gooste than kyndled to imbrace them.
column8: For the rest of people were rather more and more offended with the works of the holy ghost than kindled to embrace them.

column7: They sayd then, how happeneth thys yt we heare euerye one in hys owne tonge whych be of sundry nations, speake the great wonders and hygh workes of God, <NOTE> that is to saye, the thynges that God hath wrought in hys Christe.
column8: They said then, how happeneth this that we hear every one in his own tongue which be of sundry nations, speak the great wonders and high works of God, that is to say, the things that God hath wrought in his Christe.

column7: For to thys intent surely was the holy goost come euen to expoude and declare Christ to the disciples, and no doubt he exhorted them frely and boldlye to preache hym vnto the hole worlde, whych thynge afterwarde they manfully executed, as the sermon of Peter immediatly after made, doth declare & shewe.
column8: For to this intent surely was the holy ghost come even to expoude and declare Christ to the disciples, and no doubt he exhorted them freely and boldly to preach him unto the hold world, which thing afterward they manfully executed, as the sermon of Peter immediately after made, does declare & show.

column7: Surely the holy goost sent from heauen make men frely to confesse the Euangelicall trouth before kynges P A G Eliij and prynces, whych thynge the fleshe otherwyse is not able to do.
column8: Surely the holy ghost sent from heaven make men freely to confess the Evangelical troth before kings PAGEliij PAGEliij PAGEliij PAGEliij and princes, which thing the flesh otherwise is not able to do.

column7: For it is to muche afrayed, that it can wyllyngly and gladly suffer the hatred of thys worlde whych is knyt and ioyned wyth thys confession.
column8: For it is to much afraid, that it can willingly and gladly suffer the hatred of this world which is knit and joined with this confession.

column7: Fynally ye shall vnderstande that ye holy goost was gyuen to the Apostles in a vysible forme.
column8: Finally you shall understand that you holy ghost was given to the Apostles in a vysible form.

column7: But it is now gyuen to the chosen and electe persons inuisiblye only by the worde.
column8: But it is now given to the chosen and elect persons invisibly only by the word.

column7: Wherfore good christen people I hartely exhorte you, that ye woll earnestly imbrace and loue gods worde, and not mocke & deryde it as certayne of the Iues here sayd that the apostles were dronken and full of new wyne.
column8: Wherefore good christian people I heartily exhort you, that you will earnestly embrace and love gods word, and not mock & deride it as certain of the Iues here said that the apostles were drunken and full of new wine.

column7: Neyther do I exhorte you onely to reade and prayse the worde, but also to worke after it, to declare by youre dedes and procedynges that ye haue an vnfayned and ryght fayth in Christ.
column8: Neither do I exhort you only to read and praise the word, but also to work after it, to declare by your deeds and proceedings that you have and unfeigned and right faith in Christ.

column7: So doynge, no doubte the holy goost shal come and dwell wythin you and declare and open vnto you all trouthe necessary to your soules helth, to the extirpacion of all wycked doctrine and auauncement of gods glorye.
column8: So doing, no doubt the holy ghost shall come and dwell within you and declare and open unto you all truth necessary to your souls health, to the extirpation of all wicked doctrine and advancement of gods glory.

column7: Vnto whome be all honoure and prayse worlde wythout ende.
column8: Unto whom be all honour and praise world without end.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The gospell on Wytsondaye.
column8: : homily The gospel on Wytsondaye.

column7: The xiiij. chapter of Ihon. Thargument.
column8: The xiiij. chapter of Jhon. Thargument.

column7: Of the worde of Christe and of the holy goost
column8: Of the word of Christe and of the holy ghost

column7: I Esus sayd vnto hys disciples, Yf a man loue me, he wyl kepe my saynges, and my father wyl loue him, and we wyl come vnto him, ad dwel with him He that loueth me not, kepeth not my sayenges.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples, If a man love me, he will keep my sayings, and my father will love him, and we will come unto him, and dwell with him He that loves me not, keepeth not my sayings.

column7: And the word which ye heare, is not myne, but the fathers whych sent me.
column8: And the word which you hear, is not mine, but the father's which sent me.

column7: These thynges haue I spoken vnto you, beynge yet present wyth you.
column8: These things have I spoken unto you, being yet present with you.

column7: But the comforter which is the holy goost whome my father wyll sende in my name, he shall teache you all thynges, and brynge all thynges to your remembrauce what so euer I haue sayd vnto you.
column8: But the comforter which is the holy ghost whom my father will send in my name, he shall teach you all things, and bring all things to your remembrance what so ever I have said unto you.

column7: Peace I leaue wyth you, my peace I gyue you.
column8: Peace I leave with you, my peace I gyve you.

column7: Not as the worlde gyueth, gyue I vnto you.
column8: Not as the world gyveth, gyve I unto you.

column7: Let not your hertes be greued, neyther feare.
column8: Let not your herts be grieved, neither fear.

column7: Ye haue herde howe I sayd vnto you: I go, and come agayne vnto you.
column8: You have herd how I said unto you: I go, and come again unto you.

column7: Yf ye loued me, ye wolde verely reioyse, bycause I sayd: I go vnto the father.
column8: If you loved me, you would verily rejoice, because I said: I go unto the father.

column7: For the father is greater then I. And now haue I shewed it you before it come, that whan it is come to passe, ye myght beleue Hereafter wyll I not talke many wordes vnto you.
column8: For the father is greater then I. And now have I showed it you before it come, that when it is come to pass, you might believe Hereafter will I not talk many words unto you.

column7: For the prince of thys worlde commeth, and hath nought in me.
column8: For the prince of this world comes, and hath nought in me.

column7: But that the worlde maye know that I loue the father.
column8: But that the world may know that I love the father.

column7: And as the father gaue me comaudement, euen so do I. B Efore we touch the gospell (my brethre) we shal speake somwhat of this dayes feast. <NOTE> This feast whych they call Pentecost, began in thys wyse.
column8: And as the father gave me comaudement, even so do I. BEfore BEfore we touch the gospel (my brethren) we shall speak somewhat of this days feast. This feast which they call Pentecost, began in this wise.

column7: Whan God shulde leade the Israelites out of Egypte, ye nyght before he ordeyned Passeouer which we call Ester to be solemnised, and comaunded that P A G Eliiij euery yeare about that tyme yt daye shulde be kepte holydaye for a memory of theyr departure out of Egypte.
column8: When God should lead the Israelites out of Egypte, you night before he ordained Passeouer which we call Ester to be solemnised, and commanded that PAGEliiij PAGEliiij PAGEliiij PAGEliiij every year about that time that day should be kept holiday for a memory of their departure out of Egypte.

column7: And from that daye afterwarde for the space of fyfty dayes they walked in the wyldernes, tyll at last they came to the mout Sinay, where by Moses the lawe was gyuen them of God.
column8: And from that day afterward for the space of fyfty days they walked in the wilderness, till at last they came to the mout Sinay, where by Moses the law was given them of God.

column7: For thys cause they kept that solempne holydaye whyche we call in Greke Pentecost that is to saye the fyftye daye and in Englysh Wytsonday.
column8: For this cause they kept that solemn holiday which we call in Greek Pentecost that is to say the fyftye day and in English Wytsonday.

column7: Now therfore fyfty dayes from Ester beynge accomplyshed and the memory of the lawe whych god had promulgate to the people in the mounte Sinay fulfylled: the holy goost came and gaue an other lawe.
column8: Now therefore fyfty days from Ester being accomplished and the memory of the law which god had promulgate to the people in the mount Sinay fulfilled: the holy ghost came and gave and other law.

column7: Nowe therfore, thys day is celebrate of vs not because of ye olde facte but because of the newe, I meane, of ye sendyng of ye holy ghost.
column8: Now therefore, this day is celebrate of us not because of you old fact but because of the new, I mean, of you sending of the holy ghost.

column7: So we declare a certayne difference betwene oure Pentecoste, and the Iues Pentecost.
column8: So we declare a certain difference between our Pentecoste, and the Iues Pentecost.

column7: Fyrste the Iues kept this daye, bycause the lawe wrytten was then gyuen vnto them.
column8: Fyrste the Iues kept this day, because the law written was then given unto them.

column7: But we oughte to celebrate oure Pencecoste bycause the lawe of God was then spiritually delyuered vnto vs. For the better vnderstandynge hereof, <NOTE> Saynte Paule is to be broughte forth whiche also putteth the same difference, wher he speaketh of two maner prechynges.
column8: But we ought to celebrate our Pencecoste because the law of God was then spiritually delivered unto us For the better understanding hereof, Faint Paule is to be brought forth which also putteth the same difference, where he speaks of two manner preachings.

column7: And as there be two maner preachynges, so be there two sortes of people.
column8: And as there be two manner preachings, so be there two sorts of people.

column7: First was the lawe wryten, which God commaunded and comprised in lettres and therfore it is called the lawe of the lettre, bycause it remayneth in lettres and entreth not in the brest, neyther do any workes folowe it saue hypocritical and constreyned workes, and therfore the people also remayne styll but lyterall and fleshly.
column8: First was the law written, which God commanded and comprised in letters and therefore it is called the law of the lettre, because it remaineth in letters and entereth not in the breast, neither do any works follow it save hypocritical and constrained works, and therefore the people also remain still but lyterall and fleshly.

column7: And bycause it was comprysed onlye in lettres and was all togyther in deade wrytynge, it kylled and made a dead people, for the hart was dead bycause it dyd not of the owne accorde the commaundement of god.
column8: And because it was comprised only in letters and was all together in dead writing, it killed and made a dead people, for the heart was dead because it did not of the own accord the commandment of god.

column7: For yf euery man shuld be lefte to his owne wyll to do what hym lusteth wythout all feare of punyshement there shulde be founde none but wolde rather be fre and louse from the law then bounde therto.
column8: For if every man should be left to his own will to do what him lusteth without all fear of punishment there should be found none but would rather be from and louse from the law then bound thereto.

column7: For thus he naturally thinketh.
column8: For thus he naturally thinketh.

column7: Lo God wyll surely punyshe me, yea and dryue me into hel, onles I kepe his commaundementes.
column8: Lo God will surely punish me, yea and drive me into hell, unless I keep his commandments.

column7: Tha nature feleth it selfe vnwyllynge, and to do them wt no maner loue or delectation, wherfore man is forth wyth made enemye to god by reason of the penaltye when he fealeth hymselfe a synner, and that he walketh not ryghtly before God, so that he wold rather that there were no God.
column8: Than nature feeleth it self unwilling, and to do them with no manner love or delectation, wherefore man is forth with made enemy to god by reason of the penalty when he fealeth himself a sinner, and that he walks not rightly before God, so that he would rather that there were no God.

column7: Thys bytternes is infixed in the harte agaynst God, thoughe nature goeth about neuer so much to garnysh her selfe wyth fayre workes.
column8: This bitterness is infixed in the heart against God, though nature goes about never so much to garnish her self with fair works.

column7: It appeareth therfore how that the lawe coprysed in scripture and letters doth iustifye noman nor yet can entre into the harte.
column8: It appears therefore how that the law coprysed in scripture and letters does justify noman nor yet can enter into the heart.

column7: <NOTE> The other lawe is spirituall whyche is wrytten not wt penne or ynke, nor is declared wyth ye mouth after the fashio as Moses wrought the mater in tables of stone, but lyke as we se in thys story.
column8: The other law is spiritual which is written not with pen or ink, nor is declared with you mouth after the fashio as Moses wrought the mater in tables of stone, but like as we see in this story.

column7: The holy goost commeth downe from heauen and fylleth them all together, makynge them to haue clouen & fyry tonges and to preache frankely and frely farre otherwyse then it was done before, so that al the people was astonnyed thereat and wondered.
column8: The holy ghost comes down from heaven and filleth them all together, making them to have cloven & fyry tongues and to preach frankly and freely far otherwise then it was done before, so that all the people was astonnyed thereat and wondered.

column7: The holy gooste I saye commeth and replenisheth ye harte, he chaungeth the man whych loueth God and doth P A G Elv gladly all that euer is acceptable vnto hym.
column8: The holy ghost I say comes and replenisheth you heart, he changeth the man which loves God and does PAGElv PAGElv PAGElv PAGElv gladly all that ever is acceptable unto him.

column7: Wherfore al thynges be there lyuely, quycke is the vnderstandynge, the eye, the mynde, and the harte, whyche brenneth and is rapte wyth the desyre of all goodnes.
column8: Wherefore all things be there lively, quick is the understanding, the eye, the mind, and the heart, which brenneth and is rapt with the desire of all goodness.

column7: And thys is the true difference betwene ye lawe comprysed in letters and the spirituall lawe, & here is it sene whych be the workes of God.
column8: And this is the true difference between you law comprised in letters and the spiritual law, & here is it seen which be the works of God.

column7: Wherfore here is al the crafte set to discerne and preach ryghtly of the holy goost.
column8: Wherefore here is all the craft set to discern and preach rightly of the holy ghost.

column7: Heretofore men haue preached of hym that he bryngeth to passe and prompteth all thynges what so euer eyther the counsayles decerne or the B. of Rome in hys canonical law comaudeth where as neuertheles al those thynges be only externe and outwarde whych he ordeneth or gouerneth.
column8: Heretofore men have preached of him that he bringeth to pass and prompteth all things what so ever either the counsels decern or the B. of Rome in his canonical law comaudeth where as nevertheless all those things be only extern and outward which he ordeneth or governeth.

column7: Wherfore thys order of thynges is clene ouertwharte and preposterous, in that they make of the workes of the holy goost a lettered and a dead lawe where it ought to be spiritual and lyuely, & so there is made of it a Mosaicall and humane tradition.
column8: Wherefore this order of things is clean ouertwharte and preposterous, in that they make of the works of the holy ghost a lettered and a dead law where it ought to be spiritual and lively, & so there is made of it a Mosaical and humane tradition.

column7: The cause is that they know not what ye holy goost is, wheruto he was gyue, or what hys feate & office is.
column8: The cause is that they know not what you holy ghost is, wheruto he was gyve, or what his feat & office is.

column7: Let vs learne then and consyder wel what he is, to thintent hys offyce maye be discerned. <NOTE> In the epistle of thys daye it is shewed howe the holy goost is sent downe from aboue, and fylleth the disciples whych before sat in heuynes & feare, he cleueth theyr tonges, he kyndleth, he enflameth them, that they myght take strength of harte and frely preache the Gospell without feare of any man.
column8: Let us learn then and consider well what he is, to intent his office may be discerned. In the epistle of this day it is showed how the holy ghost is sent down from above, and filleth the disciples which before sat in heaviness & fear, he cleueth their tongues, he kyndleth, he inflameth them, that they might take strength of heart and freely preach the Gospel without fear of any man.

column7: Here thou seest it is not the offyce of the holy ghoost to make bokes & to enacte lawes, but that he is suche a God that only wryteth the thynge in ye harte, yt kyndleth it, that createth a new mynde, makynge man to reioyse before god and to be rauished with a new loue toward hym, & consequently wt glad mynde to do hys dutye and seruice to all men franckly.
column8: Here thou seest it is not the office of the holy ghost to make books & to enact laws, but that he is such a God that only writes the thing in you heart, that kyndleth it, that createth a new mind, making man to rejoice before god and to be ravished with a new love towards him, & consequently with glad mind to do his duty and service to all men frankly.

column7: After thys sort the partes of the holy ghost be ryghtly preached, he that paynteth them otherwise, beleue him not.
column8: After this sort the parts of the holy ghost be rightly preached, he that painteth them otherwise, believe him not.

column7: For where he commeth thus thou seest he taketh awaye the letter and maketh men fre from synne and from the compulsion of the lawe so that he raynynge in theyr brest maketh the in whome he is resident to do wythout compulsion all that the lawe comaundeth.
column8: For where he comes thus thou seest he takes away the letter and makes men from from sin and from the compulsion of the law so that he raining in their breast makes thee in whom he is resident to do without compulsion all that the law comaundeth.

column7: But thou wylt aske wherby he bryngeth to passe & what thynge he vseth thus to chauge and renue the hart?
column8: But thou wilt ask whereby he bringeth to pass & what thing he uses thus to chauge and renew the heart?

column7: Surely by that he sheweth and preacheth of Iesus Christ (as Christ hymselfe in the.xv. chap. of Ihon sayeth) whan the comforter cometh whome I shall sende you from my father I meane the spirite of trouth whych procedeth from ye father he shal beare wytnes of me.
column8: Surely by that he shows and preacheth of Jesus Christ (as Christ himself in the xv chap. of Ihon sayeth) when the comforter comes whom I shall send you from my father I mean the spirit of troth which proceedeth from you father he shall bear witness of me.

column7: Nowe oftentymes ye haue herde that the gospel or Euangel is the thynge whych god suffreth to be preached in the worlde and to be tolde to euery man that is to wyt that none can be iustifyed by the dedes of the lawe but rather yt a worse thinge come therby, and therfore he sente downe hys moost deare sonne to dye and to shede hys bloud for vs bycause we of our owne powers coulde not rubbe out the spotte of synne nor be delyuered from it.
column8: Now oftentimes you have herd that the gospel or Evangel is the thing which god suffers to be preached in the world and to be told to every man that is to wit that none can be justified by the deeds of the law but rather that a worse thing come thereby, and therefore he sent down his most deer son to die and to shed his blood for us because we of our own powers could not rub out the spot of sin nor be delivered from it.

column7: But to the preachynge hereof another thynge yet is requyred, euen the holy goost whome God must sende.
column8: But to the preaching hereof another thing yet is required, even the holy ghost whom God must send.

column7: He printeth in the harte thys sermon and preachyng to make it fixed and roted in it, for it is moost sure and certayne yt Christe hath done all thys geare, he hath P A G Elvj taken awaye oure synne and ouercomen all, that by hym we myght raigne ouer al, and euen here in one heape is all the treasure hurded.
column8: He printeth in the heart this sermon and preaching to make it fixed and roted in it, for it is most sure and certain that Christe hath done all this gear, he hath PAGElvj PAGElvj PAGElvj PAGElvj taken away our sin and overcomen all, that by him we might reign over all, and even here in one heap is all the treasure hurded.

column7: Thys treasure we can not get onles the holy goost be gyuen vs whych maye put in oure hartes and myndes to beleue and saye: <NOTE> I also am of the nombre of them to who so greate treasure doth belonge. When we haue ones felte thys, that God hath thus holpen vs and bestowed vpon vs so great treasure: then the mater goeth well forwarde, neyther can it otherwise be but mans mynde must be rauyshed wyth a pleasure towardes God and lyfte vp hymselfe & saye: Oh good father, if thys thy wyll be that thou haste shewed so great loue and suche excedynge kyndnes towardes me I must nedes agayne loue ye wyth my hole hart and reioise, and gladly do what so euer thy pleasure is.
column8: This treasure we can not get unless the holy ghost be given us which may put in our hearts and minds to believe and say: I also am of the number of them to who so great treasure does belong. When we have ones felt this, that God hath thus helped us and bestowed upon us so great treasure: then the mater goes well forward, neither can it otherwise be but men mind must be ravished with a pleasure towards God and lift up himself & say: O good father, if this thy will be that thou haste showed so great love and such exceeding kindness towards me I must needs again love you with my hold heart and rejoice, and gladly do what so ever thy pleasure is.

column7: Then the harte is nomore waywarde nor croked in the meditacion of God, it thynketh not to be dryuen downe to hell of hym, as before the comynge of the holy goost it thought, when it felte no goodnes no loue no fydelitie, but styll a pace the wrathe and indignacion of God.
column8: Then the heart is nomore waywarde nor crooked in the meditation of God, it thinketh not to be driven down to hell of him, as before the coming of the holy ghost it thought, when it felt no goodness no love no fydelitie, but still a pace the wrath and indignation of God.

column7: Now therfore whyle the holy goost prynteth into the christen mas harte howe he hath God hys mercyfull and graciouse Lorde, it is a pleasure for hym for Gods sake boldly to execute and suffre any maner of thynge.
column8: Now therefore while the holy ghost prynteth into the christian mass heart how he hath God his merciful and gracious Lord, it is a pleasure for him for Gods sake boldly to execute and suffer any manner of thing.

column7: After thys wyse thou shalt learne to knowe the holy goost and hys office whych is to distribute ye great treasure Christ and al that in hym is whych is, gyuen and declared vnto vs by the Gospell to thintent thou mayest put hym into thy harte to make hym thyne owne good.
column8: After this wise thou shalt learn to know the holy ghost and his office which is to distribute you great treasure Christ and all that in him is which is, given and declared unto us by the Gospel to intent thou mayest put him into thy heart to make him thine own good.

column7: Hytherto I haue declared vnto you, the hystorie of the holy goost.
column8: Hitherto I have declared unto you, the history of the holy ghost.

column7: Now what we shall do in it, we shall knowe further in the gospell.
column8: Now what we shall do in it, we shall know further in the gospel.

column7: Thus sayeth Christ
column8: Thus sayeth Christ

column7: Yf a man loue me he woll kepe my saynge, and my father shall loue hym.
column8: If a man love me he will keep my saying, and my father shall love him.

column7: Lo good people here ye maye se (as I haue often tymes preached vnto you) that the frute of fayth is charitie, <NOTE> whych thynge can not be denyed.
column8: Lo good people here you may see (as I have often times preached unto you) that the fruit of faith is charity, which thing can not be denied.

column7: For charitie or loue perfourmeth and doeth euen of the owne accorde all that euer scripture comaudeth.
column8: For charity or love performeth and doth even of the own accord all that ever scripture comaudeth.

column7: And thys doth saynt Paule declare Gal. v. He that loueth his neyghboure hath fulfylled the lawe.
column8: And this does saint Paule declare Gal. v. He that loves his neighbour hath fulfilled the law.

column7: Wherfore they that haue not fayth and charitie, do not fulfyll the lawe, albeit they seme in outwarde appearaunce to perfourme all the workes of the lawe.
column8: Wherefore they that have not faith and charity, do not fulfil the law, albeit they seem in outward appearance to perform all the works of the law.

column7: The worde whych Christ preacheth he sayeth is not hys worde but hys fathers worde declarynge herby yt nothyng ought to be added nor taken awaye from it.
column8: The word which Christ preacheth he sayeth is not his word but his father's word declaring hereby that nothing ought to be added nor taken away from it.

column7: And these thynges (sayeth Christe) concernynge aswell your loue towardes me, as the kepynge of my word haue I spoken vnto you, beynge yet present & dwellynge amonges you.
column8: And these things (sayeth Christe) concerning aswell your love towards me, as the keeping of my word have I spoken unto you, being yet present & dwelling among you.

column7: But that same comforter of whome I haue made so muche mencion vnto you, I meane the holy goost, whose feate and offyce shal be to sanctifye & lyghten you vnto all trouth, which holy goost my father shall sende in my name that is to saye for my cause, he shall teach you altogether & shall put you in remembraunce of all that euer ye haue herde of me. <NOTE> Thou wolt saye vnto me.
column8: But that same comforter of whom I have made so much mention unto you, I mean the holy ghost, whose feat and office shall be to sanctify & lighten you unto all troth, which holy ghost my father shall send in my name that is to say for my cause, he shall teach you altogether & shall put you in remembrance of all that ever you have herd of me. Thou wolt say unto me.

column7: Why? knewe not the disciples all before, whyche were so longe tyme wyth Christ?
column8: Why? knew not the disciples all before, which were so long time with Christ?

column7: I answere, that ye disciples ought nedes to haue bene taught by the holy goost, for wythout hym they were yet imperfecte and carnall, P A G Elvij for they vnderstode neyther Christes glorificacion by the crosse nor yet hys raygne or kyngdome.
column8: I answer, that you disciples ought needs to have be taught by the holy ghost, for without him they were yet imperfect and carnal, PAGElvij PAGElvij PAGElvij PAGElvij for they understood neither Christes glorification by the cross nor yet his reign or kingdom.

column7: Wherfore they neded the holy goostes teachynge, yt is to saye, <NOTE> sanctifyenge and makynge the thynges lyuely in them whych they had lerned of Christ For ye disciples were as yet but (litera) they perceyued not the thynges that were of the spirite of God, and therfore they neded the holy goost to quycken them, accordynge to the sayenge of saynt Paule.
column8: Wherefore they needed the holy ghosts teaching, that is to say, sanctifyenge and making the things lively in them which they had learned of Christ For the disciples were as yet but (litera) they perceived not the things that were of the spirit of God, and therefore they needed the holy ghost to quicken them, according to the saying of saint Paule.

column7: The letter sleeth, but the spirite quickeneth.
column8: The letter sleeth, but the spirit quickeneth.

column7: Ye may not then vnderstande by thys worde (teach) that the holy goost shal set abroch a new doctrine that Christ had not taught before, <NOTE> but ye must vnderstande by it that the holy goost shall interprete the doctrine already taught by Christ and declare it to the spirituall vnderstandynge.
column8: You may not then understand by this word (teach) that the holy ghost shall set abroach a new doctrine that Christ had not taught before, but you must understand by it that the holy ghost shall interpret the doctrine already taught by Christ and declare it to the spiritual understanding.

column7: And therfore Christ expouneth hymselfe and sayeth he shall put you in remebrauce of al the thynges that I haue shewed you.
column8: And therefore Christ exponeth himself and sayeth he shall put you in remebrauce of all the things that I have showed you.

column7: So that ye can not gather herby that ye holy goost shall adde any thynge to Christes doctrine, as the wycked papistes do wyckedly gather.
column8: So that you can not gather hereby that you holy ghost shall add any thing to Christes doctrine, as the wicked papists do wickedly gather.

column7: It foloweth.
column8: It followeth.

column7: Peace I leaue wyth you, my peace I gyue vnto you, not as the world gyueth, gyue I vnto you &c. My frendes what is Christes peace? <NOTE> Surely (to be short) it is nothynge els but the quyet and tranquilitie of conscience.
column8: Peace I leave with you, my peace I gyve unto you, not as the world gyveth, gyve I unto you etc. My friends what is Christes peace? Surely (to be short) it is nothing else but the quiet and tranquillity of conscience.

column7: Thys peace the worlde can not gyue, mans traditions can not gyue, mas owne voluntary workes can not gyue, no mokery, no pylgrimage, no popysh pardons, no pardon beades, no relyques, brefly no fleshly thynge can gyue thys peace of conscience.
column8: This peace the world can not gyve, men traditions can not gyve, mass own voluntary works can not gyve, no mokery, no pilgrimage, no popish pardons, no pardon beads, no relics, briefly no fleshly thing can gyve this peace of conscience.

column7: It is only Christe that can gyue vs thys peace whan we spiritually eate hym & drynke hym, that is to saye, when we know wherfore Christ serueth vs and so suffre hym by true fayth and charitie to entre into oure soules and to dwell wythin vs whych thynge he promyseth vs here in this gospell that he woll do, in case we declare the frute of our fayth and kepe hys worde.
column8: It is only Christe that can gyve us this peace when we spiritually eat him & drink him, that is to say, when we know wherefore Christ serveth us and so suffer him by true faith and charity to enter into our souls and to dwell within us which thing he promiseth us here in this gospel that he will do, in case we declare the fruit of our faith and keep his word.

column7: <NOTE> ye shall obserue (good people) in thys gospell, that Christe here shewed hys disciples that he must go awaye from them, but yet he sayeth he woll come agayne.
column8: you shall observe (good people) in this gospel, that Christe here showed his disciples that he must go away from them, but yet he sayeth he will come again.

column7: But I praye you when commeth Christ agayne vnto vs?
column8: But I pray you when comes Christ again unto us?

column7: Surely he cometh agayne, when he sendeth hys worde and hys spirite vnto vs. For loke where the worde is and there is Christ moost presently.
column8: Surely he comes again, when he sends his word and his spirit unto us For look where the word is and there is Christ most presently.

column7: So in an other place he sayeth: <NOTE> Lo I am wyth you euen to the ende of ye world.
column8: So in and other place he sayeth: Lo I am with you even to the end of you world.

column7: Fynally where Christ sayeth that the father is greter then he, ye shall vnderstande, that Christe otherwhyles speaketh as a man, otherwhyles as God, whyche thynge oughte diligently to be obserued of such as woll studye holy scripture.
column8: Finally where Christ sayeth that the father is greater then he, you shall understand, that Christe otherwhiles speaks as a man, otherwhiles as God, which thing ought diligently to be observed of such as will study holy scripture.

column7: For that he here sayeth: My father is greater than I, ye must referre it to hys humanitie.
column8: For that he here sayeth: My father is greater than I, you must refer it to his humanity.

column7: But of hys diuinitie in an other place he speaketh in thys wyse. <NOTE> I and my father be one.
column8: But of his divinity in and other place he speaks in this wise. I and my father be one.

column7: And now sayeth Christ callynge backe hys disciples to hys worde whereby they myght comforte themselues after hys departure, I haue tolde you of it before hande, to thintent that whan it is come to passe ye myght beleue that I wolle surely come vnto you agayne.
column8: And now sayeth Christ calling back his disciples to his word whereby they might comfort themselves after his departure, I have told you of it before hand, to intent that when it is come to pass you might believe that I wool surely come unto you again.

column7: Herafter woll I not speake much vnto you, <NOTE> that is to wyt, presently & in person wyth mans voyce.
column8: Hereafter will I not speak much unto you, that is to wit, presently & in person with men voice.

column7: For the prince of this worlde commeth P A G Elviij that is to saye, my mortall enemy and yours Sata the deuel whych treadeth vpon my hele is at hande. <NOTE> And he calleth hym the prince of the worlde of hys effecte, bycause he comaundeth and ruleth ye worlde after hys wyll and pleasure, and draweth it whether he woll as he lust hymselfe.
column8: For the prince of this world comes PAGElviij PAGElviij PAGElviij PAGElviij that is to say, my mortal enemy and yours Satan the devil which treadeth upon my he'll is at hand. And he calls him the prince of the world of his effect, because he comaundeth and ruleth you world after his will and pleasure, and draws it whither he will as he lust himself.

column7: But thys prince of the worlde thys Satan (sayeth Christe) hath nought in me.
column8: But this prince of the world this Satan (sayeth Christe) hath nought in me.

column7: As who shulde saye, albeit the prince of ye world is commyng agaynst me to vtter and worke al that euer he can deuise to put me downe, yet sure I am that I shall ouercome hym.
column8: As who should say, albeit the prince of the world is coming against me to utter and work all that ever he can devise to put me down, yet sure I am that I shall overcome him.

column7: So he maketh hys disciples afrayed in that he telleth them that the prince of thys worlde is marchyng forwarde agaynst him, but agayne he comforteth them when he sayeth, he hath nought in hym.
column8: So he makes his disciples afraid in that he telleth them that the prince of this world is marching forward against him, but again he comforts them when he sayeth, he hath nought in him.

column7: And in these few wordes is expressed the pyth of the hole gospell.
column8: And in these few words is expressed the pyth of the hold gospel.

column7: Wherfore to coclude, of thys victory of Christ all we good christen people shalbe partakers, in case we beleue accordynge as in thys Gospell we be taught.
column8: Wherefore to coclude, of this victory of Christ all we good christian people shall partakers, in case we believe according as in this Gospel we be taught.

column7: And consequently the holy goost who is the true and only comforter in al troubles and affliccion shal make hys mansion and abode wythin vs, and put vs in mynde of all Christes wyll and pleasure, to the glorye of God the father of heauen and hys only begotten sonne Christ Iesus our Lorde.
column8: And consequently the holy ghost who is the true and only comforter in all troubles and affliction shall make his mansion and abided within us, and put us in mind of all Christes will and pleasure, to the glory of God the father of heaven and his only begotten son Christ Jesus our Lord.

column7: Qui viuit & regnat in infinita secula.
column8: Qui viuit & regnat in infinita secula.

column7: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the seconde daye of Pentecost.
column8: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the seconde day of Pentecost.

column7: The.x. chapter of the Actes.
column8: The x chapter of the Acts.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: How the Heythen receyued the holy goost & were baptised.
column8: How the Heythen received the holy ghost & were baptised.

column7: P Eter opened hys mouth and sayd.
column8: PEter PEter opened his mouth and said.

column7: Iesus commaunded vs to preach vnto the people, and to testifye, that it is he, whych was ordeyned of God to be the iudge of quycke and deade.
column8: Jesus commanded us to preach unto the people, and to testify, that it is he, which was ordained of God to be the judge of quick and dead.

column7: To him gyue all the prophetes wytnes, that thorowe hys name who so euer beleueth in hym, shall receaue remission of synnes.
column8: To him gyve all the prophets witness, that thorough his name who so ever believeth in him, shall receive remission of sins.

column7: Whyle Peter yet spake these wordes the holy goost fell on all them whyche herde the preachynge.
column8: While Peter yet spoke these words the holy ghost fell on all them which herd the preaching.

column7: And they of the circumcision whyche beleued, were astonnyed, as many as came with Peter, bycause that on the Gentyls also was shed out the gyfte of the holy goost.
column8: And they of the circumcision which believed, were astonnyed, as many as came with Peter, because that on the Gentles also was shed out the gift of the holy ghost.

column7: For they herde them speake wyth tonges, and magnifye God.
column8: For they herd them speak with tongues, and magnify God.

column7: Then answered Peter: can any ma forbyd water, that these shulde not be baptised whyche haue receyued the holy goost as well as we?
column8: Then answered Peter: can any ma forbid water, that these should not be baptised which have received the holy ghost as well as we?

column7: And he commaunded them to be baptised in the name of the Lorde.
column8: And he commanded them to be baptised in the name of the Lord.

column7: <NOTE> G Ood people the summe of saynt Peters sermo here is, that Iesus Christ whych for hys benefytes and wonderfull vertues that he shewed amonges the Iues, was crucifyed, that is to wyt, nayled moost vilanously to the crosse (whych was the moost paynfull and cruell death that the Iues coulde ymagyne) dyd notwythstandynge ryse agayne from P A G Elix death to lyfe and that who soeuer wol beleue in him shalbe saued.
column8: GOod GOod people the sum of saint Peters sermon here is, that Jesus Christ which for his benefits and wonderful virtues that he showed among the Iues, was crucified, that is to wit, nailed most villanously to the cross (which was the most painful and cruel death that the Iues could imagine) did notwithstanding rise again from PAGElix PAGElix PAGElix PAGElix death to life and that who soever will believe in him shall saved.

column7: And he sayeth furthermore that God annoynted thys Iesus of Nazareth wyth the holy goost and wyth power.
column8: And he sayeth furthermore that God anointed this Jesus of Nazareth with the holy ghost and with power.

column7: Wherby he declareth hym to be the true Messias whych was promysed to the fathers and of whome the prophete Dauid spake: I haue anoynted my kinge ouer Zion my holy hyl He declareth also that Christes office is to do good to all.
column8: Whereby he declareth him to be the true Messias which was promised to the father's and of whom the prophet Dauid spoke: I have anointed my king over Zion my holy hyl He declareth also that Christes office is to do good to all.

column7: Now thys resurrection of Christ he cofirmeth both wyth hys owne wytnesse and wyth the wytnes of all that sawe the thynge wyth theyr eyes.
column8: Now this resurrection of Christ he cofirmeth both with his own witness and with the witness of all that saw the thing with their eyes.

column7: And lest a man shulde reiecte them as parciall wytnesses bycause they were hys seruauntes and disciples, he fetcheth out a moost sure recorde of scripture sayenge: that all the prophetes do testifye of thys Christ.
column8: And lest a man should reject them as partial witnesses because they were his servants and disciples, he fetches out a most sure record of scripture saying: that all the prophets do testify of this Christ.

column7: Fynally lest a man woll fynde cauillacion and say they cam forth of their owne mynd vncalled to beare wytnes of thys thynge, he addeth that they were commaunded and sent by God to preache to the people, & to testifye that it is thys same Iesus Christ which was ordeyned of God to be the iuge of the quycke & deade.
column8: Finally lest a man will find cavillation and say they cam forth of their own mind uncalled to bear witness of this thing, he adds that they were commanded and sent by God to preach to the people, & to testify that it is this same Jesus Christ which was ordained of God to be the judge of the quick & dead.

column7: Whych thynge is also an vndoubted artycle of our fayth.
column8: Which thing is also and undoubted article of our faith.

column7: To thys Christ (sayeth Peter) gyue all the prophetes wytnes that through hys name who so euer beleue in hym shalbe saued.
column8: To this Christ (sayeth Peter) gyve all the prophets witness that through his name who so ever believe in him shall saved.

column7: And amonges other, the prophete Esaye who wryteth of Christe in thys wyse. <NOTE> He only hath taken on hym our infirmitie and borne our paynes.
column8: And among other, the prophet Esaye who writes of Christe in this wise. He only hath taken on him our infirmity and born our pains.

column7: The payne of our punishment was layde vpon hym, and wyth hys strypes are we healed.
column8: The pain of our punishment was laid upon him, and with his stripes are we healed.

column7: Surely we haue gone all astray lyke shepe, euery one hath turned hys owne waye.
column8: Surely we have gone all astray like sheep, every one hath turned his own way.

column7: But through hym, the Lorde hath pardoned all our synnes.
column8: But through him, the Lord hath pardoned all our sins.

column7: Lo here ye maye se playnly aswell by the wordes of saynt Peter in thys place as by thys prophet Esay how we get remission of synnes by beleuynge in Christ.
column8: Lo here you may see plainly aswell by the words of saint Peter in this place as by this prophet Esay how we get remission of sins by believing in Christ.

column7: Thys doth also saynt Paule in many places declare & namely through out hys hole epistle to the Romaynes. <NOTE> Whereupon the auncient doctoure Origene wrytynge, sayth: Man therfore is iustified by fayth, whome the workes of the lawe do nothyng helpe to ryghtuousnes.
column8: This does also saint Paule in many places declare & namely through out his hold epistle to the Romans. Whereupon the ancient doctor Origene writing, say: Man therefore is justified by faith, whom the works of the law do nothing help to righteousness.

column7: For where fayth is not which iustifyeth the beleuer, althoughe a man haue workes of the lawe, yet bycause they be not buylded vpon the foundacion of fayth, albeit they seme to be good, they can not iustifye the worker, yf fayth be awaye whyche is the seale of all that be iustifyed of God. <NOTE> Saynt Ambrose agreyng hervnto sayth, that the redemption of Christes bloude were very vyle, yf iustification whych is done by grace shuld be due to the merites goynge before, so that it shuld be not the gyfte of the gyuer but the reward of the worker.
column8: For where faith is not which justifieth the believer, although a man have works of the law, yet because they be not builded upon the foundation of faith, albeit they seem to be good, they can not justify the worker, if faith be away which is the seal of all that be justified of God. Saint Ambrose agreeing hereunto say, that the redemption of Christes blood were very vile, if justification which is done by grace should be due to the merits going before, so that it should be not the gift of the gyuer but the reward of the worker.

column7: Also Ierome wrytynge vpon the epistle to the Galathians sayeth: <NOTE> None is saued by the lawe, but we be all saued by fayth. <NOTE> Neyther doth saynt Augustine disagre from thys, saynge: Our fayth that is to say the catholyke faythe discerneth the ryghtuouse fro the vnryghtuouse not by the lawe of workes, but by the selfe lawe of fayth.
column8: Also Ierome writing upon the epistle to the Galathians sayeth: None is saved by the law, but we be all saved by faith. Neither does saint Augustine disagree from this, saying: Our faith that is to say the catholic faith discerneth the righteous from the unrighteous not by the law of works, but by the self law of faith.

column7: But what go I aboute to allege a fewe doctours?
column8: But what go I about to allege a few doctors?

column7: All the prophetes (as Peter here sayeth) Christe hymselfe, all the Apostles yea all the holy scripture throughe out, all the auncient and ecclesiasticall doctours and holy expositours of scripture do gyue wytnesse to Christe that P A G Elx through hys name whosoeuer beleueth in hym shal receyue forgyuenesse and pardon of theyr synnes.
column8: All the prophets (as Peter here sayeth) Christe himself, all the Apostles yea all the holy scripture through out, all the ancient and ecclesiastical doctors and holy expositors of scripture do gyve witness to Christe that PAGElx PAGElx PAGElx PAGElx through his name whosoever believeth in him shall receive forgiveness and pardon of their sins.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: Whyle Peter yet spake these wordes, the holy goost fell on all them whych herde the preachyng And they of the circumcision whych beleued were astonnyed.
column8: While Peter yet spoke these words, the holy ghost fell on all them which herd the preaching And they of the circumcision which believed were astonnyed.

column7: &c. Brethren ye shall note that Christ was peculiarly promysed to the Iues as he hymselfe also sayeth in the.xv. Chapter of Mathew.
column8: etc. Brothers you shall note that Christ was peculiarly promised to the Iues as he himself also sayeth in the xv Chapter of Mathew.

column7: I am not sent but to ye lost shepe of the house of Israel.
column8: I am not sent but to you lost sheep of the house of Israel.

column7: Howbeit the callynge of the Gentyls was longe before prophecyed of by the prophetes, and here also it was opened to saynt Peter by a vision of a shete sente downe from aboue vnto hym. <NOTE> And therfore he began hys sermo on thys wyse.
column8: Howbeit the calling of the Gentles was long before prophesied of by the prophets, and here also it was opened to saint Peter by a vision of a xx sent down from above unto him. And therefore he began his sermon on this wise.

column7: Of a trouth I perceyue that there is no respecte of persons wyth God, but in all people he that feareth hym and worketh ryghtuousnes is accepted wyth hym.
column8: Of a troth I perceive that there is no respect of persons with God, but in all people he that fears him and works righteousness is accepted with him.

column7: Now so many as beleued of the circumcision that is to wyt, the Iues not knowyng hereof but beynge ignoraunt that the Gentyls also were to be admytted to the felowship of the Gospell wondered, whan they sawe that on the Gentyls also was shed out the gyfte of the holy goost, and herde them speke wyth tonges & magnifyed God.
column8: Now so many as believed of the circumcision that is to wit, the Iues not knowing hereof but being ignorant that the Gentles also were to be admitted to the fellowship of the Gospel wondered, when they saw that on the Gentles also was shed out the gift of the holy ghost, and herd them speak with tongues & magnified God.

column7: Here ye shal also marke, <NOTE> thys gyft of tonges wherwyth at the sendynge downe of ye holy goost ye Apostles and other were so indowed yt they were vnderstanded of the people of al nacions, is now ceased, but in ye meane season the prayse of gods name ceaseth not nor ought not to cease.
column8: Here you shall also mark, this gift of tongues wherewith at the sending down of you holy ghost you Apostles and other were so endowed that they were understanded of the people of all nations, is now ceased, but in you mean season the praise of gods name ceases not nor ought not to cease.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: Then answered Peter, can any man forbyd water that these shulde not be baptised whych haue receyued the holy goost aswell as we?
column8: Then answered Peter, can any man forbid water that these should not be baptised which have received the holy ghost aswell as we?

column7: Here ye se manyfestly (good people) that ye Gentyls by Peters preachynge of gods worde were replenyshed wyth the holy goost before they were outwardly baptysed wyth the water, for wyth the spirit it is playne that they were baptised.
column8: Here you see manifestly (good people) that the Gentles by Peters preaching of gods word were replenished with the holy ghost before they were outwardly baptised with the water, for with the spirit it is plain that they were baptised.

column7: Saynt Peter therfore to confirme them, and as it were to seale them wyth an outwarde sygne, commaundeth them to be baptised wyth water in the name of the Lorde For baptisme is not only a sygne of mortificacion and of remission of synnes, <NOTE> but it is also a badge or knowlege that we be receyued into the nober of the chyldren of God.
column8: Saint Peter therefore to confirm them, and as it were to seal them with and outward sign, commandeth them to be baptised with water in the name of the Lord For baptism is not only a sign of mortification and of remission of sins, but it is also a badge or knowledge that we be received into the nober of the children of God.

column7: Wherfore as al holy doctous and expositours do agre, there be two maner of baptismes. <NOTE> Now as also saynt Ierome affirmeth, ma only gyueth the water, but God gyueth the holy goost wherby the fylthe is washed awaye, and the synnes of bloude purged.
column8: Wherefore as all holy doctous and expositors do agree, there be two manner of baptisms. Now as also saint Ierome affirmeth, ma only gyveth the water, but God gyveth the holy ghost whereby the filth is washed away, and the sins of blood purged.

column7: The same Ierome also wrytyng vpon the Epistle to the Galathians, sayeth in thys wyse.
column8: The same Ierome also writing upon the Epistle to the Galathians, sayeth in this wise.

column7: Yf then they that be baptised in Christe haue done on Christ, it is manyfest that they whych haue not put on Christ, be not baptised in Christe.
column8: If then they that be baptised in Christe have done on Christ, it is manifest that they which have not put on Christ, be not baptised in Christe.

column7: For it was sayd to them whych were counted faythfull & whych were supposed to haue had the baptisme of Christ: Put ye on the Lorde Iesus Christ.
column8: For it was said to them which were counted faithful & which were supposed to have had the baptism of Christ: Put you on the Lord Jesus Christ.

column7: Yf a ma taketh only thys corporall washyng of water which is sene wyth the eyes of the flesh, he is not clad with the Lorde Iesus Christ.
column8: If a ma takes only this corporal washing of water which is seen with the eyes of the flesh, he is not clad with the Lord Jesus Christ.

column7: For albeit Simo Magus in the actes of the Apostles had receyued ye washing P A G Elxi of water, yet bycause he had not the holy gooste, he was not baptised in Christ.
column8: For albeit Simo Magus in the acts of the Apostles had received you washing PAGElxi PAGElxi PAGElxi PAGElxi of water, yet because he had not the holy ghost, he was not baptised in Christ.

column7: Wherfore (as I declared vnto you on the Ascesio day) baptisme wythout fayth is as who shulde saye, a paper sealed wythout any wrytynge in it.
column8: Wherefore (as I declared unto you on the Ascesio day) baptism without faith is as who should say, a paper sealed without any writing in it.

column7: But ye shall alwayes vnderstad that I excepte and speake not of the baptisme of infauntes or babes.
column8: But you shall always vnderstad that I except and speak not of the baptism of infants or babes.

column7: For they (as saint Austine and the other expositours of scripture do full well declare) be saued yf after baptisme they chaunce in theyr infauncy to dye, by the fayth of the catholyke church.
column8: For they (as saint Austine and the other expositors of scripture do full well declare) be saved if after baptism they chance in their infancy to die, by the faith of the catholic church.

column7: And furthermore we saye agaynst the wycked Anabaptistes that the baptisme of children is not vayne but necessarye to saluacion.
column8: And furthermore we say against the wicked Anabaptists that the baptism of children is not vain but necessary to salvation.

column7: For no doubte the promyse of saluacion perteyneth also to chyldren or infauntes.
column8: For no doubt the promise of salvation pertaineth also to children or infants.

column7: But it pertayneth not to them that be oute of the church where is neyther the worde nor the sacramentes.
column8: But it pertaineth not to them that be out of the church where is neither the word nor the sacraments.

column7: And here vpon do all lerned men agre.
column8: And here upon do all learned men agree.

column7: Now therfore (good christen people) syth your baptisme woll not serue you wythout faythe, no nor all the workes ye can do, I ernestly exhorte you that accordynge to saynt Peters declaracion here for the obteynynge of remission of youre synnes ye woll fastlye beleue in Christ.
column8: Now therefore (good christian people) sith your baptism will not serve you without faith, no nor all the works you can do, I earnestly exhort you that according to saint Peters declaration here for the obtaining of remission of your sins you will fastly believe in Christ.

column7: So doyng no doubt the holy goost shal enter into your hartes & make you euen of loue without compulsion of lawe, to worke wel to the glorye of God, and helth of your soules eternally.
