column8: So doing no doubt the holy ghost shall enter into your hearts & make you even of love without compulsion of law, to work well to the glory of God, and health of your souls eternally.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The gospell on the seconde daye of Pentecost.
column8: : homily The gospel on the seconde day of Pentecost.

column7: The.iij. chapter of Ihon. Thargument.
column8: The iij chapter of Jhon. Thargument.

column7: The moost comfortable glad tydynges of Christ is here wonderfully well described.
column8: The most comfortable glad tidings of Christ is here wonderfully well described.

column7: I Esus spake vnto a ruler amonge the pharises.
column8: IEsus IEsus spoke unto a ruler among the pharisees.

column7: God so loued the worlde, that he gaue hys only begotten sonne, that whosoeuer beleueth in hym, shulde not perysh, but haue euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten son, that whosoever believeth in him, should not perish, but have everlasting life.

column7: For God sente not hys sonne into the worlde, to condempne the worlde, but that the worlde through hym myght be saued.
column8: For God sent not his son into the world, to condemn the world, but that the world through him might be saved.

column7: He that beleueth on hym, is not condempned.
column8: He that believeth on him, is not condemned.

column7: But he that beleueth not, is condemned already, because he hath not beleued in the name of the only begotten sonne of God.
column8: But he that believeth not, is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten son of God.

column7: And thys is the condempnacion: that light is come into the worlde, and me loued darkenes more tha lyght bycause theyr dedes were euell.
column8: And this is the condemnation: that light is come into the world, and me loved darkness more than light because their deeds were evil.

column7: For euery one that euell doeth, hateth the lyght: neyther commeth to the lyght, lest hys dedes shuld be reproued.
column8: For every one that evil doth, hates the light: neither comes to the light, lest his deeds should be reproved.

column7: But he that doth trouth, commeth to the lyght, that hys dedes may be knowen, how that they are wrought in God.
column8: But he that does troth, comes to the light, that his deeds may be known, how that they are wrought in God.

column7: T He Gospell of thys daye, good people, is in very dede an Euangell or gospell that is to saye a glad tydinges.
column8: THe THe Gospel of this day, good people, is in very deed and Evangel or gospel that is to say a glad tidings.

column7: For in fewe wordes it declareth vnto vs the summe of the Christen mans religion.
column8: For in few words it declareth unto us the sum of the christian men religion.

column7: Fyrst therfore it sheweth the cause that moued God to sende downe hys sonne to the earth.
column8: Fyrst therefore it shows the cause that moved God to send down his son to the earth.

column7: The wordes here spoken be Christes wordes vnto Nicodemus.
column8: The words here spoken be Christes words unto Nicodemus.

column7: P A G Elxij Thus he sayeth: God so loued the worlde that he gaue hys only begotten sonne that who soeuer beleueth in hym shulde not perysh, but haue euerlasting lyfe. <NOTE> ye se that the cause whych moued God to sende Christe to redeme vs was loue and not mans meryte, as also saynt Austine noteth.
column8: PAGElxij PAGElxij PAGElxij PAGElxij Thus he sayeth: God so loved the world that he gave his only begotten son that who soever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life. you see that the cause which moved God to send Christe to redeem us was love and not men merit, as also saint Austine notes.

column7: And surely the dede selfe declared gods excedynge loue towardes vs in that he sent hys only sonne to delyuer vs out of bondage.
column8: And surely the deed self declared gods exceeding love towards us in that he sent his only son to deliver us out of bondage.

column7: For true loue standeth not in fayre wordes and amiable countenauce or gesture, but in the dede selfe.
column8: For true love stands not in fair words and amiable countenance or gesture, but in the deed self.

column7: Nowe the more mysery we were in before Christes commynge: the greater is his benefyte and the more bounde be we vnto hym.
column8: Now the more misery we were in before Christes coming: the greater is his benefit and the more bound be we unto him.

column7: God (as wryteth saynt Paule) setteth forth hys loue towardes vs, <NOTE> seyng that whyle we were yet synners, Christ dyed for vs. Now Christ hymselfe assureth vs that who so euer beleueth in hym thus sente of the father downe vnto vs, shall not quayle, shall not be confounded, shall not peryshe, but shalbe sure to attayne euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: God (as writes saint Paule) sets forth his love towards us, sing that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us Now Christ himself assureth us that who so ever believeth in him thus sent of the father down unto us, shall not quail, shall not be confounded, shall not perish, but shall sure to attain everlasting life.

column7: Seynge Christ hymselfe doth assure vs of euerlastynge lyfe for oure belefe or faythes sake, why shulde we doubt?
column8: Sing Christ himself does assure us of everlasting life for our belief or faiths sake, why should we doubt?

column7: Why shulde we go aboute to seke heauen by other wayes than Christ appointeth vs?
column8: Why should we go about to seek heaven by other ways than Christ appoints us?

column7: The sentece is vniuersall, all that beleue in him shall not perysh.
column8: The sentece is universal, all that believe in him shall not perish.

column7: Wherfore let noman thynke hymselfe exempted as vnworthy.
column8: Wherefore let noman think himself exempted as unworthy.

column7: Here is no respect eyther to thy worthynes, or to thy vnworthynes.
column8: Here is no respect either to thy worthiness, or to thy unworthiness.

column7: Yf thou hast faith, thou shalt be sure to be of the chosen company.
column8: If thou hast faith, thou shalt be sure to be of the chosen company.

column7: Only take hede thou mockest not God, & dissemblest not before the face of the worlde, sayeng thou hast fayth, and haue it not in dede.
column8: Only take heed thou mockest not God, & dissemblest not before the face of the world, saying thou hast faith, and have it not in deed.

column7: Yf thou hast fayth in dede, thou must nedes brynge forth the frutes of fayth, thou canst not but declare thy faith wyth workes of charitie both to God & man, whom for God thou canst not but loue as thy natural brother.
column8: If thou hast faith in deed, thou must needs bring forth the fruits of faith, thou canst not but declare thy faith with works of charity both to God & man, whom for God thou canst not but love as thy natural brother.

column7: Yf thou beyst a good tree, thou muste nedes brynge forth good frute.
column8: If thou beyst a good tree, thou must needs bring forth good fruit.

column7: But a bad tre bryngeth forth bad frute. <NOTE> Christe goeth further and sayeth: For God sente not hys sonne into the worlde to condempne the worlde but to saue the worlde.
column8: But a bad tre bringeth forth bad fruit. Christe goes further and sayeth: For God sent not his son into the world to condemn the world but to save the world.

column7: Here ye se the fynall cause of Christes commynge whyche was to saue that was lost.
column8: Here you see the final cause of Christes coming which was to save that was lost.

column7: Howbeit thys texte is to be vnderstande of Christes fyrst commynge and of the tyme of grace, ye maye not vnderstande it of his seconde aduent or commynge whyche shalbe at the last daye, for tha he shal wythout fayle come to iuge accordynge to an other place where he sayeth. <NOTE> The father hath gyuen all iudgement to the sonne.
column8: Howbeit this text is to be understand of Christes fyrst coming and of the time of grace, you may not understand it of his seconde advent or coming which shall at the last day, for than he shall without fail come to judge according to and other place where he sayeth. The father hath given all judgement to the son.

column7: Neuerthelesse in the meane season whosoeuer beleueth not is already iudged and condempned, wheras on the contrarye parte they that beleue can in no wyse be condempned.
column8: Nevertheless in the mean season whosoever believeth not is already judged and condemned, whereas on the contrary part they that believe can in no wise be condemned.

column7: But why is the infidele alreadye condempned?
column8: But why is the infidel already condemned?

column7: Bycause (sayeth Christe) he hath not beleued in the name of the onely begotten sonne of god.
column8: Because (sayeth Christe) he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten son of god.

column7: Lo here ye se agayne how fayth saueth, & lacke of fayth condempneth.
column8: Lo here you see again how faith saveth, & lack of faith condemneth.

column7: And thys is the condempnacion that lyght is come into the worlde, and men loued darkenes more then lyght, bycause theyr dedes were euyl.
column8: And this is the condemnation that light is come into the world, and men loved darkness more then light, because their deeds were evil.

column7: Who is thys lyght?
column8: Who is this light?

column7: Christ.
column8: Christ.

column7: Who is ye darkenes? <NOTE> The worlde.
column8: Who is the darkness? The world.

column7: The lyght then shyned in ye darkenes, and the darknes dyd not comprehende it.
column8: The light then shined in the darkness, and the darkness did not comprehend it.

column7: Do not men loue styll darkenes more then lyghte?
column8: Do not men love still darkness more then light?

column7: Had they not rather walke in theyr owne fanseys & wylworkes P A G Elxiij then in Christes doctrine?
column8: Had they not rather walk in their own fanseys & wylworkes PAGElxiij PAGElxiij PAGElxiij PAGElxiij then in Christes doctrine?

column7: Alacke for pytie.
column8: Alack for pity.

column7: Yea though the lyght neuer so much shyne, though the Gospell be neuer so much in the hande, yf Christ by hys holy spirite do not teache the, thou arte styll but darkenes, and why so? for thou louest styll darkenes better than the lyght, for thy dedes are euell, and therfore thou muste nedes conuince and damne thy selfe of infidelitie.
column8: Yea though the light never so much shine, though the Gospel be never so much in the hand, if Christ by his holy spirit do not teach thee, thou art still but darkness, and why so? for thou love still darkness better than the light, for thy deeds are evil, and therefore thou must needs convince and damn thy self of infidelity.

column7: It foloweth.
column8: It followeth.

column7: For euery one that doth euell hateth ye lyght, neyther woll he come to the lyght that is to saye to Christ and hys worde lest the bryghtnes of the lyght shuld reproue his dedes.
column8: For every one that does evil hates you light, neither will he come to the light that is to say to Christ and his word lest the brightness of the light should reprove his deeds.

column7: Thys is the cause (good people) why these papistes are so loth that the scripture of God shulde be redde of you laye people, lest ye myght happen to espye theyr hypocrisie and crafty iugelynge agaynste Christ and hys trouth.
column8: This is the cause (good people) why these papists are so loath that the scripture of God should be red of you say people, lest you might happen to espy their hypocrisy and crafty iugelynge against Christ and his troth.

column7: For scripture is the rule or touchstone wherby ye maye easely trye and discerne the chaffe from the corne, the chalke from chese, that is to saye, hypocrisye from true religion.
column8: For scripture is the rule or touchstone whereby you may easily try and discern the chaff from the corn, the chalk from cheese, that is to say, hypocrisy from true religion.

column7: They haue (good people) longe holden you in ignoraunce and in blyndenes to auaunce them selues and to raygne lyke kynges ouer you, contrary both to gods lawe and mans lawe.
column8: They have (good people) long held you in ignorance and in blindness to advance them selves and to reign like kings over you, contrary both to gods law and men law.

column7: Wherfore I blame them the lesse though they hate scripture, whych discloseth theyr hypocrisie and vsurped authoritie, lest (as Christe here sayeth) theyr dedes shulde be rebuked and reproued.
column8: Wherefore I blame them the less though they hate scripture, which discloseth their hypocrisy and usurped authority, lest (as Christe here sayeth) their deeds should be rebuked and reproved.

column7: But he (sayeth Christe) that doeth trouth, cometh to the lyghte, that hys dedes may be knowen, bycause they are wrought in God, as who shuld saye.
column8: But he (sayeth Christe) that doth troth, comes to the light, that his deeds may be known, because they are wrought in God, as who should say.

column7: He that is iustifyed & declared a good person by hys fayth whych he hath in me & for declaracion therof doth the truth that my worde moueth hym to do, and worketh not after hys owne fasey, thys man commeth to the lyght, that is to wyt, he gladly suffreth hys workes and procedynges to be tryed and examined by the rule of my worde, bycause they be done in God and be godly workes.
column8: He that is justified & declared a good person by his faith which he hath in me & for declaration thereof does the truth that my word moves him to do, and works not after his own fasey, this man comes to the light, that is to wit, he gladly suffers his works and proceedings to be tried and examined by the rule of my word, because they be done in God and be godly works.

column7: Where as cotrary wyse the hypocrite doth so much abhorre from the iudgement of my worde, that he fleeth by all meanes he can from it, & woll suffre none other to loke vpon it. <NOTE> He woll neyther enter into the kyngdome of heauen hymselfe nor yet suffer others that wolde enter.
column8: Where as contrary wise the hypocrite does so much abhor from the judgement of my word, that he fleeth by all means he can from it, & will suffer none other to look upon it. He will neither enter into the kingdom of heaven himself nor yet suffer others that would enter.

column7: Such persons vnder pretence of holynes haue longe shut vp the kyngdome of heaue from many men.
column8: Such persons under pretence of holiness have long shut up the kingdom of heave from many men.

column7: But now thanked be God ye lyght hath somwhat shone agayne.
column8: But now thanked be God you light hath somewhat shone again.

column7: Wherfore good people let vs not hate thys lyght and loue darknes styl as we haue done in tymes past, whan we were deceyued by the iuglynges of these papistes.
column8: Wherefore good people let us not hate this light and love darkness still as we have done in times past, when we were deceived by the jugglings of these papists.

column7: Let vs beleue in thys Christe sente downe from the father of heauen to redeme vs. And yf gods worde be true we shall surely be saued and raygne wyth hym in heauen, worlde wythout ende.
column8: Let us believe in this Christe sent down from the father of heaven to redeem us And if gods word be true we shall surely be saved and reign with him in heaven, world without end.

column7: &c.: homily The Epistle on the thyrde daye of Pentecost.
column8: etc.: homily The Epistle on the thyrde day of Pentecost.

column7: The.viij. chapter of the Actes.
column8: The viij chapter of the Acts.

column7: Thargument Peter & Ihon be sent into Samaria, where after baptisme the Samaritanes receyued the holy goost.
column8: Thargument Peter & Ihon be sent into Samaria, where after baptism the Samaritanes received the holy ghost.

column7: W Hen the Apostles whyche were at Ierusalem hearde say, that Samaria hadde receyued the word of god, they sent vnto them Peter and Ihon Whyche when they were come downe, prayed for P A G Elxv them, that they myght receaue the holy goost.
column8: WHen WHen the Apostles which were at Jerusalem heard say, that Samaria had received the word of god, they sent unto them Peter and Ihon Which when they were come down, prayed for PAGElxv PAGElxv PAGElxv PAGElxv them, that they might receive the holy ghost.

column7: For as yet he was come on none of them: but they were baptysed onely in the name of Christe Iesu.
column8: For as yet he was come on none of them: but they were baptised only in the name of Christe Jesu.

column7: Then layed they theyr handes on them, and they receaued the holy gooste.
column8: Then laid they their hands on them, and they received the holy ghost.

column7: T Hys lesson (good people) is taken forth of the eyght chapter of the Actes of thapostles, for a more perfyte vnderstandynge wherof, ye shal know that in the selfe chapter a lytle before it is shewed, how S. Philip thapostle entered into a cytie of Samaria and preached there to the Samaritanes the glad tydinges of our Sauiour Christ Iesu, how he beynge the sonne of God came downe for the redepcion of mankynde.
column8: This This lesson (good people) is taken forth of the eyght chapter of the Acts of apostles, for a more perfect understanding whereof, you shall know that in the self chapter a little before it is showed, how S. Philip apostle entered into a city of Samaria and preached there to the Samaritanes the glad tidings of our Saviour Christ Jesu, how he being the son of God came down for the redepcion of mankind.

column7: Thys his preachynge he dyd also confirme wyth myracles.
column8: This his preaching he did also confirm with miracles.

column7: For (as the texte also declareth) the vncleane spirites cryenge wyth loude voyce came out of many that were possessed of them And many take wyth palfeis and many that halted were healed.
column8: For (as the text also declareth) the unclean spirits crying with loud voice came out of many that were possessed of them And many take with palfeis and many that halted were healed.

column7: Now the people gaue great hede to the thynges whych Philip spake.
column8: Now the people gave great heed to the things which Philip spoke.

column7: And assone as they gaue credence to Philips preachynge of the kyngdome of God and of the name of Iesu Christe, they were baptised both me and wemen.
column8: And assoon as they gave credence to Philips preaching of the kingdom of God and of the name of Jesu Christe, they were baptised both me and women.

column7: Here ye se (good people) how the Samaritanes whych were Hethen persons yea and such persons as the Iues whyche were the peculiar and proper people of god toke for very contempte and vyle persons, receyued the gospell of Christ forthwyth at the preachynge of saynt Philip and were by and by baptised.
column8: Here you see (good people) how the Samaritanes which were Heathen persons yea and such persons as the Iues which were the peculiar and proper people of god took for very contempt and vile persons, received the gospel of Christ forthwith at the preaching of saint Philip and were by and by baptised.

column7: Thus farforth are the Samaritanes brought.
column8: Thus farforth are the Samaritanes brought.

column7: Now the lection red in the church thys day goeth further and sayth, that when the Apostles whyche were gathered togyther at Ierusalem herde say that the Samaritanes had receyued the worde of God, they sent vnto the Peter and Iohn, whiche when they were come downe from the hyghe cytie of Ierusalem thyther vnto the they prayed for them, to thintent they myght receiue the holy ghoste.
column8: Now the lection read in the church this day goes further and say, that when the Apostles which were gathered together at Jerusalem herd say that the Samaritanes had received the word of God, they sent unto the Peter and John, which when they were come down from the high city of Jerusalem thither unto thee they prayed for them, to intent they might receive the holy ghost.

column7: For as yet the holy ghoste was not come on none of the, onlye they were baptized in the name of Christ Iesu.
column8: For as yet the holy ghost was not come on none of thee, only they were baptised in the name of Christ Jesu.

column7: Tha layde these two Apostles theyr handes vpon ye Samaritans, and anone they receyued the holy ghost.
column8: Than laid these two Apostles their hands upon the Samaritans, and anon they received the holy ghost.

column7: This is the history redde in the church as thys daye.
column8: This is the history red in the church as this day.

column7: But now my frendes what frute and profyte shal we beare away of this lesson?
column8: But now my friends what fruit and profit shall we bear away of this lesson?

column7: What is here to be gathered?
column8: What is here to be gathered?

column7: Nothyng?
column8: Nothing?

column7: Yes truly for there is nothynge wrytten, <NOTE> sayeth S. Paule: but it is wryten for our learnynge, that by pacience and confort of scriptures we shuld haue hope. <NOTE> therfore ye shall note howe glad the Apostles were to heare, that these Samaritans were turned to the Gospell of Christe, and they were not only glad, but also carefull for them, lest they myght happen to go backe agayne to theyr olde baguage and blyndnes.
column8: Yes truly for there is nothing written, sayeth S. Paule: but it is written for our learning, that by patience and comfort of scriptures we should have hope. therefore you shall note how glad the Apostles were to hear, that these Samaritans were turned to the Gospel of Christe, and they were not only glad, but also careful for them, lest they might happen to go back again to their old baguage and blindness.

column7: And therfore in all hast they sent these two Apostles Peter and Iohn to confirme and strengthen theyr faith.
column8: And therefore in all haste they sent these two Apostles Peter and John to confirm and strengthen their faith.

column7: Here we be taught what ye office of true & good Apostles, yea of all good Christen men is.
column8: Here we be taught what you office of true & good Apostles, yea of all good christian men is.

column7: For we ought in lykewyse to be carefull for oure brethren yt they maye be broughte to the perfeyte knowlege of gods worde.
column8: For we ought in likewise to be careful for our brothers that they may be brought to the perfeyte knowledge of gods word.

column7: And namely suche as call them selfes Apostolicall persons and Apostles fellowes & successours (as the byshoppes of Rome do) oughte in this behalfe to folow thexeple of thapostles charite.
column8: And namely such as call them selves Apostolical persons and Apostles fellows & successors (as the bishops of Rome do) ought in this behalf to follow thexeple of apostles charity.

column7: P A G Elxv But they do cleane contrary, they rather plucke me from the Gospell, then allure them vnto it.
column8: PAGElxv PAGElxv PAGElxv PAGElxv But they do clean contrary, they rather pluck me from the Gospel, then allure them unto it.

column7: Seconde, ye shall note, that before the resurrection of Christe, when as yet the Iues and Gentyles were not ioyned togyther by all one fayth, <NOTE> the Apostels were forbydden to entre into the cyties of the Samaritanes.
column8: Seconde, you shall note, that before the resurrection of Christe, when as yet the Iues and Gentiles were not joined together by all one faith, the Apostles were forbidden to enter into the cities of the Samaritanes.

column7: But after the resurrection, whe they were bydden for the spredynge abrode of the gospell to go into all partes of the worlde, then that former commaundemente whiche was but temporall and whyche dyd serue but for a tyme, was taken awaye and cessed.
column8: But after the resurrection, when they were bidden for the spreading abroad of the gospel to go into all parts of the world, then that former commandment which was but temporal and which did serve but for a time, was taken away and cessed.

column7: Thyrdly, in this historye ye shall marke, that the Samaritanes receyued forthwyth the holy ghoste assone as they beleued and were baptized.
column8: Thyrdly, in this history you shall mark, that the Samaritanes received forthwith the holy ghost assoon as they believed and were baptised.

column7: For assuredly true and perfecte baptisme can not be without the holy ghost.
column8: For assuredly true and perfect baptism can not be without the holy ghost.

column7: Furthermore it is not possible that fayth can be in that person where the holy spirite of God dothe not inhabite, as many places aswell of scripture, as of auncient fathers do wytnesse.
column8: Furthermore it is not possible that faith can be in that person where the holy spirit of God doth not inhabit, as many places aswell of scripture, as of ancient father's do witness.

column7: Yea S. Austin affirmeth playnly in his boke, de presentia dei, <NOTE> that the holy ghost dothe dwell and inhabite in infauntes or childre yt be baptized.
column8: Yea S. Austin affirmeth plainly in his book, de presentia dei, that the holy ghost doth dwell and inhabit in infants or children that be baptised.

column7: Wherfore how muche more is he resident and abydynge in persons of age and discretion which haue fayth and be baptised?
column8: Wherefore how much more is he resident and abiding in persons of age and discretion which have faith and be baptised?

column7: So it is no doute, but these Samaritanes at the preachyng of S. Philip receiued the holy ghost, excepte perchaunce ye woll saye, that S. Philippes preachynge had lesse vertue and efficaciem it, then the preachynges of thother Apostles had, whyche in no wyse is to be graunted.
column8: So it is no doubt, but these Samaritanes at the preaching of S. Philip received the holy ghost, except perchance you will say, that S. Philippes preaching had less virtue and efficaciem it, then the preachings of tother Apostles had, which in no wise is to be granted.

column7: But peraduenture ye woll meruayle then, howe it is that it followeth in the historye red in the Churche this daye, that after the Samaritanes had receyued the worde of God, the holy Ghost as yet was not come on none of the.
column8: But peradventure you will marvel then, how it is that it follows in the history read in the Church this day, that after the Samaritanes had received the word of God, the holy Ghost as yet was not come on none of thee.

column7: And therfore the Apostles eue for that purpose sent Peter and Iohan, whiche prayed for them that they myght receyue the holy Ghoste.
column8: And therefore the Apostles eve for that purpose sent Peter and Johan, which prayed for them that they might receive the holy Ghost.

column7: My frendes, what shal we say to this?
column8: My friends, what shall we say to this?

column7: Dyd the Samaritanes receyue goddes worde, dyd they beleue, were they baptised, and yet were they voyde of the holy ghost?
column8: Did the Samaritanes receive gods word, did they believe, were they baptised, and yet were they void of the holy ghost?

column7: Howe ca this be?
column8: Howe ca this be?

column7: Chryste hym selfe sayeth, he that beleueth & is baptysed shall be saued. <NOTE> But onles a man be renued with the holy ghost, he can not be saued, as the same Chryst also testifyeth in the thyrde Chapter of Iohn.
column8: Chryste him self sayeth, he that believeth & is baptised shall be saved. But unless a man be renewed with the holy ghost, he can not be saved, as the same Chryst also testifieth in the thyrde Chapter of John.

column7: Wherfore it must nedes folowe that the Samaritaynes had receyued the holy ghost, forasmuch as true baptisme can not be without the holy Ghost Howe than sayth S. Luke here that the holy ghost was not yet come on the Samarytanes.
column8: Wherefore it must needs follow that the Samaritaynes had received the holy ghost, forasmuch as true baptism can not be without the holy Ghost How than say S. Lycia here that the holy ghost was not yet come on the Samarytanes.

column7: To this doubte I answere in fewe wordes, <NOTE> that this texte in this place that the holy Ghost was not yet come vpon them, is to be vnderstande not of the substauce of the spirite or holy Ghoste, <NOTE> of those manifest and notable gyftes of the holy Ghost.
column8: To this doubt I answer in few words, that this text in this place that the holy Ghost was not yet come upon them, is to be understand not of the substance of the spirit or holy Ghost, of those manifest and notable gifts of the holy Ghost.

column7: They had the holy Ghost to comforte them, and to lede them to al trueth necessary to their saluacion, but they had him not yet to do miracles and speake straunge tonges as in the primatyue Churche they had for the confirmacion of Christes doctrine.
column8: They had the holy Ghost to comfort them, and to lede them to all truth necessary to their salvation, but they had him not yet to do miracles and speak strange tongues as in the primatyue Church they had for the confirmation of Christes doctrine.

column7: Neyther is it at this day necessarye, the Gospell being nowe stablyshed, that men shuld haue suche wonderfull gyftes of the spirite.
column8: Neither is it at this day necessary, the Gospel being now established, that men should have such wonderful gifts of the spirit.

column7: Wherfore good chrysten people I exhorte you, P A G Elxvi and in the name of Christ I requyre you, that accordynge to the exemple of these Samaritanes here, ye wol laye downe your supersticion and blyndnes of harte, wherin ye haue wandered, and wyth glad mindes receyue the worde of God, accordynge to youre profession and promyse whych ye made at the fount stone, and put on Christ, renouncynge ye worlde, the flesh, and the deuell wyth stedfast and earnest fayth.
column8: Wherefore good christen people I exhort you, PAGElxvi PAGElxvi PAGElxvi PAGElxvi and in the name of Christ I require you, that according to the exemple of these Samaritanes here, you will say down your superstition and blindness of heart, wherein you have wandered, and with glad minds receive the word of God, according to your profession and promise which you made at the fount stone, and put on Christ, renouncing the world, the flesh, and the devil with steadfast and earnest faith.

column7: And no doubt ye shalbe endowed wyth ye holy goost who in all your trouble and afflictions shall coforte you and directe you in youre waye to heauenwarde where is our dwellynge place prepared wyth the father, sonne, and holy goost.
column8: And no doubt you shall endowed with you holy ghost who in all your trouble and afflictions shall coforte you and direct you in your way to heauenwarde where is our dwelling place prepared with the father, son, and holy ghost.

column7: To whome be all glorye wythout ende.
column8: To whom be all glory without end.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The gospell on the thyrde daye of Pentecost.
column8: : homily The gospel on the thyrde day of Pentecost.

column7: The.x. chapter of Ihon. Thargument.
column8: The x chapter of Jhon. Thargument.

column7: Christ is the true shepeherde.
column8: Christ is the true shepherd.

column7: I Esus sayd vnto hys disciples.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples.

column7: Verely verely I say vnto you: he that entreth not in by the dore into the shepefolde, but clymmeth vp some other way, the same is a thefe and a murtherer.
column8: Verily verily I say unto you: he that entereth not in by the door into the shepefolde, but clymmeth up some other way, the same is a thief and a murderer.

column7: But he that entereth in by the dore, is the shepherd of the shepe: to hym the porter openeth, and the shepe heare his voyce, and he calleth his owne shepe by name, and he leadeth them out.
column8: But he that entereth in by the door, is the shepherd of the sheep: to him the porter openeth, and the sheep hear his voice, and he calls his own sheep by name, and he leads them out.

column7: And whan he hath sent forth hys owne shepe, he goeth before the and the shepe folowe hym, for they knowe hys voyce.
column8: And when he hath sent forth his own sheep, he goes before thee and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.

column7: A straunger wyll they not folowe, but wyll flee from hym: for they knowe not the voyce of straungers.
column8: A stranger will they not follow, but will flee from him: for they know not the voice of strangers.

column7: Thys prouerbe spake Iesus vnto them, but they vnderstode not what thynges they were whych he spake vnto them.
column8: This proverb spoke Jesus unto them, but they understood not what things they were which he spoke unto them.

column7: Than sayd Iesus vnto them againe: Verely, verely, I saye vnto you: I am the dore of the shepe.
column8: Than said Jesus unto them again: Verily, verily, I say unto you: I am the door of the sheep.

column7: Al (euen as many as came before me) are theues and murtherers: but the shepe dyd not heare them.
column8: All (even as many as came before me) are thieves and murderers: but the sheep did not hear them.

column7: I am the dore: by me yf any man enter in, he shalbe safe, and shall go in and out, and fynde pasture.
column8: I am the door: by me if any man enter in, he shall safe, and shall go in and out, and find pasture.

column7: A thefe commeth not but for to steale, kyll, and to destroye.
column8: A thief comes not but for to steal, kill, and to destroy.

column7: I am come that they myght haue lyfe, and that they might haue it more aboudautly
column8: I am come that they might have life, and that they might have it more aboudautly

column7: IN the Gospell of thys daye (deare frendes) our sauiour Christ declareth hys owne propertie or office and he setteth out vnto vs the excedynge loue and kyndnes whyche he beareth to mankynde by a very proper and feate parable or similitude, whereby he resembleth hymselfe to a good shepeherde, and the false preachers or prelates to theues and murtherers.
column8: IN the Gospel of this day (deer friends) our saviour Christ declareth his own property or office and he sets out unto us the exceeding love and kindness which he bears to mankind by a very proper and feat parable or similitude, whereby he resembles himself to a good shepherd, and the false preachers or prelates to thieves and murderers.

column7: Certaynly all false doctours, all false prophetes, all proude pharisees that woll iustifye them selues by theyr owne workes and all hypocrites be here wonderfully touched.
column8: Certainly all false doctors, all false prophets, all proud pharisees that will justify them selves by their own works and all hypocrites be here wonderfully touched.

column7: And why?
column8: And why?

column7: Bycause they entre not into the shepefolde by the dore, but clyme vp an other waye.
column8: Because they enter not into the shepefolde by the door, but climb up and other way.

column7: What call ye clymmynge vp an other waye?
column8: What call you clymmynge up and other way?

column7: Surely it is to seke forgyuenes of thy synnes, ryghtuousmakynge, and euerlastynge lyfe by other meanes then Christ (whych is the waye, <NOTE> the trouth, and the lyfe) hath taught.
column8: Surely it is to seek forgiveness of thy sins, ryghtuousmakynge, and everlasting life by other means then Christ (which is the way, the troth, and the life) hath taught.

column7: Wherfore yf thou enterest not in by the dore, that is to saye by Christe, but an other way, I meane, yf thou wylt iustifie thy selfe and promyse thy selfe soule helth, bearynge thy P A G Elxvij self bold of thyn own proper workes, & not cleauing to the mercy of God (accordynge to thexemple of the publicane) nor dependynge vpon the merytes of Christes passion, art thou not, trowest thou, by Christes owne iudgement and sentence here, a thefe and a murtherer?
column8: Wherefore if thou enterest not in by the door, that is to say by Christe, but and other way, I mean, if thou wilt justify thy self and promise thy self soul health, bearing thy PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij self bold of thine own proper works, & not cleaving to the mercy of God (according to thexemple of the publican) nor depending upon the merits of Christes passion, art thou not, trowest thou, by Christes own judgement and sentence here, a thief and a murderer?

column7: But what a greate thefe art yu yf thou also teachest other folke to thynke ye same that thou doest?
column8: But what a great thief art thou if thou also teachest other folk to think you same that thou dost?

column7: By me, sayeth Christ, he that entereth in, shal be saued.
column8: By me, sayeth Christ, he that entereth in, shall be saved.

column7: But what is thys shepefolde that he speaketh here of? surely the shepefolde is the church, it is the congregacion and assemble of Christen people.
column8: But what is this shepefolde that he speaks here of? surely the shepefolde is the church, it is the congregation and assemble of christian people.

column7: He that wol entre into thys congregacion, into this church, into the holy communion and felowship of christen persons any other wayes than by Christ, he is a thefe and no christian person.
column8: He that will entre into this congregation, into this church, into the holy communion and fellowship of christian persons any other ways than by Christ, he is a thief and no christian person.

column7: He that also woll teache any other doctrine in Christes churche than such as Christ hath taught, is no pastoure, no bysshop, no true shepeherde, but a thefe rather, a murtherer, a wolfe.
column8: He that also will teach any other doctrine in Christes church than such as Christ hath taught, is no pasture, no bishop, no true shepherd, but a thief rather, a murderer, a wolf.

column7: And it is much to be feared, lest there be at thys daye many mo wolues and theues, than be true herdmen & feders.
column8: And it is much to be feared, lest there be at this day many more wolves and thieves, than be true herdsmen & feeders.

column7: I saye I am sore afrayed lest the prophecye of saynt Paule be yet styll veryfyed & in force in christendome.
column8: I say I am soar afraid lest the prophecy of saint Paule be yet still verified & in force in christendome.

column7: For whan S. Paule shulde departe from Ephesus, <NOTE> and knewe by the spirite of God, that his death approched, he called together the prestes or elders of the congregacion and amonges other wordes he sayth thus.
column8: For when S. Paule should depart from Ephesus, and knew by the spirit of God, that his death approached, he called together the priests or elders of the congregation and among other words he say thus.

column7: Take hede vnto your selues and to all the flocke wherin the holy goost hath made you byshops that is to saye ouerseers, to fede or guyde after the maner of good shepeherdes the church of God, whych he hath purchased wyth hys owne bloude.
column8: Take heed unto your selves and to all the flock wherein the holy ghost hath made you bishops that is to say overseers, to fede or guide after the manner of good shepherds the church of God, which he hath purchased with his own blood.

column7: For I am sure of thys, that after my departynge shal greuouse wolues enter in amonges you, not sparynge the flocke.
column8: For I am sure of this, that after my departing shall grievous wolves enter in among you, not sparing the flock.

column7: But who is the porter of thys shepefolde whych openeth ye dore to the good & faythful shepeherde of Christes flock?
column8: But who is the porter of this shepefolde which openeth you door to the good & faithful shepherd of Christes flock?

column7: Surely it is ye holy goost, <NOTE> he openeth vnto hym the scriptures of God, he leadeth hym into al trouth And hys shepe, that is to say, his paryshners, heare hys voyce, <NOTE> and he calleth hys owne shepe by name, accordynge also to the cousayle of Salomon in his prouerbes, where he sayeth: Se that thou know the nombre yf thy catell thy selfe, and loke well to thy flockes.
column8: Surely it is the holy ghost, he openeth unto him the scriptures of God, he leads him into all troth And his sheep, that is to say, his parishioners, hear his voice, and he calls his own sheep by name, according also to the cousayle of Salomon in his proverbs, where he sayeth: Se that thou know the number if thy cattle thy self, and look well to thy flocks.

column7: Moreouer thys good shepeherde, this good curate, thys byshop, thys ouerseer goeth before hys shepe and hys shepe folowe hym.
column8: Moreover this good shepherd, this good curate, this bishop, this overseer goes before his sheep and his sheep follow him.

column7: What is thys to saye?
column8: What is this to say?

column7: Truly he that is a good byshop, a good pastoure, and curate woll make himselfe comformable to hys doctrine, he wol leade them the waye, that by hys steppes and good exemple of lyuinge, they may walke in Christes groundes and pastures.
column8: Truly he that is a good bishop, a good pasture, and curate will make himself conformable to his doctrine, he will lead them the way, that by his steps and good exemple of living, they may walk in Christes grounds and pastures.

column7: He woll not playe the crabbe fysh whych wolde haue taught her doughter to go streyght, but wold not leade her the waye her selfe and teach her by her exemple how to go, as it is in Esopes fables.
column8: He will not play the crab fish which would have taught her daughter to go straight, but would not lead her the way her self and teach her by her exemple how to go, as it is in Esopes fables.

column7: I am afrayed we haue many crabbes.
column8: I am afraid we have many crabs.

column7: Saynt Paule wold haue a byshop yt is to saye an ouerseer or curate to gyue good exemple of lyuynge hymselfe and to haue a good & honest reporte of straungers, <NOTE> leste hys lyuynge be a slaunder to his doctrine.
column8: Saint Paule would have a bishop that is to say and overseer or curate to gyve good exemple of living himself and to have a good & honest report of strangers, lest his living be a slander to his doctrine.

column7: So doynge, hys shepe shal folowe hym, and shal knowe hys voyce.
column8: So doing, his sheep shall follow him, and shall know his voice.

column7: For assuredly, they that be godly persones woll knowlege none for theyr shepeherde, but such as teache gods worde True teachers of Christes Gospell be easely discerned P A G Elxvij of good christen men.
column8: For assuredly, they that be godly persons will knowledge none for their shepherd, but such as teach gods word True teachers of Christes Gospel be easily discerned PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij of good christian men.

column7: And agayne the good christen me be easely discerned and knowen of true preachers.
column8: And again the good christen me be easily discerned and known of true preachers.

column7: Thys prouerbe or parable nakedly and vnapplyed spake Iesus to hys disciples.
column8: This proverb or parable nakedly and unapplied spoke Jesus to his disciples.

column7: But they vnderstode not what thynges they were whyche he spake vnto them, and no maruayle.
column8: But they understood not what things they were which he spoke unto them, and no marvel.

column7: For (as saynt Paule sayeth) the flesh perceyueth not ye thynges yt be goostly.
column8: For (as saint Paule sayeth) the flesh perceiveth not you things that be ghostly.

column7: The disciples were as yet but carnall.
column8: The disciples were as yet but carnal.

column7: And therfore our Sauiour Christ lyke a good mayster declareth vnto them the meanynge of hys parable, & sayeth, that he hymselfe is the dore of the shepe, by hym who soeuer entreth in, shalbe saued and shal go in & out and fynde pasture, as who shulde saye, whether so euer he turneth hym, whyther so euer he casteth hys eyes, he shall fynde that shalbe for the behoufe and edificacion of hys flocke, brefley to speake, God shalbe wyth hym, the holy goost shall prompt hym and put hym in mynde of such thinges as he ought to teach hys paryshners and flocke that is commytted to hys charge.
column8: And therefore our Saviour Christ like a good master declareth unto them the meaning of his parable, & sayeth, that he himself is the door of the sheep, by him who soever entereth in, shall saved and shall go in & out and find pasture, as who should say, whither so ever he turns him, whither so ever he casts his eyes, he shall find that shall for the behoof and edification of his flock, brefley to speak, God shall with him, the holy ghost shall prompt him and put him in mind of such things as he ought to teach his parishioners and flock that is committed to his charge.

column7: But (sayeth Christe) as many as came before me are theues and murtherers, and the shepe dyd not heare them.
column8: But (sayeth Christe) as many as came before me are thieves and murderers, and the sheep did not hear them.

column7: Here doth our Sauioure Christ shewe vs the difference betwene the doctrine of the true preachers and the doctrine of heretikes, <NOTE> false prelates, & hypocrites.
column8: Here does our Saviour Christ show us the difference between the doctrine of the true preachers and the doctrine of heretics, false prelates, & hypocrites.

column7: Nowe, they go before Christ whych beare not Christ with them, and which woll seme wyser than Christ, as Peter dyd when he rebuked Christ bycause he sayd that he shulde suffer death.
column8: Now, they go before Christ which bear not Christ with them, and which will seem wiser than Christ, as Peter did when he rebuked Christ because he said that he should suffer death.

column7: And therfore Christe called hym Satan, <NOTE> and bad hym come after hym.
column8: And therefore Christe called him Satan, and bade him come after him.

column7: Wherfore marke the difference of Christ and of the false Apostles. <NOTE> Christe is the preacher of grace, the pseudapostles preach mas merytes. <NOTE> Christ is carefull for the fode of hys shepe, the false Apostles seke theyr owne lucre and gaynes Christ seketh the glorye of the father, the false Apostles steale from God hys glorye. <NOTE> Christe quyckeneth wyth hys worde, the false Apostles kyl mens soules wyth wycked doctrine.
column8: Wherefore mark the difference of Christ and of the false Apostles. Christe is the preacher of grace, the pseudapostles preach mass merits. Christ is careful for the food of his sheep, the false Apostles seek their own lucre and gains Christ seeketh the glory of the father, the false Apostles steal from God his glory. Christe quickeneth with his word, the false Apostles kill men's souls with wicked doctrine.

column7: For the thefe cometh not but to steale, to kyll, and to destroye.
column8: For the thief comes not but to steal, to kill, and to destroy.

column7: Hytherto I haue brefly and playnly declared the parable of the shepeherde.
column8: Hitherto I have briefly and plainly declared the parable of the shepherd.

column7: Now it shalbe your partes (good people) so to acquaynte youre selues wyth gods worde, that ye maye knowe the voyce of the shepeherde from the voyce of the thefe and murtherer accordinge to our Sauioure Christes wordes here.
column8: Now it shall your parts (good people) so to acquaint your selves with gods word, that you may know the voice of the shepherd from the voice of the thief and murderer according to our Saviour Christes words here.

column7: So doynge ye shall at laste be conducted to the moost swete & pleasaunt groundes of the lyuinge, and shall syt wyth Abraham, Isaac, and Iacob, and wyth the aungels in heauen, where ye shall se God face to face and haue fruicion of all ioye wyth God.
column8: So doing you shall at laste be conducted to the most sweet & pleasant grounds of the living, and shall fit with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and with the angels in heaven, where you shall see God face to face and have fruition of all joy with God.

column7: To whome be al honour and glorye worlde wythout ende.
column8: To whom be all honour and glory world without end.

column7: AMEN.
column8: AMEN.

column7: : homily P A G Elxvij The Epistle on the.iiij. daye of Pentecoste, that is to saye, on the wednesdaye in wytsonweke.
column8: : homily PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij The Epistle on the iiij day of Pentecoste, that is to say, on the wednesday in wytsonweke.

column7: The.ij. chapter of the Actes.
column8: The ij chapter of the Acts.

column7: Thargument The sermon of saynt Peter, conteynynge the prophecye of Iohel.
column8: Thargument The sermon of saint Peter, containing the prophecy of Johel.

column7: P Eter stepped forth wyth the eleuen, and lyft vp hys voyce, and sayd vnto them: Ye men of Iurye, and al ye that dwell at Ierusalem, be thys knowen vnto you, and wyth your eares heare my wordes.
column8: PEter PEter stepped forth with the eleuen, and lift up his voice, and said unto them: You men of Jury, and all you that dwell at Jerusalem, be this known unto you, and with your ears hear my words.

column7: For these are not droncken as ye suppose, seyng it is but the thyrde houre of the daye.
column8: For these are not drunken as you suppose, sing it is but the thyrde hour of the day.

column7: But thys is that whych was spoken by the prophete Iohel: And it shall be in the last dayes, sayeth God: of my spirite I wyll poure out vpon all fleshe.
column8: But this is that which was spoken by the prophet Johel: And it shall be in the last days, sayeth God: of my spirit I will pour out upon all flesh.

column7: And your sonnes and your daughters shall prophecye, and your yonge men shal se visions, and your olde me shall dreame dreames.
column8: And your sons and your daughters shall prophecy, and your young men shall see visions, and your old me shall dream dreams.

column7: And on my seruauntes, and on my hande maydens I wyll poure out of my spirite in those dayes, and they shall prophecye.
column8: And on my servants, and on my hand maidens I will pour out of my spirit in those days, and they shall prophecy.

column7: And I wyll shewe wonders in heauen aboue, and tokes in the earth beneth, bloude, and fyre, and the vapor of smoke.
column8: And I will show wonders in heaven above, and tokes in the earth beneath, blood, and fire, and the vapor of smoke.

column7: The Sonne shalbe torned into darckenes and the Mone into bloude, before that greate and notable daye of the Lord come.
column8: The Son shall turned into darkness and the Mone into blood, before that great and notable day of the Lord come.

column7: And it shall come to passe, that who soeuer shall call on the name of the Lorde, shalbe saued.
column8: And it shall come to pass, that who soever shall call on the name of the Lord, shall saved.

column7: IN the lesson of thys present daye (good Christen people) is conteyned the ryght godly sermon of ye holy Apostle saynt Peter, wherin he soberly, coldly, and lernedly maketh answere and defense to the vnreuerent talkynge and hurly burly of the people of all nations whyche when they herde Christes disciples speake wyth new tonges the great workes and wonders of god, were partly abashed and wondered therat, and partly gested vpon them and sayde they were dronken and full of newe wyne.
column8: IN the lesson of this present day (good christian people) is contained the right godly sermon of the holy Apostle saint Peter, wherein he soberly, coldly, and learnedly makes answer and defence to the unreverent talking and hurly burly of the people of all nations which when they herd Christes disciples speak with new tongues the great works and wonders of god, were partly abashed and wondered thereat, and partly gested upon them and said they were drunken and full of new wine.

column7: Saynt Peter therfore which of a fysherman is now become a great byshop and pastor ryseth vp, not alone yet, but the.xi. apostles standyng vp wyth him, leste (as Erasmus doth full well note) he myght be thought to vsurpe any tyrannye or raygne ouer hys felowes. <NOTE> He only spake ye wordes, but he spake them in the name of all hys felowes, euen as he alone dyd also before Christes passion in the name of al his felowes confesse Iesus Christ to be the sonne of the lyuynge God.
column8: Saint Peter therefore which of a fisherman is now become a great bishop and pastor riseth up, not alone yet, but the xi apostles standing up with him, lest (as Erasmus does full well note) he might be thought to usurp any tyranny or reign over his fellows. He only spoke you words, but he spoke them in the name of all his fellows, even as he alone did also before Christes passion in the name of all his fellows confess Jesus Christ to be the son of the living God.

column7: Who wolde haue thought that so simple a creature and that a fysherman shuld haue had suche audacitie ones to haue loked vpon so great a multitude.
column8: Who would have thought that so simple a creature and that a fisherman should have had such audacity ones to have looked upon so great a multitude.

column7: Oftentymes great Oratours when they brynge theyr oration that they haue longe studyed for before, to speke in a great audiece of people or before a great ruler, chauge colours, be astonyed & vtterly dismayed.
column8: Oftentimes great Orators when they bring their oration that they have long studied for before, to speak in a great audience of people or before a great ruler, chauge colours, be astonied & utterly dismayed.

column7: Truly thys was that heauenly drokennes whych they had caught of that heuenly cup wherof the prophete sayeth.
column8: Truly this was that heavenly drokennes which they had caught of that heavenly cup whereof the prophet sayeth.

column7: Calix meus inebrians q praeclarus est. Thys fysher man I saye stode before so great a multitude, he ioyned wt hym in comission the eleuen Apostles, not to ayde hym but to accompany hym, he fixed hys eyes vpon the people whych were vnknowen vnto hym, he lyfted vp hys voyce and wythout any premeditacion at al, he spake vnto P A G Elxviij them accordynge as the Lorde had commaunded hym to do.
column8: Calix meus inebrians q praeclarus est. This fisher man I say stood before so great a multitude, he joined with him in commission the eleuen Apostles, not to aid him but to accompany him, he fixed his eyes upon the people which were unknown unto him, he lifted up his voice and without any premeditation at all, he spoke unto PAGElxviij PAGElxviij PAGElxviij PAGElxviij them according as the Lord had commanded him to do.

column7: Neyther speaketh he for himselfe, but beynge the shepherde he defendeth the flocke, whyche thynge he doth not wyth humane craft or eloquece, but wt the ayde of holy scripture.
column8: Neither speaks he for himself, but being the shepherd he defendeth the flock, which thing he does not with humane craft or eloquence, but with the aid of holy scripture.

column7: Now ye hose multitude awayteth to heare what he woll saye.
column8: Now you hose multitude awaiteth to hear what he will say.

column7: Let vs also attende, for asmoche as these thynges be spoken to all.
column8: Let us also attend, for as as these things be spoken to all.

column7: Fyrst after he hadde ones wyth mouynge hys hande assuaged the murmuryng of the people, he beganne wyth such a proheme as myghte make them attente and desyrous to heare wythout any rhetoricall flattery at all.
column8: Fyrst after he had ones with moving his hand assuaged the murmuring of the people, he began with such a proem as might make them attent and desirous to hear without any rhetorical flattery at all.

column7: O ye men (sayeth he) of the Iuysh nation, <NOTE> whome it behoueth not to be ygnoraunte of the lawe and of the prophetes and namely you whych be inhabitautes of the cytie of Ierusalem where the heade of our religion and knowlege of the lawe is: Ye haue cause perchauce to wonder, but ye haue no cause to sklauder.
column8: Oh you men (sayeth he) of the Iuysh nation, whom it behooves not to be ygnoraunte of the law and of the prophets and namely you which be inhabitautes of the city of Jerusalem where the head of our religion and knowledge of the law is: You have cause perchance to wonder, but you have no cause to sklauder.

column7: Wherfore so many of you as be here, gyue attetiue eares a lytle whyle vnto me, and knowe ye matter as it lyeth.
column8: Wherefore so many of you as be here, gyve attetiue ears a little while unto me, and know you matter as it lies.

column7: For it stande you all vpon so to do.
column8: For it stand you all upon so to do.

column7: For these men of Galilie whome ye se here wyth me be not dronken nor full of new wyne, as some of you thinke, syth it is now mornynge & but ye thyrd houre fro the sonne rysynge, at whych tyme noma is wont to be dronke.
column8: For these men of Galilie whom you see here with me be not drunken nor full of new wine, as some of you think, sith it is now morning & but you thyrd hour from the son rising, at which time noma is wont to be drunk.

column7: But in these men ye se now the thynge accomplyshed whyche God longe ago promysed by Iohel hys prophete shulde come to passe.
column8: But in these men you see now the thing accomplished which God long ago promised by Johel his prophet should come to pass.

column7: Harken to the prophecye, and consyder whether the thynge be fulfylled or not.
column8: Harken to the prophecy, and consider whither the thing be fulfilled or not.

column7: Sklaunder not, bycause ye se a thynge vnwont, but receyue rather the grace whych almyghty god offereth vnto you. <NOTE> For Iohel beynge inspyred wyth the holy goost and seynge, that the tyme shulde come that God whych at sondry tymes before had imparted hys spirite to Moses and to many prophetes for your coforte and instruction wolde ones at laste whan hys onely begotten sonne shulde come, poure out moost plentefully the same spirite not vpon one or two (as hertofore) but vpon all nations of the worlde euen as many as wyth syncere fayth shulde receyue thys glad tydynges whyche at hys comaundement we brynge now vnto you: thus vttered the heuenly prophecye. <NOTE> It shal come to passe in the last dayes, sayeth the Lorde.
column8: Sklaunder not, because you see a thing unwont, but receive rather the grace which almighty god offereth unto you. For Johel being inspired with the holy ghost and sing, that the time should come that God which at sundry times before had imparted his spirit to Moses and to many prophets for your coforte and instruction would ones at laste when his only begotten son should come, pour out most plentefully the same spirit not upon one or two (as heretofore) but upon all nations of the world even as many as with sincere faith should receive this glad tidings which at his commandment we bring now unto you: thus uttered the heavenly prophecy. It shall come to pass in the last days, sayeth the Lord.

column7: I shal poure out plentefully of my spirite vpon all flesh, and sodenly your sones and your doughters shal prophecie and your yonge men shall se visions, and your olde persons shall dreame dreames.
column8: I shall pour out plentefully of my spirit upon all flesh, and suddenly your sons and your daughters shall prophecy and your young men shall see visions, and your old persons shall dream dreams.

column7: And truly vpon my seruautes & my handmaydens I shal poure out of my spirite and they shal prophecie.
column8: And truly upon my seruautes & my handmaidens I shall pour out of my spirit and they shall prophecy.

column7: And I shal gyue woders in heauen aboue, and tokens in earth beneth, bloude and fyre, & the vapoure of smoke.
column8: And I shall gyve woders in heaven above, and tokens in earth beneath, blood and fire, & the vapour of smoke.

column7: The sonne shalbe conuerted into darkenes and the moone into bloude, before that great and renowmed daye of the Lorde come.
column8: The son shall converted into darkness and the moon into blood, before that great and renowned day of the Lord come.

column7: And whosoeuer shall call on the name of the Lorde shalbe saued.
column8: And whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord shall saved.

column7: Thys my frendes hath ye prophete Iohel so longe ago prophecied vnto vs. And hetherto goeth the lesson of thys presente daye whych conteyneth the fyrst parte of S. Peters sermon.
column8: This my friends hath the prophet Johel so long ago prophesied unto us And hitherto goes the lesson of this present day which containeth the fyrst part of S. Peters sermon.

column7: Now as touchynge the fyrste parte of Iohels prophecie concernynge the sendynge downe of ye holy goost after such a plentyful sorte, the scripture teacheth vs that it was fulfylled aboute thys tyme of Pentecost, as in our sermons before we haue fully & P A G Elxix at large declared vnto you.
column8: Now as touching the fyrste part of Iohels prophecy concerning the sending down of you holy ghost after such a plentyful sort, the scripture teaches us that it was fulfilled about this time of Pentecost, as in our sermons before we have fully & PAGElxix PAGElxix PAGElxix PAGElxix at large declared unto you.

column7: And as for the rest of the prophecie concernynge the great calamitie and terrible tokens that shall come agaynste domes daye, there is no doubte but it shall come to passe, as oure sauiour Christ hath also certifyed vs. <NOTE> But my frendes let vs be nothynge dismayed nor troubled wyth the remembraunce of thys dradfull tyme, whych no doubt yet approcheth nere and shall steale vpon vs or euer we be ware, we knowe not how sone.
column8: And as for the rest of the prophecy concerning the great calamity and terrible tokens that shall come against domes day, there is no doubt but it shall come to pass, as our saviour Christ hath also certified us But my friends let us be nothing dismayed nor troubled with the remembrance of this dreadful time, which no doubt yet approaches never and shall steal upon us or ever we be aware, we know not how soon.

column7: Onely let vs do as the prophete teacheth vs here, & we shal not nede to feare.
column8: Only let us do as the prophet teaches us here, & we shall not need to fear.

column7: Let vs cal on the name of ye Lorde and we shalbe saued.
column8: Let us call on the name of you Lord and we shall saved.

column7: Let vs tha in al our aduersitie woo, and trouble, yea and also in our welth, prosperitie and felicitie remember God, loue God, prayse God, call on God with fayth.
column8: Let us than in all our adversity woo, and trouble, yea and also in our wealth, prosperity and felicity remember God, love God, praise God, call on God with faith.

column7: But let it be such faith as shall worke by charitie.
column8: But let it be such faith as shall work by charity.

column7: Let it be a lyuely fayth & no deade fayth, that maye brynge forth good workes.
column8: Let it be a lively faith & no dead faith, that may bring forth good works.

column7: Yf we thus do, we shall not nede to feare these terrible tokens, but we shalbe sure to be translated from thys myserye vnto immortall ioye wyth God.
column8: If we thus do, we shall not need to fear these terrible tokens, but we shall sure to be translated from this misery unto immortal joy with God.

column7: To whome.
column8: To whom.

column7: &c.: homily The Gospell on the.iiij. daye of Pentecost.
column8: etc.: homily The Gospel on the iiij day of Pentecost.

column7: The.vi. chapter of S. Ihon. Thargument.
column8: The vi chapter of S. Jhon. Thargument.

column7: Christ teacheth vs here yt onles we be renewed by the holy goost, we can not come vnto him.
column8: Christ teaches us hear that unless we be renewed by the holy ghost, we can not come unto him.

column7: I Esus sayd to hys disciples, and to the company of the Iewes.
column8: IEsus IEsus said to his disciples, and to the company of the Jewes.

column7: No man can come to me, excepte the father whych hath sent me, drawe hym: And I wyll rayse hym vp at the last daye.
column8: No man can come to me, except the father which hath sent me, draw him: And I will raise him up at the last day.

column7: It is wrytten in the prophetes: and they shalbe all taught of god.
column8: It is written in the prophets: and they shall all taught of god.

column7: Euery man therfore that hath herde, and hath learned of the father, cometh vnto me.
column8: Every man therefore that hath herd, and hath learned of the father, comes unto me.

column7: Not that any man hath sene the father, saue he whych is of god: the same hath sene the father.
column8: Not that any man hath seen the father, save he which is of god: the same hath seen the father.

column7: Verely, verely, I saye vnto you: he that putteth hys trust in me, hath euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: Verily, verily, I say unto you: he that putteth his trust in me, hath everlasting life.

column7: I am that bread of lyfe.
column8: I am that bred of life.

column7: Your fathers dyd eate Mana in the wyldernes and are dead.
column8: Your father's did eat Mana in the wilderness and are dead.

column7: This is that breade whych cometh downe fro heauen, that a man maye eate therof, and not dye.
column8: This is that bread which comes down from heaven, that a man may eat thereof, and not die.

column7: I am that lyuynge breade whych came downe from heauen.
column8: I am that living bread which came down from heaven.

column7: Yf any ma eate of thys bread, he shal lyue for euer.
column8: If any ma eat of this bred, he shall live for ever.

column7: And the breade that I wyll gyue, is my flesh which I wyll gyue for the lyfe of the worlde.
column8: And the bread that I will gyve, is my flesh which I will gyve for the life of the world.

column7: IN thys Gospell (good people) our sauiour Christ makynge answer to the murmourynge of ye people agaynst hym, bycause he sayd he was the breade of lyfe, and declarynge that theyr thoughtes coulde not be hyd from hym, expouneth and also fortifyeth the worde yt he spake, sayenge vnto them, yt they had no cause to murmoure amonges themselues of the thynge yt he spake.
column8: IN this Gospel (good people) our saviour Christ making answer to the murmuring of the people against him, because he said he was the bread of life, and declaring that their thoughts could not be hid from him, exponeth and also fortifyeth the word that he spoke, saying unto them, that they had no cause to murmoure among themselves of the thing that he spoke.

column7: For therfore hys worde dyd not synke into theyr myndes bycause of theyr mysbeleue Seynge, <NOTE> they saw not: and hearyng, they herde not: & beynge present they were absent.
column8: For therefore his word did not sink into their minds because of their mysbeleue Sing, they saw not: and hearing, they herd not: & being present they were absent.

column7: Whosoeuer commeth to Christ shall attayne euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: Whosoever comes to Christ shall attain everlasting life.

column7: But there is no waye to come vnto hym but by fayth.
column8: But there is no way to come unto him but by faith.

column7: Thys fayth is not lyghtly had, but cometh by the inspiracion of the father, who lyke as by ye sone he draweth mens myndes vnto hym: so wt secrete inspiracions of fayth he draweth them to the sonne.
column8: This faith is not lightly had, but comes by the inspiration of the father, who like as by you soon he draws men's minds unto him: so with secret inspirations of faith he draws them to the son.

column7: He bestoweth P A G Elxx not so great a gyfte but to suche as be wyllynge & gredy. <NOTE> then shall meryte by hys prompte wyl & deuoute mynde to be drawen of ye father, the same shall attayne by Christ to euerlasting lyfe.
column8: He bestoweth PAGElxx PAGElxx PAGElxx PAGElxx not so great a gift but to such as be willing & greedy. then shall merit by his prompt will & devout mind to be drawn of the father, the same shall attain by Christ to everlasting life.

column7: For our sauiour Christ shall also rayse ye deade to lyfe agayne in ye last daye.
column8: For our saviour Christ shall also raise you dead to life again in you last day.

column7: A great thynge taketh he that beleueth Christ, but without the helpe of the heuely father, he can not do it.
column8: A great thing takes he that believeth Christ, but without the help of the heuely father, he can not do it.

column7: Yet neuertheles they are not excused bycause they be not drawen.
column8: Yet nevertheless they are not excused because they be not drawn.

column7: For the father as much as in hym is coueteth to drawe all.
column8: For the father as much as in him is covets to draw all.

column7: He yt is not drawe, is in fault himselfe, bycause he wt draweth hymselfe fro hym yt wolde drawe hym.
column8: He that is not draw, is in fault himself, because he with draws himself from him that would draw him.

column7: Humane thynges be lerned wt humane studye, but this heauenly lernynge is not perceyued, onles ye secrete inspiracion of the father maketh hym an apte & teachable harte.
column8: Humane things be learned with humane study, but this heavenly learning is not perceived, unless you secret inspiration of the father makes him and apt & teachable heart.

column7: And this is it yt longe sythens was prophecied of the prophetes to come to passe. <NOTE> And they all shalbe taught of God. But the desyre of thys worlde do make many vnapt.
column8: And this is it that long sythens was prophesied of the prophets to come to pass. And they all shall taught of God. But the desire of this world do make many unapt.

column7: I say it is the gyft of god, but the indeuoure must be ours.
column8: I say it is the gift of god, but the endeavour must be ours.

column7: A ma heareth wt hys bodely eyen Christes wordes in vayne, onles he heare wtin fyrst ye secrete voyce of ye father, whych breatheth the mynde wt an insensible grace of fayth.
column8: A ma hears with his bodily eyes Christes words in vain, unless he hear within fyrst you secret voice of the father, which breathes the mind with and insensible grace of faith.

column7: For god is a spirite & is neyther herde nor sene, but of spiritual persons.
column8: For god is a spirit & is neither herd nor seen, but of spiritual persons.

column7: Many haue sene & herd Christ to theyr damnation.
column8: Many have seen & heard Christ to their damnation.

column7: And albeit the Iues boasted yt god was both sene & herde of Moses & of ye prophetes: yet no mortall ma euer sawe or herde god as he is.
column8: And albeit the Iues boasted that god was both seen & herd of Moses & of the prophets: yet no mortal ma ever saw or herd god as he is.

column7: For thys is only grauted to the sonne of ma oure sauiour Christ.
column8: For this is only grauted to the son of ma our saviour Christ.

column7: Let vs then shake of the care of this lyfe and not so moch seke for the bread whereby our bodyes be fedde, as thys breade whych giueth euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: Let us then shake of the care of this life and not so much seek for the bred whereby our bodies be fed, as this bread which gives everlasting life.

column7: We counte the olde fathers happye whych dyd eate Manna, yet thys Manna preserued them not from death, <NOTE> and why?
column8: We count the old father's happy which did eat Manna, yet this Manna preserved them not from death, and why?

column7: Not bycause Manna was euyll (sayeth saynte Austine) but because of theyr euyll eatyng.
column8: Not because Manna was evil (sayeth faint Austine) but because of their evil eating.

column7: Christe is the breade whych descendeth from heauen, whyche is signified by Manna.
column8: Christe is the bread which descendeth from heaven, which is signified by Manna.

column7: He that eateth of thys breade, shal lyue for euer.
column8: He that eateth of this bread, shall live for ever.

column7: But ye wol aske who thys is?
column8: But you will ask who this is?

column7: Saynt Austine answereth in thys wyse: <NOTE> He that is in ye vnitie of Christes bodye, that is to wytte, in the felowshipe of the christen mebres: the sacramete of whych body all faythfull persones be wonte to receyue, when they comunicate at the altare & come to gods borde, doth truly eate the bodye of Christe, and drynke the bloude of Christe.
column8: Saint Austine answereth in this wise: He that is in the unity of Christes body, that is to wit, in the felowshipe of the christian mebres: the sacramete of which body all faithful persons be wont to receive, when they communicate at the altar & come to gods board, does truly eat the body of Christe, and drink the blood of Christe.

column7: Nowe therfore let vs by all indeuours we ca, make ourselues mete and apte to receyue ye holye spirite of god, wherby we maye be drawen to Christ.
column8: Now therefore let us by all endeavours we ca, make ourselves meet and apt to receive you holy spirit of god, whereby we may be drawn to Christ.

column7: Let vs also take parte of hys passions, and folowe the couersation whych he had in hys fleshe. <NOTE> Whyche thynge (as S. Austine & others expoune thys place) is to eate hys fleshe and drynke hys bloude.
column8: Let us also take part of his passion, and follow the conversation which he had in his flesh. Which thing (as S. Austine & others expoune this place) is to eat his flesh and drink his blood.

column7: To whome wyth the father and holy goost be all glorye.
column8: To whom with the father and holy ghost be all glory.

column7: AMEN.
column8: AMEN.

column7: : homily P A G Elxvij The Epistle on Corpus Christi day.
column8: : homily PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij PAGElxvij The Epistle on Corpus Christi day.

column7: The fyrste epistle to the Corinthyans, the.xi. chapter.
column8: The fyrste epistle to the Corinthyans, the xi chapter.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: The institution of the most blessed sacrament of the Aulter is here by S. Paule described vnto vs.
column8: The institution of the most blessed sacrament of the Alter is here by S. Paule described unto us

column7: B Rethren, that which I deliuered vnto you I receyued of the lorde.
column8: BRethren BRethren, that which I delivered unto you I received of the lord.

column7: For the Lorde Iesus the same nyght in whych he was betrayed toke breade and when he had gyuen thakes he brake it and said.
column8: For the Lord Jesus the same night in which he was betrayed took bread and when he had given thakes he brake it and said.

column7: Take ye and eate, this is my body, whych is broken for you.
column8: Take you and eat, this is my body, which is broken for you.

column7: Thys do ye in the remembraunce of me.
column8: This do you in the remembrance of me.

column7: After the same maner also he toke the cup whe supper was done sayenge.
column8: After the same manner also he took the cup when supper was done saying.

column7: Thys cup is the newe Testament in my bloude.
column8: This cup is the new Testament in my blood.

column7: This do as oft as ye drynke it in remembraunce of me.
column8: This do as oft as you drink it in remembrance of me.

column7: For as oft as ye shal eate this bread and drinke this cup, ye shal shewe the lordes death tyl he come.
column8: For as oft as you shall eat this bred and drink this cup, you shall show the lords death till he come.

column7: Wherfore whosoeuer shall eate of thys breade and drynke of this cup vnworthyly shalbe gylty of the body and bloude of the lorde.
column8: Wherefore whosoever shall eat of this bread and drink of this cup unworthily shall guilty of the body and blood of the lord.

column7: But let a man examyne him selfe, and so let him eate of the breade and dryncke of the cup.
column8: But let a man examine him self, and so let him eat of the bread and drink of the cup.

column7: For he that eateth and drynketh vnworthely, eateth and drynketh hys owne damnation, because he maketh no difference of the lordes body.
column8: For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh his own damnation, because he makes no difference of the lords body.

column7: The exhortacion vpon this epistle ye shall fynd immediatly before the Epistle on Easter daye.
column8: The exhortation upon this epistle you shall find immediately before the Epistle on Easter day.

column7: The Gospell on Corpus Christi daye.
column8: The Gospel on Corpus Christi day.

column7: : homily The.vi chapiter of Iohn.
column8: : homily The vi chapter of John.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Christ is the true breade of lyfe.
column8: Christ is the true bread of life.

column7: I Esus sayde vnto his disciples and vnto the company of the Iues.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples and unto the company of the Iues.

column7: My fleshe is meate in dede, and my bloud is drinke in dede.
column8: My flesh is meat in deed, and my blood is drink in deed.

column7: He that eateth my flesh and drynketh my blod, dwelleth in me & I in hym.
column8: He that eateth my flesh and drinketh my blood, dwells in me & I in him.

column7: As the lyuing father hath sent me, and I lyue for the father: Euen so he that eateth me, shall lyue by the meanes of me.
column8: As the living father hath sent me, and I live for the father: Even so he that eateth me, shall live by the means of me.

column7: Thys is that breade, whiche came downe from heauen: not as your fathers dyd eate Manna, and are deade.
column8: This is that bread, which came down from heaven: not as your father's did eat Manna, and are dead.

column7: He that eateth of this bread, shall lyue euer.
column8: He that eateth of this bred, shall live ever.

column7: IN this present Gospel (good people) our sauiour Christ which is the true shepherd and feder of our soules goeth about to shake of fro oure myndes the fylthy cares of thys corporall life, willyng vs rather to apply our selfes and to labour wyth the gredy desire of the heuenly and gostly ryches, to obteyne euerlasting life.
column8: IN this present Gospel (good people) our saviour Christ which is the true shepherd and feder of our souls goes about to shake of from our minds the filthy cares of this corporal life, willing us rather to apply our selves and to labour with the greedy desire of the heavenly and ghostly riches, to obtain everlasting life.

column7: He biddeth vs caste out of our myndes the worldy breade wherwith our bodyes be fedde and couet that heuenly brede which giueth and conferreth vnto vs euerlastinge and immortall lyfe of the soule.
column8: He bids us cast out of our minds the worldy bread wherewith our bodies be fed and covet that heavenly breed which gives and conferreth unto us everlasting and immortal life of the soul.

column7: Thys breade is taken by faythe, and fayth is to be obteyned and gotten of almyghty god.
column8: This bread is taken by faith, and faith is to be obtained and got of almighty god.

column7: For it is vndoubtedly hys gyfte.
column8: For it is undoubtedly his gift.

column7: Whosoeuer therfore beleueth in Christe, he alredy hathe euerlastyng lyfe, inasmuche as he hath the foutayne of immortalitie.
column8: Whosoever therefore believeth in Christe, he already hath everlasting life, inasmuch as he hath the foutayne of immortality.

column7: I am (sayeth Christe) the breade of lyfe.
