column8: I am (sayeth Christe) the bread of life.

column7: As who shulde say.
column8: As who should say.

column7: I am that same fode whiche gyueth lyfe not only corporall, but rather the lyfe of the soule and eternall.
column8: I am that same food which gyveth life not only corporal, but rather the life of the soul and eternal.

column7: The Iues (amonges whom Christ was conuersaut, and vnto whom he had this comunicacion) bosted muche in the Manna, yt was sente downe from heauen vnto theyr auncestours.
column8: The Iues (among whom Christ was conuersaut, and unto whom he had this communication) boasted much in the Manna, that was sent down from heaven unto their ancestors.

column7: P A G Elxviij But what sayeth Christe vnto them?
column8: PAGElxviij PAGElxviij PAGElxviij PAGElxviij But what sayeth Christe unto them?

column7: Your fathers dyd eate Manna in the wyldernes, and dyed. <NOTE> Your fathers (sayeth S. Austine) bicause you be lyke them murmuryng fathers of murmuryng chyldren.
column8: Your father's did eat Manna in the wilderness, and died. Your father's (sayeth S. Austine) because you be like them murmuring father's of murmuring children.

column7: For assuredly this people in nothyng offended god more then in grutchyng and murmuryng agaynste God.
column8: For assuredly this people in nothing offended god more then in grutching and murmuring against God.

column7: Now they therfore dyed bicause they beleued (sayeth S. Austin) the thynge that they sawe, <NOTE> the thyng they sawe not, they beleued not nor yet vnderstode.
column8: Now they therefore died because they believed (sayeth S. Austin) the thing that they saw, the thing they saw not, they believed not nor yet understood.

column7: O sacramentum pietatis, o signum vnitatis, <NOTE> o vinculum charitatis.
column8: O sacramentum pietatis, o signum vnitatis, o vinculum charitatis.

column7: Qui vult viuere habet vnde viuat, accedat, credat, incorporetur, vt viuificet. O wonderfull sacrament of godlynes, o wonderfull token of vnitie, o wonderfull bond of charitie.
column8: Qui vult viuere habet vnde viuat, accedat, credat, incorporetur, vt viuificet. Oh wonderful sacrament of godliness, oh wonderful token of unity, oh wonderful bound of charity.

column7: He that wyl lyue he hath wherof he may lyue, let him drawe nigh let him beleue & let him be incorporated that he may be quickened.
column8: He that will live he hath whereof he may live, let him draw nigh let him believe & let him be incorporated that he may be quickened.

column7: Let him not departe for the frame of the membres, let him not be a rotten mebre worthy to be cut of, nor yet croked whereof he may be ashamed Let him be a fayre mebre, open, sounde & cleauing to the body.
column8: Let him not depart for the frame of the members, let him not be a rotten mebre worthy to be cut of, nor yet crooked whereof he may be ashamed Let him be a fair mebre, open, sound & cleaving to the body.

column7: Let him lyue to god.
column8: Let him live to god.

column7: Let him nowe labour in earthe, that he maye afterwarde lyue in heauen.
column8: Let him now labour in earth, that he may afterward live in heaven.

column7: The sacramet of this thing (saith this holy doctour) that is to saye, of the vnitie of the body and bloude of Christe, is taken at gods bourde of some men to their saluatio, and of some to their damnation. <NOTE> thynge it selfe is ordeined to the saluation of al men and to the destruction of none.
column8: The sacramet of this thing (says this holy doctor) that is to say, of the unity of the body and blood of Christe, is taken at gods board of some men to their saluatio, and of some to their damnation. thing it self is ordained to the salvation of all men and to the destruction of none.

column7: For my fleshe (sayeth Christe) is very meate, and my blode very dryncke.
column8: For my flesh (sayeth Christe) is very meat, and my blood very drink.

column7: Thys breade cam downe from heuen and hath an heuenly power of workynge gyuen it of god, that who so euer worthely do eate it, shall lyue eternally and neuer dye.
column8: This bread cam down from heaven and hath and heavenly power of working given it of god, that who so ever worthily do eat it, shall live eternally and never die.

column7: Wherfore good christen people, we haue no nede to demaunde from heuen any Manna sythe we haue the very heuenly breade in dede, that is to say, the body of our sauiour Christe ready vnto vs, to gyue vs euerlasting lyfe, if so be we wol take it worthely & with fayth.
column8: Wherefore good christian people, we have no need to demand from heaven any Manna sith we have the very heavenly bread in deed, that is to say, the body of our saviour Christe ready unto us, to gyve us everlasting life, if so be we will take it worthily & with faith.

column7: For vndoubtedly Christ is that heuenly breade whiche gyueth immortalitie to our soules, & whych for oure sakes was betrayed and crucifyed.
column8: For undoubtedly Christ is that heavenly bread which gyveth immortality to our souls, & which for our sakes was betrayed and crucified.

column7: He is the worde of god in whom who so euer stedfastly woll beleue, shall haue euerlasting lyfe.
column8: He is the word of god in whom who so ever steadfastly will believe, shall have everlasting life.

column7: Who so euer shall conuey thys heuenly breade into the bowels of his soule, shalbe nourished and growe vp to euerlastinge lyfe.
column8: Who so ever shall convey this heavenly bread into the bowels of his soul, shall nourished and grow up to everlasting life.

column7: For assuredly thys is the lyuely breade, whiche is descended downe from heuen, euen the moste preciouse body of our sauiour Christ whiche was betrayed and put to death to redeme the lyfe of the hole worlde.
column8: For assuredly this is the lively bread, which is descended down from heaven, even the most precious body of our saviour Christ which was betrayed and put to death to redeem the life of the hold world.

column7: Let vs beleue it, let vs take it & we shall lyue.
column8: Let us believe it, let us take it & we shall live.

column7: The mystery of this thing is right straunge and wonderfull to the world.
column8: The mystery of this thing is right strange and wonderful to the world.

column7: But suerly onles thou beest by faith ingrafted and incorporated into this mysticall body & stycke faste in the same (euen as a braunche doth in the vine tree) thou shalt haue no lyfe in the.
column8: But surely unless thou be'st by faith ingrafted and incorporated into this mystical body & stick fast in the same (even as a branch does in the vine tree) thou shalt have no life in thee.

column7: Let vs not (my frendes) murmoure wythin our selues as the Iues did, and say how can he gyue vs his fleshe to eate?
column8: Let us not (my friends) murmoure within our selves as the Iues did, and say how can he gyve us his flesh to eat?

column7: The Iues (saythe saynte Augustine) bycause they vnderstode not the breade of concorde: <NOTE> therfore they discorded, and fel at variaunce wythin themselues.
column8: The Iues (say faint Augustine) because they understood not the bread of concord: therefore they discorded, and fell at variance within themselves.

column7: But suerly they that eate this bread, do not stryue nor contende wythin themselues, for by thys most blessed and heuenly breade god maketh them to dwel in hys house in full vnitie and concorde togyther.
column8: But surely they that eat this bred, do not strive nor contend within themselves, for by this most blessed and heavenly bread god makes them to dwell in his house in full unity and concord together.

column7: Christ assureth vs, that onles we eate hys fleshe, and drynke hys P A G Elxix blode, we shall not haue lyfe in vs. <NOTE> But how shal we eate his fleshe and drynke his bloude?
column8: Christ assureth us, that unless we eat his flesh, and drink his PAGElxix PAGElxix PAGElxix PAGElxix blood, we shall not have life in us But how shall we eat his flesh and drink his blood?

column7: Truly (as all holy doctours expounde thys texte) we eate Christes fleshe and drynke his bloude, <NOTE> when we communicate and take parte of his passion, and swetly and profitably lay vp in our memory that hys fleshe was crucifyed and wounded & that his most precyouse blode was shed for vs. He that beleueth not thus in hym (sayth saynt Augustine) eateth not Christ, and therefore he hath not the Christen fayth, without whyche he can haue no pardon of hys synnes.
column8: Truly (as all holy doctors expound this text) we eat Christes flesh and drink his blood, when we communicate and take part of his passion, and sweetly and profitably lay up in our memory that his flesh was crucified and wounded & that his most precious blood was shed for us He that believeth not thus in him (say saint Augustine) eateth not Christ, and therefore he hath not the christian faith, without which he can have no pardon of his sins.

column7: Wherfore (my fredes) let vs dayly eate this heauely breade this Christ our louyng sauiour in spirite and by fayth.
column8: Wherefore (my fredes) let us daily eat this heavily bread this Christ our loving saviour in spirit and by faith.

column7: Let vs I saye take holde of him let vs apprehende him by fayth, let vs take the benefite and vse of his passion and resurrection, <NOTE> vs make him all ours.
column8: Let us I say take hold of him let us apprehend him by faith, let us take the benefit and use of his passion and resurrection, us make him all ours.

column7: Let vs suffre hym to entre into vs. Spiritually we ought dayly to receyue him.
column8: Let us suffer him to enter into us Spiritually we ought daily to receive him.

column7: But both spiritually and also sacramentally and corporally we must receiue him with most hyghe reuerece in forme of breade at suche tyme as the churche appoynteth, and namely at the feaste of Easter.
column8: But both spiritually and also sacramentally and corporally we must receive him with most high reverence in form of bread at such time as the church appointeth, and namely at the feast of Easter.

column7: I saye, when we come to the aultare of god, and to his holy borde, let vs take hede, that we worthely receyue in forme of breade his moste preciouse body, <NOTE> lest we take hym to our danacion, not discerning the lordes body.
column8: I say, when we come to the altar of god, and to his holy board, let us take heed, that we worthily receive in form of bread his most precious body, lest we take him to our danacion, not discerning the lords body.

column7: Which thyng we can not do without penauce, stedfast fayth and ful purpose of ameding our former lyfe.
column8: Which thing we can not do without penance, steadfast faith and full purpose of ameding our former life.

column7: Let vs fyrst or euer we approch to this blessid sacramet examine our selues by knowledging our sinnes against god, <NOTE> wherunto we shalbe brought by heryng & considering gods wyl declared in his lawes & perceiuing in our coscience ye god is displeased wt vs for ye same and therupon coceiuing not only greate sorowe, but also great feare of gods wrath towardes vs, cosidering we haue no worthy meritis to lay before god as sufficient satisfaction for our synnes, which done, we must coceiue sure hope & fayth yt god yet wyl forgiue vs our synnes not for our owne worthines but for ye only merites of his bloude & passion which fayth we shal cofirme by ye applieng of Christes promise coteined in his gospell & namely in ye institucyon of thys most blessed sacramet where it is sayde (giuen for the remissio of our synnes. <NOTE> <NOTE>) But to the atteining of this fayth, the seconde parte of penaunce, yt is to say, confession to the prest is necessary, <NOTE> inasmuch as the absolucion giue by him is ordeined of Christ to applie the promises of gods grace to vs, according to these textes. <NOTE> Whose synnes soeuer you forgiue shalbe forgiuen, whose synnes ye reteine, shalbe reteined.
column8: Let us fyrst or ever we approach to this blessed sacramet examine our selves by knowledging our sins against god, whereunto we shall brought by hearing & considering gods will declared in his laws & perceiving in our conscience you god is displeased with us for you same and thereupon coceiuing not only great sorrow, but also great fear of gods wrath towards us, considering we have no worthy meritis to lay before god as sufficient satisfaction for our sins, which done, we must coceiue sure hope & faith that god yet will forgive us our sins not for our own worthiness but for you only merits of his blood & passion which faith we shall cofirme by you applying of Christes promise coteined in his gospel & namely in the institution of this most blessed sacramet where it is said (given for the remissio of our sins.) But to the attaining of this faith, the seconde part of penance, that is to say, confession to the pressed is necessary, inasmuch as the absolution give by him is ordained of Christ to apply the promises of gods grace to us, according to these texts. Whose sins soever you forgive shall forgiven, whose sins you retain, shall retained.

column7: Also.
column8: Also.

column7: He that heareth you heareth me.
column8: He that hears you hears me.

column7: Finally being thus truly penitent cotrite & cofessed, we must also bryng forth ye frutes of penauce, <NOTE> as prayer, fasting & almes dede.
column8: Finally being thus truly penitent cotrite & cofessed, we must also bring forth you fruits of penance, as prayer, fasting & alms deed.

column7: We must also make restitucion or satisfaccion in wyl & dede to our neyghbours in yt we haue done them wrong.
column8: We must also make restitution or satisfaction in will & deed to our neighbours in that we have done them wrong.

column7: We must also do al other good workes of mercy & charitie & expresse our obedient wyl in fulfylling of gods comaudemet outwardly when tyme and occasion shalbe gyuen vs. Thus we shall examine our selues & so receyue this moste holy sacrament worthely.
column8: We must also do all other good works of mercy & charity & express our obedient will in fulfilling of gods comaudemet outwardly when time and occasion shall given us Thus we shall examine our selves & so receive this most holy sacrament worthily.

column7: Otherwyse we shal receiue our owne damnacion.
column8: Otherwise we shall receive our own damnation.

column7: Wherfore my fredes do as I haue here declared vnto you and ye shal receiue forgiuenes of your sinnes & at laste the croune of euerlasting lyfe.
column8: Wherefore my fredes do as I have here declared unto you and you shall receive forgiveness of your sins & at laste the crown of everlasting life.

column7: Vnto whiche.
column8: Unto which.

column7: &c.: homily P A G Elxx THE EPISTLE ON TRINITIE SONDAYE.
column8: etc.: homily PAGElxx PAGElxx PAGElxx PAGElxx THE EPISTLE ON TRINITIE SONDAYE.

column7: THE IIII. Chapter of the Apocalyps.
column8: THE IIII. Chapter of the Apocalyps.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Gods Maiestie is here described.
column8: Gods Majesty is here described.

column7: I Loked vp and sawe a dore open in heauen, and the fyrst voyce whych I herde was as it were of a trompet talkynge wyth me, whych sayd: come vp hyther and I wyll shewe the thynges, whych must be fulfylled herafter.
column8: I Looked up and saw a door open in heaven, and the fyrst voice which I herd was as it were of a trumpet talking with me, which said: come up hither and I will show the things, which must be fulfilled hereafter.

column7: And immediatly I was in the spirite and beholde a seate was set in heauen, and one sat on the seate.
column8: And immediately I was in the spirit and behold a seat was set in heaven, and one sat on the seat.

column7: And he that sat, was to loke vpo, lyke a Iaspar stone, and a Sardyne stone.
column8: And he that sat, was to look upon, like a Jasper stone, and a Sardyne stone.

column7: And there was a rayne bowe aboute the seate, in syght lyke to an Emeralde.
column8: And there was a rain bow about the seat, in sight like to and Emerald.

column7: And aboute the seate were.xxiiij. seates.
column8: And about the seat were xxiiij seats.

column7: And vpon the seates.xxiiij. Elders sytting, clothed in whyt rayment, and had on their heades crownes of golde.
column8: And upon the seats xxiiij Elders sitting, clothed in whyt raiment, and had on their heads crowns of gold.

column7: And out of the seate proceded lyghtenynges, and thundrynges, and voyces, and there were seuen lampes of fyre, burnynge before the seate, whych are the seuen spirites of God.
column8: And out of the seat proceeded lyghtenynges, and thundrynges, and voices, and there were seuen lamps of fire, burning before the seat, which are the seuen spirits of God.

column7: And before the seate there was a see of glasse, like vnto Crystal and in the myddes of the seate, and rounde aboute the seate were foure beastes ful of eyes before and behynde.
column8: And before the seat there was a see of glass, like unto Crystal and in the mids of the seat, and round about the seat were foure beasts full of eyes before and behind.

column7: And the fyrst beast was lyke a Lyon, and the seconde beast lyke a Calfe, and the thyrde beast had a face as a Man, and the fourth beast was lyke a flyenge Egle.
column8: And the fyrst beast was like a Lion, and the seconde beast like a Calf, and the thyrde beast had a face as a Man, and the fourth beast was like a flyenge Egle.

column7: And the foure beastes had eche one of them.vi. wynges about hym, and they were full of eyes wythin.
column8: And the foure beasts had eke one of them vi wings about him, and they were full of eyes within.

column7: And they had no rest daye neyther nyght, sayenge: Holy, holy, holy, Lorde God almyghty whych was, and is, and is to come.
column8: And they had no rest day neither night, saying: Holy, holy, holy, Lord God almighty which was, and is, and is to come.

column7: And whan those beastes gaue glorye and honoure, and thankes to hym that sat on the seate (whych lyueth for euer and euer) the.xxiiij. Elders fell downe before hym that satte on the trone and worshypped hym that lyueth for euer, and cast their crownes before the trone, sayenge: thou arte worthy o Lorde oure God to receyue glorye and honoure, and power, for thou hast created all thynges, and for thy wylles sake they are, and were created.
column8: And when those beasts gave glory and honour, and thanks to him that sat on the seat (which liveth for ever and ever) the xxiiij Elders fell down before him that sat on the throne and worshipped him that liveth for ever, and cast their crowns before the throne, saying: thou art worthy oh Lord our God to receive glory and honour, and power, for thou hast created all things, and for thy wills sake they are, and were created.

column7: G Ood people we be sure by scripture, that there is but one God.
column8: GOod GOod people we be sure by scripture, that there is but one God.

column7: For it sayth.
column8: For it say.

column7: Herken o Israel, thy god is one. <NOTE> But forasmuch as the scripture doth attribute godheade and diuine essencie to thre: therfore the fathers haue founde out the worde (person) for the auoydynge of many errours. <NOTE> And hereof for discernynge the sayd persons is the name of Trinitie come into the church, wherby we sygnifye not.iij. vnegall persons, but thre persons coequal of one in diuisible substaunce and essencie.
column8: Harken oh Israel, thy god is one. But forasmuch as the scripture does attribute godhead and divine essencie to thre: therefore the father's have found out the word (person) for the avoiding of many errors. And hereof for discerning the said persons is the name of Trinitie come into the church, whereby we sygnifye not iij unequal persons, but thre persons coequal of one in divisible substance and essencie.

column7: And as touchinge the vse of thys feast, oure predecessours thought it good, to haue some certayne tyme appoynted in the church, wherin they myght intreate of the offices of those thre persons egall in godheade.
column8: And as touching the use of this feast, our predecessors thought it good, to have some certain time appointed in the church, wherein they might entreat of the offices of those thre persons equal in godhead.

column7: And bycause the fourth chapter of the Apocalyps semeth to sette forth wonderfully well the maiestie of God and not obscurely to touche the mysterye of the Trinitie, the church of Englande condescended to haue the same red in the church thys daye, whych brefely, God wyllynge, we shal declare vnto you.
column8: And because the fourth chapter of the Apocalyps seemeth to set forth wonderfully well the majesty of God and not obscurely to touch the mystery of the Trinitie, the church of Englande condescended to have the same read in the church this day, which briefly, God willing, we shall declare unto you.

column7: Thus it beginneth After thys I loked, and beholde a dore open in heauen, and the fyrst voyce I herde, was as of a trope speakynge wyth me, sayenge: Come vp hither, and I shall shewe the what shalbe done herafter. Thys dore whych saynt Ihon sawe open, no doubte is the intraunce and commynge to the new and heauenly lyfe, whych Christe oure Sauioure hath made vs, as the Epistle to the Hebrues the.x. <NOTE> chapter wytnesseth.
column8: Thus it begins After this I looked, and behold a door open in heaven, and the fyrst voice I herd, was as of a trope speaking with me, saying: Come up hither, and I shall show the what shall done hereafter. This door which saint Ihon saw open, no doubt is the intrance and coming to the new and heavenly life, which Christe our Saviour hath made us, as the Epistle to the Hebrews the x chapter witnesseth.

column7: For our couersacion ought now to be in heaue.
column8: For our couersacion ought now to be in heave.

column7: And saynt Ihon doth here describe the Iudicial power of Christe gyuen hym of the heauenlye father wherewyth he defendeth hys churche from the power of the aduersaries.
column8: And saint Ihon does here describe the Judicial power of Christe given him of the heavenly father wherewith he defendeth his church from the power of the adversaries.

column7: And he sayeth: There was a seate set, and vpon it a sytter, wherby he sygnifyeth the stabilitie of Christes raygne.
column8: And he sayeth: There was a seat set, and upon it a sytter, whereby he signifieth the stability of Christes reign.

column7: For hys seate or trone is (as Dauid sayeth) worlde wythout ende.
column8: For his seat or throne is (as Dauid sayeth) world without end.

column7: And he that satte vpon thys glorious and princelye trone or seate was to loke vpon lyke a Iaspar stone and a Sardyne stone. <NOTE> By thys is vnderstanded nothynge els, but a certayne heauenly & royall bewty shewynge aswell the maiestye as the power most excellent of the iudge Christ.
column8: And he that sat upon this glorious and princely throne or seat was to look upon like a Jasper stone and a Sardyne stone. By this is understanded nothing else, but a certain heavenly & royal beauty show aswell the majesty as the power most excellent of the judge Christ.

column7: For the cloth of estate & royall seates of kynges be wont to be moost rychely decked and furnyshed for the settynge out of theyr Maiestye and authoritie.
column8: For the cloth of estate & royal seats of kings be wont to be most richly decked and furnished for the setting out of their Majesty and authority.

column7: Nowe, the Iaspar stone they saye beareth the semblaunce of water, and the Sardyn stone of fyer, wherby is vnderstanded that the Lorde is wont to make hys iudgementes in water and in fyer, as appeareth Gen. vij. and.xix. Exo. xiiij, and in the seconde Epistle of Peter the last chapiter and in many other places of scripture.
column8: Now, the Jasper stone they say bears the semblance of water, and the Sardyn stone of fire, whereby is understanded that the Lord is wont to make his judgements in water and in fire, as appears Gen. vij. and xix Exo. xiiij, and in the seconde Epistle of Peter the last chapter and in many other places of scripture.

column7: <NOTE> And a raynebowe was about the seat in syght lyke to an Emerald. The raynebowe is a token, that god the father is made at one wyth vs by Christ and reconciled to mankynde, <NOTE> as appeareth Gen. ix. Nowe the Emeralde they say is of such grenenes & vertue that it maketh all thynges aboute it to floryshe and growe. <NOTE> Euen so by Christ the world is renewed and it reflorysheth, as Lactantius doth very elegauntly and well declare in a certayne Hymne.
column8: And a raynebowe was about the seat in sight like to and Emerald. The raynebowe is a token, that god the father is made at one with us by Christ and reconciled to mankind, as appears Gen. ix. Now the Emerald they say is of such grenenes & virtue that it makes all things about it to flourish and grow. Even so by Christ the world is renewed and it reflorysheth, as Lactantius does very elegantly and well declare in a certain Hymn.

column7: And aboute the seate were.xxiiij. seates.
column8: And about the seat were xxiiij seats.

column7: And vpon the seates.xxiiij. elders syttynge, clothed in whyte raiment, and had on their heades crownes of gold Saint Ihon doth here allude to the maner of a realme well ordered, where kynges and princes whyche are to gyue sentence in maters of weyghte, woll not do it wythout the assistence of certayne auncient personages that haue good experience of thynges and knowlege of the best lawes, lest they myght seme to condempne any man of theyr owne priuate lust and pleasure.
column8: And upon the seats xxiiij elders sitting, clothed in white raiment, and had on their heads crowns of gold Saint Ihon does here allude to the manner of a realm well ordered, where kings and princes which are to gyve sentence in maters of weight, will not do it without the assistance of certain ancient personages that have good experience of things and knowledge of the best laws, lest they might seem to condemn any man of their own private lust and pleasure.

column7: Wherfore by this allusio he declareth that God is a moost iust iudge, whose sentence all iuste persons shal approue and prayse as moost ryghtful and true.
column8: Wherefore by this allusio he declareth that God is a most just judge, whose sentence all just persons shall approve and praise as most rightful and true.

column7: By the.xxiiij. elders ye shall vnderstande aswell the patriarches and prophetes of the olde synagoge, as the Apostles, Euangelistes, & doctours of the new Testament, <NOTE> and also the godly kynges & iuges of both peoples.
column8: By the xxiiij elders you shall understand aswell the patriarchs and prophets of the old synagogue, as the Apostles, Evangelists, & doctors of the new Testament, and also the godly kings & juges of both peoples.

column7: For they in scripture be called Elders.
column8: For they in scripture be called Elders.

column7: Now by the syttynge of these Elders is vnderstande the felowship of the iudiciall power wt P A G Elxxii Christ, accordynge to Christes owne sayenge.
column8: Now by the sitting of these Elders is understand the fellowship of the judicial power with PAGElxxii PAGElxxii PAGElxxii PAGElxxii Christ, according to Christes own saying.

column7: Mat. xix. Ye shall also syt vpon the.xij. seates, iudgynge ye xij. trybes. <NOTE> Also saynt Paule wytnesseth that saintes shall iudge of thys worlde.
column8: Mat. xix. You shall also fit upon the xij seats, judging you xij. tribes. Also saint Paule witnesseth that saints shall judge of this world.

column7: By theyr whyte garmentes or robes, wherewyth they were clothed, is sygnifyed purenes of mynde, innocencye, and indifferent iudgement wythout affection. <NOTE> By theyr crownes of golde vpon theyr heades I vnderstande the mooste pure sense of faith, wherby they shal iuge of al, accordynge to the arbitrement of God, so that what so euer they shall iuge vpon earth, shalbe ratifyed also in heauen, accordynge to that sayng of Christ, Mathew. xviii. What soeuer ye bynde on earth, shalbe bounde in heuen, and what soeuer ye louse on erth, the same shalbe loused in heauen.
column8: By their white garments or robes, wherewith they were clothed, is sygnifyed pureness of mind, innocency, and indifferent judgement without affection. By their crowns of gold upon their heads I understand the most pure sense of faith, whereby they shall judge of all, according to the arbitrement of God, so that what so ever they shall judge upon earth, shall ratified also in heaven, according to that saying of Christ, Mathew. xviii. What soever you bind on earth, shall bound in heaven, and what soever you louse on earth, the same shall loused in heaven.

column7: Furthermore they sygnifye the felowshyp of the victories and raygne of Christ, <NOTE> accordynge to that in the Epistle to the Hebrues.
column8: Furthermore they sygnifye the fellowship of the victories and reign of Christ, according to that in the Epistle to the Hebrews.

column7: The sayntes haue vaynquyshed realmes by fayth.
column8: The saints have vanquished realms by faith.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: And out of the seate proceded lyghtenynges, and thonderynges, and voyces.
column8: And out of the seat proceeded lyghtenynges, and thonderynges, and voices.

column7: And there were seuen lampes of fyre burnynge before the seate whyche are the seuen spirites of God. The preachynge of the Apostles and of men apostolical is compared to lyghtenynge and thondrynge, bycause by it is proclamed the fearfulnes of gods iudgementes the whych hange ouer the heades of infideles and such as beleue not.
column8: And there were seuen lamps of fire burning before the seat which are the seuen spirits of God. The preaching of the Apostles and of men apostolical is compared to lightning and thundering, because by it is proclaimed the fearfulness of gods judgements the which hang over the heads of infideles and such as believe not.

column7: By the.vii. lampes of fyre brennyng before the trone I vnderstande the septiforme spirite of God, that is to wyt, the fulnes and perfection of the heauenly graces wherwyth the kyngdome of Christ is furnyshed. <NOTE> It foloweth.
column8: By the vii lamps of fire brenning before the throne I understand the septiforme spirit of God, that is to wit, the fullness and perfection of the heavenly graces wherewith the kingdom of Christ is furnished. It followeth.

column7: And before the seate there was a see of glasse lyke vnto Crystall, and in the myddes of the seate and rounde about the seate were foure beastes full of eyes before and behynde.
column8: And before the seat there was a see of glass like unto Crystal, and in the mids of the seat and round about the seat were foure beasts full of eyes before and behind.

column7: &c. My frendes the calamities of thys worlde, wherwyth ye stynch of the fleshe is repourged and the naughtye affectes of the same vtterly mortifyed, muste nedes be passed ouer of vs, euen as it behoued the people of God to passe the red see, before they coulde entre into the lande of promission.
column8: etc. My friends the calamities of this world, wherewith you stynch of the flesh is repourged and the naughty affects of the same utterly mortified, must needs be passed over of us, even as it behooved the people of God to pass the read see, before they could enter into the land of promission.

column7: Wherfore those heauenly and spiritual waters be here sygnifyed, wherwythal ye pourgynge of the soules and the spiritual regeneratio is made. <NOTE> For onles a man be borne agayne of water and spirite he can not se God.
column8: Wherefore those heavenly and spiritual waters be here sygnifyed, wherwythal you purging of the souls and the spiritual regeneratio is made. For unless a man be born again of water and spirit he can not see God.

column7: And he calleth it a see after the Hebrues fashion, whych be wont to call al gatherynges of waters sees, as in the thyrd boke of kynges it is called the brasen see wherin the prestes in theyr ministracion washed, and in certaine other places.
column8: And he calls it a see after the Hebrews fashion, which be wont to call all gatherings of waters sees, as in the thyrd book of kings it is called the brazen see wherein the priests in their ministration washed, and in certain other places.

column7: Now glasse is a bryght thyng wherby is meant that the water of baptisme purifyeth and maketh bryght not so much the bodye as the hartes, yea eue in the outwarde conuersation of maners according to that of Christe.
column8: Now glass is a bright thing whereby is meant that the water of baptism purifieth and makes bright not so much the body as the hearts, yea eve in the outward conversation of manners according to that of Christe.

column7: Let your lyght so shyne before me that they maye se your good workes.
column8: Let your light so shine before me that they may see your good works.

column7: But why is thys see of glasse lykened to Crystall?
column8: But why is this see of glass likened to Crystal?

column7: Surely bycause Crystall is a water whych by continuaunce of tyme is tourned into the hardenes of a stone, suche ones ought they that be baptised to be brought vnto, that is to saye, stronge and harde in faythe.
column8: Surely because Crystal is a water which by continuance of time is turned into the hardens of a stone, such ones ought they that be baptised to be brought unto, that is to say, strong and harden in faith.

column7: By the.iiii. beastes full of eyes before and behynde, P A G Elxij some do vnderstande the.iiii. Euangelistes, other, (whose iugemente better agreeth to the scripture as it semeth) do vnderstande those heauenly and ministratoriouse spirites or angels whych be appoynted to stande at the foure quarters of heauen (by whych the kyngdome of Christ, that is, <NOTE> the church is spred) to execute the thynges that be determined by the vnserchable and eternall counsayle of God to be done in mens thynges.
column8: By the iiii beasts full of eyes before and behind, PAGElxij PAGElxij PAGElxij PAGElxij some do understand the iiii Evangelists, other, (whose judgement better agreeth to the scripture as it seemeth) do understand those heavenly and ministratoriouse spirits or angels which be appointed to stand at the foure quarters of heaven (by which the kingdom of Christ, that is, the church is spread) to execute the things that be determined by the vnserchable and eternal counsel of God to be done in men's things.

column7: These be full of eyes before and behynde, that is to say, they be replenyshed wyth the science and knowlege of thinges passed and thinges to come.
column8: These be full of eyes before and behind, that is to say, they be replenished with the science and knowledge of things passed and things to come.

column7: And the fyrst beast was lyke a Lyon, the seconde lyke a Calfe, the thyrd had a face like a Man, and the fourth was lyke a flyenge Egle.
column8: And the fyrst beast was like a Lion, the seconde like a Calf, the thyrd had a face like a Man, and the fourth was like a flyenge Egle.

column7: Brethren, ye shall vnderstande, that in a lyon is courage and strength, in a calfe laboure and diligence, in the face of a man prudence and ryght iudgement, in an egle swyftnes and also facilitie in doynge theyr ministeries, al whych vertues they haue nede of, <NOTE> wol administre well and prosperously any kyngdome.
column8: Brothers, you shall understand, that in a lion is courage and strength, in a calf labour and diligence, in the face of a man prudence and right judgement, in and eagle swiftness and also facility in doing their ministeries, all which virtues they have need of, will administre well and prosperously any kingdom.

column7: And for thys cause in the psalmes the Lorde is said to syt and ryde vpon Cherubim, bycause yt by them he executeth hys iudgementes couragiously, diligetly, prudently, and wyth great swyftnes.
column8: And for this cause in the psalms the Lord is said to fit and ride upon Cherubin, because that by them he executeth his judgements courageously, diligetly, prudently, and with great swiftness.

column7: To thys interpretacio doth the scripture agre.
column8: To this interpretacio does the scripture agree.

column7: For the prophete Ezechiel in the.x. chapter doth vnderstande by ye.iiii. beastes ye Cherubim, and he maketh also the foure beastes one, hauynge yet foure faces or formes for the forsayde vertues wherwyth those ministrynge spirites, whose seruice Christ vseth in ye administracion of hys kyngdome, were indowed.
column8: For the prophet Ezechiel in the x chapter does understand by you iiii beasts you Cherubin, and he makes also the foure beasts one, having yet foure faces or forms for the forsayde virtues wherewith those ministering spirits, whose service Christ uses in you administration of his kingdom, were endowed.

column7: In that they haue syxe wynges a pece, is betokened theyr swyftnes of obedience to execute the thynges that they be appoynted vnto. <NOTE> In lyke maner doth Esay describe Seraphim.
column8: In that they have syxe wings a piece, is betokened their swiftness of obedience to execute the things that they be appointed unto. In like manner does Esay describe Seraphim.

column7: These agels, or yf ye lyst, these foure Euangelistes whych also be angels that is to say messangers, by whome Christ the greate conquerour of the aduerse powers is caryed throughe out the hole worlde as it were in a triumphall charette, haue no rest neyther day nor nyght but crye without ceasing Holy, <NOTE>, holy, that is to saye, holy father, holy sonne, and holy spirite comforter, one Lorde & God almyghty, <NOTE> in whose name all we that beleue be baptised.
column8: These agels, or if you list, these foure Evangelists which also be angels that is to say messengers, by whom Christ the great conqueror of the adverse powers is carried through out the hold world as it were in a triumphal charette, have no rest neither day nor night but cry without ceasing Holy,, holy, that is to say, holy father, holy son, and holy spirit comforter, one Lord & God almighty, in whose name all we that believe be baptised.

column7: And whan those beastes gaue glorye, honoure and thankes to hym that sate on the seate whych lyueth for euer and euer, the.xxiiii. elders of whom mecion is made before fel also downe before him which sate on the trone, and worshypped hym that lyueth for euer.
column8: And when those beasts gave glory, honour and thanks to him that sat on the seat which liveth for ever and ever, the xxiiii elders of whom mention is made before fell also down before him which sat on the throne, and worshipped him that liveth for ever.

column7: Now therfore good christen people, syth those holy spirites or angels, and the hole quere and church triumphant in heauen do wythout ceasynge, laude, prayse and magnifye the hygh maiestye of the Godheade, let not vs whych be the churche or congregacion militant here in erth be behynde wyth our prayses, comendacions, and thankesgyuynge.
column8: Now therefore good christian people, sith those holy spirits or angels, and the hold quere and church triumphant in heaven do without ceasing, laud, praise and magnify the high majesty of the Godhead, let not us which be the church or congregation militant here in earth be behind with our praises, commendations, and thankesgyuynge.

column7: The holy angels do crye before, let vs answere in ye same note & saye.
column8: The holy angels do cry before, let us answer in you same note & say.

column7: Holy father, holy sonne, & holy goost coforter Let vs, I saye, accordynge to the exemple of ye.xxiiii. elders cast oure crownes before the trone, that is to saye, confesse the crownes and rewardes whyche we that be iustifyed persos haue, come of Christes mere goodnes and no parte of our owne deseruynge, and saye: Thou arte worthy o Lorde our God to receiue P A G Elxxiij glorye, and honoure, and power.
column8: Holy father, holy son, & holy ghost coforter Let us, I say, according to the exemple of you xxiiii elders cast our crowns before the throne, that is to say, confess the crowns and rewards which we that be justified persons have, come of Christes mere goodness and no part of our own deserving, and say: Thou art worthy oh Lord our God to receive PAGElxxiij PAGElxxiij PAGElxxiij PAGElxxiij glory, and honour, and power.

column7: For thou hast created all thynges and for thy wyll they be.
column8: For thou hast created all things and for thy will they be.

column7: &c.: homily The gospell on Trinitie sondaye.
column8: etc.: homily The gospel on Trinitie sondaye.

column7: The.iij. chapter of Ihon. Thargument.
column8: The iij chapter of Jhon. Thargument.

column7: A conflicte betwene the iustice of the flesh and the iustice of the spirite.
column8: A conflict between the justice of the flesh and the justice of the spirit.

column7: T Here was a man of the Pharisees named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Iewes.
column8: THere THere was a man of the Pharisees nam Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jewes.

column7: The same came to Iesus by nyght and sayd vnto hym: Rabbi, we knowe that thou arte a teacher come from God, for no man coulde do such myracles as thou doest excepte God were wyth hym.
column8: The same came to Jesus by night and said unto him: Rabbi, we know that thou art a teacher come from God, for no man could do such miracles as thou dost except God were with him.

column7: Iesus answered and sayd vnto hym: Verely, verely, I saye vnto the, excepte a ma be borne from aboue, he can not se the kyngdome of God.
column8: Jesus answered and said unto him: Verily, verily, I say unto thee, except a ma be born from above, he can not see the kingdom of God.

column7: Nicodemus sayeth vnto hym: how can a man be borne whan he is olde? can he enter into hys mothers wombe and be borne againe?
column8: Nicodemus sayeth unto him: how can a man be born when he is old? can he enter into his mother's womb and be born again?

column7: Iesus answered: verely verely I saye vnto the, excepte a man be borne of water and of the spirite, he can not enter into the kyngdome of God.
column8: Jesus answered: verily verily I say unto thee, except a man be born of water and of the spirit, he can not enter into the kingdom of God.

column7: That whych is borne of the flesh, is flesh, and that which is borne of the spirite is spirite.
column8: That which is born of the flesh, is flesh, and that which is born of the spirit is spirit.

column7: Maruayle not thou that I sayd to the, ye must be borne from aboue.
column8: Marvel not thou that I said to thee, you must be born from above.

column7: The wynde bloweth where it lysteth, and thou hearest the sounde therof, but canst not tell whence it commeth and whether it goeth.
column8: The wind blows where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not tell whence it comes and whither it goes.

column7: So is euery one that is borne of the spirite.
column8: So is every one that is born of the spirit.

column7: Nicodemus answered and sayd vnto him: how can these thynges be?
column8: Nicodemus answered and said unto him: how can these things be?

column7: Iesus answered and sayd vnto hym: arte thou a mayster in Israel and knowest not these thynges?
column8: Jesus answered and said unto him: art thou a master in Israel and knowest not these things?

column7: Verelye verelye I saye vnto the: we speake that we do knowe, and testifye that we haue sene: and ye receyue not our wytnes.
column8: Verily verily I say unto thee: we speak that we do know, and testify that we have seen: and you receive not our witness.

column7: Yf I haue tolde you earthly thinges, and ye beleue not: how shall ye beleue, yf I tell you of heauenly thynges?
column8: If I have told you earthly things, and you believe not: how shall you believe, if I tell you of heavenly things?

column7: And no man ascendeth vp to heauen, but he that came downe from heuen euen the sonne of man whych is in heauen.
column8: And no man ascendeth up to heaven, but he that came down from heaven even the son of man which is in heaven.

column7: And as Moses lyfte vp the serpent in the wyldernes, euen so muste the sonne of man be lyfte vp, that who so euer beleueth in hym perysh not, but haue eternall lyfe.
column8: And as Moses lift up the serpent in the wilderness, even so must the son of man be lift up, that who so ever believeth in him perish not, but have eternal life.

column7: IN thys Gospell (good people) is conteyned a sore disputacion vpon the iustyce of the spirtye, and the iustice of the fleshe.
column8: IN this Gospel (good people) is contained a soar disputation upon the justice of the spirtye, and the justice of the flesh.

column7: Christ teacheth and defedeth the spirituall iustice, Nicodemus thother, but so yet that he suffreth himselfe to be taught and instructed of Christ.
column8: Christ teaches and defedeth the spiritual justice, Nicodemus tother, but so yet that he suffers himself to be taught and instructed of Christ.

column7: Fyrst therfore we shall consyder the person of Nicodemus, as the Gospell describeth hym, and howe folyshly he speaketh of ye new byrth. <NOTE> For hereby we shall espye what we also can do of oure owne power in godly and spirituall maters.
column8: Fyrst therefore we shall consider the person of Nicodemus, as the Gospel describeth him, and how foolishly he speaks of you new birth. For hereby we shall espy what we also can doe of our own power in godly and spiritual maters.

column7: Now the Euangelyst certifyeth vs that Nicodemus was a Pharisee, and a ruler of ye Iues, meanynge herby, that for the outwarde conuersacion he was fautles in lyuynge and floryshed in such apparaunce of honesty and holynes, that he was nombred of the Iues euen amongest ye chefest & fyrst.
column8: Now the Evangelyst certifyeth us that Nicodemus was a Pharisee, and a ruler of the Iues, meaning hereby, that for the outward conversation he was fautles in living and flourished in such appearance of honesty and holiness, that he was numbered of the Iues even amongst the chiefest & fyrst.

column7: Lo here thou hast the descripcion of Nicodemus person which before the worlde is P A G Elxxiiij both prudent and ryghtuouse.
column8: Lo here thou hast the description of Nicodemus person which before the world is PAGElxxiiij PAGElxxiiij PAGElxxiiij PAGElxxiiij both prudent and righteous.

column7: And yet neuertheles this worldly wyse and holy man is not so hardy nor so stronge, that he dare openlye come to Christe or speake vnto hym, albeit he iudgeth Christ a teacher sente from God, and can not denye hys sygnes and myracles.
column8: And yet nevertheless this worldly wise and holy man is not so hardy nor so strong, that he dare openly come to Christe or speak unto him, albeit he judgeth Christ a teacher sent from God, and can not deny his signs and miracles.

column7: I praye you, why doth not reason here come forth, openly to confesse Christes doctrine?
column8: I pray you, why does not reason here come forth, openly to confess Christes doctrine?

column7: For thys thynge doth Christ in any wyse requyre where he sayeth.
column8: For this thing does Christ in any wise require where he sayeth.

column7: He that confesseth me before men, <NOTE> I shall also confesse him before my father and the angels of heauen.
column8: He that confesses me before men, I shall also confess him before my father and the angels of heaven.

column7: Surely reason can not do thys, it farre passeth her powers to subiecte herselfe to the hatred of the worlde for Christes sake.
column8: Surely reason can not do this, it far passes her powers to subject herself to the hatred of the world for Christes sake.

column7: And therfore Christ requyreth of vs to hate oure owne selues, to kyll oure olde Adam, <NOTE> that we may so be transformed into new creatures.
column8: And therefore Christ requireth of us to hate our own selves, to kill our old Adam, that we may so be transformed into new creatures.

column7: But what knowlege hath our flesh & our nature of such transfourmynge or new byrth?
column8: But what knowledge hath our flesh & our nature of such transfourmynge or new birth?

column7: Surely no knowlege, no felynge, no vnderstandynge at al, as thys sayntly Nicodemus this holy prelate trustynge to hys owne good workes ful wel declareth.
column8: Surely no knowledge, no feeling, no understanding at all, as this saintly Nicodemus this holy prelate trusting to his own good works full well declareth.

column7: Christ talketh of the spirituall and new byrth, & Nicodemus loketh vpo the carnal byrth, sayeng thus.
column8: Christ talketh of the spiritual and new birth, & Nicodemus looketh upon the carnal birth, saying thus.

column7: How can a man be borne agayne whan he is olde?
column8: How can a man be born again when he is old?

column7: Shall he crepe agayne into hys mothers wombe?
column8: Shall he creep again into his mother's womb?

column7: Herken how foolyshly, how vnwysely for al his outwarde holynes thys noble prelate speaketh of godly thynges?
column8: Harken how foolishly, how unwisely for all his outward holiness this noble prelate speaks of godly things?

column7: Yea Christ is fayne to expounde vnto hym, how it commeth to passe that we be made newe creatures.
column8: Yea Christ is fain to expound unto him, how it comes to pass that we be made new creatures.

column7: Howbeit he yet vnderstandeth hym not & therfore he asketh agayne how it can be.
column8: Howbeit he yet understandeth him not & therefore he asks again how it can be.

column7: I pray you what synguler poynt do ye se in thys Nicodemus, or what other thynge do ye fynde in hym but ignoraunce, blyndnes, and infidelitie?
column8: I pray you what singular point do you see in this Nicodemus, or what other thing do you find in him but ignorance, blindness, and infidelity?

column7: Wherfore though hys outwarde conuersacion shyneth neuer so muche before the worlde yet it can not please God.
column8: Wherefore though his outward conversation shineth never so much before the world yet it can not please God.

column7: God beholdeth not the outwarde face and vysoure, but the mynde and fayth, <NOTE> as also Heremy sayeth.
column8: God beholdeth not the outward face and vysoure, but the mind and faith, as also Heremy sayeth.

column7: And what so euer is not of fayth is synne.
column8: And what so ever is not of faith is sin.

column7: The inwarde ryghtuousnes and goodnes must go before, or els ye outwarde can not please God.
column8: The inward righteousness and goodness must go before, or else you outward can not please God.

column7: Yf thou hast not the inwarde iustice, forthwyth Christ sayeth: Onles your ryghtuousnes be better then ye ryghtuousnes of the scribes and pharises ye shall not come into ye kyngdome of heauen.
column8: If thou hast not the inward justice, forthwith Christ sayeth: Unless your righteousness be better then you righteousness of the scribes and pharisees you shall not come into you kingdom of heaven.

column7: Wherfore lyke as Nicodemus is here founde vnskylfull, rude, and foolysh in maters concernynge the honour of God and oure helth: eue so be all we, olde Adams, and all fleshly (accordynge to Christes sayenge, what so euer is gendred of flesh is fleshe) onles we be lyghtened of the Lordes spirite. <NOTE> We cal flesh here the hole nature of ma, the body, mynde, reson, vnderstandyng, wyl, besyde the holy goost.
column8: Wherefore like as Nicodemus is here found unskilful, rude, and foolish in maters concerning the honour of God and our health: eve so be all we, old Adams, and all fleshly (according to Christes saying, what so ever is gendered of flesh is flesh) unless we be lightened of the Lords spirit. We call flesh here the hold nature of ma, the body, mind, reason's, understanding, will, beside the holy ghost.

column7: Such a man and such a body of synne surely can do nought but synne, seme he neuer so gay to other men, and be he decked wyth neuer so many good workes, whych thynge saynt Paule declareth copiously to the Romaynes, and in thys place thys Nicodeme ful playnly sheweth by hys wyse talking
column8: Such a man and such a body of sin surely can do nought but sin, seem he never so gay to other men, and be he decked with never so many good works, which thing saint Paule declareth copiously to the Romans, and in this place this Nicodeme full plainly shows by his wise talking

column7: <NOTE> Secondly, Christ teacheth vs in thys Gospel the new byrth, whych thynge Nicodemus coulde not attayne vnto, & fyrst he so speaketh of thys new byrth or regeneration that he maketh it playnly necessary to our soules helth. <NOTE> For thus he sayeth: Onles a ma be borne agayne, he can not se the kyngdome of god Now to se the kyngdome of God is as muche as to P A G Elxxv be iustifyed.
column8: Secondly, Christ teaches us in this Gospel the new birth, which thing Nicodemus could not attain unto, & fyrst he so speaks of this new birth or regeneration that he makes it plainly necessary to our souls health. For thus he sayeth: Unless a ma be born again, he can not see the kingdom of god Now to see the kingdom of God is as much as to PAGElxxv PAGElxxv PAGElxxv PAGElxxv be justified.

column7: Wherfore consyder here wyth the eyen of thy mynde what Christe speaketh of thys maner iustificacio, and agayne what Nicodemus thinketh agaynst it.
column8: Wherefore consider here with the eyes of thy mind what Christe speaks of this manner iustificacio, and again what Nicodemus thinketh against it.

column7: Christ reasoneth and gathereth thus.
column8: Christ reasoneth and gathereth thus.

column7: No worke, no reason, no outwarde conuersacion iustifyeth, it is only the new byrth that must worke thys.
column8: No work, no reason, no outward conversation justifieth, it is only the new birth that must work this.

column7: Agaynst thys conclusion Nicodeme thus obiecteth.
column8: Against this conclusion Nicodeme thus objecteth.

column7: Yf so be my outwarde conuersacion, workes & lyfe, be coformable to the lawe, tha for such workes sake God can not but iustifye me and make me eternally blessed.
column8: If so be my outward conversation, works & life, be coformable to the law, than for such works sake God can not but justify me and make me eternally blessed.

column7: But surely thys sayenge of hym is excedingly both false and wycked, <NOTE> for asmuche as all men be lyers, and only God true.
column8: But surely this saying of him is exceedingly both false and wicked, for asmuch as all men be liars, and only God true.

column7: Wherfore let vs consyder the nature of thys regendrynge in what sorte it is.
column8: Wherefore let us consider the nature of this regendrynge in what sort it is.

column7: Onles (sayeth Christ) thou beyst borne againe of water and spirite thou canst not come into the kingdome of heauen. <NOTE> Marke yt in baptisme thys new byrth begynneth.
column8: Unless (sayeth Christ) thou beyst born again of water and spirit thou canst not come into the kingdom of heaven. Mark that in baptism this new birth beginneth.

column7: For it is a token of sleynge the fleshe, as Paule wytnesseth Rom. vi.
column8: For it is a token of sling the flesh, as Paule witnesseth Rom. vi.

column7: And thys is one parte of the newe byrth.
column8: And this is one part of the new birth.

column7: Now in baptisme the holy goost also is gyuen and where as we be thus kylled, he rayseth vs vp agayne, he dryueth, draweth, altereth, and so worketh in vs, that we be led nomore wyth fleshly affections but wyth goostly, and that we shuld breath and thynke no loger vpon earthly thynges but vpo heauenly thinges, and shulde lyue hensforth only to ryghtuousnes.
column8: Now in baptism the holy ghost also is given and where as we be thus killed, he raises us up again, he driveth, draws, altereth, and so works in us, that we be led nomore with fleshly affections but with ghostly, and that we should breath and think no lodger upon earthly things but upon heavenly things, and should live henceforth only to righteousness.

column7: And thys is thother parte of thys new byrth.
column8: And this is tother part of this new birth.

column7: It foloweth herof, <NOTE> that to be borne again is nought els but to dye to synne warde, and by spirite and fayth to lyue to iustice warde.
column8: It followeth hereof, that to be born again is nought else but to die to sin ward, and by spirit and faith to live to justice ward.

column7: Where thys chauceth there is the kyngdome of god espyed, there is the realme of heauen entred into.
column8: Where this chanceth there is the kingdom of god espied, there is the realm of heaven entered into.

column7: What gloriacion than is lefte here to the ryghtuousnes of Nicodemus?
column8: What gloriation than is left here to the righteousness of Nicodemus?

column7: Surely it is not worth a rushe, nor to be sette an hawe by, <NOTE> none otherwise than Paule estemed his ryghtuousnes that he gat in hys Iewysh lyfe no better than donge.
column8: Surely it is not worth a rush, nor to be set and hawe by, none otherwise than Paule esteemed his righteousness that he got in his Jewish life no better than dung.

column7: For not the thynge that commeth of our owne reason, but that whych the spirite worketh in vs is acceptable to God.
column8: For not the thing that comes of our own reason, but that which the spirit works in us is acceptable to God.

column7: The thynge that is gendred of the spirite is spirite, and is only of valure before God. <NOTE> And therfore saynt Paul sayeth to the Ephesians.
column8: The thing that is gendered of the spirit is spirit, and is only of valour before God. And therefore saint Paul sayeth to the Ephesians.

column7: Do of the olde man accordynge to youre former maners and conuersation, and put ye on the new man.
column8: Do of the old man according to your former manners and conversation, and put you on the new man.

column7: How can reason do or compryse these thinges, syth it can not perceyue thynges corporall and outward, as from whence the wynde commeth and whyther it woll?
column8: How can reason do or comprise these things, sith it can not perceive things corporal and outward, as from whence the wind comes and whither it will?

column7: To conclude, thys new byrth is a worke of the spirite, though the Papistes do neuer so muche preache the iustice of theyr fleshe.
column8: To conclude, this new birth is a work of the spirit, though the Papists do never so much preach the justice of their flesh.

column7: <NOTE> Thyrdly, we be here taught, who hath gotte, gyuen, delyuered, and comunicated vnto vs thys spirite, euen the sonne of man Christe, who only came from heauen and retourned into heauen.
column8: Thyrdly, we be here taught, who hath got, given, delivered, and communicated unto us this spirit, even the son of man Christe, who only came from heaven and returned into heaven.

column7: By what thynge then hathe he gotten and deserued vnto vs this spirite?
column8: By what thing then hath he got and deserved unto us this spirit?

column7: Truly herby, that he was likewise exalted as the serpent in wyldernes. <NOTE> But what maner serpent is thys?
column8: Truly hereby, that he was likewise exalted as the serpent in wilderness. But what manner serpent is this?

column7: The people of Israell ones grudged agaynst god and blaspehmed hym so heynously that he sent vpon them fyery serpentes.
column8: The people of Israell ones grudged against god and blaspehmed him so heinously that he sent upon them fiery serpents.

column7: And who so euer was bytten of any such serpent, dyed therof.
column8: And who so ever was bitten of any such serpent, died thereof.

column7: Here God at last moued with the prayers and requestes of Moses, commaunded a brasen serpent to be erected for a signe that whosoeuer beynge stryke of any suche serpent shulde loke vp to that brasen serpent, P A G Elxxvi shulde be healed.
column8: Here God at last moved with the prayers and requests of Moses, commanded a brazen serpent to be erected for a sign that whosoever being strike of any such serpent should look up to that brazen serpent, PAGElxxvi PAGElxxvi PAGElxxvi PAGElxxvi should be healed.

column7: Thys fygure Christ draweth to hymselfe, and this in sentence he sayeth: I shalbe delyuered to myne aduersaries to be crucifyed and at last slayne, for thys intente, that by my crosse and death God the moost louynge father myght be recociled to the worlde.
column8: This figure Christ draws to himself, and this in sentence he sayeth: I shall delivered to mine adversaries to be crucified and at last slain, for this intent, that by my cross and death God the most loving father might be recociled to the world.

column7: Whosoeuer therfore beynge stryken wyth the poyson darte of synne, loketh vp to me that is to saye, beleueth on me, shal not than perysh, but shall attayne euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: Whosoever therefore being stricken with the poison dart of sin, looketh up to me that is to say, believeth on me, shall not than perish, but shall attain everlasting life.

column7: Lo such one is Christ vnto vs, he forgyueth vs our synnes, and bestoweth on vs hys spirite, he trasformeth vs to new creatures, <NOTE> ordeyneth vs the sonnes and heyres of God, so that we cleaue vnto hym and beleue on him wythout doubtynge.
column8: Lo such one is Christ unto us, he forgyueth us our sins, and bestoweth on us his spirit, he trasformeth us to new creatures, ordaineth us the sons and heirs of God, so that we cleave unto him and believe on him without doubting.

column7: Wherfore good people that God of hys endles goodnes woll vouchsaue to create in vs a syncere and a ryghte fayth, let vs al praye.
column8: Wherefore good people that God of his endless goodness will vouchsaue to create in us a sincere and a right faith, let us all pray.

column7: To whom be all glorye and honour for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be all glory and honour for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the fyrst sonday after trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the fyrst sonday after trinity.

column7: The.i. epistle of Ihon the.iiij. chapter.
column8: The i epistle of Ihon the iiij chapter.

column7: Thargument How God loued vs fyrst, and how we ought by hys exemple to loue our neyghbour.
column8: Thargument How God loved us fyrst, and how we ought by his exemple to love our neighbour.

column7: M Oost dearely beloued brethren, God is loue: In thys appeared the loue of God to vs ward bycause that God sent hys only begotten sonne in to the worlde, that we myght lyue thorow hym.
column8: Most Most dearly beloved brothers, God is love: In this appeared the love of God to us ward because that God sent his only begotten son in to the world, that we might live thorough him.

column7: Herein is loue, not that we loued God: but that he loued vs, and sent his sonne to make agrement for our synnes.
column8: Herein is love, not that we loved God: but that he loved us, and sent his son to make agreement for our sins.

column7: Dearely beloued, yf God so loued vs, we ought also to loue one another.
column8: Dearly beloved, if God so loved us, we ought also to love one another.

column7: No man hath sene god at any tyme.
column8: No man hath seen god at any time.

column7: Yf we loue one another, god dwelleth in vs, and hys loue is perfyte in vs. Hereby knowe we that we dwell in hym, and he in vs, bycause he hath gyuen vs of hys spirite.
column8: If we love one another, god dwells in us, and his love is perfect in us Hereby know we that we dwell in him, and he in us, because he hath given us of his spirit.

column7: And we haue sene and do testifye, that the father sent the sonne to be the Sauiour of the world.
column8: And we have seen and do testify, that the father sent the son to be the Saviour of the world.

column7: Whosoeuer cofesseth, that Iesus is the sonne of God, in hym dwelleth God, and he in God.
column8: Whosoever cofesseth, that Jesus is the son of God, in him dwells God, and he in God.

column7: And we haue knowen, & beleued the loue that God hath to vs. God is loue, and he that dwelleth in loue, dwelleth in God, and God in hym.
column8: And we have known, & believed the love that God hath to us God is love, and he that dwells in love, dwells in God, and God in him.

column7: Herin is the loue perfite in vs, that we shulde haue trust in the daye of iudgement: For as he is, euen so are we in thys worlde.
column8: Herin is the love perfect in us, that we should have trust in the day of judgement: For as he is, even so are we in this world.

column7: There is no feare in loue but perfyte loue casteth out feare, for feare hath paynfulnes.
column8: There is no fear in love but perfect love casts out fear, for fear hath painfulness.

column7: He that feareth, is not perfyte in loue.
column8: He that fears, is not perfect in love.

column7: We loue hym, for he loued vs fyrst.
column8: We love him, for he loved us fyrst.

column7: Yf a man saye: I loue god, and yet hate hys brother he is a lyer.
column8: If a man say: I love god, and yet hate his brother he is a liar.

column7: For how can he that loueth not his brother whome he hath sene, loue God whom he hath not sene?
column8: For how can he that loves not his brother whom he hath seen, love God whom he hath not seen?

column7: And thys commaundement haue we of hym: that he whyche loueth God, shulde loue hys brother also.
column8: And this commandment have we of him: that he which loves God, should love his brother also.

column7: MY frendes thys hole lection is a commendacion of gods loue towardes vs, by whose exemple we also be commaunded to loue one another.
column8: MY friends this hold lection is a commendation of gods love towards us, by whose exemple we also be commanded to love one another.

column7: He that loueth not (sayeth saint Ihon which wrote this epistle) knoweth not God though he neuer so much bosteth hymselfe to be a christen ma, for god is loue.
column8: He that loves not (sayeth saint Ihon which wrote this epistle) knoweth not God though he never so much boasteth himself to be a christian ma, for god is love.

column7: P A G Elxxvij Yea herin appeared the greate loue and charitie of God towardes vs men, that he sent hys only begotten sonne into the worlde, to thintent, that by his meryte we myght lyue through hym whyche els shulde haue dyed wyth perpetuall death.
column8: PAGElxxvij PAGElxxvij PAGElxxvij PAGElxxvij Yea herin appeared the great love and charity of God towards us men, that he sent his only begotten son into the world, to intent, that by his merit we might live through him which else should have died with perpetual death.

column7: But happely ye wolle here saye, that we prouoked God wyth oure loue and merytes fyrst to loue vs. No not so sayeth saynt Ihon, that is a false opinion and a starke lye.
column8: But happily the wool here say, that we provoked God with our love and merits fyrst to love us No not so sayeth saint Ihon, that is a false opinion and a stark lie.

column7: For in thys is the loue, not that we loued God, but that he loued vs fyrst, and sent hys sonne to be a sacrifice and a purgynge for our synnes. <NOTE> But herken what S. Austine sayeth of thys mater.
column8: For in this is the love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us fyrst, and sent his son to be a sacrifice and a purging for our sins. But harken what S. Austine sayeth of this mater.

column7: What good merytes coulde we than haue whan we loued not God.
column8: What good merits could we than have when we loved not God.

column7: For that we myght take loue to loue wyth, we were loued, whan as yet we had it not. <NOTE> This (sayeth he) doth Ihon thapostle moost openly affirme.
column8: For that we might take love to love with, we were loved, when as yet we had it not. This (sayeth he) does Ihon apostle most openly affirm.

column7: Not that we loued God, but that he loued fyrst vs. Truly (sayeth saynt Austine) thys is moost ryghtly and well spoken.
column8: Not that we loved God, but that he loved fyrst us Truly (sayeth saint Austine) this is most rightly and well spoken.

column7: For we could not haue to loue hym onles we had taken thys of hym, in that he loued vs fyrst.
column8: For we could not have to love him unless we had taken this of him, in that he loved us fyrst.

column7: How can we do good, yf we loue not? or howe do we not good, yf we loue? <NOTE> albeit gods comaudemente semeth somtyme to be done of not louers but of fearers: yet there is no loue, no good worke is imputed, neyther ryghtly is it called a good worke, for all yt is not of fayth is synne.
column8: How can we do good, if we love not? or how do we not good, if we love? albeit gods comaudemente seemeth sometime to be done of not lovers but of fearers: yet there is no love, no good work is imputed, neither rightly is it called a good work, for all that is not of faith is sin.

column7: And fayth worketh by loue.
column8: And faith works by love.

column7: Hytherto speaketh Austine.
column8: Hitherto speaks Austine.

column7: Wherfore my dearly beloued (sayeth Ihon) yf God hath so loued vs, we ought also to loue one another.
column8: Wherefore my dearly beloved (sayeth Ihon) if God hath so loved us, we ought also to love one another.

column7: Ye wol saye: How can God dwell in vs, syth we se him not?
column8: the will say: How can God dwell in us, sith we see him not?

column7: Ihon answereth: Albeit we se hym not wyth the eyes of fleshe, yet he dwelleth in vs, for God there wol dwell where charitie is exercised.
column8: Ihon answereth: Albeit we see him not with the eyes of flesh, yet he dwells in us, for God there will dwell where charity is exercised.

column7: But againe ye wol aske, howe is it that Ihon sayeth here, <NOTE> noman euer sawe God, seynge it is red in scripture that many of ye fathers haue sene hym face to face, as Iacob, Moses, and other.
column8: But again you will ask, how is it that Ihon sayeth here, noman ever saw God, sing it is read in scripture that many of you father's have seen him face to face, as Jacob, Moses, and other.

column7: I answere, noman euer saw God as god and visibly.
column8: I answer, noman ever saw God as god and visibly.

column7: For the lawe was gyuen by angels act. vii. and it is playne that Iacob sawe but an angell.
column8: For the law was given by angels act. vii. and it is plain that Jacob saw but and angel.

column7: For euen in the selfe same.xxxiij. chapter of Exodus God sayeth: Man shall not se me and lyue.
column8: For even in the self same xxxiij chapter of Exodus God sayeth: Man shall not see me and live.

column7: So tha God dwelleth in vs inuisibly.
column8: So tha God dwells in us invisibly.

column7: It foloweth therfore, yf we loue one another, god dwelleth in vs, & hys loue is made perfyte in vs. Surely the knowlege & confession of Christe maketh vs all one wyth God, so that we shalbe perpetually in hym, <NOTE> and he in vs. But here ye muste marke that thys knowlege can not chaunce but to such as be indowed with the holy goost.
column8: It followeth therefore, if we love one another, god dwells in us, & his love is made perfect in us Surely the knowledge & confession of Christe makes us all one with God, so that we shall perpetually in him, and he in us But here you must mark that this knowledge can not chance but to such as be endowed with the holy ghost.

column7: For he sayeth: Herby we knowe yt we dwell in hym & he in vs, bycause he hath gyuen vs of hys spirite.
column8: For he sayeth: Hereby we know that we dwell in him & he in us, because he hath given us of his spirit.

column7: And we haue sene and do testifye (sayeth S. Ihon) that ye father hath sent his sonne to be ye Sauiour of the worlde.
column8: And we have seen and do testify (sayeth S. Ihon) that you father hath sent his son to be the Saviour of the world.

column7: O glad and ioyfull tydynges.
column8: O glad and joyful tidings.

column7: What an excedynge charitie and loue was thys?
column8: What and exceeding charity and love was this?

column7: Then syth God is so louynge vnto vs, yea syth he is the selfe loue, yf we woll dwell in hym, we muste loue, not only hi, but also for hym, our neighboure.
column8: Then sith God is so loving unto us, yea sith he is the self love, if we will dwell in him, we must love, not only him, but also for him, our neighbour.

column7: For that we do to our neyghbour he couteth it done to hymselfe.
column8: For that we do to our neighbour he couteth it done to himself.

column7: Now it is a moost certayne token of our loue towardes God yf we boldly & wyth confidence loke for the daye of iudgement.
column8: Now it is a most certain token of our love towards God if we boldly & with confidence look for the day of judgement.

column7: For yf we feare, we declare that we be no perfyte louers.
column8: For if we fear, we declare that we be no perfect lovers.

column7: For feare is not in loue, but perfyte loue casteth out feare.
column8: For fear is not in love, but perfect love casts out fear.

column7: My frendes herken agayne what saynt Austine sayeth P A G Elxxviij herin.
column8: My friends harken again what saint Austine sayeth PAGElxxviij PAGElxxviij PAGElxxviij PAGElxxviij herin.

column7: He that feareth hell, feareth not to synne, <NOTE> but to brenne.
column8: He that fears hell, fears not to sin, but to bren.

column7: But he feareth to synne, which hateth syn as hell.
column8: But he fears to sin, which hates sin as hell.

column7: Thys is the chast feare that remayneth for euer and euer.
column8: This is the chaste fear that remaineth for ever and ever.

column7: For that feare of punyshment hath torment and paynefulnes in it and it is not in charitie, but perfyte charitie casteth it out.
column8: For that fear of punishment hath torment and paynefulnes in it and it is not in charity, but perfect charity casts it out.

column7: And surely a ma so much hateth synne, as he loueth iustice, which he can not do, the lawe fearynge hym by the letter, but the spirite healynge hym by grace.
column8: And surely a ma so much hates sin, as he loves justice, which he can not do, the law fearing him by the letter, but the spirit healing him by grace.

column7: Thys wryteth the moost excellent doctour of the church saynt Austine to ye confusion of the vayne sophistes which blasphemously write and speake agaynst the iustifienge spirite of God whych worketh by pure and lyuely fayth.
column8: This writes the most excellent doctor of the church saint Austine to the confusion of the vain sophists which blasphemously write and speak against the iustifienge spirit of God which works by pure and lively faith.

column7: Wherfore good brethren & systers let vs not thinke trustynge to our owne merytes and workes, that we loued God fyrst and so deserued kyndnes at hys hades.
column8: Wherefore good brothers & sisters let us not think trusting to our own merits and works, that we loved God fyrst and so deserved kindness at his hades.

column7: For yf ye thynke so, saynt Ihon reproueth you, sayenge: We loue God, bycause he fyrst loued vs. Now yf a man sayeth, he loueth God, and hateth his brother, he is a lyer.
column8: For if you think so, saint Ihon reproveth you, saying: We love God, because he fyrst loved us Now if a man sayeth, he loves God, and hates his brother, he is a liar.

column7: For he that loueth not hys brother whome he seeth, how can he loue God whom he hath not sene?
column8: For he that loves not his brother whom he sees, how can he love God whom he hath not seen?

column7: And thys comaundemet (sayeth saint Iho) we haue of God, that he that loueth God, must also loue hys brother.
column8: And this comaundemet (sayeth saint Iho) we have of God, that he that loves God, must also love his brother.

column7: But I praye you howe do we loue our brother and se so many lye in euery corner wythout comforte?
column8: But I pray you how do we love our brother and see so many lie in every corner without comfort?

column7: Yea we se Christ an hogred, <NOTE> and we gyue hym no meate.
column8: Yea we see Christ and hogred, and we gyve him no meat.

column7: We se hym thyrstye, and we gyue hym no drynke.
column8: We see him thirsty, and we gyve him no drink.

column7: We se hym harbroughles, and we take hym not in, naked, & we cloth hym not, syck, and we vysite him not, in prison, and we come not to hym.
column8: We see him harbroughles, and we take him not in, naked, & we cloth him not, sick, and we visit him not, in prison, and we come not to him.

column7: For in asmuch as we do it not to one of these our poore brethren, Christ count it vndone to hym.
column8: For in as as we do it not to one of these our poor brothers, Christ count it undone to him.

column7: Wherfore yf we vnfaynedlye loue God, let vs declare our loue wyth worthy frutes, let vs loue oure brethren, as we be here wylled to do.
column8: Wherefore if we unfeignedly love God, let us declare our love with worthy fruits, let us love our brothers, as we be here willed to do.

column7: Then shall we wyth confidence and full hope loke for the daye of iudgement wythout feare, at whych tyme the heuenly kynge shall saye vnto vs. Come ye blessed of my father inherite the kyngdome prepared for you from the begynnynge of the worlde.
column8: Then shall we with confidence and full hope look for the day of judgement without fear, at which time the heavenly king shall say unto us Come you blessed of my father inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the beginning of the world.

column7: To thys heauenly kynge the sonne of man oure Lorde and Sauiour be gyuen al glorye for euer and euer.
column8: To this heavenly king the son of man our Lord and Saviour be given all glory for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospell on the fyrst sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the fyrst sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.xvi. chapter of Luke.
column8: The xvi chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Of the ryche man and of poore Lazarus.
column8: Of the rich man and of poor Lazarus.

column7: I Esus put forth a parable vnto hys disciples, sayenge: There was a certayne rych man, whyche was clothed in purple and fyne whyte, and fared deliciously euery daye: And there was a certayne begger named Lazarus, which laye at his gates ful of sores, desyrynge to be refreshed wyth the cromes, which fell from the rych mans borde, and no man gaue vnto hym.
column8: IEsus IEsus put forth a parable unto his disciples, saying: There was a certain rich man, which was clothed in purple and fine white, and fared deliciously every day: And there was a certain beggar nam Lazarus, which say at his gates full of sores, desiring to be refreshed with the cromes, which fell from the rich men board, and no man gave unto him.

column7: The dogges came also, and lycked hys sores.
column8: The dogs came also, and lycked his sores.

column7: And it fortuned that the begger dyed, and was caried by the angels into Abrahams bosome.
column8: And it fortuned that the beggar died, and was carried by the angels into Abrahams bosom.

column7: The rich man also dyed, and was buried.
column8: The rich man also died, and was buried.
