column7: P A G Elxxix And beyng in hel in tormetes, he lyft vp hys eyes and sawe Abraham a farre of, and Lazarus in hys bosome, and he cryed and sayd: father Abraham: haue mercy on me, and sende Lazarus, that he may dyppe the typpe of hys fynger in water, and coole my tonge: for I am tormented in thys flame.
column8: PAGElxxix PAGElxxix PAGElxxix PAGElxxix And being in hell in tormetes, he lift up his eyes and saw Abraham a far of, and Lazarus in his bosom, and he cried and said: father Abraham: have mercy on me, and send Lazarus, that he may dyppe the tip of his finger in water, and cool my tongue: for I am tormented in this flame.

column7: But Abraham sayd: Sonne remember that thou in thy lyfe tyme, receyuest thy pleasure, and cotrary wyse Lazarus receyued payne.
column8: But Abraham said: Son remember that thou in thy life time, receivest thy pleasure, and contrary wise Lazarus received pain.

column7: But nowe is he coforted, and thou arte punyshed.
column8: But now is he coforted, and thou art punished.

column7: Beyonde all this, betwene vs and you there is a greate space set, so that they whych wolde go from hence to you can not: neyther maye come from thence to vs. Then he sayd: I praye the therfore father, sende hym to my fathers house (For I haue fyue brethre) for to warne them, lest they also come into this place of tormet.
column8: Beyond all this, between us and you there is a great space set, so that they which would go from hence to you can not: neither may come from thence to us Then he said: I pray the therefore father, send him to my father's house (For I have fyue brethren) for to warn them, lest they also come into this place of tormet.

column7: Abraham sayd vnto hym: they haue Moses and the prophetes, let them heare them.
column8: Abraham said unto him: they have Moses and the prophets, let them hear them.

column7: And he sayd: naye father Abraham: but yf one come vnto them from the deade, they wyll repente.
column8: And he said: nay father Abraham: but if one come unto them from the dead, they will repent.

column7: He sayd vnto hym: Yf they heare not Moses and the Prophetes, neyther wyll they beleue, thoughe one rose frome death agayne.
column8: He said unto him: If they hear not Moses and the Prophets, neither will they believe, though one rose from death again.

column7: G Ood people thys Gospel as it is ryght comfortable to the poore godly persons: so it is ryght fearfull to the vngodly rych persons.
column8: GOod GOod people this Gospel as it is right comfortable to the poor godly persons: so it is right fearful to the ungodly rich persons.

column7: The sely pore godly person is muche vexed wyth troubles and diseases in thys lyfe, he lyeth otherwhyles beggynge at ryche mens gates, ful of sores, desyrynge to be refreshed wyth the cromes whych fal fro theyr tables The vngodly person lyueth all at pleasure and florysheth.
column8: The sely poor godly person is much vexed with troubles and diseases in this life, he lies otherwhiles begging at rich men's gates, full of sores, desiring to be refreshed with the cromes which fall from their tables The ungodly person liveth all at pleasure and flourisheth.

column7: But se the ende of these two in theyr death.
column8: But see the end of these two in their death.

column7: The poore Lazarus is forthwyth caryed by angels into Abrahams bosome.
column8: The poor Lazarus is forthwith carried by angels into Abrahams bosom.

column7: The rych man is buryed in hell.
column8: The rich man is buried in hell.

column7: What is thys, to be borne vp of angels and to be layd in Abrahas bosome?
column8: What is this, to be born up of angels and to be laid in Abrahas bosom?

column7: Surely it is nothynge els, but to dye in the fayth of Abraham, whose soules must nedes be in the handes of God.
column8: Surely it is nothing else, but to die in the faith of Abraham, whose souls must needs be in the hands of God.

column7: What is it to be buryed and to lye in hell in tormentes?
column8: What is it to be buried and to lie in hell in torments?

column7: To dye wyth an euell conscience.
column8: To die with and evil conscience.

column7: These thynges do chauce in death, <NOTE> tyme we passe out of thys worlde.
column8: These things do chance in death, time we pass out of this world.

column7: Albeit ye shall yet vnderstande, that it was not pouertie that saued Lazarus, nor the ryches that damned the rych man, but it is the fayth that saueth & which worketh pacience and hope, and agayne it is ye lacke of fayth and despisynge of the neyghboure that daneth.
column8: Albeit you shall yet understand, that it was not poverty that saved Lazarus, nor the riches that damned the rich man, but it is the faith that saveth & which works patience and hope, and again it is the lack of faith and despising of the neighbour that daneth.

column7: As longe as the rych man lyued he was so choked wyth worldlye pleasures, that he coulde not se what was what, but whan he was in hell and in tormentes than he lyfted vp hys eyes, then he sawe Abraham afarre of, and Lazarus in hys bosome.
column8: As long as the rich man lived he was so choked with worldly pleasures, that he could not see what was what, but when he was in hell and in torments than he lifted up his eyes, then he saw Abraham afar of, and Lazarus in his bosom.

column7: Surely my frendes in death fyrst we espye our vngodlynes and damnacion.
column8: Surely my friends in death fyrst we espy our ungodliness and damnation.

column7: Tha we se the felicitie & ioye of the godly persons. <NOTE> Thys is that worme that dyeth not, whych the prophete Esaye speaketh of.
column8: Than we see the felicity & joy of the godly persons. This is that worm that dyeth not, which the prophet Esaye speaks of.

column7: Tha fyrst the vnwyse virgines se that the wyse haue oyle Then it commeth to our mynde, to whome we haue done good, and to whome we haue done euel.
column8: Than fyrst the unwise virgins see that the wise have oil Then it comes to our mind, to whom we have done good, and to whom we have done evil.

column7: Then doth the lawe shewe it selfe, where as the gospell is taken awaye, then fyrst, but to late and in vayne, we seke fauoure. <NOTE> Then thou rych ma thou canst speake fayre and saye: Father Abraham, haue mercy on me P A G Elxxx But herken o thou vngodly rych man, what father Abraham shall answere the agayne.
column8: Then does the law show it self, where as the gospel is taken away, then fyrst, but to late and in vain, we seek favour. Then thou rich ma thou canst speak fair and say: Father Abraham, have mercy on me PAGElxxx PAGElxxx PAGElxxx PAGElxxx But harken oh thou ungodly rich man, what father Abraham shall answer the again.

column7: Sonne remember that thou in thy lyfe tyme receyuedst thy pleasure, and contrary wyse thys poore Lazarus receyued payne.
column8: Son remember that thou in thy life time receivedst thy pleasure, and contrary wise this poor Lazarus received pain.

column7: Lo the sentence of the sharpe iudgement of God.
column8: Lo the sentence of the sharp judgement of God.

column7: For as saynt Iames sayeth: <NOTE> Iudgemente wythout mercy shalbe to them, whych haue shewed no mercy.
column8: For as saint Iames sayeth: Judgement without mercy shall to them, which have showed no mercy.

column7: Also the wyse man sayeth in hys prouerbes.
column8: Also the wise man sayeth in his proverbs.

column7: He that stoppeth hys eare at the cryenge of the poore, shall also crye, and not be herde.
column8: He that stoppeth his ear at the crying of the poor, shall also cry, and not be herd.

column7: Furthermore the prophete sayeth: <NOTE> For thys shall euery godly person make hys prayer vnto the in due season, but in the greate water floudes they shall not come nyghe hym.
column8: Furthermore the prophet sayeth: For this shall every godly person make his prayer unto thee in due season, but in the great water floods they shall not come nigh him.

column7: So good people ye se by thys parable, that after thys lyfe we shall come shorte to make intercession eyther for our selues or for others.
column8: So good people you see by this parable, that after this life we shall come short to make intercession either for our selves or for others.

column7: For the soule of thys rych glutto here espyenge he could nothing preuayle for hymselfe began to intreate for hys fyue brethren, and desyred that Lazarus might be sent to hys fathers house for to warne them, leste they also come into that place of tourmet.
column8: For the soul of this rich glutto here espyenge he could nothing prevail for himself began to entreat for his fyue brothers, and desired that Lazarus might be sent to his father's house for to warn them, lest they also come into that place of tourmet.

column7: But what was answered vnto hym agayne?
column8: But what was answered unto him again?

column7: They haue Moses and the prophetes, let them heare them, as who shulde saye, they haue gods worde amonges them, whyche teacheth them how to eschue euerlastynge punyshmentes, and how to be saued, yf they wol not regard it, there is no recouery in them.
column8: They have Moses and the prophets, let them hear them, as who should say, they have gods word among them, which teaches them how to eschew everlasting punishments, and how to be saved, if they will not regard it, there is no recovery in them.

column7: Vndoubtedly thys answere teacheth vs two thynges.
column8: Undoubtedly this answer teaches us two things.

column7: Fyrst, <NOTE> ye wyll of God ought not to be learned of the dead, as Moses also forbyddeth in Deuteronomye, sayenge: <NOTE> Let noman serch the trouth of the deade, for God abhorreth it.
column8: Fyrst, you will of God ought not to be learned of the dead, as Moses also forbiddeth in Deuteronomye, saying: Let noman search the troth of the dead, for God abhorreth it.

column7: And surely not wythout cause, for he that ensercheth the trouth of deade men, sheweth hymselfe not contented wyth gods worde, whych is a synne agaynst the seconde commaundement.
column8: And surely not without cause, for he that ensercheth the troth of dead men, shows himself not contented with gods word, which is a sin against the seconde commandment.

column7: Also to serche the trouth of deade men, is to put other meanes tha preachers, by whome God wol haue hys word knowen and spred abrode.
column8: Also to search the troth of dead men, is to put other means than preachers, by whom God will have his word known and spread abroad.

column7: Thys thynge doth the exemple of Saule teach vs, <NOTE> whych after he was caste vp of the Lorde and vtterly wycked in his harte, by the helpe of a wytche raysed vp the prophete Samuell from death, that is to wyt, a certayne person resemblynge Samuel in voyce and vysage.
column8: This thing does the exemple of Saule teach us, which after he was cast up of the Lord and utterly wicked in his heart, by the help of a wytche raised up the prophet Samuell from death, that is to wit, a certain person resembling Samuel in voice and visage.

column7: Secondly, thys answere of Abraham teacheth vs, that besyde the worde wrytten, none other is to be loked for or to be herde, though an angell shulde come from heauen, or a goost ryse fro death to lyfe.
column8: Secondly, this answer of Abraham teaches us, that beside the word written, none other is to be looked for or to be herd, though and angel should come from heaven, or a ghost rise from death to life.

column7: Wherfore good christen brethren and systers, I exhorte in the Lordes name you that be rych, to make your selues frendes of your wicked Mammon, <NOTE> that is to saye, of your worldly goodes that when ye dye, they may receyue you into euerlastyng tabernacles, lest ye be serued as thys ryche ma was.
column8: Wherefore good christian brothers and sisters, I exhort in the Lords name you that be rich, to make your selves friends of your wicked Mammon, that is to say, of your worldly goods that when you die, they may receive you into everlasting tabernacles, lest you be served as this rich ma was.

column7: And agayne I exhorte you that be poore to haue sure faith in the Lorde and pacience in your aduersitie and pouertie And doubt ye not, but at your departure out of this transitory worlde, accordynge to the example of this poore Lazarus, ye shalbe caryed by angels into the bosome of Abraham, <NOTE> that is to say, into euerlastyng lyfe, in whych after the exemple of the father Abraham, who is the father of al beleuynge chyldren, the godly be receyued as into the bosome of the heuely father.
column8: And again I exhort you that be poor to have sure faith in the Lord and patience in your adversity and poverty And doubt you not, but at your departure out of this transitory world, according to the example of this poor Lazarus, you shall carried by angels into the bosom of Abraham, that is to say, into everlasting life, in which after the exemple of the father Abraham, who is the father of all believing children, the godly be received as into the bosom of the heuely father.

column7: To whom wyth the sonne and holy goost be all honoure and glorye.
column8: To whom with the son and holy ghost be all honour and glory.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily P A G Elxxxi The Epistle on the.ij. sondaye after trinitie.
column8: : homily PAGElxxxi PAGElxxxi PAGElxxxi PAGElxxxi The Epistle on the ij sondaye after trinity.

column7: The.i. epistle of Ihon the.iij. chapter.
column8: The i epistle of Ihon the iij chapter.

column7: Thargument Of the syngular loue of God towardes vs, and howe we ought agayne to loue one another
column8: Thargument Of the singular love of God towards us, and how we ought again to love one another

column7: M Aruayle not my brethren thoughe the worlde hate you.
column8: Marvel Marvel not my brothers though the world hate you.

column7: We know, that we are translated fro death vnto lyfe, bycause we loue the brethren.
column8: We know, that we are translated from death unto life, because we love the brothers.

column7: He that loueth not hys brother, abydeth in death.
column8: He that loves not his brother, abideth in death.

column7: Who so euer hateth hys brother, is a mansleer.
column8: Who so ever hates his brother, is a mansleer.

column7: And ye knowe, that no mansleer hath eternall lyfe abydynge in hym.
column8: And you know, that no mansleer hath eternal life abiding in him.

column7: Hereby perceyue we loue: bycause he gaue hys lyfe for vs: and we ought to gyue our lyues for the brethren.
column8: Hereby perceive we love: because he gave his life for us: and we ought to gyve our lives for the brothers.

column7: But who so hath thys worldes good and seeth hys brother haue nede, & shutteth vp hys compassion from hym: how dwelleth the loue of God in hym?
column8: But who so hath this world's good and sees his brother have need, & shutteth up his compassion from him: how dwells the love of God in him?

column7: My babes let vs not loue in worde, neyther in tonge: but in dede and in veritie.
column8: My babes let us not love in word, neither in tongue: but in deed and in verity.

column7: F Or asmuch as (deare brethren and systers) euen from the begynnynge of the worlde it hath bene sene, as the exemple of Abel wytnesseth, that the godly haue suffred persecution, trouble, <NOTE> vexation of the vngodly and wycked persons: therfore the holy Apostle of God saynt Ihon doth here exhorte vs to pacience in persecution and in aduersitie, and that we shulde not be false harted and discouraged bycause we se we be euell and vnworthely handeled & intreated of the wycked worlde.
column8: FOr FOr as as (deer brothers and sisters) even from the beginning of the world it hath be seen, as the exemple of Abel witnesseth, that the godly have suffered persecution, trouble, vexation of the ungodly and wicked persons: therefore the holy Apostle of God saint Ihon does here exhort us to patience in persecution and in adversity, and that we should not be false hearted and discouraged because we see we be evil and unworthily handled & entreated of the wicked world.

column7: And it is not without cause that saynt Ihon moueth vs to pacience, for of truth it is a ryght harde thynge a ma to stade fast in trouble and not to despayre, or at leste waye not to doubte of the trouth of gods word for al that he seeth so many euell and vnhappy chaunces vnto hym on euery syde.
column8: And it is not without cause that saint Ihon moves us to patience, for of truth it is a right harden thing a ma to stade fast in trouble and not to despair, or at lest way not to doubt of the troth of gods word for all that he sees so many evil and unhappy chances unto him on every side.

column7: And besydes that he exhorteth vs in thys place vnto pacience, he also therwythall comforteth al that be vexed & troubled for trouthes sake wyth the greate benefyte and profyte whyche they haue taken through gods worde, that is to wyt that they be translated fro death to lyfe, and be now made the beloued sonnes of God, to whych commodities and profytes al the persecutions in the world be not able to be compared.
column8: And besides that he exhorteth us in this place unto patience, he also therwythall comforts all that be vexed & troubled for truths sake with the great benefit and profit which they have taken through gods word, that is to wit that they be translated from death to life, and be now made the beloved sons of God, to which commodities and profits all the persecutions in the world be not able to be compared.

column7: Maruayle not (sayeth S. Ihon) though the worlde hate you.
column8: Marvel not (sayeth S. Ihon) though the world hate you.

column7: We knowe that we are translated frome death vnto lyfe, bycause we loue our brethren.
column8: We know that we are translated from death unto life, because we love our brothers.

column7: O what an vnspeakable solace and comforte is this (my frendes) vnto vs to know that we now lyue vnto God warde, albeit before the worlde we be daylye mortifyed and euen kylled none otherwise tha shepe that go to the slaughter.
column8: O what and unspeakable solace and comfort is this (my friends) unto us to know that we now live unto God ward, albeit before the world we be daily mortified and even killed none otherwise than sheep that go to the slaughter.

column7: And agayne on the contrary parte what a fearful & horrible thynge is it yt the wycked persons whych pursue the godly be dead to god warde?
column8: And again on the contrary part what a fearful & horrible thing is it that the wicked persons which pursue the godly be dead to god ward?

column7: We be than translated fro death to lyfe Wherfore?
column8: We be than translated from death to life Wherefore?

column7: Bycause sayeth Ihon we loue oure brethren.
column8: Because sayeth Ihon we love our brothers.

column7: Surely my frendes, the louynge of our brethren is an open declaracion & token to the worlde, that we be the chyldren of God.
column8: Surely my friends, the loving of our brothers is and open declaration & token to the world, that we be the children of God.

column7: For he that sayeth he hath faythe and loue towardes God, and yet loueth not hys neyghbour maketh a starke lye.
column8: For he that sayeth he hath faith and love towards God, and yet loves not his neighbour makes a stark lie.

column7: For a good tree, must nedes brynge forth good frute.
column8: For a good tree, must needs bring forth good fruit.

column7: He then that loueth not hys brother abydeth in death, P A G Elxxxij that is to saye, <NOTE> he is not yet rysen from death to lyfe wyth Christ vnto a new lyfe.
column8: He then that loves not his brother abideth in death, PAGElxxxij PAGElxxxij PAGElxxxij PAGElxxxij that is to say, he is not yet risen from death to life with Christ unto a new life.

column7: Yea saynt Ihon goeth forther and sayeth:
column8: Yea saint Ihon goes further and sayeth:

column7: Who so euer hateth hys brother is a manslayer.
column8: Who so ever hates his brother is a manslayer.

column7: <NOTE>
Surely my frendes the lawe is spirituall, and requyreth also the inwarde affections as Ihon doth here testifye.
column8: Surely my friends the law is spiritual, and requireth also the inward affections as Ihon does here testify.

column7: For not only he that kylleth by layeng on of handes and violence vpon hys brother is in daunger to the law of murther, but also he that pursueth hys neyghbour wyth hatred.
column8: For not only he that killeth by laying on of hands and violence upon his brother is in danger to the law of murder, but also he that pursueth his neighbour with hatred.

column7: So though that he be not a murtherer and masleer in outward dede, yet in harte he is.
column8: So though that he be not a murderer and masleer in outward deed, yet in heart he is.

column7: But no mansleer hath eternal lyfe abydynge in hym.
column8: But no mansleer hath eternal life abiding in him.

column7: For loke wyth what measure we meate to other, <NOTE> wyth the same shall it be measured agayne to vs.
column8: For look with what measure we meat to other, with the same shall it be measured again to us

column7: Now in the doctrine and teachynge of charitie ye shal vnderstande, that it is the maner of thapostles euer to brynge vs to the exemple of Christ, whereby to frame our lyfe, lest we shuld inuent and deuise of our owne heades newe formes & fashions of louing our brethren.
column8: Now in the doctrine and teaching of charity you shall understand, that it is the manner of apostles ever to bring us to the exemple of Christ, whereby to frame our life, lest we should invent and devise of our own heads new forms & fashions of loving our brothers.

column7: S. Ihon therfore doth here preuente vs and setteth forth Christ for an exemple to be folowed of vs, <NOTE> whych loued vs hys brethren not after a lyght and base sorte, but euen wyth the peryll of his owne lyfe.
column8: S. Ihon therefore does here prevent us and sets forth Christ for and exemple to be followed of us, which loved us his brothers not after a light and base sort, but even with the peril of his own life.

column7: He wol haue vs than in lyke wyse to loue our brethren not lyghtly, but so vehemently yt when nede requyreth, we shulde not stycke to venture our goodes yea & our lyfe also for theyr sauetie & welth.
column8: He will have us than in like wise to love our brothers not lightly, but so vehemently that when need requireth, we should not stick to venture our goods yea & our life also for their sauetie & wealth.

column7: By thys we knowe charitie, that is to saye, the loue of Christ towardes vs and what our loue and charitie ought to be, in asmuche as he gaue his soule or lyfe for vs, O what excedynge and vehemente loue was thys of Christ?
column8: By this we know charity, that is to say, the love of Christ towards us and what our love and charity ought to be, in asmuch as he gave his soul or life for us, Oh what exceeding and vehement love was this of Christ?

column7: And shall we then shewe our selues churlysh and vnkynde agayne to hym and not to expresse our loue towardes him vpon our brethre accordynge to hys commaudement?
column8: And shall we then show our selves churlish and kind again to him and not to express our love towards him upon our brethren according to his commaudement?

column7: For that whych is done to them he counteth it done to hym selfe.
column8: For that which is done to them he counteth it done to him self.

column7: Who so euer then hath thys worldes good and seeth hys brother haue nede, and shutteth vp his copassion from hym, how dwelleth the loue of god in hym? As who shulde saye, yf we be not beneficiall and good to our nedy and poore neyghbour, it is a sure token that we loue not God and consequently that he neyther loueth vs. And in contrary wyse, yf we be beneficiall and good to oure neyghboure for gods sake it is a ryght sure sygne and declaracion of our fayth towardes God and that god loueth vs Wherfore (deare brethren) let vs be mercyfull accordynge to thexemple of the heauenly father as Christ monysheth vs Luc. vi.
column8: Who so ever then hath this world's good and sees his brother have need, and shutteth up his copassion from him, how dwells the love of god in him? As who should say, if we be not beneficial and good to our needy and poor neighbour, it is a sure token that we love not God and consequently that he neither loves us And in contrary wise, if we be beneficial and good to our neighbour for gods sake it is a right sure sign and declaration of our faith towards God and that god loves us Wherefore (deer brothers) let us be merciful according to thexemple of the heavenly father as Christ monisheth us Luc. vi.

column7: And let vs not (as Ihon sayeth here) loue in worde, <NOTE> neyther yet in tonge, but in dede and in trouth, and as saynt Paule sayeth, of a pure harte and of a good conscience, and of faith vnfayned.
column8: And let us not (as Ihon sayeth here) love in word, neither yet in tongue, but in deed and in troth, and as saint Paule sayeth, of a pure heart and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned.

column7: Whych thynge he calleth the ende of the comaundement.
column8: Which thing he calls the end of the commandment.

column7: These be the worthy frutes of fayth.
column8: These be the worthy fruits of faith.

column7: These frutes yf we brynge forth we declare our selues to be good trees plated by the ryuer syde whych bryngeth forth frute in due season, <NOTE> we declare oure selues to be of the nombre of them whych S. Ihon here speaketh of, that be translated from death to lyfe euerlastynge.
column8: These fruits if we bring forth we declare our selves to be good trees plated by the river side which bringeth forth fruit in due season, we declare our selves to be of the number of them which S. Ihon here speaks of, that be translated from death to life everlasting.

column7: Where we shall lyue eternally wyth the father, sonne, and holy gost.
column8: Where we shall live eternally with the father, son, and holy ghost.

column7: To whome be all glorye.
column8: To whom be all glory.

column7: AMEN.
column8: AMEN.

column7: : homily P A G Elxxxiij The gospell on.ij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily PAGElxxxiij PAGElxxxiij PAGElxxxiij PAGElxxxiij The gospel on ij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.xiiij. chapter of Luke.
column8: The xiiij chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Christe in thys parable declareth that he is not apte to the kyngdome of heauen whych wyl ones laye hys hande to the plough & loke backe to hys affections.
column8: Christe in this parable declareth that he is not apt to the kingdom of heaven which will ones say his hand to the plough & look back to his affections.

column7: I Esus put forth a similitude to hys disciples, sayenge: A certayne man ordeyned a great supper, and bad many, and sente hys seruaunt at supper tyme, to saye to them that were bydden, come: for al thynges are now ready.
column8: IEsus IEsus put forth a similitude to his disciples, saying: A certain man ordained a great supper, and bade many, and sent his servant at supper time, to say to them that were bidden, come: for all things are now ready.

column7: And they all at once began to make excuse.
column8: And they all at once began to make excuse.

column7: The fyrst sayd vnto hym: I haue bought a farme, and I must nedes go & se it, I pray the haue me excused.
column8: The fyrst said unto him: I have bought a farm, and I must needs go & see it, I pray thee have me excused.

column7: And another sayd: I haue bought fyue yooke of oxen, & I go to proue them I praye the haue me excused.
column8: And another said: I have bought fyue yooke of oxen, & I go to prove them I pray thee have me excused.

column7: And another sayde: I haue maryed a wyfe, and therfore I can not come.
column8: And another said: I have married a wife, and therefore I can not come.

column7: And the seruaunt retourned and brought hys mayster worde agayne therof.
column8: And the servant returned and brought his master word again thereof.

column7: Then was the good man of the house displeased, and sayd to hys seruaunt: Go out quyckely into the stretes and quarters of the cytie and brynge in hyther the poore, and the feble, and the halt, and the blynde.
column8: Then was the good man of the house displeased, and said to his servant: Go out quyckely into the streets and quarters of the city and bring in hither the poor, and the feeble, and the halt, and the blind.

column7: And the seruaunt sayd: Lorde it is done as thou hast commaunded, and yet there is rowme.
column8: And the servant said: Lord it is done as thou hast commanded, and yet there is room.

column7: And the Lorde sayd to the seruaunt: Go out vnto the hye wayes and hedges, and compell them to come in, that my house may be fylled.
column8: And the Lord said to the servant: Go out unto the high ways and hedges, and compel them to come in, that my house may be filled.

column7: For I saye vnto you, that none of those men whych were bydden, shall tast of my supper.
column8: For I say unto you, that none of those men which were bidden, shall taste of my supper.

column7: O Vr Sauiour Christ (good christen people) consyderynge the vanitie of mens myndes in the worlde: whych for the moost parte are wonte rather to talke of God, of hys word, and of the blessed state of the lyfe to come: tha ernestly to appoint theyr mindes to remoue out of theyr lyfes such impedimetes as myght hynder them from God and hys worde & shutte them out in coclusion from the kyngdome of heauen, declareth in thys gospell as in a proper parable the great foly of suche as so content themselfe wyth wordes only and vayne prayses, and consyder no further to temper theyr lyues in suche wyse that an other daye they maye enioye in dede the euerlastynge lyfe in the kyngdome of heauen wherin they confesse so muche blysse & felicitie to be: as one ther was whych was syttynge at the table wyth Christe hearynge hym talke of the resurrection of the iuste, sayd vnto hym: Blyssed is he whych eateth bread in the kyngdome of God.
column8: Our Our Saviour Christ (good christian people) considering the vanity of men's minds in the world: which for the most part are wont rather to talk of God, of his word, and of the blessed state of the life to come: tha earnestly to appoint their minds to remove out of their life's such impedimetes as might hinder them from God and his word & shut them out in coclusion from the kingdom of heaven, declareth in this gospel as in a proper parable the great folly of such as so content themselves with words only and vain praises, and consider no further to temper their lives in such wise that and other day they may enjoy in deed the everlasting life in the kingdom of heaven wherein they confess so much bliss & felicity to be: as one there was which was sitting at the table with Christe hearing him talk of the resurrection of the just, said unto him: Blessed is he which eateth bred in the kingdom of God.

column7: Christ takynge occasion of hys wordes taught both hym and all other in hym, that many ther were whych could cofesse wyth theyr mouth such to be happy yt shulde be receyued there, but yet in the course of theyr lyues semed not much desyrous to be partakers of that blysse, howe greate so euer it be & how frely so euer it be offred: or howe kyndly so euer they be called ther to, whose vnkyndnes, and forgetfulnes of theyr owne welth and commoditie he resembled and lykened to such gestes as were gently & louyngly called to a rych feaste wel & aboundauntly prepared in all thynges, and yet refused to come: hauynge very vayne excuses for them P A G Elxxxiiij selues, whose vnkynde behauiour was reported to the feastmaker & moued hym to displeasure & to renounce them for theyr vnworthynes & to take other to syt at hys feast.
column8: Christ taking occasion of his words taught both him and all other in him, that many there were which could cofesse with their mouth such to be happy that should be received there, but yet in the course of their lives seemed not much desirous to be partakers of that bliss, how great so ever it be & how freely so ever it be offered: or how kindly so ever they be called there to, whose unkindness, and forgetfulness of their own wealth and commodity he resembled and likened to such gests as were gently & lovingly called to a rich feast well & abundantly prepared in all things, and yet refused to come: having very vain excuses for them PAGElxxxiiij PAGElxxxiiij PAGElxxxiiij PAGElxxxiiij selves, whose kind behaviour was reported to the feastmaker & moved him to displeasure & to renounce them for their unworthiness & to take other to fit at his feast.

column7: Whyche although they were but of poore estimation, yet bycause they were ready wt great thankes to receyue the lyberalitie of the feaste maker so gently offred wythout theyr deseruynge, they were admytted to sytte at hys owne table wyth hymselfe & had the fruition of those delicates, which the other that were fyrst called refused & despysed.
column8: Which although they were but of poor estimation, yet because they were ready with great thanks to receive the lyberalitie of the feast maker so gently offered without their deserving, they were admitted to fit at his own table with himself & had the fruition of those delicates, which the other that were fyrst called refused & despised.

column7: Here is mater (my frendes) for vs that be Gentyles to consyder wyth great thankes to almyghty God, <NOTE> where as the people of the Iues were fyrst called by the seruauntes and messangers of hys word, to the great supper of the ioye of heauen, and they refused to come: that then it pleased the father of al mercy to sende hys seruauntes to call vs to his said feast, whych of al people were moost vnworthy, and furdest from hym, in somuch as we were wyde of all truth and lyght, syttynge in moost blynde darkenes of errour and ydolatrye, wanderynge in the bye pathes and croked wayes of our owne lustes and ymaginations, so poore and voyde of all grace that in stede of the true God we honoured mortal men and brute beastes as our God.
column8: Here is mater (my friends) for us that be Gentiles to consider with great thanks to almighty God, where as the people of the Iues were fyrst called by the servants and messengers of his word, to the great supper of the joy of heaven, and they refused to come: that then it pleased the father of all mercy to send his servants to call us to his said feast, which of all people were most unworthy, and furthest from him, in somuch as we were wide of all truth and light, sitting in most blind darkness of error and idolatry, wandering in the buy paths and crooked ways of our own lusts and imaginations, so poor and void of all grace that in stead of the true God we honoured mortal men and brutus beasts as our God.

column7: Thus prouoked we hym fyrst, these were our merytes and deseruynges vnto hym: And yet pleased it hym to sende hys seruauntes to preach vs hys gospell and by the violence of so great gentylnes offered vs and earnest callynge on vs by hys Apostles, we were brought into his holy house & church of hys electe: and there plenteously were set before vs to receyue frely ye innumerable graces & benefytes conteined and promysed in the worde of the gospell: so that now Christ wyth al his ryghtuousnes, wyth all hys iustice and holynes is frely gyuen vs to our welth and commoditie yf we wyll applye our selues by fayth and charitie to oure callynge.
column8: Thus provoked we him fyrst, these were our merits and deservings unto him: And yet pleased it him to send his servants to preach us his gospel and by the violence of so great gentleness offered us and earnest calling on us by his Apostles, we were brought into his holy house & church of his elect: and there plenteously were set before us to receive freely the innumerable graces & benefits contained and promised in the word of the gospel: so that now Christ with all his righteousness, with all his justice and holiness is freely given us to our wealth and commodity if we will apply our selves by faith and charity to our calling.

column7: Yf we se the want of ryghtuousnes in our selfe & be anhongred therfore, let vs sue vnto Christ and he shall replenysh vs therwyth.
column8: If we see the want of righteousness in our self & be anhongred therefore, let us sue unto Christ and he shall replenish us therewith.

column7: Yf we be stuge wyth synne, and wolde be delyuered from the daunger therof: in Christe shall we fynde clere remyssion and shalbe quyte discharged.
column8: If we be stuge with sin, and would be delivered from the danger thereof: in Christe shall we find clear remission and shall quite discharged.

column7: Yf we wante strength to fyght agaynst our inuisible enemyes, the worlde, the fleshe, and the deuell, in Christes power and assystence shall we no fayle haue the victory and ouer come them all.
column8: If we want strength to fight against our invisible enemies, the world, the flesh, and the devil, in Christes power and assistance shall we not fail have the victory and over come them all.

column7: Yf we desyre to be delyuered of thys transytory world and to be present wyth God to syt at hys table, let vs a whyle tary in hope vntyll the Lorde call vs and we shall not doubt but be caryed thyther wyth his holy angels, wyth hym to dwel for euer.
column8: If we desire to be delivered of this transitory world and to be present with God to fit at his table, let us a while tarry in hope until the Lord call us and we shall not doubt but be carried thither with his holy angels, with him to dwell for ever.

column7: He hath not prepared thys supper of euerlastynge lyfe of hys fre mercy onely but hath also as frely prepared all necessarye helpes and meanes for vs to vse to the better attaynynge of thys supper.
column8: He hath not prepared this supper of everlasting life of his from mercy only but hath also as freely prepared all necessary helps and means for us to use to the better attaining of this supper.

column7: Onely let vs be ware by the exemples of the Iues that we be not vnkynde to so mercyfull a callynge leste we be refused as they were.
column8: Only let us be aware by the examples of the Iues that we be not kind to so merciful a calling lest we be refused as they were.

column7: We be not more in gods fauour than they were.
column8: We be not more in gods favour than they were.

column7: They were gods elect people, we were not so.
column8: They were gods elect people, we were not so.

column7: They were ye chyldren of the house, we were foryners and straungers and none of the householde.
column8: They were the children of the house, we were foryners and strangers and none of the household.

column7: They were the natural brauches, we are but grafted in theyr stockes and receyued in theyr rowmes.
column8: They were the natural branches, we are but grafted in their stocks and received in their rooms.

column7: We ought to feare the more, that we P A G Elxxxv shall not be spared, yf we shewe vnkyndnes as they dyd.
column8: We ought to fear the more, that we PAGElxxxv PAGElxxxv PAGElxxxv PAGElxxxv shall not be spared, if we show unkindness as they did.

column7: Ye haue herd what were the lettes, wherby the Iewes were drawen abacke from theyr saluation: One had bought a farme and was so holly bente to improue and enlarge that, to beare rule and raygne in the worlde, that he hadde no leasure nor space to gyue eare to the feastmakers callynge, and to come to hys supper.
column8: You have heard what were the lets, whereby the Jewes were drawn aback from their salvation: One had bought a farm and was so holly bent to improve and enlarge that, to bear rule and reign in the world, that he had no leisure nor space to gyve ear to the feastmakers calling, and to come to his supper.

column7: An other was so busely set about hys oxen and other possession, couetously gatherynge lucre and gaynes, to enrych hymselfe, that he chose rather to lose the commoditie of that delicate supper then to lose hys gaynes.
column8: And other was so busily set about his oxen and other possession, covetously gathering lucre and gains, to enrych himself, that he chosen rather to loose the commodity of that delicate supper then to loose his gains.

column7: An other excused hymselfe that he had maryed a wyfe, and therfore answered he that he coulde not come.
column8: And other excused himself that he had married a wife, and therefore answered he that he could not come.

column7: He desyred not to be excused, as the other two dyd, but sayde flatlye that he coulde not come, so harde it is for hym to come to Christ, whych hath hys harte set vpo ye flateryng vanities and pleasures of the worlde.
column8: He desired not to be excused, as the other two did, but said flatly that he could not come, so harden it is for him to come to Christ, which hath his heart set upon the flattering vanities and pleasures of the world.

column7: Let vs take hede my frendes that we be not so ouercome of these euel affections before rehersed, that we folowe not them and refuse to come to the supper of euerlastyng lyfe wherevnto we be called. <NOTE> Let vs call to mynde what our sauiour Christe sayeth, excepte we renounce all that we possesse, we ca not be hys disciples.
column8: Let us take heed my friends that we be not so overcome of these evil affections before rehearsed, that we follow not them and refuse to come to the supper of everlasting life whereunto we be called. Let us call to mind what our saviour Christe sayeth, except we renounce all that we possess, we ca not be his disciples.

column7: It is not euell to haue rule and dominion in the worlde: but so to set our hartes vpon our dignities and preeminence, that we shal for the sauegard of them forsake the truth, and peruerte iustice: that is abhominable before God.
column8: It is not evil to have rule and dominion in the world: but so to set our hearts upon our dignities and preeminence, that we shall for the safeguard of them forsake the truth, and pervert justice: that is abominable before God.

column7: So to ensue honoure and worshyp, that we shall labour by falshode and sedition, by secrete conspiracye to gette it, that is abominable before God, and wylbe surely reuenged: <NOTE> for God euer hateth the proude in harte, he setteth hymselfe a parte agaynst them, <NOTE> euer to depose such.
column8: So to ensue honour and worship, that we shall labour by falsehood and sedition, by secret conspiracy to get it, that is abominable before God, and wylbe surely revenged: for God ever hates the proud in heart, he sets himself a part against them, ever to depose such.

column7: Though (sayeth Dauid) the vngodlye shryne hymselfe neuer so hye yet I sawe hym whan he was exalted aboue the Cedre trees, brought downe agayne to the grounde: I sought hys rowme and place, but he was wasted and vanyshed awaye lyke the smoke: Kepe therfore (byddeth Dauid) innocency and beholde equitie: for the godly man hath euer permanent issue.
column8: Though (sayeth Dauid) the ungodly shrine himself never so high yet I saw him when he was exalted above the Cedre trees, brought down again to the ground: I sought his room and place, but he was wasted and vanished away like the smoke: Keep therefore (biddeth Dauid) innocency and behold equity: for the godly man hath ever permanent issue.

column7: It is not euell to haue ryches and possessios: to vse the course of lawfull occupyenge, but so to ensue our gaynes that we shall not spare by ryght or wronge to gette them, yt is wyckednes before God.
column8: It is not evil to have riches and possessios: to use the course of lawful occupying, but so to ensue our gains that we shall not spare by right or wrong to get them, that is wickedness before God.

column7: So to possesse ryches that vnmercyfully we shall kepe them and not reliefe the poore with our superfluities, as Christ comaundeth vs to be stewardes of hys goodes comytted in our trust, <NOTE> that is the thynge which prouoketh hym to displeasure to pronouce that it is very harde for a rych man to entre in the kyngdome of heauen: <NOTE> more easy for a camell to go thorowe a nedles eye.
column8: So to possess riches that unmercifully we shall keep them and not relief the poor with our superfluities, as Christ comaundeth us to be stewards of his goods comytted in our trust, that is the thing which provoketh him to displeasure to pronounce that it is very harden for a rich man to enter in the kingdom of heaven: more easy for a camel to go thorough a needles eye.

column7: Of all myschyfe is couetyse the roote and foutayne sayeth S. Paule, <NOTE> & sayeth that they whych desyre to be rych fall into temptacion and snare of the deuell and to dyuerse lustes hurtfull and foolyshe, whyche drowne men in death and destruction.
column8: Of all myschyfe is covetise the root and foutayne sayeth S. Paule, & sayeth that they which desire to be rich fallen into temptation and snare of the devil and to diverse lusts hurtful and foolish, which drown men in death and destruction.

column7: It is that affection sayeth saynte Paule whyche make the suers therof to erre fro theyr fayth: They can neuer haue leasure to wayte vpon Christ and his worde that folowe thys affection: saye, and cal Christ what ye wyl they haue no lust nor desyre to come vnto hym.
column8: It is that affection sayeth faint Paule which make the suers thereof to err from their faith: They can never have leisure to wait upon Christ and his word that follow this affection: say, and call Christ what you will they have no lust nor desire to come unto him.

column7: And the reason of thys thynge he openeth in an other place where he sayeth, <NOTE> that the Gospell is not receyued P A G Elxxxvi of these worldlye men bycause the God of thys worlde hath blynded theyr vnderstandynge leste the lyght of the gospel shuld shyne & appeare vnto the.
column8: And the reason of this thing he openeth in and other place where he sayeth, that the Gospel is not received PAGElxxxvi PAGElxxxvi PAGElxxxvi PAGElxxxvi of these worldly men because the God of this world hath blinded their understanding lest the light of the gospel should shine & appear unto thee.

column7: As these.ij. euell affections I meane the desyre of dominion and authoritie, and the insaciable desyre of ryches be greate impedimentes and lettes that hynder many a man from saluation: so is the affection to pleasures of thys worlde as great a let, in whome it raygneth, to cause them set lytel by the callynge of God to thys great feast of the glorye to come.
column8: As these ij evil affections I mean the desire of dominion and authority, and the insatiable desire of riches be great impediments and lets that hinder many a man from salvation: so is the affection to pleasures of this world as great a let, in whom it reigneth, to cause them set little by the calling of God to this great feast of the glory to come.

column7: This affection is so subtle, that where the other two can not alter and occupye the mynde of many men, yet of thys they be ouercome.
column8: This affection is so subtle, that where the other two can not altar and occupy the mind of many men, yet of this they be overcome.

column7: A beastly affection to be led wyth the volupties of thys worlde, and therfore Christ compareth them to swyne walowynge in the myer of beastly and carnal lyfe, and wolde haue no perles cast before them, for they can none otherwyse do but trede them vnder foote & despyse them.
column8: A beastly affection to be led with the volupties of this world, and therefore Christ compareth them to swine wallowing in the mire of beastly and carnal life, and would have no pearls cast before them, for they can none otherwise doe but trede them under foot & despise them.

column7: Let vs therfore good people take good aduisement, let vs consyder of what gentlenes and mercy we be called.
column8: Let us therefore good people take good advisement, let us consider of what gentleness and mercy we be called.

column7: Let vs consyder whereto we be called, not to payne and mysery, but to feastynge and bankettyng in the kyngdome of heauen.
column8: Let us consider whereto we be called, not to pain and misery, but to feasting and bankettyng in the kingdom of heaven.

column7: We prouoked not God to call vs by our merytes which were nothynge but blyndnes and Idolatry, but he of hys mercy preuented vs, only to haue ye prayse of our saluacion which wyl come at hys calling.
column8: We provoked not God to call us by our merits which were nothing but blindness and Idolatry, but he of his mercy prevented us, only to have you praise of our salvation which will come at his calling.

column7: Let vs cosider how great a zele God beareth to our helth whych semeth to be angrye whan we refuse to come at hys callynge, & not only calleth vs and leaueth vs there, but hath prouided all thynges to helpe vs to come thyther whervnto we be called, hys worde we haue, hys sacrametes, and hys holy spirite workynge in our hartes we haue, to be present wyth vs, to strength vs to come.
column8: Let us consider how great a zeal God bears to our health which seemeth to be angry when we refuse to come at his calling, & not only calls us and leaveth us there, but hath provided all things to help us to come thither whereunto we be called, his word we have, his sacrametes, and his holy spirit working in our hearts we have, to be present with us, to strength us to come.

column7: Yf we come we be saued and shalbe blessed for euer, if we com not but make our excuses, we deceiue our selues, and for the loue of vayne and transytory delytes and pleasures lose the lyfe euerlastynge.
column8: If we come we be saved and shall blessed for ever, if we come not but make our excuses, we deceive our selves, and for the love of vain and transitory delights and pleasures loose the life everlasting.

column7: And what shall it auayle to wynne all the worlde & lose our soules Yf we refuse to come to thys feast, let vs not loke to be bydden to any other: for it is ye last feast and none other to be loked for after.
column8: And what shall it avail to win all the world & loose our souls If we refuse to come to this feast, let us not look to be bidden to any other: for it is the last feast and none other to be looked for after.

column7: No better messanger could he sende to vs to moue vs to come to thys feast than hys owne welbeloued sonne.
column8: No better messenger could he send to us to move us to come to this feast than his own well-beloved son.

column7: God graunt vs all grace so to heare the callynge of almyghtye God to thys hys mercyfull feaste, that we may be redy to come vnto hym in thys lyfe by grace and in the lyfe to come to be at the feaste wyth hym in hys heauenly kyngdome in glorye.
column8: God grant us all grace so to hear the calling of almighty God to this his merciful feast, that we may be ready to come unto him in this life by grace and in the life to come to be at the feast with him in his heavenly kingdom in glory.

column7: To whome wyth the sonne, and the holy goost be euermore honoure and prayse worlde wythout ende.
column8: To whom with the son, and the holy ghost be evermore honour and praise world without end.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.iij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the iij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.i. epistle of Peter the.v. Chapter.
column8: The i epistle of Peter the v Chapter.

column7: Thargument An exhortacion to humilitie.
column8: Thargument And exhortation to humility.

column7: B Rethren, submyt your selues therfore vnder the myghtye hande of God, that he maye exalte you whan the tyme is come.
column8: BRethren BRethren, submit your selves therefore under the mighty hand of God, that he may exalt you when the time is come.

column7: Cast all your care vpo him: for he careth for you.
column8: Cast all your care upon him: for he careth for you.

column7: Be sober & watch, for your aduersary the deuell as a roarynge Lyon walketh about, sekynge whome he maye deuoure: P A G Elxxxvij whom resyst stedfast in the fayth, knowynge, that the same afflictions are apoynted vnto youre brethren, that are in the worlde.
column8: Be sober & watch, for your adversary the devil as a roaring Lion walks about, seeking whom he may devour: PAGElxxxvij PAGElxxxvij PAGElxxxvij PAGElxxxvij whom resist steadfast in the faith, knowing, that the same afflictions are appointed unto your brothers, that are in the world.

column7: But the God of all grace whych hath called vs vnto hys eternall glory by Christ Iesus, shall hys owne selfe (after that ye haue suffred a lytell affliccion) make you perfyt setle, strength, and stablysh you.
column8: But the God of all grace which hath called us unto his eternal glory by Christ Jesus, shall his own self (after that you have suffered a little affliction) make you perfect settle, strength, and stablish you.

column7: To him be glorye and dominion for euer and euer.
column8: To him be glory and dominion for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: T Hys epistle (good people) is a ryght comfortable lesson, exhortynge vs to lowlynes and modestye by the hope of euerlastynge rewardes whych remayne vnto vs. Fyrst therfore saynt Peter byddeth vs here to be humbled vnder the myghty hade of god.
column8: This This epistle (good people) is a right comfortable lesson, exhorting us to lowliness and modesty by the hope of everlasting rewards which remain unto us Fyrst therefore saint Peter biddeth us here to be humbled under the mighty hade of god.

column7: But what calleth the scripture to be hubled? <NOTE> Surely to be humbled sygnifyeth in holy scripture to be throwen downe, to be depressed, and vtterly to be brought to nought, so that dispayryng of al mas helpe, we perceyue both that we be nothynge & that we can do nothyng, vpon whych humilitie also a certayne outwarde sobernes and mekenes foloweth towardes the worlde.
column8: But what calls the scripture to be hubled? Surely to be humbled signifieth in holy scripture to be thrown down, to be depressed, and utterly to be brought to nought, so that despairing of all mass help, we perceive both that we be nothing & that we can do nothing, upon which humility also a certain outward soberness and meekness followeth towards the world.

column7: They that in thys wyse beynge humbled, do cast the hole trust and affiauce of theyr harte vpon God shall at length no doubt be promoted and auaunced vp on hygh.
column8: They that in this wise being humbled, do cast the hold trust and affiance of their heart upon God shall at length no doubt be promoted and advanced up on high.

column7: Let vs then my frendes be humbled, let vs submytte oure selues vnder the myghty hade of God, that is to say let vs know, that whyle we submytte oure selues one to another, <NOTE> exhibite and do thys office of obediece not to me, but to God hymselfe.
column8: Let us then my friends be humbled, let us submit our selves under the mighty hade of God, that is to say let us know, that while we submit our selves one to another, exhibit and do this office of obedience not to me, but to God himself.

column7: And assuredly thys oughte to be a ryght syngular comforte vnto vs, yf we knowe that we by our obedience do please not me only, but also God hymselfe.
column8: And assuredly this ought to be a right singular comfort unto us, if we know that we by our obedience do please not me only, but also God himself.

column7: But ye woll obiecte agaynst me.
column8: But you will object against me.

column7: Who wolde not wysh to be obedient vnto God?
column8: Who would not wish to be obedient unto God?

column7: Ye saye well, but we worship God wyth thoffice and seruice of obedience, whan we honoure our neyghbour wyth obedience, whom god commaundeth to be honoured.
column8: You say well, but we worship God with intent and service of obedience, when we honour our neighbour with obedience, whom god commandeth to be honoured.

column7: Let vs then my frendes be meke and huble aswell in weale as in wo, and let vs euermore haue in remembraunce the myghty hande of God, wherewyth we knowe that we shall ones be delyuered, yea and also be exalted.
column8: Let us then my friends be meek and huble aswell in weal as in woe, and let us evermore have in remembrance the mighty hand of God, wherewith we know that we shall ones be delivered, yea and also be exalted.

column7: But when? surely in due tyme, not whan it semeth good to vs, but whan God shall se it moost conuenient for vs. And let vs cast all our care vpon hym, let vs (I saye) commende and commytte our cause to God, whych shall fyght and care for vs.
column8: But when? surely in due time, not when it seemeth good to us, but when God shall see it most convenient for us And let us cast all our care upon him, let us (I say) commend and commit our cause to God, which shall fight and care for us

column7: Seconde, for asmuch as the deuel hateth nothynge worse then mutuall obedience and subiection in the congregacion: <NOTE> Peter also in thys epistle monysheth vs that we shulde be sobre & watch, lest ye deuell disturbe our concorde, and whyle we be aslepe come and sowe tares accordynge to the parable of Christ in the.xiij. chapter of Matheu.
column8: Second, for as as the devil hates nothing worse then mutual obedience and subjection in the congregation: Peter also in this epistle monisheth us that we should be sober & watch, lest you devil disturb our concord, and while we be asleep come and sow tares according to the parable of Christ in the xiij chapter of Matheu.

column7: Let vs tha be sober aswel in our doctrine, as in our outwarde couersation and maners of lyfe.
column8: Let us than be sober aswell in our doctrine, as in our outward conversation and manners of life.

column7: Let vs be vigilant & prudent in all our doynges and procedynges.
column8: Let us be vigilant & prudent in all our doings and proceedings.

column7: And why?
column8: And why?

column7: For our aduersary (I say not ye worldes aduersary but ye aduersary of the which folow godlynes,) I meane the deuell busely wythout ceasynge walketh about lyke a roarynge Lyon on euery syde, <NOTE> to what ende? to deuoure and vtterly to destroye vs. Surely (good people our mortall enemye the deuell is euer lyenge in wayte not agaynst the worlde but P A G Elxxxviij agaynst such as renounce the worlde & folow Christ I meane such as be ryght christian me and women to thintent he myghte chase and dryue them awaye from the confession of the Gospel vnto foule and vncleane lustes, whome onles we resyst wyth fayth, sobrenes, watchyng, and warenes, he wol surely haue the vpper hande of vs, and cast vs downe hedlong.
column8: For our adversary (I say not the world's adversary but you adversary of the which follow godliness,) I mean the devil busily without ceasing walks about like a roaring Lion on every side, to what end? to devour and utterly to destroy us Surely (good people our mortal enemy the devil is ever lying in wait not against the world but PAGElxxxviij PAGElxxxviij PAGElxxxviij PAGElxxxviij against such as renounce the world & follow Christ I mean such as be right christian me and women to intent he might chase and drive them away from the confession of the Gospel unto foul and unclean lusts, whom unless we resist with faith, soberness, watching, and wariness, he will surely have the upper hand of us, and cast us down headlong.

column7: How then shall we chase awaye the deuel? wyth outwarde and carnall thynges?
column8: How then shall we chase away the devil? with outward and carnal things?

column7: No truly, but with stedfast fayth, whych commeth from the harte cleauyng fast to Christ the Lorde and conquerour of Satan our enemye, knowynge this, <NOTE> the same affliccios be appoynted to ye hole christen brotherhod through out the worlde.
column8: No truly, but with steadfast faith, which comes from the heart cleaving fast to Christ the Lord and conqueror of Satan our enemy, knowing this, the same affliccios be appointed to you hold christian brotherhood through out the world.

column7: Wherfore we ought not to thynke that we only be tempted and troubled, but we suffer it in comune wyth so many as are earnest beleuers of Christes holy worde.
column8: Wherefore we ought not to think that we only be tempted and troubled, but we suffer it in common with so many as are earnest believers of Christes holy word.

column7: Fynally we be here coforted agaynst the crosse and temptacions and be put in mynde by saynt Peter, yt the God of all grace whych hath called vs to hys eternal glorye by Christ our Lorde, woll at last delyuer vs, and not suffer vs to be tempted aboue oure powers, and where he suffreth vs to be tempted, yet he wyll make perfyte our temptacions and wyl confirme, strengthen, and stablysh vs in them, lest we perysh or take a fal and so be vtterly vainquyshed of our enemy and be confounded.
column8: Finally we be here coforted against the cross and temptations and be put in mind by saint Peter, that the God of all grace which hath called us to his eternal glory by Christ our Lord, will at last deliver us, and not suffer us to be tempted above our powers, and where he suffers us to be tempted, yet he will make perfect our temptations and will confirm, strengthen, and stablish us in them, lest we perish or take a fall and so be utterly vanquished of our enemy and be confounded.

column7: To hym be glorye, prayse, & dominion worlde wythout ende.
column8: To him be glory, praise, & dominion world without end.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospell on the.iij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the iij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.xv. chapter of Luke.
column8: The xv chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: The parable of the hundred shepe and of the grote.
column8: The parable of the hundred sheep and of the groat.

column7: T Hen resorted vnto hym all the publicanes & synners, for to heare hym.
column8: THen THen resorted unto him all the publicans & sinners, for to hear him.

column7: And the pharisees and scribes murmured, sayenge: He receyueth synners, and eateth wyth them.
column8: And the pharisees and scribes murmured, saying: He receiveth sinners, and eateth with them.

column7: But he put forth thys parable vnto them, sayenge: What man of you hauynge an hundred shepe (yf he lose one of them) doth not leaue nynty and nyne in the wyldernes, & go after that whych is lost, vntyll he fynde it?
column8: But he put forth this parable unto them, saying: What man of you having and hundred sheep (if he loose one of them) does not leave nynty and nyne in the wilderness, & go after that which is lost, until he find it?

column7: And whan he hath founde it, he layeth it on his shulders wyth ioye.
column8: And when he hath found it, he layeth it on his shoulders with joy.

column7: And assone as he cometh home, he calleth together hys louers and neyghbours, sayenge vnto them: Reioyse wyth me for I haue foude my shepe, whych was lost.
column8: And assoon as he comes home, he calls together his lovers and neighbours, saying unto them: Rejoice with me for I have foude my sheep, which was lost.

column7: I saye vnto you, that lykewyse ioye shalbe in heauen ouer one synner that repenteth, more than ouer nyntye and nyne iust persons, whych nede no repentaunce.
column8: I say unto you, that likewise joy shall in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over nyntye and nyne just persons, which need no repentance.

column7: Eyther what woman hauynge ten grotes, yf she lose one doth not she lyght a candell, and swepe the house, and seke diligently tyl she fynde it?
column8: Either what woman having ten grotes, if she loose one does not she light a candle, and swepe the house, and seek diligently till she find it?

column7: And whan she hath founde it, she calleth her louers and her neghbours together, sayenge: Reioyce wyth me, for I haue founde the grote whych I had lost.
column8: And when she hath found it, she calls her lovers and her neighbours together, saying: Rejoice with me, for I have found the groat which I had lost.

column7: Lykewise I say vnto you, shall there be ioye in the presence of the angels of god, ouer one synner that repenteth.
column8: Likewise I say unto you, shall there be joy in the presence of the angels of god, over one sinner that repenteth.

column7: P A G Elxxxix IN thys Gospell (deare brethren) is set before our eyen the notable exemple of the louyng kyndnes and mercy of Christ towardes vs wretched synners and lost shepe, vnto whome only thys gospell is propouned for a synguler comforte.
column8: PAGElxxxix PAGElxxxix PAGElxxxix PAGElxxxix IN this Gospel (deer brothers) is set before our eyes the notable exemple of the loving kindness and mercy of Christ towards us wretched sinners and lost sheep, unto whom only this gospel is proponed for a singular comfort.

column7: For the pharisees & scribes whych be blynded with theyr owne proper iustice, be not only no partakers of thys moost comfortable Gospell, but more ouer they vtterly vnderstad it not.
column8: For the pharisees & scribes which be blinded with their own proper justice, be not only no partakers of this most comfortable Gospel, but more over they utterly vnderstad it not.

column7: Yea whan they se that Christe bestoweth hys Gospell vpon synners, they grudge therat, & inuye that they shulde haue such fauour and grace at hys handes.
column8: Yea when they see that Christe bestoweth his Gospel upon sinners, they grudge thereat, & inuye that they should have such favour and grace at his hands.

column7: The publicanes then, that is to saye, customers, <NOTE> tribute gatherers, or baylyfes, whych amonges the Iues and namely amoges the religiouse pharisees were counted vnholy persons, and the other notorious and open synners resorted to Christe, to heare hym.
column8: The publicans then, that is to say, customers, tribute gatherers, or baliffs, which among the Iues and namely amoges the religious pharisees were counted unholy persons, and the other notorious and open sinners resorted to Christe, to hear him.

column7: They had herde much of hym, and what wonders and myracles he had shewed amonges the people, and namely they had herde of hys comfortable doctrine.
column8: They had herd much of him, and what wonders and miracles he had showed among the people, and namely they had herd of his comfortable doctrine.

column7: Wherfore they come now, knowyng them selues synners, and therfore not quyet in theyr coscience, to seke rest to theyr soules, and to heare Christ, whome forthwyth he louyngly receyueth, and lyke a tender and a good phisician goeth about to laye his medecine and salue to theyr diseases.
column8: Wherefore they come now, knowing them selves sinners, and therefore not quiet in their conscience, to seek rest to their souls, and to hear Christ, whom forthwith he lovingly receiveth, and like a tender and a good physician goes about to say his medicine and salve to their diseases.

column7: All hys pacient hearers and humble suters he healeth, not onely in body, but also in soule.
column8: All his patient hearers and humble suitors he heals, not only in body, but also in soul.

column7: But the moost holy and religious pharisees and famouse doctours of the law and scribes are nothynge content herewt, they murmoure, they grudge, they snouffe at hym, and what saye they?
column8: But the most holy and religious pharisees and famous doctors of the law and scribes are nothing content herewt, they murmoure, they grudge, they snouffe at him, and what say they?

column7: Lo thys felowe, whyche is reported to be the sonne of God and whych maketh himselfe so perfyte and holy a persone receyueth synful persons in to hys company, and eateth & drynketh wyth them.
column8: Lo this fellow, which is reported to be the son of God and which makes himself so perfect and holy a person receiveth sinful persons in to his company, and eateth & drinketh with them.

column7: But he put forth this parable vnto them.
column8: But he put forth this parable unto them.

column7: &c. Good people ye shal vnderstande, that our mayster Christ bycause he wolde not gyue a iust cause of offense to the pharisees & scribes, studyeth to heale them wyth two feate parables, by whych he teacheth, that not without cause, he receiueth synners and eateth with them.
column8: etc. Good people you shall understand, that our master Christ because he would not gyve a just cause of offence to the pharisees & scribes, studieth to heal them with two feat parables, by which he teaches, that not without cause, he receiveth sinners and eateth with them.

column7: Yea he declareth, that hys office requyreth to preache glad tydynges to the poore, not to breake a broused rede, nor to quenche the smokynge flaxe, as Esay had prophecyed of hym. <NOTE> Moreouer that hys offyce and feate was to feede hys flocke lyke a shepeherde, to gather together the lambes with hys arme to releue them in hys bosome, <NOTE> also such as be lost to seke vp, such as go astraye to brynge agayne, suche as be wounded to bynde vp, suche as be weake to make stronge, and so forth.
column8: Yea he declareth, that his office requireth to preach glad tidings to the poor, not to break a broused rede, nor to quench the smoking flax, as Esay had prophesied of him. Moreover that his office and feat was to feed his flock like a shepherd, to gather together the lambs with his arm to relieve them in his bosom, also such as be lost to seek up, such as go astray to bring again, such as be wounded to bind up, such as be weak to make strong, and so forth.

column7: Al these offyces of Christ be euery where recorded in scripture, and he doth expresse them here in the parables insuynge, to thintet he wolde shewe that he doth not amysse in that he receyueth synners and taketh meate wyth them.
column8: All these offices of Christ be every where recorded in scripture, and he does express them here in the parables ensuing, to thintet he would show that he does not amiss in that he receiveth sinners and takes meat with them.

column7: In dede Christ myght haue made answere to the pharisees and scribes wythout parables euen wyth open textes out of the prophetes concernynge hys offices But thys he doth not, that hearynge they shuld not heare, and seynge they shuld not se, but at last shuld peryshe by the iust iudgement of God.
column8: In deed Christ might have made answer to the pharisees and scribes without parables even with open texts out of the prophets concerning his offices But this he does not, that hearing they should not hear, and sing they should not see, but at last should perish by the just judgement of God.

column7: And in these parables lyeth hyd the ryght dradfull iudgement of God agaynst these proude religious and holy pharisees that woll euermore iustifye themselues which P A G Exc shalbe reiected and shaken of wyth theyr iusticies, where as the penitent and lowly synners shalbe receyued.
column8: And in these parables lies hid the right dreadful judgement of God against these proud religious and holy pharisees that will evermore justify themselves which PAGExc PAGExc PAGExc PAGExc shall rejected and shaken of with their justices, where as the penitent and lowly sinners shall received.

column7: What man of you, (sayth Christe) whyche yf he haue an hundred shepe and fortune to lose one of them wyll not forthwyth leaue the fourescore & nyntene in wyldernesse, and go after that whych is lost vntyll he fynde it?
column8: What man of you, (say Christe) which if he have and hundred sheep and fortune to loose one of them will not forthwith leave the fourescore & nyntene in wilderness, and go after that which is lost until he find it?

column7: And whan he hath founde it, for ioye he layeth it on hys shulders, and he cometh not so sone home, but he calleth together hys frendes & hys neyghbours and desyreth them to reioyse wyth hym for the fyndynge agayne of hys lost shepe.
column8: And when he hath found it, for joy he layeth it on his shoulders, and he comes not so soon home, but he calls together his friends & his neighbours and desireth them to rejoice with him for the finding again of his lost sheep.

column7: So sayeth Christ, ioye shalbe in heauen ouer one synner that repenteth more then ouer foure score and.xix. persons whych nede no repentaunce.
column8: So sayeth Christ, joy shall in heaven over one sinner that repenteth more then over foure score and xix persons which need no repentance.

column7: My frendes what meaneth thys parable? <NOTE> who is thys sheperd or shepemayster?
column8: My friends what means this parable? who is this sheperd or shepemayster?

column7: Surely it is our mayster Christ, he fedeth hys shepe, he teacheth all men in the wylsome & deserte worlde, of these shepe, one strayth abrode and is lost, the other in theyr owne conceytes and iudgement erre not but be styll in the ryght waye and therfore they nede not to be sought and to be redemed.
column8: Surely it is our master Christ, he feedeth his sheep, he teaches all men in the wylsome & desert world, of these sheep, one strayth abroad and is lost, the other in their own conceits and judgement err not but be still in the right way and therefore they need not to be sought and to be redeemed.

column7: And truly (good people) the nomber is very smal of them yt shalbe saued, for the rest of the people thinke themselues iust and ryghtuous persons by the merytes of theyr owne workes.
column8: And truly (good people) the number is very small of them that shall saved, for the rest of the people think themselves just and righteous persons by the merits of their own works.

column7: The shepe that goeth a straye sygnifyeth them whych know themselues synners, these doth Christ seke vp, yea he came for these mens sakes that he myght redeme them.
column8: The sheep that goes a stray signifieth them which know themselves sinners, these does Christ seek up, yea he came for these men's sakes that he might redeem them.

column7: Here then ye se the fynall cause and vse of Christ. <NOTE> The sonne of man came to seke and saue that was lost, he came in to thys worlde to saue synners.
column8: Here then you see the final cause and use of Christ. The son of man came to seek and save that was lost, he came in to this world to save sinners.

column7: So then there be.ij. sortes of iust or ryghtuous persons in the worlde.
column8: So then there be ij sorts of just or righteous persons in the world.

column7: He that knowlegeth his synnes & vnworthines, and beleueth on hym that iustifyeth the wycked, is iuste by fayth, and he is the true iust and good person.
column8: He that knowledgeth his sins & unworthiness, and believeth on him that justifieth the wicked, is just by faith, and he is the true just and good person.

column7: The other is he that woll be iustifyed & made good by the workes of the lawe, <NOTE> thys iustice is called the pharisaicall iustice.
column8: The other is he that will be justified & made good by the works of the law, this justice is called the pharisaical justice.

column7: Of thys iustice Christ speaketh thus.
column8: Of this justice Christ speaks thus.

column7: Onles your ryghtuousnes passe the ryghtuousnes of the scribes and pharisees, ye shall not entre into the kyngdome of God. <NOTE> And in the.xvi. chapter of Luke he sayeth.
column8: Unless your righteousness pass the righteousness of the scribes and pharisees, you shall not enter into the kingdom of God. And in the xvi chapter of Luke he sayeth.

column7: Ye be they which iustify your selues before men, but God knoweth your hartes.
column8: You be they which justify your selves before men, but God knoweth your hearts.

column7: The seconde parable of the woman whych had lost a grote, and after much sekynge, founde it agayne, meaneth the same thynge, that ye other parable doth In dede the woman is a weake vessell. <NOTE> Christe applyeth hymselfe to the weake and vnperfyte persons.
column8: The seconde parable of the woman which had lost a groat, and after much seeking, found it again, means the same thing, that you other parable does In deed the woman is a weak vessel. Christe applieth himself to the weak and unperfect persons.

column7: The woman lyghteth a candell, swepeth her house, seketh diligently her coigne that she hath lost she neuer ceaseth tyl she hath foude it agayne.
column8: The woman lighteth a candle, sweepeth her house, seeketh diligently her coign that she hath lost she never ceases till she hath foude it again.

column7: Euen so carefull and desyrous is our Sauiour Christe to call synners to repentaunce. <NOTE> yf ye woll knowe the cause of our repentaunce, ye shall vnderstande, that it is not our owne worke nor our owne meryte and deseruynge, but bycause Christ our shepeherde seketh vs, yea we shulde vtterly perysh strayenge in the wyldernes, yf Christ our herdma sought vs not vp.
column8: Euen so careful and desirous is our Saviour Christe to call sinners to repentance. if you will know the cause of our repentance, you shall understand, that it is not our own work nor our own merit and deserving, but because Christ our shepherd seeketh us, yea we should utterly perish strayenge in the wilderness, if Christ our herdma sought us not up.

column7: But how doth he seke vs?
column8: But how does he seek us?

column7: Truly by hys worde, whyche beynge preached vnto vs reproueth vs of our wandrynge and strayenge abrode, whyche knowen, we be brought agayne by Christe our pastoure and shepeherde to the flocke, that is to wyte, we be made the true members of the true church.
column8: Truly by his word, which being preached unto us reproveth us of our wandering and strayenge abroad, which known, we be brought again by Christe our pasture and shepherd to the flock, that is to wit, we be made the true members of the true church.

column7: And after P A G Exci we be ones reduced and broughte home agayne to the flocke, we be not set in a felde alone by our selues, where we alone shall fede, but togyther wyth yt rest of the flocke and vnder our shepeherde we seke all one and the same fode and do the same that the rest of the shepe do.
column8: And after PAGExci PAGExci PAGExci PAGExci we be ones reduced and brought home again to the flock, we be not set in a field alone by our selves, where we alone shall fede, but together with that rest of the flock and under our shepherd we seek all one and the same food and do the same that the rest of the sheep do.

column7: Finally forasmuch as Christ sayeth, that the angels in heauen do ioye vpon such as repent, we be here taught yt repentaunce is a worke very acceptable and pleasynge to God.
column8: Finally forasmuch as Christ sayeth, that the angels in heaven do joy upon such as repent, we be here taught that repentance is a work very acceptable and pleasing to God.

column7: Wherfore my frendes let vs not be lykened to these religiouse proude and presumptuouse Pharisees & scribes whych murmured and grudged at the teder harte and kyndnes of our Sauiour Christ, & which iustifyed themselues; despysynge all other in comparison of them, bycause of theyr owne tradicions and obseruaunces & therfore thoughte they had no nede of Christ.
