column8: Wherefore my friends let us not be likened to these religious proud and presumptuous Pharisees & scribes which murmured and grudged at the teder heart and kindness of our Saviour Christ, & which justified themselves; despising all other in comparison of them, because of their own traditions and observances & therefore thought they had no need of Christ.

column7: But let vs humbly and thankfully at the preachynge of Christes holy worde, whyche it hathe pleased hym now in these last dayes to disclose and open agayne vnto vs, to repente vs of oure wandrynge out of the ryght waye.
column8: But let us humbly and thankfully at the preaching of Christes holy word, which it hath pleased him now in these last days to disclose and open again unto us, to repent us of our wandering out of the right way.

column7: And tha doubtles the angels in heauen shall haue more ioye ouer vs, tha ouer all those which were counted moost holy & perfyte persons in the syght of the worlde.
column8: And than doubtless the angels in heaven shall have more joy over us, than over all those which were counted most holy & perfect persons in the sight of the world.

column7: Whych angels also at oure departure out of thys vale of mysery shal cary vp our soules into heuen, where we shall haue the moost ful fruition of all ioye wyth Christe our Lorde.
column8: Which angels also at our departure out of this vale of misery shall carry up our souls into heaven, where we shall have the most full fruition of all joy with Christe our Lord.

column7: To whome wyth the father and holy goost be all glorye.
column8: To whom with the father and holy ghost be all glory.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.iiij. sondaye after trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the iiij sondaye after trinity.

column7: The.viij. chapter to the Romaynes.
column8: The viij chapter to the Romans.

column7: Thargument In thys epistle we be comforted to beare aduersitie well in worth, seynge it is the waye to euerlastynge glorye.
column8: Thargument In this epistle we be comforted to bear adversity well in worth, sing it is the way to everlasting glory.

column7: B Rethren, I suppose that the afflictions of thys lyfe, are not worthy of the glory, whych shal be shewed vpon vs. For the feruent desyre of the creature abydeth, lokynge whan the sonnes of god shall appeare, bycause the creature is subdued to vanitie, agaynst the wyll therof, but for hys wyll whych hath subdued the same in hope.
column8: BRethren BRethren, I suppose that the afflictions of this life, are not worthy of the glory, which shall be showed upon us For the fervent desire of the creature abideth, looking when the sons of god shall appear, because the creature is subdued to vanity, against the will thereof, but for his will which hath subdued the same in hope.

column7: For the same creature shalbe deliuered from the bondage of corrupcion into the glorious libertie of the sonnes of God.
column8: For the same creature shall delivered from the bondage of corruption into the glorious liberty of the sons of God.

column7: For we know, that euery creature groneth wyth vs also, and trauayleth in payne, euen vnto thys tyme.
column8: For we know, that every creature groans with us also, and travaileth in pain, even unto this time.

column7: Not only it, but we also which haue the fyrst frutes of the spirite, mourne in our selues also and wayte for the adoption of the chyldre of god euen the delyueraunce of our bodye.
column8: Not only it, but we also which have the fyrst fruits of the spirit, mourn in our selves also and wait for the adoption of the children of god even the deliverance of our body.

column7: T He holy Apostle saynt Paule welbeloued brethren and systers consyderyng the state of true christen men whych lyue godly in thys worlde to be full of aduersities and troubles whych be offred vnto them both by the worlde, <NOTE> the fleshe, and the deuel, and knowynge the weake power of frayle men to be farre vnable to stande stedfastly in them, onles they be armed & fensed with the armoure of gods worde, exhorteth vs therfore in thys epistle by dyuerse reasons P A G Elxcij to pacience and sufferauce: and comforteth vs wyth the great ioye and glorye that shal be declared vnto vs in the worlde to come.
column8: THe THe holy Apostle saint Paule well-beloved brothers and sisters considering the state of true christian men which live godly in this world to be full of adversities and troubles which be offered unto them both by the world, the flesh, and the devil, and knowing the weak power of frail men to be far unable to stand steadfastly in them, unless they be armed & fenced with the armour of gods word, exhorteth us therefore in this epistle by diverse reasons PAGElxcij PAGElxcij PAGElxcij PAGElxcij to patience and sufferance: and comforts us with the great joy and glory that shall be declared unto us in the world to come.

column7: He affirmeth vnto vs that what so euer we can suffer in thys worlde is but shorte and transytory: but the ioye that we shall receyue is durable and euerlastynge.
column8: He affirmeth unto us that what so ever we can suffer in this world is but short and transitory: but the joy that we shall receive is durable and everlasting.

column7: Howe great so euer the payne be of oure aduersitie that we suffer here, I thynke it nothynge (sayeth saynt Paule) to ye glorye that shall appeare vnto vs, which is so great and infinite that it can not be comprehended of any mans vnderstandynge. <NOTE> It farre passeth the eye of man to se thorowe it, or the eare to heare ye greatnes therof or the harte of man to vnderstande the glorye that God hath prepared for them yt loue hym, which are content after the exemple of hys welbeloued son Christ to suffer and to beare theyr crosse wyth good harte and wyll.
column8: Howe great so ever the pain be of our adversity that we suffer here, I think it nothing (sayeth saint Paule) to the glory that shall appear unto us, which is so great and infinite that it can not be comprehended of any men understanding. It far passes the eye of man to see thorough it, or the ear to hear you greatness thereof or the heart of man to understand the glory that God hath prepared for them that love him, which are content after the exemple of his well-beloved son Christ to suffer and to bear their cross with good heart and will.

column7: Let vs therfore behold not so much the grefe and despyte of persecution and despleasures of thys worlde, as the bryghtnes and excellency of the glorye that we shalbe in, whyche although we se it not wyth our corporall eye, yet wyth the eye of our fayth in the myrrour of goddes worde we se it much more clerly, and shall more surely enioye it tha we se & enioye those thynges, whyche be vnder oure corporall syght.
column8: Let us therefore behold not so much the grief and despite of persecution and despleasures of this world, as the brightness and excellency of the glory that we shall in, which although we see it not with our corporal eye, yet with the eye of our faith in the mirror of gods word we see it much more clearly, and shall more surely enjoy it than we see & enjoy those things, which be under our corporal sight.

column7: Yf the greatnes of aduersitie feareth vs, let vs call to mynde that whan we suffer innocently, we suffer wyth Christ and Christ wyth vs. Yf we be of the body by true fayth, than maye we be sure that the heade beareth parte wyth vs and helpeth vs in our aduersitie.
column8: If the greatness of adversity fears us, let us call to mind that when we suffer innocently, we suffer with Christ and Christ with us If we be of the body by true faith, than may we be sure that the head bears part with us and helpeth us in our adversity.

column7: In hys power & assistence we shall ouercome.
column8: In his power & assistance we shall overcome.

column7: Of our selfe we be to weake, but in hys power sayeth saynt Paule in whom is my coforte <NOTE> I can do all thynges.
column8: Of our self we be to weak, but in his power sayeth saint Paule in whom is my coforte I can do all things.

column7: Let noman thynke it impossible to beare paciently the losse of name, of goodes, of wyfe and chyldren, to beare the great assaultes of the deuels temptacions: for to ouercome the stronge & vnruly affections of our corrupte nature, and thervpon in cowardnes to gyue ouer and suffer our selues to be led vnder theyr captiuitie, nay there is nothynge to harde to be performed of a christian man in whome the spirite of God is abydynge.
column8: Let noman think it impossible to bear patiently the loss of name, of goods, of wife and children, to bear the great assaults of the devils temptations: for to overcome the strong & unruly affections of our corrupt nature, and thereupon in cowardness to gyve over and suffer our selves to be led under their captivity, nay there is nothing to harden to be performed of a christian man in whom the spirit of God is abiding.

column7: <NOTE> Take good hart sayeth our Sauiour and captaine Christ I haue ouercome the worlde and al these for you.
column8: Take good heart sayeth our Saviour and captain Christ I have overcome the world and all these for you.

column7: It is not impossible for you to resyst & to haue the victory: for fayth subdueth all thynges and hath the victory of al thynges that be agaynst you, for al thynges be possible to fayth. <NOTE> Thys is the comforte that a christian man maye haue to consyder that it is not hys aduersitie alone whyche he suffreth, but Christ hys heade and captayne suffereth wyth hym.
column8: It is not impossible for you to resist & to have the victory: for faith subdueth all things and hath the victory of all things that be against you, for all things be possible to faith. This is the comfort that a christian man may have to consider that it is not his adversity alone which he suffers, but Christ his head and captain suffers with him.

column7: As he sayd to Saul wha he persecuted the christian men, <NOTE> Saul Saul, why doest thou persecute me?
column8: As he said to Saul wha he persecuted the christian men, Saul Saul, why dost thou persecute me?

column7: It ought to be no straunge thynge to vs to suffer. <NOTE> For saynt Paul sayeth that we be ordeyned for thys vse and purpose.
column8: It ought to be no strange thing to us to suffer. For saint Paul sayeth that we be ordained for this use and purpose.

column7: In chastisement doth god nurture his chyldren whome he loueth.
column8: In chastisement does god nurture his children whom he loves.

column7: Yf our lyfe be in chastisement and aduersitie and we lyue in paciece: we may haue good hope that as we be made lyke to Christe in trouble and affliction, so shall we be lyke to hym in glorye.
column8: If our life be in chastisement and adversity and we live in patience: we may have good hope that as we be made like to Christe in trouble and affliction, so shall we be like to him in glory.

column7: The waye to pleasure is by aduersitie, to welth by infirmitie, to glorye by rebuke and shame, to ryches euerlastyng, by transitory pouertie.
column8: The way to pleasure is by adversity, to wealth by infirmity, to glory by rebuke and shame, to riches everlasting, by transitory poverty.

column7: After none other sorte walked our sauiour Christ in thys worlde. <NOTE> It were vnmete the disciple to be aboue the P A G Exciij mayster.
column8: After none other sort walked our saviour Christ in this world. It were unmeet the disciple to be above the PAGExciij PAGExciij PAGExciij PAGExciij master.

column7: It were not mete the souldioure to be more delicatly handled than hys captayne. <NOTE> Who can requyre of God to be spared fro hys crosse, where god spared not hys owne deare and welbeloued sonne Christ?
column8: It were not meet the soldier to be more delicately handled than his captain. Who can require of God to be spared from his cross, where god spared not his own deer and well-beloved son Christ?

column7: He suffred al reproffes and afflictions & suffered to the death of ye crosse and yet deserued it not, <NOTE> why than shuld not we that be synners content our selues to suffer, whether God ordeyneth aduersitie to fall vpon vs, for our synnes to thintent to purge vs of them, or whether he wolde haue vs suffer for the tryall of oure faytht, hat so by oure pacience, we myght glorifye hys name and edify our neyghbour by our exemple?
column8: He suffered all reproffes and afflictions & suffered to the death of the cross and yet deserved it not, why than should not we that be sinners content our selves to suffer, whither God ordaineth adversity to fallen upon us, for our sins to intent to purge us of them, or whither he would have us suffer for the trial of our faytht, hat so by our patience, we might glorify his name and edify our neighbour by our exemple?

column7: Let vs blisse our selues in the name of the father, of the sonne, and the holy goost, & offer oure selues to beare what so euer he thynketh mete for our soule.
column8: Let us bliss our selves in the name of the father, of the son, and the holy ghost, & offer our selves to bear what so ever he thinketh meet for our soul.

column7: Let vs praye that we may haue fayth to stande and not be ouercomed of the temtacion of aduersitie.
column8: Let us pray that we may have faith to stand and not be overcomed of the temptation of adversity.

column7: It is no small coforte to vs that we suffer not alone.
column8: It is no small coforte to us that we suffer not alone.

column7: Such an vnitie & consente is there betwene the members of Christes mysticall body, that what one member suffreth, <NOTE> all the resydue fele the grefe of the same: & beare theyr parte of the burthen And yf thys semeth not ynough all the creatures of God, seme to fele our aduersitie and to suffre wyth vs: and desyre and tarye for (in hope) theyr delyueraunce.
column8: Such and unity & consent is there between the members of Christes mystical body, that what one member suffers, all the residue feel the grief of the same: & bear their part of the burden And if this seemeth not enough all the creatures of God, seem to feel our adversity and to suffer with us: and desire and tarry for (in hope) their deliverance.

column7: They seme to vnderstande, as they be abused in the worlde, that so also be the electe.
column8: They seem to understand, as they be abused in the world, that so also be the elect.

column7: They se themselues created of God to the vse and necessitie of ma, whom they serue wt ryght good wil, & they se theselfes otherwhyles sore abused in excesse & riot, & therfore they be greued therwyth.
column8: They see themselves created of God to the use and necessity of ma, whom they serve with right good will, & they see theselfes otherwhiles soar abused in excess & riot, & therefore they be grieved therewith.

column7: And yet though it be against theyr wylles, they are styl subiecte for his sake that ordeyned them, and are cotent for his pleasure to be subiecte to mutabilitie and beare paciently the vanitie of me in theyr abuse in hope yet ones of delyueraunce.
column8: And yet though it be against their wills, they are still subject for his sake that ordained them, and are content for his pleasure to be subject to mUTABILITY and bear patiently the vanity of me in their abuse in hope yet ones of deliverance.

column7: They desyre not to be aboue ye dignitie of goddes deare and chosen seruauntes, whom they se vnworthely dealte wythal in the worlde, but beare theyr bondage and captiuitie well in worth, takynge such parte as goddes moost worthye creatures do, for they knowe that they shall ones be delyuered, not only from theyr payne and trauayle in chaugynge and renewynge themselues fro tyme to tyme for mans vse and commoditie, in perpetuall generation and corruption: but shal also be delyuered from the abuse whych the vngodly holde & occupye them vniustly in.
column8: They desire not to be above you dignity of gods deer and chosen servants, whom they see unworthily dealt withal in the world, but bear their bondage and captivity well in worth, taking such part as gods most worthy creatures do, for they know that they shall ones be delivered, not only from their pain and travail in chaugynge and renewing themselves from time to time for men use and commodity, in perpetual generation and corruption: but shall also be delivered from the abuse which the ungodly hold & occupy them unjustly in.

column7: A lybertie and delyueraunce they loke for in hope, whych they knowe certaynly shall than chauce to them, whan they shal se ye chyldren of god deliuered from theyr labours and trauayles and set in theyr glorye of ioyfull rest.
column8: A liberty and deliverance they look for in hope, which they know certainly shall than chance to them, when they shall see you children of god delivered from their labours and travails and set in their glory of joyful rest.

column7: Thys is the delyueraunce whych all creatures sorowe and wayle dayly for, and are in as feruente desyre to se thys delyueraunce, as the woman whyche is in trauayle of hyr chylde longeth for the delyueraunce therof.
column8: This is the deliverance which all creatures sorrow and wail daily for, and are in as fervent desire to see this deliverance, as the woman which is in travail of her child longeth for the deliverance thereof.

column7: In a parable (good frendes) thus saynt Paule speaketh vnto you, to comforte you, that for some solace of your payne and aduersitie, ye haue all ye creatures of god suffer with you.
column8: In a parable (good friends) thus saint Paule speaks unto you, to comfort you, that for some solace of your pain and adversity, you have all you creatures of god suffer with you.

column7: Count it not for any vayn inuentio fayned of saynt Paule, for he sayd that he knewe it to be thus in dede, that al creatures do suffer parte wyth goddes electe in theyr troubles.
column8: Count it not for any vain inuentio feigned of saint Paule, for he said that he knew it to be thus in deed, that all creatures do suffer part with gods elect in their troubles.

column7: Which thinge myght we lerne and know also yf we woll consyder wyth better aduysement the thynge whych he speaketh.
column8: Which thing might we learn and know also if we will consider with better advisement the thing which he speaks.

column7: For consyder me what doth it sygnifye to vs: P A G Exciiij whan we se the wery oxe wayle and pante vnder his yooke: the horse grone vnder hys burthen, and the poore lambe blete whan he is drawen and dryuen to hys slaughter: wha all beastes trauayle wyth payne and doloure to increase in theyr kynde, whan al creatures are subiecte to such continuall alteration, formed and reformed fro one fasshion to another, what sygnifyeth it vnto vs but that they be partakers of such paynes as goddes seruauntes be put to?
column8: For consider me what does it sygnifye to us: PAGExciiij PAGExciiij PAGExciiij PAGExciiij when we see the weary ox wail and pante under his yooke: the horse groan under his burden, and the poor lamb blete when he is drawn and driven to his slaughter: wha all beasts travail with pain and dolour to increase in their kind, when all creatures are subject to such continual alteration, formed and reformed from one fashion to another, what signifieth it unto us but that they be partakers of such pains as gods servants be put to?

column7: They suffer and resyst not, for so they se such porcion to fall to the electe of God.
column8: They suffer and resist not, for so they see such portion to fallen to the elect of God.

column7: And therfore in hope of delyuerauce they abyde what so euer the vse and necessitie of man requyreth of them, or yet what soeuer abuse and tyranny mans malyce put them to.
column8: And therefore in hope of delyuerauce they abide what so ever the use and necessity of man requireth of them, or yet what soever abuse and tyranny men malice put them to.

column7: And thus in theyr paynfull trauayle they continue tyll the daye come whan goddes chyldren shalbe delyuered of all theyr mysery, which they loge for both for the electes sake and theyr owne also.
column8: And thus in their painful travail they continue till the day come when gods children shall delivered of all their misery, which they loge for both for the elects sake and their own also.

column7: Thys desyre and carefulnes is not in vnreasonable creatures only, neyther do they alone suffer such vexacion and abuse in the world to be wrongfully dealt with: but we our selues (sayeth saynt Paule) whych haue the fyrst frutes of goddes spirite, endowed wyth singuler prerogatyues aboue other of goddes householde, beynge the heades and teachers of the people and made of God ye vessels to receaue and kepe the moost worthy and excellent treasure of hys gospell, <NOTE> we our selfe are in daunger & subiecte to manyfolde aduersities in the worlde, in somuch that we are as men dayly in daunger and iudged to death, and are reputed as shepe euermore ready to the slaughter.
column8: This desire and carefulness is not in unreasonable creatures only, neither do they alone suffer such vexation and abuse in the world to be wrongfully dealt with: but we our selves (sayeth saint Paule) which have the fyrst fruits of gods spirit, endowed with singular prerogatyues above other of gods household, being the heads and teachers of the people and made of God the vessels to receive and keep the most worthy and excellent treasure of his gospel, we our self are in danger & subject to manifold adversities in the world, in somuch that we are as men daily in danger and judged to death, and are reputed as sheep evermore ready to the slaughter.

column7: We se so many vnworthy thynges done in ye world, <NOTE> that we desyre to be out of the worlde and to be with Christ.
column8: We see so many unworthy things done in you world, that we desire to be out of the world and to be with Christ.

column7: Such combraunce and greuauce we fele in thys corruptible body, that we sygh and dayly loge to be delyuered.
column8: Such combraunce and greuauce we feel in this corruptible body, that we sygh and daily loge to be delivered.

column7: We desyre much to haue thys tabernacle of our bodyes to be chaunged and altered that we maye be endowed wyth our heuenly house from aboue. <NOTE> Now (my frendes) these thynges well consydered, <NOTE> let vs take vpo vs ye armure of God, to fyght agaynst our inuisible enemyes.
column8: We desire much to have this tabernacle of our bodies to be changed and altered that we may be endowed with our heavenly house from above. Now (my friends) these things well considered, let us take upon us the armure of God, to fight against our invisible enemies.

column7: Let vs paciently abyde all griefes and displeasures of thys lyfe, that we maye raygne wyth Christ another daye.
column8: Let us patiently abide all griefs and displeasures of this life, that we may reign with Christ another day.

column7: It is no smale ioye that we be called to.
column8: It is no small joy that we be called to.

column7: It is farre passynge all the passions that we can suffer here.
column8: It is far passing all the passion that we can suffer here.

column7: And let vs as I sayd call to mynde, that we suffer not alone.
column8: And let us as I said call to mind, that we suffer not alone.

column7: Christ our heade suffereth wyth vs, by whose assystence, we shalbe able to stande.
column8: Christ our head suffers with us, by whose assistance, we shall able to stand.

column7: And suche comunion and felowship is there betwene the mebers of Christes body, that what the one suffereth, all other suffer wyth it.
column8: And such communion and fellowship is there between the mebers of Christes body, that what the one suffers, all other suffer with it.

column7: Yea al ye creatures of god are partakers wyth vs, and in hope to be delyuered they suffer paciently.
column8: Yea all you creatures of god are partakers with us, and in hope to be delivered they suffer patiently.

column7: No creature shulde desyre to be exempte fro trouble in thys worlde: seynge Christ goddes naturall sonne, was not exempt, seynge goddes holy prophetes and apostles were not exempt.
column8: No creature should desire to be exempt from trouble in this world: sing Christ gods natural son, was not exempt, sing gods holy prophets and apostles were not exempt.

column7: Let vs tha comytte our selues into the handes of God, and arme our selues wyth pacience, so that we maye glorifye goddes holy name by our well doynge, that an other daye, we maye be taken for hys well beloued chyldren.
column8: Let us than comytte our selves into the hands of God, and arm our selves with patience, so that we may glorify gods holy name by our well doing, that and other day, we may be taken for his well beloved children.

column7: To whome be all glorye for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be all glory for ever and ever.

column7: AMEN.
column8: AMEN.

column7: : homily P A G Excv The Gospell on the.iiij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily PAGExcv PAGExcv PAGExcv PAGExcv The Gospel on the iiij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.vi. chapter of Luke.
column8: The vi chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Christian lawes be here described.
column8: Christian laws be here described.

column7: I Esus sayd vnto hys disciples.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples.

column7: Be ye mercyful, as your father also is mercyfull.
column8: Be you merciful, as your father also is merciful.

column7: Iudge not and ye shall not be iudged: Condempne not, and ye shall not be condemned.
column8: Judge not and you shall not be judged: Condemn not, and you shall not be condemned.

column7: Forgyue, and ye shalbe forgyuen.
column8: Forgive, and you shall forgiven.

column7: Gyue, and it shalbe gyue vnto you: good measure and pressed downe, and shaken together and runnynge ouer shall men gyue into your bosomes For wyth the same measure that ye mete wythall, shal other me mete to you again.
column8: Gyve, and it shall gyve unto you: good measure and pressed down, and shaken together and running over shall men gyve into your bosoms For with the same measure that you meet withal, shall other me meet to you again.

column7: And he put forth a similitude vnto them.
column8: And he put forth a similitude unto them.

column7: Can the blynde leade the blynde?
column8: Can the blind lead the blind?

column7: Do they not both fall into the dycke?
column8: Do they not both fallen into the dycke?

column7: The disciple is not aboue hys mayster.
column8: The disciple is not above his master.

column7: Euery man shall be perfyte, euen as hys mayster is.
column8: Every man shall be perfect, even as his master is.

column7: Why seyst thou a moate in thy brothers eye, but cosyderest not the beame that is in thyne owne eye?
column8: Why sayest thou a moat in thy brother's eye, but cosyderest not the beam that is in thine own eye?

column7: Eyther how cannest thou saye to thy brother, Brother, let me pull out the moote that is in thyne eye, when thou seest not the beame that is in thyne owne eye.
column8: Either how canst thou say to thy brother, Brother, let me pull out the moot that is in thine eye, when thou seest not the beam that is in thine own eye.

column7: Thou ypocrite cast out the beame out of thine owne eye first and rhen shalt thou se perfytly, to pul out the moat that is in thy brothers eye.
column8: Thou ypocrite cast out the beam out of thine own eye first and rhen shalt thou see perfectly, to pull out the moat that is in thy brother's eye.

column7: G Ood people our Sauiour Christ in thys gospell setteth forth vnto vs certayne christian lawes that is to saye certayne officies or duties of charitie and frutes of fayth.
column8: GOod GOod people our Saviour Christ in this gospel sets forth unto us certain christian laws that is to say certain offices or duties of charity and fruits of faith.

column7: Fyrst he byddeth vs be mercyfull and tender of hart But after what sorte?
column8: Fyrst he biddeth us be merciful and tender of heart But after what sort?

column7: As paynyms or publicanes be?
column8: As painims or publicans be?

column7: No, but euen accordyng to thexemple of our heauenly father.
column8: No, but even according to thexemple of our heavenly father.

column7: Why, how mercyfull is oure heauenly father vnto vs?
column8: Why, how merciful is our heavenly father unto us?

column7: Surely he whan we were hys enemyes and had deserued no kyndnes at hys handes, yet of an excedyng mercy whych he bare to makynd, vouchesaued to sende downe hys only begotte sone to redeme vs wyth hys moost precious bloude.
column8: Surely he when we were his enemies and had deserved no kindness at his hands, yet of and exceeding mercy which he bore to makynd, vouchsafed to send down his only begotten soon to redeem us with his most precious blood.

column7: He also from tyme to tyme as often as by frayltie we offende hys maiestye, yf we humbly aske mercy, forgyueth vs. <NOTE> Yea he sendeth hys rayne, he causeth the Sonne, the moone, the starres, and hys heuenly planetes to shyne, aswel vpon hys enemyes as frendes and louers.
column8: He also from time to time as often as by frailty we offend his majesty, if we humbly ask mercy, forgyueth us Yea he sends his rain, he causeth the Son, the moon, the stars, and his heavenly planets to shine, aswell upon his enemies as friends and lovers.

column7: But yet (sayth Christ) blessed and happy be the mercyfull, for they shall agayne receyue mercy.
column8: But yet (say Christ) blessed and happy be the merciful, for they shall again receive mercy.

column7: He that hath the substaunce and goodes of thys worlde, and seeth hys brother in nede, and shutteth vp the intrayles of hys harte from hym, howe can the loue and charitie of God remayne in such a person, <NOTE> sayeth ye Euangelist Ihon?
column8: He that hath the substance and goods of this world, and sees his brother in need, and shutteth up the intrayles of his heart from him, how can the love and charity of God remain in such a person, sayeth the Euangelist Ihon?

column7: Certes, he that hath compassion and pytie of the poore, is a great gayner and who so fedeth, shalbe fedde agayne.
column8: Certes, he that hath compassion and pity of the poor, is a great gainer and who so feedeth, shall fed again.

column7: Seconde, Christ byddeth vs here not to iudge, and we shall not be iudged.
column8: Seconde, Christ biddeth us here not to judge, and we shall not be judged.

column7: For he shall haue iudgemete wythout mercy (sayth saynt Iames) whych sheweth no mercy. <NOTE> Let me alone therfore wyth vengeaunce sayeth the Lorde, and I shall requyte.
column8: For he shall have iudgemete without mercy (say saint Iames) which shows no mercy. Let me alone therefore with vengeance sayeth the Lord, and I shall requit.

column7: But marke my frendes that thys is only spoken of priuate iudgement and priuate condemnation, that is to saye, I maye not be myne owne iudge, I maye not reuenge myne owne quarell, but I muste comytte the cause to God and he shall iudge my quarel and punysh P A G Excvi accordyngly.
column8: But mark my friends that this is only spoken of private judgement and private condemnation, that is to say, I may not be mine own judge, I may not revenge mine own quarrel, but I must comytte the cause to God and he shall judge my quarrel and punish PAGExcvi PAGExcvi PAGExcvi PAGExcvi accordingly.

column7: It is not ment of publyke iudgement.
column8: It is not meant of public judgement.

column7: For suche as be rulers and publyke officers represent not theyr owne persons, but they represent the person of almyghty God, and they be hys deputies and ministers. <NOTE> And for thys cause saynt Paule woll that euery soule shulde submytte hymselfe to ye authoritie of the hygh powers.
column8: For such as be rulers and public officers represent not their own persons, but they represent the person of almighty God, and they be his deputies and ministers. And for this cause saint Paule will that every soul should submit himself to the authority of the high powers.

column7: For there is (sayeth he) no power but of God.
column8: For there is (sayeth he) no power but of God.

column7: Yea the iudges and Magistrates in scripture be called Goddes.
column8: Yea the judges and Magistrates in scripture be called Gods.

column7: Also saynt Peter thapostle sayeth. <NOTE> Submytte your selues vnto euery humane creature for our Lordes sake whether it be vnto a kynge as vnto ye chefe heade, or vnto rulers as vnto them that are sente of hym, for the punyshment of euell doers, and prayse of wel doers By thys texte of S. Peter ye se playnly yt it is lawfull for rulers to punysh.
column8: Also saint Peter apostle sayeth. Submit your selves unto every humane creature for our Lords sake whither it be unto a king as unto you chief head, or unto rulers as unto them that are sent of him, for the punishment of evil doers, and praise of well doers By this text of S. Peter you see plainly that it is lawful for rulers to punish.

column7: But punysh they can not, onles they iudge and condemne the gyltye.
column8: But punish they can not, unless they judge and condemn the guilty.

column7: So tha it is lawfull for rulers, to iudge and to codemne, bycause they do it not in theyr own name, but as gods ministers and vycares.
column8: So tha it is lawful for rulers, to judge and to codemne, because they do it not in their own name, but as gods ministers and vycares.

column7: To thys do all the auncient expositours and doctours agre, as saynte Austine, <NOTE>, Ambrose, Chrysostome and the rest.
column8: To this do all the ancient expositors and doctors agree, as faint Austine,, Ambrose, Chrysostome and the rest.

column7: Wherfore the wycked Anabaptistes are to be banyshed whych condemne temporall or ciuile iudgementes.
column8: Wherefore the wicked Anabaptists are to be banished which condemn temporal or civil judgements.

column7: It foloweth in the texte.
column8: It followeth in the text.

column7: Forgyue and ye shalbe forgyuen. Here my frendes ye se, that onles we forgyue other me theyr offences, whych they haue trespassed agaynst vs, our heauenly father woll not surely forgyue vs. And therfore we saye in our pater noster called ye Lordes prayer.
column8: Forgive and you shall forgiven. Here my friends you see, that unless we forgive other me their offences, which they have trespassed against us, our heavenly father will not surely forgive us And therefore we say in our pater noster called the Lords prayer.

column7: Dimitte nobis debita nostra, <NOTE> sicut & nos dimittimus debitoribus nostris. That is to saye: Forgyue vs our dettes or synnes, euen as we forgyue them that trespasse agaynst vs. So, yf thou cannest not fynde in thy harte, to forgyue thy neyghboure hys faultes thou mayest be ryght sure, that god wyl not forgiue the thy faultes.
column8: Dimitte nobis debita nostra, sicut & nos dimittimus debitoribus nostris. That is to say: Forgive us our debts or sins, even as we forgive them that trespass against us So, if thou canst not find in thy heart, to forgive thy neighbour his faults thou mayest be right sure, that god will not forgive the thy faults.

column7: He byddeth vs also gyue, and it shal be gyuen vnto vs. <NOTE> For frely haue we taken and therfore frely we ought to gyue.
column8: He biddeth us also gyve, and it shall be given unto us For freely have we taken and therefore freely we ought to gyve.

column7: What hast thou (sayeth Paule) but thou hast receyued the same before of almyghty God? <NOTE> Surely, he that soweth skantly & nygardly, shall repe skantly.
column8: What hast thou (sayeth Paule) but thou hast received the same before of almighty God? Surely, he that soweth skantly & nygardly, shall repe skantly.

column7: Yf we be faythfull stewardes in lytle, God wyll surely rewarde vs in muche.
column8: If we be faithful stewards in little, God will surely reward us in much.

column7: But he yt is vnfaythfull in lytle, how can he be faythfull in muche sayeth Christ?
column8: But he that is unfaithful in little, how can he be faithful in much sayeth Christ?

column7: Wherfore loke wt what measure that we mete wythall to others, wyth the same shal other men mete to vs agayne.
column8: Wherefore look with what measure that we meet withal to others, with the same shall other men meet to us again.

column7: I pray you (sayeth our Sauiour Christ) can the blynde leade the blynde? Here he teacheth vs to be contente wyth hys doctrine, for els we shal wander lyke blynde betels.
column8: I pray you (sayeth our Saviour Christ) can the blind lead the blind? Here he teaches us to be content with his doctrine, for else we shall wander like blind beetles.

column7: He is blynde whych hath not the pure & ryghte vnderstandynge of gods worde, yf thys man teacheth, he teacheth not well, he can be no good leader or guyde.
column8: He is blind which hath not the pure & right understanding of gods word, if this man teaches, he teaches not well, he can be no good leader or guide.

column7: Why seest thou a moate in thy brothers eye, but considerest not the beame in thyne owne eye?
column8: Why seest thou a moat in thy brother's eye, but considerest not the beam in thine own eye?

column7: O how vncomly, how wycked, how ypocrite lyke, how vncharitable a thynge is it, to iudge oure neyghbours of lyghte maters, where as we be an hundred tymes worse our selues?
column8: O how uncomely, how wicked, how ypocrite like, how uncharitable a thing is it, to judge our neighbours of light maters, where as we be and hundred times worse our selves?

column7: Why do we not rather getly bear, dissemble, and interprete well the small erroure and faulte of our brethren?
column8: Why do we not rather getly bear, dissemble, and interpret well the small error and fault of our brothers?

column7: Why do we not rather go downe to the intrayles of our owne harte, <NOTE> and se our owne stuffe?
column8: Why do we not rather go down to the intrayles of our own heart, and see our own stuff?

column7: Esope the fable wryter doth very P A G Excvij well paynt vs, he fayneth that euery man hath two pookes or wallettes, the one hangynge before him, the other hangynge behynde hym.
column8: Esope the fable writer does very PAGExcvij PAGExcvij PAGExcvij PAGExcvij well paint us, he feigneth that every man hath two pookes or wallettes, the one hanging before him, the other hanging behind him.

column7: In that whyche hangeth before vs be put other mens faultes.
column8: In that which hangs before us be put other men's faults.

column7: Into thys pooke we be alwayes perynge and lokyng, but in the other pooke of the wallet whyche hangeth at our backe wherin our own faultes be put, we neuer loke.
column8: Into this pook we be always perynge and looking, but in the other pook of the wallet which hangs at our back wherein our own faults be put, we never look.

column7: Wherfore he wolde haue vs turne the wallet an other whyle the cotrary way.
column8: Wherefore he would have us turn the wallet and other while the contrary way.

column7: Assuredly he ought to be voyde of all faultes, that shulde be ready to speake agaynst other me.
column8: Assuredly he ought to be void of all faults, that should be ready to speak against other me.

column7: Also it is dyrectly agaynst the eyght commaundemente of God, to speake any false testimony or worde agaynst thy brother.
column8: Also it is directly against the eyght commandment of God, to speak any false testimony or word against thy brother.

column7: Yet thys notwythstandynge it is lawful for the charitably to monyshe thy neyghboure of hys faulte, accordynge to saynt Paules lesson.
column8: Yet this notwithstanding it is lawful for the charitably to monish thy neighbour of his fault, according to saint Paules lesson.

column7: Yf a man be founde in any faulte, ye that be goostly, reproue suche a person after a gentle sorte.
column8: If a man be found in any fault, you that be ghostly, reprove such a person after a gentle sort.

column7: Also he sayeth: Reproue, <NOTE> besech, blame tymely vntymely in all pacience.
column8: Also he sayeth: Reprove, beseech, blame timely untimely in all patience.

column7: Crye, cease not, as a trompe lyfte vp thy voyce.
column8: Cry, cease not, as a trump lift up thy voice.

column7: Yf thy brother (sayeth Christ) trespasse agaynst the, <NOTE> go and tell hym hys faulte betwene the and hym alone.
column8: If thy brother (sayeth Christ) trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault between thee and him alone.

column7: Yf he heare the, thou hast wone thy brother, but yf he hear the not, than take yet with the one or two, that in the mouth of two or thre wytnesses euery matter maye be establyshed.
column8: If he hear thee, thou hast won thy brother, but if he hear thee not, than take yet with the one or two, that in the mouth of two or thre witnesses every matter may be established.

column7: Yf he heare not them, tell it vnto the congregacion.
column8: If he hear not them, tell it unto the congregation.

column7: Yf he heare not the congregacion, let hym be vnto the as an hethen ma & as a publicane.
column8: If he hear not the congregation, let him be unto thee as and heathen ma & as a publican.

column7: Lo good frendes here ye be taught by Christe, to be tender harted or mercyfull accordynge to thexemple of the father in heauen, not to iudge, not to codemne but to remytte all to God and to gods minister the temporall ruler, we be taughte to be perfyte and not to be captiouse but gently to wynke at the small offenses of our brethre.
column8: Lo good friends here you be taught by Christe, to be tender hearted or merciful according to thexemple of the father in heaven, not to judge, not to codemne but to remytte all to God and to gods minister the temporal ruler, we be taught to be perfect and not to be captious but gently to wink at the small offenses of our brethren.

column7: These be the preceptes of our Sauiour Christ, wherby a christian ma shalbe knowen.
column8: These be the precepts of our Saviour Christ, whereby a christian ma shall known.

column7: Wherfore let vs earnestly imbrase them & execute them in our lyuynge.
column8: Wherefore let us earnestly embrace them & execute them in our living.

column7: So doynge we shall declare our selues, that we be in dede ye chyldren of the father in heauen whose properties we folowe.
column8: So doing we shall declare our selves, that we be in deed you children of the father in heaven whose properties we follow.

column7: To whome wyth the sonne and holy goost be all glorye in infinita secula.
column8: To whom with the son and holy ghost be all glory in infinita secula.

column7: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the.v. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the v sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.i. epistle of S. Peter the.iij. chapter.
column8: The i epistle of S. Peter the iij chapter.

column7: Thargument
column8: Thargument

column7: B Rethren, be ye all of one mynde, of one harte loue as brethre, be pytiful, be courteous meke not rendrynge euell for euel, or rebuke for rebuke: but cotrary wyse, blesse: knowing that ye are there vnto called, eue that ye shuld be heyres of the blessynge.
column8: BRethren BRethren, be you all of one mind, of one heart love as brethren, be pytiful, be courteous meek not rendering evil for evil, or rebuke for rebuke: but contrary wise, bless: knowing that you are there unto called, eve that you should be heirs of the blessing.

column7: For he that doth loge after lyfe, and loueth to se good dayes, let hym refrayne hys tonge from euell, and hys lyppes that they speke not gyle.
column8: For he that does loge after life, and loves to see good days, let him refrain his tongue from evil, and his lips that they speak not gyle.

column7: Let hym eschue euell, and do good: let him seke peace, and ensue it: For the eyes of the Lorde are ouer the ryghtuous, and hys eares are open vnto theyr prayers.
column8: Let him eschew evil, and do good: let him seek peace, and ensue it: For the eyes of the Lord are over the righteous, and his ears are open unto their prayers.

column7: Agayne the face of the Lorde is ouer them that do euell.
column8: Again the face of the Lord is over them that do evil.

column7: Moreouer who is it that wyll harme you, yf ye folowe that whych is good?
column8: Moreover who is it that will harm you, if you follow that which is good?

column7: Yea happy are ye yf any trouble happen vnto you for ryghtuousnes sake.
column8: Yea happy are you if any trouble happen unto you for righteousness sake.

column7: Be not ye afraied for any terroure of the, nether be ye troubled, but sanctifye the Lorde God in your hartes.
column8: Be not you afraid for any terror of thee, neither be you troubled, but sanctify the Lord God in your hearts.

column7: P A G Excviij IN thys Epistle good people thapostle Peter instructeth vs in a generaltye what it becommeth all good christen folke to do.
column8: PAGExcviij PAGExcviij PAGExcviij PAGExcviij IN this Epistle good people apostle Peter instructeth us in a generalty what it becomes all good christian folk to do.

column7: Brefly therfore to conclude (sayeth saynt Peter) se ye be all of one mynde, as who shulde saye, be not contentiouse & stryuynge one agaynst another, neyther in lernynge, nor yet in your other worldly matters, but be ye compaciente, <NOTE> that is to saye, suffer together and beare one wyth an other, be ye indowed with brotherly loue and charitie, be ye tender of harte & pytifull, easy to forgyue all offences, easy to departe youre goodes and money, as ye may spare it, to the reliefe and succoure of your pore neighbour, se ye be also meke, courteouse, affable, gentle to speake vnto.
column8: Briefly therefore to conclude (sayeth saint Peter) see you be all of one mind, as who should say, be not contentious & striving one against another, neither in learning, nor yet in your other worldly matters, but be you compaciente, that is to say, suffer together and bear one with and other, be you endowed with brotherly love and charity, be you tender of heart & pytifull, easy to forgive all offences, easy to depart your goods and money, as you may spare it, to the relief and succour of your poor neighbour, see you be also meek, courteous, affable, gentle to speak unto.

column7: Moreouer se ye reder not euel for euell, but beare ye iniurye and wronge paciently, accordynge to the example of Christ, resignynge and commyttynge the punyshment and vengeauce to gods hande, or to the correction of the ruler whych is gods minister and which beareth not a swearde for nought.
column8: Moreover see you reder not evil for evil, but bear you injury and wrong patiently, according to the example of Christ, resignynge and commyttynge the punishment and vengeance to gods hand, or to the correction of the ruler which is gods minister and which bears not a sword for nought.

column7: Yea rather contrary wyse, <NOTE> se ye do good, and blesse you them, that wronge you, and whych worke you displeasures, knowyng thys, that ye were called by the franke election of God & of his special grace and mere goodnes euen before the foudacions of the worlde were layde, <NOTE> that ye shulde receyue not the blessynge of the world but the blessing of the heritage of God, that is to wyt, euerlastynge lyfe, whych heritage pertayneth vnto vs not as vnto naturall chyldren but as chyldren of adoption & election.
column8: Yea rather contrary wise, se you do good, and bless you them, that wrong you, and which work you displeasures, knowing this, that you were called by the frank election of God & of his special grace and mere goodness even before the foudacions of the world were laid, that you should receive not the blessing of the world but the blessing of the heritage of God, that is to wit, everlasting life, which heritage pertaineth unto us not as unto natural children but as children of adoption & election.

column7: For assuredly, my frendes, he that woll be happy and be counted iust eyther in thys lyfe before men, or in the lyfe to come wyth God, and wyth hys holy angels, what shall he do sayeth saynt Peter.
column8: For assuredly, my friends, he that will be happy and be counted just either in this life before men, or in the life to come with God, and with his holy angels, what shall he do sayeth saint Peter.

column7: Let hym refrayne and temper his tonge from euel, so that he breake not charitie, and let hym holde in & represse hys lyppes, yt they vtter no gyle, no deceypt, no fraude, no dissimulation, no hypocrisie, no vntrouth.
column8: Let him refrain and temper his tongue from evil, so that he break not charity, and let him hold in & repress his lips, that they utter no gyle, no deceit, no fraud, no dissimulation, no hypocrisy, no untroth.

column7: Let hym, I saye, eschue from euel, and do the thynge that is good and honest both before God & man.
column8: Let him, I say, eschew from evil, and do the thing that is good and honest both before God & man.

column7: Let hym seke not after discorde, variauce, and debate, but after peace, after vnitie, after concorde, & let hym folowe and insue it.
column8: Let him seek not after discord, variance, and debate, but after peace, after unity, after concord, & let him follow and ensue it.

column7: For be ye ryght well assured, that the eyen of the Lorde God are ouer the ryghtuouse, and hys eares are ope to theyr prayers.
column8: For be you right well assured, that the eyes of the Lord God are over the righteous, and his ears are open to their prayers.

column7: And agayne, the terrible visage and face of ye Lorde is ouer all them that do euell, as who shulde saye: God loueth and fauoreth al such, as do wel & which lyue after a godly and honest sorte, & beynge in perfyte loue and charitye wyth theyr neyghbours and euen christen, he heareth theyr prayers, he accepteth theyr oblacions and sacrificies, as oure Sauioure Christ hath taught vs in the.v. chapter of S. Mattheu.
column8: And again, the terrible visage and face of you Lord is over all them that do evil, as who should say: God loves and favoureth all such, as do well & which live after a godly and honest sort, & being in perfect love and charity with their neighbours and even christen, he hears their prayers, he accepteth their oblations and sacrifices, as our Saviour Christ hath taught us in the v chapter of S. Mattheum.

column7: But on the contrary syde God hateth and abhorreth all such as be euel doers, yea and also he punysheth them whan he seeth hys tyme.
column8: But on the contrary side God hates and abhorreth all such as be evil doers, yea and also he punisheth them when he sees his time.

column7: Fynally, the Apostle Peter doth here propoude and set forth vnto vs two great commodities and profytes, whych folow them that worke well, the one is a temporall pleasure and commoditie to be taken here in thys worlde, whyche is, that no man shall harme them, yf they lyue after a ciuile and honeste fashion amonges men in the worlde, the other is an euerlastynge and heauenly commoditie to be taken in the worlde to come, whych is, euerlastynge blesse.
column8: Finally, the Apostle Peter does here propoude and set forth unto us two great commodities and profits, which follow them that work well, the one is a temporal pleasure and commodity to be taken here in this world, which is, that no man shall harm them, if they live after a civil and honest fashion among men in the world, the other is and everlasting and heavenly commodity to be taken in the world to come, which is, everlasting bless.

column7: But P A G Excix peraduenture ye woll saye: <NOTE> yf we do well and yet we be wrongfully vexed & troubled in ye worlde?
column8: But PAGExcix PAGExcix PAGExcix PAGExcix peradventure you will say: if we do well and yet we be wrongfully vexed & troubled in you world?

column7: Saynt Peter answereth, and sayeth.
column8: Saint Peter answereth, and sayeth.

column7: Happy are ye, yf ye suffer for ryghtuousnesse sake, and therfore he wylleth vs, not to be affrayed for any terrour of the, neyther yet to be troubled, but thankfully to prayse and glorifye God in our hartes.
column8: Happy are you, if you suffer for ryghtuousnesse sake, and therefore he willeth us, not to be afraid for any terror of thee, neither yet to be troubled, but thankfully to praise and glorify God in our hearts.

column7: Hythervnto my frendes, I haue brefly declared the mynde of S. Peter vnto you, whych exhorteth you in thys epistle to good workes.
column8: Hythervnto my friends, I have briefly declared the mind of S. Peter unto you, which exhorteth you in this epistle to good works.

column7: But ye muste consyder that in the former parte of hys epistle he taught and spake of fayth to be reposed and set in our Sauiour Christ.
column8: But you must consider that in the former part of his epistle he taught and spoke of faith to be reposed and set in our Saviour Christ.

column7: For as saynt Austine affirmeth, <NOTE> it is the intencion that maketh the good worke, and it is the fayth that must directe the intencion.
column8: For as saint Austine affirmeth, it is the intention that makes the good work, and it is the faith that must direct the intention.

column7: Let vs tha do good workes, accordynge to saynt Peters exhortacion here, of pure loue and faythe vnfayned.
column8: Let us tha do good works, according to saint Peters exhortation here, of pure love and faith unfeigned.

column7: So doynge, we shalbe sure to be crowned wyth immortalitie by god the father of heauen.
column8: So doing, we shall sure to be crowned with immortality by god the father of heaven.

column7: To whome be glorye and prayse for euer.
column8: To whom be glory and praise for ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The gospell on the.v. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The gospel on the v sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.v. chapter of Luke.
column8: The v chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Christ declareth the power of hys worde.
column8: Christ declareth the power of his word.

column7: W Han the people preassed vnto Iesus to heare the word of God, he stode by the lake of Genezareth: and sawe two shippes stande by the lake syde, but the fysshermen were gone out of them, and were wasshynge theyr nettes.
column8: When When the people pressed unto Jesus to hear the word of God, he stood by the lake of Genezareth: and saw two ships stand by the lake side, but the fishermen were gone out of them, and were washing their nets.

column7: And he entred in to one of the shyppes (whych perteyned to Simo) and prayed him that he wolde thrust out a lytle fro the lande.
column8: And he entered in to one of the ships (which pertained to Simo) and prayed him that he would thrust out a little from the land.

column7: And he sat downe and taught the people out of the shyp.
column8: And he sat down and taught the people out of the ship.

column7: Whan he had lefte speakynge, he sayd vnto Symon: Launche out into the depe, and let slyppe your nettes to make a draught.
column8: When he had left speaking, he said unto Symon: Launche out into the deep, and let slip your nets to make a draught.

column7: And Simon answered, and sayd vnto hym: Mayster we haue laboured all nyght, and haue taken nothynge.
column8: And Simon answered, and said unto him: Master we have laboured all night, and have taken nothing.

column7: Neuertheles, at thy commaundement I wyll louse forth the nette.
column8: Nevertheless, at thy commandment I will louse forth the net.

column7: And whan they had thys done, they inclosed a great multitude of fysshes.
column8: And when they had this done, they enclosed a great multitude of fishes.

column7: But theyr net brake, & they beckned to theyr felowes (which were in the shyp) that they shulde come and helpe them.
column8: But their net brake, & they beckoned to their fellows (which were in the ship) that they should come and help them.

column7: And they came, and fylled both the shyppes that they sonke agayne.
column8: And they came, and filled both the ships that they sunk again.

column7: Whan Simon Peter sawe thys, he fell downe at Iesus knees, sayenge: Lorde, go from me, for I am a synfull man.
column8: When Simon Peter saw this, he fell down at Jesus knees, saying: Lord, go from me, for I am a sinful man.

column7: For he was astonnyed & al that were wyth hym, at the draught of fysshes whych they had taken: and so was also Iames and Ihon the sonnes of Zebede, which were parteners with Simon.
column8: For he was astonnyed & all that were with him, at the draught of fishes which they had taken: and so was also Iames and Ihon the sons of Zebede, which were partners with Simon.

column7: And Iesus said vnto Simo: feare not, from hence forth thou shalt catch men.
column8: And Jesus said unto Simo: fear not, from hence forth thou shalt catch men.

column7: And they broughte the shyppes to lande, and forsoke all, and folowed hym.
column8: And they brought the ships to land, and forsook all, and followed him.

column7: IN thys Gospel (good people) Christ teacheth the vertue and power of hys worde, to thyntent to cofirme the fayth of hys disciples, that he is the true Messias, God an man.
column8: IN this Gospel (good people) Christ teaches the virtue and power of his word, to thyntent to cofirme the faith of his disciples, that he is the true Messias, God and man.

column7: Furthermore he taketh care for theyr bodelye sustenaunce sygnifyenge, that nothyng can wel prosper, onles he furthereth and putteth PAGEC hys hande thervnto.
column8: Furthermore he takes care for their bodily sustenance sygnifyenge, that nothing can well prosper, unless he furthereth and putteth PAGEC his hand thereunto.

column7: Now tha after that Christ had preached in Galilie (as in the chapter before is mencioned) it came to passe, when the synfull people whych were troubled in conscience wyth theyr offenses, preassed vpon hym, to heare the worde of God, that theyr conscience myghte be healed by the medicine therof, he stode by the lake of Genezareth which is a water of Galilie, and he saw two shippes stande by the water syde, but the fyshermen were gone out of them and were washynge theyr nettes.
column8: Now tha after that Christ had preached in Galilie (as in the chapter before is mentioned) it came to pass, when the sinful people which were troubled in conscience with their offenses, pressed upon him, to hear the word of God, that their conscience might be healed by the medicine thereof, he stood by the lake of Genezareth which is a water of Galilie, and he saw two ships stand by the water side, but the fishermen were gone out of them and were washing their nets.

column7: For they had laboured al nyght in vayne and had caught no fyshe.
column8: For they had laboured all night in vain and had caught no fish.

column7: Wherfore they now vtterly despayred to take any there, and therfore they were about to haue left worke.
column8: Wherefore they now utterly despaired to take any there, and therefore they were about to have left work.

column7: But our Sauioure Christe, knowynge all wythin hymselfe, & sekynge herby occasion, to shewe hys power (for tha is god wont moost of al to helpe, when man can do no good) entred into one of ye shippes whych pertayned to Simon, whome afterward Christ named Peter.
column8: But our Saviour Christe, knowing all within himself, & seeking hereby occasion, to show his power (for than is god wont most of all to help, when man can do no good) entered into one of you ships which pertained to Simon, whom afterwards Christ nam Peter.

column7: And Christ, <NOTE> wheras he was the sonne of God and had all in hys hande, and myght haue commaunded, and taken awaye all, yet he dyd none of all thys, but mekely and gently prayed this Symon, that he wolde thurst out his shyppe a lytle from the lande, to thintent he myght the more quyetly syt hymselfe downe and teache.
column8: And Christ, whereas he was the son of God and had all in his hand, and might have commanded, and taken away all, yet he did none of all this, but meekly and gently prayed this Symon, that he would thirst out his ship a little from the land, to intent he might the more quietly fit himself down and teach.

column7: But ye wyll aske, <NOTE> why Christ sat whan he taught?
column8: But you will ask, why Christ sat when he taught?

column7: Surely, syttinge is a sygne of a meke and peacible preacher, he was not a busye and braggynge stryuer or contender, as many preachers be, but he taught in moost quyet and sober wyse.
column8: Surely, sitting is a sign of a meek and peaceable preacher, he was not a busy and bragging striver or contender, as many preachers be, but he taught in most quiet and sober wise.

column7: And whan he had lefte speakyng, he bad Simon launche out into the depe & let slyppe theyr nettes to make a draught.
column8: And when he had left speaking, he bade Simon launch out into the deep & let slip their nets to make a draught.

column7: Here ye shall marke, <NOTE> Christ fyrst feadeth the soule wyth hys preachynge, or euer he feade the bodye wyth meate, for els forthwyth, whan he had sene ye fyshermen washyng theyr nettes, he myght haue wrought the myracle folowynge.
column8: Here you shall mark, Christ fyrst feadeth the soul with his preaching, or ever he feade the body with meat, for else forthwith, when he had seen you fishermen washing their nets, he might have wrought the miracle following.

column7: But Christ is euer wonte to preferre the fode of the soule, before the thynges pertaynynge to the sustentacion of the body, <NOTE> and therfore he wylleth vs fyrst to seke the kyngdome of heauen and the iustice therof, and all shalbe cast vnto vs. Wherfore after he had fedde the people wyth preachynge, he confirmeth it wyth a myracle. <NOTE> For the vse of all myracles is that by the same the doctrine of Christe shulde be confirmed.
column8: But Christ is ever wont to prefer the food of the soul, before the things pertaining to the sustentation of the body, and therefore he willeth us fyrst to seek the kingdom of heaven and the justice thereof, and all shall cast unto us Wherefore after he had fed the people with preaching, he confirmeth it with a miracle. For the use of all miracles is that by the same the doctrine of Christe should be confirmed.

column7: Now thys myracle tendeth hervnto, that all our labour & trauayle for our bodely sustenauce is in vayne, onles the blessynge and helpinge hande of God be put therto.
column8: Now this miracle tendeth hereunto, that all our labour & travail for our bodily sustenance is in vain, unless the blessing and helping hand of God be put thereto.

column7: Wherfore these fyshermen, bycause they fyrst sought the kyngdom of god, be now bydden to lauche out into the depe, and to let slyppe theyr nettes to make a draught.
column8: Wherefore these fishermen, because they fyrst sought the kingdom of god, be now bidden to lauche out into the deep, and to let slip their nets to make a draught.

column7: And albeit that Simon Peter dispayred that the lettynge downe of the nettes coulde do any good, seynge they had laboured all the nyght before in vayne, yet anone he beleueth Christes worde and applyeth hymselfe by faith to the byddynge of Christ.
column8: And albeit that Simon Peter despaired that the letting down of the nets could do any good, sing they had laboured all the night before in vain, yet anon he believeth Christes word and applieth himself by faith to the bidding of Christ.

column7: So they dyd cast downe theyr nette and caught an excedynge great nombre of fyshes.
column8: So they did cast down their net and caught and exceeding great number of fishes.

column7: Here we be exhorted to labour, and also to fayth, that we shulde beleue the worde of god, which yf we do, there shalbe no doubt at al for our lyuing, but it shall folow, not skasely, but pletyfully, so that it shalbe ynough for Peter, <NOTE> that Peter maye gyue parte to other.
column8: Here we be exhorted to labour, and also to faith, that we should believe the word of god, which if we do, there shall no doubt at all for our living, but it shall follow, not skasely, but pletyfully, so that it shall enough for Peter, that Peter may gyve part to other.

column7: Now whan Simon Peter sawe the great myracle that Christ wrought here wyth hym, P A G Eci he fell downe at Iesus knees, sayenge: Lorde, go fro me, for I am a synfull man.
column8: Now when Simon Peter saw the great miracle that Christ wrought here with him, PAGEci PAGEci PAGEci PAGEci he fell down at Jesus knees, saying: Lord, go from me, for I am a sinful man.

column7: Here good people we be taught, what we owe to the Lorde for hys benefites and large blessynge of foode.
column8: Here good people we be taught, what we owe to the Lord for his benefits and large blessing of food.

column7: Fyrst to be thankefull vnto hym accordynge to thexemple of Peter.
column8: Fyrst to be thankful unto him according to thexemple of Peter.

column7: Secondly, that we shulde acknowlege oure vnworthynes, how we be farre vnworthy that God shulde bestowe so hygh benefytes vpon vs. <NOTE> And thys vnworthynes ought to sprynge of the knowlege of our sinnes, as Peter here lyke a good penitent person said: Lorde departe from me, for I am a synfull man.
column8: Secondly, that we should acknowledge our unworthiness, how we be far unworthy that God should bestow so high benefits upon us And this unworthiness ought to spring of the knowledge of our sins, as Peter here like a good penitent person said: Lord depart from me, for I am a sinful man.

column7: Thus a man to shewe hys kyndnes and to knowlege hymselfe a synfull person before God, the scripture calleth it the sacrifice of prayse moost acceptable to the Lorde of heauen. <NOTE> what dyd our Sauiour Christ answere agayne vnto Symon Peter?
column8: Thus a man to show his kindness and to knowledge himself a sinful person before God, the scripture calls it the sacrifice of praise most acceptable to the Lord of heaven. what did our Saviour Christ answer again unto Symon Peter?

column7: Feare not from hence forth thou shalt catch men. Here we be warned by thexemple of Peter, Iames, & Ihon, to set all thynges behynde the studye of the Gospell, and yf by the state of oure lyfe we be called to the offyce of preachynge, to obey our callynge.
column8: Fear not from hence forth thou shalt catch men. Here we be warned by thexemple of Peter, Iames, & Ihon, to set all things behind the study of the Gospel, and if by the state of our life we be called to the office of preaching, to obey our calling.

column7: But mans reason, as it woll rule all: so it is here also very busye, whych whan it heareth, yt these fyshermen left altogether and folowed Christe, forthwyth gathereth.
column8: But men reason, as it will rule all: so it is here also very busy, which when it hears, that these fishermen left altogether and followed Christe, forthwith gathereth.

column7: Then after the receyuynge of the gospell we must forsake, wyfe, chyldren, landes, and all that we haue.
column8: Then after the receiving of the gospel we must forsake, wife, children, lands, and all that we have.

column7: To thys I answere, that thys conclusion can not be applyed to the exemples of these fyshermen. <NOTE> For they chaunged not the condicion and state of theyr lyfe.
column8: To this I answer, that this conclusion can not be applied to the examples of these fishermen. For they changed not the condition and state of their life.

column7: For the Euangelist doth not expresse that.
column8: For the Euangelist does not express that.

column7: But admytte they chaunged the state of theyr lyfe: Ye muste consyder that they were called to an other state for they were called to catche men, that is to saye, to preach gods worde.
column8: But admit they changed the state of their life: You must consider that they were called to and other state for they were called to catch men, that is to say, to preach gods word.

column7: Howbeit here is not prescribed in these Apostles a commaundement for vs to folowe the same, albeit they left al yt they had.
column8: Howbeit here is not prescribed in these Apostles a commandment for us to follow the same, albeit they left all that they had.

column7: The fayth of sayntes or holy persons is to be folowed of all men generally, <NOTE> it is not necessary that the workes shulde be egall in all.
column8: The faith of saints or holy persons is to be followed of all men generally, it is not necessary that the works should be equal in all.

column7: For els we shulde be compelled to become fyrste fyshermen, and afterwarde to leaue fyshyngcraft as these disciples dyd.
column8: For else we should be compelled to become fyrste fishermen, and afterward to leave fyshyngcraft as these disciples did.

column7: Ye must vnderstande then that the Gospell perteyneth to the conscience, and therfore it teacheth not ye chaunge of the temporall lyfe or state whyche ciuile ordinaunce alloweth.
column8: You must understand then that the Gospel pertaineth to the conscience, and therefore it teaches not you change of the temporal life or state which civil ordinance alloweth.

column7: Let vs then (my frendes) folowe the fayth of thys Apostle Peter, and hys penitent harte, confessynge our vnworthynes.
column8: Let us then (my friends) follow the faith of this Apostle Peter, and his penitent heart, confessing our unworthiness.

column7: And then doubt we not, but we shalbe called to the greate feaste, where we shall sytte at table wyth the hole company of heauen in the heauenly palace of God the father.
column8: And then doubt we not, but we shall called to the great feast, where we shall fit at table with the hold company of heaven in the heavenly palace of God the father.

column7: To whome wyth the sonne and holy goost be prayse and glorye.
column8: To whom with the son and holy ghost be praise and glory.

column7: AMEN.
column8: AMEN.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.vj. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the vj sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.vi. chapter to the Romaynes.
column8: The vi chapter to the Romans.

column7: Thargument Of the spirituall signification of oure baptisme.
column8: Thargument Of the spiritual signification of our baptism.

column7: B Rethren, knowe ye not that all we whych are baptised into Iesu Christ, are baptysed to dye wyth hym?
column8: BRethren BRethren, know you not that all we which are baptised into Jesu Christ, are baptised to die with him?

column7: We are buryed then wyth him by baptysme, P A G Ecij for to dye: that lykewyse as Christ was raysed vp from death by the glory of the father, euen so we also shulde walke in a new lyfe.
column8: We are buried then with him by baptism, PAGEcij PAGEcij PAGEcij PAGEcij for to die: that likewise as Christ was raised up from death by the glory of the father, even so we also should walk in a new life.

column7: For yf we be grafte in death lyke vnto hym: euen so shall we be partakers of the resurrection: knowynge thys, that our olde man is crucifyed wyth hym also, that the bodye of synne myghte vtterly be destroyed, that henseforth we shulde not be seruautes vnto synne.
column8: For if we be graft in death like unto him: even so shall we be partakers of the resurrection: knowing this, that our old man is crucified with him also, that the body of sin might utterly be destroyed, that henceforth we should not be seruautes unto sin.

column7: For he that is dead, is iustifyed from synne.
column8: For he that is dead, is justified from sin.

column7: Wherfore yf we be deade wyth Christ, we beleue, that we shall also lyue wyth hym: knowynge, that Christe beynge raysed from death, dyeth nomore.
column8: Wherefore if we be dead with Christ, we believe, that we shall also live with him: knowing, that Christe being raised from death, dyeth nomore.

column7: Death hath nomore power ouer hym.
column8: Death hath nomore power over him.

column7: For as touchynge that he dyed he dyed concernynge synne once.
column8: For as touching that he died he died concerning sin once.

column7: And as touchynge that he lyueth, he lyueth vnto God.
column8: And as touching that he liveth, he liveth unto God.

column7: Lykewise consyder ye also, that ye are dead as touchynge synne, but are alyue vnto God thorowe Iesus Christ our Lorde.
column8: Likewise consider you also, that you are dead as touching sin, but are alive unto God thorough Jesus Christ our Lord.

column7: A Fter the holy Apostle saint Paule (good christe people) had declared to the Romaynes the profyte of these two great artycles of our fayth, that is to saye, christes death and his resurrection, shewing them, that Christ by hys moost precious death purchased the euerlastynge remission of our synne, and by hys resurrection ascended vp to heauen to open the gates therof for vs, and apeased ye wrath of the father and made vs in fauoure agayne wyth hym & that by this his dede we be iustified, <NOTE> goddes louynge chyldren and the ryghte enheritours of the kyngdome of heuen: now in thys epistle he teacheth vs an other lesson to be cosydered in Christes death and resurrection, and setteth it before vs as an exeple to folow the maner therof in our owne selfe, meanynge it shulde not auayle vs to beleue that Christe dyed and rose agayne from death: excepte we woll conforme our lyfe to hys death and resurrection.
column8: AFter AFter the holy Apostle saint Paule (good christe people) had declared to the Romans the profit of these two great articles of our faith, that is to say, christes death and his resurrection, showing them, that Christ by his most precious death purchased the everlasting remission of our sin, and by his resurrection ascended up to heaven to open the gates thereof for us, and appeased you wrath of the father and made us in favour again with him & that by this his deed we be justified, gods loving children and the right enheritours of the kingdom of heaven: now in this epistle he teaches us and other lesson to be cosydered in Christes death and resurrection, and sets it before us as and exeple to follow the manner thereof in our own self, meaning it should not avail us to believe that Christe died and rose again from death: except we will conform our life to his death and resurrection.

column7: Do ye not knowe (sayeth saynt Paule) what further thynge is sygnifyed vnto you in Christes death? or to what ende ye be baptysed?
column8: Do you not know (sayeth saint Paule) what further thing is sygnifyed unto you in Christes death? or to what end you be baptised?

column7: Verely so many as be christened in the name of Christ Iesus and by baptisme be grafte in the nomber of hys seruauntes, be therfore baptised that in a certayne similitude they shulde dye wyth hym.
column8: Verily so many as be christened in the name of Christ Jesus and by baptism be graft in the number of his servants, be therefore baptised that in a certain similitude they should die with him.

column7: Such a signification and fygure hath Christes death vnto vs, that besyde that it is the pryce of our synnes, it monysheth vs daylye to dye to synne, dayly to mortifye and to slee ye euell affections and motions of synne and concupiscence rysynge vp in our hartes agaynst the wyll of God.
column8: Such a signification and figure hath Christes death unto us, that beside that it is the price of our sins, it monisheth us daily to die to sin, daily to mortify and to slee you evil affections and motions of sin and concupiscence rising up in our hearts against the will of God.

column7: And verely such a sygnification hath the ceremonye of our baptysme also vnto vs. <NOTE> For whan we be plonged vnder the water, and be lyfte vp agayne: it meaneth nothinge els but that our synne is washed and slayne by Christ, and we by hys grace lyft vp frome deth (whych our synne deserued) to euerlasting lyfe.
column8: And verily such a sygnification hath the ceremony of our baptism also unto us For when we be plunged under the water, and be lift up again: it means nothing else but that our sin is washed and slain by Christ, and we by his grace lift up from death (which our sin deserved) to everlasting life.

column7: It sygnifyeth furthermore that we there promyse to dye to synne & dayly to ryse vp agayne out of synne to a new lyfe, the lyfe of ryghtuousnes.
column8: It signifieth furthermore that we there promise to die to sin & daily to rise up again out of sin to a new life, the life of righteousness.

column7: And thys is the vertue & fygure of baptysme, whych yf we take not after thys purpose, we do but deceyue oure selues wyth the outwarde token of the sacrament and lose the inwarde commoditie therof.
column8: And this is the virtue & figure of baptism, which if we take not after this purpose, we do but deceive our selves with the outward token of the sacrament and loose the inward commodity thereof.

column7: Wherfore my frendes consyder the spirituall meanynge of this holy P A G Eciij sacrament, & let it put you in mynde that ye haue promysed there a perpetuall mortificacion and penaunce of your synne: wherof it is a sygne.
column8: Wherefore my friends consider the spiritual meaning of this holy PAGEciij PAGEciij PAGEciij PAGEciij sacrament, & let it put you in mind that you have promised there a perpetual mortification and penance of your sin: whereof it is a sign.

column7: Ye be ones baptysed, and nede nomore to receyue the sacrament, but yet the sygnification therof muste ye dayly fulfyll, that is, to dye to synne, & to ryse more and more to perfytnes of lyfe.
column8: You be ones baptised, and need nomore to receive the sacrament, but yet the sygnification thereof must you daily fulfil, that is, to die to sin, & to rise more and more to perfytnes of life.

column7: For we be not washed from our synne by the bloude of Christe shed for vs in hys death, that we shulde retourne agayne therto but therfore be we clensed, that from henseforth we shulde defoule our selfe nomore wyth synne.
column8: For we be not washed from our sin by the blood of Christe shed for us in his death, that we should return again thereto but therefore be we cleansed, that from henceforth we should defoul our self nomore with sin.

column7: And as Christ dyed and was buryed for vs, so shuld we dye and be buryed wyth him, that is to saye, synne shuld dye in vs and be vtterly as buryed, neuer to be sene agayne in our lyfe.
column8: And as Christ died and was buried for us, so should we die and be buried with him, that is to say, sin should die in us and be utterly as buried, never to be seen again in our life.

column7: And as Christe was raysed vp from death by the glorious spirite of the father to lyfe agayne, so shulde we dayly ryse vp from the frutes of synne to a new lyfe & walke continually there in.
column8: And as Christe was raised up from death by the glorious spirit of the father to life again, so should we daily rise up from the fruits of sin to a new life & walk continually there in.

column7: And as the power of goddes holy spirite raysed Christ vp agayne from death to lyfe whyche worke redounded to the greate glorye and prayse of God: euen so by the power of the same spirite, shall we be able to ryse fro death of synne to the newnes of vertuouse lyfe.
