column8: And as the power of gods holy spirit raised Christ up again from death to life which work redounded to the great glory and praise of God: even so by the power of the same spirit, shall we be able to rise from death of sin to the newness of virtuous life.

column7: In whych our doynge we shall in some maner, worke to the glorye of god when men shal se our well doynge: and prayse the father of heauen for hys grace that he worketh in vs. Let then noman refuse to mortifye hys euell affections that he fealeth in hym.
column8: In which our doing we shall in some manner, work to the glory of god when men shall see our well doing: and praise the father of heaven for his grace that he works in us Let then noman refuse to mortify his evil affections that he fealeth in him.

column7: That yf it be paynfull for hym to abstayne from synne: let hym consyder that els he can not be the chylde of God.
column8: That if it be painful for him to abstain from sin: let him consider that else he can not be the child of God.

column7: For he is none of Christes yt hath not hys spirite, and by thys token is it knowen who is grafte in Christe, and is in the state of saluation.
column8: For he is none of Christes that hath not his spirit, and by this token is it known who is graft in Christe, and is in the state of salvation.

column7: For it is not he whyche foloweth the lustes of hys fleshe, but he whych walketh after the spirite.
column8: For it is not he which followeth the lusts of his flesh, but he which walks after the spirit.

column7: Let vs consyder what saynt Paule sayeth here: Yf we be lyke Christ in the similitude of hys death: we shalbe partakers wyth hym in the generall resurrection, for yf the selfe same spirite ruleth in vs to fyghte agaynst synne whych raysed Christe from death to euerlastynge lyfe, it shall also rayse vs from the corporall death of our body to lyfe agayne and that to lyfe euerlastynge.
column8: Let us consider what saint Paule sayeth here: If we be like Christ in the similitude of his death: we shall partakers with him in the general resurrection, for if the self same spirit ruleth in us to fight against sin which raised Christe from death to everlasting life, it shall also raise us from the corporal death of our body to life again and that to life everlasting.

column7: And let vs knowe thys of suertye that as Christe hath not slayne synne and crucifyed it vpon the crosse, that we shulde lyue in it and serue the desyre therof but that we shulde be deliuered fro the daunger of it: euen so ought we to slee oure olde Adam, that is to saye, all euyll motions and lustes of synne whyche we inheryte by that we be Adams chyldren conceyued and borne in synne.
column8: And let us know this of surety that as Christe hath not slain sin and crucified it upon the cross, that we should live in it and serve the desire thereof but that we should be delivered from the danger of it: even so ought we to slee our old Adam, that is to say, all evil motions and lusts of sin which we inheryte by that we be Adams children conceived and born in sin.

column7: I saye we ought to subdue hym all oure lyfe tyme & kepe hym vnder by the crosse of wylful penaunce and afflictio, so by lytle and lytle to abolysh and expell out of our soules the hole body and lompe of synne & viciouse nature wherin we be borne.
column8: I say we ought to subdue him all our life time & keep him under by the cross of wilful penance and afflictio, so by little and little to abolish and expel out of our souls the hold body and lompe of sin & vicious nature wherein we be born.

column7: In dede so to mortifye synne, that we shulde fele no motions therof so loge as we be in the body, it can not be: but yet by goddes holy spirite yf we take good hede, we maye so lyue that we shall not serue synne and be led wylfully vnder the dominion therof.
column8: In deed so to mortify sin, that we should feel no motions thereof so loge as we be in the body, it can not be: but yet by gods holy spirit if we take good heed, we may so live that we shall not serve sin and be led wilfully under the dominion thereof.

column7: Wherfore they whyche so loue theyr euell affections, yt they stryue not agaynst them to subdue them to God: wante goddes spirite (the gage of theyr saluation) and so serue synne as theyr lorde and mayster: and therfore be vnder the P A G Eciiij daunger of synne and deserue the stypende therof whych is euerlastyng deth: <NOTE> but he that wt good hart and wyll studyeth to resyst and fyght against synne and the motions therof and laboureth to kyll it dayly more and more, is now iustifyed from synne that is to saye delyuered from the daunger and penaltye therof. <NOTE> For saynt Paule sayeth playnly to the Romaynes.
column8: Wherefore they which so love their evil affections, that they strive not against them to subdue them to God: want gods spirit (the gage of their salvation) and so serve sin as their lord and master: and therefore be under the PAGEciiij PAGEciiij PAGEciiij PAGEciiij danger of sin and deserve thee stypende thereof which is everlasting death: but he that with good heart and will studieth to resist and fight against sin and the motions thereof and laboureth to kill it daily more and more, is now justified from sin that is to say delivered from the danger and penalty thereof. For saint Paule sayeth plainly to the Romans.

column7: Yf ye mortifye the dedes of the fleshe and lustes of the corruptible body, ye shal lyue, & in this epistle he sayeth the same, that yf we be folowers of Christ in his death, that is in dyeng to synne, we beleue certaynly that we shall lyue wyth hym.
column8: If you mortify the deeds of the flesh and lusts of the corruptible body, you shall live, & in this epistle he sayeth the same, that if we be followers of Christ in his death, that is in dying to sin, we believe certainly that we shall live with him.

column7: Christe ones was rysen fro death and dyeth nomore, death shall nomore haue power of hym, for in that he dyed (sayeth oure epistle) he dyed ones for all, and by hys ones dyenge he destroyed synne for euer.
column8: Christe ones was risen from death and dyeth nomore, death shall nomore have power of him, for in that he died (sayeth our epistle) he died ones for all, and by his ones dying he destroyed sin for ever.

column7: He dyed ones to synne and after he was ones deade he was neuer assauted of synne after, but quyte discharged of it and nowe lyueth to God and euermore shall he enioye the lyfe whych he is now attayned vnto, and shall neuer dye agayne.
column8: He died ones to sin and after he was ones dead he was never assaulted of sin after, but quite discharged of it and now liveth to God and evermore shall he enjoy the life which he is now attained unto, and shall never die again.

column7: Euen so suppose you youre selues deade to synne, that is to saye, thynke youre selues so to be discharged from synne & that Christe hath destroyed the power therof for you, as ye conforme your selfe to the lyfe of vertue.
column8: Euen so suppose you your selves dead to sin, that is to say, think your selves so to be discharged from sin & that Christe hath destroyed the power thereof for you, as you conform your self to the life of virtue.

column7: In baptysme ye dye to synne and promyse to lyue to ryghtuousnes: and therfore yf ye kepe youre promyse you be deade to synne and synne is vtterly deade in you, so that ye folowe not the lustes therof.
column8: In baptism you die to sin and promise to live to righteousness: and therefore if you keep your promise you be dead to sin and sin is utterly dead in you, so that you follow not the lusts thereof.

column7: Euen so the lyfe whych you now lyue, is to God and to hys pleasure Ye lyue now by your fayth in ryghtuousnes, which commeth by Iesus Christ our Lorde not of any workes of ryghtuousnes whyche we haue done sayeth S. Paule, lest we shulde glorye in our selfe for thys lyfe of grace wherin we lyue before God. <NOTE> But of his mercy hath he saued vs thorow the foutayne of baptysme wherin we be new borne agayne and renewed by the holy goost, to lyue thys newe lyfe acceptable before god.
column8: Euen so the life which you now live, is to God and to his pleasure You live now by your faith in righteousness, which comes by Jesus Christ our Lord not of any works of righteousness which we have done sayeth S. Paule, lest we should glory in our self for this life of grace wherein we live before God. But of his mercy hath he saved us thorough the foutayne of baptism wherein we be new born again and renewed by the holy ghost, to live this new life acceptable before god.

column7: And as by the mercy of our Lorde we be set in thys lyfe of grace and strenghthed by hys gracyouse spirite to contynue vs therin, no more to retorne and fall to synne and to the lustes therof: euen so is the lyfe of glory which we now tary for in hope the gyfte of almyghty God thorow the merites and purchasynge of Christe Iesu, <NOTE> that all myghte be of God: and no fleshe shulde glorye in his syght but he that wyll glory, let hym glorye in the Lorde.
column8: And as by the mercy of our Lord we be set in this life of grace and strenghthed by his gracious spirit to continue us therein, no more to return and fallen to sin and to the lusts thereof: even so is the life of glory which we now tarry for in hope the gift of almighty God thorough the merits and purchasing of Christe Jesu, that all might be of God: and no flesh should glory in his sight but he that will glory, let him glory in the Lord.

column7: Nowe my frendes, these thynges afore rehersed wel consydered, let vs diligently laboure wyth oure selues to mortifye and subdue the euell desyres of our fleshe.
column8: Now my friends, these things afore rehearsed well considered, let us diligently labour with our selves to mortify and subdue the evil desires of our flesh.

column7: Yf we wyll haue any parte of Christes death and resurrection, let vs kepe batayl wyth the flesh and beware we be not subdued therof.
column8: If we will have any part of Christes death and resurrection, let us keep battle with the flesh and beware we be not subdued thereof.

column7: We do boast of Christ in vayne, yf we serue the desyre of synne.
column8: We do boast of Christ in vain, if we serve the desire of sin.

column7: For it is not ynough to say that we be christen men and that we pertayne to Christe, <NOTE> for he that sayeth he abyde in Christ (as wryteth saynt Ihon) must in such wyse walke in hys lyfe as Christ walked in hys, for it is not he (sayeth our Sauiour) whyche sayeth to me Lorde, <NOTE> Lorde, that shal enter into the kyngdome of heauen, but he that doeth the wyll of my father whych is in heauen.
column8: For it is not enough to say that we be christian men and that we pertain to Christe, for he that sayeth he abide in Christ (as writes saint Ihon) must in such wise walk in his life as Christ walked in his, for it is not he (sayeth our Saviour) which sayeth to me Lord, Lord, that shall enter into the kingdom of heaven, but he that doth the will of my father which is in heaven.

column7: How much then are they deceyued whych in such wyse do fansye of Christ and hys death, that they care not into what synne they fall & P A G Ecv continue in only trustyng vaynly vpon the merytes of the same: where here saynt Paule affirmeth that we shall neuer lyue wyth Christ, excepte we mortifye our euyll affections and desyres, and lyue in ryghtuousnes. <NOTE> For though God requyreth fayth as ye fyrste entre to come to Christe, yet he requyreth also, yt out of thys fayth shulde springe good and vertuouse lyuyng.
column8: How much then are they deceived which in such wise do fancy of Christ and his death, that they care not into what sin they fallen & PAGEcv PAGEcv PAGEcv PAGEcv continue in only trusting vainly upon the merits of the same: where here saint Paule affirmeth that we shall never live with Christ, except we mortify our evil affections and desires, and live in righteousness. For though God requireth faith as you fyrste enter to come to Christe, yet he requireth also, that out of this faith should spring good and virtuous living.

column7: Fyrst he sayeth in the gospel of saynt Marke. <NOTE> Repent and beleue the Gospell: It is no fayth that hath not repentaunce.
column8: Fyrst he sayeth in the gospel of saint Mark. Repent and believe the Gospel: It is no faith that hath not repentance.

column7: It is a vayne repentaunce wherin be espyed no workes of repentaunce.
column8: It is a vain repentance wherein be espied no works of repentance.

column7: Nowe the workes of true repentaunce be feare and drede of God, hatred of synne, purpose of amendemente, & diligence to watch agaynst the euell motions of syn Surely ther is no fayth, where the spirite of God is not: And there is not the spirite of God but the spirite of the deuell: where such frutes be raygnyng, as be adultery, fornication, wantonnes, hatred, stryfe, enuye, wrath, cotention, sedition, partestakyng, <NOTE> murther, dronkennes, and excesse.
column8: Now the works of true repentance be fear and dread of God, hatred of sin, purpose of amendment, & diligence to watch against the evil motions of sin Surely there is no faith, where the spirit of God is not: And there is not the spirit of God but the spirit of the devil: where such fruits be reigning, as be adultery, fornication, wantonness, hatred, strife, envy, wrath, cotention, sedition, partestakyng, murder, drunkenness, and excess.

column7: The doers of these, yf they repent not: shall neuer be inheritours wt Christ how much so euer they boast of Christ.
column8: The doers of these, if they repent not: shall never be inheritors with Christ how much so ever they boast of Christ.

column7: And agaynst these must we dayly fight to subdue them, yf we wil be of Christes flocke.
column8: And against these must we daily fight to subdue them, if we will be of Christes flock.

column7: For as saynt Hierom wryteth: Ne semel putemus ardorem fidei posse sufficere: <NOTE> semper crux portanda est, vt semper Christum amare doceamur.
column8: For as saint Hierom writes: Ne semel putemus ardorem fidei posse sufficere: semper crux portanda est, vt semper Christum amare doceamur.

column7: Ita apostolus portabat iugiter carnis mortificationem in corpore suo, quod qui facit omni tempore semper orat, semper poenitet.
column8: Ita apostolus portabat iugiter carnis mortificationem in corpore suo, quod qui facit omni tempore semper orat, semper poenitet.

column7: &c. Let vs not thinke that the feruentnesse of fayth can ones suffyse, euermore must the crosse be borne, that so we maye be taught euer to loue Christ.
column8: etc. Let us not think that the ferventness of faith can ones suffice, evermore must the cross be born, that so we may be taught ever to love Christ.

column7: Thus dyd the apostle beare cotinually the mortification of the fleshe in hys body: <NOTE> whych thynge he that doth: dothe praye alwaye and repent alwaye.
column8: Thus did the apostle bear continually the mortification of the flesh in his body: which thing he that does: doth pray alway and repent alway.

column7: Also saint Austine sayeth: Whosoeuer is wythout the fayth which worketh by charitie (though he seme to repent doynge it but faynedly) is an euel tree, and of such a tree what sayeth saynt Ihon baptyst. <NOTE> Euery tree whych bryngeth not forth good frute, shalbe cut vp and cast into the fyer.
column8: Also saint Austine sayeth: Whosoever is without the faith which works by charity (though he seem to repent doing it but fainedly) is and evil tree, and of such a tree what sayeth saint Ihon baptist. Every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit, shall cut up and cast into the fire.

column7: Let vs my frendes (all vayne presumptions and false trustes cast awaye) labour to performe our promyse whych we made at the fount stone, let vs I saye renounce the deuell and hys suggestions, and serue Christ our Lorde and mayster by the true workes of ryghtuousnes.
column8: Let us my friends (all vain presumptions and false trusts cast away) labour to perform our promise which we made at the fount stone, let us I say renounce the devil and his suggestions, and serve Christ our Lord and master by the true works of righteousness.

column7: Let vs watch daylye agaynst oure euell dispositions, that we maye lyke obedient chyldren of God glorifye God in oure lyfe. <NOTE> In so doynge we shall persuade oure owne hartes that we pertayne to hym and that we haue the true fayth whych is of value before God.
column8: Let us watch daily against our evil dispositions, that we may like obedient children of God glorify God in our life. In so doing we shall persuade our own hearts that we pertain to him and that we have the true faith which is of valve before God.

column7: To whome wyth the sonne and the holy goost be prayse for euer and euer.
column8: To whom with the son and the holy ghost be praise for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospell on the.vj. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the vj sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.v. chapter of Matheu.
column8: The v chapter of Matheu.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: P A G Ecvi Christ correcteth the false doctrine of the pharisees and teacheth the true iustice.
column8: PAGEcvi PAGEcvi PAGEcvi PAGEcvi Christ correcteth the false doctrine of the pharisees and teaches the true justice.

column7: I Esus sayd vnto hys disciples, Verely I saye vnto you: except your ryghteousnes excede the ryghteousnes of the scribes and pharisees, ye can not entre into the kyngdome of heuen.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples, Verily I say unto you: except your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the scribes and pharisees, you can not enter into the kingdom of heaven.

column7: Ye haue herd that it was sayd vnto them of the old tyme: Thou shalt not kyll: who soeuer kylleth, shalbe in daunger of iudgement.
column8: You have heard that it was said unto them of the old time: Thou shalt not kill: who soever killeth, shall in danger of judgement.

column7: But I saye vnto you: that who soeuer is angrye wyth hys brother (vnaduisedly) shalbe in daunger of iudgement.
column8: But I say unto you: that who soever is angry with his brother (unadvisedly) shall in danger of judgement.

column7: And whosoeuer saye vnto hys brother, Racha, shalbe in dauger of a councel.
column8: And whosoever say unto his brother, Racha, shall in dauger of a council.

column7: But whosoeuer sayeth, thou fole, shalbe in dauger of hell fyre.
column8: But whosoever sayeth, thou sole, shall in dauger of hell fire.

column7: Therfore, yf thou offrest thy gyfte at the altare, and there remembrest that thy brother hath ought agaynst the: leaue there thyne offrynge before the aulter, & go thy way fyrst, and be reconciled to thy brother, & then come, & offre thy gift
column8: Therefore, if thou offerest thy gift at the altar, and there remembrest that thy brother hath ought against thee: leave there thine offering before the alter, & go thy way fyrst, and be reconciled to thy brother, & then come, & offer thy gift

column7: IN thys Gospell (good people) our sauiour Christ correcteth the corrupte doctrine of the Scribes and Pharisees, and vtterly disproueth theyr ryghtuousnes, and teacheth vs whych is the true ryghtuousnes, sayenge: Onles youre ryghtuousnes passe the ryghtuousnes of the scribes and pharisees, ye can not entre into the kyngdome of heauen. As who shulde saye, onles your couersacion, your good lyuynge in loue and charitie, your studye and zele to folowe gods commaundementes be aboue the pharisees, thynke not to come to heauen.
column8: IN this Gospel (good people) our saviour Christ correcteth the corrupt doctrine of the Scribes and Pharisees, and utterly disproveth their righteousness, and teaches us which is the true righteousness, saying: Unless your righteousness pass the righteousness of the scribes and pharisees, you can not enter into the kingdom of heaven. As who should say, unless your couersacion, your good living in love and charity, your study and zeal to follow gods commandments be above the pharisees, think not to come to heaven.

column7: Fyrst ye muste marke the difference betwene gods comaundementes and mans, whych is touched in thys selfe chapter a lytle before, where Christ sayd.
column8: Fyrst you must mark the difference between gods commandments and men, which is touched in this self chapter a little before, where Christ said.

column7: Whosoeuer shal breake one of these lest commaundentes, shalbe called the leste in the kyngdome of heauen, that is, he shalbe sure neuer to entre into heauen.
column8: Whosoever shall break one of these lest commaundentes, shall called the lest in the kingdom of heaven, that is, he shall sure never to enter into heaven.

column7: Here ye may not gather, that these be lytle or small commaundementes of God.
column8: Here you may not gather, that these be little or small commandments of God.

column7: For Christe speaketh here after the iudgement of the people.
column8: For Christe speaks here after the judgement of the people.

column7: For the scribes and pharisees had so taught and entysed the people to folowe the lawes and constitutions of men, that gods lawe was lytle or nothynge regarded.
column8: For the scribes and pharisees had so taught and enticed the people to follow the laws and constitutions of men, that gods law was little or nothing regarded.

column7: So that Christe there dyd speake after the maner and reputacion of them.
column8: So that Christe there did speak after the manner and reputation of them.

column7: But surely he that shal teache so, shalbe called the lest in heauen, that is, he shall not come there at all.
column8: But surely he that shall teach so, shall called the lest in heaven, that is, he shall not come there at all.

column7: For the pharisees had auaunced the lawes, commaundementes, ceremonies, tradicions, and inuencions of men aboue the lawes and commaundementes of god. <NOTE> Christ therfore expouneth the lawe accordynge to the mynde and sentence of God, whych requyreth eue moost pure affections of the harte, wheras the pharisees thought it ynough to fulfyl ye lawe in outwarde worke after theyr exposition.
column8: For the pharisees had advanced the laws, commandments, ceremonies, traditions, and inventions of men above the laws and commandments of god. Christ therefore exponeth the law according to the mind and sentence of God, which requireth eve most pure affections of the heart, whereas the pharisees thought it enough to fulfil you law in outward work after their exposition.

column7: Ye haue herde (sayeth Christ) that it was sayd vnto them of the olde tyme. <NOTE> Thou shalte not kyll.
column8: You have herd (sayeth Christ) that it was said unto them of the old time. Thou shalt not kill.

column7: &c. My fredes fyrst ye muste note, that it is the father of heauen yt speaketh these wordes, and that he speaketh them to euery one of vs. Nowe what meaneth he by these wordes?
column8: etc. My fredes fyrst you must note, that it is the father of heaven that speaks these words, and that he speaks them to every one of us Now what means he by these words?

column7: Surely he meaneth playnly herby, that thou mayst not slee neyther wyth thy body nor wyth any member.
column8: Surely he means plainly hereby, that thou mayest not slee neither with thy body nor with any member.

column7: But seynge these wordes were spoken to man, let vs consyder, wherof man is made.
column8: But sing these words were spoken to man, let us consider, whereof man is made.

column7: Euery one of vs is made of body and soule.
column8: Every one of us is made of body and soul.

column7: To the bodye P A G Ecvij longeth the heade, feete, armes, and the other mebers.
column8: To the body PAGEcvij PAGEcvij PAGEcvij PAGEcvij longeth the head, feet, arms, and the other mebers.

column7: In the soule or mynde of man do raygne affections, as rancour, malice, hatred, grudge, wrath, and enuie.
column8: In the soul or mind of man do reign affections, as rancour, malice, hatred, grudge, wrath, and envy.

column7: To the bodye I saye perteyne all thy mebers.
column8: To the body I say pertain all thy mebers.

column7: Then thou mayst kyll noman wyth thy heade, that is, thou mayest gyue no token to any other man to kyll, nor yet gyue counsayll to any other to do it.
column8: Then thou mayest kill noman with thy head, that is, thou mayest gyve no token to any other man to kill, nor yet gyve counsel to any other to do it.

column7: Nor thou mayest kyll noman wyth thy handes.
column8: Nor thou mayest kill noman with thy hands.

column7: So in lyke wyse of the mynde, thou mayst not be wroth, nor out of charitie wyth thy brethren, nor desyre or wyll them any hurte by corrupte affections of thy mynde, yf thou doest, thou surely breakest thys comaudement.
column8: So in like wise of the mind, thou mayest not be wroth, nor out of charity with thy brothers, nor desire or will them any hurt by corrupt affections of thy mind, if thou dost, thou surely breakest this comaudement.

column7: Now the Iues & pharisees dyd not vnderstande theyr lawe, but toke it carnally.
column8: Now the Iues & pharisees did not understand their law, but took it carnally.

column7: For they thought yf they did not kyl outwardly wyth sword, all was saufe.
column8: For they thought if they did not kill outwardly with sword, all was saufe.

column7: But bycause they were so blynded wyth ignoraunce, therfore Christe expouneth them thys commaundement sayenge:
column8: But because they were so blinded with ignorance, therefore Christe exponeth them this commandment saying:

column7: But I saye vnto you that whosoeuer is angry with hys brother wythout cause shalbe in daunger of iudgement, <NOTE> and who soeuer sayeth to hys brother (racha) shalbe in daunger of counsayll But who so euer sayeth foole, shalbe in daunger of hell fyre. Surely my frendes to beare malyce and yre in hart secretly agaynst thy neyghbour is not so greate as to speke it also, as to cal thy brother Racha, as who shulde saye, ah, or well.
column8: But I say unto you that whosoever is angry with his brother without cause shall in danger of judgement, and who soever sayeth to his brother (racha) shall in danger of counsel But who so ever sayeth fool, shall in danger of hell fire. Surely my friends to bear malice and ire in heart secretly against thy neighbour is not so great as to speak it also, as to call thy brother Racha, as who should say, ah, or well.

column7: For vndoubtedlye it is a token of a greater malyce whan it breaketh out and is spoken.
column8: For undoubtedly it is a token of a greater malice when it breaks out and is spoken.

column7: But it is a more offence to speake it wyth a greater violence, as to saye foole to thy brother in despyte and malyce wyllynge hym hurte, and it is vndoubtedly ryght damnable, and so be they al thre but yet there be degrees.
column8: But it is a more offence to speak it with a greater violence, as to say fool to thy brother in despite and malice willing him hurt, and it is undoubtedly right damnable, and so be they all thre but yet there be degrees.

column7: For loke how the grefe of the offense be spoken and done: so shall the payne be distributed.
column8: For look how the grief of the offence be spoken and done: so shall the pain be distributed.

column7: I saye they be all damnable, but the one is deper then the other.
column8: I say they be all damnable, but the one is deeper then the other.

column7: The greater the offence be, ye more paine in hel.
column8: The greater the offence be, you more pain in hell.

column7: But now a dayes we go further then to saye foole.
column8: But now a days we go further then to say fool.

column7: For we call in despyte hooremayster, thefe, horeson, vilayne, yea traytour, heretique, pharisee, infidele, and not alonly in speakynge, but also intendynge to auenge and execute our malicious mynde.
column8: For we call in despite hooremayster, thief, whoreson, villain, yea traitor, heretic, pharisee, infidel, and not alonely in speaking, but also intending to avenge and execute our malicious mind.

column7: Oh what a depe damnation hangeth ouer these men.
column8: O what a deep damnation hangs over these men.

column7: How hygh a presumption is thys, to compare wyth God, to auaunce oure selues in gods rowme and to auenge our selues, whych thynge only perteyneth to hym.
column8: How high a presumption is this, to compare with God, to advance our selves in gods room and to avenge our selves, which thing only pertaineth to him.

column7: For he sayeth: Let me alone wyth vengeaunce and I shall paye it.
column8: For he sayeth: Let me alone with vengeance and I shall pay it.

column7: It foloweth: Therfore yf thou offerest thy gyfte at the aultare, and there remembrest that thy brother hath ought agaynst the, leaue there thyne offerynge before the aultare.
column8: It followeth: Therefore if thou offerest thy gift at the altar, and there remembrest that thy brother hath ought against thee, leave there thine offering before the altar.

column7: &c. Good people I praye you marke well thys maner of speakynge that Christ vseth.
column8: etc. Good people I pray you mark well this manner of speaking that Christ uses.

column7: He byddeth vs leaue there our offeryng.
column8: He biddeth us leave there our offering.

column7: He differreth no tyme, but sayeth, go by and by, and reconcile thy brother, or els I hate the and thy offerynge.
column8: He differeth no time, but sayeth, go by and by, and reconcile thy brother, or else I hate thee and thy offering.

column7: Therfore fyrst reconcile thy brother and then come and offer vp thy gyfte. <NOTE> By recocilyng of thy brother is meant to make hym at one, whan thou haste brought hym out of charitie, or hast seperated him out of Christes flocke and made hym the chylde of euerlastyng dapnacion.
column8: Therefore fyrst reconcile thy brother and then come and offer up thy gift. By recocilyng of thy brother is meant to make him at one, when thou haste brought him out of charity, or hast separated him out of Christes flock and made him the child of everlasting dapnacion.

column7: And thys makynge at one, in to brynge hym agayne into Christes flocke & to make hym ye chylde P A G Ecviij of saluation.
column8: And this making at one, in to bring him again into Christes flock & to make him the child PAGEcviij PAGEcviij PAGEcviij PAGEcviij of salvation.

column7: Furthermore yf thou perceyuest thy brother offended and angrye wyth the, though thou hast gyuen hym no cause: yet thou arte bydden here of Christ to go, and make him at one and then come and offer vp thy gyfte.
column8: Furthermore if thou perceivest thy brother offended and angry with thee, though thou hast given him no cause: yet thou art bidden here of Christ to go, and make him at one and then come and offer up thy gift.

column7: After this maner thou muste offer thy gyfte to the aultare & wyth a good mynde and glad harte and not grudgyngly.
column8: After this manner thou must offer thy gift to the altar & with a good mind and glad heart and not grudgingly.

column7: For els, all is nought that thou doest.
column8: For else, all is nought that thou dost.

column7: For where the spirite of god is, there is lybertie.
column8: For where the spirit of god is, there is liberty.

column7: So that we muste do all thynges that God commaundeth vs to do, frely wyth a good mynde and a louynge harte.
column8: So that we must do all things that God commandeth us to do, freely with a good mind and a loving heart.

column7: Christ sayeth, yf thou offerest thy gyft.
column8: Christ sayeth, if thou offerest thy gift.

column7: Here therfore thou muste consyder fyrste and knowe whether it be thyne or no, for yf it be not thyne, brynge none.
column8: Here therefore thou must consider fyrste and know whither it be thine or no, for if it be not thine, bring none.

column7: Surely as longe as thou gettest thy goodes wyth true laboure and wyth no deceyte, nor breakyng goddes comaundementes, & yf the poore man hath no nede of thy goodes, so longe it is thyne owne and thou mayest offer it.
column8: Surely as long as thou gettest thy goods with true labour and with no deceit, nor breaking gods commandments, & if the poor man hath no need of thy goods, so long it is thine own and thou mayest offer it.

column7: But yf thou kepest it awaye from the poore man wha he nedeth it, or gettest it by any false meanes deceyuynge the people, than it is not thine, but thou arte a thefe and doest steale it.
column8: But if thou keepest it away from the poor man wha he needeth it, or gettest it by any false means deceiving the people, than it is not thine, but thou art a thief and dost steal it.

column7: Therfore then offer none, but restore it agayne, for yf thou offerest it, it is in vayne, and God abhorreth both the and thyne offerynge.
column8: Therefore then offer none, but restore it again, for if thou offerest it, it is in vain, and God abhorreth both the and thine offering.

column7: But as touchynge thy tythes and such offerynges as the lawe compelleth the to paye vnto thy curate, <NOTE> surely thou arte bounde faythfully and truly to pay them.
column8: But as touching thy tithes and such offerings as the law compelleth thee to pay unto thy curate, surely thou art bound faithfully and truly to pay them.

column7: Thou mayest not take from the prestes duetye, and gyue it to the poore, for then thou art a thefe and thou robbest Peter to paye Paule.
column8: Thou mayest not take from the priests duty, and gyve it to the poor, for then thou art a thief and thou robbest Peter to pay Paule.

column7: Gyue therfore to euery one that whyche is hys.
column8: Gyve therefore to every one that which is his.

column7: Gyue to thy kynge hys duetye, to thy poore & nedye brother that whych charitie wylleth the to gyue, and paye thy curate hys duetye, yea though he be neuer so naughty of lyuynge, thoughe he be viciouse, proude, ambiciouse, and though he lyue neuer so gloriously and voluptuously.
column8: Gyve to thy king his duty, to thy poor & needy brother that which charity willeth thee to gyve, and pay thy curate his duty, yea though he be never so naughty of living, though he be vicious, proud, ambiciouse, and though he live never so gloriously and voluptuously.

column7: Peraduenture thou wylt saye.
column8: Peradventure thou wilt say.

column7: Why, shall I paye my tythes and offerynges to such a curate to maynteyne hys vngracious lyuynge?
column8: Why, shall I pay my tithes and offerings to such a curate to maintain his ungracious living?

column7: Yea forsoth.
column8: Yea forsooth.

column7: Why?
column8: Why?

column7: For the church hath so decreed and the lawes hathe ordeyned and commaunded.
column8: For the church hath so decreed and the laws hath ordained and commanded.

column7: Therfore paye him his duetye wyth a good wyl, and no doute thou art discharged towardes God.
column8: Therefore pay him his duty with a good will, and no doubt thou art discharged towards God.

column7: But he for receyuynge and spendynge it on that maner is a stronge thefe and shalbe hanged in hell for it, yf he make not amedes.
column8: But he for receiving and spending it on that manner is a strong thief and shall hanged in hell for it, if he make not amedes.

column7: In dede yf thou gyuest to suche a curate more then hys dutye, <NOTE> thou mayest be a maynteyner of his euyll lyuinge and naughtynes.
column8: In deed if thou gyvest to such a curate more then his duty, thou mayest be a maynteyner of his evil living and naughtynes.

column7: But yf he be a good curate doynge hys duetye, preachyng to hys paryshners the worde of God, gyuing them exeple of good lyuynge and teachyng them Christes rule, that they may knowe it and folow it: forsoth to such one thou canst not gyue to much.
column8: But if he be a good curate doing his duty, preaching to his parishioners the word of God, gyving them exeple of good living and teaching them Christes rule, that they may know it and follow it: forsooth to such one thou canst not gyve to much.

column7: Why?
column8: Why?

column7: For thou shalte be sure to haue it agayne whan so euer thou shalt haue nede of it.
column8: For thou shalt be sure to have it again when so ever thou shalt have need of it.

column7: For such a charitable man woll surely not se the poore man wante.
column8: For such a charitable man will surely not see the poor man want.

column7: Thus my frendes I haue declared vnto you the true ryghtuousnes that Christ requyreth of vs. Ye be here taught to mortifye the affections of ye harte.
column8: Thus my friends I have declared unto you the true righteousness that Christ requireth of us You be here taught to mortify the affections of the heart.

column7: Yf ye do thys, ye shall shewe youre selues to be in dede ryght and perfyte christen people, the chyldren of saluacion and the enheritours of the kyngdome of P A G Ecix God.
column8: If you do this, you shall show your selves to be in deed right and perfect christian people, the children of salvation and the enheritours of the kingdom of PAGEcix PAGEcix PAGEcix PAGEcix God.

column7: To whome be honoure and glorye.
column8: To whom be honour and glory.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.vij. sondaye after Trinitie The.vi. chapter to the Romaynes.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the vij sondaye after Trinitie The vi chapter to the Romans.

column7: Thargument An exhortacion to good workes.
column8: Thargument And exhortation to good works.

column7: B Rethren, I wyll speake grosly, because of the infirmitie of youre fleshe.
column8: BRethren BRethren, I will speak grossly, because of the infirmity of your flesh.

column7: As ye haue gyuen your members seruauntes to vnclennes and to iniquitie (fro one iniquitie to an other) euen so nowe gyue ouer youre members, seruauntes vnto ryghteousnes, that ye maye be sanctified.
column8: As you have given your members servants to uncleanness and to iniquity (from one iniquity to and other) even so now gyve over your members, servants unto righteousness, that you may be sanctified.

column7: For when ye were the seruauntes of synne, ye were not vnder ryghteousnes.
column8: For when you were the servants of sin, you were not under righteousness.

column7: What frute hadde ye than in those thinges, wherof ye are nowe ashamed?
column8: What fruit had you than in those things, whereof you are now ashamed?

column7: For thende of those thynges, is deathe.
column8: For th'end of those things, is death.

column7: But nowe are ye delyuered from synne and made the seruautes of god and haue your frute to be sanctified, and the ende euerlastyng lyfe.
column8: But now are you delivered from sin and made the seruautes of god and have your fruit to be sanctified, and the end everlasting life.

column7: For the rewarde of synne is deathe: but eternall lyfe is the gyfte of god, thorough Iesus Christe our Lorde.
column8: For the reward of sin is death: but eternal life is the gift of god, through Jesus Christe our Lord.

column7: IN thys lesson (good christen people) thapostle S. Paule exhorteth the Romaynes and in them vs al, that now syth by the benefyte of Christes redemption we be made fre fro the condempnation of synne and be iustifyed and reconciled to God the father of heauen by the mediacion of Christes bloude which was shed on the aultare of the crosse for our transgressions and offenses: we woll gyue our selues to good and vertuouse lyuynge.
column8: IN this lesson (good christian people) apostle S. Paule exhorteth the Romans and in them us all, that now sith by the benefit of Christes redemption we be made from from the condemnation of sin and be justified and reconciled to God the father of heaven by the mediation of Christes blood which was shed on the altar of the cross for our transgressions and offenses: we will gyve our selves to good and virtuous living.

column7: For albeit sayeth S. Paule, ye be enfraunchysed and made fre fro synne and as who shulde saye manumissed as bondmen be wonte: yet ye be not so vtterly fre, but ye be styl in bondage and seruitude to ryghtuousnes, that is to saye, to good lyuynge and honest conuersacion.
column8: For albeit sayeth S. Paule, you be enfraunchysed and made from from sin and as who should say manumissed as bondmen be wont: yet you be not so utterly from, but you be still in bondage and servitude to righteousness, that is to say, to good living and honest conversation.

column7: So ye be free and not free, free from synne, but bonde to ryghteousnes and good lyuynge.
column8: So you be free and not free, free from sin, but bond to righteousness and good living.

column7: I speake grossely and after an humane fashion sayeth Paule to call you the bondmen and seruauntes of ryghtuousnes But to thys impropre and homelye maner of speakynge I am dryue bycause of the weaknes of your fleshe. <NOTE> I am, I saye, fayne to applye & frame my wordes accordynge to your capacitie & vnderstandynge I knowe ryght wel the infirmitie, and the weaknes of your fleshe, whych as yet is not come to ye perfection, no nor can not come to ye ful perfection so loge as ye be in thys mortall and frayle lyfe.
column8: I speak grossly and after and humane fashion sayeth Paule to call you the bondmen and servants of righteousness But to this impropre and homely manner of speaking I am drive because of the weakness of your flesh. I am, I say, fain to apply & frame my words according to your capacity & understanding I know right well the infirmity, and the weakness of your flesh, which as yet is not come to you perfection, no nor can not come to you full perfection so loge as you be in this mortal and frail life.

column7: Yea our sauiour Christ hymselfe a lytle before hys departure out of thys worlde, complayned of the infirmitie of the fleshe.
column8: Yea our saviour Christ himself a little before his departure out of this world, complained of the infirmity of the flesh.

column7: Wherfore my frendes, lyke as before ye receyued the Gospell of Christ ye haue frely and volutarely giuen and exhibited your membres as slaues and bonde to serue all naughtynes, all vnclennes & wyckednes, and that from one wyckednes to an ather euery one worse then other.
column8: Wherefore my friends, like as before you received the Gospel of Christ you have freely and volutarely given and exhibited your members as slaves and bond to serve all naughtynes, all uncleanness & wickedness, and that from one wickedness to and ather every one worse then other.

column7: So now, where as ye be vnder grace, and become christen persons and haue receyued Christes Gospell, I exhorte you that ye woll an other whyle serue ryghtuousnes, that is to saye, that wyth all your myght and force, ye woll studye and applye your selues to vertue, honest conuersation and good lyuyng.
column8: So now, where as you be under grace, and become christian persons and have received Christes Gospel, I exhort you that you will and other while serve righteousness, that is to say, that with all your might and force, you will study and apply your selves to virtue, honest conversation and good living.

column7: Yf ye do thys, vndoubtedly ye shalbe sanctifyed and made holy in goddes syght, whyle through ye worke and operation of the P A G Ecx holy goost new motions be created in you, whyche after a certayne maner shall answere to the lawe & satisfye the same though in great infirmitie & weakenes, makynge you wyth your harte to loue God euen of a good conscience and fayth vnfeyned.
column8: If you do this, undoubtedly you shall sanctified and made holy in gods sight, while through you work and operation of the PAGEcx PAGEcx PAGEcx PAGEcx holy ghost new motions be created in you, which after a certain manner shall answer to the law & satisfy the same though in great infirmity & weakness, making you with your heart to love God even of a good conscience and faith unfeigned.

column7: For so longe as ye were in your former state, and knewe not Christe, but lyued in ydolatrye and blyndnes of harte, seruynge synne: ye were as fremen to ryghtuousnes, that is to saye, ye serued her not, ye hadde no iustice, no ryghtuousnes in you, ye were not vnder her power and dominion.
column8: For so long as you were in your former state, and knew not Christe, but lived in idolatry and blindness of heart, serving sin: you were as fremen to righteousness, that is to say, you served her not, you had no justice, no righteousness in you, you were not under her power and dominion.

column7: I praye you then my frendes what profyte, frute, and commoditie toke ye at that tyme of your louse and fre lyuynge, I meane of your synne whych ye comonly then hauted, wherof now that ye be in the state of grace and haue receyued the tytle and also the religion of christen persones, ye be ashamed of.
column8: I pray you then my friends what profit, fruit, and commodity took you at that time of your louse and from living, I mean of your sin which you commonly then hauted, whereof now that you be in the state of grace and have received the title and also the religion of christian persons, you be ashamed of.

column7: And why be ye ashamed?
column8: And why be you ashamed?

column7: Truly bycause ye perceyue yt the ende of suche loose and vnruly lyuyng is death, and what death? death euerlastynge, eternal dampnacion in the fyre of hel, where is continuall wepynge and gnasshynge of teeth.
column8: Truly because you perceive that the end of such lose and unruly living is death, and what death? death everlasting, eternal damnation in the fire of hell, where is continual weeping and gnashing of teeth.

column7: But now good people seynge ye be infrauchysed and delyuered from the bondage and consequetly from the condemnation of synne: and are become the seruauntes of God: ye haue your frute into sanctification, that is to saye, thys frute, thys comoditie thys auauntage ye haue therby, that ye be now sanctifyed and made holy and iuste persons in goddes syght, and your ende shalbe euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: But now good people sing you be infrauchysed and delivered from the bondage and consequetly from the condemnation of sin: and are become the servants of God: you have your fruit into sanctification, that is to say, this fruit, this commodity this advantage you have thereby, that you be now sanctified and made holy and just persons in gods sight, and your end shall everlasting life.

column7: For truely so longe as ye were seruauntes to synne, ye coulde loke for none other rewarde, for none other stypende or wages, then death.
column8: For truly so long as you were servants to sin, you could look for none other reward, for none other stypende or wages, then death.

column7: Death I saye is the vndoubted stypende of synne and of beastly lyuyng But contrary wyse, <NOTE> yf ye woll be folowers of ryghtuousnes, and force your selues to serue God, vtterly renouncynge the stynkynge seruyce of synne: ye shall surely haue a farre contrarye rewarde, that is to wyt euerlastynge lyfe, <NOTE> which (as wryteth saint Austine) is a certayne rewarde of good workes, albeit the Apostle calleth it not so here, but he calleth it the grace or gyfte of God.
column8: Death I say is the undoubted stypende of sin and of beastly living But contrary wise, if you will be followers of righteousness, and force your selves to serve God, utterly renouncing the stinking service of sin: you shall surely have a far contrary reward, that is to wit everlasting life, which (as writes saint Austine) is a certain reward of good works, albeit the Apostle calls it not so here, but he calls it the grace or gift of God.

column7: Therfore herken what saynt Austine sayeth further. <NOTE> A stypende or wages due for the worke of a souldioure is payde and not gyuen, & therfore the apostle sayeth, the stypende of synne is death, to shewe that death is not vndeseruedlye put but due to synne.
column8: Therefore harken what saint Austine sayeth further. A stypende or wages due for the work of a soldier is paid and not given, & therefore the apostle sayeth, the stypende of sin is death, to show that death is not undeservedly put but due to sin.

column7: But grace yf it be not frely is no grace.
column8: But grace if it be not freely is not grace.

column7: Ye muste therfore vnderstande that euen the selfe good merytes of man be the rewardes of God vnto whych whan eternall lyfe is yelded, what is redred but grace for grace?
column8: You must therefore understand that even the self good merits of man be the rewards of God unto which when eternal life is yielded, what is redred but grace for grace?

column7: These be saynt Austines wordes.
column8: These be saint Austines words.

column7: Wherfore good people let vs not thynke yt we be fre from good workes, by the bloud of Christ but rather cleane contrary that we be nowe bounde to good workes accordyng to saynt Pauls doctrine here whych affirmeth that yf we serue synne, we shal be sure to haue the wages of synne euen euerlasting death.
column8: Wherefore good people let us not think that we be from from good works, by the blood of Christ but rather clean contrary that we be now bound to good works according to saint Pauls doctrine here which affirmeth that if we serve sin, we shall be sure to have the wages of sin even everlasting death.

column7: But yf we lyue vertuously and iustly & serue God, we shalbe sure to haue euerlastyng lyfe not as a rewarde of dutye but as a gyfte and grace of god, through Iesus Christ our Lorde.
column8: But if we live virtuously and justly & serve God, we shall sure to have everlasting life not as a reward of duty but as a gift and grace of god, through Jesus Christ our Lord.

column7: To whome be all glorye.
column8: To whom be all glory.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The gospell on the.vij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The gospel on the vij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.viij. chapter of Marke.
column8: The viij chapter of Mark.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: P A G Ecxj The myracle of the.vij. loues.
column8: PAGEcxj PAGEcxj PAGEcxj PAGEcxj The miracle of the vij loves.

column7: Whan there was a verye greate companye, and had nothynge to eate, Iesus called hys disciples to hym, and sayde vnto them: I haue copassion on the people, because they haue nowe bene wyth me thre dayes, and haue nothynge to eat and yf I sende them awaye fastyng to theyr owne houses, they shall faynt by the waye.
column8: When there was a very great company, and had nothing to eat, Jesus called his disciples to him, and said unto them: I have copassion on the people, because they have now be with me thre days, and have nothing to eat and if I send them away fasting to their own houses, they shall faint by the way.

column7: For dyuerse of them came from farre.
column8: For diverse of them came from far.

column7: And hys disciples answered hym: where shulde a man haue breade here in the wyldernesse to satisfye these?
column8: And his disciples answered him: where should a man have bread here in the wilderness to satisfy these?

column7: And he asked them how many looues haue ye?
column8: And he asked them how many loves have you?

column7: They sayd: seuen. And he commaunded the people to syt downe on the grounde.
column8: They said: seuen. And he commanded the people to fit down on the ground.

column7: And he toke the seuen looues: and whan he had gyuen thankes, he brake, and gaue to his disciples, to set before them.
column8: And he took the seuen loves: and when he had given thanks, he brake, and gave to his disciples, to set before them.

column7: And they dyd set them before the people.
column8: And they did set them before the people.

column7: And they had a few smal fyshes And whan he had blessed, he comauded them also to be set before them.
column8: And they had a few small fishes And when he had blessed, he comauded them also to be set before them.

column7: And they dyd eate and were suffysed.
column8: And they did eat and were sufficed.

column7: And they toke vp of the broke meate that was lefte seuen baskettes full.
column8: And they took up of the broke meat that was left seuen baskets full.

column7: And they that dyd eate, were aboute foure thousande. And he sente them awaye.
column8: And they that did eat, were about foure thousande. And he sent them away.

column7: IN thys gospel, good christen people, ye shal note, that they whyche fyrst and formest do seke for the kyngdome of god and the ryghtuousnes of ye same, can in no wyse peryshe and dye for honger, but that the grace of God doth preuente them in al thynges, as we se in thys hystorye howe tenderly and buselye our Sauiour Christ prouideth for the peoples bodely sustenauce, euen before they aske it, sayng: I haue compassion ouer the people forasmuch as they haue bene now wyth me thre dayes and haue nothyng to eate.
column8: IN this gospel, good christian people, you shall note, that they which fyrst and formest doe seek for the kingdom of god and the righteousness of you same, can in no wise perish and die for hunger, but that the grace of God does prevent them in all things, as we see in this history how tenderly and busily our Saviour Christ provideth for the peoples bodily sustenance, even before they ask it, saying: I have compassion over the people forasmuch as they have be now with me thre days and have nothing to eat.

column7: Thys then is Christes order of fedynge, fyrste to repast ye soule wyth hys worde, and then to releue the bodye. <NOTE> But the worldly care is contrarye, accordynge to a Poetes sayenge: O ciues ciues, quaereda pecunia primum est, virtus post nummos. That is to saye: O citizens citizens, fyrst seke for money, and after money for vertue.
column8: This then is Christes order of feeding, fyrste to repast you soul with his word, and then to relieve the body. But the worldly care is contrary, according to a Poets saying: O ciues ciues, quaereda pecunia primum est, virtus post nummos. That is to say: Oh citizens citizens, fyrst seek for money, and after money for virtue.

column7: But Christ sayth: Fyrst seke for the kyngdome of God and al these thynges shal be cast vnto you. <NOTE>
column8: But Christ say: Fyrst seek for the kingdom of God and all these things shall be cast unto you.

column7: Secondly, here is described vnto vs an exemple of infidelitie in thapostles and vnder them in all suche as woll do as they dyd here, whyche leauynge gods worde & forgettynge all the myracles whych Christ had done before, by whyche they ought well to haue gathered that Christ myght haue fedde thys multytude wythout any vytayll at all, be deceyued by the iudgement of reason whyche onely loketh vpon the thynge present, and thynketh thynges only to folow of sure occasios only.
column8: Secondly, here is described unto us and exemple of infidelity in apostles and under them in all such as will do as they did here, which leaving gods word & forgetting all the miracles which Christ had done before, by which they ought well to have gathered that Christ might have fed this multitude without any vytayll at all, be deceived by the judgement of reason which only looketh upon the thing present, and thinketh things only to follow of sure occasios only.

column7: Surely whyle reason iudgeth thus, it iudgeth wel before the worlde in ciuile thynges.
column8: Surely while reason judgeth thus, it judgeth well before the world in civil things.

column7: But before Christ and in his presence to cal reason into iudgement, & thervpon to despayre of Christes power: is certaynly a point of infidelitie, namely syth before God there is nothyng impossible. <NOTE> And here furthermore we haue an exemple in Christe of great gentlenes and pacience, <NOTE> whych reiecteth not the vnfaythfull disciples.
column8: But before Christ and in his presence to call reason into judgement, & thereupon to despair of Christes power: is certainly a point of infidelity, namely sith before God there is nothing impossible. And here furthermore we have and exemple in Christe of great gentleness and patience, which rejects not the unfaithful disciples.

column7: Thyrdly, here is prescribed vnto vs the tyme whan Christ is wont moost of all to helpe, whyche is euen P A G Ecxij then when no occasion is present, but whan reason vtterly despayreth of her argumentes or coniectures.
column8: Thyrdly, here is prescribed unto us the time when Christ is wont most of all to help, which is even PAGEcxij PAGEcxij PAGEcxij PAGEcxij then when no occasion is present, but when reason utterly despaireth of her arguments or conjectures.

column7: So Christe in thys historye suffreth hys Apostles a lytle whyle to delude themselues wyth the argumetes of theyr owne reason, that he might bringe them to the vttter denyall of themselues & also that they myght learne to flee to the almyghtynes of god wherby he is able to helpe, euen there where no occasion of helpynge is offered. <NOTE> be neuertheles here taught and admonished, not to despise suche occasions of temporal lyuynge as be offered vnto vs. For Christ of hys omnipotency myght haue made bread of stones, or myght haue caused foode to haue rayned downe fro heauen, or yf he had wolde, he myght haue fedde the people onely wyth the vertue of hys worde.
column8: So Christe in this history suffers his Apostles a little while to delude themselves with the argumetes of their own reason, that he might bring them to the vttter denial of themselves & also that they might learn to flee to the almyghtynes of god whereby he is able to help, even there where no occasion of helping is offered. be nevertheless here taught and admonished, not to despise such occasions of temporal living as be offered unto us For Christ of his omnipotency might have made bred of stones, or might have caused food to have rained down from heaven, or if he had would, he might have fed the people only with the virtue of his word.

column7: But Christ doth none of all these, but taketh the breade and the fewe fyshes whyche by occasion was ministred vnto hym, and by hys blessynge of breade, maketh breade: and of fyshe, fyshe.
column8: But Christ does none of all these, but takes the bread and the few fishes which by occasion was ministered unto him, and by his blessing of bread, makes bread: and of fish, fish.

column7: Fynally we be here instructed and taught, that bodely foode and sustenaunce wyth all other necessaries of our lyfe commeth vnto vs by the only prouidence and blessynge of God, yea euen then whan we thynke lest of it.
column8: Finally we be here instructed and taught, that bodily food and sustenance with all other necessaries of our life comes unto us by the only providence and blessing of God, yea even then when we think lest of it.

column7: Wherfore good people accordynge to the lesson of thys Gospel, let vs fyrst seke for our soule helth and foode, as we se the people dyd here, and doubt we no thynge, but God wyll prouyde well ynough for our bodely foode.
column8: Wherefore good people according to the lesson of this Gospel, let us fyrst seek for our soul health and food, as we see the people did here, and doubt we no thing, but God will provide well enough for our bodily food.

column7: Let vs not do as the Romane citizens dyd whych fyrst sought for money and then for vertue, but let vs fyrst seke for vertue and for the kingdome of God, and then wythout muche sekynge the rest shalbe aboundauntly gyue vs. Let vs not trust to much to our owne carnall reason as the Apostles dyd here, but let vs thynke nothynge impossible to God, yea let vs be ful assured that he wol helpe wha he seeth best hys tyme, beynge throughly persuaded that all thynges come by the large blessynge of god To whome be all glorye.
column8: Let us not do as the Roman citizens did which fyrst sought for money and then for virtue, but let us fyrst seek for virtue and for the kingdom of God, and then without much seeking the rest shall abundantly gyve us Let us not trust to much to our own carnal reason as the Apostles did here, but let us think nothing impossible to God, yea let us be full assured that he will help wha he sees best his time, being thoroughly persuaded that all things come by the large blessing of god To whom be all glory.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.viij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the viij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.viij. chapter to the Romaynes.
column8: The viij chapter to the Romans.

column7: Thargument Of the mortification of the fleshe.
column8: Thargument Of the mortification of the flesh.

column7: B Rethren, we are detters, not to the fleshe to lyue after the fleshe.
column8: BRethren BRethren, we are debtors, not to the flesh to live after the flesh.

column7: For yf ye lyue after the fleshe, ye shall dye.
column8: For if you live after the flesh, you shall die.

column7: But yf ye (thorowe the spirite) do mortifie the dedes of the body, ye shall lyue.
column8: But if you (thorough the spirit) do mortify the deeds of the body, you shall live.

column7: For as many as are led by the spirite of God, they are the sonnes of God.
column8: For as many as are led by the spirit of God, they are the sons of God.

column7: For ye haue not receyued the spirite of bondage to feare eny moare, but ye haue receyued the spirite of adoption, whereby we crye: Abba, father.
column8: For you have not received the spirit of bondage to fear any moare, but you have received the spirit of adoption, whereby we cry: Abba, father.

column7: The same spirite certifieth our spirite that we are the sonnes of god.
column8: The same spirit certifieth our spirit that we are the sons of god.

column7: Yf we be sonnes, then are we also heyres: the heyres I meane of God, and heyres anexed wyth Christ: yf so be that we suffer wyth hym, that we maye be also glorified together wyth hym.
column8: If we be sons, then are we also heirs: the heirs I mean of God, and heirs adnexed with Christ: if so be that we suffer with him, that we may be also glorified together with him.

column7: F Yrst in thys Epistle we be taught, good christen people, <NOTE> that after we be ones grafted by the sacrament of baptysme into the holy communion of christen persons and thervpon through the intercession and merytes of Christes most holy bloude shed P A G Ecxiij for vs be iustyfyed and reconcyled to the father of Heauen: we ought nowe not to lyue accordynge to the lust of the flesshe, but vtterly to mortyfye the dedes of the same, and to do the workes of the spirite, that is to say, not fleshly workes but spirituall workes, honest, vertuous, and charitable workes, the stypende and reward wherof is euerlastyng lyfe, wheras the rewarde of them that do otherwyse and that lyue after the fleshe is death without ende.
column8: FYrst FYrst in this Epistle we be taught, good christian people, that after we be ones grafted by the sacrament of baptism into the holy communion of christian persons and thereupon through the intercession and merits of Christes most holy blood shed PAGEcxiij PAGEcxiij PAGEcxiij PAGEcxiij for us be iustyfyed and reconciled to the father of Heaven: we ought now not to live according to the lust of the flesh, but utterly to mortyfye the deeds of the same, and to do the works of the spirit, that is to say, not fleshly works but spiritual works, honest, virtuous, and charitable works, the stypende and reward whereof is everlasting life, whereas the reward of them that do otherwise and that live after the flesh is death without end.

column7: And here the Apostle Paule setteth before our eyes aswell the promyses as the thretnynges & terrours, wherwith he frayth vs away from carnall workes, and exhorteth vs to the mortyfycacion of the flesshe and vnto ghostly workes whiche be semynge for christen men to vse.
column8: And here the Apostle Paule sets before our eyes aswell the promises as the threatenings & terrors, wherewith he frayth us away from carnal works, and exhorteth us to the mortyfycacion of the flesh and unto ghostly works which be seeming for christian men to use.

column7: To the carnal workes he yeldeth for rewarde death, and consequently eternal damnacyon.
column8: To the carnal works he yieldeth for reward death, and consequently eternal damnation.

column7: To spirituall and good worckes in place of rewarde he ascrybeth lyfe, wherein the godly parsons do here in this worlde lyue holyly, and after this worlde shall enioye eternall lyfe.
column8: To spiritual and good works in place of reward he ascrybeth life, wherein the godly parsons do here in this world live holily, and after this world shall enjoy eternal life.

column7: Secondly, we be here taught by S. Paule that yf we be right Christias, I meane, yf we lyue not after the fleshe, but after the spirite and christianly: we be sure to be the sons and chyldren of God.
column8: Secondly, we be here taught by S. Paule that if we be right Christias, I mean, if we live not after the flesh, but after the spirit and christianly: we be sure to be the sons and children of God.

column7: And on the contrary syde yf we lyue otherwyse, we be vndoubtedly the chyldren of Sata. <NOTE> And forasmuch as there be two sortes of spirites, the spirite of feare or bondage, and the spirite of adoptyon, wherof the fyrste pertayneth to wycked persons, and the other pertayneth to the good and godly persons: therfore ye shal vnderstande that they whiche haue the spirite of bodage do all that they do coactly and not of a fre hert these be the chyldren of the law or letter and be mere hypocrytes.
column8: And on the contrary side if we live otherwise, we be undoubtedly the children of Satan. And forasmuch as there be two sorts of spirits, the spirit of fear or bondage, and the spirit of adoption, whereof the fyrste pertaineth to wicked persons, and the other pertaineth to the good and godly persons: therefore you shall understand that they which have the spirit of bodage do all that they do coactly and not of a from heart these be the children of the law or letter and be mere hypocrites.

column7: But they whiche do good workes euen of a fre hert and not as copelled by feare of the lawe but euen of loue, these be the ryght chyldren of god, these be the true christians, these haue the harte and the grace in all their necessities to crye to God theyr father and to call hym Abba father and to aske of him with certayne and sure fayth all that they want whiche is necessarye for them to haue.
column8: But they which do good works even of a from heart and not as copelled by fear of the law but even of love, these be the right children of god, these be the true christians, these have the heart and the grace in all their necessities to cry to God their father and to call him Abba father and to ask of him with certain and sure faith all that they want which is necessary for them to have.

column7: These haue peace of conscyence, wherby they beynge iustyfyed and led of the spirite of god, be throughly persuaded in their conscience, that by the merites of Christ they haue God their mercyfull Lorde and father, whiche wyll bothe helpe them and here them in theyr nede.
column8: These have peace of conscience, whereby they being iustyfyed and led of the spirit of god, be thoroughly persuaded in their conscience, that by the merits of Christ they have God their merciful Lord and father, which will both help them and here them in their need.

column7: Of this peace speaketh S. Paule in the.v. Chapter of the Romaynes, saying.
column8: Of this peace speaks S. Paule in the v Chapter of the Romans, saying.

column7: Nowe then that we be iustyfyed by fayth, we haue peace towardes God by our Lord Iesu Christ.
column8: Now then that we be iustyfyed by faith, we have peace towards God by our Lord Jesu Christ.

column7: But of the seruyle feare wherwith all hypocrites & no true christians by indowed, saynt Iohn wryteth in this wise, <NOTE> feare is not in loue but perfecte loue casteth forthe feare, because feare hath torment. <NOTE>
column8: But of the seruyle fear wherewith all hypocrites & no true christians by endowed, saint John writes in this wise, fear is not in love but perfect love casts forth fear, because fear hath torment.

column7: Thyrdly, we be here taught what is the moste propre offyce of the holy ghost, that is to say, to certyfye vs of our enheritaunce whiche we receyue in Chryst Iesu.
column8: Thyrdly, we be here taught what is the most proper office of the holy ghost, that is to say, to certyfye us of our inheritance which we receive in Chryst Jesu.

column7: With this confyrmacyon of the holy Ghoste were all sayntes and holy men sealed euen as many as constantly stode and persisted in the confession of Christe and whiche at this daye do persyst.
column8: With this confirmation of the holy Ghost were all saints and holy men sealed even as many as constantly stood and persisted in the confession of Christe and which at this day do persyst.

column7: And for this cause dothe the Apostle oftentymes wyshe and desyre to suche as he wrote, the strengthnyng of the holy ghost, <NOTE> as to the Ephesians, where he sayth.
column8: And for this cause doth the Apostle oftentimes wish and desire to such as he wrote, the strengthening of the holy ghost, as to the Ephesians, where he say.

column7: P A G Ecxiiij For thys thynge do I bowe my knees that ye maye be strengthened by hys holy spirite.
column8: PAGEcxiiij PAGEcxiiij PAGEcxiiij PAGEcxiiij For this thing do I bow my knees that you may be strengthened by his holy spirit.

column7: And of thys office or propertie whych the holy goost hath, <NOTE> he is oftentymes called the ernest, the pledge, the gage, the seale, or certificate.
column8: And of this office or property which the holy ghost hath, he is oftentimes called the earnest, the pledge, the gage, the seal, or certificate.

column7: Fynally we be here instructed, <NOTE> that albeit we surelye knowe we be the heyres of God and felowe heyres with Christ, yet neuertheles it behoueth vs to be glorifyed by tamynge and mortifyenge of oure lustes, by pacient suffrynge of tribulation and displeasures as the apostle sayeth here.
column8: Finally we be here instructed, that albeit we surely know we be the heirs of God and fellow heirs with Christ, yet nevertheless it behooves us to be glorified by taming and mortifyenge of our lusts, by patient suffering of tribulation and displeasures as the apostle sayeth here.

column7: Heyres wyth Christe yf so be we suffre wyth hym that we may also be glorifyed wyth hym.
column8: Heirs with Christe if so be we suffer with him that we may also be glorified with him.

column7: Wherfore my frendes yf we couet to be of the saued nombre: let vs accordynge to S. Paules exhortacion, kyll the lustes of oure fleshe, to thyntent we maye lyue and walke spiritually.
column8: Wherefore my friends if we covet to be of the saved number: let us according to S. Paules exhortation, kill the lusts of our flesh, to thyntent we may live and walk spiritually.

column7: Then in all oure nedes we shall as louynge chyldren be bolde to call to our moost tender and kynde father for succoure.
column8: Then in all our needs we shall as loving children be bold to call to our most tender and kind father for succour.

column7: Then shall we be certifyed by the holy goost, that we be the sonnes and heyres of God, and ioynt neyres wyth Christ wyth whome, yf we suffre wyth hym, we shall also be glorifyed.
column8: Then shall we be certified by the holy ghost, that we be the sons and heirs of God, and joint neyres with Christ with whom, if we suffer with him, we shall also be glorified.

column7: To whome be honoure and glorye per infinita secula.
column8: To whom be honour and glory per infinita secula.

column7: Amen.: homily The Gospell on the.viij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: Amen.: homily The Gospel on the viij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.vij. chapter of Matheu.
column8: The vij chapter of Matheu.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Signes wherby to discerne false teachers.
column8: Signs whereby to discern false teachers.

column7: I Esus sayd vnto hys dysciples.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples.

column7: Beware of false prophetes, whyche come to you in shepes clothynge, but inwardly they are rauenynge wolues.
column8: Beware of false prophets, which come to you in sheeps clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.

column7: Ye shall knowe them by theyr frutes.
column8: You shall know them by their fruits.

column7: Do men gather grapes of thornes? or fygges of thystles?
column8: Do men gather grapes of thorns? or figs of thystles?

column7: Euen so euery good tre bringeth forth good frutes.
column8: Euen so every good tre brings forth good fruits.

column7: But a corrupte tre, bryngeth forth euell frutes.
column8: But a corrupt tre, bringeth forth evil fruits.

column7: A good tre can not brynge forth bad frute: neyther can a bad tre brynge forth good frutes.
column8: A good tre can not bring forth bad fruit: neither can a bad tre bring forth good fruits.

column7: Euery tre that bryngeth not forth good frute, is hewen downe, and cast into the fyre.
column8: Every tre that bringeth not forth good fruit, is hewn down, and cast into the fire.

column7: Wherfore, by theyr frutes ye shall knowe them.
column8: Wherefore, by their fruits you shall know them.

column7: Not euery one that sayeth vnto me, Lorde, Lorde, shall enter into the kyngdome of heauen: but he that doth the wyll of my father, whych is in heaue, he shal entre into the kyngdom of heauen.
column8: Not every one that sayeth unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven: but he that does the will of my father, which is in heave, he shall enter into the kingdom of heaven.

column7: F Orasmuche as (good christen people) it is harde to know false teachers and theyr doctrine: therfore our Sauiour Christ thought it not ynough to bydde vs beware of them, but he addeth also certain tokens and sygnes wherby we maye easely discerne and knowe them.
column8: Forasmuch Forasmuch as (good christian people) it is harden to know false teachers and their doctrine: therefore our Saviour Christ thought it not enough to bid us beware of them, but he adds also certain tokens and signs whereby we may easily discern and know them.

column7: They come (sayeth Christe) vnto you in shepes clothynge, but inwardlye they are rauenynge wolues.
column8: They come (sayeth Christe) unto you in sheeps clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.

column7: They come vncalled, vnappoynted, vnsent of God, naye sent rather of the deuell to blase and sowe abrode the wycked learnynge & doctrine eyther of the byshop of Rome, or of the cursed Anabaptistes, or of the sacramentaries, or brefly to conclude of some other vngodly and detestable here tykes.
column8: They come uncalled, unappointed, unsent of God, nay sent rather of the devil to blaze and sow abroad the wicked learning & doctrine either of the bishop of Room, or of the cursed Anabaptists, or of the sacramentaries, or briefly to conclude of some other ungodly and detestable here tykes.

column7: The Lorde of heauen kepe vs and preserue vs all from theyr infections.
column8: The Lord of heaven keep us and preserve us all from their infections.

column7: They come I saye vnsent for, accordynge to the sayenge of the prophete Hieremye. <NOTE> Currebant & ego non misi eos. They ranne and I sente them not, sayeth the Lorde.
column8: They come I say unsent for, according to the saying of the prophet Hieremye. Currebant & ego non misi eos. They ran and I sent them not, sayeth the Lord.

column7: In outwarde appearaunce they seme moost holy P A G Ecxv men and of great simplicitie.
column8: In outward appearance they seem most holy PAGEcxv PAGEcxv PAGEcxv PAGEcxv men and of great simplicity.

column7: But surely accordinge to the comon prouerbe they be foxes or rather wolues cladde in lambes skynnes.
column8: But surely according to the common proverb they be foxes or rather wolves clad in lambs skins.

column7: They be lyke paynted and gaye sepulchres, whyche be fayre wythout & full of all stynche and caren wythin.
column8: They be like painted and gay sepulchres, which be fair without & full of all stynche and caren within.

column7: They come in shepes clothynge.
column8: They come in sheeps clothing.

column7: What beast is more simple, more harmeles, yea more profytable also to the common welth then the shepe?
column8: What beast is more simple, more harmless, yea more profitable also to the common wealth then the sheep?

column7: But what be these false teachers inwardly?
column8: But what be these false teachers inwardly?

column7: Inwardly sayeth Christ they be rauenouse wolues.
column8: Inwardly sayeth Christ they be rauenouse wolves.

column7: The wolues propertie is to rauen, <NOTE> to rente, to spoyle, to deuoure the shepe.
column8: The wolves property is to raven, to rend, to spoil, to devour the sheep.

column7: But nowe how shall we kepe vs and beware of these woluyshe preachers?
column8: But now how shall we keep us and beware of these wolvish preachers?

column7: By theyr frutes, sayeth Christe, ye shall knowe them, as who shulde saye.
column8: By their fruits, sayeth Christe, you shall know them, as who should say.

column7: Yf they be good men in dede and ryght teachers and no hyprocrites I meane no counterfeyte nor deceiuable preachers, they must nedes brynge forth good and godly workes, euen such workes as God comaundeth them to do, and not workes of theyr owne deuysynge & fantasyenge, but such as God alloweth, and whych procede of a fayth vnfayned.
column8: If they be good men in deed and right teachers and no hyprocrites I mean no counterfeit nor deceivable preachers, they must needs bring forth good and godly works, even such works as God comaundeth them to do, and not works of their own devising & fantasyenge, but such as God alloweth, and which proceed of a faith unfeigned.

column7: And not only they woll do them but also teache the same to other, eue as Christ and hys Apostles wold haue them taught & as they themselues taught them, not that by them we shuld iustifye our selues as the proude and gloriouse pharisee dyd that Christ speaketh of in the.xviij. chapter of Luke, <NOTE> but that we shulde accordynge to thexemple of the lowly publicane cofesse our selues synners, and desyre gods mercy.
column8: And not only they will do them but also teach the same to other, eve as Christ and his Apostles would have them taught & as they themselves taught them, not that by them we should justify our selves as the proud and glorious pharisee did that Christ speaks of in the xviij chapter of Luke, but that we should according to thexemple of the lowly publican cofesse our selves sinners, and desire gods mercy.

column7: The good and ryghte preacher woll teach the people vnfaynedly to truste & repose themselues in Christ, to stycke to the merytes of hys passion, & vtterly to reuounce theyr owne ryghtuousnes and merytes in gods syght.
column8: The good and right preacher will teach the people unfeignedly to trust & repose themselves in Christ, to stick to the merits of his passion, & utterly to reuounce their own righteousness and merits in gods sight.
