column7: He woll teache them neuertheles to mortifye theyr carnal afections and to do good workes euen of a fre harte or els yt accordyng to Paules rule they declare them selues not to be the chyldren of God. <NOTE> For yf sayeth Paule, ye lyue after the fleshe, ye shall dye.
column8: He will teach them nevertheless to mortify their carnal afections and to do good works even of a from heart or else that according to Paules rule they declare them selves not to be the children of God. For if sayeth Paule, you live after the flesh, you shall die.

column7: But yf ye mortifye the dedes of the body through the spirite, ye shall lyue.
column8: But if you mortify the deeds of the body through the spirit, you shall live.

column7: But agayne he wol teache them not to clayme heauen as of duetye for theyr workes sake, <NOTE> but rather for the promyse sake.
column8: But again he will teach them not to claim heaven as of duty for their works sake, but rather for the promise sake.

column7: For thoughe death be the wages of synne, yet eternall lyfe is no wages but (as Paule calleth it) the gyfte of God, throughe Iesus Christ our Lorde.
column8: For though death be the wages of sin, yet eternal life is no wages but (as Paule calls it) the gift of God, through Jesus Christ our Lord.

column7: Yea he woll teache them whan they haue done altogether, yet to confesse and saye that they be vnprofytable seruauntes.
column8: Yea he will teach them when they have done altogether, yet to confess and say that they be unprofitable servants.

column7: These I saye be the frutes of good teachers, these be the grapes, these be the figges that come of the good trees.
column8: These I say be the fruits of good teachers, these be the grapes, these be the figs that come of the good trees.

column7: They that teache or lyue otherwyse be naughtye & corrupte trees, & theyr frutes that they brynge forth be thornes and thystyls.
column8: They that teach or live otherwise be naughty & corrupt trees, & their fruits that they bring forth be thorns and thystyls.

column7: And I passe not though dyuerse false teachers haue dyed moost costantly and paciently in theyr erronious opinions, as many papistes, and also Anabaptistes & sacrametaries haue done in our tyme, and as it is redde that certayne heretiques named Donatistes dydde in olde tyme.
column8: And I pass not though diverse false teachers have died most costantly and patiently in their erroneous opinions, as many papists, and also Anabaptists & sacrametaries have done in our time, and as it is red that certain heretics nam Donatists did in old time.

column7: Whose erroure S. Augustine confutynge wryteth, <NOTE> that in a christian man the sufferyng of death is not to be consydered, but the cause of sufferynge, that is to wyt, whether hys doctrine be suche that he ought to suffer death for, by the comaundement of God.
column8: Whose error S. Augustine confuting writes, that in a christian man the suffering of death is not to be considered, but the cause of suffering, that is to wit, whither his doctrine be such that he ought to suffer death for, by the commandment of God.

column7: Seconde, we be here taught that wycked & euel doctrine can not endure but as an euell tree whyche P A G Ecxvi beareth no good frute is hewen downe and caste in to the fyre: euen so it is wyth euel doctrine and wyth the teachers therof.
column8: Seconde, we be here taught that wicked & evil doctrine can not endure but as and evil tree which PAGEcxvi PAGEcxvi PAGEcxvi PAGEcxvi bears no good fruit is hewn down and cast in to the fire: even so it is with evil doctrine and with the teachers thereof.

column7: Let men buylde vpon the foundacion of Christ what they woll, surely yf theyr buyldynge be stubble or haye that is to saye yf it be no sounde & sure doctrine, <NOTE> the fyre at length woll brene it vp.
column8: Let men build upon the foundation of Christ what they will, surely if their building be stubble or hay that is to say if it be no sound & sure doctrine, the fire at length will brene it up.

column7: But yf the buyldynge be golde syluer, or preciouse stones, it shall stande agaynst all tempestes.
column8: But if the building be gold silver, or precious stones, it shall stand against all tempests.

column7: As we se at thys daye how the papistical doctrine at the touch stone of gods worde appeareth in the lykenes what it is, and how it begynneth to vanyshe awaye euerywhere, where the gospell is preached.
column8: As we see at this day how the papistical doctrine at the touch stone of gods word appears in the likeness what it is, and how it beginneth to vanish away everywhere, where the gospel is preached.

column7: But the pure worde of God abydeth for euer.
column8: But the pure word of God abideth for ever.

column7: Fynally Christ doth teach vs here, that these gloriouse and holy hypocrites whych in outwarde apparaunce and in name appeare christias speakynge alwayes of god, but doynge nothing yt god byddeth them do, shal not entre into the kingdome of heuen.
column8: Finally Christ does teach us here, that these glorious and holy hypocrites which in outward appearance and in name appear christias speaking always of god, but doing nothing that god biddeth them do, shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.

column7: But they shal come thyther, whych haue Christ, and the gospell not in theyr mouthes onely, but in theyr hartes also, whych do the wyl of Christ and lyue as the gospell teacheth them.
column8: But they shall come thither, which have Christ, and the gospel not in their mouths only, but in their hearts also, which do the will of Christ and live as the gospel teaches them.

column7: These shall enheryte the kyngdome of heauen, where they shall lyue eternally in all ioye wyth the father, sonne, and holy goost.
column8: These shall enheryte the kingdom of heaven, where they shall live eternally in all joy with the father, son, and holy ghost.

column7: To whome be glorye.
column8: To whom be glory.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.ix. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the ix sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.i. Epistle to the Corin. the.x. Chap. Thargument.
column8: The i Epistle to the Corin. the x Chap. Thargument.

column7: Gods vengeaunce vpon euell lyuers and ydolaters is here set forth in exemples vnto vs.
column8: Gods vengeance upon evil livers and idolaters is here set forth in examples unto us

column7: B Rethren, we shulde not lust after euel thynges as they lusted.
column8: BRethren BRethren, we should not lust after evil things as they lusted.

column7: And that ye shulde not be worshyppers of ymages, as were some of them, accordynge as it is written: The people sat downe to eat and drynke, and rose vp to playe.
column8: And that you should not be worshippers of images, as were some of them, according as it is written: The people sat down to eat and drink, and rose up to play.

column7: Neyther let vs be defyled wyth fornication, as some of them were defyled wyth fornicatio, and fel in one daye.xxiij. thousande. Neyther let vs tempte Christe, as some of them tempted, and were destroyed of serpentes Neyther murmure ye, as some of them murmured and were destroyed of the destroyer.
column8: Neither let us be defiled with fornication, as some of them were defiled with fornicatio, and fell in one day xxiij thousande. Neither let us tempt Christe, as some of them tempted, and were destroyed of serpents Neither murmur you, as some of them murmured and were destroyed of the destroyer.

column7: All these thinges happened vnto them for exemples: but are written to put vs in remembraunce, whome the endes of the worlde are come vpon.
column8: All these things happened unto them for examples: but are written to put us in remembrance, whom the ends of the world are come upon.

column7: Wherfore let hym that thynketh he standeth, take hede, lest he fall.
column8: Wherefore let him that thinketh he stands, take heed, lest he fallen.

column7: There hath none other temptacion taken you, but such as foloweth the nature of man.
column8: There hath none other temptation taken you, but such as followeth the nature of man.

column7: But God is faythfull whych shal not suffer you to be tempted aboue your strength: but shal in the myddes of the temptacion make a waye, that ye maye be able to beare it.
column8: But God is faithful which shall not suffer you to be tempted above your strength: but shall in the mids of the temptation make a way, that you may be able to bear it.

column7: T Hys lesson my frendes of the holy apostle saint Paule conteyneth certayne notable exemples of gods vengeaunce and punyshmet whych he toke vpon the vnfaythfull fathers of olde tyme, whyche where as God had moost plentyfully heaped vpon them hys innumerable benefytes & graces: yet they euer abode vnfaythfull and wolde not in any wyse chaunge nor amende theyr naughty and beastly lyuynge.
column8: This This lesson my friends of the holy apostle saint Paule containeth certain notable examples of gods vengeance and punyshmet which he took upon the unfaithful father's of old time, which where as God had most plentifully heaped upon them his innumerable benefits & graces: yet they ever abided unfaithful and would not in any wise change nor amend their naughty and beastly living.

column7: And therfore they suffered horrible punyshementes P A G Ecxvij aswell for theyre mysbeleue as for theyre euell and detestable lyuynge. <NOTE> whych thynges (as sayeth thapostle) chaunced vnto vs in fygure, that is to wyt, that we shulde therby lerne to feare God, to beleue in God, to amende our lyfe, to gyue our selues to good workes, & not (bearynge our selfe bolde vpon vayne and ydell fayth) to force not howe we lyue as many swete brethren and new gospellers or rather false brethren & false gospellers at thys daye do, <NOTE> whych thynke they offende not what so euer they do, but that they haue full remission of theyr synnes euen in the myddes of theyr abhominable lyuynge bycause they persuade themselues to be chosen and sanctifyed before the begynnynge of the worlde.
column8: And therefore they suffered horrible punishments PAGEcxvij PAGEcxvij PAGEcxvij PAGEcxvij aswell for their mysbeleue as for their evil and detestable living. which things (as sayeth apostle) chanced unto us in figure, that is to wit, that we should thereby learn to fear God, to believe in God, to amend our life, to gyve our selves to good works, & not (bearing our self bold upon vain and idle faith) to force not how we live as many sweet brothers and new gospelers or rather false brothers & false gospelers at this day do, which think they offend not what so ever they do, but that they have full remission of their sins even in the mids of their abominable living because they persuade themselves to be chosen and sanctified before the beginning of the world.

column7: O Lorde, what a deuelish and damnable persuasion is thys?
column8: O Lord, what a devilish and damnable persuasion is this?

column7: What spirite of erroure, what deuel occupieth and vexeth these men thus to thynke?
column8: What spirit of error, what devil occupieth and vexes these men thus to think?

column7: And yet they woll be counted great clerkes and allege nothynge but scripture for them, they be full of saynt Paule.
column8: And yet they will be counted great clerks and allege nothing but scripture for them, they be full of saint Paule.

column7: But they belye saynt Paule and they falsefye scripture.
column8: But they belie saint Paule and they falsefye scripture.

column7: For saint Paule mysreported, is not S. Paule.
column8: For saint Paule mysreported, is not S. Paule.

column7: Nor scripture that is wrested is not scripture.
column8: Nor scripture that is wrested is not scripture.

column7: Let these persons then beware the soden vengeaunce of God whych hangeth ouer theyr heade.
column8: Let these persons then beware the sudden vengeance of God which hangs over their head.

column7: For yf God spared not the Israelites vpon whome he had heaped so many benefytes and whych were hys chosen and peculiare people, surely he wyl not spare vs, neither shall our baptisme, our hearyng of gods worde nor hys grace yt we haue receyued any thynge helpe vs, onles we constantly continue and abyde in oure religion and chaunge our lyfe into better.
column8: For if God spared not the Israelites upon whom he had heaped so many benefits and which were his chosen and peculiar people, surely he will not spare us, neither shall our baptism, our hearing of gods word nor his grace that we have received any thing help us, unless we constantly continue and abide in our religion and change our life into better.

column7: So then we be here monyshed, that those alonly be saued and do entre into the lade of promysse, whych stande fast to the ende, as Christ sayeth in an other place.
column8: So then we be here monished, that those alonely be saved and do enter into the lade of promise, which stand fast to the end, as Christ sayeth in and other place.

column7: He that continueth to the ende, shalbe saued.
column8: He that continueth to the end, shall saved.

column7: These exemples then of the fathers be warnynges and fygures vnto vs, that we shulde not lust after euell thynges as they lusted, as that we shulde not be ydolaters that is to saye, that we shulde not gyue to creatures suche honoure as is due only to God the creator & maker of all thynges, as the Israelites gaue to theyr golden calfe, and as the byshop of Rome do clayme at thys daye to haue, whych woll haue Emperours, Kynges, and Prynces, to fall downe prostrate on the grounde and to worship hym, euen as the deuell wold haue had Christ to do to hym. <NOTE> Wherfore in so doynge he resembleth the deuell and is no better then an Antichrist, forasmuch as such honour is due only to God, As Christ there declareth alledgynge scripture for hym.
column8: These examples then of the father's be warnings and figures unto us, that we should not lust after evil things as they lusted, as that we should not be idolaters that is to say, that we should not gyve to creatures such honour as is due only to God the creator & maker of all things, as the Israelites gave to their golden calf, and as the bishop of Rome do claim at this day to have, which will have Emperors, Kings, and Princes, to fallen down prostrate on the ground and to worship him, even as the devil would have had Christ to do to him. Wherefore in so doing he resembles the devil and is no better then and Antichrist, forasmuch as such honour is due only to God, As Christ there declareth alleging scripture for him.

column7: Furthermore yt we shulde not commytte fornicacion, <NOTE> as they dyd, as the historye of Phinees telleth, for whych defylynge of themselues there fell in one daye.xxiij. thousande. Also that we shulde not tempte Christe, that is, that we shulde do nothynge contrarye to faythe and despice such meanes and remedies as God hath appoynted for vs to vse in al thynges, as the Israelites dyd, & therfore were destroyed of serpentes, as it is red in the.xxi. chapter of Numeri.
column8: Furthermore that we should not commit fornication, as they did, as the history of Phinees telleth, for which defiling of themselves there fell in one day xxiij thousande. Also that we should not tempt Christe, that is, that we should do nothing contrary to faith and despice such means and remedies as God hath appointed for us to use in all things, as the Israelites did, & therefore were destroyed of serpents, as it is read in the xxi chapter of Numeri.

column7: Finally that we shulde not grudge and murmoure agaynst God of an ambiciouse mynde, sekynge sediciously & contenciously an other callynge then God hath appoynted vs vnto, as Chore, Dathan, and Abyron dyd, and were destroyed of the destroyer.
column8: Finally that we should not grudge and murmoure against God of and ambiciouse mind, seeking seditiously & contenciously and other calling then God hath appointed us unto, as Chore, Dathan, and Abyron did, and were destroyed of the destroyer.

column7: All these thynges I say befell, P A G Ecxviij to be exemples, presidentes and fygures, to admonysh vs, how God taketh vengeaunce vpo such dissolute and careles lyuers, and to put vs in remebraunce whych be now in the later dayes of ye world Wherfore my fredes he that thynketh that he stade that is to wyt, <NOTE> that he ryghtly perceyueth and vnderstandeth all thynges and walketh now surely in the knowlege of God, so that he despyseth al other in coparison of hymselfe and iudgeth euery man at hys pleasure, let hym take hede lest by reason of hys surenes and pryde he fall agayne from grace, from vnderstandynge and fro the knowlege of gods worde.
column8: All these things I say befell, PAGEcxviij PAGEcxviij PAGEcxviij PAGEcxviij to be examples, presidents and figures, to admonish us, how God takes vengeance upon such dissolute and careless livers, and to put us in remebraunce which be now in the later days of the world Wherefore my fredes he that thinketh that he stade that is to wit, that he rightly perceiveth and understandeth all things and walks now surely in the knowledge of God, so that he despiseth all other in coparison of himself and judgeth every man at his pleasure, let him take heed lest by reason of his sureness and pride he fallen again from grace, from understanding and from the knowledge of gods word.

column7: Now albeit many temptacions haue assaulted vs, & that we haue therby also gone astreye, yet we ought to comforte and lyft vp our selues wyth thys ryght comfortable sentence of saynt Paule, that the temptacion which hath taken vs is humane, and such as commonly chaunceth to men.
column8: Now albeit many temptations have assaulted us, & that we have thereby also gone astreye, yet we ought to comfort and lift up our selves with this right comfortable sentence of saint Paule, that the temptation which hath taken us is humane, and such as commonly chanceth to men.

column7: But God is faythfull and iust of the promyse whych he maketh to such as feare and stande in awe of hym.
column8: But God is faithful and just of the promise which he makes to such as fear and stand in awe of him.

column7: For surely he woll not suffer vs to be tempted ouer that we be able to beare, <NOTE> to the peticion in our pater noster Let vs not be ledde into temptacion.
column8: For surely he will not suffer us to be tempted over that we be able to bear, to the petition in our pater noster Let us not be led into temptation.

column7: For doubtles God tempteth no man to euel, but euery man is tepted of his owne cocupiscence and flesh whe god permytteth it so to be.
column8: For doubtless God tempts no man to evil, but every man is tepted of his own cocupiscence and flesh when god permytteth it so to be.

column7: But God shall in the myddes of the temptacion (yf wyth ernest prayer ye woll desyre hym) make a waye that ye shalbe able to beare it.
column8: But God shall in the mids of the temptation (if with earnest prayer you will desire him) make a way that you shall able to bear it.

column7: Let vs then (good people) yf we be true christen persons and do answere to our name, stande in awe euer of God, not tempte hym, not prouoke hym to anger and vengeaunce, but mekely and louynglye worke and walke as he hath comauded vs to walke So shall we haue eternal blesse wyth God.
column8: Let us then (good people) if we be true christian persons and do answer to our name, stand in awe ever of God, not tempt him, not provoke him to anger and vengeance, but meekly and lovingly work and walk as he hath comauded us to walk So shall we have eternal bless with God.

column7: To who be all glorye, prayse, and imperie for euer and euer.
column8: To who be all glory, praise, and impery for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The gospell on the.ix. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The gospel on the ix sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.xvi. chapter of Luke.
column8: The xvi chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Of the rych man and of hys stewarde.
column8: Of the rich man and of his steward.

column7: I Esus put forth a similitude vnto hys disciples, sayenge: There was a certayne ryche man whyche had a stewarde and the same was accused vnto hym that he had wasted hys goodes.
column8: IEsus IEsus put forth a similitude unto his disciples, saying: There was a certain rich man which had a steward and the same was accused unto him that he had wasted his goods.

column7: And he called hym, and sayd vnto hym: Howe is it, that I heare this of the?
column8: And he called him, and said unto him: How is it, that I hear this of thee?

column7: Gyue acomptes of thy stewardshype: For thou mayest be no longer stewarde.
column8: Gyve accounts of thy stewardshype: For thou mayest be no longer steward.

column7: The stewarde sayde wythin hymselfe: what shall I do?
column8: The steward said within himself: what shall I do?

column7: For my mayster taketh from me the stewardshyp.
column8: For my master takes from me the stewardshyp.

column7: I ca not dygge, and to begge I am ashamed.
column8: I ca not dig, and to beg I am ashamed.

column7: I wotte what to do, that when I am put out of the stewardshyp, they maye receyue me into theyr houses.
column8: I wot what to do, that when I am put out of the stewardshyp, they may receive me into their houses.

column7: So whan he had called all hys maysters detters together, he sayde vnto the fyrste: howe moche oweste thou vnto my mayster?
column8: So when he had called all his masters debtors together, he said unto the fyrste: how much oweste thou unto my master?

column7: And he sayde: an hundred tonnes of oyle.
column8: And he said: and hundred tons of oil.

column7: And he sayd vnto hym: take thy byl and sytte downe quycklye, and wryte fyftye. Than sayde he to an other: howe moche oweste thou?
column8: And he said unto him: take thy byl and fit down quickly, and write fyftye. Than said he to and other: how much oweste thou?

column7: And he sayde: an hundrede quarters of wheate.
column8: And he said: and hundrede quarters of wheat.

column7: He said vnto him: Take thy byl, and wryte foure score And the Lorde commended the vniuste stewarde, P A G Ecxix because he had done wyselye.
column8: He said unto him: Take thy byl, and write foure score And the Lord commended the unjust steward, PAGEcxix PAGEcxix PAGEcxix PAGEcxix because he had done wisely.

column7: For the chyldren of thys world are in their nacion wyser, then the children of lyght.
column8: For the children of this world are in their nation wiser, then the children of light.

column7: And I saye vnto you, make you frendes of the vnryghteouse mammon, that when ye shall haue neade, they may receyue you into euerlastynge habitacions.
column8: And I say unto you, make you friends of the unrighteous mammon, that when you shall have neade, they may receive you into everlasting habitations.

column7: G Ood people, bycause these wordes before rehersed are so spoken in parable, and are so wrapped in wrinkels that yet they seme to haue a face of a thynge done in dede and lyke an historie: I thinke it much profytable, to tarye somwhat in them.
column8: GOod GOod people, because these words before rehearsed are so spoken in parable, and are so wrapped in wrinkels that yet they seem to have a face of a thing done in deed and like and history: I think it much profitable, to tarry somewhat in them.

column7: And though we maye fynde in our hartes to beleue all yt is here spoken to be true: yet I doubte whether we maye abyde that these wordes of Christe shulde perteyne to vs, and admonysh vs of our duetye, whych lyue after suche sorte, as thoughe Christe whan he spake any thynge regarded not the tyme that came after hym, neyther prouided for vs, or any matters of ours, as some of the philosophers thought, which sayd, that God walketh vp and downe in heauen, & thynketh neuer a deale of our doynges.
column8: And though we may find in our hearts to believe all that is here spoken to be true: yet I doubt whither we may abide that these words of Christe should pertain to us, and admonish us of our duty, which live after such sort, as though Christe when he spoke any thing regarded not the time that came after him, neither provided for us, or any matters of ours, as some of the philosophers thought, which said, that God walks up and down in heaven, & thinketh never a deal of our doings.

column7: But erre not you so, stycke not you to such imaginations.
column8: But err not you so, stick not you to such imaginations.

column7: For yf ye inwardly behold these wordes, yf ye diligently rolle them in youre myndes, & after vnwynde them, ye shal se our tyme much touched in these mysteries Ye shall perceyue that god, <NOTE> by thys exemple shaketh vs by the noses, and pulleth vs by ye eares.
column8: For if you inwardly behold these words, if you diligently roll them in your minds, & after unwind them, you shall see our time much touched in these mysteries You shall perceive that god, by this exemple shakes us by the noses, and pulls us by the ears.

column7: Ye shall perceyue very playne, that God setteth before oure eyes in thys similitude, what we ought moost to flee and what we ought soonest to folowe.
column8: You shall perceive very plain, that God sets before our eyes in this similitude, what we ought most to flee and what we ought soonest to follow.

column7: For Luke sayeth, the Lorde spake these wordes to hys disciples.
column8: For Luke sayeth, the Lord spoke these words to his disciples.

column7: Wherfore let it be out of doubte, that he spake them to vs, whyche euen as we woll be counted Christes disciples, so we be, yf we be good stewardes and do our dutie.
column8: Wherefore let it be out of doubt, that he spoke them to us, which even as we will be counted Christes disciples, so we be, if we be good stewards and do our duty.

column7: He said these thynges partly to vs, and he spake them partly of hymselfe.
column8: He said these things partly to us, and he spoke them partly of himself.

column7: For he is that ryche man whych not only had but hath and shall haue euermore, I say not one but many & sudry stewardes euen to thende of the worlde.
column8: For he is that rich man which not only had but hath and shall have evermore, I say not one but many & sudry stewards even to th'end of the world.

column7: He is man, seinge he is God and man.
column8: He is man, sing he is God and man.

column7: He is ryche, not only in mercy, but in all kynde of rychesse.
column8: He is rich, not only in mercy, but in all kind of richesse.

column7: For it is he, that gyueth vs all thynges abundantly.
column8: For it is he, that gyveth us all things abundantly.

column7: It is he, of whose hande we receyued both our lyues, and other thinges necessarye for the conseruacion therof.
column8: It is he, of whose hand we received both our lives, and other things necessary for the conservation thereof.

column7: What man hath any thynge I praye you, but he hath receyued it of hys plentyfulnes?
column8: What man hath any thing I pray you, but he hath received it of his plentyfulnes?

column7: To be shorte, it is he, that not only gyueth vnto vs in most ample wyse hys benediccion, but also openeth hys hande, and fylleth al beastes wyth hys blessynge.
column8: To be short, it is he, that not only gyveth unto us in most ample wise his benediction, but also openeth his hand, and filleth all beasts with his blessing.

column7: Neyther can hys treasure be spente, howe muche so euer he lashe out, howe muche so euer we take of hym, hys treasure taryeth styll, euer taken, neuer spente.
column8: Neither can his treasure be spent, how much so ever he lash out, how much so ever we take of him, his treasure tarrieth still, ever taken, never spent.

column7: He is also the good man of the house.
column8: He is also the good man of the house.

column7: The church and congregacion is hys housholde whych ought wyth al diligence to be fedde not only with bodily meates but also with his worde and hys sacramentes.
column8: The church and congregation is his household which ought with all diligence to be fed not only with bodily meats but also with his word and his sacraments.

column7: These be hys goodes moost precious, the bestowynge and mynistracion herof, he wolde byshops and curates shulde haue.
column8: These be his goods most precious, the bestowing and mynistracion hereof, he would bishops and curates should have.

column7: Whych thynge saynt Paule affirmeth, sayeng: Let me esteme vs as the mynisters of Christ and stewardes of goddes mysteries. <NOTE> But I praye you what is to be loked for in a stewarde?
column8: Which thing saint Paule affirmeth, saying: Let me esteem us as the ministers of Christ and stewards of gods mysteries. But I pray you what is to be looked for in a steward?

column7: Thys surely, that he be founde faythfull, and that he truely laye out the P A G Ecxx goodes of ye lorde, that he gyue meate in tyme, gyue it I say, and not sel it: meate I say, and not poyson.
column8: This surely, that he be found faithful, and that he truly say out the PAGEcxx PAGEcxx PAGEcxx PAGEcxx goods of the lord, that he gyve meat in time, gyve it I say, and not sell it: meat I say, and not poison.

column7: Fynally let hym not slacke and differre the doynge of hys office, but let hym do his dutie when tyme is, and whe nede requyreth it.
column8: Finally let him not slack and differre the doing of his office, but let him do his duty when time is, and when need requireth it.

column7: Thys is also to be loked for, that he be one, whome God hath called and put in office, and not one that commeth vncalled, vnsent for, not one that of hymselfe presumeth to take honoure vpo hym, he must I say be a steward of office & not a steward at lybertie.
column8: This is also to be looked for, that he be one, whom God hath called and put in office, and not one that comes uncalled, unsent for, not one that of himself presumeth to take honour upon him, he must I say be a steward of office & not a steward at liberty.

column7: What is to be loked for?
column8: What is to be looked for?

column7: Surely, yf all thys yt I saye, be requyred in a good minister, it is much lyghter to wysh them all in euery one, than to fynde one any where that hath them al. Who is a true & faythfull steward?
column8: Surely, if all this that I say, be required in a good minister, it is much lighter to wish them all in every one, than to find one any where that hath them all Who is a true & faithful steward?

column7: He is true, <NOTE> he is faythfull, that coyneth no new money, but taketh it redy coyned of the good man of the house, and neither chaungeth it, nor clyppeth it, after it is taken to hym to spende, but spendeth euen the selfe same that he had of hys lorde, and spendeth it as hys lordes commaundement is, neyther to hys owne auautage vtterynge it, nor as the leude seruaunt dyd, <NOTE> hydyng it in the grounde.
column8: He is true, he is faithful, that coineth no new money, but takes it ready coined of the good man of the house, and neither changeth it, nor clyppeth it, after it is taken to him to spend, but spendeth even the self same that he had of his lord, and spendeth it as his lords commandment is, neither to his own auautage uttering it, nor as the leude servant did, hiding it in the ground.

column7: Now yf a faythful steward ought to do, as I haue sayd, I praye you ponder thys wel, whether in christendome there haue bene hytherto faythfull stewardes or no?
column8: Now if a faithful steward ought to do, as I have said, I pray you ponder this well, whither in christendome there have be hitherto faithful stewards or no?

column7: I praye you was there not some, that despisynge the money of the lorde, as copre & not curraunt, eyther coyned new themselues or els vttered abrode newlye coyned of other, some tyme eyther adulteratynge the worde of God, or els mynglyng it (as tauerners do, <NOTE> brewe and vtter the euell and good both in a potte) sometyme in the stede of goddes worde, blowynge out the dreames of men: whyle they preached to the people, the redemption that cometh by Christes death to serue only them that dyed before hys commyng that were in the tyme of the olde testament, and that nowe redempcion and forgyuenes of synnes purchased by money, and deuysed of men, is of efficacy, and not redeption purchased by Christ.
column8: I pray you was there not some, that despising the money of the lord, as copre & not currant, either coined new themselves or else uttered abroad newly coined of other, some time either adulteratynge the word of God, or else mingling it (as taverners doe, brew and utter the evil and good both in a pot) sometime in the stead of gods word, blowing out the dreams of men: while they preached to the people, the redemption that comes by Christes death to serve only them that died before his coming that were in the time of the old testament, and that now redemption and forgiveness of sins purchased by money, and devised of men, is of efficacy, and not redeption purchased by Christ.

column7: Be these the faythfull stewardes of goddes mysteries, and not rather fals dissipatours of them? whom god neuer put in office but rather the deuel sette them ouer a myserable familie, ouer an house miserably ordered & entreated.
column8: Be these the faithful stewards of gods mysteries, and not rather falls dissipatours of them? whom god never put in office but rather the devil set them over a miserable family, over and house miserably ordered & entreated.

column7: Happy were Christedome, yf such preached seldome.
column8: Happy were Christedome, if such preached seldom.

column7: And yet it is a wonder to se these, in theyr generacion, to be moch more prudent and politike, than the faythfull ministers are in theyr generacion, whyle they go aboute more prudently to stablyshe mennes dreames, than they do to holde vp gods comaundementes.
column8: And yet it is a wonder to see these, in their generation, to be much more prudent and politic, than the faithful ministers are in their generation, while they go about more prudently to stablish men's dreams, than they do to hold up gods commandments.

column7: Thus it cometh to passe that workes lucratyue, wylworkes, mennes fansyes reygne, & christiane workes, necessary workes, frutefull woorkes, be troden vnder foote.
column8: Thus it comes to pass that works lucratyue, wylworkes, men's fansyes reign, & christian works, necessary works, fruitful works, be trodden under foot.

column7: Thus the euell is moch better set out by euel menne, than is the good by good me: because the euell be more wyse, than be the good in theyr generacion.
column8: Thus the evil is much better set out by evil men, than is the good by good me: because the evil be more wise, than be the good in their generation.

column7: These be the false stewardes, who all good and faythfull men euery daye accuse vnto the rych mayster of ye household, not wythout great heuynesse, that they wast hys goodes, whom he also one daye woll call to hym and saye vnto them, as he dyd to hys steward whan he sayd, what is thys that I heare of the?
column8: These be the false stewards, who all good and faithful men every day accuse unto the rich master of you household, not without great heaviness, that they wast his goods, whom he also one day will call to him and say unto them, as he did to his steward when he said, what is this that I hear of thee?

column7: Here God partly wondereth at oure vnkyndnes and perfidie, partly chideth vs for them and beynge both full of wonder, and ready to chyde P A G Ecxxi axeth vs: What is thys that I heare of you? As thoughe he shulde saye vnto vs, all good men in all places complayne of you, accuse your auaryce, your exactions, your tyrannye.
column8: Here God partly wondereth at our unkindness and perfidy, partly chideth us for them and being both full of wonder, and ready to chide PAGEcxxi PAGEcxxi PAGEcxxi PAGEcxxi axeth us: What is this that I hear of you? As though he should say unto us, all good men in all places complain of you, accuse your avarice, your exactions, your tyranny.

column7: They haue desyred in you a long season, and yet desyre diligece and synceritie.
column8: They have desired in you a long season, and yet desire diligence and sincerity.

column7: I commaunded you, that wyth all industrie and laboure ye shulde feade my lytle ons both bodyly with your temporall goodes and rentes whyche ye haue for that purpose delyuered vnto you, and also gostlye wyth my worde.
column8: I commanded you, that with all industry and labour you should feade my little ons both bodily with your temporal goods and rents which you have for that purpose delivered unto you, and also ghostly with my word.

column7: But what do you? ye ernestlye fede your selfes, from daye to daye, wallowynge in delytes and ydlenes.
column8: But what do you? you earnestly fede your selves, from day to day, wallowing in delights and idleness.

column7: I bad you teach my commaudementes and not your fansyes, and that ye shulde seke my glory & my vauntage: you teach your owne tradicyons, and seke your owne glorye and profyte.
column8: I bade you teach my commaudementes and not your fansyes, and that you should seek my glory & my vantage: you teach your own traditions, and seek your own glory and profit.

column7: You preach very seldome, and wha ye preache, ye do nothyng but snappe them that preach truly, asmoch as lieth in you, so that it were moch better suche not to preach at all, than so to preach.
column8: You preach very seldom, and wha you preach, you do nothing but snap them that preach truly, as as lies in you, so that it were much better such not to preach at all, than so to preach.

column7: Oh, what heare I of you?
column8: O, what hear I of you?

column7: You that ought to be my stewardes, what other thynge do you, than applye all your studye to brynge my lytle ons to enuye, shame, contempte, yea more then thys, ye pulle them into peryls, into prysons, and as moch as in you lyeth, to cruel deathes.
column8: You that ought to be my stewards, what other thing do you, than apply all your study to bring my little ons to envy, shame, contempt, yea more then this, you pull them into perils, into prisons, and as much as in you lies, to cruel deaths.

column7: To be shorte, I wolde that my people shulde heare my doctrine, and at theyr comodytie reade it also as many as wold: your care is not, that all men maye heare it, but all your care is, that none shulde reade it, because ye be afrayed leste they by the readynge shulde vnderstand it: and vnderstandyng, learne to rebuke your nygardnes, infidelytie, & slouthfulnes.
column8: To be short, I would that my people should hear my doctrine, and at their comodytie read it also as many as would: your care is not, that all men may hear it, but all your care is, that none should read it, because you be afraid lest they by the reading should understand it: and understanding, learn to rebuke your nygardnes, infidelytie, & slothfulness.

column7: Thys is your generacion, thys is your bestowynge of my treasur: thys is your wysdome.
column8: This is your generation, this is your bestowing of my treasure: this is your wisdom.

column7: In this generacion, in thys dispensacion, you be moste politike, moste wyttye.
column8: In this generation, in this dispensation, you be most politic, most witty.

column7: These be the thynges that I heare of your demeanour.
column8: These be the things that I hear of your demeanour.

column7: I wyshed to heare better reaporte of you.
column8: I wished to hear better reaporte of you.

column7: Haue ye thus deceyued me? or haue ye rather deceyued yourselues?
column8: Have you thus deceived me? or have the rather deceived yourselves?

column7: Where I had but one house, that is to saye, ye churche, and thys so dearly beloued of me that for ye loue of her I dyd put myselfe forth to be slayne & to shede my bloude: thys church at my departure, I comitted vnto youre charge to be fed, to be noryshed, and to be made moch of.
column8: Where I had but one house, that is to say, you church, and this so dearly beloved of me that for you love of her I did put myself forth to be slain & to shed my blood: this church at my departure, I committed unto your charge to be fed, to be nourished, and to be made much of.

column7: My plesure was, ye shulde occupye my place: my desyre was, ye shulde haue borne lyke loue to thys church, lyke fatherly affection, as I dyd.
column8: My pleasure was, you should occupy my place: my desire was, you should have born like love to this church, like fatherly affection, as I did.

column7: I made you my stewardes, yea in matters of moste importaunce.
column8: I made you my stewards, yea in matters of most importance.

column7: For thus I taught openly: <NOTE> He that shulde heare you, shulde heare me: He that shulde despice you, shulde despice me. <NOTE> I gaue you also keyes, not erthly keyes, but heuenlye.
column8: For thus I taught openly: He that should hear you, should hear me: He that should despice you, should despice me. I gave you also keys, not earthly keys, but heavenly.

column7: I left my goodes yt I haue euermore moost highly estemed, that is, my worde and sacramentes, to be dispensed & ministred of you.
column8: I left my goods that I have evermore most highly esteemed, that is, my word and sacraments, to be dispensed & ministered of you.

column7: These benefites I gaue you: and do ye gyue me these thankes?
column8: These benefits I gave you: and do you gyve me these thanks?

column7: Can ye fynde in your hartes thus to abuse my goodnes?
column8: Can you find in your hearts thus to abuse my goodness?

column7: Haue ye thus deceyued me?
column8: Have you thus deceived me?

column7: No no, ye haue not deceyued me, but your selues.
column8: No no, you have not deceived me, but your selves.

column7: My gyftes & benefytes towarde you, shalbe to your greater danation.
column8: My gifts & benefits toward you, shall to your greater danation.

column7: Bycause ye haue contepned the lenitie & clemecy of the mayster of the house, ye haue ryght wel deserued to abyde the rygoure and seueritie of the iudge.
column8: Because you have contepned the lenity & clemency of the master of the house, you have right well deserved to abide the rygoure and severity of the judge.

column7: Come forth than, let vs se accompte of your stewardship.
column8: Come forth than, let us see accompt of your stewardship.

column7: An horrible and fearfull sentence: ye maye haue no longer my goodes in your handes.
column8: And horrible and fearful sentence: you may have no longer my goods in your hands.

column7: A voyce to wepe P A G Ecxxij at, and to make me tremble.
column8: A voice to weep PAGEcxxij PAGEcxxij PAGEcxxij PAGEcxxij at, and to make me tremble.

column7: You se my frendes, you se, to what euel, ye euel stewardes must come to, your laboure is payde for, yf ye can so take hede, that no such sentence be spoke to you.
column8: You see my friends, you see, to what evil, the evil stewards must come to, your labour is paid for, if you can so take heed, that no such sentence be spoke to you.

column7: Naye we must al take hede, lest these threatenynges one daye take place in vs al, aswell vs of the clergye for myspendynge the spirituall treasure, as you of the laytie for myspendynge the temporal treasure, wherof god hath made vs stewardes.
column8: Nay we must all take heed, lest these threatenings one day take place in us all, aswell us of the clergy for myspendynge the spiritual treasure, as you of the laity for myspendynge the temporal treasure, whereof god hath made us stewards.

column7: Wherfore good people at the lest way let vs take exemple & folow the policie of ye worldly stewarde yt our sauiour Christe here telleth hys tale of, to thintent we shulde do the same.
column8: Wherefore good people at the lest way let us take exemple & follow the policy of the worldly steward that our saviour Christe here telleth his tale of, to intent we should do the same.

column7: This worldly stewarde whan he sawe he was accused to hys lorde that he had wasted hys goodes, thought thus wyth hymselfe.
column8: This worldly steward when he saw he was accused to his lord that he had wasted his goods, thought thus with himself.

column7: What shal I do? my lorde wol surely take from me my stewardshyp.
column8: What shall I do? my lord will surely take from me my stewardshyp.

column7: Dygge I can not, and to begge, I am ashamed.
column8: Dig I can not, and to beg, I am ashamed.

column7: Wel, I wol at lest way make me frendes of my lordes goodes, whych whan I am remoued out of myne office, shall take me into theyr houses for the kyndnes and benefyte that they shall haue receyued at my handes.
column8: Well, I will at lest way make me friends of my lords goods, which when I am removed out of mine office, shall take me into their houses for the kindness and benefit that they shall have received at my hands.

column7: So whan he had assebled together all hys lordes detters, he sayde to the fyrst.
column8: So when he had assebled together all his lords debtors, he said to the fyrst.

column7: What owest thou to my lorde?
column8: What owest thou to my lord?

column7: He answered, an hundred tonnes of oyle.
column8: He answered, and hundred tons of oil.

column7: Than the stewarde to hym sayd: Take thy wrytynge and syt downe quyckely, & wryte for an hundred, but fyftye. My lorde is very ryche, I woll that by my meanes thou shalte wynne the one halfe.
column8: Than the steward to him said: Take thy writing and fit down quyckely, & write for and hundred, but fyftye. My lord is very rich, I will that by my means thou shalt win the one half.

column7: Thys done, he sayd to an other.
column8: This done, he said to and other.

column7: Howe much owest thou?
column8: Howe much owest thou?

column7: He answered, an hundred quarters of wheat.
column8: He answered, and hundred quarters of wheat.

column7: The steward also bad hym: syt downe and wryt in hys byll but foure score.
column8: The steward also bade him: fit down and writ in his bill but foure score.

column7: For (sayeth he) my lorde shal not espye twentye taken awaye, but to the, whych arte a poore man, it maye do pleasure.
column8: For (sayeth he) my lord shall not espy twentye taken away, but to the, which art a poor man, it may do pleasure.

column7: In semblable wyse he dyd wyth the reste of hys lordes detters.
column8: In semblable wise he did with the rest of his lords debtors.

column7: Now thys disceyt and polycie yf thys temporal rych man had espyed, he wolde surely haue punyshed hys stewarde.
column8: Now this disceyt and policy if this temporal rich man had espied, he would surely have punished his steward.

column7: But yet the Lorde Iesus for an exemple of lyberalitie, commended and praysed vnto hys disciples the disceytfull but yet wyse policie of thys stewarde, and to the imitacion and folowynge of hym he prouoketh all vs christen men and rebuketh our slouthfulnes, in asmuche as worldlye wyse men and suche as serue thys worlde are wyser and more busye in prouidynge for themselues the sustenaunce of the bodye, then we be whych oughte to forsake the vanities of thys worlde and folowe the thynges yt be eternall.
column8: But yet the Lord Jesus for and exemple of lyberalitie, commended and praised unto his disciples the disceytfull but yet wise policy of this steward, and to the imitation and following of him he provoketh all us christen men and rebuketh our slothfulness, in asmuch as worldly wise men and such as serve this world are wiser and more busy in providing for themselves the sustenance of the body, then we be which ought to forsake the vanities of this world and follow the things that be eternal.

column7: The chyldren of thys worlde (sayeth he) are wyser than the chyldren of lyght in their natio. My fredes ye shal vnderstad yt our sauiour Christe in thys saynge, touched ye slouth & fluggishnes of hys: he dyd not alowe the fraude and sudtyltie of other, neyther was he glad yt it was in dede as he had sayed, but coplayned rather that it shulde be so: as many men speake many thynges, not that they ought to be so, but that they are wont to be so.
column8: The children of this world (sayeth he) are wiser than the children of light in their natio. My fredes you shall vnderstad that our saviour Christe in this saying, touched you sloth & fluggishnes of his: he did not allow the fraud and sudtyltie of other, neither was he glad that it was in deed as he had said, but coplayned rather that it should be so: as many men speak many things, not that they ought to be so, but that they are wont to be so.

column7: Naye, thys greued Christ, yt ye chyldre of this world shulde be of more polycie than the chyldren of light, whych thyng yet was true in Christes tyme, & nowe in our tyme is moste true.
column8: Nay, this grieved Christ, that the children of this world should be of more policy than the children of light, which thing yet was true in Christes time, & now in our time is most true.

column7: Who is so blynde but he seeth thys clearly, excepte perchaunce there be any yt cannot discerne the chyldren of the worlde frome the chyldren of lighte?
column8: Who is so blind but he sees this clearly, except perchance there be any that cannot discern the children of the world from the children of light?

column7: The chyldren of the worlde conceyue & forth brynge more prudently, & thynges conceyued and brought forth, they nourysh and coscrue P A G Ecxxiij wyth moch more polycie, than do ye children of light.
column8: The children of the world conceive & forth bring more prudently, & things conceived and brought forth, they nourish and coscrue PAGEcxxiij PAGEcxxiij PAGEcxxiij PAGEcxxiij with much more policy, than do you children of light.

column7: Whych thynge is as sorowfull to be sayed, as it semeth straunge to be hearde.
column8: Which thing is as sorrowful to be said, as it seemeth strange to be heard.

column7: Whan ye heare ye chyldren of the worlde, you muste vnderstand the world, as a father. <NOTE> For ye worlde is father of many children not by fyrste creacion and worke, but by imitacion & loue.
column8: When you hear you children of the world, you must understand the world, as a father. For the world is father of many children not by fyrste creation and work, but by imitation & love.

column7: He is not only a father, but also the sone of another father.
column8: He is not only a father, but also the soon of another father.

column7: If ye knowe ones hys father, by & by ye shal knowe his children.
column8: If you know ones his father, by & by you shall know his children.

column7: For he yt hath ye deuyl to hys father, muste nedes haue dyuelyshe chyldren. <NOTE> Nowe ye deuyll is not only taken for father, but also for prince of ye worlde, that is, of worldy folke.
column8: For he that hath the devil to his father, must needs have dyuelyshe children. Now you devil is not only taken for father, but also for prince of the world, that is, of worldy folk.

column7: It is all one thynge or not moch differete to saye children of the worlde, and chyldren of the deuell, <NOTE> accordynge to that, that Christ sayd to the Iues.
column8: It is all one thing or not much differete to say children of the world, and children of the devil, according to that, that Christ said to the Iues.

column7: Ye are of your father the deuel: where vndoubtedly he spake to children of thys worlde.
column8: You are of your father the devil: where undoubtedly he spoke to children of this world.

column7: Now seynge the deuell is both author & ruler of darknes in whych ye childre of this worlde walke, or rather wander, they hate deadly both the lyght, and also the chyldren of lyght. <NOTE> herof it commeth, that the chyldren of lyght neuer or verye seldome do lacke persecution in thys worlde, whervnto the chyldren of the worlde, that is, of the deuell, bringeth them.
column8: Now sing the devil is both author & ruler of darkness in which you children of this world walk, or rather wander, they hate deadly both the light, and also the children of light. hereof it comes, that the children of light never or very seldom do lack persecution in this world, whereunto the children of the world, that is, of the devil, brings them.

column7: No ma there is but seeth, that these vse much more policie in procurynge the hurte and damage of the good, than those in defendynge themselues.
column8: No ma there is but sees, that these use much more policy in procuring the hurt and damage of the good, than those in defending themselves.

column7: Therfore gather you the disposition of the chyldren, by the disposition of the fathers.
column8: Therefore gather you the disposition of the children, by the disposition of the father's.

column7: You knowe thys is a prouerbe much vsed, An euel crow, <NOTE> an euell egge.
column8: You know this is a proverb much used, And evil crow, and evil egg.

column7: Than the chyldre of thys worlde that are knowen to haue so euel a father the worlde, so euell a grandfather the deuell, can not chose but be euel.
column8: Than the children of this world that are known to have so evil a father the world, so evil a grandfather the devil, can not chosen but be evil.

column7: Surely the fyrste heade of theyr auncester was that deceytful serpent the deuel a monster mostrous aboue all monsters. <NOTE> I can not holly expresse hym, I wote not what to call hym, but a certayne thynge al together made of the hatred of God, of mystrust in God, of lyenges, deceytes, periuries, discordes, manslaughters, and to saye at one worde, a thynge congeled, heaped vp, and made of all kynde of myschefe But what go I aboute to discriue particularly the deuels nature, whan no reason, no power of mans mynde, can compryse it?
column8: Surely the fyrste head of their ancestor was that deceitful serpent the devil a monster monstrous above all monsters. I can not holly express him, I wot not what to call him, but a certain thing all together made of the hatred of God, of mistrust in God, of lyenges, deceits, perjuries, discords, manslaughters, and to say at one word, a thing congealed, heaped up, and made of all kind of mischief But what go I about to discriue particularly the devils nature, when no reason, no power of men mind, can comprise it?

column7: This only I can say as in a grosse summe, of the whych all we (oure hurte is the more) haue experience, yt the deuel is a stynkyng puddel of al vyces, a foule fylthye chanell of al myscheues: & that thys worlde, hys issue, euen a chylde mete to haue such a paret, is not much vnlyke his father.
column8: This only I can say as in a gross sum, of the which all we (our hurt is the more) have experience, that the devil is a stinking puddel of all vices, a foul filthy channel of all myscheues: & that this world, his issue, even a child meet to have such a paret, is not much unlike his father.

column7: Than thys deuell beynge such one, <NOTE> as can neuer be vnlyke hymselfe, Lo of enuye hys welbeloued lemman begat the worlde, and after left it wyth discorde at nours.
column8: Than this devil being such one, as can never be unlike himself, Lo of envy his well-beloved leman begat the world, and after left it with discord at nours.

column7: Whych world, after it rain to ye ful growe, had of many concubynes, many sonnes.
column8: Which world, after it rain to you full grow, had of many concubines, many sons.

column7: He was so plentyfull a father, and had gotten so many chyldre of lady pryde, dame glotony, maystres auarice, lady lechery, and of dame subtyltie: that nowe harde and scante, ye maye fynde any corner, any kynde of lyfe, where many of hys chyldren be not.
column8: He was so plentiful a father, and had got so many children of lady pride, dame gluttony, masters avarice, lady lechery, and of dame subtyltie: that now harden and scant, you may find any corner, any kind of life, where many of his children be not.

column7: In court, in coutrey, in cytie, i village, i college, in teporaltie, i clergie yea where shal ye not fynd the?
column8: In court, in country, in city, i village, i college, in teporaltie, i clergy yea where shall you not find thee?

column7: Howe be it they that be secular and laye men are not by and by chyldren of the worlde: neyther yet be they forthwyth the chyldren of lyght, that are called spirituall and of ye clergie.
column8: Howe be it they that be secular and say men are not by and by children of the world: neither yet be they forthwith the children of light, that are called spiritual and of the clergy.

column7: No no, as ye maye fynde amonge the laytie many P A G Ecxxiiij chyldren of lyghte: so amonge the clergie (howe much so euer we chalenge these holy tytles vnto vs, and thynke them only due to vs: <NOTE> Vos estis lux mundi, peculium Christi.
column8: No no, as you may find among the laity many PAGEcxxiiij PAGEcxxiiij PAGEcxxiiij PAGEcxxiiij children of light: so among the clergy (how much so ever we challenge these holy titles unto us, and think them only endue to us: Vos estis lux mundi, peculium Christi.

column7: &c. Ye are ye lyght of ye worlde the chosen people of Christ, a kyngely presthode, <NOTE> an holy nation, and such other) Ye shall I saye amoge vs of the clergie yet fynde many chyldre of ye world, bycause in all places the worlde getteth many chyldren.
column8: etc. You are the light of you world the chosen people of Christ, a kingly priesthood, and holy nation, and such other) You shall I say amoge us of the clergy yet find many children of the world, because in all places the world gets many children.

column7: Amonge the laye people the world ceasseth not to brynge to passe that as they be called worldly, so they are worldly in dede dryue headlonge by worldly desyres, in so muche that they maye ryghte well seme to haue taken as well the maners as the name of theyr father.
column8: Among the say people the world ceaseth not to bring to pass that as they be called worldly, so they are worldly in deed drive headlong by worldly desires, in so much that they may right well seem to have taken as well the manners as the name of their father.

column7: In the clergye the worlde also hath lerned a ways, to make of men spirituall, worldlynges, yea and there also to forme worldlye chyldren where wyth great pretense of holynes and crafty coloure of religion they vtterly desyre to hyde & cloke the name of ye worlde, as though they were ashamed of theyr father, whych do execrate and detest ye world (beynge neuerthelesse theyr father) in wordes & outwarde signes, but in harte and worke, they colle and kysse hym, and in all theyr lyues declare themselues to be hys babes: in so much that in all worldly poyntes, they farre passe and surmounte those, that they call seculars, laye men, men of the world.
column8: In the clergy the world also hath learned a ways, to make of men spiritual, worldlings, yea and there also to form worldly children where with great pretense of holiness and crafty colour of religion they utterly desire to hide & cloak the name of you world, as though they were ashamed of their father, which do execrate and detest you world (being nevertheless their father) in words & outward signs, but in heart and work, they colle and kiss him, and in all their lives declare themselves to be his babes: in so much that in all worldly points, they far pass and surmount those, that they call seculars, say men, men of the world.

column7: The chyld so diligently foloweth the steppes of hys father, neuer destitute of the ayde of hys grandfather.
column8: The child so diligently followeth the steps of his father, never destitute of the aid of his grandfather.

column7: The chyldren of lyght haue policie, <NOTE> but it is lyke the policie of the serpent, and is ioyned wyth douuyshe simplicitie.
column8: The children of light have policy, but it is like the policy of the serpent, and is joined with douuyshe simplicity.

column7: They iugender nothynge but symply faythfully, and playnly, euen so doynge all that they do.
column8: They iugender nothing but simply faithfully, and plainly, even so doing all that they do.

column7: And therfore they maye the easylyer be combred in theyr ingendrynge, and be ye more redy, to take wroges.
column8: And therefore they may the easylyer be cumbered in their ingendrynge, and be you more ready, to take wroges.

column7: But the chyldren of thys worlde, haue worldly policie, foxely crafte, lyonnesh crueltie, power to do hurte, more than eyther aspis or basiliscus, ingendrynge and doynge all thynges craftly, deceytfully, gylefully.
column8: But the children of this world, have worldly policy, foxely craft, lyonnesh cruelty, power to do hurt, more than either aspis or basiliscus, ingendrynge and doing all things craftily, deceitfully, gylefully.

column7: Whych as Nembrothes and such sturdye and stoute hunters, beynge full of simulation & dissimulation, before the lorde, deceyue the chyldren of lyght, and combre them easely.
column8: Which as Nembrothes and such sturdy and stout hunter's, being full of simulation & dissimulation, before the lord, deceive the children of light, and combre them easily.

column7: Hunters go not forth in euery mans syght, but do theyr matters closely, & wyth vse of gyle and deceyte waxe euery daye more craftier than other.
column8: Hunter's go not forth in every men sight, but do their matters closely, & with use of gyle and deceit wax every day more craftier than other.

column7: The chyldren of thys worlde be lyke crafty hunters, they be mysnamed chyldren of lyght, for asmuch as they so hate lyght, & so study to do the workes of darknes.
column8: The children of this world be like crafty hunter's, they be mysnamed children of light, for as as they so hate light, & so study to do the works of darkness.

column7: Yf they were ye chyldre of lyght, they wolde not loue darkenes.
column8: If they were the children of light, they would not love darkness.

column7: It is no maruail, yt they go about to kepe other in darknes seyng they be in darkenes, fro top to toe ouerwhelmed wt darknes, darker tha is ye darknes of hel.
column8: It is no marvel, that they go about to keep other in darkness sing they be in darkness, from top to toe overwhelmed with darkness, darker than is the darkness of hell.

column7: Wherfore it is well done in all orders of men, to put a difference betwene chyldren of lyght, and chyldren of ye world, bycause great deceyte aryseth in takynge the one for the other.
column8: Wherefore it is well done in all order of men, to put a difference between children of light, and children of the world, because great deceit ariseth in taking the one for the other.

column7: For is it a lytle deceyte, when they that the common people take for the lyght, go about to take the sonne and the lyght out of the worlde?
column8: For is it a little deceit, when they that the common people take for the light, go about to take the son and the light out of the world?

column7: But these be easely knowen, both by the diuersitie of myndes, and also theyr armours.
column8: But these be easily known, both by the diversity of minds, and also their armours.

column7: For where as the chyldren of lyght are thus minded, that they seke theyr aduersaries helth, welth, and profite wt losse of theyr owne commodities, and oftymes wyth ieopardye of theyr lyfe: The chyldren of the worlde contrary wyse haue P A G Ecxxv suche stomakes that they woll soner se them deed, yt doth them good, then susteyne any losse of temporal thynges.
column8: For where as the children of light are thus minded, that they seek their adversaries health, wealth, and profit with loss of their own commodities, and oftimes with jeopardy of their life: The children of the world contrary wise have PAGEcxxv PAGEcxxv PAGEcxxv PAGEcxxv such stomachs that they will sooner see them deed, that does them good, then sustain any loss of temporal things.

column7: The armure of the chyldren of lyghte, <NOTE> are fyrst the worde of God, whych they euer sette forth, & wyth all diligence put it abrode, that as much as in them lyeth, it maye brynge forth fruite: after this, pacience and prayer, wyth the whych in all aduersities the Lorde comforteth them.
column8: The armure of the children of light, are fyrst the word of God, which they ever set forth, & with all diligence put it abroad, that as much as in them lies, it may bring forth fruit: after this, patience and prayer, with the which in all adversities the Lord comforts them.

column7: Other thynges they comitte to God, vnto whom they leue al reuengemete. <NOTE> The armure of the chyldren of the worlde, are somtyme fraudes and deceytes, somtyme lyes & money: By the fyrst, they make theyr dreames, theyr traditions: by the seconde, they stablyshe and confyrme the same, be they neuer so fonde, neuer so agaynst scripture, honestye, reason.
column8: Other things they comitte to God, unto whom they leave all reuengemete. The armure of the children of the world, are sometime frauds and deceits, sometime lies & money: By the fyrst, they make their dreams, their traditions: by the seconde, they stablish and confirm the same, be they never so fond, never so against scripture, honesty, reason.

column7: And yf any man resiste them, euen wyth these weapons they procure to slee hym.
column8: And if any man resist them, even with these weapons they procure to slee him.

column7: Thus they bought Christes death, the verye lighte it selfe: and obscured him after hys deth.
column8: Thus they bought Christes death, the very light it self: and obscured him after his death.

column7: Thus they bye euery day the chyldren of lyght, & obscure them, and shall so do, vntyll the worlde be at an ende.
column8: Thus they buy every day the children of light, & obscure them, and shall so do, until the world be at and end.

column7: So that it maye be euer true, that Christ sayd.
column8: So that it may be ever true, that Christ said.

column7: The children of the worlde be wyser in their nacion then be ye children of light.
column8: The children of the world be wiser in their nation then be you children of light.

column7: These wordlynges pull downe the lyuely fayth whych worketh by charitie and loue, & sette vp an other fayth, an other confidence of theyr owne makyng as in pardos and such trompery: the chyldren of lyght contrary.
column8: These wordlynges pull down the lively faith which works by charity and love, & set up and other faith, and other confidence of their own making as in pardos and such trompery: the children of light contrary.

column7: These wordlynges sette lytel by such workes as God hath prepared for oure saluation, but they auaunce traditions and workes of theyr owne inuention: the chyldren of lyghte contrary.
column8: These wordlynges set little by such works as God hath prepared for our salvation, but they advance traditions and works of their own invention: the children of light contrary.

column7: The wordlinges, yf they espye profite, gaines, lucre in any thynge, be it neuer such a tryfle, be it neuer so danable, they preach it to the people: and defende it wyth toth and nayle.
column8: The worldlings, if they espy profit, gains, lucre in any thing, be it never such a trifle, be it never so danable, they preach it to the people: and defend it with tooth and nail.

column7: They can scarse disalowe any abuses of thynges, albeit they be intollerable, lest in disalowynge the abuse, they lose parte of theyr profyte.
column8: They can scarce disallow any abuses of things, albeit they be intolerable, lest in disalowynge the abuse, they loose part of their profit.

column7: The chyldren of the lyght, cotrary put all thynges in theyr degre, best hyghest, next, next, ye worst lowest.
column8: The children of the light, contrary put all things in their degree, best highest, next, next, you worst lowest.

column7: They extoll thynges necessary, christian, and comaunded of God.
column8: They extol things necessary, christian, and commanded of God.

column7: They pull downe wyll workes fayned by men, and put them in theyr place.
column8: They pull down will works feigned by men, and put them in their place.

column7: The abuses of all thynge they ernestly rebuke.
column8: The abuses of all thing they earnestly rebuke.

column7: But yet these thynges be so done on both parties, and so they both do gendre, yt chyldren of the worlde shewe themselues wyser than the chyldren of lyght.
column8: But yet these things be so done on both parties, and so they both do gender, that children of the world show themselves wiser than the children of light.

column7: Neyther the chyldren of the worlde be onely wyser, than the chyldren of lyghte, but are also some of them, amonge themself, much wyser then the other in theyr generation.
column8: Neither the children of the world be only wiser, than the children of light, but are also some of them, among themselves, much wiser then the other in their generation.

column7: For albeit, as touchyng the ende, the generation of them all, is one: yet in thys same generation, some of them haue more craftely ingedred, tha the other of their felowes.
column8: For albeit, as touching the end, the generation of them all, is one: yet in this same generation, some of them have more craftily ingedred, than the other of their fellows.

column7: For what a thinge was yt, that ones euery.
column8: For what a thing was that, that ones every.

column7: C. yere, was brought forth in Rome of ye chyldre of this worlde, & wt how much policie it was made it is a woder to heare.
column8: C. year, was brought forth in Room of you children of this world, & with how much policy it was made it is a woder to hear.

column7: How som brought forth Canonizations, some Expectations, some pluralities and vnions, some totquottes, and dispensations, some pardons, and these of wonderfull varietie, some stationaries, some Iubilaries, some pocularies for drynkers, some manuaries for handlers of relyques, some pedaries for pylgrimes, some oscularies for kyssers: some of them engedred one, some other such fetures, and euery one in that he deuysed, was excellent, politike, wyse, yea so wyse, that wyth P A G Ecxxvi theyr wysedome they had almoost made al ye worlde fooles.
column8: How some brought forth Canonizations, some Expectations, some pluralities and unions, some totquottes, and dispensations, some pardons, and these of wonderful variety, some stationaries, some Iubilaries, some pocularies for drinkers, some manuaries for handlers of relics, some pedaries for pylgrimes, some oscularies for kyssers: some of them engedred one, some other such features, and every one in that he devised, was excellent, politic, wise, yea so wise, that with PAGEcxxvi PAGEcxxvi PAGEcxxvi PAGEcxxvi their wisdom they had almost made all the world fools.

column7: But yet they that begotte and brought forth yt theyr old auciet purgatorie picke pourse, I meane that which was swaged & cooled wt a graye freers coule put vpon a deade mans backe, to the fourth parte of hys synnes, that that was vtterly to be spoiled, and of none other, but of the moost prudet lorde the byshop of Rome, and of hym as ofte as hym lysted: they, I saye, that were the wyse fathers and brochers of thys purgatorie, were doubtles, the wyseste of all theyr generation: and so farre passe both the chyldren of lyght, and also the rest of theyr company that they both are but fooles, yf ye compare them wt these.
column8: But yet they that begotten and brought forth that their old auciet purgatory pick pourse, I mean that which was suaged & cooled with a gray freers coule put upon a dead men back, to the fourth part of his sins, that that was utterly to be spoiled, and of none other, but of the most prudet lord the bishop of Room, and of him as oft as him listed: they, I say, that were the wise father's and broachers of this purgatory, were doubtless, the wisest of all their generation: and so far pass both the children of light, and also the rest of their company that they both are but fools, if you compare them with these.

column7: It was a pleasaunt fiction, and from the begynnynge so profytable to the feyners of it, that almost, I dare boldly say, there hath ben no emperour that hath gotte more by taxes and tallages of them that were alyue, than these the very and ryghte begotten sonnes of the worlde gotte by deade mennes tributes and gyftes.
column8: It was a pleasant fiction, and from the beginning so profitable to the feyners of it, that almost, I dare boldly say, there hath been no emperor that hath got more by taxes and tallages of them that were alive, than these the very and right begotten sons of the world got by dead men's tributes and gifts.

column7: But what go I aboute particularly to recoute vnto you the wonderfull craftes and policies of the chyldren of thys worlde?
column8: But what go I about particularly to recoute unto you the wonderful crafts and policies of the children of this world?

column7: Certes no tonge, no oration is able to expresse them, they be so many and so sundry.
column8: Certes no tongue, no oration is able to express them, they be so many and so sundry.

column7: Wherfore my welbeloued fredes, were it not a right foule shame for vs English men, for vs, I saye, that pretende vtterly to detest and renounce the fraudes and policies of the byshope of Rome and of all hys limmes, and to ensue the true religion of Christ and whych counte oure selues the children of the lyghte, were it not I say a shame yt these worldlinges shuld haue such a forsyght, prudence, and wisdom in theyr kinde for thynges transitorie, whych be of small valure and mere vanities, and that we shuld be stacke and negligent by doinge of oure officies and duties towardes our neighbours to gette vs the rewardes of euerlastinge life, namely sithe euery one of vs bycause of the incertain terme of thys life oughte euer to be in a redynes and to awayte when the Lorde of heuen wol say vnto vs as was here said to the Stuard.
column8: Wherefore my well-beloved fredes, were it not a right foul shame for us English men, for us, I say, that pretend utterly to detest and renounce the frauds and policies of the bishop of Room and of all his limbs, and to ensue the true religion of Christ and which count our selves the children of the light, were it not I say a shame that these worldlings should have such a forsyght, prudence, and wisdom in their kind for things transitory, which be of small valour and mere vanities, and that we should be stack and negligent by doing of our offices and duties towards our neighbours to get us the rewards of everlasting life, namely sith every one of us because of the incertain term of this life ought ever to be in a readiness and to await when the Lord of heaven will say unto us as was here said to the Steward.

column7: Gyue accomptes of thy stuardshippe, for thou maiste be no lengar stuard.
column8: Gyve accounts of thy stuardshippe, for thou maiste be no lengar steward.

column7: Thys tyme, bicause it is both vncertaine to euery man & also shorte, we must therfore hasten vs to bestowe our erthly substaunce vpon the pore wherby to gette vs a pasporte to eternall life.
column8: This time, because it is both uncertain to every man & also short, we must therefore hasten us to bestow our earthly substance upon the poor whereby to get us a pasporte to eternal life.

column7: For so shall it come to passe, that the good dedes & benefites whyche other folke haue done, we shalbe made partakers of, whyl we helpe them with our goodes.
column8: For so shall it come to pass, that the good deeds & benefits which other folk have done, we shall made partakers of, whyl we help them with our goods.

column7: For assuredly he that wyth hys wordlye substaunce helpeth the prophete I meane hym that setteth forth Christes worde, the same shall receyue the rewarde of the prophete, & shalbe reliued in semblable wyse in the kyngdome of heuen wyth ye good deades of the prophete or preacher.
column8: For assuredly he that with his wordly substance helpeth the prophet I mean him that sets forth Christes word, the same shall receive the reward of the prophet, & shall relived in semblable wise in the kingdom of heaven with you good deads of the prophet or preacher.

column7: And therfore the Lorde sayeth here in thys place: <NOTE> Make you frendes of the Mammon of iniquitie. As who shulde saye: Se yt ye prouyde for yourselues in tyme, accordinge to thexemple of thys prudent and politike steward.
column8: And therefore the Lord sayeth here in this place: Make you friends of the Mammon of iniquity. As who should say: See that you provide for yourselves in time, according to thexemple of this prudent and politic steward.

column7: Get you good frendes of an euel thynge, that whan at the lordes commaundement ye shalbe compelled to departe from thys tente and pauilion of your bodye, they maye receyue you into euerlastynge habitacions.
column8: Get you good friends of and evil thing, that when at the lords commandment you shall compelled to depart from this tent and pavilion of your body, they may receive you into everlasting habitations.

column7: It is an happye chaunge, whan earthly thynges be permuted for heauenly.
column8: It is and happy change, when earthly things be permuted for heavenly.

column7: What thynge is vyler, P A G Ecxxvij or goeth further from vertue, tha the goodes of thys worlde?
column8: What thing is vyler, PAGEcxxvij PAGEcxxvij PAGEcxxvij PAGEcxxvij or goes further from virtue, than the goods of this world?

column7: They are skant at any tyme gotten wythout fraude, wythout deceyt, and crafte, neyther is there any other waye of kepynge & augmentynge them, than of gettynge them.
column8: They are skant at any time got without fraud, without deceit, and craft, neither is there any other way of keeping & augmenting them, than of getting them.

column7: It is (no doubt) an onerouse, and a chargeable possession, and in ye meane season neyther sure nor longe lastynge.
column8: It is (no doubt) and onerouse, and a chargeable possession, and in the mean season neither sure nor long lasting.

column7: For truely they folowe not theyr mayster, whan he departeth hense.
column8: For truly they follow not their master, when he departeth hence.

column7: But wyth these yet maye he bye the thynge, that is euerlastynge, and that maye do hym good in the lyfe to come.
column8: But with these yet may he buy the thing, that is everlasting, and that may do him good in the life to come.

column7: So shall it come to passe, that that thynge, whych yf it be layde vp, maketh a man wycked and subiecte to many cares, the same yf it be wel bestowed, is become an instrument of the euangelicall ryghtuousnes, whyle both he is relyued of hys necessities whych serueth the gospel, and a rewarde retourneth wyth much gaynes to the gyuer.
column8: So shall it come to pass, that that thing, which if it be laid up, makes a man wicked and subject to many cares, the same if it be well bestowed, is become and instrument of the evangelical righteousness, while both he is relyued of his necessities which serveth the gospel, and a reward returneth with much gains to the gyuer.
