column7: Wherfore my frendes to conclude, yf we wyll not be lyke these chyldren of the worlde, whome I haue spoken of, let vs hartely loue the lyghte, let vs walke in the lyght and let vs so be the chyldre of lyght whyle we are in thys worlde, that we may shyne in the worlde yt is to come bryght as the Sone.
column8: Wherefore my friends to conclude, if we will not be like these children of the world, whom I have spoken of, let us heartily love the light, let us walk in the light and let us so be the children of light while we are in this world, that we may shine in the world that is to come bright as the Soon.

column7: Let vs accordyng to our sauioure Christes aduertisement & counsaile here, playe the partes of the wyse stewarde.
column8: Let us according to our saviour Christes advertisement & counsel here, play the parts of the wise steward.

column7: Let vs make vs frendes of our money and worldly goodes in bestowynge them not vpon pardons as ye byshop of Rome teacheth vs, but vpon our poore and nedy neyghbours, to thintent that they maye receyue vs agayne, whither? into theyr owne houses to gyue vs dyner for dyner, cote for cote, money for money?
column8: Let us make us friends of our money and worldly goods in bestowing them not upon pardons as you bishop of Rome teaches us, but upon our poor and needy neighbours, to intent that they may receive us again, whither? into their own houses to gyve us dinner for dinner, coat for coat, money for money?

column7: No but into euerlastinge habitacios and tabernacles in heauen, there to haue fruition of all celestiall ioye wyth the father, sonne, and holy goost.
column8: No but into everlasting habitacios and tabernacles in heaven, there to have fruition of all celestial joy with the father, son, and holy ghost.

column7: To whome be all honoure, all glorye, al imperie for euer & euer.
column8: To whom be all honour, all glory, all impery for ever & ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.x. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the x sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.i. Epistle to the Corin. the.xij. Chap. Thargument.
column8: The i Epistle to the Corin. the xij Chap. Thargument.

column7: The diuersitie of the gyftes of ye holy goost.
column8: The diversity of the gifts of the holy ghost.

column7: B Rethren, ye knowe that ye were gentyles, and wente your wayes vnto domme ymages, euen as ye were led.
column8: BRethren BRethren, you know that you were gentiles, and went your ways unto domme images, even as you were led.

column7: Wherfore I declare vnto you that no man speakyng by the spirite of God, defieth Iesus.
column8: Wherefore I declare unto you that no man speaking by the spirit of God, defieth Jesus.

column7: Also no man can saye that Iesus is the Lord, but by the holy ghoste.
column8: Also no man can say that Jesus is the Lord, but by the holy ghost.

column7: There are diuersities of gyftes, yet but one spirite.
column8: There are diversities of gifts, yet but one spirit.

column7: And there are differeces of administracions, and yet but one Lord.
column8: And there are differences of administrations, and yet but one Lord.

column7: And there are dyuerse maners of operacions, and yet but one God whyche worketh all in all.
column8: And there are diverse manners of operations, and yet but one God which works all in all.

column7: The gyfte of the spirite is gyuen to euery ma, to edifie wythall.
column8: The gift of the spirit is given to every ma, to edify withal.

column7: For to one is gyuen thorowe the spirite, the vttraunce of wysdome.
column8: For to one is given thorough the spirit, the vttraunce of wisdom.

column7: To an other, is gyuen the vttrauce of knolege by the same spirite.
column8: To and other, is given the vttrauce of knowledge by the same spirit.

column7: To an other is gyuen fayth, by the same spirite.
column8: To and other is given faith, by the same spirit.

column7: To an other, the gyftes of healyng, by the same spirite.
column8: To and other, the gifts of healing, by the same spirit.

column7: To an other power to do miracles.
column8: To and other power to do miracles.

column7: To an other, prophecie.
column8: To and other, prophecy.

column7: To an other, iudgemente to discerne spirites.
column8: To and other, judgement to discern spirits.

column7: To an other, diuerse toges.
column8: To and other, diverse toges.

column7: To an other, the interpretacion of tonges.
column8: To and other, the interpretation of tongues.

column7: But these al, worketh euen the selfe same spirite diuidyng to euery man a seuerall gyfte, euen as he wyll.
column8: But these all, works even the self same spirit dividing to every man a several gift, even as he will.

column7: P A G Ecxxviij T He auncient fathers (good people) which ordeyned thys epistle to be redde thys daye in the church, thought it (no doubt) ryght necessarye, that there shuld be some certayne tyme appoynted in the churche, to intreate of the gyftes of the holy goost, wherwyth he hath adourned and furnyshed one meber of the same before another to thyntent that they whych haue the mo gyftes, shulde the more laboure and the rather helpe other.
column8: PAGEcxxviij PAGEcxxviij PAGEcxxviij PAGEcxxviij THe THe ancient father's (good people) which ordained this epistle to be red this day in the church, thought it (not doubt) right necessary, that there should be some certain time appointed in the church, to entreat of the gifts of the holy ghost, wherewith he hath adjourned and furnished one meber of the same before another to thyntent that they which have the more gifts, should the more labour and the rather help other.

column7: And therfore Christ sayd to hys disciples.
column8: And therefore Christ said to his disciples.

column7: He that is the greater man of you, be he the seruaunt of thother. <NOTE> The occasion that moued saynt Paule to wryte these thynges of gyftes semeth to be thys.
column8: He that is the greater man of you, be he the servant of tother. The occasion that moved saint Paule to write these things of gifts seemeth to be this.

column7: The worde of God whan it is purely and syncerely preached, can not be abyde ne suffred of the deuell, who is the moost sworne enemy of the pure worde.
column8: The word of God when it is purely and sincerely preached, can not be abide ne suffered of the devil, who is the most sworn enemy of the pure word.

column7: He commeth therfore by and by, and attempteth al the meanes possible, eyther vtterly to destroye it, or at least waye to blotte it wyth false doctrine, as we se ye thynge to haue come to passe in our tyme not wythout great confusion.
column8: He comes therefore by and by, and attempteth all the means possible, either utterly to destroy it, or at least way to blot it with false doctrine, as we see you thing to have come to pass in our time not without great confusion.

column7: The Apostle to remedye these inconueniencies, wryteth these thynges concernynge gyftes, bycause that of pryde and vayneglorye whych is conceyued by great gyftes of God, sundrye sectes and cotencions, be wont to ryse.
column8: The Apostle to remedy these inconveniences, writes these things concerning gifts, because that of pride and vainglory which is conceived by great gifts of God, sundry sects and cotencions, be wont to rise.

column7: Yea the deuell hath no redyer waye to take awaye gods worde, than to make vs puffed vp wyth pryde in our lernynge and knowlege, and so to set vs together by the eares, whych meane also the deuell vsed in the church of the Corinthians, in whych one pursued an other very vnchristianly for theyr gyftes.
column8: Yea the devil hath no redyer way to take away gods word, than to make us puffed up with pride in our learning and knowledge, and so to set us together by the ears, which mean also the devil used in the church of the Corinthians, in which one pursued and other very unchristianly for their gifts.

column7: Some there were whyche despysed the gyftes of the holy goost, as at this daye there be some whych despice the expositions and interpretacions of all holy doctours & fathers of the church, leanynge onely to theyr owne wytte & exposition, some whych despice ye lyberall sciencies, and good artes, some whych saye that the knowlege of the tonges do no good in the church.
column8: Some there were which despised the gifts of the holy ghost, as at this day there be some which despice the expositions and interpretations of all holy doctors & father's of the church, leaning only to their own wit & exposition, some which despice you liberal sciencies, and good arts, some which say that the knowledge of the tongues do not good in the church.

column7: But thys is the strayght waye to take away gods worde.
column8: But this is the straight way to take away gods word.

column7: For wha preachers yea or laye me shal stryue amonges themselues of vayne glorie: there must the pure worde of God nedes be adulterated & corrupted wyth infinite sectes.
column8: For wha preachers yea or say me shall strive among themselves of vain glory: there must the pure word of God needs be adulterated & corrupted with infinite sects.

column7: Fyrste therfore saynte Paule in thys epistle putteth the Corinthians in remembraunce of the state of theyr former lyfe that they lyued in before they came to the knowlege of gods worde.
column8: Fyrste therefore faint Paule in this epistle putteth the Corinthians in remembrance of the state of their former life that they lived in before they came to the knowledge of gods word.

column7: For there is surely no argument eyther greater or stroger to stey men fro takynge pryde of theyr gyftes, than is this, to put them in mynde of theyr former state and conuersation that they were in, whyle they were oute of grace & walked in blyndnes & ydolatrie.
column8: For there is surely no argument either greater or stroger to stey men from taking pride of their gifts, than is this, to put them in mind of their former state and conversation that they were in, while they were out of grace & walked in blindness & idolatry.

column7: For what other thynge were we, before the knowlege of gods worde, than wycked panyms and ydolaters?
column8: For what other thing were we, before the knowledge of gods word, than wicked painims and idolaters?

column7: From whych inconueniencies and euels, whan we are delyuered by grace, I praye you what occasion doeth now remayne for vs to be proude?
column8: From which inconveniences and evils, when we are delivered by grace, I pray you what occasion doth now remain for us to be proud?

column7: In that we be turned of wycked panyms into christians, it is not our meryte.
column8: In that we be turned of wicked painims into christians, it is not our merit.

column7: Furthermore where as of ydolaters we be made the true worshippers of God, neyther can we ascribe thys to our owne powers.
column8: Furthermore where as of idolaters we be made the true worshippers of God, neither can we ascribe this to our own powers.

column7: That we haue gyftes now beynge vnder the Gospell, by whose benefyte commeth it?
column8: That we have gifts now being under the Gospel, by whose benefit comes it?

column7: Surely not by our owne merite.
column8: Surely not by our own merit.

column7: By whose than?
column8: By whose than?

column7: By the bountifulnes and benefyte of the holy goost.
column8: By the bountifulness and benefit of the holy ghost.

column7: What gloriacion than remayneth P A G Ecxxix vnto vs?
column8: What gloriation than remaineth PAGEcxxix PAGEcxxix PAGEcxxix PAGEcxxix unto us?

column7: Forsoth thys, that we may saye we were wycked panyms, worshippers of ydols, & enemyes of God, but now through the grace & fauour of god we be delyuered from so great euels.
column8: Forsooth this, that we may say we were wicked painims, worshippers of idols, & enemies of God, but now through the grace & favour of god we be delivered from so great evils.

column7: Afore ye worlde it wolde seme a great foly and madnes, a ma to glorie and boast in other mens benefytes.
column8: Afore you world it would seem a great folly and madness, a ma to glory and boast in other men's benefits.

column7: But what a greater foly and madnes is it, as the Corinthians dyd, to glorye in the gyftes of god, whych do chauce vnto men of mere grace, and that but only for a tyme of thys lyfe? <NOTE> Assuredly my frendes the chiefe arrogancie inflacion or puffynge vp with pryde which some men vpon theyr syngular gyftes at thys daye haue, springeth principally herby, that they consyder not what they were before the openynge and reuelacion of the gospel.
column8: But what a greater folly and madness is it, as the Corinthians did, to glory in the gifts of god, which do chance unto men of mere grace, and that but only for a time of this life? Assuredly my friends the chief arrogancy inflation or puffing up with pride which some men upon their singular gifts at this day have, springs principally hereby, that they consider not what they were before the opening and revelation of the gospel.

column7: Hetherto pertayneth the sayenge of Paule in the.viij. chapter of the fyrst epistle to the Corinthians.
column8: Hitherto pertaineth the saying of Paule in the viij chapter of the fyrst epistle to the Corinthians.

column7: Scientia inflat. <NOTE> Knowlege maketh a man swell in pryde, as who shulde saye: When men knowe that they be no longer vnder the condemnation of the lawe but in the state of grace, thys knowlege namely yf it be not ryghtly vnderstanded maketh many men proude, arrogant, puffed vp, negligent, slacke in the office of charitie, and ouermuche spirituall, whych oftentymes wyth great contempte of other do glorie of theyr giftes and take a pryde in them.
column8: Scientia inflat. Knowledge makes a man swell in pride, as who should say: When men know that they be no longer under the condemnation of the law but in the state of grace, this knowledge namely if it be not rightly understanded makes many men proud, arrogant, puffed up, negligent, slack in the office of charity, and overmuch spiritual, which oftentimes with great contempt of other doe glory of their gifts and take a pride in them.

column7: But agaynst thys inflacion and pryde (as I haue sayd) there is no remedye more present for vs, then often to cal agayne to our remebrauce our pristine and former state of lyfe, which thinge ye apostle Paule before the rest of the Apostles doth moost diligently in all hys epistles & namely in thys epistle.
column8: But against this inflation and pride (as I have said) there is no remedy more present for us, then often to call again to our remebrauce our pristine and former state of life, which thing you apostle Paule before the rest of the Apostles does most diligently in all his epistles & namely in this epistle.

column7: To thys agreeth that whych he sayeth in the fourth chapter of thys epistle. <NOTE> What haste thou that thou hast not receyued the same before?
column8: To this agreeth that which he sayeth in the fourth chapter of this epistle. What haste thou that thou hast not received the same before?

column7: And yf thou hast receyued it, why doest thou bragge?
column8: And if thou hast received it, why dost thou brag?

column7: Secondly, we be here taught and informed of the authour and cause of these gyftes, that is to saye, ye holy ghost & of hys principall office: and in especiall of the greatest gyft of all, whych is to endowe vs wt the knowlege of Christe, out of whych gyfte ye other speciall gyftes do flowe none otherwyse then out of a quycke sprynge. <NOTE> Christe beynge knowen and apprehended by a lyuely fayth, whyche is euer in a redynesse whan occasion serueth, to worke by charytye and to fructifie, is the cause that we receyue the holy ghoste and all hys gyftes, accordyng to the sayng of the prophete. <NOTE> When he ascended vp to heuen, he led captiuitie a prysoner, and gaue giftes to me.
column8: Secondly, we be here taught and informed of the author and cause of these gifts, that is to say, you holy ghost & of his principal office: and in especial of the greatest gift of all, which is to endow us with the knowledge of Christe, out of which gift you other special gifts do flow none otherwise then out of a quick spring. Christe being known and apprehended by a lively faith, which is ever in a redynesse when occasion serveth, to work by charytye and to fructify, is the cause that we receive the holy ghost and all his gifts, according to the saying of the prophet. When he ascended up to heaven, he led captivity a prisoner, and gave gifts to me.

column7: Thys ascension is yet daylye accomplyshed in vs, when by ye ayde of the holyghoste we knowe Christe and take holde of hym by lyuely fayth, who beynge knowne & appreheded, sendeth vnto vs more abundantly the holy ghoste, and endoweth vs wt gyftes.
column8: This ascension is yet daily accomplished in us, when by you aid of the holyghoste we know Christe and take hold of him by lively faith, who being known & appreheded, sends unto us more abundantly the holy ghost, and endoweth us with gifts.

column7: To saye then that Christe is the Lorde, is the verye gyfte of ye holy gooste wherupon all the reste of the gyftes be founded and layde, as appeareth by the verse of ye psalme aboue remebred: Ascendit in altu captiua duxit captiuitate, dedit dona hominibus. And surely, who soeuer hath thys gyfte of the holy ghoste, that he can saye Christ to be the Lorde, maye sone be made also partaker of the other gyftes.
column8: To say then that Christe is the Lord, is the very gift of the holy ghost whereupon all the rest of the gifts be founded and laid, as appears by the verse of the psalm above remebred: Ascendit in altu captiua duxit captiuitate, dedit dona hominibus. And surely, who soever hath this gift of the holy ghost, that he can say Christ to be the Lord, may soon be made also partaker of the other gifts.

column7: But he that defieth Christ, he yt calleth Christ Anathema he can be partaker of no gyftes of the holye ghoste.
column8: But he that defieth Christ, he that calls Christ Anathema he can be partaker of no gifts of the holy ghost.

column7: They call Christe Anathema, whyche denye hym to P A G Ecxxx be Lorde, whyche thynge is as moch to saye, as to denye hym to be the Sauiour of the worlde, whych hath ouercome death, and whych nowe wyth great power raygneth ouer synne, death, and the deuell.
column8: They call Christe Anathema, which deny him to PAGEcxxx PAGEcxxx PAGEcxxx PAGEcxxx be Lord, which thing is as much to say, as to deny him to be the Saviour of the world, which hath overcome death, and which now with great power reigneth over sin, death, and the devil.

column7: It is also to denye Christ to be our iustice, sanctification, and redeption, who furthermore lyke a moste valiaut Lorde protecteth, defendeth, and saueth vs from all euels. <NOTE> Anathema is a Greke worde & signifyeth a layenge asyde or separacion of gyftes which were offred vp to goddes and whyche was lawfull for no man to remoue out of theyr place.
column8: It is also to deny Christ to be our justice, sanctification, and redeption, who furthermore like a most valiaut Lord protecteth, defendeth, and saveth us from all evils. Anathema is a Greek word & signifieth a layenge aside or separation of gifts which were offered up to gods and which was lawful for no man to remove out of their place.

column7: Euen so do hypocrites set aparte Christ, and vse not hym, <NOTE> the workes of theyr owne inuention, to such hypocrites Christ is Anathema, that is to saye, a cast awaye a thynge accursed, abhorred, and detested as in lykewyse the Iues by Anathema do sygnifye an execracion or cursynge, as saynt Hierome also wytnesseth. <NOTE>
column8: Euen so do hypocrites set apart Christ, and use not him, the works of their own invention, to such hypocrites Christ is Anathema, that is to say, a cast away a thing accursed, abhorred, and detested as in likewise the Iues by Anathema do sygnifye and execration or cursing, as saint Hierome also witnesseth.

column7: Thyrdly the apostle doth here teach vs the final vse and ende of all gyftes, whych is vnitie and concorde, so that we must knowe, that the holy goost as he is one, so he gyueth hys gyftes to men to the vnitie and edificacion of the churche and not that men shulde after a contenciouse and vncharitable sorte be proude and glorie of theyr gyftes and talentes yt God hath indowed them wyth.
column8: Thyrdly the apostle does here teach us the final use and end of all gifts, which is unity and concord, so that we must know, that the holy ghost as he is one, so he gyveth his gifts to men to the unity and edification of the church and not that men should after a contenciouse and uncharitable sort be proud and glory of their gifts and talents that God hath endowed them with.

column7: These men preache rather for vayne glorie and to wynne them prayse of men, than to edifye the christen flocke.
column8: These men preach rather for vain glory and to win them praise of men, than to edify the christian flock.

column7: Wherfore they haue theyr mede and rewarde.
column8: Wherefore they have their mede and reward.

column7: Let vs then my welbeloued brethren, cease of all such contenciouse & vncharitable boastyng & despysynge of others that haue not the knowlege whych we haue.
column8: Let us then my well-beloved brothers, cease of all such contenciouse & uncharitable boasting & despising of others that have not the knowledge which we have.

column7: Yf they offende, let vs rather gently and charitably monyshe them betwene them and vs, and not rayle, triumphe detracte and defame them with vnsemynge names.
column8: If they offend, let us rather gently and charitably monish them between them and us, and not rail, triumph detract and defame them with vnsemynge names.

column7: Let vs call to mynde what we were oure selues and what we be of oure selues.
column8: Let us call to mind what we were our selves and what we be of our selves.

column7: Let vs remember that what so euer we haue, the same we haue receyued of gods grace and not of owne proper powers.
column8: Let us remember that what so ever we have, the same we have received of gods grace and not of own proper powers.

column7: Thus doynge, we shal edifye our brethren and systerne, we shall declare, that we be in dede the persons that we be named, that is to saye, christen men and women, folowers of Christe, and fynally inheritours of euerlastynge blesse prepared for vs by the father of heauen.
column8: Thus doing, we shall edify our brothers and systerne, we shall declare, that we be in deed the persons that we be nam, that is to say, christen men and women, followers of Christe, and finally inheritors of everlasting bless prepared for us by the father of heaven.

column7: To whome be all glorye and prayse worlde wythout ende.
column8: To whom be all glory and praise world without end.

column7: AMEN.
column8: AMEN.

column7: : homily The gospell on the.x. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The gospel on the x sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.xix. chapter of Luke.
column8: The xix chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: The punyshment of such as despice goddes worde and how Christ casteth out byers and sellers in the temple.
column8: The punishment of such as despice gods word and how Christ casts out byers and sellers in the temple.

column7: W Han he was come neare, he behelde the cytie and wepte on it, sayenge: Yf thou haddest knowen those thynges whyche belonge vnto thy peace, euen in thys thy daye, thou woldest take hede.
column8: When When he was come near, he beheld the city and wept on it, saying: If thou hadst known those things which belong unto thy peace, even in this thy day, thou wouldst take heed.

column7: But nowe are they hydde from thyne eyes.
column8: But now are they hid from thine eyes.

column7: For the dayes shall come vpon the that thyne enemyes also shall caste a banke aboute the, and compasse the rounde, and kepe the in, on euery syde, and make the euen wyth the grounde, and thy chyldren whych are in the.
column8: For the days shall come upon thee that thine enemies also shall cast a bank about thee, and compass the round, and keep thee in, on every side, and make the even with the ground, and thy children which are in thee.

column7: And they shal not leaue P A G Ecxxxi in the one stone vpon an other, bycause thou knowest not the tyme of thy visitacion.
column8: And they shall not leave PAGEcxxxi PAGEcxxxi PAGEcxxxi PAGEcxxxi in the one stone upon and other, because thou knowest not the time of thy visitation.

column7: And he wente into the temple, and began to caste out them that solde therin, and them that bought, sayenge vnto them: It is writte, my house is the house of prayer: but ye haue made it a den of theues: And he taught dayly in the temple.
column8: And he went into the temple, and began to cast out them that sold therein, and them that bought, saying unto them: It is written, my house is the house of prayer: but you have made it a den of thieves: And he taught daily in the temple.

column7: MY welbeloued frendes in Christ ye shal vnderstand yt God is right good and much mercyful towarde vs. Father of mercy and God of all consolation is he as saynt Paule sayeth.
column8: MY well-beloved friends in Christ you shall understand that God is right good and much merciful toward us Father of mercy and God of all consolation is he as saint Paule sayeth.

column7: And yet for all that we muste take good hede, that we do not abuse the hygh benefyte and commoditie of hys mercyfulnes & goodnes as they of Ierusale hath done, lyke as in thys storye we rede.
column8: And yet for all that we must take good heed, that we do not abuse the high benefit and commodity of his mercyfulnes & goodness as they of Ierusale hath done, like as in this story we rede.

column7: We se how Iesus Christe was come for to brynge them grace for to teach and to saue them, and they haue refused him.
column8: We see how Jesus Christe was come for to bring them grace for to teach and to save them, and they have refused him.

column7: It was for that cause only that he wepte whan he dyd beholde the cytie as is now made mecion in the gospel.
column8: It was for that cause only that he wept when he did behold the city as is now made mention in the gospel.

column7: And in that yt he hath wept he hath wel shewed yt he wold not couete the death nor the damnation of the synner.
column8: And in that that he hath wept he hath well showed that he would not covet the death nor the damnation of the sinner.

column7: He dyd not wepe for the ruyne and fall that he knew shuld ensue of the fayre houses, of the towers, and great edifices and buyldynges, but he bewayled the losse, the ruyne, and damnation of the people He sayde O Ierusalem yf thou dyddest knowe the thynges that belonge vnto thy peace euen in thys thy daye, thou woldest take hede.
column8: He did not weep for the ruin and fallen that he knew should ensue of the fair houses, of the towers, and great edifices and buildings, but he bewailed the loss, the ruin, and damnation of the people He said Oh Jerusalem if thou didst know the things that belong unto thy peace even in this thy day, thou wouldst take heed.

column7: As yf he had sayd, yf thou knewest thy mysery, & the confusion, & desolation whych is to come to the, and specially yf thou dyddest knowe it in these dayes whan I am descended from heuen for to make thy peace wyth god my father and get the remyssion of thy synnes, yf thou (I saye) dyddest knowe it: thou shuldest haue good cause for to wepe wyth me.
column8: As if he had said, if thou knewest thy misery, & the confusion, & desolation which is to come to thee, and specially if thou didst know it in these days when I am descended from heaven for to make thy peace with god my father and get the remission of thy sins, if thou (I say) didst know it: thou shouldst have good cause for to weep with me.

column7: But now all thys is hydden from the, thou fearest nothynge forbycause that thou carest for nothynge.
column8: But now all this is hidden from thee, thou fearest nothing forbycause that thou carest for nothing.

column7: But ye dayes shall come in the and thyne enemyes shall enuiron the wyth bulwarkes.
column8: But you days shall come in thee and thine enemies shall environ thee with bulwarks.

column7: &c. Now my frendes by desolation and confusion temporall of them of Ierusalem whych wold not beleue nor receyue Iesu Christ, is fygured ye spirituall confusion whych shal come vnto them which yet wyll not receyue hym nor folowe hym and which make resystence agaynst hym & hys gospel of whom the nomber is great.
column8: etc. Now my friends by desolation and confusion temporal of them of Jerusalem which would not believe nor receive Jesu Christ, is figured you spiritual confusion which shall come unto them which yet will not receive him nor follow him and which make resistance against him & his gospel of whom the number is great.

column7: For whome also Iesus Christe knowynge theyr distruction that was to come hath wept.
column8: For whom also Jesus Christe knowing their destruction that was to come hath wept.

column7: Those whych thynke to be saued by any other meanes then by hym and whych haue theyr fayth & theyr hope in any other then in hym and by him, surely they haue not yet receyued hym, and euell shall come vnto them.
column8: Those which think to be saved by any other means then by him and which have their faith & their hope in any other then in him and by him, surely they have not yet received him, and evil shall come unto them.

column7: For God alone is the obiecte of the fayth, hope, and charitie of christen men.
column8: For God alone is the object of the faith, hope, and charity of christian men.

column7: Then foloweth that after he was arryued there, he entred into the temple and droue out of it the byers and sellers.
column8: Then followeth that after he was arrived there, he entered into the temple and drove out of it the byers and sellers.

column7: God (yf hys pleasure were) I hertely beseche hym to vysite agayne hys holy temple I meane the churche of christen men and women and the house of prayer where as he alonly ought to be serued and worshipped by hys subiectes in spirite: <NOTE> and veritie.
column8: God (if his pleasure were) I heartily beseech him to visit again his holy temple I mean the church of christian men and women and the house of prayer where as he alonely ought to be served and worshipped by his subjects in spirit: and verity.

column7: And that it wolde please hym to caste out those whych shalbe founde byers and sellers by simonye and couetousnes and that woll resyst hys moost holy and sacred worde and that wyll let that the seruice of god in spirite P A G Ecxxxij and veritie be not accomplyshed accordynge as he wolde by hys ryghte holy worde & ordenaunce to be serued and honoured.
column8: And that it would please him to cast out those which shall found byers and sellers by simony and covetousness and that will resist his most holy and sacred word and that will let that the service of god in spirit PAGEcxxxij PAGEcxxxij PAGEcxxxij PAGEcxxxij and verity be not accomplished according as he would by his right holy word & ordinance to be served and honoured.

column7: Vnto him be al glorye and honoure in infinita secula.
column8: Unto him be all glory and honour in infinita secula.

column7: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the.xi. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the xi sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.i. epistle to the Corin. the.xv. chapter.
column8: The i epistle to the Corin. the xv chapter.

column7: Thargument The resurrection of the deade.
column8: Thargument The resurrection of the dead.

column7: B Rethren, as perteynynge to the gospel whych I preached vnto you, whyche ye haue also accepted, and in the whyche ye continue, by the which also ye are saued: I do you to wytte, after what maner I preached vnto you, yf ye kepe it, except ye haue beleued in vayne.
column8: BRethren BRethren, as pertaining to the gospel which I preached unto you, which you have also accepted, and in the which you continue, by the which also you are saved: I do you to wit, after what manner I preached unto you, if you keep it, except you have believed in vain.

column7: For fyrst of all I delyuered vnto you, that whyche I receyued: howe that Christe dyed for our synnes, agreynge to the scriptures: And that he was buryed, and that he arose agayne the thyrde daye accordynge to the scriptures: and that he was sene of Cephas, than of the twelue. After that was he sene of mo then fyue hundred brethren atonce: of whyche many remayne vnto thys daye, and many are fallen aslepe.
column8: For fyrst of all I delivered unto you, that which I received: how that Christe died for our sins, agreeing to the scriptures: And that he was buried, and that he arose again the thyrde day according to the scriptures: and that he was seen of Cephas, than of the twelue. After that was he seen of more then fyue hundred brothers atonce: of which many remain unto this day, and many are fallen asleep.

column7: After that appeared he to Iames, then to all the apostles.
column8: After that appeared he to Iames, then to all the apostles.

column7: And last of all he was sene of me, as of one that was borne out of due tyme.
column8: And last of all he was seen of me, as of one that was born out of due time.

column7: For I am the lest of the Apostles, which am not worthy to be called an Apostle, because I persecuted the congregacion of God.
column8: For I am the lest of the Apostles, which am not worthy to be called and Apostle, because I persecuted the congregation of God.

column7: But by the grace of god, I am that I am.
column8: But by the grace of god, I am that I am.

column7: And hys grace whych is in me, was not in vayne.
column8: And his grace which is in me, was not in vain.

column7: T He thynge good people wherfore saynt Paule beynge in this worlde toke moost thought for, and the whych he had moost at hys harte nexte Iesu Christ, was for to knowe how euery churche dyd gouerne and entertayne themselues in the Gospell of Iesu Christ, to thintet that yf perdauenture any went out of the waye of trouth, he shulde be forth wyth redressed as specially he doth shewe in ye epistle of thys daye.
column8: THe THe thing good people wherefore saint Paule being in this world took most thought for, and the which he had most at his heart nexte Jesu Christ, was for to know how every church did govern and entertain themselves in the Gospel of Jesu Christ, to thintet that if perdauenture any went out of the way of troth, he should be forth with redressed as specially he does show in you epistle of this day.

column7: He admonysheth and reduceth in memory vnto the Corinthias principally two thynges on the whych all the fayth and all the assurauce and hope of christen men is founded.
column8: He admonisheth and reduceth in memory unto the Corinthias principally two things on the which all the faith and all the assurance and hope of christian men is founded.

column7: The fyrst is that Iesus Christ is deade for our synnes.
column8: The fyrst is that Jesus Christ is dead for our sins.

column7: It is a worde whych ought well to be imprinted in the hartes of christen people, or els one ought not nor is not worthy to be called christened.
column8: It is a word which ought well to be imprinted in the hearts of christian people, or else one ought not nor is not worthy to be called christened.

column7: Iesus Christ is dead for our synnes (sayth saynt Paul.)
column8: Jesus Christ is dead for our sins (say saint Paul.)

column7: Then we be nomore in dette for our synnes syth that Iesus Christ hath satisfyed and payde for vs. Nor also we ought nomore to serue vnto synne seynge that by hys death he hath wylled to cause synne to dye in vs yf so be we beleue stedfastlye in hym.
column8: Then we be nomore in debt for our sins sith that Jesus Christ hath satisfied and paid for us Nor also we ought nomore to serve unto sin sing that by his death he hath willed to cause sin to die in us if so be we believe steadfastly in him.

column7: The seconde thynge whych he reduceth in memory vnto the Corinthias and to vs, is that Iesus Christ hath ben buried and is rysen to lyfe agayne.
column8: The seconde thing which he reduceth in memory unto the Corinthias and to us, is that Jesus Christ hath been buried and is risen to life again.

column7: Thys is it where on ye hope of the christen people ought to be founded.
column8: This is it where on you hope of the christian people ought to be founded.

column7: For yf the heade be rysen agayne to lyfe in triumphe & glorye, in lyke case shall the mebers ryse agayne.
column8: For if the head be risen again to life in triumph & glory, in like case shall the mebers rise again.

column7: They shal ryse agayne vnto grace and vnto spiritual lyfe in thys worlde and vnto glorye and lyfe eternall in the other. <NOTE> As saynt Ihon sayeth in hys Apocalyps.
column8: They shall rise again unto grace and unto spiritual life in this world and unto glory and life eternal in the other. As saint Ihon sayeth in his Apocalyps.

column7: Happye shall they be & holy is he whych hath parte P A G Ecxxxiij in ye fyrst resurrectio, the secode death hath no power ouer them.
column8: Happy shall they be & holy is he which hath part PAGEcxxxiij PAGEcxxxiij PAGEcxxxiij PAGEcxxxiij in the fyrst resurrectio, the secode death hath no power over them.

column7: Some false preachers wolde haue tourned the Corinthians from the sayd fayth & for thys cause doth saynt Paule warne them so busely, sayenge: My brethren I do you to vnderstande and I do reduce to your memory the good newes which I haue preached vnto you I meane the gospell which ye haue receyued by fayth to ye whych ye haue stayed your selues and by the which ye shalbe saued yf you folow it.
column8: Some false preachers would have turned the Corinthians from the said faith & for this cause does saint Paule warn them so busily, saying: My brothers I do you to understand and I do reduce to your memory the good news which I have preached unto you I mean the gospel which you have received by faith to you which you have stayed your selves and by the which you shall saved if you follow it.

column7: I let you to wyt for what reason & in what fashion I haue preached it vnto you yf ye haue remembraunce therof, yea yf ye haue not beleued in vayne.
column8: I let you to wit for what reason & in what fashion I have preached it unto you if you have remembrance thereof, yea if you have not believed in vain.

column7: Fyrst that whyche I haue receyued of God whyche hath bene to me reuelate.
column8: Fyrst that which I have received of God which hath be to me reuelate.

column7: What?
column8: What?

column7: Christe is deade for our synnes accordynge as it is wrytten as it hath ben sayd before and wrytte by the prophetes.
column8: Christe is dead for our sins according as it is written as it hath been said before and writ by the prophets.

column7: Then he sayeth he hath bene buryed and is rysen agayne to lyfe.
column8: Then he sayeth he hath be buried and is risen again to life.

column7: And for to confirme the same ye more, he sayeth more ouer, that Iesus Christ after hys resurrection hath bene sene by Peter and after by the xij. apostles and sythin hath bene sene by.v. hudreth brethren beynge together.
column8: And for to confirm the same you more, he sayeth more over, that Jesus Christ after his resurrection hath be seen by Peter and after by the xij. apostles and sythin hath be seen by v hudreth brothers being together.

column7: As yf he had sayd: You ought to be well assured of thys for asmuch as these mysteries haue not ben shewed vnto me alone, but the holy wrytynges doth wytnesse ye same.
column8: As if he had said: You ought to be well assured of this for as as these mysteries have not been showed unto me alone, but the holy writings does witness you same.

column7: And also they vnto whome he hath appeared after hys resurrection whych be of great nomber.
column8: And also they unto whom he hath appeared after his resurrection which be of great number.

column7: Certes who soeuer leseth the hope of resurrection the same also leseth all spirituall consolation and comforte.
column8: Certes who soever leseth the hope of resurrection the same also leseth all spiritual consolation and comfort.

column7: Then after he commeth to speake (in a great humilitie) of the grace whych Iesus Christ hath gyuen him.
column8: Then after he comes to speak (in a great humility) of the grace which Jesus Christ hath given him.

column7: And after all (he sayeth) he hath bene sene by me, he hath appeared vnto me whyche am as an abortiue creature.
column8: And after all (he sayeth) he hath be seen by me, he hath appeared unto me which am as and abortive creature.

column7: For I am the least of the Apostles whyche am not worthy to be called an Apostle, for I haue persecuted ye church of God, but I am that I am, apostle amonge the Gentyls in fayth and in trouth.
column8: For I am the least of the Apostles which am not worthy to be called and Apostle, for I have persecuted you church of God, but I am that I am, apostle among the Gentles in faith and in troth.

column7: I am that that I am not by my workes, not by my merytes, but by the grace of God.
column8: I am that that I am not by my works, not by my merits, but by the grace of God.

column7: And hys grace (sayeth he) hath not ben ydle in me.
column8: And his grace (sayeth he) hath not been idle in me.

column7: As yf he wolde saye: I haue not hyd the talent of gold whyche my mayster & lorde Iesu Christ toke me to bestowe, but I haue made it to gayne more then any other.
column8: As if he would say: I have not hid the talon of gold which my master & lord Jesu Christ took me to bestow, but I have made it to gain more then any other.

column7: I haue laboured more abundauntly then they all.
column8: I have laboured more abundantly then they all.

column7: But not I yet but the grace of God whych is in me.
column8: But not I yet but the grace of God which is in me.

column7: Saint Paule in speakynge of hys owne person and of hys grace whyche he receyued of God speaketh vnto vs teachyng vs by hys exemple that we ought to presume nothynge of our selues but to yelde all vnto God & vnderstande that all cometh from hym.
column8: Saint Paule in speaking of his own person and of his grace which he received of God speaks unto us teaching us by his exemple that we ought to presume nothing of our selves but to yield all unto God & understand that all comes from him.

column7: The ecclesiastes sayeth speakynge of the See.
column8: The ecclesiastes sayeth speaking of the See.

column7: The waters returne vnto the place from whence they come forth to thende that they may runne agayne.
column8: The waters return unto the place from whence they come forth to th'end that they may run again.

column7: In lyke maner we must sende agayne and knowlege God to be all grace to thende that he maye alwayes augment it vnto vs vnto the tyme that we maye come wyth hym into hys glorye for to prayse hym, exalte hym, & perpetually to glorifye hym.
column8: In like manner we must send again and knowledge God to be all grace to th'end that he may always augment it unto us unto the time that we may come with him into his glory for to praise him, exalt him, & perpetually to glorify him.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospell on the.xi. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the xi sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.xviij. Chapter of Luke.
column8: The xviij Chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: The parable of the Pharise and Publicane.
column8: The parable of the Pharisee and Publican.

column7: I Esus put forth thys parable vnto certayn which trusted in themselues that they were perfite, and P A G Ecxxxiiij despised other.
column8: IEsus IEsus put forth this parable unto certain which trusted in themselves that they were perfect, and PAGEcxxxiiij PAGEcxxxiiij PAGEcxxxiiij PAGEcxxxiiij despised other.

column7: Two men wente vp into the temple to praye: the one a Pharise and the other a Publicane.
column8: Two men went up into the temple to pray: the one a Pharisee and the other a Publican.

column7: The pharise stode and prayed thus wyth hymselfe: God, I thanke the, that I am not as other men are, extorsioners, vniust, aduoutrers, or as thys publicane.
column8: The pharisee stood and prayed thus with himself: God, I thank thee, that I am not as other men are, extortioners, unjust, aduoutrers, or as this publican.

column7: I fast twyse in the weke.
column8: I fast twice in the week.

column7: I gyue tyth of all that I possesse.
column8: I gyve tyth of all that I possess.

column7: And the publicane standynge afarre of, wolde not lyfte vp his eyes to heuen, but smote vpon hys brest, sayenge: God be mercyfull to me a synner: I tell you: thys man departed home to hys house iustifyed, more tha the other.
column8: And the publican standing afar of, would not lift up his eyes to heaven, but smote upon his breast, saying: God be merciful to me a sinner: I tell you: this man departed home to his house justified, more than the other.

column7: For euery one that exalteth hymselfe, shalbe brought lowe: And he that humbleth hymselfe, shalbe exalted.
column8: For every one that exalteth himself, shall brought low: And he that humbleth himself, shall exalted.

column7: MY frendes and brethre in our Sauiour Christ Iesu, I do you well to vnderstande, that there was somtyme amonges the Iues and is yet at thys daye amonges christen folke a certayne pharisaicall kynde of iuste or ryghtuous persons, whyche haue theyr cofidence and trust in theyr owne workes, and whych presumptuouslye seke to themselues laude & prayse of iustice therby, <NOTE> where as afore God as wytnesseth the prophete there is no ryghtuous persone.
column8: MY friends and brethren in our Saviour Christ Jesu, I do you well to understand, that there was sometime among the Iues and is yet at this day among christian folk a certain pharisaical kind of just or righteous persons, which have their confidence and trust in their own works, and which presumptuously seek to themselves laud & praise of justice thereby, where as afore God as witnesseth the prophet there is no righteous person.

column7: Neyther dyd they only stade foolyshly in theyr owne conceytes and pleased well themselues, but also in comparison of themselues they dispraysed and also despysed others as synfulle and worldlye persones, where as in very dede the humblenes and modestie of suche as be synners and the condenation of themselues wyth request of mercy is muche more regarded and is more acceptable to God, than is ye proude and arrogant workynge of such pharisaical persos.
column8: Neither did they only stade foolishly in their own conceits and pleased well themselves, but also in comparison of themselves they dispraised and also despised others as synfulle and worldly persons, where as in very deed the humbleness and modesty of such as be sinners and the condenation of themselves with request of mercy is much more regarded and is more acceptable to God, than is the proud and arrogant working of such pharisaical persons.

column7: Wherfore against such pharisaical rightuous folke and for the coforte of such sinners as displease themselues and be hartely sory for theyr mysordred lyfe, our sauiour and Lorde Iesus Christ dyd propoune thys parable or similitude vnto the Iues & by them to all the worlde.
column8: Wherefore against such pharisaical righteous folk and for the coforte of such sinners as displease themselves and be heartily sorry for their mysordred life, our saviour and Lord Jesus Christ did propoune this parable or similitude unto the Iues & by them to all the world.

column7: It befell so (sayeth Christ) that two certayne persons wente vp to the temple or churche for to praye, the one was a Pharise (that is to saye one that diuideth hymselfe as better from the multitude & comon sorte of men, <NOTE> accordynge to Origenes interpretacion) the other was a publicane, that is to saye, a customer, a gatherer of toll or tribute, or such other common officer deputed for such purposes.
column8: It befell so (sayeth Christ) that two certain persons went up to the temple or church for to pray, the one was a Pharisee (that is to say one that divideth himself as better from the multitude & common sort of men, according to Origenes interpretation) the other was a publican, that is to say, a customer, a gatherer of toll or tribute, or such other common officer deputed for such purposes.

column7: The pharise standynge nye to the hygh aultare, as one that thought hymselfe worthy to talke presently wyth God, thus began to praye wyth himselfe.
column8: The pharisee standing nigh to the high altar, as one that thought himself worthy to talk presently with God, thus began to pray with himself.

column7: God I thanke the, that I am not lyke to ye rest of folke, whych lyue by rauyne, pyllage, and extorcion, which do increase theyr substaunce by fraude and crafte, which defyle other mens beddes wyth aduoutrye, or finally whych bearynge any sklaunderouse rowme or office do pyll and poll the people of God or holy church, as is thys publicane, thys tribute gatherer, thys collectour.
column8: God I thank thee, that I am not like to you rest of folk, which live by rauyne, pillage, and extortion, which do increase their substance by fraud and craft, which defile other men's beds with aduoutrye, or finally which bearing any sklaunderouse room or office do pyll and poll the people of God or holy church, as is this publican, this tribute gatherer, this collector.

column7: I am not riottouse and sumptuous in my fare and apparell, as is the common sorte of people, I fast twyse a weke, and in somuch defraude I noman, that also I distribute the tenth parte of my goodes vpon the poore people.
column8: I am not riottouse and sumptuous in my fare and apparel, as is the common sort of people, I fast twice a week, and in somuch defraud I noman, that also I distribute the tenth part of my goods upon the poor people.

column7: Thys was the prayer of the swellynge and proude pharise, whyche albeit he reapported of hymselfe the trouth and thaked God: yet he displeased the eyes of God euen bycause he pleased hymselfe, flatterynge hymselfe, and P A G Ecxxxv beynge cotumeliouse agaynst hys neyghboure.
column8: This was the prayer of the swelling and proud pharisee, which albeit he reapported of himself the troth and thaked God: yet he displeased the eyes of God even because he pleased himself, flattering himself, and PAGEcxxxv PAGEcxxxv PAGEcxxxv PAGEcxxxv being cotumeliouse against his neighbour.

column7: On the contrarye, the publicane altogether displeasyng hymselfe for the knowlege of hys synnes stode a great waye of from the aultare, beynge so ashamed of hymselfe and penitent, that he durst not ones lyft vp hys eyen to heauen but strake hys brest, sayeng: Deus propitius esto mihi peccatori. That is to say, God, be thou mercyfull vnto me a synner.
column8: On the contrary, the publican altogether displeasing himself for the knowledge of his sins stood a great way of from the altar, being so ashamed of himself and penitent, that he durst not ones lift up his eyes to heaven but strake his breast, saying: Deus propitius esto mihi peccatori. That is to say, God, be thou merciful unto me a sinner.

column7: The pharise thought it ynough to gyue God thankes, supposynge that he lacked nothynge, that shulde be requisyte vnto perfyte holynes, and therfore he confessed no offenses, wheras in very dede euen in hys selfe prayers he synned moost greuouslye in that he boasted of hymselfe and despysed the penitent persone, beynge an arrogant prayser of hymselfe and a rashe accuser of hys neyghbour.
column8: The pharisee thought it enough to gyve God thanks, supposing that he lacked nothing, that should be requisyte unto perfect holiness, and therefore he confessed no offenses, whereas in very deed even in his self prayers he sinned most grievously in that he boasted of himself and despised the penitent person, being and arrogant praiser of himself and a rash accuser of his neighbour.

column7: Contrarye, the publicane made no rehersall at all of hys good dedes.
column8: Contrary, the publican made no rehearsal at all of his good deeds.

column7: Only acknowlegynge and confessynge hys naughtynes, he knocketh hys brest, condemnyng hymselfe and humbly beggynge grace and pardon of hys offenses.
column8: Only acknowledging and confessing his naughtynes, he knocketh his breast, condemning himself and humbly begging grace and pardon of his offenses.

column7: My frendes, woll ye knowe the conclusion and ende of thys sondrye and dyuerse prayer?
column8: My friends, will you know the conclusion and end of this sundry and diverse prayer?

column7: That same publicane, whych came a synner into ye church, by Christes owne sentence and determination went home in the syght of God more iust and ryghtuouse than that pharise, whyche thought hymselfe moost ryghtuouse.
column8: That same publican, which came a sinner into you church, by Christes own sentence and determination went home in the sight of God more just and righteous than that pharisee, which thought himself most righteous.

column7: For assuredly whosoeuer auaunceth hymselfe wyth hymself, shalbe deiected & cast downe in the eyen of God.
column8: For assuredly whosoever auaunceth himself with himself, shall dejected & cast down in the eyes of God.

column7: And whosoeuer deiecteth and casteth hymselfe downe wyth hymselfe, shalbe hygh in the eyen of god.
column8: And whosoever deiecteth and casts himself down with himself, shall high in the eyes of god.

column7: By thys parable then (good people) let vs lerne to humble and lowly our selues.
column8: By this parable then (good people) let us learn to humble and lowly our selves.

column7: Let vs lerne, whan we be out of gods fauoure for the haynousnes of our sinnes, by due penaunce to reconcile our selues agayne and to purchase remission of the same. <NOTE> I call penauce (accordynge to saynt Austines definicion) a dayly payne and greue of the good and lowly christians wherin we knocke our brestes, sayenge: <NOTE> Forgyue vs our trespasses as we forgyue the that trespasse agaynst vs. And by these wordes (sayeth saynt Austine) humblynge oure soules we cease not after a maner to do dayly penaunce.
column8: Let us learn, when we be out of gods favour for the haynousnes of our sins, by due penance to reconcile our selves again and to purchase remission of the same. I call penance (according to saint Austines definition) a daily pain and grieve of the good and lowly christians wherein we knock our breasts, saying: Forgive us our trespasses as we forgive the that trespass against us And by these words (sayeth saint Austine) humbling our souls we cease not after a manner to do daily penance.

column7: But it is to be feared, lest many of vs playe rather the pharisees parte, thynkynge our selues hyghly in gods fauour and in the meane season despysynge our neghbours whych by theyr humble submission and penitent hertes shall get vp before vs. Heauen is gyuen not to such as iustifie themselues by their owne dedes, but to such as mekely and penitently call for mercy, pardon, and grace wherby they maye afterward worke that maye be pleasaunt in gods syght.
column8: But it is to be feared, lest many of us play rather the pharisees part, thinking our selves highly in gods favour and in the mean season despising our neighbours which by their humble submission and penitent herts shall get up before us Heaven is given not to such as justify themselves by their own deeds, but to such as meekly and penitently call for mercy, pardon, and grace whereby they may afterwards work that may be pleasant in gods sight.

column7: Who wol surely in heauen crowne them wyth glorye immortall.
column8: Who will surely in heaven crown them with glory immortal.

column7: To whome be honoure and prayse for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be honour and praise for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.xij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the xij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.ij. Epistle to the Corin. the.iij. Chap. Thargument.
column8: The ij Epistle to the Corin. the iij Chap. Thargument.

column7: The ministration of ye gospel is here praysed
column8: The ministration of the gospel is here praised

column7: B Rethren, such trust haue we thorow Christ to godwarde, not that we are sufficient of oure selues to thynke any thynge, as of oure selues: but yf we be able vnto any thynge the same commeth of God, whych hath made vs able to minister the P A G Ecxxxvi new testament, not of the letter, but of the spirite.
column8: BRethren BRethren, such trust have we thorough Christ to godward, not that we are sufficient of our selves to think any thing, as of our selves: but if we be able unto any thing the same comes of God, which hath made us able to minister the PAGEcxxxvi PAGEcxxxvi PAGEcxxxvi PAGEcxxxvi new testament, not of the letter, but of the spirit.

column7: For the letter kylleth, but the spirite gyueth lyfe.
column8: For the letter killeth, but the spirit gyveth life.

column7: Yf the ministracion of death thorow the letters fygured in stones, was glorious, so that the chyldren of Israel coulde not behold the face of Moses, for the glorye of hys countenaunce (whych glorye is done awaye) why shall not the ministracion of the spirite be much more glorious?
column8: If the ministration of death thorough the letters figured in stones, was glorious, so that the children of Israel could not behold the face of Moses, for the glory of his countenance (which glory is done away) why shall not the ministration of the spirit be much more glorious?

column7: For yf the ministrynge of condemnation be glorious: much more doth the ministration of ryghtuousnes excede in glorye.
column8: For if the ministering of condemnation be glorious: much more does the ministration of righteousness exceed in glory.

column7: F Or bycause that saint Paule welbeloued brethre in our sauiour Christe had a lytle before the begynnynge of the epistle of thys daye praysed the Corinthians sayenge vnto them that they were hys epistle in Iesu Christe in asmuch as they had receyued hys gospell and had wrytten and imprinted his fayth in theyr hartes by hys administration & preachynge.
column8: FOr FOr because that saint Paule well-beloved brethren in our saviour Christe had a little before the beginning of the epistle of this day praised the Corinthians saying unto them that they were his epistle in Jesu Christe in as as they had received his gospel and had written and imprinted his faith in their hearts by his administration & preaching.

column7: Ministred by vs (sayeth he) not wrytte with ynke but by the spirite of the lyuyng God.
column8: Ministered by us (sayeth he) not writ with ink but by the spirit of the living God.

column7: Not written in tables of stone as those that Moses had, but in tables of flesh in the harte: therfore to thyntent to gyue them none occasion that they shulde waxe therwyth proude and to hope and glorie in themselues and not in God, and also for to holde them in humilitie vnder the sauegarde of God: saynt Paule sayeth: We haue truely such hope in God by Christ not that we are sufficient of our selues.
column8: Not written in tables of stone as those that Moses had, but in tables of flesh in the heart: therefore to thyntent to gyve them none occasion that they should wax therewith proud and to hope and glory in themselves and not in God, and also for to hold them in humility under the safeguard of God: saint Paule sayeth: We have truly such hope in God by Christ not that we are sufficient of our selves.

column7: &c. As yf he had sayd.
column8: etc. As if he had said.

column7: Thys yt I saye, I do not speake it arrogantly, presumynge of myne owne wyttes, but I haue such hope in God by Iesu Christ, that thys that I say, is true, and shall abyde true.
column8: This that I say, I do not speak it arrogantly, presuming of mine own wits, but I have such hope in God by Jesu Christ, that this that I say, is true, and shall abide true.

column7: I do not saye it of my selfe, as of my selfe, for we be not sufficient to thinke any thynge of our selues, as of our selues, but oure sufficientnes, and all that whyche we maye thynke, speake, and do, touchynge goodnes, cometh and dependeth from God, whych is begynnynge, myddes, and ende of all goodnes.
column8: I do not say it of my self, as of my self, for we be not sufficient to think any thing of our selves, as of our selves, but our sufficientnes, and all that which we may think, speak, and do, touching goodness, comes and dependeth from God, which is beginning, mids, and end of all goodness.

column7: The whych hath made vs and gyuen vs power to be ministers and preachers of the new testament, of the new and good promises whych are by Iesu Christ.
column8: The which hath made us and given us power to be ministers and preachers of the new testament, of the new and good promises which are by Jesu Christ.

column7: He hath gyuen vs authoritie and commission to be a preacher, not of the letter, but of the spirite, for the letter sayeth saint Paul sleeth the soule, and the spirite doth quycken it.
column8: He hath given us authority and commission to be a preacher, not of the letter, but of the spirit, for the letter sayeth saint Paul sleeth the soul, and the spirit does quicken it.

column7: We ought here to note well the difference that there is to preache the letter and the spirite.
column8: We ought here to note well the difference that there is to preach the letter and the spirit.

column7: For vnto ye tyme that the lyuely worde of God be by feruet fayth rooted in our hartes, vnto the tyme I say that we serue God nomore wyth euell wyll, but ioyfully and frely what studye or lections soeuer we take, yea yf we knewe the olde and new testament by rote of harte: yet folowe we the letter.
column8: For unto the time that the lively word of God be by fervet faith rooted in our hearts, unto the time I say that we serve God nomore with evil will, but joyfully and freely what study or lections soever we take, yea if we knew the old and new testament by rote of heart: yet follow we the letter.

column7: But the spirite of God, the spirite of scripture, the spirite of the which S. Paul speaketh of here, is out of feare, it serueth in lybertie For where the spirite of the Lorde is, there is lybertie & fredome.
column8: But the spirit of God, the spirit of scripture, the spirit of the which S. Paul speaks of here, is out of fear, it serveth in liberty For where the spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty & freedom's.

column7: Saynt Paule now after that he bare the lyght of God I meane the worde of Iesu Christ beynge desyrous and wyllynge, not to hyde it vnder a bushell, but exaltynge it and settynge it vp to be bruted and praysed of angels and of men: commeth to compare the eternall gospell vnto the transitorye lawe of Moses.
column8: Saint Paule now after that he bore the light of God I mean the word of Jesu Christ being desirous and willing, not to hide it under a bushel, but exalting it and setting it up to be bruited and praised of angels and of men: comes to compare the eternal gospel unto the transitory law of Moses.

column7: He calleth the lawe of Moses the executynge or administracion of death & damnation.
column8: He calls the law of Moses the executing or administration of death & damnation.

column7: P A G Ecxxxvij Not but that the law is good and holy, yf it be vsed lawfully: but forbycause the Iues haue abused it to theyr damnation.
column8: PAGEcxxxvij PAGEcxxxvij PAGEcxxxvij PAGEcxxxvij Not but that the law is good and holy, if it be used lawfully: but forbycause the Iues have abused it to their damnation.

column7: And for the same cause, by occasion, it is called administration of death.
column8: And for the same cause, by occasion, it is called administration of death.

column7: He sayeth than, yf the administration of death, that is to saye, yf the auncient lawe was delyuered and gyuen in lyght in puissaunce and in glorye: what shall ye lawe of the gospell be whych is the administration of the spirite, of lyfe, and of iustice, But forasmuche as dyuerse heretikes and vnlearned persones haue mysvnderstanded thys wrytynge of saint Paule in thys place: therfore I thynke it not amysse brefly to make a faythfull reapport vnto you of S. Austines wordes concernynge the interpretacion of thys place.
column8: He sayeth than, if the administration of death, that is to say, if the ancient law was delivered and given in light in puissance and in glory: what shall you law of the gospel be which is the administration of the spirit, of life, and of justice, But forasmuch as diverse heretics and unlearned persons have mysvnderstanded this writing of saint Paule in this place: therefore I think it not amiss briefly to make a faithful reapport unto you of S. Austines words concerning the interpretation of this place.

column7: Thus he wryteth in hys seconde boke agaynst the aduersary of the lawe and prophetes.
column8: Thus he writes in his seconde book against the adversary of the law and prophets.

column7: The lawe albeit it be holy, iust, and good, <NOTE> yet it bryngeth death to the transgressours and breakers therof, whome the grace of God helpeth not to fulfyl the iustice of the lawe.
column8: The law albeit it be holy, just, and good, yet it bringeth death to the transgressors and breakers thereof, whom the grace of God helpeth not to fulfil the justice of the law.

column7: For it behoued, that in the olde testament a lawe shuld be layde vpon the proude and stubborne Iues and on such as trusted vpon the power of theyr owne wyll, whych lawe shuld not gyue them ryghtuousnes, but shulde commaunde vnto them ryghtuousnes, and so beynge wrapped and in tangled wyth the death for transgression, that they myght fle to grace, which grace not only comaudeth but also helpeth, thys grace in the new testament is reuelate and opened vnto vs. And of thys occasion do these blasphemours of gods worde thynke, that the lawe was nought whych was gyuen by Moses, bycause it is called the ministration of death fygured in stony letters.
column8: For it behooved, that in the old testament a law should be laid upon the proud and stubborn Iues and on such as trusted upon the power of their own will, which law should not gyve them righteousness, but should command unto them righteousness, and so being wrapped and in tangled with the death for transgression, that they might fle to grace, which grace not only comaudeth but also helpeth, this grace in the new testament is reuelate and opened unto us And of this occasion do these blasphemous of gods word think, that the law was nought which was given by Moses, because it is called the ministration of death figured in stony letters.

column7: They consyder not that it was so called bycause of them whyche thoughte by theyr owne fre wyll to satisfye the lawe & not holpen with the spirite of grace were holden gyltye of transgression vnder the letter of the same lawe.
column8: They consider not that it was so called because of them which thought by their own from will to satisfy the law & not helped with the spirit of grace were held guilty of transgression under the letter of the same law.

column7: For assuredly the transgression or breakinge of the lawe shuld not be euell: onles the law it selfe were good.
column8: For assuredly the transgression or breaking of the law should not be evil: unless the law it self were good.

column7: What maruayle is it than, yf it be called the ministracion of death, where the letter kylleth in prohibitynge euell whych is done, and in commaundynge good whych is not done, and on the contrary syde that the other is called the ministracion of the spirite whych quyckeneth, that we mought ryse from the death of preuarication and rede, not gyltie, in tables ryghtuousnes, <NOTE> beynge fre, might haue it in our hartes and maners, that is to saye, the newe testament, differrynge from the olde, in asmuch as in the one, the old man is hedged in wyth the straytes of feare, but in the other the new man walketh at large in the wydenes of charitie.
column8: What marvel is it than, if it be called the ministration of death, where the letter killeth in prohibiting evil which is done, and in commanding good which is not done, and on the contrary side that the other is called the ministration of the spirit which quickeneth, that we might rise from the death of prevarication and rede, not guilty, in tables righteousness, being from, might have it in our hearts and manners, that is to say, the new testament, differrynge from the old, in as as in the one, the old man is hedged in with the straits of fear, but in the other the new man walks at large in the wydenes of charity.

column7: For the prohibicion of sinne, bycause it is a lawe, vndoubtedly increaseth the desyre of sinnynge, whych is not quenched but by the cotrary desyre of doynge well, where fayth worketh by loue.
column8: For the prohibition of sin, because it is a law, undoubtedly increases the desire of sinning, which is not quenched but by the contrary desire of doing well, where faith works by love.

column7: Hythervnto I haue reported the wordes of S. Austine, whych doth full well expounde and declare vnto vs the sentence & meanynge of the Apostle Paule in thys epistle, whose only mynde and purpose is to prouoke vs to loue, esteme; and folowe the holy and syncere gospell, by the whych the holy goost is gyue vnto vs, and by ye whych we be newly borne agayne and lyuynge in spirite or goost and no more after a fleshly sorte.
column8: Hythervnto I have reported the words of S. Austine, which does full well expound and declare unto us the sentence & meaning of the Apostle Paule in this epistle, whose only mind and purpose is to provoke us to love, esteem; and follow the holy and sincere gospel, by the which the holy ghost is gyve unto us, and by you which we be newly born again and living in spirit or ghost and no more after a fleshly sort.

column7: God gyue vs the grace that it maye be P A G Ecxxxviii shedde ouer all the worlde, as the foure floddes of paradyse, as a see flowynge, as floddes rysynge in lyfe eternal, that euery body may drinke plentefully of eternall lyfe, to thys ende & purpose that we may altogether prayse and glorifye God euerlastyngly, by our Lorde Iesu Christ.
column8: God gyve us the grace that it may be PAGEcxxxviii PAGEcxxxviii PAGEcxxxviii PAGEcxxxviii shed over all the world, as the foure floddes of paradise, as a see flowing, as floddes rising in life eternal, that every body may drink plentefully of eternal life, to this end & purpose that we may altogether praise and glorify God everlastingly, by our Lord Jesu Christ.

column7: To whome be al honour, Amen.
column8: To whom be all honour, Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospel on the.xij. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the xij sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.vij. Chapter of Marke.
column8: The vij Chapter of Mark.

column7: Thargument The healynge of the deafe and dombe man.
column8: Thargument The healing of the deaf and dumb man.

column7: I Esus departed agayne from the coastes of Tyre and Sidon, and came vnto the see of Galile thorowe the myddes of the coastes of the ten cyties.
column8: IEsus IEsus departed again from the coasts of Tyre and Sidon, and came unto the see of Galilee thorough the mids of the coasts of the ten cities.

column7: And they brought vnto hym one that was deaffe and hadde an impedimente in hys speche, and they prayed hym to put hys hande vpon hym.
column8: And they brought unto him one that was deaf and had and impediment in his speech, and they prayed him to put his hand upon him.

column7: And wha he had taken him asyde from the people, he put his fyngers into hys eares, and dyd spyt, and touched his tonge, and loked vp to heauen, and syghed, and sayd vnto hym: Ephata, that is to saye, be opened.
column8: And wha he had taken him aside from the people, he put his fingers into his ears, and did spit, and touched his tongue, and looked up to heaven, and sighed, and said unto him: Ephata, that is to say, be opened.

column7: And strayght waye hys eares were opened, and the strynge of hys tonge was loused, and spake plaine.
column8: And straight way his ears were opened, and the string of his tongue was loused, and spoke plain.

column7: And he commaunded them that they shulde tell no man.
column8: And he commanded them that they should tell no man.

column7: But the more he forbad them, so muche the more a great deale they published, sayeng: he hath done all thynges wel, he hath made both the deafe to heare, and the dombe to speake.
column8: But the more he forbade them, so much the more a great deal they published, saying: he hath done all things well, he hath made both the deaf to hear, and the dumb to speak.

column7: T He Gospell redde in the church thys day good christen people teacheth vs, that after that our sauiour Christ had priuely stolen away out of Iewry and had amonges the Tyrians, Sidonians, and Cananites secretlye sowen there the sede of his holy worde, he reflected hys iourney, and came agayne to the lake of Galilee, takynge in hys waye the region of Decapoly, where before that tyme he had healed a man possessed of a deuell.
column8: THe THe Gospel red in the church this day good christian people teaches us, that after that our saviour Christ had privily stolen away out of Jewry and had among the Tyrians, Sidonians, and Cananites secretly sown there the seed of his holy word, he reflected his journey, and came again to the lake of Galilee, taking in his way the region of Decapoly, where before that time he had healed a man possessed of a devil.

column7: Whan he was come hyther, they brought vnto hym a ryght myserable spectacle, that is to saye, a man both deafe and dombe.
column8: When he was come hither, they brought unto him a right miserable spectacle, that is to say, a man both deaf and dumb.

column7: For he muste nedes be dombe, whyche is of nature deafe. <NOTE> he is more myserably deafe, whych hath no mete eares to heare gods word, he is worse dobe, whych hath no tonge to confesse hys fylthynes and gods mercy.
column8: For he must needs be dumb, which is of nature deaf. he is more miserably deaf, which hath no meet ears to hear gods word, he is worse dobe, which hath no tongue to confess his filthiness and gods mercy.

column7: By hearynge of the fayth, is the begynnynge of health and saluation, and by confession of the mouth is the perfection of helth.
column8: By hearing of the faith, is the beginning of health and salvation, and by confession of the mouth is the perfection of health.

column7: The Iues, albeit they dayly herde Iesus speakyng, yet hearynge they herde not, for asmuch as accordynge to thexemple of the serpent called the Aspik whyche stoppeth her eares agaynst the voyce of the wyse inchaunter, <NOTE> they wolde not beleue such thynges as they herde, And therfore they had a tonge to backbyte and detracte, but they had no toge to the holsome professio of faith.
column8: The Iues, albeit they daily herd Jesus speaking, yet hearing they herd not, for as as according to thexemple of the serpent called the Aspik which stoppeth her ears against the voice of the wise inchaunter, they would not believe such things as they herd, And therefore they had a tongue to backbyte and detract, but they had no toga to the wholesome professio of faith.

column7: But what shal this sely poore ma do, which hath no tonge wherewyth he maye craue hys soule helth of the Lorde, whych hath no eares wherby he maye perceyue the voyce of Iesus whych is wonte to rayse euen the deade to lyfe?
column8: But what shall this sely poor ma do, which hath no tongue wherewith he may crave his soul health of the Lord, which hath no ears whereby he may perceive the voice of Jesus which is wont to raise even the dead to life?

column7: They that had tonges and eares do helpe the sely ma, they brynge him to Iesus.
column8: They that had tongues and ears do help the sely ma, they bring him to Jesus.

column7: They besech hym of hys teder mercy, that he woll vouchsaue to laye hys hande vpon hym.
column8: They beseech him of his teder mercy, that he will vouchsaue to say his hand upon him.

column7: Thus it pleaseth the moost mercyfull Lorde, that P A G Ecxxxix euen other mens fayth shuld helpe synners. <NOTE> In lykewyse the hethen person whych is about to leaue his hethen lyfe & to become christianed in which state he is called of ye aucient fathers of ye church catechumenus is brought to Iesus, he hath stynted to do euel, he hath stinted to speake euel, but he hath not yet lerned to do wel, he hath not yet lerned to cofesse ye goodnes of ye gospel.
column8: Thus it pleases the most merciful Lord, that PAGEcxxxix PAGEcxxxix PAGEcxxxix PAGEcxxxix even other men's faith should help sinners. In likewise the heathen person which is about to leave his heathen life & to become christianed in which state he is called of you ancient father's of the church catechumenus is brought to Jesus, he hath stinted to do evil, he hath stinted to speak evil, but he hath not yet learned to do well, he hath not yet learned to cofesse you goodness of the gospel.

column7: For how ca he do thys, yf Iesus lay not hys hade vpo hym?
column8: For how ca he do this, if Jesus lay not his hade upon him?

column7: Me labour in vayne, onles the secrete power and vertue of Christ be put therto It was an easy thynge for the Lorde, euen wyth the bare worde of hys mouth, to gyue helth to the deafe and dombe man, but thys forme of thynges is purposed and set forth vnto vs. For lyke as for ye moost parte, it is a parable, that Christ speaketh: so oftentymes it is a parable, yt he doth.
column8: Me labour in vain, unless the secret power and virtue of Christ be put thereto It was and easy thing for the Lord, even with the bore word of his mouth, to gyve health to the deaf and dumb man, but this form of things is purposed and set forth unto us For like as for you most part, it is a parable, that Christ speaks: so oftentimes it is a parable, that he does.

column7: He toke the man by the hade, & led hym asyde fro ye multitude of people.
column8: He took the man by the hade, & led him aside from you multitude of people.

column7: He is saufe, whom Iesus taketh vp, who he leadeth away fro ye hurley burly of thys worlde.
column8: He is saufe, whom Jesus takes up, who he leads away from you hurley burly of this world.

column7: He put hys fyngers into hys eares, and wyth hys spyttell, touched hys tonge.
column8: He put his fingers into his ears, and with his spyttell, touched his tongue.
