column7: Assuredly, my frendes, <NOTE> and saluacion is then at hande, whan our sauioure Christe Iesus, by the vertue of hys spirite, <NOTE> whych is the fynger of God, vouchsaueth to touch the eares of oure mynde, and as often as wyth the spyttell of the heauenly wysedome, whych is hymselfe, commynge out from ye mouth of the father aboue, he vouchsaueth to touche the tonge of oure mynde, to thintent that those thynges myght sauour vnto vs, which beloge to God and be godly.
column8: Assuredly, my friends, and salvation is then at hand, when our saviour Christe Jesus, by the virtue of his spirit, which is the finger of God, vouchsaueth to touch the ears of our mind, and as often as with the spyttell of the heavenly wisdom, which is himself, coming out from you mouth of the father above, he vouchsaueth to touch the tongue of our mind, to intent that those things might savour unto us, which beloge to God and be godly.

column7: For wythout thys humour is made no taste, & mans spyttell, yf it be infected, hath a peruerse iudgement.
column8: For without this humour is made no taste, & men spyttell, if it be infected, hath a perverse judgement.

column7: Thys spettell not onely louseth the tonge, but also openeth the eyen of him, that is borne blynde, as often as, beynge myxed wt earth it be layde vpon the eyes, wheras on the contraryesyde, <NOTE> spettel of philosophers and of pharisees, do rather put out the eyes.
column8: This spettell not only louseth the tongue, but also openeth the eyes of him, that is born blind, as often as, being mixed with earth it be laid upon the eyes, whereas on the contraryesyde, spettel of philosophers and of pharisees, do rather put out the eyes.

column7: The same thynge in maner do also the teachers of the gospell.
column8: The same thing in manner do also the teachers of the gospel.

column7: They take men and leade them awaye from the multitude, wha out of the broade way, wherin the moost parte of people do walke into theyr owne damnacion, they cal them backe and brynge them agayne to the felowship of the lytle flocke.
column8: They take men and lead them away from the multitude, wha out of the broad way, wherein the most part of people do walk into their own damnation, they call them back and bring them again to the fellowship of the little flock.

column7: They put theyr fyngers into theyr eares, whan by callynge them awaye from the vanities of thys worlde, they sturre them to receyue the heauenly doctrine.
column8: They put their fingers into their ears, when by calling them away from the vanities of this world, they stir them to receive the heavenly doctrine.

column7: They laye spettell vpon theyr toges, whan they exhorte them to professe the euangelicall fayth, they laye theyr handes vpon them, wha they gyue the holy goost to such as be baptised, by whome theyr synnes be wyped awaye, and innocencie is conferred.
column8: They say spettell upon their toges, when they exhort them to profess the evangelical faith, they say their hands upon them, wha they gyve the holy ghost to such as be baptised, by whom their sins be wiped away, and innocence is conferred.

column7: But all these thynges the curate or byshop doth outwardlye in vayne, yf Christe worke not wythin and sende out hys godly vertue fro heauen.
column8: But all these things the curate or bishop does outwardly in vain, if Christe work not within and send out his godly virtue from heaven.

column7: Of thys thynge Christe Iesus, wyllynge to declare vnto vs as it were a certayne ymage or token, after he had taken the man vnto hym, after he had put hys fyngers into hys eares and had spetted on hys tonge: he lyfted vp hys eyen to heuen & syghed.
column8: Of this thing Christe Jesus, willing to declare unto us as it were a certain image or token, after he had taken the man unto him, after he had put his fingers into his ears and had spitted on his tongue: he lifted up his eyes to heaven & sighed.

column7: Thys syghynge was no mystrustynge, <NOTE> but a bewaylynge of mans mysery & calamitie.
column8: This sighing was not mistrusting, but a bewailing of men misery & calamity.

column7: For what thinge can be more myserable, than they, whych haue ye eares of theyr mynde so encombred and occupied with earthly lustes, that they can not heare the worde of God? and whych haue theyr tonge so entangled and P A G Ecxl infected wyth vicious affectios, that they sauer not of heauenly thynges, that they be dombe to confesse theyr naughtynes, dombe to auaunce gods mercye?
column8: For what thing can be more miserable, than they, which have you ears of their mind so encumbered and occupied with earthly lusts, that they can not hear the word of God? and which have their tongue so entangled and PAGEcxl PAGEcxl PAGEcxl PAGEcxl infected with vicious affectios, that they savour not of heavenly things, that they be dumb to confess their naughtynes, dumb to advance gods mercy?

column7: Wherfore the syghynge of Iesus admonysheth vs what we were, <NOTE> hys lokynge vp to heauen plucketh awaye desperation, declarynge from whence helpe commeth vnto vs, & also whome we be boude to thanke, that wheras before we had our eares ope to detraction, backbytynge, to rybaudrye and foule wordes; to foolysh fables, to pharisaicall doctrine, to vayne philosophie, to the suggestios of the deuel: we haue them now open to receyue the heuenly doctrine of the gospell, and wheras before we had oure toge so infected wyth the spettel of flesh, that ye delicate foode of the gospel was loothed of vs, so boude wyth the bondes of Sathan, that we could neyther confesse our owne sinnes, nor yet auaunce the glorie of god: we now confesse, that of oure owne merytes we deserue nothynge but hell, and that it commeth holly of gods goodnes, that we be chosen to the name and inheritaunce of the chyldren of god.
column8: Wherefore the sighing of Jesus admonisheth us what we were, his looking up to heaven plucketh away desperation, declaring from whence help comes unto us, & also whom we be boude to thank, that whereas before we had our ears open to detraction, backbiting, to rybaudrye and foul words; to foolish fables, to pharisaical doctrine, to vain philosophy, to the suggestios of the devil: we have them now open to receive the heavenly doctrine of the gospel, and whereas before we had our toga so infected with the spettel of flesh, that you delicate food of the gospel was loothed of us, so boude with the bonds of Sathan, that we could neither confess our own sins, nor yet advance the glory of god: we now confess, that of our own merits we deserve nothing but hell, and that it comes holly of gods goodness, that we be chosen to the name and inheritance of the children of god.

column7: Wherfore in lyke wyse doth euery good curate and preste bewayle rather then rage vpon mens synnes, he is rather sory than angrye, neyther doth he arrogantly calenge to hymselfe the power of assoylynge, but he loketh vp to heauen, confessyng and testifyenge, that all that euer is done through the rytes of holy sacramentes, is done by gods vertue, and not mans power.
column8: Wherefore in like wise does every good curate and pressed bewail rather then rage upon men's sins, he is rather sorry than angry, neither does he arrogantly calenge to himself the power of assoiling, but he looketh up to heaven, confessing and testifyenge, that all that ever is done through the rites of holy sacraments, is done by gods virtue, and not men power.

column7: It foloweth in the texte, that Iesus sayd vnto hym: Ephata, that is to say, be opened. And forthwyth the vertue folowed ye worde.
column8: It followeth in the text, that Jesus said unto him: Ephata, that is to say, be opened. And forthwith the virtue followed you word.

column7: For strayght hys eares were opened, and the strynge of his tonge loused, and he spake distinctly.
column8: For straight his ears were opened, and the string of his tongue loused, and he spoke distinctly.

column7: They had open cares, whych when the Lorde sayd vnto them: Come after me, <NOTE> left all, and folowed hym.
column8: They had open cares, which when the Lord said unto them: Come after me, left all, and followed him.

column7: They had an vntangled and louse tonge, which after they had receyued the holy goost, spake wyth sondrye tonges the wonders of God, and whych answered ye ruler that charged them no more to preach ye name of Iesu, in thys wyse. <NOTE> Whyther it be ryght in the syght of God to obeye you rather then God, iudge you.
column8: They had and untangled and louse tongue, which after they had received the holy ghost, spoke with sundry tongues the wonders of God, and which answered you ruler that charged them no more to preach you name of Jesu, in this wise. Whither it be right in the sight of God to obey you rather then God, judge you.

column7: Nowe these thynges that Christe dyd, were done asyde from the multitude.
column8: Now these things that Christe did, were done aside from the multitude.

column7: For he thought it not best to make the rude multitude a wytnes of the euangelicall begynnynges, lest they shulde mocke the thynge that as yet they knew not.
column8: For he thought it not best to make the rude multitude a witness of the evangelical beginnings, lest they should mock the thing that as yet they knew not.

column7: Iesus therfore comaunded them that they shuld tell noma herof, not bycause he wold not that the thynge were knowe that was done, but bycause the thynge selfe speaketh better the heauely vertue, than doth the brute and reapporte of men.
column8: Jesus therefore commanded them that they should tell noma hereof, not because he would not that the thing were know that was done, but because the thing self speaks better the heavily virtue, than does the brutus and reapporte of men.

column7: They knewe all well ynough the deafe and dombe man.
column8: They knew all well enough the deaf and dumb man.

column7: Now he herde and spake plainly, so he not disclosynge the thynge yet bruted ye benefyte of Christ.
column8: Now he herd and spoke plainly, so he not disclosing the thing yet bruited you benefit of Christ.

column7: Furthermore Iesus bare here the ymage of man, <NOTE> thintent he wolde instructe men what they ought to do. <NOTE> What soeuer excellent thynge a ma doth, let him couet to haue hys dede vnknowen, that the glorie of man myght be huyshed, and the glorie of God preached.
column8: Furthermore Jesus bore here the image of man, intent he would instruct men what they ought to do. What soever excellent thing a ma does, let him covet to have his deed unknown, that the glory of man might be huyshed, and the glory of God preached.

column7: Man is ieopardously praysed, but the power & goodnes of God is worthely auaunced.
column8: Man is jeopardously praised, but the power & goodness of God is worthily advanced.

column7: Albeit neyther is mans glorye huyshed (yf yet he hath any glorie) but oftetymes ye more it is eschued, the more it foloweth.
column8: Albeit neither is men glory huyshed (if yet he hath any glory) but oftetymes you more it is eschewed, the more it followeth.

column7: Yet neuerthelesse a christe teacher ought to be thus affected, that as much as in hym lyeth, he couette P A G Ecxli to be knowen d^ly of God.
column8: Yet nevertheless a christe teacher ought to be thus affected, that as much as in him lies, he covet PAGEcxli PAGEcxli PAGEcxli PAGEcxli to be known d^ly of God.

column7: And herin he is the worthyer to be praysed amonges all men.
column8: And herin he is the worthier to be praised among all men.

column7: For who soeuer seketh for glorie amonges men, is euen for that cause vnworthy therof.
column8: For who soever seeketh for glory among men, is even for that cause unworthy thereof.

column7: Wherfore that Iesus forbad them whych brought ye do^be man, that they shulde tell no bodye what was done, the selfe same thynge prouoked them the more, to bl^se it abrode, and so much the more also they magnifyed & auaunced Christ which wheras he had so great vertue and power, & dyd them therwyth such pleasure not onely requyred no rewarde of them for the same, but also wolde not ones inioye the glorie of so noble a farre.
column8: Wherefore that Jesus forbade them which brought you do^be man, that they should tell no body what was done, the self same thing provoked them the more, to bl^se it abroad, and so much the more also they magnified & advanced Christ which whereas he had so great virtue and power, & did them therewith such pleasure not only required no reward of them for the same, but also would not ones enjoy the glory of so noble a far.

column7: But as it is the parte of a weldoer not to requyre prayse for hys benefyte: so agayne it is the office of a kynde man so much the more to gyue thankes, in that that he whych dyd ye benefyte loke for no thake.
column8: But as it is the part of a weldoer not to require praise for his benefit: so again it is the office of a kind man so much the more to gyve thanks, in that that he which did you benefit look for no thake.

column7: Wherfore they neuer ceased to blase abrod the name of Iesus in euery place where so euer they came, sayenge: He hath done all thynges well.
column8: Wherefore they never ceased to blaze abroad the name of Jesus in every place where so ever they came, saying: He hath done all things well.

column7: He hath restored aswell hearynge to the deaffe, as tonge to the dombe.
column8: He hath restored aswell hearing to the deaf, as tongue to the dumb.

column7: Assuredly my frendes thys prayse agreeth only vpon God.
column8: Assuredly my friends this praise agreeth only upon God.

column7: There is no earthly, no mortal person, that doth all thynges well.
column8: There is no earthly, no mortal person, that does all things well.

column7: All Christes myracles no doubt were oure benefytes, which myracles, yf ye waye and expende them after the outward face of corporall thynges: in dede there were many myracles whych he dyd that were of much more excellecy and worthynes than thys yt of a deafe man he made an hearer, of a dombe a speaker. <NOTE> accordynge to the spirituall sense, the summe of all a christian mas felicitie standeth in thys poynt, that wyth hys eares he mought heare the worde of the gospell, & speake that he hath lerned and beleued.
column8: All Christes miracles no doubt were our benefits, which miracles, if you way and expend them after the outward face of corporal things: in deed there were many miracles which he did that were of much more excellency and worthiness than this that of a deaf man he made and hearer, of a dumb a speaker. according to the spiritual sense, the sum of all a christian mass felicity stands in this point, that with his ears he might hear the word of the gospel, & speak that he hath learned and believed.

column7: This thynge, good christen people yf we do, we shall surely at length in heryte the kyngdome of heauen prepared for vs. Where God the father, the sonne, & holy goost thre persons in deytie raygne eternally.
column8: This thing, good christian people if we do, we shall surely at length in heryte the kingdom of heaven prepared for us Where God the father, the son, & holy ghost thre persons in deity reign eternally.

column7: To whome be al glorie.
column8: To whom be all glory.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.xiij. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the xiij sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.iij. chapter to the Galathians.
column8: The iij chapter to the Galathians.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: The lawe saueth vs not but Christ.
column8: The law saveth us not but Christ.

column7: B Rethren, to Abraham and hys sede were the promyses made.
column8: BRethren BRethren, to Abraham and his seed were the promises made.

column7: He sayeth not in the sedes, as many: but in thy sede, as of one, whych is Christ.
column8: He sayeth not in the sedes, as many: but in thy seed, as of one, which is Christ.

column7: Thys I saye, that the lawe whych began afterward, beyond foure hundreth and thyrtye yeares, doeth not disanull the testament, that was confermed afore of God vnto Christward, to make the promes of none effect.
column8: This I say, that the law which began afterwards, beyond foure hundreth and thyrtye years, doth not disannul the testament, that was confirmed afore of God unto Christward, to make the promise of none effect.

column7: For yf the inheritaunce come of the lawe, it cometh not now of promes.
column8: For if the inheritance come of the law, it comes not now of promise.

column7: But God gaue it vnto Abraham by promes.
column8: But God gave it unto Abraham by promise.

column7: Wherfore than serueth the lawe?
column8: Wherefore than serveth the law?

column7: The lawe was added because of trasgression (tyll the sede came, to whome the promes was made) and it was ordeyned by Angels in the hande of a mediator.
column8: The law was added because of transgression (till the seed came, to whom the promise was made) and it was ordained by Angels in the hand of a mediator.

column7: A mediator is a mediator of one. But God is one.
column8: A mediator is a mediator of one. But God is one.

column7: Is the lawe than agaynst the promes of God?
column8: Is the law than against the promise of God?

column7: God forbyd.
column8: God forbid.

column7: For yf ther had ben a lawe gyuen whych coulde haue gyuen lyfe: than no doubte ryghtuousnes shulde come by the lawe But the scripture concluded all thynges vnder syn, that the promes by the fayth of Iesus Christ shuld P A G Ecxlij be gyuen vnto them that beleue.
column8: For if there had been a law given which could have given life: than no doubt righteousness should come by the law But the scripture concluded all things under sin, that the promise by the faith of Jesus Christ should PAGEcxlij PAGEcxlij PAGEcxlij PAGEcxlij be given unto them that believe.

column7: S Aynt Paul my welbeloued frendes in the epistle of thys day declareth vnto vs, that they chauge the testament & the euerlastynge wyll of God, which testament, wyll, or couenaunt god hath concluded in Christ our only iustifyer and sauiour, which seke saluation and iustification by the lawe & not by Christ I speake (sayeth saynt Paule) after mans fashion, that ye maye the better vnderstande me.
column8: SAynt SAynt Paul my well-beloved friends in the epistle of this day declareth unto us, that they chauge the testament & the everlasting will of God, which testament, will, or covenant god hath concluded in Christ our only iustifyer and saviour, which seek salvation and justification by the law & not by Christ I speak (sayeth saint Paule) after men fashion, that you may the better understand me.

column7: Though it be but the testament and last wyll of a man, yet yf it be ones authorised and allowed, noma cutteth it of, or addeth any thynge therto. <NOTE> Here saynt Ambrose noteth, that the Apostle vseth thys comparison or similitude, to thintent he wold declare that they be falsifyers of goddes testament, whych wheras they beleue in Christ, yet mengle wt Christ the law & whych hope to be partly saued by the law.
column8: Though it be but the testament and last will of a man, yet if it be ones authorised and allowed, noma cutteth it of, or adds any thing thereto. Here saint Ambrose notes, that the Apostle uses this comparison or similitude, to intent he would declare that they be falsifiers of gods testament, which whereas they believe in Christ, yet mengle with Christ the law & which hope to be partly saved by the law.

column7: For in very dede the hole cause of our saluation is Christ Iesus, and no iote of the lawe, as the Apostle saynt Paule doth in thys epistle very fully and effectually proue.
column8: For in very deed the hold cause of our salvation is Christ Jesus, and no jot of the law, as the Apostle saint Paule does in this epistle very fully and effectually prove.

column7: Yf mans testamet ought to be of such strength, that we ought nether take ought therfro, nor put ought ther to: how much rather ought gods testament & wyl to be such?
column8: If men testamet ought to be of such strength, that we ought neither take ought therfro, nor put ought there to: how much rather ought gods testament & will to be such?

column7: But in gods testamet to Abraham was the promise of eternal saluacion and iustification made and vnto hys sede. <NOTE> In thy sede (sayd god to Abraha) shall all the nations of the earth be blessed.
column8: But in gods testamet to Abraham was the promise of eternal salvation and justification made and unto his seed. In thy seed (said god to Abraha) shall all the nations of the earth be blessed.

column7: He sayth not in the sedes as many, but in thy sede, as of one, whych is Christ.
column8: He say not in the sedes as many, but in thy seed, as of one, which is Christ.

column7: Now tha seynge this wrytyng, this testamente and couenaunte maketh mencion but of one heyre in whome God promysed, that we shulde all be saued and iustifyed: then we ought to allowe none other thynge to our iustification to oure blesse and saluation but only Christ.
column8: Now tha sing this writing, this testament and covenant makes mention but of one heir in whom God promised, that we should all be saved and justified: then we ought to allow none other thing to our justification to our bless and salvation but only Christ.

column7: Secondly, S. Paule proueth by the circustauce of the tyme, that the law blessed not nor iustifyed makynde.
column8: Secondly, S. Paule proves by the circustauce of the time, that the law blessed not nor justified makynde.

column7: For the promyse or wrytyng of the testament was proued and confirmed by god in the only heyre Iesu Christ before the law was gyuen.
column8: For the promise or writing of the testament was proved and confirmed by god in the only heir Jesu Christ before the law was given.

column7: For the law was gyuen longe after, that is to saye (as Paul here wytnesseth) aboue foure hundred and thyrty yeares after.
column8: For the law was given long after, that is to say (as Paul here witnesseth) above foure hundred and thyrty years after.

column7: Wherfore yf the law were any cause of our iustification: then the people whych were before ye law was gyuen, coulde not be iustifyed, whych thynge is false, <NOTE> as ye Apostle manyfestly proueth in hys epistle to the Romaynes.
column8: Wherefore if the law were any cause of our justification: then the people which were before the law was given, could not be justified, which thing is false, as you Apostle manifestly proves in his epistle to the Romans.

column7: For Abraham was iustifyed loge before the lawe came, yea and that before he was circumcised.
column8: For Abraham was justified loge before the law came, yea and that before he was circumcised.

column7: It is therfore playne, that the euerlastyng inheritaunce can not come by the law.
column8: It is therefore plain, that the everlasting inheritance can not come by the law.

column7: For yf it were by the lawe, (as reasoneth saynt Paule) than it can not come by promyse.
column8: For if it were by the law, (as reasoneth saint Paule) than it can not come by promise.

column7: But so it is, that god gaue it vnto Abraham by promyse.
column8: But so it is, that god gave it unto Abraham by promise.

column7: Ergo the heritage of heuen and saluacion commeth by promyse and not by the lawe.
column8: Ergo the heritage of heaven and salvation comes by promise and not by the law.

column7: <NOTE> But here (sayeth he) ye wol aske me, syth the law is not the cause of saluation, but Christ is the onely gyuer of it to such as cleaue faste vnto hym by true fayth, hope, and charitie, wherfore then serueth the lawe, <NOTE> what good do it?
column8: But here (sayeth he) you will ask me, sith the law is not the cause of salvation, but Christ is the only gyuer of it to such as cleave fast unto him by true faith, hope, and charity, wherefore then serveth the law, what good do it?

column7: Surely much good my frendes.
column8: Surely much good my friends.

column7: The vse & profyte of the lawe is great, thoughe it be not cause of our iustification.
column8: The use & profit of the law is great, though it be not cause of our justification.

column7: I say the workes of the lawe saue vs not, but it is only the merytes of Christ that saueth vs, that iustifieth vs yf we stycke vnto hym by ernest & quycke fayth whych worketh P A G Ecxliij of loue and not of compulsion.
column8: I say the works of the law save us not, but it is only the merits of Christ that saveth us, that justifieth us if we stick unto him by earnest & quick faith which works PAGEcxliij PAGEcxliij PAGEcxliij PAGEcxliij of love and not of compulsion.

column7: In dede a true and ryght christon man, I meane a person that is cleane turned into a new man & whych hath so great fayth and charitie in hym, that for Christes loue, he is ready to do all thynges, such as man nede no lawe. <NOTE> For the lawe (as the Apostle also testifyeth) is not gyue vnto the ryghtuouse man but vnto the vnryghtuouse and disobedient, to the vngodly and vnto synners, to vnholy and vncleane, to murtherers of fathers and murtherers of mothers, to mansleers, to whoremongers, to beastly persons, to theues and so forth.
column8: In deed a true and right christon man, I mean a person that is clean turned into a new man & which hath so great faith and charity in him, that for Christes love, he is ready to do all things, such as man need no law. For the law (as the Apostle also testifieth) is not gyve unto the righteous man but unto the unrighteous and disobedient, to the ungodly and unto sinners, to unholy and unclean, to murderers of father's and murderers of mother's, to mansleers, to whoremongers, to beastly persons, to thieves and so forth.

column7: The lawe than is rather a restrayner from euell, than a iustifyer, it is, as it were a brydell tyll Christ come and be setled in vs whyche maye cause vs to worke euen of loue wythout copulsion of law.
column8: The law than is rather a restrayner from evil, than a iustifyer, it is, as it were a bridle till Christ come and be settled in us which may cause us to work even of love without copulsion of law.

column7: The lawe (sayth Paule) was added bycause of trasgression tyll Christ, whych was ye sede that was promysed came.
column8: The law (say Paule) was added because of transgression till Christ, which was the seed that was promised came.

column7: So the lawe is not agaynst ye promyse of God, but it standeth wyth the promyse, it is as it were our schole mayster and leader to Christe.
column8: So the law is not against you promise of God, but it stands with the promise, it is as it were our school master and leader to Christe.

column7: For (sayeth saynt Paule) yf there had ben any lawe gyuen which coulde haue gyuen vs lyfe, that is to say, whych coulde haue iustifyed and saued vs, than (no doubt) shulde ryghtuousnes haue come by the lawe.
column8: For (sayeth saint Paule) if there had been any law given which could have given us life, that is to say, which could have justified and saved us, than (not doubt) should righteousness have come by the law.

column7: But that could not be.
column8: But that could not be.

column7: And therfore the scripture cocluded al vnder synne to thende that the promyse by the fayth of Iesus Christ shuld be gyuen to al such as beleue the same.
column8: And therefore the scripture cocluded all under sin to th'end that the promise by the faith of Jesus Christ should be given to all such as believe the same.

column7: The lawe than was added not to iustifye, but to brydell vs in, to leade vs lyke a scholemayster vnto Christ.
column8: The law than was added not to justify, but to bridle us in, to lead us like a scholemayster unto Christ.

column7: And it was ordeined and gyuen (sayeth Paule) by angels (as is wytnessed also in the Actes) in the hande of a mediatoure, <NOTE> that is to saye, in the hande of Moses, whych went betwene as a spokesman betwene the angels and the people.
column8: And it was ordained and given (sayeth Paule) by angels (as is witnessed also in the Acts) in the hand of a mediator, that is to say, in the hand of Moses, which went between as a spokesman between the angels and the people.

column7: The people coulde not heare the lawe that was ordeyned and gyuen of the angels from god wythout a mediatour.
column8: The people could not hear the law that was ordained and given of the angels from god without a mediator.

column7: Wherfore nowe we haue muche more nede of the mediatour Christ whych may brynge vs the waye to God.
column8: Wherefore now we have much more need of the mediator Christ which may bring us the way to God.

column7: Here therfore good people, ye lerne in this epistle two thynges, the one is wherfore Christ serueth and the other wherfore the lawe serueth.
column8: Here therefore good people, you learn in this epistle two things, the one is wherefore Christ serveth and the other wherefore the law serveth.

column7: The lawe must be our brydell our staye our scholemayster to directe and leade vs to the true & vnfayned fayth in Christ whych fayth may make vs to worke euen of loue.
column8: The law must be our bridle our stay our scholemayster to direct and lead us to the true & unfeigned faith in Christ which faith may make us to work even of love.

column7: But Christ must be counted our only iustifyer, and the only cause of our saluacion.
column8: But Christ must be counted our only iustifyer, and the only cause of our salvation.

column7: We must do ye workes of the lawe not as compelled by law, but as prouoked by loue whych we beare fyrst to God and consequently to our neyghbour for Christes sake.
column8: We must do you works of the law not as compelled by law, but as provoked by love which we bear fyrst to God and consequently to our neighbour for Christes sake.

column7: This doynge we shall surely be iustifyed and sanctifyed persons, and shall inherite the eternall inheritaunce of God.
column8: This doing we shall surely be justified and sanctified persons, and shall inherit the eternal inheritance of God.

column7: To whome be glorye.
column8: To whom be glory.

column7: &c.: homily The Gospel on the.xiij. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: etc.: homily The Gospel on the xiij sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The x. Chapter of Luke.
column8: The x. Chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Of the lawyers question & of Christes answere.
column8: Of the lawyers question & of Christes answer.

column7: I Esus sayd to hys disciples.
column8: IEsus IEsus said to his disciples.

column7: Happye are the eyes whych se the thynges that ye se.
column8: Happy are the eyes which see the things that you see.

column7: For I tell you that many prophetes and kynges haue desyred to se those thynges whych ye se, & haue not sene the: and to heare those thynges whych ye heare, and haue not herde them.
column8: For I tell you that many prophets and kings have desired to see those things which you see, & have not seen thee: and to hear those things which you hear, and have not herd them.

column7: And beholde a certayne lawyer P A G Ecxliiij stode vp and tempted hym, sayenge: Mayster, what shall I do to inherite eternal lyfe?
column8: And behold a certain lawyer PAGEcxliiij PAGEcxliiij PAGEcxliiij PAGEcxliiij stood up and tempted him, saying: Master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?

column7: He said vnto him what is wrytten in the lawe?
column8: He said unto him what is written in the law?

column7: How redest thou?
column8: How redest thou?

column7: And he answered and sayde: Loue the Lorde thy God, wyth all thy hart, and wyth all thy soule, and wyth all thy strength, and wyth all thy mynde: and thy neyghbour as thy selfe.
column8: And he answered and said: Love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind: and thy neighbour as thy self.

column7: And he sayde vnto hym: Thou hast answered ryght.
column8: And he said unto him: Thou hast answered right.

column7: This do, and thou shalt lyue.
column8: This do, and thou shalt live.

column7: But he wyllynge to iustifye hymselfe, sayd vnto Iesus: And who is my neyghboure?
column8: But he willing to justify himself, said unto Jesus: And who is my neighbour?

column7: Iesus answered, and sayd: A certayne man descended from Ierusalem to Hierico, and fell amonge theues, which robbed hym of hys rayment and wounded hym, and departed, leauynge hym halfe deade.
column8: Jesus answered, and said: A certain man descended from Jerusalem to Hierico, and fell among thieves, which robbed him of his raiment and wounded him, and departed, leaving him half dead.

column7: And it chaunced, that there came downe a certayne prest that same waye, and whan he sawe hym, he passed by.
column8: And it chanced, that there came down a certain pressed that same way, and when he saw him, he passed by.

column7: And lykewyse a Leuite, whan he wente nye to the place, came and loked on hym, and passed by.
column8: And likewise a Leuite, when he went nigh to the place, came and looked on him, and passed by.

column7: But a certayne Samaritane, as he iorneyed, came vnto hym: and wha he sawe hym, he had compassion on hym and went to, and bounde vp hys woundes & poured in oyle and wyne & set him on his owne beast, and brought hym to a comon ynne, & made prouision for hym.
column8: But a certain Samaritane, as he journeyed, came unto him: and wha he saw him, he had compassion on him and went to, and bound up his wounds & poured in oil and wine & set him on his own beast, and brought him to a common in, & made provision for him.

column7: And on the morowe, whan he departed, he toke out two pence, and gaue them to the hoost, and sayd vnto hym.
column8: And on the morrow, when he departed, he took out two pence, and gave them to the host, and said unto him.

column7: Take cure of hym and what so euer thou spendest more, wha I come agayne I wyll recopence the.
column8: Take cure of him and what so ever thou spendest more, wha I come again I will recopence the.

column7: Whych now of these thre thynkest thou, was neyghbour vnto hym that fel amonge the theues?
column8: Which now of these thre thinkest thou, was neighbour unto him that fell among the thieves?

column7: And he said: he that shewed mercy on hym.
column8: And he said: he that showed mercy on him.

column7: Than sayde Iesus vnto hym: Go, and do thou lykewyse.
column8: Than said Jesus unto him: Go, and do thou likewise.

column7: B Lessed be the eyen whych se that you haue sene &c. Welbeloued audience these be the wordes of our Sauiour Christ spoken to hys disciples in the x. chapter of Luke whych be red in the churche thys daye.
column8: BLessed BLessed be the eyes which see that you have seen etc. Well-beloved audience these be the words of our Saviour Christ spoken to his disciples in the x. chapter of Luke which be read in the church this day.

column7: For the better vnderstandynge wherof, ye shal marke, that Christe a lytle before the speakynge of these wordes reioysyng in spirite, gaue prayses and thankes to hys father of heuen, bycause he had hyd the mysterye of the gospell from the proude Pharisees whych were counted the wyse and wyttye persones of the worlde, and had disclosed and opened it to symple and vnlerned persons, as to fysherme, publicanes, and so forth, such as were hys disciples.
column8: For the better understanding whereof, you shall mark, that Christe a little before the speaking of these words rejoicing in spirit, gave praises and thanks to his father of heaven, because he had hid the mystery of the gospel from the proud Pharisees which were counted the wise and witty persons of the world, and had disclosed and opened it to simple and unlearned persons, as to fysherme, publicans, and so forth, such as were his disciples.

column7: And speakynge these wordes, he turned hymselfe to hys disciples apart, and sayde the wordes before rehersed.
column8: And speaking these words, he turned himself to his disciples apart, and said the words before rehearsed.

column7: Blessed be the eyen that se, whych you do se.
column8: Blessed be the eyes that see, which you do see.

column7: For I tell you that many prophetes & kynges wold haue sene that you se, and sawe not, and wolde haue herde that you heare, & herde not.
column8: For I tell you that many prophets & kings would have seen that you see, and saw not, and would have herd that you hear, & herd not.

column7: I praye you what herde, what sawe these disciples that the prophetes and kynges whych were before them, herde not nor sawe not?
column8: I pray you what herd, what saw these disciples that the prophets and kings which were before them, herd not nor saw not?

column7: Truly, they sawe not, they herd not Christ as dyd thappostles.
column8: Truly, they saw not, they heard not Christ as did apostles.

column7: They busely wayted and loked for hym, they knewe such one shulde come to redeme and saue them from euerlastynge danation & death wherof they were gyltie by the synne of Adam theyr fyrst father.
column8: They busily waited and looked for him, they knew such one should come to redeem and save them from everlasting danation & death whereof they were guilty by the sin of Adam their fyrst father.

column7: But they coulde not se hym personally.
column8: But they could not see him personally.

column7: For the tyme was not yet come, that the father of heuen P A G Ecxlv had set and determined to sende hym.
column8: For the time was not yet come, that the father of heaven PAGEcxlv PAGEcxlv PAGEcxlv PAGEcxlv had set and determined to send him.

column7: And amoges other holy fathers whych loked for thys redeption, <NOTE> we reade in holy scripture of one Symeon a ryghtuouse and deuoute man, whyche had receyued an answere of the holy goost, that he shulde not se death, tyll he had sene wyth hys eyen the Christe of the Lorde, that is to saye, the Messias that shulde saue and redeme the worlde, whyche thynge came to passe.
column8: And amoges other holy father's which looked for this redeption, we read in holy scripture of one Symeon a righteous and devout man, which had received and answer of the holy ghost, that he should not see death, till he had seen with his eyes the Christe of the Lord, that is to say, the Messias that should save and redeem the world, which thing came to pass.

column7: For whan Christ our sauiour was brought to the temple on the eyght daye to be circumcised accordynge to the custome of the Iues, thys Symeon in spyred with the holy goost came into the temple and takynge the chylde in hys armes praysed God and sayd: Now thou lycencest me thy seruaunt to depart (o Lorde) accordyng to thy word in peace.
column8: For when Christ our saviour was brought to the temple on the eyght day to be circumcised according to the custom of the Iues, this Symeon in spired with the holy ghost came into the temple and taking the child in his arms praised God and said: Now thou lycencest me thy servant to depart (oh Lord) according to thy word in peace.

column7: For myne eyen haue sene thy sauynge stocke, whych thou hast prepared before the face of all people.
column8: For mine eyes have seen thy saving stock, which thou hast prepared before the face of all people.

column7: &c. We reade also of a certayne wydowe prophetisse named Anne doughter of Phanuell, <NOTE> which was also in the temple the same tyme, and praysed the Lorde in lyke wyse & spake of thys Christ vnto all those that wayted for the redemption of Israell.
column8: etc. We read also of a certain widow prophetisse nam Anne daughter of Phanuell, which was also in the temple the same time, and praised the Lord in like wise & spoke of this Christ unto all those that waited for the redemption of Israell.

column7: These I saye and suche other whyche were in Christes tyme reioysed to se yt they sawe, and to heare that they herde.
column8: These I say and such other which were in Christes time rejoiced to see that they saw, and to hear that they herd.

column7: But thys coulde not the holy prophetes and kynges whyche were before Christes commynge into thys world se, bycause ye tyme was not yet come.
column8: But this could not the holy prophets and kings which were before Christes coming into this world see, because you time was not yet come.

column7: So Christ myght very well call the disciples blessed bycause they saw thynges and also herde doctrine taught them which were not sene nor herde before.
column8: So Christ might very well call the disciples blessed because they saw things and also herd doctrine taught them which were not seen nor herd before.

column7: Now whan Christe had spoken these wordes and was come agayne to the people to teache and instructe them hys doctrine beholde, a certayne scribe which was a lawyer sterte vp to take Christ in a trippe and to tempte hym, sayenge: Mayster, what shall I do to inherite euerlastynge lyfe?
column8: Now when Christe had spoken these words and was come again to the people to teach and instruct them his doctrine behold, a certain scribe which was a lawyer start up to take Christ in a trip and to tempt him, saying: Master, what shall I do to inherit everlasting life?

column7: Christ perceyuynge wherabout he went answered and sayd to the lawyer.
column8: Christ perceiving whereabout he went answered and said to the lawyer.

column7: What is wrytten in the lawe? <NOTE> How doest thou rede there?
column8: What is written in the law? How dost thou rede there?

column7: He sayd: In the lawe thus is it wrytten.
column8: He said: In the law thus is it written.

column7: Thou shalt loue ye Lord thy God with thy hole harte, and thy hole soule, and wyth thy hole myght, and wyth all thy mynde, and thy neyghboure as thy selfe.
column8: Thou shalt love you Lord thy God with thy hold heart, and thy hold soul, and with thy hold might, and with all thy mind, and thy neighbour as thy self.

column7: Than sayd Christ vnto hym: Thou hast well answered.
column8: Than said Christ unto him: Thou hast well answered.

column7: Thys do, and thou shalt lyue.
column8: This do, and thou shalt live.

column7: As who shulde saye: Thou art a doctour a teacher and mayster in Israel.
column8: As who should say: Thou art a doctor a teacher and master in Israel.

column7: Do the thynge that thou teachest other to do, be a worker of the thynge that thou readest.
column8: Do the thing that thou teachest other to do, be a worker of the thing that thou readest.

column7: For not the hearers of the lawe be iust before God, <NOTE> but the doers of the lawe shalbe iustifyed.
column8: For not the hearers of the law be just before God, but the doers of the law shall justified.

column7: Thynke not, for al my new and strauge doctrine to your eares, <NOTE> yt I am come to destroye the law and the prophetes as many do thinke of me.
column8: Think not, for all my new and strauge doctrine to your ears, that I am come to destroy the law and the prophets as many do think of me.

column7: No no, I am not come to destroye, but to fulfyll.
column8: No no, I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.

column7: Ye scribes and pharisees comonly set lytle by gods hestes and commaundementes, all your busye studye & labour is to auaunce & set vp your owne lawes, your owne rytes and traditions.
column8: the scribes and pharisees commonly set little by gods hests and commandments, all your busy study & labour is to advance & set up your own laws, your own rites and traditions.

column7: But I tel you, and take it for a warnynge, that who so euer breaketh one of these lytle prety comaundementes of God (for so ye coute them in comparison of yours) and teacheth men to do as he doth, as comonly ye scribes and pharisees do, <NOTE> beleue me, he shall haue lest to do in heauen.
column8: But I tell you, and take it for a warning, that who so ever breaks one of these little pretty commandments of God (for so you coute them in comparison of yours) and teaches men to do as he does, as commonly you scribes and pharisees do, believe me, he shall have lest to do in heaven.

column7: But that person whych fyrst doth hymselfe, & afterwarde teacheth other men these comaundementes of God, of whych thou hast rekened vp the chefest of all and P A G Ecxlvi that whych conteyneth all the rest, doubtles, thys felowe shalbe called a great man in heuen.
column8: But that person which fyrst does himself, & afterward teaches other men these commandments of God, of which thou hast reckoned up the chiefest of all and PAGEcxlvi PAGEcxlvi PAGEcxlvi PAGEcxlvi that which containeth all the rest, doubtless, this fellow shall called a great man in heaven.

column7: Now good people, ye shall vnderstande, that the scribes & pharisees amonges the Iues in dede taught, wha they sate in Moses chaire, the lawe of God and hys commaundementes, but they added many gloses, interpretacions, and additions of theyr owne heades.
column8: Now good people, you shall understand, that the scribes & pharisees among the Iues in deed taught, wha they sat in Moses chair, the law of God and his commandments, but they added many gloss, interpretations, and additions of their own heads.

column7: They corrupted gods worde wyth theyr owne traditions, as tauerners be wont to brewe and corrupt the pure wyne wyth other vnholsome thynges for theyr owne gaynes and auauntage.
column8: They corrupted gods word with their own traditions, as taverners be wont to brew and corrupt the pure wine with other unwholesome things for their own gains and advantage.

column7: And therfore whan oure sauiour Christe came amonges them he went aboute to restore all agayne to the ryght sence and purenes, and to seuer and wede out the fansyes dreames and leuen of the pharisees wherwyth they had ensoured and corrupted ye swete breade of lyfe, and he openly tolde the people, that onles theyr perfection, theyr goodnes and rightuousnes passed the ryghtuousnes and good lyuynge of the scribes and pharisees, they shulde neuer come to the kyngdome of heauen.
column8: And therefore when our saviour Christe came among them he went about to restore all again to the right sense and pureness, and to sever and weed out the fansyes dreams and leuen of the pharisees wherewith they had ensoured and corrupted you sweet bread of life, and he openly told the people, that unless their perfection, their goodness and righteousness passed the righteousness and good living of the scribes and pharisees, they should never come to the kingdom of heaven.

column7: Whervpon he went on, and taught the commaundementes of God and the pure and ryght vnderstandynge of them as in hys moost excellente and swete sermon whyche he made to hys disciples on the mountayne, whych the holy Euangelist saint Matthew setteth forth vnto vs in the. v.vi. and.vij. chapters, more at large doth appeare. <NOTE> A good tree (sayth Christ) bringeth forth good frute.
column8: Whereupon he went on, and taught the commandments of God and the pure and right understanding of them as in his most excellent and sweet sermon which he made to his disciples on the mountain, which the holy Euangelist saint Matthew sets forth unto us in thee. v.vi. and vij chapters, more at large does appear. A good tree (say Christ) brings forth good fruit.

column7: For not euery one, that sayth vnto me, Lorde Lord, shal entre in to the kyngdome of heauen, but he that doth ye wyll of my father whych is in heauen.
column8: For not every one, that say unto me, Lord Lord, shall enter in to the kingdom of heaven, but he that does the will of my father which is in heaven.

column7: Thou readest in ye lawe.
column8: Thou readest in the law.

column7: Thou shalt loue thy Lorde God wyth all thy harte, wyth al thy soule, wyth al thy power & minde.
column8: Thou shalt love thy Lord God with all thy heart, with all thy soul, with all thy power & mind.

column7: Do thys sayeth Christ, and thou shalte lyue eternally in heauen.
column8: Do this sayeth Christ, and thou shalt live eternally in heaven.

column7: Thou mayest not speake of God wyth thy mouth or praye vnto hym wyth thy lyppes, and thy harte be farre from God.
column8: Thou mayest not speak of God with thy mouth or pray unto him with thy lips, and thy heart be far from God.

column7: Naye, thou must loue hym wyth thy hole harte, mynde and power, and not fayntly.
column8: Nay, thou must love him with thy hold heart, mind and power, and not faintly.

column7: And thou must loue thy neyghboure as thy selfe.
column8: And thou must love thy neighbour as thy self.

column7: Who soeuer doth thys, shall lyue.
column8: Who soever does this, shall live.

column7: And who soeuer hath not done thys, let hym repent and become a newe ma.
column8: And who soever hath not done this, let him repent and become a new ma.

column7: Let hym aske grace of God that he may be able through hys ayde and helpe to do it.
column8: Let him ask grace of God that he may be able through his aid and help to do it.

column7: He that seketh shall fynde, he that asketh shall obtayne, to hym that knocketh, it shalbe opened.
column8: He that seeketh shall find, he that asks shall obtain, to him that knocketh, it shall opened.

column7: There is nothynge impossible to God.
column8: There is nothing impossible to God.

column7: So longe as we be carnall and vnrenewed by the spirite it is not possible for vs to loue God wyth harte.
column8: So long as we be carnal and unrenewed by the spirit it is not possible for us to love God with heart.

column7: We maye wel drede hym as a Lorde & punysher of synne, but loue hym as a father we can not.
column8: We may well dread him as a Lord & punisher of sin, but love him as a father we can not.

column7: We maye well lyke seruauntes feare hym, but reuerently loue hym lyke sonnes and doughters, we canot.
column8: We may well like servants fear him, but reverently love him like sons and daughters, we canot.

column7: It is not possible (I say) for a carnall man to fulfyll the lawe whych is spirituall. <NOTE> The lawe (as ye haue herde) requyreth ye hart.
column8: It is not possible (I say) for a carnal man to fulfil the law which is spiritual. The law (as you have herd) requireth you heart.

column7: We must loue God wyth harte, and not drede hym for feare of punyshment, as bondmen and bondwomen do theyr lorde.
column8: We must love God with heart, and not dread him for fear of punishment, as bondmen and bondwomen do their lord.

column7: Yf we woll consyder what God hath done for vs, fyrst he made vs of nought, he prouydeth for vs all thynges necessarie to oure soules helth, he hath made our soules not as be the soules of beastes wythout reason and whych peryshe & dye wyth ye body, but reasonable, but immortall, he sente also hys owne sonne from heauen to redeme mankinde from the tyranny and thraldome of the deuel, P A G Ecxlvij and to teach them how to lyue a godly and an innocent lyfe.
column8: If we will consider what God hath done for us, fyrst he made us of nought, he prouydeth for us all things necessary to our souls health, he hath made our souls not as be the souls of beasts without reason and which perish & die with you body, but reasonable, but immortal, he sent also his own son from heaven to redeem mankind from the tyranny and thraldom of the devil, PAGEcxlvij PAGEcxlvij PAGEcxlvij PAGEcxlvij and to teach them how to live a godly and and innocent life.

column7: Yf I saye we woll consyder all thys, howe can we but loue god euen wyth harte & do his swete wyll and pleasure, onles we be harder then the Adamant stones, onles we be made of suche a churlyshe nature that nothynge can moue vs. But the pharisees for moost parte were carnal and fleshly persons They obserued the letter of the lawe, they kepte the outwarde wordes, they dyd no lechery outwardlye, they comytted no thefte, no murther, no periury nor suche other vyces outwardlye, they dyd sacrifice to God, they offered vnto him, they sensed, they pyped, they played, they prayed after theyr fashio, but none of all thys was done wyth the harte.
column8: If I say we will consider all this, how can we but love god even with heart & do his sweet will and pleasure, unless we be harder then the Adamant stones, unless we be made of such a churlish nature that nothing can move us But the pharisees for most part were carnal and fleshly persons They observed the letter of the law, they kept the outward words, they did no lechery outwardly, they comytted no theft, no murder, no perjury nor such other vices outwardly, they did sacrifice to God, they offered unto him, they sensed, they piped, they played, they prayed after their fashio, but none of all this was done with the heart.

column7: For inwardly they were full of all abhominacion, as Christe hymselfe wytnessed vnto them.
column8: For inwardly they were full of all abomination, as Christe himself witnessed unto them.

column7: For they dyd it onely for feare of punyshmet and not for any harty loue that they had to God.
column8: For they did it only for fear of punyshmet and not for any hearty love that they had to God.

column7: They fulfylled the letter of ye lawe outwardly.
column8: They fulfilled the letter of the law outwardly.

column7: But theyr minde, theyr spirite, theyr hart was vpo other thynges, that is to wyt, vpo worldly vanities and pleasures.
column8: But their mind, their spirit, their heart was upon other things, that is to wit, upon worldly vanities and pleasures.

column7: So they coulde not fulfyll the lawe so longe as they were in that case.
column8: So they could not fulfil the law so long as they were in that case.

column7: For as Paule full well declareth, the lawe is spirituall, <NOTE> and ought to be done and executed wyth the harte, wyth the spirite, and mynde, and not only outwardly.
column8: For as Paule full well declareth, the law is spiritual, and ought to be done and executed with the heart, with the spirit, and mind, and not only outwardly.

column7: Yet neuertheles all the Iewes were not in thys case, for there were holy and iuste persons in all ages, as appeareth full wel in the bokes of holy scripture.
column8: Yet nevertheless all the Jewes were not in this case, for there were holy and just persons in all ages, as appears full well in the books of holy scripture.

column7: And there were also many, whych had good intentes, but they were so drowned wyth the blyndnes, supersticion, gloses, tradicions, interpretacions and dreames of the pharisees and elders that they espyed not the true honoure and worshyp of God, of whyche sorte was Nicodemus, <NOTE> whych came by nyght to Christ to learne of hym and to dispute wyth hym.
column8: And there were also many, which had good intentes, but they were so drowned with the blindness, superstition, gloss, traditions, interpretations and dreams of the pharisees and elders that they espied not the true honour and worship of God, of which sort was Nicodemus, which came by night to Christ to learn of him and to dispute with him.

column7: But Christ perceyuynge that he was yet carnall and that he obserued but the letter of the lawe, and not the spirite and mynde of the lawe, sayd by and by vnto hym: Verely verely I say vnto the, onles thou be (as who shulde saye) new borne, not of thy mother, but of water and spirite, thou canst not enter into the kyngdome of god.
column8: But Christ perceiving that he was yet carnal and that he observed but the letter of the law, and not the spirit and mind of the law, said by and by unto him: Verily verily I say unto thee, unless thou be (as who should say) new born, not of thy mother, but of water and spirit, thou canst not enter into the kingdom of god.

column7: That that is borne of flesh is flesh, but that whych is borne of spirite is spirite.
column8: That that is born of flesh is flesh, but that which is born of spirit is spirit.

column7: A fleshly ma a naturall man, a man vnbaptized, vnrenewed with the spirite can not smel nor haue any sauour of thinges spirituall, he can not worke ye wyll and pleasure of God.
column8: A fleshly ma a natural man, a man unbaptized, unrenewed with the spirit can not smel nor have any savour of things spiritual, he can not work you will and pleasure of God.

column7: He maye well for feare satisfye the outward wordes, but he shall neuer do the wyll of God wyllyngly, hartely, and with spirite, as it is requyred of God that he shulde do.
column8: He may well for fear satisfy the outward words, but he shall never do the will of God willingly, heartily, and with spirit, as it is required of God that he should do.

column7: For as I haue sayd, the law is spirituall and requyreth the harte.
column8: For as I have said, the law is spiritual and requireth the heart.

column7: And surely it appeareth well that thys lawyer toke but the letter of the lawe & not ye spirite, by the question folowyng where he asketh Christ who is hys neyghboure.
column8: And surely it appears well that this lawyer took but the letter of the law & not the spirit, by the question following where he asks Christ who is his neighbour.

column7: For yf he had loued God hertely he shulde haue counted euery man hys neyghboure as Christes similitude byddeth and not only hys owne nation as comonly the Iues dyd.
column8: For if he had loved God heartily he should have counted every man his neighbour as Christes similitude biddeth and not only his own nation as commonly the Iues did.

column7: Wherfore my frendes yf we wol haue euerlastynge lyfe, let vs do as Christe here byddeth vs. Let vs not be speakers nor hearers of ye law but doers, and not outwarde and lyterall doers, but hartye, but spirituall doers, not for feare as bondmen but for loue as freme and sonnes and heyres.
column8: Wherefore my friends if we will have everlasting life, let us do as Christe here biddeth us Let us not be speakers nor hearers of the law but doers, and not outward and lyterall doers, but hearty, but spiritual doers, not for fear as bondmen but for love as freme and sons and heirs.

column7: Thys let vs do and we shall lyue euerlastyngly in heauen P A G Ecxlviij wyth God.
column8: This let us doe and we shall live everlastingly in heaven PAGEcxlviij PAGEcxlviij PAGEcxlviij PAGEcxlviij with God.

column7: To whome be all honoure and imperie for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be all honour and impery for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Epistle on the.xiiij. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Epistle on the xiiij sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.v. chapter to the Galathians.
column8: The v chapter to the Galathians.

column7: Thargument The batell betwene the spirite and the fleshe, and the frutes of them both.
column8: Thargument The battle between the spirit and the flesh, and the fruits of them both.

column7: B Rethren, walke in the spirite, and fulfil not the lust of the flesh.
column8: BRethren BRethren, walk in the spirit, and fulfil not the lust of the flesh.

column7: For the flesh lusteth contrary to the spirite, and the spirite contrary to the fleshe: These are contrary one to another, so that ye can not do what soeuer ye wolde.
column8: For the flesh lusteth contrary to the spirit, and the spirit contrary to the flesh: These are contrary one to another, so that you can not do what soever you would.

column7: But and yf ye be led of the spirite, than are ye not vnder the lawe.
column8: But and if you be led of the spirit, than are you not under the law.

column7: The dedes of the fleshe are manyfest, whyche are these, aduoutrye, fornication, vnclenes, wantones, worshyppynge of ymages, wytchcraft, hatred, variaunce, zele, wrath, stryfe, sedicio, sectes, enuyeng murther, dronkennes, glottony, and suche lyke: of the whych I tell you before as I haue tolde you in tymes past, that they whych commytte such thynges, shall not be inheritours of the kyngdome of God.
column8: The deeds of the flesh are manifest, which are these, aduoutrye, fornication, uncleans, wantons, worshipping of images, wytchcraft, hatred, variance, zeal, wrath, strife, sedicio, sects, enuyeng murder, drunkenness, gluttony, and such like: of the which I tell you before as I have told you in times past, that they which commit such things, shall not be inheritors of the kingdom of God.

column7: Contrarely they frute of the spirite, is loue, ioye, peace, longe sufferynge, gentlenes, goodnes, faythfulnes, mekenes, temperancy.
column8: Contrarily they fruit of the spirit, is love, joy, peace, long suffering, gentleness, goodness, faithfulness, meekness, temperancy.

column7: Agaynst suche there is no lawe.
column8: Against such there is no law.

column7: They that are Christes haue crucifyed the flesh wyth the affections and lustes.
column8: They that are Christes have crucified the flesh with the affections and lusts.

column7: MY welbeloued brethren and systers in Christe, ye muste well consyder and vnderstande, that the lyfe of a christen man and woma in thys present worlde is as who shulde saye a continuall warfare, a dayly batell and fyghtynge, accordynge to the sayeng of Iob. <NOTE> Mans lyfe is on erth a warfare.
column8: MY well-beloved brothers and sisters in Christe, you must well consider and understand, that the life of a christian man and woma in this present world is as who should say a continual warfare, a daily battle and fighting, according to the saying of Iob. men life is on earth a warfare.

column7: And ye shall furthermore vnderstande, that the greatest aduersarie, the greatest enemye ye ma hath, is him selfe.
column8: And you shall furthermore understand, that the greatest adversary, the greatest enemy you ma hath, is him self.

column7: Neyther hath ma any thinge so harde and so stroge an enemye to ouercome as hys owne flesh, his owne stubborne and rebellous mynde and lust, forasmuch as of our owne corrupt natures we be inclined to al naughtynes and euels as it is wrytten in the boke of Genesis. <NOTE> The vnderstandinge and ymaginacion of mans harte is euell euen from hys youth.
column8: Neither hath ma any thing so harden and so stroge and enemy to overcome as his own flesh, his own stubborn and rebellious mind and lust, forasmuch as of our own corrupt nature's we be inclined to all naughtynes and evils as it is written in the book of Genesis. The understanding and ymaginacion of men heart is evil even from his youth.

column7: The flesh lusteth contrary to the spirite and the spirite to the flesh. <NOTE> Wherfore yf we be not regenerate, yf we be not borne agayne, yf we be not purged, clensed, & renewed by the spirite of God and so gouerned and directed in al our procedinges and doynges of ye same surely we shall neuer enter into the kyngdome of heuen, and thys is it that saint Paule doth here tel vs of.
column8: The flesh lusteth contrary to the spirit and the spirit to the flesh. Wherefore if we be not regenerate, if we be not born again, if we be not purged, cleansed, & renewed by the spirit of God and so governed and directed in all our proceedings and doings of the same surely we shall never enter into the kingdom of heaven, and this is it that saint Paule does here tell us of.

column7: He byddeth vs walke in the spirite, that is to say, cast awaye our olde corrupt nature, and put on vs a new nature, that is to saye, a spirituall nature, a new man, so shall we not fulfyll the lustes and desyres of the flesh.
column8: He biddeth us walk in the spirit, that is to say, cast away our old corrupt nature, and put on us a new nature, that is to say, a spiritual nature, a new man, so shall we not fulfil the lusts and desires of the flesh.

column7: As who shulde say.
column8: As who should say.

column7: Albeit your flesh wrastleth and fyghteth agaynst your spirite whyche ye haue obtayned by Christ and againe your spirite agaynst your fleshe bycause it is not yet throughlye mortifyed nor crucifyed in such wyse that somtyme ye do not the thynge that ye wold fayne do through the infirmitie and weakenes of the fleshe whyche ye haue not yet fully conquered: yet thys notwythstandynge se ye go styll on, and walke accordynge to the spirite.
column8: Albeit your flesh wrestleth and fighteth against your spirit which you have obtained by Christ and again your spirit against your flesh because it is not yet thoroughly mortified nor crucified in such wise that sometime you do not the thing that you would fain do through the infirmity and weakness of the flesh which you have not yet fully conquered: yet this notwithstanding see you go still on, and walk according to the spirit.

column7: Folowe I saye the thynges of the spirite, as P A G Ecxlix holy meditacions & readynges of scripture, deuoute prayers, abstinence of the body, and all godly exercises.
column8: Follow I say the things of the spirit, as PAGEcxlix PAGEcxlix PAGEcxlix PAGEcxlix holy meditations & readings of scripture, devout prayers, abstinence of the body, and all godly exercises.

column7: Thus doynge, ye shall growe stronge in ye spirite, ye shalbe hable by gods grace and assistence to wythstande the lustes and desyres of the flesh and of the corrupte nature, yea ye shalbe new me, spirituall men, conducted, led and gouerned by the holy spirit of god, ye shall then embrase the wyll of God frelye without compulsion, and not as bondmen to ye law.
column8: Thus doing, you shall grow strong in you spirit, you shall able by gods grace and assistance to withstand the lusts and desires of the flesh and of the corrupt nature, yea you shall new me, spiritual men, conducted, led and governed by the holy spirit of god, you shall then embrace the will of God freely without compulsion, and not as bondmen to you law.

column7: Ye shall then be enfraunchised from the thraldome of the deuell.
column8: You shall then be enfranchised from the thraldom of the devil.

column7: Then shall charitie worke more in you than any outwarde lawe can do. <NOTE> For a lawe is not made for iust and parfyte persons, but to brydel and represse the lustes of synfull persons of carnall and beastly folke, for as a certayne Philosopher sayeth: <NOTE> Of the euell maners of men dyd good lawes take begynnynge.
column8: Then shall charity work more in you than any outward law can do. For a law is not made for just and perfect persons, but to bridle and repress the lusts of sinful persons of carnal and beastly folk, for as a certain Philosopher sayeth: Of the evil manners of men did good laws take beginning.

column7: For yf all men wold do as they ought to do, we shulde nede no lawes.
column8: For if all men would do as they ought to do, we should need no laws.

column7: Good men therfore be not vnder the lawe.
column8: Good men therefore be not under the law.

column7: For to be vnder the lawe is to be in seruile feare and not to do the lawe frely.
column8: For to be under the law is to be in servile fear and not to do the law freely.

column7: And bycause ye shulde knowe the better whan ye walke fleshly and whan spiritually, the Apostle S. Paule setteth forth vnto vs the frutes of the fleshe and the frutes of the spirite. <NOTE> The workes of ye fleshe (sayeth he) be easely knowen, whych are these, aduoutrye, letchery, vnclennes, ydolatrye, wytchcraft, poysonynge, hatred, stryfe, hartbrennynge, fume, chafynge, discorde, heresies, sectes, enuye, dronkennes, ryotte, surfettynge, and such lyke.
column8: And because you should know the better when you walk fleshly and when spiritually, the Apostle S. Paule sets forth unto us the fruits of the flesh and the fruits of the spirit. The works of you flesh (sayeth he) be easily known, which are these, aduoutrye, lechery, uncleanness, idolatry, wytchcraft, poisoning, hatred, strife, hartbrennynge, fume, chafing, discord, heresies, sects, envy, drunkenness, riot, surfeiting, and such like.

column7: Of these foule vyces and frutes of the corrupte nature, I tell you before (sayeth saynt Paule) that who so euer do them (onles he ryse agayne by dew penaunce) shall neuer inherite the kyngdome of God.
column8: Of these foul vices and fruits of the corrupt nature, I tell you before (sayeth saint Paule) that who so ever do them (unless he rise again by due penance) shall never inherit the kingdom of God.

column7: On the contrarye syde, the frute of ye spirite is loue, charitie, ioye, peace wyth all men, pacience, sufferaunce, myldnes, lyberalitie, faythfulnes, meknes, temperauce.
column8: On the contrary side, the fruit of the spirit is love, charity, joy, peace with all men, patience, sufferance, myldnes, lyberalitie, faithfulness, meknes, temperance.

column7: And against such persons sayeth S. Paule as shew these frutes, surely there is no lawe. <NOTE> For (as sayde is) the lawe is made for the other sorte of men whych be iniust and disobedient, it is not ordeyned for the chyldren of the spirite whych be infraunchysed and whyche be wyllyngly wythout compulsion obedient ynough.
column8: And against such persons sayeth S. Paule as show these fruits, surely there is no law. For (as said is) the law is made for the other sort of men which be injust and disobedient, it is not ordained for the children of the spirit which be infraunchysed and which be willingly without compulsion obedient enough.

column7: For the chyldren of the spirite, I meane all suche whych belonge vnto Iesu Christ haue mortifyed and crucifyed and do cotinually mortifye and crucifye theyr fleshe, theyr vyces and concupiscences by the power of the spirite that raygneth in them, as S. Paul dyd sayenge: <NOTE> I tame my bodye and brynge it into subiection.
column8: For the children of the spirit, I mean all such which belong unto Jesu Christ have mortified and crucified and do continually mortify and crucify their flesh, their vices and concupiscences by the power of the spirit that reigneth in them, as S. Paul did saying: I tame my body and bring it into subjection.

column7: Assuredly my frendes the chyldren of the spirite be now nomore subiecte to the fleshe, but ye fleshe rather is subiecte vnto them or at lest wayes vnto the spirite whych is in them.
column8: Assuredly my friends the children of the spirit be now nomore subject to the flesh, but you flesh rather is subject unto them or at lest ways unto the spirit which is in them.

column7: Our Lorde graut, that hys spirite maye so worke in vs by hys lyuely word that we maye eschue the workes of the fleshe and folowe the frutes and workes of the same spirite by our Lorde Iesu Christ.
column8: Our Lord graut, that his spirit may so work in us by his lively word that we may eschew the works of the flesh and follow the fruits and works of the same spirit by our Lord Jesu Christ.

column7: To whome wyth the father and holy goost thre persons and one God, be redred all honoure, glorie, prayse, and thankes for euer and euer.
column8: To whom with the father and holy ghost thre persons and one God, be redred all honour, glory, praise, and thanks for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospel on the.xiiij. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the xiiij sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.xvij. Chapter of Luke.
column8: The xvij Chapter of Luke.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Christ healeth the.x. lepers.
column8: Christ heals the x lepers.

column7: P A G Ecl AS Iesus wente to Hierusalem he passed thorowe Samaria and Galile.
column8: PAGEcl PAGEcl PAGEcl PAGEcl AS Jesus went to Hierusalem he passed thorough Samaria and Galilee.

column7: And as he entred in to a certayne towne, there met hym ten men that were lepers.
column8: And as he entered in to a certain town, there met him ten men that were lepers.

column7: Whych stode afarre of, and put forth theyr voyces and sayd: Iesu mayster, haue mercye on vs. When he sawe them, he sayd vnto them: Go shewe your selues vnto the prestes.
column8: Which stood afar of, and put forth their voices and said: Jesu master, have mercy on us When he saw them, he said unto them: Go show your selves unto the priests.

column7: And it came to passe, that as they wente, they were clensed.
column8: And it came to pass, that as they went, they were cleansed.

column7: And one of them, when he sawe that he was clensed, turned backe agayne, and with a loude voyce praysed God, and fell downe on hys face at hys fete, & gaue hym thankes.
column8: And one of them, when he saw that he was cleansed, turned back again, and with a loud voice praised God, and fell down on his face at his feet, & gave him thanks.

column7: And the same was a Samaritane.
column8: And the same was a Samaritane.

column7: And Iesus answered, and sayd: are there not ten clesed?
column8: And Jesus answered, and said: are there not ten clesed?

column7: But where are those nyne? There are not foud that returned againe to gyue God prayse, saue only thys straunger.
column8: But where are those nyne? There are not foud that returned again to gyve God praise, save only this stranger.

column7: And he sayd vnto hym: aryse, go thy waye, thy fayth hath made the hole.
column8: And he said unto him: arise, go thy way, thy faith hath made the hold.

column7: G Ood christe people not only the wordes of our Lorde be full of great mysteries and significacions, but also hys myracles and hys workes be as it were parables and ful of mystery, and by them we ought to nourysh & increase oure weake fayth more and more and to make it stronge, as one may se and consyder in the gospell of thys daye, whych maketh mencion of.x. lazers or lepers, whome at that tyme our Lorde clensed of theyr leprye, and of hys large mercye made them hole.
column8: GOod GOod christe people not only the words of our Lord be full of great mysteries and significations, but also his miracles and his works be as it were parables and full of mystery, and by them we ought to nourish & increase our weak faith more and more and to make it strong, as one may see and consider in the gospel of this day, which makes mention of x lazers or lepers, whom at that time our Lord cleansed of their lepry, and of his large mercy made them hold.

column7: But what sygnifye these.x. lazers or lepers vnto vs?
column8: But what sygnifye these x lazers or lepers unto us?

column7: Truly in the lawe of Moses God had forbydden that none shulde kepe company with them whych were infected and sycke with bodely leprye but commaunded that they shulde be put forth from amonges them and from the company of the rest, lest they shulde infecte and pollute other as it is redde in the boke of Numeri where it is wrytte in this wyse. <NOTE> The Lord god spake to Moses sayenge: Commaunde the chyldren of Israell, that they put out from theyr tentes all lazars or lepers.
column8: Truly in the law of Moses God had forbidden that none should keep company with them which were infected and sick with bodily lepry but commanded that they should be put forth from among them and from the company of the rest, lest they should infect and pollute other as it is red in the book of Numeri where it is writ in this wise. The Lord god spoke to Moses saying: Command the children of Israell, that they put out from their tents all lazars or lepers.

column7: But certaynly we ought a great deale more to take hede that we do not communicate nor kepe company wyth such as be lazars spiritually.
column8: But certainly we ought a great deal more to take heed that we do not communicate nor keep company with such as be lazars spiritually.

column7: The spiritual lepry is infidelitie, heresie, and ignoraunce of God.
column8: The spiritual lepry is infidelity, heresy, and ignorance of God.

column7: For lyke as the bodely leprye doth corrupt al the body, euen so doth infidelitie corrupt all the soule, and by the stynkynge breath therof, that is to say, by the wordes and conuersacion of suche as be corrupted therwith, be other corrupted ye company wyth them, accordynge to that sayenge.
column8: For like as the bodily lepry does corrupt all the body, even so does infidelity corrupt all the soul, and by the stinking breath thereof, that is to say, by the words and conversation of such as be corrupted therewith, be other corrupted you company with them, according to that saying.

column7: Corrumput bonos mores colloquia praua, that is to saye, euell communicacions do corrupt good maners.
column8: Corrumput bonos mores colloquia praua, that is to say, evil communications do corrupt good manners.

column7: Wherfore al such ought to be eschued and fled from, as lepers and lazars, they must be excomunicate and put out of the assemble and congregacion of christen people.
column8: Wherefore all such ought to be eschewed and fled from, as lepers and lazars, they must be excommunicate and put out of the assemble and congregation of christian people.

column7: Yet thys notwythstandynge, there is no sycknes, no maladie, no lepry so greuous, but that the moost excellent phisician and surgeon our Lord and Sauiour Christ Iesus both can heale and wyll heale, yf he be faithfully sought and called vpon, as by exemple is well shewed in thys gospell.
column8: Yet this notwithstanding, there is no sickness, no malady, no lepry so grievous, but that the most excellent physician and surgeon our Lord and Saviour Christ Jesus both can heal and will heal, if he be faithfully sought and called upon, as by exemple is well showed in this gospel.

column7: But I say it is our partes, to seke and call vpon hym, it is our offyce to go and mete Iesu Christ, yf we woll be cured.
column8: But I say it is our parts, to seek and call upon him, it is our office to go and meet Jesu Christ, if we will be cured.

column7: We must crye afarre of after hym, we muste wyth depe lowlynes and humilitie of harte, pray vnto hym and say: P A G Ecli Iesus, Sauioure, and mayster, haue mercy on vs, take pytie and compassion ouer vs. By this meanes after that we haue ones offred and presented our selues vnto the prestes, whych haue authoritie and power of God for to discerne and iudge, <NOTE> vnto the scripture, betwene the lepry and not lepry, that is to saye, betwene heresye and veritie, betwene vice and vertue, and accordynge vnto the scripture, to assoyle, as saynt Paule dyd assoyle a synner of whych is made mencion in the seconde epistle vnto the Corinthians, <NOTE> we shalbe receyued agayne into the nomber of the faythful, euen into ye flocke of Iesu Christ But after that we shalbe assoyled of God in trouth, and of men in sygnes, we muste yet beware that we be not ingrate, churlysh, nor vnthankfull to God, as the.ix. lazars were whyche dyd not retourne, for to yeld thankes and prayses to Christ, and for to gyue glorye vnto god for the great benefite and goodnes that they had receyued of hym.
