column8: In these two comaudementes hang all the law and the prophets.

column7: Whyle the pharisees were gathered together, Iesus asked them, sayenge: what thynke ye of Christ?
column8: While the pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them, saying: what think you of Christ?

column7: Whose sonne is he?
column8: Whose son is he?

column7: They sayd vnto hym: the sone of Dauid.
column8: They said unto him: the soon of Dauid.

column7: He sayde vnto them: howe then doth Dauid in spirite cal hym Lorde, sayeng: The Lorde sayde vnto my Lorde syt thou on my ryght hande tyll I make thyne enemyes a footestoole.
column8: He said unto them: how then does Dauid in spirit call him Lord, saying: The Lord said unto my Lord fit thou on my right hand till I make thine enemies a footstool.

column7: Yf Dauid than call hym Lorde, howe is he then hys sonne?
column8: If Dauid than call him Lord, how is he then his son?

column7: And no man was able to answere hym any thynge: neyther durst any man (from that day forth) aske hym any mo questions.
column8: And no man was able to answer him any thing: neither durst any man (from that day forth) ask him any more questions.

column7: T He Gospell red in the churche thys daye good christen audiece doth reherse vnto vs, how the pharisees, <NOTE> hearynge that Iesus Christ had confounded the Saducees, whych as saynt Hierome noteth were of contrarye opinions wythin themselues and as it were enemyes one to another, yet they come & ioyne together agaynst Christe to thintent as Ihon Chrysostome sayeth they myghte ouercome hym by multitude, <NOTE> whome they coulde not couince wyth reasons.
column8: THe THe Gospel read in the church this day good christian audience does rehearse unto us, how the pharisees, hearing that Jesus Christ had confounded the Saducees, which as saint Hierome notes were of contrary opinions within themselves and as it were enemies one to another, yet they come & join together against Christe to intent as Ihon Chrysostome sayeth they might overcome him by multitude, whom they could not couince with reasons.

column7: And so sayeth he they confessed themselues to be naked of the trouth whych armed theselues with multitude.
column8: And so sayeth he they confessed themselves to be naked of the troth which armed themselves with multitude.

column7: They come than all together.
column8: They come than all together.

column7: And one amonge them a doctour of the lawe speakynge for all the reste (to thintent yf that one ouercame they myght al seme to haue the vpperhande) in teptynge our Lorde Iesu Christ, dyd put thys question vnto hym, sayenge: Mayster whyche is the greatest commaundement of the lawe?
column8: And one among them a doctor of the law speaking for all the rest (to intent if that one overcame they might all seem to have the upperland) in teptynge our Lord Jesu Christ, did put this question unto him, saying: Master which is the greatest commandment of the law?

column7: Here you maye se what fashions these false foxes and ypocrites had.
column8: Here you may see what fashions these false foxes and hypocrites had.

column7: Fyrste they called Iesu Christe mayster: whose disciple for all that, they had no desyre to be.
column8: Fyrste they called Jesu Christe master: whose disciple for all that, they had no desire to be.

column7: And they dyd demaunde hym of the greatest commaundement (as Chrysostome sayeth) which neuer had accomplished the least: <NOTE> but rather by theyr cursed and auaricious constitucions had transgressed all the lawe of God.
column8: And they did demand him of the greatest commandment (as Chrysostome sayeth) which never had accomplished the least: but rather by their cursed and avaricious constitutions had transgressed all the law of God.

column7: And they thought that it was ynough for to dispute P A G Eclxiiij the one agaynst the other by pryde and vanitie, for they dyd not desyre but all only to be sene and praysed of men, yet for all thys the swete Sauiour desyrynge theyr saluation doth gyue them here true and sounde doctrine and healthfull correction, answerynge them mekely, that they ought to loue God wt all theyr thought, the whych they dyd not: and theyr neyghbour as themselues, but they dyd cleane contrarye.
column8: And they thought that it was enough for to dispute PAGEclxiiij PAGEclxiiij PAGEclxiiij PAGEclxiiij the one against the other by pride and vanity, for they did not desire but all only to be seen and praised of men, yet for all this the sweet Saviour desiring their salvation does gyve them here true and sound doctrine and healthful correction, answering them meekly, that they ought to love God with all their thought, the which they did not: and their neighbour as themselves, but they did clean contrary.

column7: For he whych was theyr God, & theyr neyghbour in as much as he was man, they wold put him to death.
column8: For he which was their God, & their neighbour in as much as he was man, they would put him to death.

column7: In whych he shewed them to be synners, ypocrites that is to saye counterfayted holy & transgressours of all the lawe and of the prophetes.
column8: In which he showed them to be sinners, hypocrites that is to say counterfeited holy & transgressors of all the law and of the prophets.

column7: And accordynge vnto saynt Marke in the.xij. chapter, they wyst not what to answere, but theyr owne doctoure gaue sentence agaynst them, sayenge: Mayster, in truth thou hast sayd well.
column8: And according unto saint Mark in the xij chapter, they wist not what to answer, but their own doctor gave sentence against them, saying: Master, in truth thou hast said well.

column7: For there is one only god, and ther is none other but he.
column8: For there is one only god, and there is none other but he.

column7: And to loue hym wyth all the harte, wyth all the vnderstandyng wyth all the soule, and with all the strength, and the neyghbour as hymselfe: is a greater thynge then al the brentofferynges and sacrifices made vnto God.
column8: And to love him with all the heart, with all the understanding with all the soul, and with all the strength, and the neighbour as himself: is a greater thing then all the brentofferynges and sacrifices made unto God.

column7: Here maye you se, howe he hymselfe gyueth iudgement agaynst the couetousnes of the scribes & pharisees whych loued so well the sacrifices for the profyte that came therof vnto them.
column8: Here may you see, how he himself gyveth judgement against the covetousness of the scribes & pharisees which loved so well the sacrifices for the profit that came thereof unto them.

column7: And on the contrary syde he approueth the answere of Iesu Christ, the whych they thought to haue interrupted and checked.
column8: And on the contrary side he approveth the answer of Jesu Christ, the which they thought to have interrupted and checked.

column7: Thus it appeareth that the craftye be taken in theyr craftynes, and yt ther is no cousell against god And then fynally our Lorde demaunded of the pharisees beynge all there together, whose sonne Christ was.
column8: Thus it appears that the crafty be taken in their craftynes, and that there is no cousell against god And then finally our Lord demanded of the pharisees being all there together, whose son Christ was.

column7: And forbycause they were carnall they knewe nothynge in Christ & in Messias but flesh, and they answered hym that he was the sonne of Dauid.
column8: And forbycause they were carnal they knew nothing in Christ & in Messias but flesh, and they answered him that he was the son of Dauid.

column7: And then oure Lorde wolde shewe them and teache theyr saluatio.
column8: And then our Lord would show them and teach their saluatio.

column7: For it was not ynough for to beleue that he was a man comen of royall bloude, but also it must be beleued that he was God vnied vnto humayne nature for to make the redemption of men.
column8: For it was not enough for to believe that he was a man come of royal blood, but also it must be believed that he was God unied unto human nature for to make the redemption of men.

column7: And therfore he sheweth them by ye wytnesse of Dauid selfe that he is God, <NOTE> where Dauid sayeth in spirite.
column8: And therefore he shows them by you witness of Dauid self that he is God, where Dauid sayeth in spirit.

column7: The Lorde god hath sayd vnto my Lorde.
column8: The Lord god hath said unto my Lord.

column7: Syt on my ryght hande vnto the tyme that I put thyne enemyes a foote stoole to thy feete.
column8: Fit on my right hand unto the time that I put thine enemies a foot stool to thy feet.

column7: Dauid calleth Christ hys Lorde syttynge on the ryghte hande of God whych is to vnderstande (as the auncient doctour S. Remigius & other doth expoune it) not that God is corporall that he shulde haue a ryght or left syde but to syt on the ryghte hande of God, <NOTE> is to remayne in the same honoure and dignitie egall wyth the father, so that herby he cofesseth that he is God.
column8: Dauid calls Christ his Lord sitting on the right hand of God which is to understand (as the ancient doctor S. Remigius & other does expoune it) not that God is corporal that he should have a right or left side but to fit on the right hand of God, is to remain in the same honour and dignity equal with the father, so that hereby he cofesseth that he is God.

column7: And this the pharisees vnderstode not to be sayd of Christe: but they were those whych ye spirite of god calleth the enemyes of Christe, for to be put vnder hys feete.
column8: And this the pharisees understood not to be said of Christe: but they were those which you spirit of god calls the enemies of Christe, for to be put under his feet.

column7: Than my brethren let vs not tempt Iesu Christ.
column8: Than my brothers let us not tempt Jesu Christ.

column7: Let vs beleue, that the greatest and the fyrst commaundement: is to loue God wyth all our hart, wyth all our thought, and wyth all our soule, that he is true God and that he is true ma.
column8: Let us believe, that the greatest and the fyrst commandment: is to love God with all our heart, with all our thought, and with all our soul, that he is true God and that he is true ma.

column7: And we shall be of the nombre of the chosen for to laude the heauenly father, and our Lorde Iesu Christ syttyng on hys ryght hande.
column8: And we shall be of the number of the chosen for to laud the heavenly father, and our Lord Jesu Christ sitting on his right hand.

column7: Vnto the whyche wyth the holy goost be glorie wythout ende.
column8: Unto the which with the holy ghost be glory without end.

column7: : homily P A G Eclxv The Epistle on the.xix. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily PAGEclxv PAGEclxv PAGEclxv PAGEclxv The Epistle on the xix sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.iiij. chapter to the Ephesians.
column8: The iiij chapter to the Ephesians.

column7: Thargument How we ought to put of our olde Adam, and put on the newe.
column8: Thargument How we ought to put of our old Adam, and put on the new.

column7: B Rethren, be ye renewed in the spirite of youre mynde, and to put on that newe man, whych after God is shapen in ryghtuousnes and true holynes.
column8: BRethren BRethren, be you renewed in the spirit of your mind, and to put on that new man, which after God is shapen in righteousness and true holiness.

column7: Wherfore, put away lienge, & speake euery ma trouth vnto hys neyghbour, for as much as we are members one of another.
column8: Wherefore, put away lienge, & speak every ma troth unto his neighbour, for as much as we are members one of another.

column7: Be angry and synne not: let not the Sonne go downe vpon your wrath, neyther gyue place vnto the backbyter.
column8: Be angry and sin not: let not the Son go down upon your wrath, neither gyve place unto the backbyter.

column7: Let hym that stole, steale no more but let hym rather labour with hys handes the thynge which is good, that he may gyue vnto hym that nedeth.
column8: Let him that stole, steal no more but let him rather labour with his hands the thing which is good, that he may gyve unto him that needeth.

column7: MY welbeloued frendes in our sauiour Christ ye shall vnderstande that in the texte immediatly goynge before thys epistle of thys present daye, the Apostle doth admonysh vs for to leaue the olde ma, that is to say our fyrst natiuitie or byrth by ye which we be borne chyldren of the yre and wrath of God, & we be fulfylled wyth synnes, wyth euel desyres, and wyth concupiscences, the whych woll turne vs vnto corrupcion and eternall death.
column8: MY well-beloved friends in our saviour Christ you shall understand that in the text immediately going before this epistle of this present day, the Apostle does admonish us for to leave the old ma, that is to say our fyrst nativity or birth by you which we be born children of the ire and wrath of God, & we be fulfilled with sins, with evil desires, and with concupiscences, the which will turn us unto corruption and eternal death.

column7: After in our epistle he exhorteth vs, that we shuld be renewed, not accordynge vnto the body, but in the spirite of our soule.
column8: After in our epistle he exhorteth us, that we should be renewed, not according unto the body, but in the spirit of our soul.

column7: For it is the spirite of God that wyl inhabyte there, and do hys workes.
column8: For it is the spirit of God that will inhabit there, and do his works.

column7: Then we must, for to be renued in our hartes haue nede that the gyftes and graces of God maye abyde there in stede of the concupiscences whyche the deuell hath put there by the synne of Adam.
column8: Then we must, for to be renewed in our hearts have need that the gifts and graces of God may abide there in stead of the concupiscences which the devil hath put there by the sin of Adam.

column7: As agaynst couetousnesse, mercy and lyberalitie.
column8: As against covetousness, mercy and lyberalitie.

column7: Agaynst lechery, continence, & chastite.
column8: Against lechery, continence, & chastity.

column7: Against pryde and rygoure, frendshyp mekenes and all humilitie.
column8: Against pride and rygoure, friendship meekness and all humility.

column7: Agaynst hathered and rancor, loue and charitie.
column8: Against hathered and rancour, love and charity.

column7: Agaynst iniquitie and synne, iustice & al grace.
column8: Against iniquity and sin, justice & all grace.

column7: And thus we shalbe newly arrayed wyth the newe man Iesu Christ: whych by hys holy spirite shal make vs also new men, holy men, and vertuouse me lyuynge no more in foule and stynkynge synne as we were wont to do, but walkyng in newnes of lyfe by the grace of God by whom we shalbe iustifyed and truly sanctifyed.
column8: And thus we shall newly arrayed with the new man Jesu Christ: which by his holy spirit shall make us also new men, holy men, and virtuous me living no more in foul and stinking sin as we were wont to do, but walking in newness of life by the grace of God by whom we shall justified and truly sanctified.

column7: And for bycause he is all trouth, yf we wolde abyde in hym, we muste cast out and put from vs al lyes and false tales, the whych from our byrth is conioyned and euen knytte fast vnto oure fleshe. <NOTE> For as the prophete sayeth.
column8: And for because he is all troth, if we would abide in him, we must cast out and put from us all lies and false tales, the which from our birth is conjoined and even knit fast unto our flesh. For as the prophet sayeth.

column7: All men be lyers, they haue spoken vanities and false thynges from theyr byrth, And god alone is veritable & eue trouth it selfe the whych wylleth that we speake trouth one to an other for we be all mebers of hys body, which is hys church and spouse, whych spouse ought to be gouerned ledde & conducted by the spirite of trouth.
column8: All men be liars, they have spoken vanities and false things from their birth, And god alone is veritable & eve troth it self the which willeth that we speak troth one to and other for we be all mebers of his body, which is his church and spouse, which spouse ought to be governed led & conducted by the spirit of troth.

column7: And thys spirite of trouth yf it dwell in vs, shall doubtles gyue vs all holy zele and a certayne godly angre agaynst synne whych shalbe wythout synne.
column8: And this spirit of troth if it dwell in us, shall doubtless gyve us all holy zeal and a certain godly anger against sin which shall without sin.

column7: As in seynge the blyndnes and the vnhappynes of the poore synners, we shalbe sorowfull and heuy.
column8: As in sing the blindness and the unhappiness of the poor sinners, we shall sorrowful and heavy.

column7: As it is wrytten in the.iij. chapter of saynt Marke, that our sauiour Iesu Christ whan he dyd se the wyckednes of the scribes and pharisees he was sore troubled and heuy wyth anger for the blyndnes of theyr P A G Eclxvi hartes.
column8: As it is written in the iij chapter of saint Mark, that our saviour Jesu Christ when he did see the wickedness of the scribes and pharisees he was soar troubled and heavy with anger for the blindness of their PAGEclxvi PAGEclxvi PAGEclxvi PAGEclxvi hearts.

column7: But here my frendes we must be well ware, that thys anger be not agaynst our christen brother but agaynst the wycked enemye and the synne.
column8: But here my friends we must be well aware, that this anger be not against our christian brother but against the wicked enemy and the sin.

column7: And also that it do not abyd ouerlonge in our hartes for feare that it shulde happen that the sonne of iustice, whych is Iesu Christe, shulde byde and go downe from vs for our anger and yre, for in leauynge god, we shulde gyue place to the deuell.
column8: And also that it do not abyd ouerlonge in our hearts for fear that it should happen that the son of justice, which is Jesu Christe, should bide and go down from us for our anger and ire, for in leaving god, we should gyve place to the devil.

column7: Fynally the Apostle doth admonysh vs that they whych haue ben theues and robbers, that they shuld do nomore theftes & robberies: but rather that they shulde laboure wyth theyr handes in good workes, not by auaryce or couetousnes for to waxe ryche, but for to ayde charitably and reliefe theyr christen brethre which haue nede and pouertie.
column8: Finally the Apostle does admonish us that they which have been thieves and robbers, that they should do nomore thefts & robberies: but rather that they should labour with their hands in good works, not by avarice or covetousness for to wax rich, but for to aid charitably and relief their christen brethren which have need and poverty.

column7: And in doynge thys God shal be in lykewyse mercyfull vnto vs, and shall haue pitie of vs. For he loueth mercy more than sacrifice as our sauiour Christ hymselfe recordeth.
column8: And in doing this God shall be in likewise merciful unto us, and shall have pity of us For he loves mercy more than sacrifice as our saviour Christ himself recordeth.

column7: After thys wyse yf we fynyshe the course of oure lyfe, we maye truste that the crowne of iustice is layde vp for vs whych our Lorde shall render vnto vs who is a iust iudge as S. Paule sayeth. <NOTE> For he shall render vnto euery man accordynge to hys workes.
column8: After this wise if we fynyshe the course of our life, we may trust that the crown of justice is laid up for us which our Lord shall render unto us who is a just judge as S. Paule sayeth. For he shall render unto every man according to his works.

column7: We shal sayeth Paule be set before the trone of Christ to beare a waye accordynge as we haue done in our bodye, <NOTE> eyther good or euell.
column8: We shall sayeth Paule be set before the throne of Christ to bear a way according as we have done in our body, either good or evil.

column7: Let oure fayth then brynge forth worthy frutes of christianite that by gods grace we maye be crowned accordyngly.
column8: Let our faith then bring forth worthy fruits of christianity that by gods grace we may be crowned accordingly.

column7: To whome be al glorie and prayse for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be all glory and praise for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospel on the.xix. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the xix sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.ix. chapter of Mathew.
column8: The ix chapter of Mathew.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Iesus forgyueth the sycke man of the palsey hys synnes, and healeth hym.
column8: Jesus forgyueth the sick man of the palsy his sins, and heals him.

column7: I Esus entred into a shyppe, and passed ouer, and came into hys owne cytie: and beholde, they brought to hym a man sycke of the palsye, lyenge in a bed.
column8: IEsus IEsus entered into a ship, and passed over, and came into his own city: and behold, they brought to him a man sick of the palsy, lying in a bed.

column7: And whan Iesus saw the fayth of them, he sayd vnto the sycke of the palsye: sone, be of good chere, thy synnes be forgyuen the.
column8: And when Jesus saw the faith of them, he said unto the sick of the palsy: soon, be of good cheer, thy sins be forgiven the.

column7: And behold, certayne of the scribes sayd wythin themselues: thys man blasphemeth.
column8: And behold, certain of the scribes said within themselves: this man blasphemeth.

column7: And whan Iesus sawe theyr thoughtes, he said: wherfore thinke ye euel in your hartes?
column8: And when Jesus saw their thoughts, he said: wherefore think you evil in your hearts?

column7: Whether is easyer to saye, thy synnes be forgyuen the, or to saye aryse and walke?
column8: Whither is easier to say, thy sins be forgiven the, or to say arise and walk?

column7: But that ye maye knowe, that the sonne of man hath power to forgyue synnes in earth.
column8: But that you may know, that the son of man hath power to forgive sins in earth.

column7: Then sayeth he vnto the sycke of the palsye: aryse, take vp thy bed, and go vnto thy house.
column8: Then sayeth he unto the sick of the palsy: arise, take up thy bed, and go unto thy house.

column7: And he arose, and departed to hys house.
column8: And he arose, and departed to his house.

column7: But the people that sawe it, maruayled, and glorifyed God, whych had gyuen such power vnto men.
column8: But the people that saw it, marveled, and glorified God, which had given such power unto men.

column7: MY welbeloued brethre and frendes, the cytie of Iesu Christ as noteth Chrysostomus the holy doctour of the church is Capharnaum, <NOTE> the whyche is called hys cytie forbycause that in leuynge Nazareth he wente and dwelled there, and also for the noble sermons, and great myracles whych he dyd ofte there, as also now he doth one, whych we ought wel to marke and note: for therin is comprysed for vs noble and helthfull instruction.
column8: MY well-beloved brethren and friends, the city of Jesu Christ as notes Chrysostomus the holy doctor of the church is Capharnaum, the which is called his city forbycause that in leuynge Nazareth he went and dwelled there, and also for the noble sermons, and great miracles which he did oft there, as also now he does one, which we ought well to mark and note: for therein is comprised for us noble and healtful instruction.

column7: Fyrste of all then we ought to consyder that our Sauiour Iesu Christe, P A G Eclxvij hath perceyued and beholden the fayth of them that dyd beare the man hauynge the palsey, but here is no mention at al made of the great payne that they toke.
column8: Fyrste of all then we ought to consider that our Saviour Jesu Christe, PAGEclxvij PAGEclxvij PAGEclxvij PAGEclxvij hath perceived and beholden the faith of them that did bear the man having the palsy, but here is no mention at all made of the great pain that they took.

column7: For saynt Marke in the seconde chapter, and saynt Luke in the.v. chapter do reherce thys selfe myracle and say that they vncouered the house, and so dyd let downe the bedde wherin the sycke man of the palsey laye before oure Lorde, for bycause that ther was so great multitude of people that dyd folowe hym that they coulde not come nere vnto hym Notwythstandynge all thys, ther is made no mencion here but of theyr fayth and trust: instructynge vs, that God doth not so greatlye esteme oure outwarde workes, though that they be fayre and in apparauce good, yf we haue not fayth by charitie workynge in vs, the whych only and her workes he estemeth.
column8: For saint Mark in the seconde chapter, and saint Lycia in the v chapter do rehearse this self miracle and say that they uncovered the house, and so did let down the bed wherein the sick man of the palsy say before our Lord, for because that there was so great multitude of people that did follow him that they could not come never unto him Notwithstanding all this, there is made no mention here but of their faith and trust: instructing us, that God does not so greatly esteem our outward works, though that they be fair and in appearance good, if we have not faith by charity working in us, the which only and her works he esteemeth.

column7: For certes what soeuer procedeth not of fayth whych is the roote and foundacion of al good workes is synne as thapostle S. Paule doth wytnesse. <NOTE> And therfore the prophete Hieromie sayeth: <NOTE> Lorde God thy eyes do beholde ye fayth.
column8: For certes what soever proceedeth not of faith which is the root and foundation of all good works is sin as apostle S. Paule does witness. And therefore the prophet Hieromie sayeth: Lord God thy eyes do behold you faith.

column7: Therfore sayd our lord vnto ye paralitique.
column8: Therefore said our lord unto you paralytic.

column7: Sone haue hope, be of good chere thy synnes be forgyue the, shewyng vnto vs yt our sinnes is ye sycknes yt god wyl principally heale & of ye whych aboue al thinges we ought to desyre ye healyng, which is the remission: whych we shal haue not by outward workes done wtout fayth, but by ye fayth & cofidece yt we shal haue in Iesu Christ in returning agayn vnto him for al our businesses aswel spirituall as corporall, as vnto our creatour & redemer, whych is only myghty ynough for to help vs, & pricipally for to pardo our synnes, which is ye moost daungerous syckenesse that can be to makynde, for by the same we dye of euerlastynge death.
column8: Soon have hope, be of good cheer thy sins be forgive the, show unto us that our sins is the sickness that god will principally heal & of the which above all things we ought to desire you healing, which is the remission: which we shall have not by outward works done without faith, but by you faith & cofidece that we shall have in Jesu Christ in returning again unto him for all our businesses aswell spiritual as corporal, as unto our creator & redeemer, which is only mighty enough for to help us, & principally for to pardon our sins, which is the most dangerous sickness that can be to makynde, for by the same we die of everlasting death.

column7: And forbycause that the scribes and doctours of the lawe dyd not beleue that Christe was God, they sayde in theyr hartes, that he blasphemed in forgyuinge and pardonynge the synnes vnto the palsye man.
column8: And forbycause that the scribes and doctors of the law did not believe that Christe was God, they said in their hearts, that he blasphemed in forgyuinge and pardoning the sins unto the palsy man.

column7: And it maye be that they had red that whych god had sayd in the.xliij. chapter of Esay: It is I, it is I my selfe that pardone the synnes bycause of me.
column8: And it may be that they had read that which god had said in the xliij chapter of Esay: It is I, it is I my self that pardon the sins because of me.

column7: Then God dyd shewe hymselfe true God, in rebukinge them of theyr euell thoughtes, and seynge theyr hertes (the whych apperteyneth vnto God onely, of whome is sayd.
column8: Then God did show himself true God, in rebuking them of their evil thoughts, and sing their herts (the which appertaineth unto God only, of whom is said.

column7: It is thou Lorde God whych sercheth the hartes and the raynes.
column8: It is thou Lord God which searcheth the hearts and the reins.

column7: And yet more outwardly he shewed hymselfe.
column8: And yet more outwardly he showed himself.

column7: For visibly and by hys only worde he healed the sycke ma, & dyd gyue him sodenly bodely strength, and wythout beynge in any maner weake of hys syckenesse, he commaunded hym to beare awaye hys bedde and to go vnto hys house, shewyng that it was he of whom it is sayd.
column8: For visibly and by his only word he healed the sick ma, & did gyve him suddenly bodily strength, and without being in any manner weak of his sickness, he commanded him to bear away his bed and to go unto his house, show that it was he of whom it is said.

column7: He hath sayd and they were done.
column8: He hath said and they were done.

column7: Thys poore paralitique is the fygure of all synners, the whych be vnable as of themselues to do any good, & they be borne in theyr beddes, that is to saye in the fleshe of theyr concupiscences.
column8: This poor paralytic is the figure of all sinners, the which be unable as of themselves to do any good, & they be born in their beds, that is to say in the flesh of their concupiscences.

column7: But whan they haue fayth vnto the worde of God whych apprehedeth gods promyse wyth an ernest repentaunce of theyr former lyfe and a study of a newe lyfe they receyue full helth: and where as before they were subiectes vnto theyr fleshe and fleshly desyres, they be now maysters, and holde them subiectes, and fynally they go by the grace of God and the vertue of hys worde beynge conducted and fortifyed P A G Eclxviij by the same in newnes of lyfe walkinge in the preceptes and ordinauces of god, they go I say vnto theyr house whych is the moost blessed and ioyful kyngdome of heauen.
column8: But when they have faith unto the word of God which apprehedeth gods promise with and earnest repentance of their former life and a study of a new life they receive full health: and where as before they were subjects unto their flesh and fleshly desires, they be now masters, and hold them subjects, and finally they go by the grace of God and the virtue of his word being conducted and fortified PAGEclxviij PAGEclxviij PAGEclxviij PAGEclxviij by the same in newness of life walking in the precepts and ordinances of god, they go I say unto their house which is the most blessed and joyful kingdom of heaven.

column7: And the people wha they saw thys myracle had feare and greate reuerence vnto God: and espyenge hys great benefytes to makinde gaue to hym glorie, knowynge that the men coulde not do such workes whych be aboue nature, yf God do it not by them: and in thys doynge, they glorified Iesu Christe whych is true God and true man, and whych vndoubtedly is the iustice, the glorie, and perfection of all men, whych not trustynge in themselues as dyd the proude pharisee whome the Gospell maketh mencion of but wyth sorowfull harte & due penaunce accordynge to thexemple of the publicane lamentynge theyr synnes haue stedfast fayth and cofidence in hym beynge in full mynde and a redynes not only to be hearers of the lawe and Gospell but also to be doers and workers of the same as Christe hath appoynted vs to do.
column8: And the people wha they saw this miracle had fear and great reverence unto God: and espyenge his great benefits to makinde gave to him glory, knowing that the men could not do such works which be above nature, if God do it not by them: and in this doing, they glorified Jesu Christe which is true God and true man, and which undoubtedly is the justice, the glory, and perfection of all men, which not trusting in themselves as did the proud pharisee whom the Gospel makes mention of but with sorrowful heart & due penance according to thexemple of the publican lamenting their sins have steadfast faith and confidence in him being in full mind and a readiness not only to be hearers of the law and Gospel but also to be doers and workers of the same as Christe hath appointed us to do.

column7: God graut vs that grace To whome be all glorie imperie and peace in infinita seculorum secula.
column8: God graut us that grace To whom be all glory impery and peace in infinita seculorum secula.

column7: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the.xx. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the xx sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The. v. chapter to the Ephesians.
column8: The. v. chapter to the Ephesians.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: An exhortacion to vertuouse lyuynge.
column8: And exhortation to virtuous living.

column7: B Rethren, take hede therfore howe ye walke circumspectly: not as vnwyse, but as wyse men: auoydynge occasion, bycause the dayes are euell.
column8: BRethren BRethren, take heed therefore how you walk circumspectly: not as unwise, but as wise men: avoiding occasion, because the days are evil.

column7: Wherfore, be ye not vnwyse, but vnderstand what the wyll of the Lorde is, and be not dronke wyth wyth wyne wherin is excesse: but be fylled wyth the spirite, speakynge vnto your selues in psalmes and in hymnes, and spiritual songes, syngynge and makynge melodie to the Lorde in your hartes, gyuynge thankes alwayes for all thynges vnto God the father, in the name of our lord Iesus Christ submyttynge your selues one to another in the feare of God.
column8: Wherefore, be you not unwise, but understand what the will of the Lord is, and be not drunk with with wine wherein is excess: but be filled with the spirit, speaking unto your selves in psalms and in hymns, and spiritual songs, singing and making melody to the Lord in your hearts, gyving thanks always for all things unto God the father, in the name of our lord Jesus Christ submitting your selves one to another in the fear of God.

column7: MY good brethren and systers the wyse man sayeth in hys prouerbes that ther is a waye the whych semeth vnto me to be strayght and good, but it leadeth vnto eternall death.
column8: MY good brothers and sisters the wise man sayeth in his proverbs that there is a way the which seemeth unto me to be straight and good, but it leads unto eternal death.

column7: Certes thys is ye way of the worldly people, whych lyue accordynge to the desyres of the fleshe, not remebrynge, how they shall descede in a minute of an houre vnto hell.
column8: Certes this is the way of the worldly people, which live according to the desires of the flesh, not remebrynge, how they shall descede in a minute of and hour unto hell.

column7: Therfore in our epistle whych thys day is redde in the church The apostle doth exhorte vs that we wol walke prudently and wysely as becommeth christe men in the meane tyme, whyle we shalbe in thys worlde & vale of mysery: not as the foolysh folke that shall perysh but as the wyse folke replenyshed with the true and heauenly sapience, <NOTE> followyng the steppes so nere as God shall gyue vs grace of oure Sauioure Iesu Christe, sekynge by all meanes we possible can occasio and oportunitie to do well, as workes of fayth workes of mercy and pytie towardes our euen christen. <NOTE> in thus doynge vndoubtedly we shall redeme or bye agayne the tyme whych we haue yll bestowed.
column8: Therefore in our epistle which this day is red in the church The apostle does exhort us that we will walk prudently and wisely as becomes christe men in the mean time, while we shall in this world & vale of misery: not as the foolish folk that shall perish but as the wise folk replenished with the true and heavenly sapience, following the steps so never as God shall gyve us grace of our Saviour Jesu Christe, seeking by all means we possible can occasio and opportunity to do well, as works of faith works of mercy and pity towards our even christian. in thus doing undoubtedly we shall redeem or buy again the time which we have ill bestowed.

column7: And certainly we shuld be moued vnto this namely forbycause that the dayes be euel, not in theselues, P A G Eclxix but for the synnes that be comytted in them.
column8: And certainly we should be moved unto this namely forbycause that the days be evil, not in themselves, PAGEclxix PAGEclxix PAGEclxix PAGEclxix but for the sins that be comytted in them.

column7: For the deuell doth all he can to turne vs from the good waye: whych be the comaundementes of God and the obseruation & executyng of hys holy worde vnto the whych we must dyrecte our hole lyfe yf we wyll be saued and not perysh eternally.
column8: For the devil does all he can to turn us from the good way: which be the commandments of God and the observation & executing of his holy word unto the which we must dyrecte our hold life if we will be saved and not perish eternally.

column7: Let vs not tha good people be as brute and vnreasonable beastes, imprudent, recheles, vncircumspecte & without vnderstandynge: but let vs vnderstande what the good wyll of our Lorde Iesu Christe is, the whyche wylleth that we shulde be saued all.
column8: Let us not than good people be as brutus and unreasonable beasts, imprudent, recheles, uncircumspect & without understanding: but let us understand what the good will of our Lord Jesu Christe is, the which willeth that we should be saved all.

column7: And for yt cause he hath suffred death, vnto the whyche we muste be confourmable in dyenge to our synnes lustes & concupiscences, to thende that we be sober and chaste, & replynyshed wyth the holy goost, the whyche shall cause vs to saye in our selues praysynges and spirituall songes vnto God: and that wyth a pure and a clene harte and not alonly with outwarde voyces & open deuotions, the whych be often full of hypocrisye and pryde: and for that cause displeasaunt vnto God.
column8: And for that cause he hath suffered death, unto the which we must be confourmable in dying to our sins lusts & concupiscences, to th'end that we be sober and chaste, & replynyshed with the holy ghost, the which shall cause us to say in our selves praysynges and spiritual songs unto God: and that with a pure and a clean heart and not alonely with outward voices & open devotions, the which be often full of hypocrisy and pride: and for that cause displeasant unto God.

column7: And our Lorde sayeth in the Gospell of saynt Mathew, <NOTE> where he speaketh of the pharisees which dyd all that they dyd ether by hypocrisie or by couetousnes.
column8: And our Lord sayeth in the Gospel of saint Mathew, where he speaks of the pharisees which did all that they did either by hypocrisy or by covetousness.

column7: Thys people (sayeth he) doth honoure me wyth theyr mouth, but theyr herte is farre from me, shewynge herby vnto vs that aboue all thynges he wold haue and requyre of vs the good desyre of the herte whych is true prayse and prayer.
column8: This people (sayeth he) does honour me with their mouth, but their heart is far from me, show hereby unto us that above all things he would have and require of us the good desire of the heart which is true praise and prayer.

column7: And thus we shall yelde graces and louynge thankes alwayes vnto God for all thynges in our Lorde Iesu Christ aswell for aduesitie and tribulation, as for prosperitie & welth.
column8: And thus we shall yield graces and loving thanks always unto God for all things in our Lord Jesu Christ aswell for aduesitie and tribulation, as for prosperity & wealth.

column7: For we shall sauour of god in al goodnesse: in such wyse that al thynges that it shal please hym to sende vs, we shall beleue it to be ryght good ordeyned vnto hys glorie and honour, and vnto the saluation of our soules.
column8: For we shall savour of god in all goodness: in such wise that all things that it shall please him to send us, we shall believe it to be right good ordained unto his glory and honour, and unto the salvation of our souls.

column7: And yet we ought to do all thys in the name of Iesu Christ, that is for to saye, that all the goodnes that we shall do, we do knowlege that it is he whych doth it in vs, and we ought to gyue hym the honoure and the glorie.
column8: And yet we ought to do all this in the name of Jesu Christ, that is for to say, that all the goodness that we shall do, we do knowledge that it is he which does it in us, and we ought to gyve him the honour and the glory.

column7: For it is in hym only that the father hath taken pleasure.
column8: For it is in him only that the father hath taken pleasure.

column7: And also we shall suffre all thynges ioyously for the loue of hym whych hath suffred so much for vs. And in hys feare and charitie we must be subiectes the one to the other, for he hymselfe that was mayster and Lord by charitie was made minister & seruaunt vnto all.
column8: And also we shall suffer all things joyously for the love of him which hath suffered so much for us And in his fear and charity we must be subjects the one to the other, for he himself that was master and Lord by charity was made minister & servant unto all.

column7: God gyue vs then grace good people to accoplyshe in al thynges his wyl.
column8: God gyve us then grace good people to accoplyshe in all things his will.

column7: To whom be gyuen al prayse glory and thankes for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be given all praise glory and thanks for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospel on the.xx. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the xx sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.xxij. Chapter of Matthewe.
column8: The xxij Chapter of Matthewe.

column7: Thargument The kyngdome of heuen is resembled to the wedding of a kinges sonne.
column8: Thargument The kingdom of heaven is resembled to the wedding of a kings son.
etc.

column7: I Esus saide vnto his disciples.
column8: IEsus IEsus said unto his disciples.

column7: The kyngdome of heuen is lyke vnto a man that was a kyng, which made a mariage for his sone and sent forth his seruauntes, to cal them that were byd to the weddyng and they wolde not come.
column8: The kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that was a king, which made a marriage for his soon and sent forth his servants, to call them that were bid to the wedding and they would not come.

column7: Agayne, he sente forthe other seruauntes sayeng.
column8: Again, he sent forth other servants saying.

column7: Tell them which are bydden: beholde, I haue prepared my dyner: myne oxe and my fatlynges are kylled, & althynges are ready come vnto the mariage.
column8: Tell them which are bidden: behold, I have prepared my dinner: mine ox and my fatlings are killed, & allthings are ready come unto the marriage.

column7: But they made lyght of it, P A G Eclxx and went theyr wayes: one to his ferme place, another to his marchandise, and the remnaunt toke his seruauntes, and intreted them shamefully and slew them.
column8: But they made light of it, PAGEclxx PAGEclxx PAGEclxx PAGEclxx and went their ways: one to his ferme place, another to his merchandise, and the remnant took his servants, and entreated them shamefully and slew them.

column7: But when the king hard therof, he was wroth and sent forth his me of warre and destroied those murtherers, and bret vp their citie.
column8: But when the king hard thereof, he was wroth and sent forth his me of war and destroyed those murderers, and bret up their city.

column7: Then sayd he to his seruauntes: the mariage in dede is prepared.
column8: Then said he to his servants: the marriage in deed is prepared.

column7: But they which were bydden, were not worthy.
column8: But they which were bidden, were not worthy.

column7: Go ye therfore out into the hye wayes: and as many as ye find byd them to the mariage.
column8: Go you therefore out into the high ways: and as many as you find bid them to the marriage.

column7: And the seruauntes went out into the hye waies, and gathered together all, as many as they coulde fynde, both good and bad, and the weddyng was furnyshed with gestes.
column8: And the servants went out into the high ways, and gathered together all, as many as they could find, both good and bad, and the wedding was furnished with gests.

column7: Then the kynge came in to se the gestes, and whan he spied there a man, which had not on a wedding garmente, he sayde vnto him, frend howe cameste thou in hyther not hauynge a wedding garmente?
column8: Then the king came in to see the gests, and when he spied there a man, which had not on a wedding garment, he said unto him, friend how camest thou in hither not having a wedding garment?

column7: And he was euen spechlesse.
column8: And he was even spechlesse.

column7: Then sayd the kynge to the ministers: take & bind him had & fote, & cast him into vtter darkenes there shall be wepynge and gnashing of teth.
column8: Then said the king to the ministers: take & bind him had & foot, & cast him into utter darkness there shall be weeping and gnashing of teth.

column7: For many be called but fewe are chosen.
column8: For many be called but few are chosen.

column7: T He mooste soueraygne goodnesse of god (good christen people) hathe bene so greate and large towardes vs sely poore synners that when we all worshiped ydoles, seruing the deuell of hell and for our rewarde and stipende descendinge with him vnto eternall deathe and perdition, it yet hathe pleased him of his clemencye for to haue pitie and mercy on vs. And thervpon he vouchesaued to sende none other 1 page duplicate P A G Eclxx 1 page duplicate but euen his own sonne into this worlde for to take our fleshe vpon him and to be made man for to be the spouse (as saynte Gregorie saythe) of our nature then beyng so vyle and vnhappye. <NOTE> This hathe bene for to take vpon him all our synnes and myseryes: and for to gyue and distribute vnto vs all hys graces and richesses.
column8: THe THe most sovereign goodness of god (good christian people) hath be so great and large towards us sely poor sinners that when we all worshipped idols, serving the devil of hell and for our reward and stipend descending with him unto eternal death and perdition, it yet hath pleased him of his clemency for to have pity and mercy on us And thereupon he vouchsafed to send none other 1 page duplicate PAGEclxx PAGEclxx PAGEclxx PAGEclxx 1 page duplicate but even his own son into this world for to take our flesh upon him and to be made man for to be the spouse (as faint Gregorie say) of our nature then being so vile and unhappy. This hath be for to take upon him all our sins and miseries: and for to gyve and distribute unto us all his graces and richesses.

column7: And this as holy doctours expounde is the weddinges wherof oure gospel speaketh, whyche be truly weddinges: of the whyche the bodely and worldly weddinges is but a figure. <NOTE> as we saye, who weddethe the woman, weddethe the debtes, and is boude for to paye them: in like maner our most mercyfull Sauiour Iesu Christe in weddinge oure soules is becommyn debtour and payer of al our synnes, and debtes.
column8: And this as holy doctors expound is the weddings whereof our gospel speaks, which be truly weddings: of the which the bodily and worldly weddings is but a figure. as we say, who weddethe the woman, weddethe the debts, and is boude for to pay them: in like manner our most merciful Saviour Jesu Christe in wedding our souls is becommyn debtor and payer of all our sins, and debts.

column7: And also al the goodes of the husbonde be commyn vnto the wyfe, therfore he hathe made vs possessours & heritours with hym of all hys goodes and his realme, in whyche shalbe truly solemnised the weddinges, & ther shalbe made the greate euerlastinge banket whych he shall make vnto al them that shal haue bene in thys world perseuerantly conioyned and vnied vnto hym by faith.
column8: And also all the goods of the husband be command unto the wife, therefore he hath made us possessors & heritors with him of all his goods and his realm, in which shall truly solemnised the weddings, & there shall made the great everlasting banquet which he shall make unto all them that shall have be in this world perseverantly conjoined and unied unto him by faith.

column7: Vnto the whych weddinges the Iues were called & inuited whyche haue dispised them, and wolde not comme thyther, but haue vilanously slayne the prophetes, and also Iesu Christe himselfe, and some of hys apostles and dysciples that did call them vnto the euerlastinge feaste.
column8: Unto the which weddings the Iues were called & invited which have despised them, and would not comme thither, but have villanously slain the prophets, and also Jesu Christe himself, and some of his apostles and disciples that did call them unto the everlasting feast.

column7: And therfore god hath sente hys men of warre that is to saye, as sainct Hierom and other expositours do expounde thys place, the romaines, Vaspasian and Titus, the whyche haue put the Iewes to death that were such murderers & P A G Eclxxi homicides and haue put their citie in ruyne and destruction.
column8: And therefore god hath sent his men of war that is to say, as saint Hierom and other expositors do expound this place, the romans, Vaspasian and Titus, the which have put the Jewes to death that were such murderers & PAGEclxxi PAGEclxxi PAGEclxxi PAGEclxxi homicides and have put their city in ruin and destruction.

column7: And when the Iewes shewed them selues thus vnworthy of the grace of god whych was thus frely offred and presented vnto them: the apostles & disciples by the commaundemente of god wente to preache vnto the Gentilles whych as then were idolaters, and out of the wayes of god, and did assemble a church, the whych is called catholike, a church of fayth and of christendome.
column8: And when the Jewes showed them selves thus unworthy of the grace of god which was thus freely offered and presented unto them: the apostles & disciples by the commandment of god went to preach unto the Gentiles which as then were idolaters, and out of the ways of god, and did assemble a church, the which is called catholic, a church of faith and of christendome.

column7: And by the visitation that thys kynge maketh for to se them that be sette: is figurid vnto vs the examinatio whych God shall make of all them that be in his churche, which shall do rigorous iustice vpon al them that shall be foud wythoute the weddynge garmente: that is to wytte wythout fayth workinge by charitie or (as S Gregorie expouneth) wythout charitie. <NOTE> He therfore (sayeth this holy doctour) entreth to ye mariages or weddynges wythout the weddynge garmente which in the church hath faith but hath not charitie.
column8: And by the visitation that this king makes for to see them that be set: is figurid unto us the examinatio which God shall make of all them that be in his church, which shall do rigorous justice upon all them that shall be foud without the wedding garment: that is to wit without faith working by charity or (as S Gregorie exponeth) without charity. He therefore (sayeth this holy doctor) entereth to you marriages or weddings without the wedding garment which in the church hath faith but hath not charity.

column7: Or after the mynde of saynt Hierome the weddyng garment be our Lordes commaundementes and the workes whych a man is bound to do by the lawe and gospel and whych make the garment of a newe man which garmente at the daye of iudgemente he that shalbe founde vnder a christen mans name not to haue, is forthwyth taken awey.
column8: Or after the mind of saint Hierome the wedding garment be our Lords commandments and the works which a man is bound to do by the law and gospel and which make the garment of a new man which garment at the day of judgement he that shall found under a christian men name not to have, is forthwith taken away.

column7: And the kynge sayeth vnto him.
column8: And the king sayeth unto him.

column7: Frend how comest thou hither or what makeste thou here not hauing the weddyng wede?
column8: Friend how comest thou hither or what makest thou here not having the wedding weed?

column7: He calleth him frend forasmoch as he was bydde to the mariages as he had bene a frende by fayth.
column8: He calls him friend forasmuch as he was bid to the marriages as he had be a friend by faith.

column7: But he reproueth hym of foly bycause wyth his fylthy garmente he hath defiled the clenes of the mariage.
column8: But he reproveth him of folly because with his filthy garment he hath defiled the cleans of the marriage.

column7: For those that oure Lorde God almyghty the father of heuen doth call vnto this most noble and blessed wedding he woll haue them come not wyth fete (sayeth Chrisostome) but wyth fayth & maners.
column8: For those that our Lord God almighty the father of heaven does call unto this most noble and blessed wedding he will have them come not with feet (sayeth Chrisostome) but with faith & manners.

column7: This weddynge garmet then they ye lacke I meane they yt haue not ye liuely faith which by charitie worketh ye wyl plesure and comaudemetes of oure Lord, albeit in outward apparaunce they haue done many goodly workes & also myracles: yet for all that they shalbe gyuen vnto the mynisters and hangmen of hell, for to be sent vnto the tormentes eternall, hauinge their fete and handes bounde, that is to saye, that they shall neuer desire nor do any thynge that shalbe pleasaut vnto God.
column8: This wedding garmet then they the lack I mean they that have not you lively faith which by charity works you will pleasure and comaudemetes of our Lord, albeit in outward appearance they have done many goodly works & also miracles: yet for all that they shall given unto the ministers and hangmen of hell, for to be sent unto the torments eternal, having their feet and hands bound, that is to say, that they shall never desire nor doe any thing that shall pleasaut unto God.

column7: And for the ende and conclusion of our gospel bycause (as saynt Hierom sayth) not the begynnyng but the ende is to be sought, <NOTE> therfore oure sauyoure Iesu Christ saith that many be called, For assuredly all they that haue herde the apostles and disciples (whose wordes haue bene herde ouer all the earthe) be called but yet fewe be chosen and elected, The whyche sentence oughte to be a wonderfull cause of humilite before god: and specially a cause for vs to despise all the thynges that be in thys worlde for to wynne Iesu christe.
column8: And for the end and conclusion of our gospel because (as saint Hierom say) not the beginning but the end is to be sought, therefore our saviour Jesu Christ says that many be called, For assuredly all they that have herd the apostles and disciples (whose words have be herd over all the earth) be called but yet few be chosen and elected, The which sentence ought to be a wonderful cause of humility before god: and specially a cause for us to despise all the things that be in this world for to win Jesu christe.

column7: Therfore the apostle in the.iij. chapter of his epistle vnto the Colossias doth exhort vs sayenge: Arraye you as chosen of God holy and beloued from the entrayles of mercy, benignite, humilite, mekenesse, and patience.
column8: Therefore the apostle in the iij chapter of his epistle unto the Colossias does exhort us saying: Array you as chosen of God holy and beloved from the entrails of mercy, benignity, humility, meekness, and patience.

column7: Supporte the one the other, and pardone and forgyue one an other amonge your selues, if any hath quarell to other.
column8: Support the one the other, and pardon and forgive one and other among your selves, if any hath quarrel to other.

column7: So as god hathe pardonyd, so pardone you.
column8: So as god hath pardoned, so pardon you.

column7: And aboue all thynges haue charite whych is the bonde of perfection.
column8: And above all things have charity which is the bond of perfection.

column7: P A G Eclxxij If we do thus we shall at laste comme vnto his bankete of the weddinges of the sonne of God and his spouse, and we shall haue the weddinge garment where shalbe nothinge reproched vnto vs: but we shalbe in the nombre of the chosen people, & shall haue the pleasures of the kingdome of heuen.
column8: PAGEclxxij PAGEclxxij PAGEclxxij PAGEclxxij If we do thus we shall at laste comme unto his bankete of the weddings of the son of God and his spouse, and we shall have the wedding garment where shall nothing reproached unto us: but we shall in the number of the chosen people, & shall have the pleasures of the kingdom of heaven.

column7: Vnto the glory of the father and of the sonne & of the holy ghost whych conueyth all them that doth good vnto thys glorious weddinge, wherunto he bryng vs al. Qui viuit et regnat in infinita secula.
column8: Unto the glory of the father and of the son & of the holy ghost which conueyth all them that does good unto this glorious wedding, whereunto he bring us all Qui viuit et regnat in infinita secula.

column7: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the.xxj. sondaye after Trinitie.
column8: Amen.: homily The Epistle on the xxj sondaye after Trinitie.

column7: The.vj. chapter to the Ephesians.
column8: The vj chapter to the Ephesians.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Sayncte Paule doth here describe vnto vs the armour of the christian souldioure.
column8: Saint Paule does here describe unto us the armour of the christian soldier.

column7: MY brethren, be stronge thorow the Lorde and thorowe the power of hys myghte.
column8: MY brothers, be strong thorough the Lord and thorough the power of his might.

column7: Put on al the armour of God, that ye maye stande agaynst the assautes of the deuil.
column8: Put on all the armour of God, that you may stand against the assaults of the devil.

column7: For we wrestle not against bloude and flesh, but agaynst rule, agaynst power, agaynst worldly rulers, euen gouerners of the darkenes of thys worlde, againste spiritual craftynesse in heauenly thynges.
column8: For we wrestle not against blood and flesh, but against rule, against power, against worldly rulers, even governors of the darkness of this world, against spiritual craftynesse in heavenly things.

column7: Wherfore take vnto you the whole armoure of God, that ye maye be hable to resiste in the euell daye, and stande perfecte in all thynges.
column8: Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that you may be able to resist in the evil day, and stand perfect in all things.

column7: Stande therfore, and youre loynes gyrde wyth the trouth, hauyng on the breste plate of ryghteousnes, and hauynge shoes on your fete, that ye maye be prepared for the Gospell of peace.
column8: Stand therefore, and your loins gird with the troth, having on the breast plate of righteousness, and having shoes on your feet, that you may be prepared for the Gospel of peace.

column7: Aboue all, take to you the shild of fayth, wherwith ye may quenche all the fyrye dartes of the wycked.
column8: Above all, take to you the shield of faith, wherewith you may quench all the fyrye darts of the wicked.

column7: And take the helmet of saluation, and the sword of the spirite, whych is the worde of God.
column8: And take the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the spirit, which is the word of God.

column7: MY brethren and frendes ye shal marke & consydre that our enemye the deuel doth warre contynually agaynst vs, and sercheth by all wyles and meanes possible to bryng vs to cofusyon and death, and that we maye be vnable to resiste hys assaultes and powers: The apostle doth therefore teache vs what thyng we haue to do in such and so greate peryls: that is, that we shuld comfort and lyfte vp our selues in God and in hys moste comfortable myght and power. <NOTE> For as it is sayed in ye.xxiij. psalme: The Lorde God is strong and mightye: The Lorde god is mighty in battel.
column8: MY brothers and friends you shall mark & consider that our enemy the devil does war continually against us, and searcheth by all wiles and means possible to bring us to cofusyon and death, and that we may be unable to resist his assaults and powers: The apostle does therefore teach us what thing we have to do in such and so great perils: that is, that we should comfort and lift up our selves in God and in his most comfortable might and power. For as it is said in you xxiij psalm: The Lord God is strong and mighty: The Lord god is mighty in battle.

column7: Certes my fredes it is our Lord Iesus Christe yt the prophete here speaketh of which by hys moste triumphante and gloriouse death and passion hath bene mighty in surmountyng our enemye, I meane, oure mortall enemye the Deuyll.
column8: Certes my fredes it is our Lord Jesus Christe that the prophet here speaks of which by his most triumphant and glorious death and passion hath be mighty in surmounting our enemy, I mean, our mortal enemy the Devil.

column7: Then in thys bytter conflycte and battell that we haue agaynste both hym, the worlde, and the fleshe, let vs take good corage and harte vnto vs: not in trustyng so moch vnto our own power and stregth, but in the strenght and puysaunce of Iesus Christe whyche shall fight for vs, and whych shall not leaue vs that be his membres: but in hym and by hym we shalbe made myghty to resiste & valiauntly to withstande all temptacions, yea and all the maliciouse powers of any princes & myghty men that gouerne the darkenes of this worlde whych wolde inforce vs P A G Eclxxij to vngodlynes or for vngodlynes wolde persecute and afflycte vs. Let vs then take the armour & herneys of god wherwith we maye make resistence and stande stedfast agaynst the strenghtes assaultes and embushementes of the deuyl.
column8: Then in this bitter conflict and battle that we have against both him, the world, and the flesh, let us take good courage and heart unto us: not in trusting so much unto our own power and strength, but in the strength and puysaunce of Jesus Christe which shall fight for us, and which shall not leave us that be his members: but in him and by him we shall made mighty to resist & valiantly to withstand all temptations, yea and all the malicious powers of any princes & mighty men that govern the darkness of this world which would enforce us PAGEclxxij PAGEclxxij PAGEclxxij PAGEclxxij to ungodliness or for ungodliness would persecute and afflycte us Let us then take the armour & herneys of god wherewith we may make resistance and stand steadfast against the strengths assaults and embushementes of the devil.

column7: For if we be knyghtes of Iesu Christ certeynly we must entre in to battayl wyth hym, for there shalbe none crowned, <NOTE> they that shall haue fought worthylye. <NOTE> And what is the armoure of god?
column8: For if we be knights of Jesu Christ certainly we must enter in to battayl with him, for there shall none crowned, they that shall have fought worthily. And what is the armour of god?

column7: Certes it is thys.
column8: Certes it is this.

column7: Firste we muste haue agaynst all corrupt lustes and concupiscences our loynes or raynes gyrthed with trueth.
column8: Firste we must have against all corrupt lusts and concupiscences our loins or reins gyrthed with truth.

column7: Agaynst synne, the brene plate of iustice and innocencye.
column8: Against sin, the brene plate of justice and innocency.

column7: For shoes, we must haue pure affection, whych is the preparacion for to walke in the gospell of peace.
column8: For shoes, we must have pure affection, which is the preparation for to walk in the gospel of peace.

column7: And in all thinges, we muste take faythe for oure shelde: by whych we maye put out the vehement temptacions of the deuell, wherewyth he doth assayle vs as wyth dartes inflamed, the whyche shal by no meanes annoye vs, if we haue stedfast faith in Iesu Christ and in his holy worde.
column8: And in all things, we must take faith for our shield: by which we may put out the vehement temptations of the devil, wherewith he does assail us as with darts inflamed, the which shall by no means annoy us, if we have steadfast faith in Jesu Christ and in his holy word.

column7: For helmet, we must haue hope of saluation.
column8: For helmet, we must have hope of salvation.

column7: And thus armed yet muste we haue the sworde of the spirite, that is the worde of god, by the whyche sworde all the puissances and force of the euyl spirite shalbe cut.
column8: And thus armed yet must we have the sword of the spirit, that is the word of god, by the which sword all the puissances and force of the evil spirit shall cut.

column7: And furthermore we muste neuer leue these armours as longe as we be in thys worlde: for we shall alweyes haue batayle.
column8: And furthermore we must never leave these armours as long as we be in this world: for we shall always have battle.

column7: But by these armours we shall vanquyshe in Iesu Christe, and by Iesu Christ: and not by oure owne strength, vnto hym then be perpetuall glorye togyther wyth the father and holy ghost, in infinita seculorum secula.
column8: But by these armours we shall vanquish in Jesu Christe, and by Jesu Christ: and not by our own strength, unto him then be perpetual glory together with the father and holy ghost, in infinita seculorum secula.

column7: Amen.: homily The gospel on the.xxi. sonday after Trinitie sonday.
column8: Amen.: homily The gospel on the xxi sonday after Trinitie sonday.

column7: The.iiij. chap. of Iohn.
column8: The iiij chap. of John.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Iesus healeth the rulers sonne.
column8: Jesus heals the rulers son.

column7: T Here was a certen ruler, whose sone was sicke at Capernaum.
column8: THere THere was a certain ruler, whose soon was sick at Capernaum.

column7: As sone as the same herd that Iesus was come out of Iewry into Galile, he went vnto hym and besought hym, that he wolde come downe and heale his sonne.
column8: As soon as the same heard that Jesus was come out of Jewry into Galilee, he went unto him and besought him, that he would come down and heal his son.

column7: For he was euen at the poynt of death.
column8: For he was even at the point of death.

column7: The sayde Iesus vnto hym: except ye se sygnes and wodres ye wyl not beleue.
column8: The said Jesus unto him: except you see signs and wodres you will not believe.

column7: The ruler sayeth vnto hym: Syr, come downe or euer that my sone dye.
column8: The ruler sayeth unto him: Sir, come down or ever that my soon die.

column7: Iesus saieth vnto hym: Go thy waye, thy sonne lyueth.
column8: Jesus sayeth unto him: Go thy way, thy son liveth.

column7: The man beleued the worde that Iesus had spoken vnto him.
column8: The man believed the word that Jesus had spoken unto him.

column7: And he wet hys waye.
column8: And he wet his way.

column7: And as he was nowe goinge downe the seruauntes met hym and tolde hym saying: thy sonne lyueth.
column8: And as he was now going down the servants met him and told him saying: thy son liveth.

column7: Then enquired he of them the hour whe he begane to amend.
column8: Then inquired he of them the hour when he began to amend.

column7: And they sayde vnto him: Yester daye at the seuenth houre the feuer left hym.
column8: And they said unto him: Yester day at the seuenth hour the fever left him.

column7: So the father knewe that it was the same hour in the which Iesus sayde vnto him: Thy sonne lyueth.
column8: So the father knew that it was the same hour in the which Jesus said unto him: Thy son liveth.

column7: And he beleued and al hys housholde.
column8: And he believed and all his household.

column7: IN this gospell (good christen audience) our Lord Iesus Christ doth rebuke hym whych desired the health of his sonne, forbicause that he did not beleue sufficiently, that is to saye, that he had not hope in him as he ought to haue.
column8: IN this gospel (good christian audience) our Lord Jesus Christ does rebuke him which desired the health of his son, forbicause that he did not believe sufficiently, that is to say, that he had not hope in him as he ought to have.

column7: And did reproche him that if they se not tokens, they wolde not beleue.
column8: And did reproach him that if they see not tokens, they would not believe.

column7: But ye P A G Eclxxiiij wol say, Why he that desired Christ to heale his son dyd not beleue? <NOTE> To thys doubte thus aunswereth S. Austine.
column8: But you PAGEclxxiiij PAGEclxxiiij PAGEclxxiiij PAGEclxxiiij will say, Why he that desired Christ to heal his son did not believe? To this doubt thus answereth S. Austine.

column7: Aske not me but aske Christe what he thoughte of this ma.
column8: Ask not me but ask Christe what he thought of this ma.

column7: For it foloweth in the text that Iesus sayd vnto hym.
column8: For it followeth in the text that Jesus said unto him.

column7: Onles ye se sygnes and wonders ye wyll not beleue.
column8: Unless you see signs and wonders you will not believe.

column7: So (saith S. Austine) he reproueth him bicause he was colde in fayth or at leste way neither hot nor colde forasmoche as he thought our Sauiour Christ could not help hys sone except he wente home wyth hym, where as in verye dede Christ was able by the only word and commaundement of hys mouth to heal hym namely sith wt hys wil he created and made al thynges of nought wherfore by thys he rebuked all them that do demaunde outward signes.
column8: So (says S. Austine) he reproveth him because he was cold in faith or at lest way neither hight nor cold forasmuch as he thought our Saviour Christ could not help his soon except he went home with him, where as in very deed Christ was able by the only word and commandment of his mouth to heal him namely sith with his will he created and made all things of nought wherefore by this he rebuked all them that do demand outward signs.

column7: For he wil not giue vs any signes, but only the token of his death and resurrection, as only sufficient for oure temporall consolation and eternal saluation, knowinge (as saith saynte Paule) that our olde man (that is our sinnes and concupiscences) is crucified and deade wyth hym: to the ende that we serue no more to sinne, but yt we shuld walke in newnes of lyffe as risen agayne wyth hym.
column8: For he will not give us any signs, but only the token of his death and resurrection, as only sufficient for our temporal consolation and eternal salvation, knowing (as says faint Paule) that our old man (that is our sins and concupiscences) is crucified and dead with him: to the end that we serve no more to sin, but that we should walk in newness of life as risen again with him.

column7: Thys is the token that is giuen vnto vs for our saluation And albeit that he of whom we speake, had not such fayth vnto Iesu Christ as he ought to haue had (for he demaunded hys bodyly presence as neadefull for to helpe hys sone) yet for all that by hys inestimable goodnes, he shewed hymselfe vnto hym suche as he was, that is to saye, God, whyche is not absent from any place, hauyng might by hys only word to heale all maladyes and infirmities as well spirituall as corporal, and sayd vnto hym: Go thy waye, thy sone lyueth and he beleued hys word.
column8: This is the token that is given unto us for our salvation And albeit that he of whom we speak, had not such faith unto Jesu Christ as he ought to have had (for he demanded his bodily presence as neadefull for to help his soon) yet for all that by his inestimable goodness, he showed himself unto him such as he was, that is to say, God, which is not absent from any place, having might by his only word to heal all maladies and infirmities as well spiritual as corporal, and said unto him: Go thy way, thy soon liveth and he believed his word.

column7: And in goyng, dyd mete wyth hys seruautes the whych gaue hym witnesse of the lyfe and health of hys sonne.
column8: And in going, did meet with his seruautes the which gave him witness of the life and health of his son.

column7: And whan he had demaunded of them the houre of the health of hys sonne, and that he knewe yt at the selfe houre that Iesu Christ had spoken the worde he was healed, he beleued the more, and hys fayth was augmeted, and he dydde not only beleue, but also all hys housholde. <NOTE> Wherfore my fredes, the excellent clerke Bede noteth here in thys place that in fayth ther be degrees lyke as in other vertues whych haue initiu incrementum et perfectionem, that is to saye, a begynnynge, an increase, and a perfection.
column8: And when he had demanded of them the hour of the health of his son, and that he knew that at the self hour that Jesu Christ had spoken the word he was healed, he believed the more, and his faith was augmeted, and he did not only believe, but also all his household. Wherefore my fredes, the excellent clerk Bede notes here in this place that in faith there be degrees like as in other virtues which have initiu incrementum et perfectionem, that is to say, a beginning, and increase, and a perfection.

column7: The faythe then of thys man had begynnynge, when he asked hys sones health: increase, when he beleued Christes wordes, saynge, thy sonne lyueth: perfection, when hys seruauntes brought hym tydynges yt hys sone was hole in dede & aboute what tyme he recouered.
column8: The faith then of this man had beginning, when he asked his sons health: increase, when he believed Christes words, saying, thy son liveth: perfection, when his servants brought him tidings that his soon was hold in deed & about what time he recovered.

column7: O howe the worde of god is myghty and of greate power, the whych destroyeth thus al syknesses, principally infidelite, whych is the greuoust syknes that maye be: for yt is cause of death not only bodely but eternall.
column8: O how the word of god is mighty and of great power, the which destroyeth thus all syknesses, principally infidelite, which is the greuoust sickness that may be: for that is cause of death not only bodily but eternal.

column7: Let vs then haue fayth and stedfast hope in our Lord Iesu Christ, whych seeth all and knoweth all and whyche is in all places.
column8: Let us then have faith and steadfast hope in our Lord Jesu Christ, which sees all and knoweth all and which is in all places.

column7: And wyth one onlye worde shall he gyue vs lyfe both bodely and gostly, vnto the glory of the celestiall father whych healeth all and wyll heale all that be sycke by him.
column8: And with one only word shall he gyve us life both bodily and ghostly, unto the glory of the celestial father which heals all and will heal all that be sick by him.

column7: Qui uiuit et regnat.
column8: Qui uiuit et regnat.

column7: &c. Amen.: homily Thepistle on the.xxij. Sondaye after Trinitie sonday.
column8: etc. Amen.: homily Thepistle on the xxij Sondaye after Trinitie sonday.

column7: The first chap. to the Philippyans.
column8: The first chap. to the Philippyans.

column7: P A G Eclxxiiij Thargument Paule wishethe that the grace of god & charitie myght increase in vs.
column8: PAGEclxxiiij PAGEclxxiiij PAGEclxxiiij PAGEclxxiiij Thargument Paule wisheth that the grace of god & charity might increase in us

column7: B Rethren, we trust in our Lord Iesu Christ, that he whych hath begonne a good worke in you, shall performe it vntyll the daye of Iesus Christ, as it becomethe me so to iudge of you all, because I haue you in my harte: forasmoche as ye al are companyons of grace with me, euen in my bondes, and in the defendinge and stablyshynge of the gospell.
column8: BRethren BRethren, we trust in our Lord Jesu Christ, that he which hath begun a good work in you, shall perform it until the day of Jesus Christ, as it becometh me so to judge of you all, because I have you in my heart: forasmuch as you all are companions of grace with me, even in my bonds, and in the defending and stablishing of the gospel.

column7: For god is my record, how gretly I long after you all from the very hert rote in Iesus Christ.
column8: For god is my record, how greatly I long after you all from the very heart rote in Jesus Christ.

column7: And this I pray, that your loue maye increace yet more and more in knowledge and in all vnderstandinge, that ye maye accepte the thyngs that are most excellet, that ye maye be pure, and suche, as hurte no mans concsiens vntyll the daye of Christe: beyng fylled with the frute of ryghtousnes, which frute cometh by Iesus Christ vnto the glory and prayse of god.
column8: And this I pray, that your love may increase yet more and more in knowledge and in all understanding, that you may accept the things that are most excellet, that you may be pure, and such, as hurt no men concsiens until the day of Christe: being filled with the fruit of righteousness, which fruit comes by Jesus Christ unto the glory and praise of god.

column7: T He apostle saynt Paule good people doth here teach vs that we must abyde and wayte for fro God the perfection and accomplyshyng of all good workes begonne, sayeng: that it apperteyneth vnto hym to make an ende of the woorke that he hath begonne, the whych is wtout doute the worke of fayth whych worketh by charytie.
column8: THe THe apostle saint Paule good people does here teach us that we must abide and wait for from God the perfection and accomplishing of all good works begun, saying: that it appertaineth unto him to make and end of the work that he hath begun, the which is without doubt the work of faith which works by charity.

column7: For Iesu Christe sayeth in the.vj. chapter of saynt Ihon: <NOTE> Yt is the worke of God (sayeth oure Lorde) that ye beleue in hym that he hath sente.
column8: For Jesu Christe sayeth in the vj chapter of saint Ihon: It is the work of God (sayeth our Lord) that you believe in him that he hath sent.

column7: And also Iesu Christe is called auctor of fayth.
column8: And also Jesu Christe is called auctor of faith.

column7: Also it apperteyneth vnto God for to gyue vs perseuerance and contynuauce in the same fayth vnto the daye of Iesu Christe, as it is written in the.xxxvi. psalme.
column8: Also it appertaineth unto God for to gyve us perseverance and continuance in the same faith unto the day of Jesu Christe, as it is written in the xxxvi psalm.

column7: The afflictions of man shalbe redressed in welth by god, wherby we maye lightly vnderstand that man as of hymselfe cannot do any good: and that all they whych vaunte them of theyr power, do erre and blaspheme agaynste God, when they attribute vnto theselfes yt whych apperteyneth vnto God, whose power it is when we do any good.
column8: The afflictions of man shall redressed in wealth by god, whereby we may lightly understand that man as of himself cannot do any good: and that all they which vaunt them of their power, do err and blaspheme against God, when they attribute unto theselfes that which appertaineth unto God, whose power it is when we do any good.

column7: The daye of Iesu Christe is the daye of the death of euery body: <NOTE> and to speke generally, it is domes daye at the whych daye he shall yelde vnto euery one accordyng vnto hys fayth, or infidelitie, that they shal haue folowed: vnto the faythfull, lyfe eternall, and vnto the vnfaythfull, the deathe eternall.
