column8: The day of Jesu Christe is the day of the death of every body: and to speak generally, it is domes day at the which day he shall yield unto every one according unto his faith, or infidelity, that they shall have followed: unto the faithful, life eternal, and unto the unfaithful, the death eternal.

column7: And the apostle might iustly thynke of the Philippians that god wold do vnto them this grace for to make them to perseuer vnto thende, for the charite that he had vnto them, the which beleue lightly al thinges that is to the honour, & forbycause also that themselues did reioyce, when they had vnderstande that in prysonmente at Rome he defended hym after suche a sorte that it was vnto the confirmation of the gospell, and the greate ioye of the same.
column8: And the apostle might justly think of the Philippians that god would do unto them this grace for to make them to persever unto th'end, for the charity that he had unto them, the which believe lightly all things that is to the honour, & forbycause also that themselves did rejoice, when they had understand that in prysonmente at Room he defended him after such a sort that it was unto the confirmation of the gospel, and the great joy of the same.

column7: And therfore he prayed them that thys charytie towarde god, and loue vnto hys worde might aboude and increase alwayes more & more, in the knowlege of god, and in all spirituall sense for to discerne and approue the meruelouse thynges, and for to be pure and clene, and without offending and rebuke at the day of our lorde Iesu Christ, both particuler & vniuersal, al replenished with ye frute of iustice which is P A G Eclxxvi ye iustice of faith by our lord Iesu christ vnto ye glory of ye eternal father.
column8: And therefore he prayed them that this charity toward god, and love unto his word might aboude and increase always more & more, in the knowledge of god, and in all spiritual sense for to discern and approve the marvelous things, and for to be pure and clean, and without offending and rebuke at the day of our lord Jesu Christ, both particular & universal, all replenished with you fruit of justice which is PAGEclxxvi PAGEclxxvi PAGEclxxvi PAGEclxxvi the justice of faith by our lord Jesu christ unto the glory of you eternal father.

column7: In this saint Paule giueth vs to vnderstand how yt al begynning & the endes of good workes ought to be attributed vnto God.
column8: In this saint Paule gives us to understand how that all beginning & the ends of good works ought to be attributed unto God.

column7: And ye charytie whych one ought to haue to another when one heareth or vnderstadeth that the worde of God doth growe, it augmenteth and confirmeth, whych is the doctrine of the Gospell, for in the same is the true science and knowlege of god, and the wit of the holy ghost: wherby one maye proue and assaye the better thinges whych be the welthes spirituall and heuenly.
column8: And you charity which one ought to have to another when one hears or vnderstadeth that the word of God does grow, it augmenteth and confirmeth, which is the doctrine of the Gospel, for in the same is the true science and knowledge of god, and the wit of the holy ghost: whereby one may prove and assay the better things which be the wealths spiritual and heavenly.

column7: The whyche graunt vs the heuenly father by our lorde Iesu Christ.
column8: The which grant us the heavenly father by our lord Jesu Christ.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The gospel on the.xxii. Sonday. the xviij. chapter of Mathewe.
column8: : homily The gospel on the xxii Sonday. the xviij. chapter of Mathewe.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: The parable of the kinge that forgaue hys seruaunte whiche was founde in arerages vnto hym vpon his accomptes.
column8: The parable of the king that forgave his servant which was found in arerages unto him upon his accounts.

column7: I Esus put forth a similitude vnto hys discyples, sayeng, the kyngdome of heuen ys lykened vnto a certeyn man that was a kynge, whych wolde take accomptes of hys seruauntes.
column8: IEsus IEsus put forth a similitude unto his disciples, saying, the kingdom of heaven is likened unto a certain man that was a king, which would take accounts of his servants.

column7: And when he had begonne to reken, one was brought vnto hym whych ought him ten thousand talentes, but forasmoche as he was not able to paye, hys lorde commaunded hym to be solde, and his wyfe and hys chyldren, and all that he had, and paymente to be made.
column8: And when he had begun to reckon, one was brought unto him which ought him ten thousand talents, but forasmuch as he was not able to pay, his lord commanded him to be sold, and his wife and his children, and all that he had, and paymente to be made.

column7: The seruaunt fell downe and besought him sayeng.
column8: The servant fell down and besought him saying.

column7: Syr haue pacience with me, and I wyll paye the all.
column8: Sir have patience with me, and I will pay the all.

column7: The had the lorde pytie on that seruaunte, and lowsede him and forgaue him the det.
column8: The had the lord pity on that servant, and lowsede him and forgave him the debt.

column7: So the same seruaunt went oute, and founde one of hys felowes, whyche ought him an hundreth pence, and he layde handes on hym, and toke him by the throte, sayeng: paye that thou owest.
column8: So the same servant went out, and found one of his fellows, which ought him and hundreth pence, and he laid hands on him, and took him by the throat, saying: pay that thou owest.

column7: And hys felow fell downe and besought him sayenge: haue pacience wyth me, and I wyl paye the al. And he wold not, but went and cast hi into preso, tyl he shuld paye the det.
column8: And his fellow fell down and besought him saying: have patience with me, and I will pay the all And he would not, but went and cast him into preso, till he should pay the debt.

column7: So when his felowes saw what was done, they were very sory, and came and tolde vnto their Lorde all that had happened.
column8: So when his fellows saw what was done, they were very sorry, and came and told unto their Lord all that had happened.

column7: Then his Lord called hym and sayd vnto him: O thou vngracious seruaunt, I forgaue the al that dette whan thou desyredst me: shuldest not thou also haue had compassion on thy felow euen as I had pytie on the?
column8: Then his Lord called him and said unto him: Oh thou ungracious servant, I forgave the all that debt when thou desyredst me: shouldst not thou also have had compassion on thy fellow even as I had pity on thee?

column7: And his lord was wrothe and delyuered him to the ^aylers tyll he shuld paye al that was due vnto him.
column8: And his lord was wroth and delivered him to the aylers till he should pay all that was due unto him.

column7: And his Lord was wrooth, and delyuered him to the iaylers, tyl he shuld paye all that was due vnto hym.
column8: And his Lord was wrooth, and delivered him to the jailers, till he should pay all that was due unto him.

column7: So lykewyse shall my heauenly father do also vnto you if ye from youre hartes forgyue not euerye one hys brother theyr trespasses.
column8: So likewise shall my heavenly father do also unto you if you from your hearts forgive not every one his brother their trespasses.

column7: In the parable declared in the gospell of this daye good people is shewed vnto vs howe god shall make hys iudgement of synners that shall not haue asked him mercy, Agayn al those whych shal knowledge themselues synners before hym and shall demaunde mercy and grace of hym he shall pardone P A G Eclxxvi them of al their synnes, if so be they do remytte and pardone also wyth good harte and in charyte for the loue of hym the synnes & offences that theyr neyghbours haue commytted agaynste them.
column8: In the parable declared in the gospel of this day good people is showed unto us how god shall make his judgement of sinners that shall not have asked him mercy, Again all those which shall knowledge themselves sinners before him and shall demand mercy and grace of him he shall pardon PAGEclxxvi PAGEclxxvi PAGEclxxvi PAGEclxxvi them of all their sins, if so be they do remytte and pardon also with good heart and in charity for the love of him the sins & offences that their neighbours have committed against them.

column7: For it is the rule to obteyne pardone of god for to forgyue.
column8: For it is the rule to obtain pardon of god for to forgive.

column7: As it is wrytten in the prayer that oure lorde Iesu Christe hath gyuen vs for to pray vnto his father and ours, when we saye, <NOTE> Et dimitte nobis debita nostra sicut et nos dimittimus debitoribus nostris, that is to say Forgyue vs our trespssaes as we forgyue them that trespasse agaynst vs. And after our lord sayth, if you pardon men theyr synnes, your father also that is in heuen shall pardone you your faultes.
column8: As it is written in the prayer that our lord Jesu Christe hath given us for to pray unto his father and ours, when we say, Et dimitte nobis debita nostra sicut et nos dimittimus debitoribus nostris, that is to say Forgive us our trespssaes as we forgive them that trespass against us And after our lord say, if you pardon men their sins, your father also that is in heaven shall pardon you your faults.

column7: And if we do not pardon nor forgyue othr men, nomore woll your father pardon nor remytte you of your synnes.
column8: And if we do not pardon nor forgive othr men, nomore will your father pardon nor remytte you of your sins.

column7: Alas my fredes howe many be there nowe a dayes whych thynke lytle on these wordes, as if they were vayne and of none effect.
column8: Alas my fredes how many be there now a days which think little on these words, as if they were vain and of none effect.

column7: And yet for al that, they be so true that it is a iudgement gyuen from ye mouth of god, which is al trouth.
column8: And yet for all that, they be so true that it is a judgement given from you mouth of god, which is all troth.

column7: Ther be many which oftentymes do saye thys most holy prayer without hauinge any will to forgyue the offences comytted against them, the whych suerly were better not to praye so agaynst themselues.
column8: There be many which oftentimes do say this most holy prayer without having any will to forgive the offences comytted against them, the which surely were better not to pray so against themselves.

column7: This is well shewed vnto vs by the parable of the kingdome of heuen in thys present gospell, of the seruaunt whych ought ten thousande talentes vnto his kinge.
column8: This is well showed unto us by the parable of the kingdom of heaven in this present gospel, of the servant which ought ten thousande talents unto his king.

column7: And when he had not wherewyth he myght paye it, the kinge commaunded, that he and hys wife and hys chyldren and al his goodes shulde be solde, to thentente that he myght be payed of that that was due vnto him.
column8: And when he had not wherewith he might pay it, the king commanded, that he and his wife and his children and all his goods should be sold, to tenteth that he might be paid of that that was due unto him.

column7: The seruaunt seyng thys kneled down and prayed the king that he wold take patience and tary and he wolde paye him all.
column8: The servant sing this kneed down and prayed the king that he would take patience and tarry and he would pay him all.

column7: The lorde that was pitiful and mercifull had mercy on hym, and sente him awaye and forgaue hym the dette.
column8: The lord that was pitiful and merciful had mercy on him, and sent him away and forgave him the debt.

column7: But the seruaunte departinge from hys lorde, was not pitifull nor merciful as was hys lord.
column8: But the servant departing from his lord, was not pitiful nor merciful as was his lord.

column7: For in meting an other yt was seruaunt with him which ought him only an hundreth pens, he toke him and strayned him by the throte and misintreatinge him sayd, paye me that, that thou owest me.
column8: For in meeting and other that was servant with him which ought him only and hundreth pens, he took him and strained him by the throat and misintreatinge him said, pay me that, that thou owest me.

column7: And the pore seruant knelyd before the first seruant, & prayed him to haue pacience & to tarye and he wolde paye hym all.
column8: And the poor servant kneeled before the first servant, & prayed him to have patience & to tarry and he would pay him all.

column7: But he wolde not heare hym, but forthwith sente him to prison, vnto the tyme that he had payed him. but what did the lorde when he herde these newes?
column8: But he would not hear him, but forthwith sent him to prison, unto the time that he had paid him. but what did the lord when he herd these news?

column7: He keste in his teth the mercy whiche he had vsed towardes him, when he prayed hym, and on the other syde the cruelty whiche he had vsed agaynst his felowe seruaut.
column8: He cast in his teth the mercy which he had used towards him, when he prayed him, and on the other side the cruelty which he had used against his fellow seruaut.

column7: And therupon he dyd gyue him to the kepars of ye prison, vntyl he had payed al his dutye.
column8: And thereupon he did gyve him to the kepars of the prison, until he had paid all his duty.

column7: And this parable our lorde declareth himselfe.
column8: And this parable our lord declareth himself.

column7: This kynge, is god the father almyghty.
column8: This king, is god the father almighty.

column7: This fyrste dettour: is a great synner to god.
column8: This fyrste debtor: is a great sinner to god.

column7: This seconde dettour is a lytle synner to man.
column8: This seconde debtor is a little sinner to man.

column7: And what may the offence be vnto man, but only a lytle offence to the regarde of that whiche is to god?
column8: And what may the offence be unto man, but only a little offence to the regard of that which is to god?

column7: And that yt is to god what may it be but a ryght greate offence?
column8: And that that is to god what may it be but a right great offence?

column7: For as the auncient douctour of the churche Iohn Chrysostom sayeth, <NOTE> there is as greate difference betwene the synnes whiche be done to men and the synnes whiche be comitted agaynste god, as there is difference betwene ten thousade talentes of golde & an hundreth pense.
column8: For as the ancient douctour of the church John Chrysostom sayeth, there is as great difference between the sins which be done to men and the sins which be committed against god, as there is difference between ten thousade talents of gold & and hundreth pense.

column7: But God is so meke and so mercyfull, that if alonly P A G Eclxxvij one do praye hym, he forgiueth all synne and offence howe greate so euer it be, yf that in folowyng of hys meakenesse and mercyfulnesse we pardone one lytle offence agaynste vs vnto our brother.
column8: But God is so meek and so merciful, that if alonely PAGEclxxvij PAGEclxxvij PAGEclxxvij PAGEclxxvij one doe pray him, he forgives all sin and offence how great so ever it be, if that in following of his meakenesse and mercyfulnesse we pardon one little offence against us unto our brother.

column7: But yf any of vs do not pardon, God shal aske of hym the greate debte, <NOTE> and he shalbe in paynes vntyll he shall haue payed it out, whyche worde (vntyll) is taken of holy doctours, pro infinito. And thys is the meanynge & sense of thys texte sayeth Remigius ye auncient doctour, semper soluet, sed nunquam persoluet, <NOTE> et semper poenam luet, that is to saye, he shall euer paye but neuer paye it out, and he shall euermore suffre payne.
column8: But if any of us do not pardon, God shall ask of him the great debt, and he shall in pains until he shall have paid it out, which word (until) is taken of holy doctors, pro infiinite. And this is the meaning & sense of this text sayeth Remigius the ancient doctor, semper soluet, sed nunquam persoluet, et semper poenam luet, that is to say, he shall ever pay but never pay it out, and he shall evermore suffer pain.

column7: Then my brethren and frendes, though that it be so that all the offences agaynst vs in the world be nothynge in regarde of one only offence agaynst God: let vs then pardone them lightly not alonlye by mouth and outwardly, but wyth good wyll, and in our hartes inwardly.
column8: Then my brothers and friends, though that it be so that all the offences against us in the world be nothing in regard of one only offence against God: let us then pardon them lightly not alonely by mouth and outwardly, but with good will, and in our hearts inwardly.

column7: And yf we thus do, assuredly God shall pardone vs them that be so greate (for who is it that hath not offended hym many tymes) and we shalbe fynally made ye chyldren of God and followers of hys swetenesse, meakenes, and mercye.
column8: And if we thus do, assuredly God shall pardon us them that be so great (for who is it that hath not offended him many times) and we shall finally made you children of God and followers of his sweetness, meakenes, and mercy.

column7: The whyche it shall please thys greate kynge to graunte vs (vnto whom we be all so greate detters) the father of mercy, by our Lorde Iesus Christe, by whom he hathe done and doth mercy vnto all.
column8: The which it shall please this great king to grant us (unto whom we be all so great debtors) the father of mercy, by our Lord Jesus Christe, by whom he hath done and does mercy unto all.

column7: To whom be gyuen al honour glory and prayse for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be given all honour glory and praise for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Pystle on the.xxiij. Sonday after Trinyte sonday.
column8: : homily The Pystle on the xxiij Sonday after Trinyte sonday.

column7: The thyrde chapiter to the Philippians.
column8: The thyrde chapter to the Philippians.

column7: Thargument Paule exhorteth vs to folowe him and such other holy men in lyuinge.
column8: Thargument Paule exhorteth us to follow him and such other holy men in living.

column7: B Rethre, be folowers together of me, and loke on them whiche walke euen so, as ye haue vs for an ensample.
column8: BRethre BRethre, be followers together of me, and look on them which walk even so, as you have us for and ensample.

column7: For many walke (of whom I haue tolde you often, and now tell you wepynge) that they are the enemies of the crosse of Christ, whose end is danacion, whose bely is their god, and glory to theyr shame, whych are worldly mynded.
column8: For many walk (of whom I have told you often, and now tell you weeping) that they are the enemies of the cross of Christ, whose end is danacion, whose belly is their god, and glory to their shame, which are worldly minded.

column7: But our couersacion is in heauen, from whence we loke for the sauiour, euen the Lorde Iesus Christ, which shall chaunge our vyle bodye, that he may make it lyke vnto his glorious body: according to the workyng, wherby he is hable also to subdue all thinges vnto him selfe.
column8: But our couersacion is in heaven, from whence we look for the saviour, even the Lord Jesus Christ, which shall change our vile body, that he may make it like unto his glorious body: according to the working, whereby he is able also to subdue all things unto him self.

column7: S Aynt Paul my welbeloued frendes, doth exhort vs in this epistle, that we shuld be his folowers that is to saye, that we shulde lyue lyke vnto him, folowynge the worde of fayth and of grace, whyche is the truthe of the gospell, and that we shulde so folowe the fourme and rule which is giuen vnto vs and that we shuld take exemple of them which lyue according to the same.
column8: SAynt SAynt Paul my well-beloved friends, does exhort us in this epistle, that we should be his followers that is to say, that we should live like unto him, following the word of faith and of grace, which is the truth of the gospel, and that we should so follow the form and rule which is given unto us and that we should take exemple of them which live according to the same.

column7: For there be some other whyche be enemyes vnto the gospel and vnto the crosse, that is to say of ye tribulatios suffred by Iesu Christ louyng the glory of the worlde, which is confusion, makyng god of theyr bely, and they be not to be followed, but occcasion to vepe.
column8: For there be some other which be enemies unto the gospel and unto the cross, that is to say of you tribulatios suffered by Jesu Christ loving the glory of the world, which is confusion, making god of their belly, and they be not to be followed, but occasion to vepe.

column7: For our glory, our lyfe and conuersacion is not in earthly thynges, but in heauely thynges from whence also we do abyde our Lorde Iesu Christe at his seconde commyng: which P A G Eclxxvjii shal forme our body of newe, beyng now vyle, abiect corruptible & mortall, into a body noble, profytable incorruptible, & immortall.
column8: For our glory, our life and conversation is not in earthly things, but in heavily things from whence also we do abide our Lord Jesu Christe at his seconde coming: which PAGEclxxvjii PAGEclxxvjii PAGEclxxvjii PAGEclxxvjii shall form our body of new, being now vile, abject corruptible & mortal, into a body noble, profitable incorruptible, & immortal.

column7: And he shall fygure and chaunge it vnto the similytude of the clearnesse and glorye of hys body, by the power that he hath for to make all thynges to obey at hys wyll. <NOTE> the apostle prayeth vs (and it is good reason yt we shuld so do) that we do kepe ourselues stedfaste in the rule and couersation of ye Gospell. <NOTE> And thys he reputeth and taketh to be hys crowne and hys glorye, yf that by hys exhortation and motion we do thus.
column8: And he shall figure and change it unto the similitude of the clearness and glory of his body, by the power that he hath for to make all things to obey at his will. the apostle prayeth us (and it is good reason that we should so do) that we do keep ourselves steadfast in the rule and conversation of the Gospel. And this he reputeth and takes to be his crown and his glory, if that by his exhortation and motion we do thus.

column7: Yt is charitie yt thus constreyneth the hartes of faythfull men for to desyre the saluation of euery bodye.
column8: It is charity that thus constreyneth the hearts of faithful men for to desire the salvation of every body.

column7: And thys charytie dyd not alonly extende vnto men, but also vnto women, of the which here he prayeth some of them, that is to wit, Euodia and Synticha, that they shulde vnderstande none other thinge, but only this forme and rule of the gospell.
column8: And this charity did not alonely extend unto men, but also unto women, of the which here he prayeth some of them, that is to wit, Euodia and Synticha, that they should understand none other thing, but only this form and rule of the gospel.

column7: And yet furthermore he prayeth an other whyche he calleth his dere beloued felowe that she wolde helpe all them whych had laboured wyth him, and wyth Clement vnto the furtheraunce & promotion of the gospell, of whome (sayth he) the names be wrytten in the boke of liefe.
column8: And yet furthermore he prayeth and other which he calls his dear beloved fellow that she would help all them which had laboured with him, and with Clement unto the furtherance & promotion of the gospel, of whom (say he) the names be written in the book of lief.

column7: And what helpe doth he desyre that she shuld do vnto them but only to comforte and strengthe them in this purpose, for to drawe alweyes the other, aswell the virgins as the olde women vnto the fayth and vnto ye doctrine of the gospel, the whych is the only rule of lief, & that of eternal life.
column8: And what help does he desire that she should do unto them but only to comfort and strength them in this purpose, for to draw always the other, aswell the virgins as the old women unto the faith and unto the doctrine of the gospel, the which is the only rule of lief, & that of eternal life.

column7: Then my fredes as wel men as wome, let vs hold this only rule.
column8: Then my fredes as well men as wome, let us hold this only rule.

column7: Let vs teache them yt be not so perfite as we oure selues be.
column8: Let us teach them that be not so perfect as we our selves be.

column7: Let vs take exemple of them whych be iuste & stedfaste in fayth and ernest louers of the Gospell.
column8: Let us take exemple of them which be just & steadfast in faith and earnest lovers of the Gospel.

column7: Let vs haue in abhomination the lyfe of the enemyes of the Gospell, and of them yt do not set by the paynes trauayles afflictions death & passyon that our Lord hath suffred for to redeme vs and them, and for to gyue vs the celestiall treasures.
column8: Let us have in abomination the life of the enemies of the Gospel, and of them that do not set by the pains travails afflictions death & passion that our Lord hath suffered for to redeem us and them, and for to gyve us the celestial treasures.

column7: And let vs wepe in our hartes for theyr myscheuous and abhominable lyfe, prayeng vnto God yt he wyll gyue them light, and that they maye not trouble any by theyr euyll lyfe and wicked exemple.
column8: And let us weep in our hearts for their mischievous and abominable life, praying unto God that he will gyve them light, and that they may not trouble any by their evil life and wicked exemple.

column7: Let our hartes be where oure treasure is, whych is in heauen and not in the earth.
column8: Let our hearts be where our treasure is, which is in heaven and not in the earth.

column7: Let vs be stedfast and vnchaungeable in this fayth and purpose of the Gospel.
column8: Let us be steadfast and unchangeable in this faith and purpose of the Gospel.

column7: Let vs laboure as well men as women that all maye come vnto thys light, vnto the only worde of God lyuynge.
column8: Let us labour as well men as women that all may come unto this light, unto the only word of God living.

column7: Let vs coforte them in thys yt we all haue but one doctrine, one God, and one helper.
column8: Let us coforte them in this that we all have but one doctrine, one God, and one helper.

column7: Let all our hope be there, as was the hope of saynt Paule, and of Clement, of Euodia, of Syntycha, and of all the other faythfull and true christen people of the fyrste and primatyue churche.
column8: Let all our hope be there, as was the hope of saint Paule, and of Clement, of Euodia, of Syntycha, and of all the other faithful and true christian people of the fyrste and primatyue church.

column7: And be we then well assured yt oure names shalbe wrytten with them in heuen euen in the boke of liefe, vnto the glory of the father of heue and our lorde Iesu Christe.
column8: And be we then well assured that our names shall written with them in heaven even in the book of lief, unto the glory of the father of heaven and our lord Jesu Christe.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospel on the.xxiij. sonday after Trinitie.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the xxiij sonday after Trinitie.

column7: The.xxij. Chapter of Matthewe.
column8: The xxij Chapter of Matthewe.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Christe is demaunded whether it be lawfull to paye tribute to Cesar or not.
column8: Christe is demanded whither it be lawful to pay tribute to Cesar or not.

column7: T He pharisees went and toke councel how they myght tangle hym in his wordes.
column8: THe THe pharisees went and took council how they might tangle him in his words.

column7: And they P A G Eclxxix sente oute vnto hym their disciples with Herodes seruautes, saieg.
column8: And they PAGEclxxix PAGEclxxix PAGEclxxix PAGEclxxix sent out unto him their disciples with Herodes seruautes, saieg.

column7: Master we know that thou art true and teachest the waye of god truly, neyther careste thou for eny man, for thou regardest not the outwarde apparaunce of men.
column8: Master we know that thou art true and teachest the way of god truly, neither carest thou for any man, for thou regardest not the outward appearance of men.

column7: Tell vs therfore, howe thinkest thou?
column8: Tell us therefore, how thinkest thou?

column7: Is it lawful that tribute be gyuen vnto Cesar or not?
column8: Is it lawful that tribute be given unto Cesar or not?

column7: But Iesus perceyuing their wickednes sayde.
column8: But Jesus perceiving their wickedness said.

column7: Why tempte ye me ye ypocrites? shewe me the tribute money.
column8: Why tempt you me the hypocrites? show me the tribute money.

column7: And they toke him a peny.
column8: And they took him a penny.

column7: And he sayde vnto them, whose is this ymage and superscription?
column8: And he said unto them, whose is this image and superscription?

column7: They sayde vnto him, Cesars.
column8: They said unto him, Cesars.

column7: Then sayed he vnto them.
column8: Then said he unto them.

column7: Geue therfore vnto Cesar, the thinges which are Cesars, and vnto god those thinges that are godes.
column8: Give therefore unto Cesar, the things which are Cesars, and unto god those things that are gods.

column7: T He Gospell of this present sondaye good people putteth before vs, the malice of the pharasies which did send their disciples wyth the Herodians, <NOTE> which herodians after the mynd of saynte Hierom were the souldiours of Herod (for the pharasies durst not go themselues for feare of ye people) wherfore they sent theyr disciples wyth these souldiours, for to attrappe our Lorde and to fynde out some occasion for to delyuer hym to death.
column8: THe THe Gospel of this present sondaye good people putteth before us, the malice of the pharasies which did send their disciples with the Herodians, which herodians after the mind of faint Hierom were the soldiers of Herod (for the pharasies durst not go themselves for fear of you people) wherefore they sent their disciples with these soldiers, for to attrappe our Lord and to find out some occasion for to deliver him to death.

column7: And they came subtylly accordyng to the malyce of the worlde and of the fleshe flattering and sayeng, maister.
column8: And they came subtly according to the malice of the world and of the flesh flattering and saying, master.

column7: This is the first simulation of hypocrites (saythe Chrysostomus) to praise them whome we go aboute to destroy and vndo. <NOTE> And therfore they breake out into prayse sayeng Maister we knowe that thou arte rightfull & a teller of trouth.
column8: This is the first simulation of hypocrites (say Chrysostomus) to praise them whom we go about to destroy and undo. And therefore they break out into praise saying Master we know that thou art rightful & a teller of troth.

column7: They call him maister to thintet that beynge nowe honoured and praysed of them he myght open simplely the secretes of hys harte vnto them as desyrouse to haue them hys dyscyples.
column8: They call him master to thintet that being now honoured and praised of them he might open simply the secrets of his heart unto them as desirous to have them his disciples.

column7: We knowe (saye they) that thou art rightfull and yt thou teachest the doctrine of God in trouth, and regardest no persone, as who shulde saye, thou haste respecte neyther to Herode nor yet to Cesar, whych exacteth tribute of vs but only teachest frely ye trouth.
column8: We know (say they) that thou art rightful and that thou teachest the doctrine of God in troth, and regardest no person, as who should say, thou haste respect neither to Herode nor yet to Cesar, which exacteth tribute of us but only teachest freely the troth.

column7: Therfore shewe vs playnly we beseche the if it be leful for vs to gyue tribute vnto Cesar or no?
column8: Therefore show us plainly we beseech the if it be leful for us to gyve tribute unto Cesar or no?

column7: Oure sauiour and maister Iesus Christ whych knoweth all mens thoughtes sayde vnto them.
column8: Oure saviour and master Jesus Christ which knoweth all men's thoughts said unto them.

column7: Wherfore do ye tempte me you hypocrites?
column8: Wherefore do you tempt me you hypocrites?

column7: He answereth them, not fayerly accordinge to their fayer wordes but roughly accordinge to their cruel conscience.
column8: He answereth them, not fayerly according to their fair words but roughly according to their cruel conscience.

column7: For god is wonte to aunswere to the will & not to the word.
column8: For god is wont to answer to the will & not to the word.

column7: And he sayth vnto them.
column8: And he say unto them.

column7: Shewe me ye money of the tribute?
column8: Show me the money of the tribute?

column7: And they did gyue him a pece.
column8: And they did gyve him a piece.

column7: And he demauded of them (to thende that he shuld shame them with their own wordes) whose was the ymage & the superscription?
column8: And he demauded of them (to th'end that he should shame them with their own words) whose was the image & the superscription?

column7: And they aunswered, of Cesar.
column8: And they answered, of Cesar.

column7: And then he aunswered them.
column8: And then he answered them.

column7: The yelde ye vnto Cesar, the thinges that apperteyne vnto Cesar.
column8: The yield you unto Cesar, the things that appertain unto Cesar.

column7: And paye to god that which belongeth to god.
column8: And pay to god that which belongeth to god.

column7: But these dissemblers surely did not vnderstande this aunswere, for they loked that he shulde haue sayde eyther ye or no.
column8: But these dissemblers surely did not understand this answer, for they looked that he should have said either you or no.

column7: If he had sayd that they ought for to haue gyuen tribute vnto Cesar, they myghte haue accused hym as speakinge agaynst the lybertye gyuen vnto the children of Israell and also as a transgressour of the lawe, and if he had sayd that it had not bene lawful to gyue tribute vnto Cesar, the Herodians wolde haue accused hym forthwyth of treason and sedicion agaynst themperour P A G Eclxxx of Rome.
column8: If he had said that they ought for to have given tribute unto Cesar, they might have accused him as speaking against the liberty given unto the children of Israell and also as a transgressor of the law, and if he had said that it had not be lawful to gyve tribute unto Cesar, the Herodians would have accused him forthwith of treason and sedition against themperour PAGEclxxx PAGEclxxx PAGEclxxx PAGEclxxx of Rome.

column7: And so in all fashions they myght haue had open occasion to cause hym to be condemned to death, but by hys aunswere they had none occasion, but were all ashamed.
column8: And so in all fashions they might have had open occasion to cause him to be condemned to death, but by his answer they had none occasion, but were all ashamed.

column7: And he shewed them well, yt agaynst the Lorde God there is no counsell that can serue.
column8: And he showed them well, that against the Lord God there is no counsel that can serve.

column7: Wherefore thys Gospell doth teach vs that they that teach the doctrine of Iesu Christe, I meane, the true Gospell, shall haue other whyles the Pharisees and theyr discyples lyenge in wayte agaynste them (whych shall accompany themselues wyth infidels beleuynge nothyng of God, suche as were these Herodians) for to attrappe them subtylly in theyr interrogations, in any thyng that they saye whether it be so or not so, searchyng apparant occasions for to delyuer them vnto death.
column8: Wherefore this Gospel does teach us that they that teach the doctrine of Jesu Christe, I mean, the true Gospel, shall have other whiles the Pharisees and their disciples lying in wait against them (which shall accompany themselves with infidels believing nothing of God, such as were these Herodians) for to attrappe them subtly in their interrogations, in any thing that they say whither it be so or not so, searching apparent occasions for to deliver them unto death.

column7: And so they shall not be able to eschue it, yf the spirite of God do not delyuer them.
column8: And so they shall not be able to eschew it, if the spirit of God do not deliver them.

column7: Wherfore my brethren let vs all take good courage, for to announce and preache the word of Iesu Christ, the holy Gospell.
column8: Wherefore my brothers let us all take good courage, for to announce and preach the word of Jesu Christ, the holy Gospel.

column7: Let vs leaue vnto the men, that yt is of men.
column8: Let us leave unto the men, that that is of men.

column7: And let vs yeld vnto God that that is Gods, that is fayth, all hope and charytie, vnto hym dewe by hys holye worde.
column8: And let us yield unto God that that is Gods, that is faith, all hope and charity, unto him dew by his holy word.

column7: And our kynge whych is Iesu Christ shall reioyce in hys heauenly father, the whych wyth hym shall gyue vs hys graces, and our prayses shalbe of God, yt whych also shall shutte vppe the mouthe of ye sklaunderers and euyll speakers of hys holye worde, as it is also wrytten: But the kynge shall reioyce hym in God.
column8: And our king which is Jesu Christ shall rejoice in his heavenly father, the which with him shall gyve us his graces, and our praises shall of God, that which also shall shut up the mouth of the sklaunderers and evil speakers of his holy word, as it is also written: But the king shall rejoice him in God.

column7: All those wyth true hartes shalbe praysed, for the mouth of them whych speake iniquitie is close, vnto the glorye of oure Lorde Iesus Christe, Qui viuit et regnat in seculorum secula Amen.: homily The Epystle on the.xxiiij. sonday after Trinite sonday.
column8: All those with true hearts shall praised, for the mouth of them which speak iniquity is close, unto the glory of our Lord Jesus Christe, Qui viuit et regnat in seculorum secula Amen.: homily The Epistle on the xxiiij sonday after Trinite sonday.

column7: The. fyrst chapiter to the Colossians.
column8: The. fyrst chapter to the Colossians.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: Paule desiereth and praieth for the collossias that they myght be fruetfull in all good workes and increasing in the knowledge of god.
column8: Paule desireth and prayeth for the collossias that they might be fruetfull in all good works and increasing in the knowledge of god.

column7: B Rethren, we haue not ceased to praye for you and to desire that ye myght be fulfylled wyth the knowledge of hys wyll in al wysdome and spiritual vnderstanding, that ye myght walke worthy of the lorde that in al thinges ye maye please, being frutefull in all good workes, and encreasing in the knowledge of god, strengthed with al myght thoroughe hys glorious power, vnto all pacience and longe sufferinge wyth ioyfulnes.
column8: BRethren BRethren, we have not ceased to pray for you and to desire that you might be fulfilled with the knowledge of his will in all wisdom and spiritual understanding, that you might walk worthy of the lord that in all things you may please, being fruitful in all good works, and increasing in the knowledge of god, strengthened with all might thorough his glorious power, unto all patience and long suffering with ioyfulnes.

column7: T He epistle of thys daye, my welbeloued frnedes doth teache vs how all christen men ought continually to desire and syghe (whych is to pray and to demaunde) vnto god that all the contreyes and nacions maye be replenyshed wyth the holy ghoste, the whych folowe the fayth of the word of god, that they may be replenyshed wyth the knowledge of the wyll of god whyche is all wisdome from aboue, and vnderstanding from aboue of the holy ghoste.
column8: THe THe epistle of this day, my well-beloved frnedes does teach us how all christian men ought continually to desire and syghe (which is to pray and to demand) unto god that all the countries and nations may be replenished with the holy ghost, the which follow the faith of the word of god, that they may be replenished with the knowledge of the will of god which is all wisdom from above, and understanding from above of the holy ghost.

column7: Whiche thyng we ought to praye to thentent yt in all places we maye walke worthyly accordyng vnto God, and that in al good workes we maye please God, that al maye fructifye and take encrease in the knowlege of God, which is the vnderstadyng of hys worde.
column8: Which thing we ought to pray to thentent that in all places we may walk worthily according unto God, and that in all good works we may please God, that all may fructify and take increase in the knowledge of God, which is the vnderstadyng of his word.

column7: Furthermore we must praye that al may be comforted in P A G Eclxxxi all strength, vertue and might of god not according vnto our myght or the myght of men, but according vnto the puissauce and incomparable might of hys glory, in the whych all they that knowledge to haue it of hym, do prayse hym & gloryfie hym in al mekenesse and pacience of hys abydyng in spirituall ioye in our Lorde Iesu Christe. <NOTE> Truly my brethren these be the desyres, sighes prayers and peticyons of all christen men, the whych be vnderstaded by ye desyres prayers and peticios of.
column8: Furthermore we must pray that all may be comforted in PAGEclxxxi PAGEclxxxi PAGEclxxxi PAGEclxxxi all strength, virtue and might of god not according unto our might or the might of men, but according unto the puissance and incomparable might of his glory, in the which all they that knowledge to have it of him, do praise him & glorify him in all meekness and patience of his abiding in spiritual joy in our Lord Jesu Christe. Truly my brothers these be the desires, sighs prayers and petitions of all christian men, the which be vnderstaded by you desires prayers and peticios of.

column7: S. Paule for the Collosies for in ye scriptures the thynges spoken particularly, oughte to be taken vniuersally, that is, that they be sayed vnto all men, as oure Lorde doth wytnesse it spekyng vnto hys disciples, this yt I saye vnto you, I speake it vnto all.
column8: S. Paule for the Collosies for in you scriptures the things spoken particularly, ought to be taken universally, that is, that they be said unto all men, as our Lord does witness it speaking unto his disciples, this that I say unto you, I speak it unto all.

column7: Let vs then praye contynually by these noble desyres and sighes, whych the holye ghost maketh in vs, & we shalbe spiritual, we shalbe a temple of ye holye ghoste, and such as we desyre the other to be.
column8: Let us then pray continually by these noble desires and sighs, which the holy ghost makes in us, & we shall spiritual, we shall a temple of the holy ghost, and such as we desire the other to be.

column7: We shall haue knowledge of ye good wyll of God, whych is the saluation of euery body by the fayth in Iesus Christe and in hys worde.
column8: We shall have knowledge of the good will of God, which is the salvation of every body by the faith in Jesus Christe and in his word.

column7: These desyres and prayers be workes of charytye, workes of sapience, and such as teach the wysdom of God, and not of men, they be woorkes pleasaunte vnto God, frutefull and increasynge from daye to daye in the knowlege of god, they be the woorkes of pacience, abyding (in ioye of spirite) what soeuer thyng it shal please god for to sende, whether it be prosperytye or aduersytye, whether it be syckenes or health, for the strength from aboue gyuen by Iesu Christe and his spirite doth comforte & gyueth liefe to al. To whom be immortal glory and prayse wythout ende.
column8: These desires and prayers be works of charytye, works of sapience, and such as teach the wisdom of God, and not of men, they be works pleasant unto God, fruitful and increasing from day to day in the knowledge of god, they be the works of patience, abiding (in joy of spirit) what soever thing it shall please god for to send, whither it be prosperytye or aduersytye, whither it be sickness or health, for the strength from above given by Jesu Christe and his spirit does comfort & gyveth lief to all To whom be immortal glory and praise without end.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The Gospell on the.xxiiij. sondaye after Trinitie sondaye.
column8: : homily The Gospel on the xxiiij sondaye after Trinitie sondaye.

column7: The.ix. chapiter of Mathewe.
column8: The ix chapter of Mathewe.

column7: Thargument.
column8: Thargument.

column7: The woman whyche had the issue of bloude is healed.
column8: The woman which had the issue of blood is healed.

column7: W Hyle Iesus yet spake vnto the people, behold ther cam a certeyn ruler and worshipped him sayenge, my doughter is euen nowe disceased, but come and laie thy hand vpon her, and she shal lyue.
column8: While While Jesus yet spoke unto the people, behold there cam a certain ruler and worshipped him saying, my daughter is even now diseased, but come and lay thy hand upon her, and she shall live.

column7: And Iesus arose, and folowed hym and so dyd hys disciples.
column8: And Jesus arose, and followed him and so did his disciples.

column7: And beholde a woman whych was diseased wyth an issue of blod twelue yeres, cam behind him, and touched the hem of hys vesture.
column8: And behold a woman which was diseased with and issue of blood twelue years, cam behind him, and touched the hem of his vesture.

column7: For she sayd wythin her selfe, if I maye touche but euen his vesture only, I shalbe safe.
column8: For she said within her self, if I may touch but even his vesture only, I shall safe.

column7: But Iesus turned hym aboute and when he sawe her he sayde.
column8: But Jesus turned him about and when he saw her he said.

column7: Doughter be of good comforte, thy faythe hath made the safe.
column8: Daughter be of good comfort, thy faith hath made the safe.

column7: And the woman was made hole, euen that same tyme.
column8: And the woman was made hold, even that same time.

column7: T Hys Gospell (good christen audience) doth put before our eyes how moche that our fayth and hope in god our sauiour doth please hym, and is to hym gratefull and acceptable, and whych thing our lorde doth shewe vs here by the faythe of a prince of the Sinagoge which (as sayeth saynte Marke) was named Iayrus.
column8: This This Gospel (good christian audience) does put before our eyes how much that our faith and hope in god our saviour does please him, and is to him grateful and acceptable, and which thing our lord does show us here by the faith of a prince of the Synagogue which (as sayeth faint Mark) was nam Iayrus.

column7: And albeit that hys fayth and confidence in god was vnperfite, yet neuerthelesse oure lorde did applye and graunte to his prayer, yea and wente also with him for to rayse his doughter which P A G Eclxxxij was nere deade, and in dede she dyed.
column8: And albeit that his faith and confidence in god was unperfect, yet nevertheless our lord did apply and grant to his prayer, yea and went also with him for to raise his daughter which PAGEclxxxij PAGEclxxxij PAGEclxxxij PAGEclxxxij was never dead, and in deed she died.

column7: In whyche thing the holy doctour Remigius sayth that the humilite and mildnes of our lorde is moche to be wondered at, and also to be folowed of vs by exemple, <NOTE> For forthwith as sone as he was desired he beganne to folowe him that desired him.
column8: In which thing the holy doctor Remigius say that the humility and mildness of our lord is much to be wondered at, and also to be followed of us by exemple, For forthwith as soon as he was desired he began to follow him that desired him.

column7: Wherin he instructeth (sayth thys doctour) both subiectes and also prelates.
column8: Wherein he instructeth (say this doctor) both subjects and also prelates.

column7: To subiectes he hath left an exemple of obedience.
column8: To subjects he hath left and exemple of obedience.

column7: To prelates he did demostrate and shewe howe they ought to be instaunte and paynfull in the office of teachynge, that as often as they here tell of any parson to be deade in soule, they shulde study forthwyth to be at hand and presente with hym to reuiele and rayse him vp agayn, euen as our sauiour Christ of hys most tendre pitie and mercy was ready forthwith at the humble sute of this ruler to go with him to rayse vp his doughter.
column8: To prelates he did demonstrate and show how they ought to be instant and painful in the office of teaching, that as often as they here tell of any parson to be dead in soul, they should study forthwith to be at hand and present with him to reuiele and raise him up again, even as our saviour Christ of his most tendre pity and mercy was ready forthwith at the humble suit of this ruler to go with him to raise up his daughter.

column7: And if that he had had as perfecte fayth as he which saied, lord I am not worthy that thou shuldest entre in to my howse, but only saye the worde, and my chylde shalbe hole, he myght haue healed her wyth a worde and saye, be it done to the according vnto thy faith, and it shuld haue bene so, but he did to him accordinge vnto hys fayth, and so he doth to vs. He had thus moche fayth that if he touched her she shulde lyue, and so was it therfore done to hym according vnto his fayth.
column8: And if that he had had as perfect faith as he which said, lord I am not worthy that thou shouldst enter in to my house, but only say the word, and my child shall hold, he might have healed her with a word and say, be it done to the according unto thy faith, and it should have be so, but he did to him according unto his faith, and so he does to us He had thus much faith that if he touched her she should live, and so was it therefore done to him according unto his faith.

column7: He shewed it vs also by the woman whych had the blody flyxe by the space of.xij. yeres, the whyche had thys fayth in him, that if she touched alonly hys garmet she shuld be healed.
column8: He showed it us also by the woman which had the bloody flyxe by the space of xij years, the which had this faith in him, that if she touched alonely his garmet she should be healed.

column7: She did touche it, and she had accordinge vnto her fayth, not that she had her fayth in the garmente or that the garmente shulde heale her, but her fayth and her hope was in Iesu Christ.
column8: She did touch it, and she had according unto her faith, not that she had her faith in the garment or that the garment should heal her, but her faith and her hope was in Jesu Christ.

column7: For assuredly the vertue of her healinge did not come from the garment, but from our lord Iesu Christ as he saied, I haue knowne that power is issued oute from me.
column8: For assuredly the virtue of her healing did not come from the garment, but from our lord Jesu Christ as he said, I have known that power is issued out from me.

column7: For certes she touched oure lorde inuisibly by fayth, and the garment visibly by signe of fayth.
column8: For certes she touched our lord invisibly by faith, and the garment visibly by sign of faith.

column7: And therfore oure Lorde sayde vnto her.
column8: And therefore our Lord said unto her.

column7: Daughter haue full hope and be of good chere, thy fayth hath made yt to be saued, for he did vnto her accordig vnto her fayth Then the gospel dothe shew vs here, that if we haue right perfyte fayth, ther shalbe done vnto vs accordinge to our fayth. <NOTE> that mortall men and women wold haue this perfecte fayth working by charytie & confidece, and thys trust in our lorde Iesus Chryst?
column8: Daughter have full hope and be of good cheer, thy faith hath made that to be saved, for he did unto her according unto her faith Then the gospel doth show us here, that if we have right perfect faith, there shall done unto us according to our faith. that mortal men and women would have this perfect faith working by charity & confidence, and this trust in our lord Jesus Chryst?

column7: Our lord did neuer denye any whych hath had stedfast fayth & hope in hym.
column8: Our lord did never deny any which hath had steadfast faith & hope in him.

column7: If we be in neuer so great sickenes of synne, yea if we be deade by synne, yet yf we praye vnto hym, and desyre him of pardon hauig full hope and faythe in him, that in asking it of hym we shalbe healyd and iustified, that is for to saie that our sinnes shalbe pardomd, and that we shalbe reuiued fro ye death of synne, assuredlye it shalbe so done vnto vs, and we shal heare thys swete answere.
column8: If we be in never so great sickness of sin, yea if we be dead by sin, yet if we pray unto him, and desire him of pardon hauig full hope and faith in him, that in asking it of him we shall healed and justified, that is for to say that our sins shall pardomd, and that we shall revived from you death of sin, assuredly it shall so done unto us, and we shall hear this sweet answer.

column7: Thy fayth hath saued the.
column8: Thy faith hath saved thee.

column7: And ye gospel is ful of the same that he wyl do to vs according to oure fayth.
column8: And you gospel is full of the same that he will do to us according to our faith.

column7: Wherfore let vs haue stedfast fayth in all the promysses of the wordes of God: and then shalbe accomplished in all hys promysses. <NOTE> But thys fayth is a liuely fayth which worketh by charitie.
column8: Wherefore let us have steadfast faith in all the promises of the words of God: and then shall accomplished in all his promises. But this faith is a lively faith which works by charity.

column7: The sone which shyneth & gyueth no heate, dothe not gyue lyfe to any thyng, no more doth faiyh without charitie.
column8: The soon which shineth & gyveth no heat, doth not gyve life to any thing, no more does faiyh without charity.

column7: If yu haue thys fayth that Iesu Christ is dead for the, and for to put P A G Eclxxxiij awaye thy synnes, it is soo, and thy synnes be put awaye, and hys death is thine: and the merite of hys death thyne.
column8: If thou have this faith that Jesu Christ is dead for thee, and for to put PAGEclxxxiij PAGEclxxxiij PAGEclxxxiij PAGEclxxxiij away thy sins, it is so, and thy sins be put away, and his death is thine: and the merit of his death thine.

column7: If thou beleue also not faynedly but truly that he is risen agayne for thy iustificatio, it is soo, and his resurrection is thyne & thy iustification and thou art truly iustified if yu so perseuer & cotinue in godly lyuing as becommeth a christen man.
column8: If thou believe also not fainedly but truly that he is risen again for thy iustificatio, it is so, and his resurrection is thine & thy justification and thou art truly justified if thou so persever & cotinue in godly living as becomes a christian man.

column7: And thus of all the other wordes of God and of the holy scripture, the whych is clene hydde fro vs and made darke and vnprofitable without thys working faith and agayne all open and shyninge by thys fayth.
column8: And thus of all the other words of God and of the holy scripture, the which is clean hid from us and made dark and unprofitable without this working faith and again all open and shining by this faith.

column7: It is it that is alwayes sene of God, and is neuer denyed in all signes and meruels & in al holy reuiuinges of God.
column8: It is it that is always seen of God, and is never denied in all signs and meruels & in all holy reuiuinges of God.

column7: For to be healed of all syckenesses and death we nede principally thys lyuely and workyng fayth whych is the most beloued grace of God.
column8: For to be healed of all sicknesses and death we need principally this lively and working faith which is the most beloved grace of God.

column7: The woma hadde none other thynge to be healed of her bloudy flixe.
column8: The woma had none other thing to be healed of her bloody flix.

column7: The prince of the synagoge hadde none other thynge for to haue hys doughter reysed from death to lyffe.
column8: The prince of the synagogue had none other thing for to have his daughter raised from death to life.

column7: For to be inheritour vnto the kyngdome of heauen is required this fayth that I now speake of, as first & chife foudatio of all together.
column8: For to be inheritor unto the kingdom of heaven is required this faith that I now speak of, as first & chife foudatio of all together.

column7: What wolde you that I shulde saye vnto you?
column8: What would you that I should say unto you?

column7: There is nothyng impossible vnto fayth.
column8: There is nothing impossible unto faith.

column7: Wherfore then lette vs praye vnto oure Lorde Iesu Christe whyche is auctour of fayth that he maye giue vs this fayeth: to thintent yt we maye praye laude and glorifie him so as he wold be prayed, & that he wol not denye or hyde any thing vnto them whych so do praye hym in fayeth but that he woll enflambe them from daye to daye, for to luoe feare honoure and serue hym more and more, and to praye hym the more feruentlye vnto the glorie of the celestiall father whyche giueth vs all in hym and by hym in thys world and in the other by glorie eternally.
column8: Wherefore then let us pray unto our Lord Jesu Christe which is author of faith that he may give us this fayeth: to intent that we may pray laud and glorify him so as he would be prayed, & that he will not deny or hide any thing unto them which so do pray him in fayeth but that he will enflambe them from day to day, for to luoe fear honour and serve him more and more, and to pray him the more fervently unto the glory of the celestial father which gives us all in him and by him in this world and in the other by glory eternally.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: : homily The epistle on the.xxv. sonday after Trinitie sonday which is the nexte sondaie before Aduent sonday.
column8: : homily The epistle on the xxv sonday after Trinitie sonday which is the nexte sondaie before Advent sonday.

column7: Ieremias.xxxiij. Thargument.
column8: Ieremias xxxiij Thargument.

column7: The prophecye of Hieremye concerninge the raygne of Christe.
column8: The prophecy of Hieremye concerning the reign of Christe.

column7: B Retherne, beholde the tyme commeth sayeth the lorde, that I wyll rayse vp the ryghteous braunche of Dauid, whych shall beare rule, and discusse maters with wisdome, and shal set vp equitie and righteousnes agayne in the erthe.
column8: BRetherne BRetherne, behold the time comes sayeth the lord, that I will raise up the righteous branch of Dauid, which shall bear rule, and discuss maters with wisdom, and shall set up equity and righteousness again in the earth.

column7: In hys tyme shall Iuda be saued, and Israel shal dwell wythoute feare.
column8: In his time shall Juda be saved, and Israel shall dwell without fear.

column7: And thys is the name that they shall call hym, euen the lorde our rightousnesse.
column8: And this is the name that they shall call him, even the lord our rightousnesse.

column7: And therfore beholde, the tyme commeth sayeth the lorde, that it shall nomore be sayde, the Lorde lyuethe, whyche brought the chyldrene of Israell oute of the lande of Egypte.
column8: And therefore behold, the time comes sayeth the lord, that it shall nomore be said, the Lord lyuethe, which brought the chyldrene of Israell out of the land of Egypte.

column7: But the lorde lyueth, whyche broughte forth, and led the sede of the house of Israel, out of the northlande, and frome all countreyes where I had scatered them, and they shal dwel in theyr own lande agayne.
column8: But the lord liveth, which brought forth, and led the seed of the house of Israel, out of the northlande, and from all countries where I had scattered them, and they shall dwell in their own land again.

column7: T His prophecy of Hieremie (good people) which we rede for our epistle in the churche thys daye doth shew vs that the dayes of ye comming of messias our Sauiour Iesu Christ be at hande & accoplyshed.
column8: THis THis prophecy of Hieremie (good people) which we rede for our epistle in the church this day does show us that the days of the coming of messias our Saviour Jesu Christ be at hand & accoplyshed.

column7: This is ye trew braunche which God shal rcyse P A G Eclxxxiiij vp vnto Dauid.
column8: This is the true branch which God shall rcyse PAGEclxxxiiij PAGEclxxxiiij PAGEclxxxiiij PAGEclxxxiiij up unto Dauid.

column7: And when shal this braunche be take?
column8: And when shall this branch be take?

column7: Of a vyrgyn descendyd from Dauid, He shalbe trewly iust, for he shalbe the iustice of all iust: and he alonly ought of his owne purenes to be conceiued & borne among men without syn.
column8: Of a virgin descended from Dauid, He shall truly just, for he shall the justice of all just: and he alonely ought of his own pureness to be conceived & born among men without sin.

column7: But who shall reyse him vp vnto Dauid?
column8: But who shall raise him up unto Dauid?

column7: God alone, and no tany man.
column8: God alone, and no tany man.

column7: And therfore he shalbe God, and sonne of God.
column8: And therefore he shall God, and son of God.

column7: And wherfore vnto Dauid?
column8: And wherefore unto Dauid?

column7: Forbicause yt god shall reyse him vp and make him to be borne of a virgyn descedyd of Dauid.
column8: Forbicause that god shall raise him up and make him to be born of a virgin descedyd of Dauid.

column7: He shall reygne kynge.
column8: He shall reign king.

column7: For he shalbe kyng of kynges.
column8: For he shall king of kings.

column7: It is he which sayeth in ye person of kyng Dauid in the seconde psalme. <NOTE> But I am constituted kyng by him ouer Sion his holy moutayne preachyng his comaundement.
column8: It is he which sayeth in you person of king Dauid in the seconde psalm. But I am constituted king by him over Sion his holy moutayne preaching his commandment.

column7: And he shalbe wyse: not without cause, for he is the wysdome of god.
column8: And he shall wise: not without cause, for he is the wisdom of god.

column7: He shall do iustice and iudgement in earth, for he shall condemne synne and the prynce of synne, and shall iustifie by him selfe which is the sacrifice, the redepcion and iustice of pore synners.
column8: He shall do justice and judgement in earth, for he shall condemn sin and the prince of sin, and shall justify by him self which is the sacrifice, the redepcion and justice of poor sinners.

column7: And by this father: he shall iustifie the synners.
column8: And by this father: he shall justify the sinners.

column7: In those dayes, Iuda, yt is to saye, those that shall confesse in faith, shalbe saued: and Israell that is for to saye those that shall knowledge there strengthe to come from God, shall liue in greate suertie and trust.
column8: In those days, Juda, that is to say, those that shall confess in faith, shall saved: and Israell that is for to say those that shall knowledge there strength to come from God, shall live in great surety and trust.

column7: Iudas signifieth cofessyng, laudinge and thankyng, and Israel strong in God.
column8: Judas signifies cofessyng, lauding and thanking, and Israel strong in God.

column7: And the name of messias shall be thys, The Lorde God which is the greate name of God.
column8: And the name of messias shall be this, The Lord God which is the great name of God.

column7: Wherby Hieremie in spirite giueth to vnderstande that he shall be the greate God, hys name also shalbe oure iuste.
column8: Whereby Hieremie in spirit gives to understand that he shall be the great God, his name also shall our just.

column7: Oures: forbycause that he shall be made man for vs: and in such wyse iust, that he shall iustifie vs al that shal beleue in him, as in God and man & therfore he shalbe ours, and his iustice ours, and for this he shuld come.
column8: Ours: forbycause that he shall be made man for us: and in such wise just, that he shall justify us all that shall believe in him, as in God and man & therefore he shall ours, and his justice ours, and for this he should come.

column7: For (as Esaie sayeth) the lytle is borne vnto vs, and the sonne is gyue vnto vs, and for this cause in the tyme of Messias one shall not affyrme any more in saieng.
column8: For (as Esaie sayeth) the little is born unto us, and the son is gyve unto us, and for this cause in the time of Messias one shall not affirm any more in saying.

column7: The lord liueth which hath with drawen the chyldren of Israel out from the lande of Egypte.
column8: The lord lives which hath with drawn the children of Israel out from the land of Egypte.

column7: But it shalbe affyrmed in one hole witnes.
column8: But it shall affirmed in one hold witness.

column7: The lorde god lyueth that hath drawen out the sede of the chyldren of Israel from ye lande of the North, and from all other places where they were cast.
column8: The lord god liveth that hath drawn out the seed of the children of Israel from the land of the North, and from all other places where they were cast.

column7: The lorde god is the Messias: of whome Heremie sayde, the dayes of his comyng is at hade.
column8: The lord god is the Messias: of whom Heremie said, the days of his coming is at hade.

column7: The which whe he shulde be comen shulde renewe al thinges, al shadowes and all figures shulde cease, and then shulde truthe reygne, none shulde affyrme more accordyng to the olde lawe in fygure but according to the newe in truthe.
column8: The which when he should be come should renew all things, all shadows and all figures should cease, and then should truth reign, none should affirm more according to the old law in figure but according to the new in truth.

column7: The chyldre of Israel were deliuered from the lande of Egypte and Pharon in fygure: But in the tyme of Messias the sede and chyldre of true Israel which shalbe sede and chyldren of faythe, shalbe delyuered in all places where they were caste before by god as enemies of the lande, from the region and puissaunce of the greate Aquilon, from whence dependeth all euyll, which is the croked serpent the diuell of hell the prynce of darkenesse.
column8: The children of Israel were delivered from the land of Egypte and Pharon in figure: But in the time of Messias the seed and children of true Israel which shall seed and children of faith, shall delivered in all places where they were cast before by god as enemies of the land, from the region and puissance of the great Aquilon, from whence dependeth all evil, which is the crooked serpent the devil of hell the prince of darkness.

column7: And they that shal inhabite in their lande of lyuinge people by the Messias which is our lorde Iesu Christ.
column8: And they that shall inhabit in their land of living people by the Messias which is our lord Jesu Christ.

column7: Striue we then my brethren, with all our strength, to be of the sede of fayth of the trewe Israel whiche is the onely stronge, in our lorde Iesu Christ, that hath vainquished the greate Aquilon: which hath drawen vs out from the puissance and tyranye of the same, from all P A G Eclxxxv places, from all nations.
column8: Strive we then my brothers, with all our strength, to be of the seed of faith of the true Israel which is the only strong, in our lord Jesu Christ, that hath vanquished the great Aquilon: which hath drawn us out from the puissance and tyranny of the same, from all PAGEclxxxv PAGEclxxxv PAGEclxxxv PAGEclxxxv places, from all nations.

column7: And then he shall leade vs with hym into the lande of the lyuyng men eternally And we muste be all wel assured of this: for this sayeth the lorde god almyghty.
column8: And then he shall lead us with him into the land of the living men eternally And we must be all well assured of this: for this sayeth the lord god almighty.

column7: Vnto whom be glory honour and myght eternally.
column8: Unto whom be glory honour and might eternally.

column7: AMEN.: homily The Gospell on the.xxv. sondaye after Trinitie sondaye which is the nexte sonday before Aduent sonday. the.vi. cha. of Ihon. The argument.
column8: AMEN.: homily The Gospel on the xxv sondaye after Trinitie sondaye which is the nexte sonday before Advent sonday. the vi cham. of Jhon. The argument.

column7: Our lorde feadeth fyue thousande men with v. barley loues and two fyshes.
column8: Our lord feadeth fyue thousande men with v. barley loves and two fishes.

column7: W Hen Iesus then lyfte vp hys eyes, and sawe a great company come vnto him, he sayth vnto Philip: whence shal we bye bread, that these may eate?
column8: WHen WHen Jesus then lift up his eyes, and saw a great company come unto him, he say unto Philip: whence shall we buy bred, that these may eat?

column7: Thys he sayde to proue him: for he hym selfe knew what he wolde do.
column8: This he said to prove him: for he him self knew what he would do.

column7: Philip answered him, two hundred peny worth of bread are not sufficient for them, that euery man maye take a lytle.
column8: Philip answered him, two hundred penny worth of bred are not sufficient for them, that every man may take a little.

column7: One of hys disciples (Andrew, Symon Peters brother) saith vnto hym: There is a lad here whiche hath fyue barlye loues and two fyshes: but what are they among so many?
column8: One of his disciples (Andrew, Symon Peters brother) says unto him: There is a lad here which hath fyue barley loves and two fishes: but what are they among so many?

column7: And Iesus sayd.
column8: And Jesus said.

column7: Make the people syt downe There was moch grasse in the place.
column8: Make the people fit down There was much grass in the place.

column7: So the men sat downe in nombre, about fyue thousand. And Iesus toke the bread: And when he had geuen thankes, he gaue to the disciples, and the disciples to them that were set down: And likewyse of the fyshes as much as they wold.
column8: So the men sat down in number, about fyue thousand. And Jesus took the bred: And when he had given thanks, he gave to the disciples, and the disciples to them that were set down: And likewise of the fishes as much as they would.

column7: When they had eate ynough, he sayth vnto his disciples: gather vp the broke meate which remayneth: that nothynge be lost.
column8: When they had eat enough, he say unto his disciples: gather up the broke meat which remaineth: that nothing be lost.

column7: And they gathered it together, and fylled twelue baskettes wyth the broke meate of the fyue barly loues: which broken meate remayned to them that had eaten.
column8: And they gathered it together, and filled twelue baskets with the broke meat of the fyue barley loves: which broken meat remained to them that had eaten.

column7: Then those men (when they had sene the myracle that Iesus dyd) said, thys is of a trueth the same Prophete that shulde come into the worlde.
column8: Then those men (when they had seen the miracle that Jesus did) said, this is of a truth the same Prophet that should come into the world.

column7: T He royal prophete Dauid (welbeloued audiece) knowing that the fedyng and meate as well of the body as of the soule is gyuen and distributed vnto men by the only goodnesse and grace of god, howbeit more diligently neuerthelesse that of the soule, then that of the body: he maketh this request vnto god.
column8: THe THe royal prophet Dauid (well-beloved audience) knowing that the feeding and meat as well of the body as of the soul is given and distributed unto men by the only goodness and grace of god, howbeit more diligently nevertheless that of the soul, then that of the body: he makes this request unto god.

column7: Lorde I haue had my refuge to the, teach me to do thy wyll.
column8: Lord I have had my refuge to thee, teach me to do thy will.

column7: And in another place he fayth.
column8: And in another place he faith.

column7: The lord god doth noryshe me, and I shall lacke nothyng, he hath set me in the place of the fedyng, whiche is the place of the fedyng of god, my frendes?
column8: The lord god does nourish me, and I shall lack nothing, he hath set me in the place of the feeding, which is the place of the feeding of god, my friends?

column7: Trewly it is the holy scripture, in whiche is declared vnto ss the wyll of this greate lorde, and with the whiche euery christen soule is spiritually and ghostely fed reueled and nouryshed.
column8: Trewly it is the holy scripture, in which is declared unto ss the will of this great lord, and with the which every christian soul is spiritually and ghostly fed revealed and nourished.

column7: And this is it whiche at this daye is represented vnto vs, by saynt Iohn in his.vj. chap. where as he sayeth, that whe Iesus had lyfte vp his eyes, and sawe that so greate a multitude was come vnto him, he sayde vnto his disciple saynt Philippe, wherwith shall we bye breade, that these folkes here may eate?
column8: And this is it which at this day is represented unto us, by saint John in his vj chap. where as he sayeth, that when Jesus had lift up his eyes, and saw that so great a multitude was come unto him, he said unto his disciple saint Philippe, wherewith shall we buy bread, that these folks here may eat?

column7: He spake not this that he knewe not perfetly, what he wolde do: but he proued his fayth (for it is he as sayeth Dauid that gyueth meate to beastes, and vnto smale rauens that call to him) and for P A G Eclxxxvi to confyrme it, and to giue knowledge vnto him and vnto the other that he was god.
column8: He spoke not this that he knew not perfectly, what he would do: but he proved his faith (for it is he as sayeth Dauid that gyveth meat to beasts, and unto small ravens that call to him) and for PAGEclxxxvi PAGEclxxxvi PAGEclxxxvi PAGEclxxxvi to confirm it, and to give knowledge unto him and unto the other that he was god.

column7: Take we then doctryne of this place my frendys that our Lorde Iesu Christ is only gouernour of al thinges what so euer they be, not only as towchinge the bodye, but principally as towching ye sowl.
column8: Take we then doctrine of this place my friends that our Lord Jesu Christ is only governor of all things what so ever they be, not only as touching the body, but principally as touching the sowl.

column7: And let vs not be as Philip and Andrew, which not hauing yet stedfast fayth beleued not yt he which by his only worde had made and created all the worlde, myghte lykewyse by hys worde create and gyue noryshynge by fyue loues & two fyshes vnto so great a multitude.
column8: And let us not be as Philip and Andrew, which not having yet steadfast faith believed not that he which by his only word had made and created all the world, might likewise by his word create and gyve nourishing by fyue loves & two fishes unto so great a multitude.

column7: But what signifieth vnto vs the fyue loues and the two fyshes?
column8: But what signifies unto us the fyue loves and the two fishes?

column7: Suerly my frendes the fyue loues the whiche as S. Iohn sayeth were of barly, represent vnto vs (as S. Austine and other holy expositours thynke) the fyue bokes of Moyses. <NOTE> For as barley outwarde hathe a huske very prickyng: euen so haue ye bokes of Moyses, for as touchyng the lawe whiche they conteyne, they be merueilous rough and rygorous, but if they be spiritually vnderstandyd (which can not be without faythe) they gyue norishyng vnto the soule.
column8: Suerly my friends the fyue loves the which as S. John sayeth were of barley, represent unto us (as S. Austine and other holy expositors think) the fyue books of Moyses. For as barley outward hath a husk very pricking: even so have you books of Moyses, for as touching the law which they contain, they be marvelous rough and rigorous, but if they be spiritually understanded (which can not be without faith) they gyve nourishing unto the soul.

column7: For as sayeth the prophete Abacuc. <NOTE> The rightwyse man shall lyue by fayth.
column8: For as sayeth the prophet Abacuc. The rightwise man shall live by faith.

column7: And the two fyshes may sygnify the olde and newe testamet.
column8: And the two fishes may sygnify the old and new testamet.

column7: The newe testament as touchyng the euangelicall & apostolicall wrytinges wherin the christen mans faythe is lyuely described.
column8: The new testament as touching the evangelical & apostolical writings wherein the christian men faith is lively described.

column7: The olde as touchyng the other bokes and prophecies. <NOTE> eue as the fyshes can not lyue without water, so lykewyse without faythe, none hathe bene, is, nor shalbe saued.
column8: The old as touching the other books and prophecies. eve as the fishes can not live without water, so likewise without faith, none hath be, is, nor shall saved.

column7: These fyue loues therfore and two fyshes spiritually vnderstanded haue bene distributed vnto al christen people.
column8: These fyue loves therefore and two fishes spiritually understanded have be distributed unto all christian people.

column7: And if ye aske by whom?
column8: And if you ask by whom?

column7: Surely it is to be answered by the apostles & they which be sent from god.
column8: Surely it is to be answered by the apostles & they which be sent from god.

column7: For this cause (my frendes) take ye the refection and fode of the soule in the fyue loues, and two fyshes spiritually vnderstanded: that is to say in the holy scriptures, and in fayth.
column8: For this cause (my friends) take you the refection and food of the soul in the fyue loves, and two fishes spiritually understanded: that is to say in the holy scriptures, and in faith.

column7: And vnderstande that ye worldly doctrines can nat nourishe your soules, but rather slee the, for our lorde sayeth, that for nought we honour him in kepyng the doctrine of men namely if it be not grounded of gods worde but rather made to ouerwhelme subuerte and darken the same.
column8: And understand that you worldly doctrines can nat nourish your souls, but rather slee thee, for our lord sayeth, that for nought we honour him in keeping the doctrine of men namely if it be not grounded of gods word but rather made to overwhelm subvert and darken the same.

column7: Let vs then desyre with instant and feruent peticions this heauenly fode of almyghty God and he wyll without doute gyue it vs aboundantly.
column8: Let us then desire with instant and fervent petitions this heavenly food of almighty God and he will without doubt gyve it us abundantly.

column7: To whom be all honour glory prayse & thankes for euer and euer.
column8: To whom be all honour glory praise & thanks for ever and ever.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: Finis.
column8: Finis.
